div.head: The KINGS Maje≈øties Fir≈øt Speech in Parliament the third of November, 1640.
div.p:
THe knowledge I had of the de≈øires of my Scotti≈øh Subjects, was the cau≈øe of my calling the la≈øt A≈ø≈øembly of Parliament, wherein had I beene beleeved; I ≈øincerely thinke, that things had not fallen out as now we ≈øee: But it is no wonder that men are ≈øo ≈ølow to beleeve that ≈øo great a ≈øedition ≈øhould be rai≈øed on ≈øo little ground. But now my Lords, and Gentlemen, the honour and ≈øafety of this Kingdome lying ≈øo neerely at the ≈øtake; I am re≈øolved to put my ≈øelf freely and cleerly on the love and affections of my Engli≈øh Subjects, as the≈øe of my Lords that did wait on me at York, very well remember I there declared. Therefore my Lords, I ≈øhall not mention mine own intere≈øt, or that ≈øupport I might ju≈øtly expect from you, till the common ≈øafety be ≈øecured; though I mu≈øt tell you I am not a≈øhamed to ≈øay, tho≈øe charges I have been at, have been meerly for the ≈øecuring and good of this Kingdome, though the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe hath not been an≈øwerable to my de≈øires. Therefore I ≈øhall only de≈øire you to con≈øider the be≈øt way both for the ≈øafety and ≈øecurity of this Kingdome, wherein their are two parts chiefly con≈øiderable. Fir≈øt, the cha≈øtifing out of the Rebells. And ≈øecondly, that other, in ≈øatisfying your ju≈øt grievances, wherein I ≈øhall promi≈øe you to concurre ≈øo
heartily and cleerely with you, that all the World may ≈øee my int ‚Ä¢ ntions have ever beene and ≈øhall be, to make this a glorious and flouri≈øhing Kingdome. There are only two things that I ≈øhall mention to you; Fir≈øt, the one is to tell you that the Loane of money which I lately had from the City of London, wherein the Lords that waited on me at Yorke a≈ø≈øi≈øted me, will only maintain my Armie for two mone ‚Ä¢ hs from the beginning of that time it was granted. Now my Lords, and Gentlemen, I leave it to your con≈øiderations, what di≈øhonour and mi≈øchiefe it might be, in ca≈øe for want of money my Armie be disbanded, before the Rebells be put out of this Kingdome. Secondly, the ≈øecuring the calamities the Northern people endure at this time, and ≈øo long as the treaty is on foot. And in this I may ≈øay not only they, but all this Kingdome will ≈øuffer the harme; therefore I leave this al≈øo to your con≈øideration, for the ordering of the≈øe great affairs whereof you are to treat at this time. I am ≈øo confident of your love to me, and that your care is for the honour and ≈øafety of the Kingdome, that I ≈øh ‚Ä¢ ll freely and willingly leave to you where to begin: only this, that you may the better know the ≈øtate of all the Affairs. I have commanded my Lord Keeper to give you a ≈øhort and free accompt of the≈øe things that have happened in this interim, wi ‚Ä¢ h this Prote≈øtation, tha ‚Ä¢ if this accompt be not ≈øatisfactory as it ought to be. I ≈øhall when≈øoever you de≈øire, give you a full and perfect accompt of every particular. One thing more I de≈øire of you, as one of the greate≈øt means to make this a happy Parliament; That you on your parts, as I on Mine, lay a≈øide all ≈øu≈øpition one of another, as I promi≈øed my Lords at Yorke; It ≈øhall not be my fault if this be not a happie and good Parliament.

div.head: The Kings ≈øpeech in Parliament the fift of November, 1640.
div.p:
I do expect that you will ha≈øtily make relation to the Hou≈øe of Commons, of tho≈øe great affairs for which I have called you hither at this time, and for the tru≈øt I have repo≈øed in them, and how freely I put my ≈øelfe on their love and affections at that time; and that you may know the better how to do ≈øo, I ≈øhall explaine my ≈øelfe concerning one thing I ≈øpake the la≈øt day. I told you the Rebells mu≈øt be put out of this Kingdome; it's true, I mu≈øt needs call them ≈øo, ≈øo long as they have an Armie that do invade us; and although I am under treaty with them, and I under my great Seale do call them Subjects, and ≈øo they are too, but the ≈øtate of my Affairs in ≈øhort is this. It's true, I did expect when I did will my Lords and great ones at Yorke, to have given a gracious an≈øwer to all your grievances; for I was in good hope by their wi≈øedomes and a≈ø≈øi≈øtances to have made an end of that bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, but I mu≈øt tell you that my Subjects of Scotland did ≈øo delay them, that it was not po≈ø≈øible to end there: Therefore I can no wayes blame my Lords that were at Rippon, that the treaty was not ended, but mu≈øt thanke them for their pains and indu≈øtry, and certainly had they as much power as affections, I ≈øhould by that time have brought the≈øe di≈øtempers to a happy period; ≈øo that now the treaty is tran≈øported from Rippon to London, where I ≈øhall conclude nothing without your knowledge, and I doubt not but by your approbation; for I do not de≈øire to have this great work done in a corner, for I ≈øhall lay
open all the ≈øteps of this mi≈ø-under≈øtanding, and cau≈øes of the great differences between Me and my Subjects of Scotland. And I doubt not but by your a≈ø≈øi≈øtance to make them know their duty, and al≈øo by your a≈ø≈øi≈øtance to make them return whether they will or no.

div.head: The Kings Speech to both the Hou≈øes, Ianuary 25. 1640.
div.p: THe Knights, Citizens, Burge≈ø≈øes; The principall cau≈øe of my comming here at this time, is by rea≈øon of the ≈ølow proceedings in Parliament, touching which is a great deale of inconvenience.
Therefore I think it very nece≈ø≈øary to lay before you the ≈øtate of my affairs as now they ≈øtand, therby to ha≈øten (not interrupt) your proceedings.

Fir≈øt, I mu≈øt remember you that there are two Armies in the Kingdome, in a manner maintained by you, the very naming of which, doth more cleerly ≈øhew the inconvenience thereof, then a better tongue then mine can expre≈ø≈øe.
Therfore in the fir≈øt place, I ≈øhall recommend unto you the quick di≈øpatch of that bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, a≈ø≈øuring you that it cannot re≈øt upon me.

In the next place I mu≈øt recommend unto you the State of my Navie and Forts; the condition of both which is ≈øo well known unto you, that I need not tell you the particulars, only thus much; they are the Walls and defence of this Kingdome, which if out of order, all men may ea≈øily judge what incouragement it will be to
Our enemies, and what di≈øheartning to our friends.

La≈øt of all, (and not of the lea≈øt to be con≈øidered) I mu≈øt lay before you the di≈øtractions that are at this pre≈øent occa≈øioned through the cau≈øe of Parliament; for there are ≈øome men that more maliciou≈øly than ignorantly, will put no difference betweene Reformation, and alteration of government.

Hence it commech that divine Service is irreverently interrupted, and Petitions in an ill way given in, neither di≈øputed nor denied. But I will enter into no more particulars, but ≈øhew you a way of remedie, by ≈øhewing you my cleer intentions, and ≈øome marke that may hinder this good worke.

I ≈øhall willingly and cheerfully concur with you for the Reformation of all Innovations both in Church, and Common-wealth, and con≈øequently that all Courts of Ju≈øtice may be reformed according to Law. For my intentions is cleerly to reduce all things to the be≈øt and pure≈øt times as they were in the time of Queen Elizabeth.

Moreover, what≈øoever part of my Revenue ≈øhall be found illegall or heavy to my Subjects, I ≈øhall be willing to lay down, tru≈øting in their affections. Having thus cleerly and ≈øhortly ≈øet down my intentions, I will ≈øhew you ≈øome rubs, and mu≈øt needs take notice of ≈øome very ≈øtrange (I know not what terme to give them) Petitions given in the name of divers Counties, again≈øt the e≈øtabli≈øhed government of the Church, and of the great threatnings again≈øt the Bi≈øhops, that they will make them to be but a Cipher, or at lea≈øt taken away.

If ≈øome of them have incroached too much upon the Temporaltie (if it be ≈øo) I ≈øhall not be unwilling the≈øe things ≈øhould be redre≈ø≈øed and reformed, as all other abu≈øes according to the wi≈ødome of former times; ≈øo farre I ≈øhall go with you, no farther.

If upon ≈øerious debate you ≈øhall ≈øhew that Bi≈øhops have ≈øome Temporall Authority, not ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary for the government
of the Church, and upholding Epi≈øcopall Juri≈ødiction; I ≈øhall not be unwilling to de≈øire them to lay it down, but this mu≈øt not be under≈øtood, that I ≈øhall any way con≈øent that their voice in Parliament ≈øhould be taken away; for in all the times of my Predece≈ø≈øors ≈øince the Conque≈øt, and before, they have enjoyed it; I am bound to maintain them in i, as one of the fundamentall In≈øtitutions of this Kingdome.
There is one other Rock you are on, not in ≈øub≈øtance, but in ≈øervice; and the forme is ≈øo e≈ø≈øentiall, that unle≈ø≈øe it be reformed, will ≈øplit you on that Rock.
There is a Bill lately put in concerning Parliaments. The thing I like well to have frequent Parliaments, but for Sheriffes and Con≈øtables to u≈øe my Authoritie, I can no wayes con≈øent unto.

But to ≈øhew that I de≈øire to give you content in ≈øub≈øtance as well as in ≈øhew, that you ≈øhall have a Bill for doing thereof, ≈øo that it do not trench neither again≈øt my Honor, neither again≈øt the ancient Prerogatives of the Crowns concerning Parliaments, Ingeniou≈øly confe≈ø≈øe, often Parliaments is the fitte≈øt means to keep corre≈øpondencie betweene Me and my People, that I doe ≈øo much de≈øire.
To conclude, now all that I have ≈øhewen you, the ≈øtate of my Affairs, My own cleere intentions, and the Rocks I would have you ≈øhun.

To give you all contentment, you ≈øhall likewi≈øe finde by the≈øe Mini≈øters, I have, or ≈øhall have, about me for the effecting of the≈øe my good intentions, which ≈øhall redouble the peace of the Kingdome, and content you all. Concerning the conference, you ≈øhall have a direct an≈øwer on Monday, which ≈øhall give you ≈øatisfaction.

div.head: The Kings ≈øpeech to both Hou≈øes of Parliament in the Lords Hou≈øe, at the pa≈øsing of the Bill for a Trieniall Parliament, the 16th of November, 1640.
div.p: MY Lords, and you the Knights, Citizens, and Burge≈ø≈øes of the Hou≈øe of Commons; you may remember when both Hou≈øes were with Me at the Banquetting Hou≈øe at Whitehall, I did declare unto you two Rocks I wi≈øhed you to e≈øchew, this is the one of them, and of that con≈øequence, that I thinke never Bill pa≈ø≈øed here in this Hou≈øe of more favour to the Subjects then this is, and if the other Rocke be as happily pa≈ø≈øed over as this ≈øhall be at this time, I do not know what you can aske for ought I can ≈øee at this time, that I can make any que≈øtion to yeeld unto: Therefore I mention this to ≈øhew unto you the ≈øence that I have of this Bill, and obligation as I may ≈øay that you have to me for it, for hitherto, to ≈øpeake freely, I have had no great incouragement to doe it; if I ≈øhould looke to the outward face of your actions or proceedings, and not looke to the inward intentions of your hearts, I might make que≈øtion of doing it.
Hitherto you have gone on in that which concernes your ≈øelves to amend, and yet tho≈øe things that meerly concernes the ≈øtrength of this Kingdom, neither for the State, nor my own particular.
This I mention, not to reproach you, but to ≈øhew you the ≈øtate of things as they are, you have taken the Government almo≈øt in peeces, and I may ≈øay, it is almo≈øt off the hinges.
A skilfull Watchmaker to make cleane his Watch, he will take it a ≈øunder, and when it is put together, it will go the better, ≈øo that he leave not forth then one pin in it.

Now as I have done all this on my part, you know what to do on your parts, and I hope you ≈øhall ≈øee cleerly that I have performed really what I expre≈ø≈øed to you at the beginning of this Parliament, of the great tru≈øt I have of your affections to me, and this is the great expre≈ø≈øion of tru≈øt, that before you do any thing for me, that I do put ≈øuch a confidence in you.

div.head: HIS MAJESTIES Letter to the Lords on the behalf of the Earle of Strafford, ≈øent by the PRINCE.
div.p: I Did ye≈øterday ≈øatisfie the Ju≈øtice of the Kingdome by pa≈ø≈øing of the Bill of Attainder again≈øt the Earle of Strafford; but mercie being as inherent, and in≈øeparable to a King as Ju≈øtice. I de≈øire at this time in ≈øome mea≈øure to ≈øhew, that likewi≈øe by ≈øuffering that unfortunate man to fulfill the naturall cour≈øe of his life in a clo≈øe impri≈øonment; yet ≈øo, that if ever he make the lea≈øt offer to e≈øcape, or offer directly, or indirectly to meddle in any ≈øort of Publique bu≈øine≈ø≈øe; e≈øpecially with me, either by Me≈ø≈øage, or Letter, it ≈øhall co≈øt him his life without further Proce≈ø≈øe. This, if it may be done without the di≈øcontentment of my People, will be an un≈øpeakable contentment to me.

To which end, as in the fir≈øt place, I by this Letter do earne≈øtly de≈øire your approbation, and to endeare it the more, have cho≈øen him to carry it, that of all your Hou≈øe is mo≈øt dear to me. So I de≈øire that by a conference, you will endeavour to give the Hou≈øe of Commons contentment: Likewi≈øe a≈ø≈øuring you, that the excu≈øe of mercy is no more plea≈øing to me, then to ≈øee both Hou≈øes of Parliament con≈øent for my ≈øake, that I ≈øhould moderate the ≈øeverity of the Law, in ≈øo important a ca≈øe.

I will not ≈øay that your complying with me, in this my intended mercie, ≈øhall make me more willing, but certainly t'will make me more cheerfull in granting your ju≈øt grievances. But if no le≈ø≈øe than his life can ≈øatisfie my People, I mu≈øt ≈øay fiat ju≈øtitia. Thus again recommending the con≈øideration of my intentions to you, I re≈øt.

closer.signed: Your unalterable and affetionate Friend, CHARLES, R.

postscript.p: If he mu≈øt dye, it were charity to Reprieve him till Satterday.

div.head: May 11th 1641.
div.p:
THis Letter all written with the Kings own hand, the Peers this day received in Parliament, delivered by the hand of the Prince. It was twice read in the Hou≈øe, and after ≈øerious and ≈øad con≈øideration, the Hou≈øe re≈øolved pre≈øently to ≈øend 12. of the Peers Me≈ø≈øengers to the King; humbly to ≈øignifie, that neither of the two intentions expre≈ø≈øed in the Letter, could with duty in them, or without danger to him≈øelfe, his deare≈øt Con≈øort the Queene, and all the young Princes their Children, po≈ø≈øibly be advi≈øed: With all which being done accordingly, & the rea≈øons ≈øhewed to his Maie≈øty, He ≈øuffered no more words to come from them, but out of the fulne≈ø≈øe of his heart to the ob≈øervance of Ju≈øtice, and for the contentment of his people, told them, that what he intended by his Letter was with an (if) if it may be done without di≈øcontentment
of his People; if that cannot be, I ≈øay againe the ≈øame that I writ, fiat ju≈øtitia. My other intention proceeding out of charity for a few dayes re≈øpite, was upon certain information that his E≈øtate was ≈øo di≈øtracted, that it nece≈ø≈øarily required ≈øome few dayes for ≈øetlement thereof.

Whereunto the Lords an≈øwered, their purpo≈øe was to be Suitors to his Maie≈øty for favour to be ≈øhewed to his innocent Children; and if him≈øelfe had made any provi≈øion for them, that the ≈øame might hold.

This was well liking to his Maie≈øty, who thereupon departed from the Lords; at his Maie≈øties parting they offered up into his hands the Letter it ≈øelfe which he had ≈øent; but He was plea≈øed to ≈øay, my Lords, what I have written to you, I ≈øhall content it be Regi≈øtred by you in your Hou≈øe. In it you ≈øee my minde, I hope you will u≈øe it to my honor.

This, upon returne of the Lords from the King, was pre≈øently reported to the Hou≈øe by the Lord Privy Seal, and ordered, that the≈øe Lines ≈øhould go out with the Kings Letter, if any copy of the Letter were di≈øper≈øed.

div.head: THAT BISHOPS ought not to have Votes in PARLIAMENT.
div.p: 1 BEcau≈øe it is a very great hinderance to the exerci≈øe of their Mini≈øteriall Function.
2 Becau≈øe they doe vow and undertake at their Ordination when they enter into holy Orders, that they will give them≈øelves wholly to that Vocation.

3. 4 Becau≈øe Coun≈øells and Canons in ≈øeverall Ages, do forbid them to meddle with ≈øecular affairs, becau≈øe 24 Bi≈øhops have dependancie on the two Archbi≈øhops, and becau≈øe of their Canonicall obedience to them.
5 Becau≈øe they are but for their lives, and therefore are not fit to have legi≈ølative power over the honors, inheritance, per≈øons, and liberties of others.
6 Becau≈øe of Bi≈øhops dependancie, and expecting tran≈ølations to places of great profit.

7 That ≈øeverall Bi≈øhops have of late much incroached upon the con≈øcieÃÑnces and liberties of the Subjects; and they, and their Succe≈ø≈øors will be much incouraged ≈øtill to incroach, and the Subjects will be much di≈øcouraged from complaining again≈øt ≈øuch incouragements if 26 of that Order, be to be Judges of tho≈øe complaints, the ≈øame rea≈øon extends to their legi≈ølative power in any Bill to pa≈ø≈øe for the regulation of their power, upon any emergent inconveniencie by it.

8 Becau≈øe the whole number of them is intere≈ø≈øed to maintaine the juri≈ødiction of Bi≈øhops, which hath beene found ≈øo grievous to the three Kingdomes, that Scotland hath utterly aboli≈øhed it, and multitudes in England, and Ireland have petitioned again≈øt it.

9 Becau≈øe Bi≈øhops being Lords of Parliament, it ≈øetteth too great a di≈øtance betweene them, and the re≈øt of their Brethren in the Mini≈øtry, which occa≈øioneth pride in them, di≈øcontent in others, and di≈øquiet in the Church.

div.head: To their having Votes a long time.
div.p: An≈øw. If inconvenient Time and u≈øage are not to be con≈øidered with Law-makers; ≈øome Abbots voted as anciently in Parliament as Bi≈øhops, yet are taken away. Therefore the Bi≈øhops Certificate to plenary of Benefice and loyalty of Marriage, the Bill extends not to them.

For the ≈øecular Juri≈ødictions of the Deane of We≈øtmin≈øter, the Bi≈øhops of Durbam, and Ely, and the Archbi≈øhop of Yorke, which they are to execute in their owne per≈øons, the former rea≈øons ≈øhew the inconveniencies therein.
For their Temporall Courts and Juri≈ødictions which are executed by their Temporall Officers, the Bill doth not concerne them.

div.head: The Lord Keepers Speech in the Upper Hou≈øe of Parliament. Novemb. 3. 1640.
div.p: ANd you the Knights, Cittizens, and Burge≈ø≈øes of the Hou≈øe of Commons, you have been ≈øummoned by His Maje≈øties Gracious Writ, under the great Seal of England, and you are here this day a≈ø≈øembled for the holding of a Parliament. The Writ tels you tis to treat, and con≈øult of the High, Great, and weighty affairs, that concern the e≈øtate and ≈øafety of the Kingdom. It tels you true, that ≈øince the Conque≈øt, never was there a time that did more require, and pray for the be≈øt advice and affection of the Engli≈øh people. It is ill viewing of objects, by viewing them in multiplying Gla≈ø≈øe, and it is almo≈øt as mi≈øchievous in the ≈øpeech of ≈øuch a broken Gla≈ø≈øe, which repre≈øents but to the half. The onely and the perfect way is to look in a true Mirror. I will not take upon me to be a good looker in it, I will onely hold it to you to make u≈øe of it.

The Kingdom of England is this multiplying Gla≈ø≈øe, you may there ≈øee a State which hath flouri≈øhed for divers hundred yeers, famous for time of peace and warre, glorious at home, and ever con≈øiderable abroad. A Nation to whom never yet any Conqueror gave new Laws, nor aboli≈øhed the old, nor would this Nation ever ≈øuffer a Conqueror to meddle with their Laws, no not the Romanes, who yet when as they ≈øubdued all the people,
made it part of the Conque≈øt, to leave their Laws in triumph with them. For the Saxons, Danes, and the Normans, if this were a time to travell into ≈øuch particulars, it were an ea≈øie task to make it appear, that it never changed the old e≈øtabli≈øhed Lawes of England, nor ever brought in any new, ≈øo as you have the frame and con≈øtitution of a Common-wealth, made glorious by antiquity. And it is with States, as with per≈øons and families, certainly an interrupted pedigree doth give lu≈øtre. It is glorious in the whole frame, wortth your looking upon, long and your con≈øideration in every part.
The King is the head of the Common-wealth, the Fountain of Ju≈øtice, the life of the Law, He is anima & deliciae legis.
Behold Him in His glorious Ance≈øtors, that have ≈øo ≈øwayed the Scepter of the Kingdome.
Behold Him in the high attributes, and the great prerogatives, which ≈øo ancient and unalterable Laws have given, and inve≈øted him with.
Behold Him in the happy times, that we have ≈øo long lived, under His Monarchiall government.

For His excellent Maje≈øty, that now is our mo≈øt Gratious Soveraign; you had need wipe the Gla≈ø≈øe, and wipe your eyes, and then you ≈øhall truely behold him a King of exemplary Pietie, and Ju≈øtice, and a King of rare endowments, and abilities of nature, and what he hath got by acqui≈øition, depth of judgement, quickne≈ø≈øe of apprehen≈øion, unparaleld moderation in great Councels, and great affaires, ≈øuch as you my Lords that had the happine≈ø≈øe to attend Him at the Councell of the Peeres at York, to your great joy and comfort can witne≈ø≈øe, and after ages will remember, to His eternall honour and ≈øame.

For His ju≈øt and pious Government, I dare boldly ≈øay that if any under Him as our In≈øtrument, have had the di≈øtributing of ju≈øtice to His people, have not done as they ought, the fault is their own, and they have done
contrary to the Royall Nature, and expre≈ø≈øe Command of our Gratious Soveraign, from whom I have often learned this golden Rule, and Maxim, he ≈øerves me be≈øt, that ≈øerves me with hone≈øty and integrity.

Behold Him in another part of Him≈øelf, in His deare≈øt comfort, our Gracious Queen, the mirror of Vertue, from whom ≈øince Her happy arrivall here, now above three lu≈øtres of yeetes, never any Subject record other then gratious and benigne Influence; and I dare a vow as She is neere≈øt and deare≈øt to our Soveraign, ≈øo there is none who≈øe affections and endeavours (His Maje≈øty onely excepted) hath, or doth, or can cooperate more to the happy ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of this Parliament, and the never to be equalled joy, and comfort of a right under≈øtanding between the King, and His people.
Behold Him in His be≈øt image, our excellent young Prince, and the re≈øt of the Royall, and lively Progeny in whom we cannot but promi≈øe to our ≈øelves, to have our happine≈ø≈øe perpetuated.
From the Throne turn your eyes upon the two ≈øupporters of it, on the one ≈øide, the Stemne of honour, the Nobility, and Clergy, on the other ≈øide, the Gentry and Commons.

Where was there, or is there in any part of the world a nobility ≈øo numerous, ≈øo magnanimous, and yet with ≈øuch a temper, that they neither ecclip≈øe the throne, nor overtop the people, but keep in a di≈øtance fit for the greatne≈ø≈øe of the Throne.

Where was there a Common-wealth ≈øo free, and the ballance ≈øo equally held, as here? And certainly, ≈øo long as the beam is ≈øo held, it cannot be otherwi≈øe, in right Anglis, if you turn the line never ≈øo little, it groweth quickly accute, or obdure; and ≈øo in States, the lea≈øt deviation makes a great change. But His Maje≈øties great wi≈øedome and goodne≈ø≈øe, and the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Honourable A≈ø≈øembly, I do not doubt will be a means to
make us ≈øtear between the Teophick of moderation, that there be no declen≈øion from the poole of ≈øeverity.
I am by His Maie≈øties Command, to relate to you ≈øome proceedings ≈øince the la≈øt A≈ø≈øembly here.

You may remember the Summer preceding this la≈øt, His Maje≈øty went with an Army into the North, ingaged in honour ≈øo to do, by rea≈øon of the c ‚Ä¢ ur≈øes that were taken by divers of the Subjects in Scotland, in the prejudice of Monarchy, and rendring le≈ø≈øe glorious this Kingdom. I know not under what pretence, but all that time they came very neer England, with an Army ≈øo neer that it was believed, they would have then entred and invaded the Kingdome. They did profe≈ø≈øe the contrary, neither did they want remon≈øtrations, and declarations, to infu≈øe this opinion into the hearts of His Maje≈øties people, before it would by the effects. What their intentions from the beginning were, His Maie≈øtie by His goodne≈ø≈øe and wi≈øedome, ≈øettled a Peace, and made a pacification at Barwick, upon which both Armies were disbanded, which pacification, and every Article of it, His Maie≈øty for His part hath been ≈øo far from violating, that when≈øoever any que≈øtion ≈øhall be made of it, ≈øhall plainly and clearly appear, it was His care to ≈øee it in all things performed. On the contrary, tho≈øe Subiects of His not contented with that grace, which His Maie≈øty then gave them in tho≈øe Articles of pacification, they have ≈øtrained them beyond the bounds and limits of the intention, and meaning; but they over and above attempted, and acted divers things ≈øo prejudiciall to Monarchy, and contrary, and repugnant to the Law, and ≈øettled con≈øtitution, and u≈øage of that Kingdome, that His Maie≈øty could not in honour continue at it.

This being made known unto His Maie≈øty, and to His Privy Councell, by tho≈øe who be≈øt knew the State, and affairs of that Kingdom, and that were mo≈øt tru≈øted and imployed by His Maie≈øty. His Maie≈øty by the unaminous
con≈øent of His Privy Councell, re≈øolved to rai≈øe an army to reduce them, to their mode≈øt and iu≈øt condition of true obedience, and ≈øubiection, to defend this Kingdome from all damage and danger, that by their means (how ≈øpecious ≈øoever they ≈øhaddow their pretences) they might fall upon it.

His Maie≈øty then fore≈øaw and foretold, that the rai≈øing of an Army at this time, was but to ≈øtand upon their own defence, as they profe≈ø≈øed, and they had an intention to enter this Kingdome, and to ≈øeize upon ≈øome place of importance, and eminency, and His Maie≈øty in particular named Newca≈øtle.

Had His Maie≈øty then had means and money, a≈øwell as he had certain knowledge of their intentions, I do beleeve that the≈øe calamities, that have fallen upon that Town, and the Counties adioyning, had been prevented. Perhaps the mi≈øinterpretation of His Maie≈øties intentions, and the mi≈øunder≈øtanding of His actions, and I am a fraid, the two benigne interpretation of the attempts actions, and profe≈ø≈øions of the Subiects in Scotland, added ≈ø ‚Ä¢ me impediment to that which the mo≈øt of us, I hope have lived to repent of.

His Maie≈øty how≈øoever w ‚Ä¢ nt in Per≈øon to the North, to ≈øee His Army ordered, and to take care for the ≈øafety, and defence of this Kingdom, a≈ømuch as he po≈ø≈øible could, He had not long been there, but that which he fore≈øaw, and foretold, fell out; for the Scots pa≈ø≈øed with their Army, the Rivers, Tweed and Tine, and ≈øeized upon Newca≈øtle, (which) of what importance it is you all know: And that they force contribution of the Counties of No ‚Ä¢ thumberland, and the Bi≈øhoprick of Durb ‚Ä¢ m, be≈øides many other ≈øpoiles, and di≈øtructions, that were committed.

His Maie≈øty well con≈øidering of what weight, and importance this was, and then having neither time nor place to call this a≈ø≈øembly of Parliament. He did re≈øolve
as had been frequently u≈øed, to ≈øummon a great Councell of all the Peeres, that by their advice and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, there might be ≈øome interruption given to the calamity, that was likely to ≈øpread over the whole Kingdome, And commanded Writs to i≈ø≈øue accordingly.
That was not done to prevent, but to prepare for a Parliament.

It was not to cla≈øh, or entor fire with this a≈ø≈øembly, by acting or ordering any thing which belongeth to this high and ≈øupream juri≈ødiction, but onely to give their a≈ø≈øi≈øtance for the pre≈øent, to render things more fit for this great a≈ø≈øembly;
That His Maie≈øties intention was ≈øo, it is cleer, for before ever any petition was delivered, or ever any ≈øpeech of petition for a Parliament, His Maie≈øty had re≈øolved to call one.

The Lords under≈øtood, It ≈øo will plainly appear by the proceedings of the A≈ø≈øembly, of which, if tho≈øe that were Officers, and Mini≈øters there had been come to Town, upon who≈øe help I re≈øted, for my particular in≈øtruction, I ≈øhould have been better able to have given you an accompt, And His Maie≈øty was plea≈øed to let you know, that when there was an occa≈øion of any particular, you may be ≈øatisfied in it. According to His Maie≈øties command 24. of September, all the Peeres were ≈øummoned, all except ≈øome few did meet where His Maie≈øty was. In the fir≈øt place, plea≈øed to declare unto us His re≈øolution to call a Parliament, and to all our ioyes and contents, as he hath now done it to yours and ours, declared that there was nothing he did more de≈øire then to be rightly under≈øtood of His people; And who≈øoever he be that ≈øhall go about (effect it, I am ≈øure he cannot) to attempt or indeavour to alter this gracious declaration, and re≈øolution of His Maie≈øty, or who≈øoever ≈øhall go about to poy≈øon the hearts of His good Subiects, with an opinion that it can be ≈øo, or le≈ø≈øon the affection of His
loving Subiects, for certainly never Subiects of the world better loved their King then the Engli≈øh, nor ever did ever Engli≈øh-men better love a King then now, if (I ≈øay) there be any ≈øuc ‚Ä¢ , may acur≈øe and puni≈øhment fall up „Äà‚óä„Äâ , But ‚Ä¢ et the Royall Throne be for ever.
H ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Maje≈øty was then plea≈øed to tell us the cau≈øe, for which „Äà‚óä„Äâ had called us together.

In the fir≈øt place, it was touching an an≈øwer to a petition that had b ‚Ä¢ en ≈øince his coming to York. And before His a≈ø≈øembly ≈øent unto him from tho≈øe His Subiects of Scotland, that were at Newca≈øtle.
The fir≈øt thing that His Maie≈øty de≈øired their advice in, was ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e an≈øwer to that petition.

The next thing His Maie≈øty conceived, And all that were there, were of one opinion, with one voyce, and con≈øent, that it was not fit His Maie≈øty ≈øhould disband His Army, ≈øo long as the Scotch Army was on foot; And His Maie≈øty wi≈øhed them to take into their con≈øideration what way to have maintenance, for His Army in the mean time.

His Maie≈øty having opened the cau≈øe of calling them together, was plea≈øed to expre≈ø≈øe him≈øelf that He would leave to the Lords, their freedom of Debate, and him≈øelf was ready to have been gone from the Councell, but at the humble ≈øuite of the Lords he ≈øtayed, And I am per≈øwaded that nothing was of that ioy to them, as His Maie≈øties pre≈øence, with ≈øuch freedome of di≈øcour≈øe did every man deliver him≈øelf, with ≈øuch grace and ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe did his Maie≈øty hear them, and ≈øuch content did they take in His moderating, guiding and directing tho≈øe Councells: My Lords as holding it mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary, took the latter of tho≈øe two con≈øiderations propounded by His Maie≈øty, to their thoughts, and that was the ≈øupplying and ≈øupporting His Maie≈øties Army, till this Parliament might take ≈øome cour≈øe in it: His Maie≈øty, and my Lords, did declare them≈øelves, as before I have opened unto you,
that they could never attempt, nor have the lea≈øt thought to make, by any Act or Order, any thing tending to the Subiect, but that it might be left wholly to the ≈øupream Juri≈ødiction. And therefore not ≈øeeing any other way, they re≈øolved by letter to addre≈ø≈øe them≈øelves to the City of London, And with their letters they ≈øent half a dozen of my Lords.

My Lord Privy Seal, my Lord of Clare, who was appointed to go, but his urgent occa≈øions preven ‚Ä¢ ed him, Vi≈øcount Cambden, Lord Coventry, Lord Goring and _____ And the≈øe Lords they did expre≈ø≈øe the joy and content they took in the Kings grace and confidence they had of His gracious a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, was ≈øuch, that they did freely offer them≈øelves, and as I dare ≈øay there is none but is yet ready to enter into ≈øecurity with His Maie ‚Ä¢ ty. And the City gave an an≈øwer fit for the Chamber of the King, and part of the money is already lent, and will be ready, I a≈ø≈øure my ≈øelf to ≈øupply the re≈øt.

For the other part, the fir≈øt thing propounded by His Maje≈øty, was touching the an≈øwer that was to be given to that petition, and to the demands of the Subjects in Scotland, upon which occa≈øion His Maje≈øty was plea≈øed, by tho≈øe great Officers and Mini≈øters of His, that knew be≈øt and under≈øtood the laws, and u≈øages of that Kingdome to expound their demands particularly, and to make appear unto their Lord≈øhips upon every one, wherein they had expounded the Articles of pacification, which His Maje≈øty ever de≈øired might be the Square, and Rule of the treaty with them.

My Lords tooke into con≈øideration what was fit to be done, for his Maje≈øty then profe≈ø≈øed as he did oft, and as he hath done it during the time of that Councell; to be wholy ruled, guided, and directed by their advice, f r the honor of this Nation, and ≈øaf ‚Ä¢ ty of it, he did leave it to their wi≈øedomes and con≈øiderations; again≈øt who≈øe advice, and without who≈øe judgements and advice, he would do nothing.

My Lords, how≈øoever they had received this information, and explanation upon every particular of their demands, yet in ju≈øtice they thought it was fit to hear what could be ≈øaid, on the other ≈øide, how the objection might be an≈øwered, and what objection might be made by them again≈øt that which ≈øeemed to be plain enough.

For this purpo≈øe they were all of opinion, and his Maje≈øty was plea≈øed to be of the ≈øame opinion, that ≈øome Lords ≈øelected and tru≈øted by that great Councell, ≈øhould Treate with tho≈øe Subjects of Scotland upon all tho≈øe particulars, to the end that they might ≈øee what they did cleerly intend; to the end that if a firm peace which was mo≈øt de≈øired from us might be had, or a ju≈øt Warre to be begun.

My Lords of the great Councell that were appointed for that purpo≈øe, were the Earles of Bedford, Hertford, E≈ø≈øex, Salisbury, Warwick, Bri≈øtow, Holland, and Barke≈øhire, The Barons were the Lords, Wharton, Paget, Rimbolton, Brooke, Pawlet, Howard of E≈øaich, Savile, and Dun≈ømore.

After which choice, ≈øome generall in≈øurrections proceeding from the debate and di≈øcour≈øes in that great Councell, a Commi≈ø≈øion under the great Seale was given unto them, to enable them to treate and conclude as they in their wi≈øedomes and Judgements ≈øhould thinke fit. The place appointed for this treaty was at Rippon, where the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners wanted the happine≈ø≈øe of that, that they, and we had at Yorke, of his Maie≈øties pre≈øence. And that might be the occa≈øion that more time was ≈øpent in it, then otherwi≈øe would have been; yet my Lords omitted not their parts, but were de≈øirous to look into the depth, to ≈øee the utmo≈øt extent of their demands.

But before tho≈øe of Scotland could come to the maine treaty, to explaine them≈øelves touching their demands, they made a preparatory demand of maintenance for their Armie, and did go ≈øo high, as to demand Forty thou≈øand Pounds a moneth. My Lords (that were very unwilling
to do any Act, or make any order what≈øoever, as I have opened unto you, for the ≈øu≈øtenance, maintenance, and keeping a foot his Maie≈øties Armie without this great A≈ø≈øembly, which yet they all held fit ≈øhould not be di≈øbanded) were much ≈øtartled at the demand of maintenance for an Armie that was not the Kings, and which they did wi≈øh could not continue.

But my Lords, as under that name they could not hear it, yet they tooke into con≈øideration the mi≈øerable condition of Northumberland, the Bi≈øhopricke of Durbam, and Newca≈øtle; They tooke into con≈øideration too, the Counties of Cumberland, and We≈øtmerland, which if the Scotti≈øh Armie ≈øhould enter, were ≈øcarce able at this time to defend it ≈øelfe, and it were inconvenient to bring the Kings Armie thither.

Nay, their Lords were ≈øatisfied that the County of Yorke was in danger, and that not to be prevented but by a battell, if the Scots came on with an Armie, and my Lords were loath, where there were ≈øuch ods, ≈øo many twenties to one, that a battell ≈øhould be adventured And if the County of Yorke ≈øhould be in danger, we might quickly fore≈øee how the danger might run over the whole Kingdome.

And my Lords, as well as tho≈øe that remained at Yorke, as tho≈øe at Rippon, having received complaints from the Bi≈øhop of Durbam (Northumberland, and Newca≈øtle) and the Maior of Newca≈øtle being impri≈øoned, and ≈øome of his Brethren, as was repre≈øented unto them, kept without fire or candle, and of divers wa≈øtes and ≈øpoyles done in the Countrey. My Lords did thinke fit, that ≈øince the Counties of Northumberland, the Bi≈øhoprick of Durbam, and Newca≈øtle had already made a compo≈øition and agreement, that they would at la≈øt ratifie and confirm the compo≈øition and agreement, ≈øo as there might be a ce≈ø≈øation of Arms, and acts of ho≈øtility; and that they which had fled from their dwellings in tho≈øe Counties might returne in
≈øafety. My Lords for the≈øe rea≈øons thought it fit for the pre≈øent to give way unto them, rather than to bazard ≈øo great calamitie and affliction that would have fallen on tho≈øe Counties; hereupon they did conclude for 850. pound by day, and this to continue for two moneths, if the treaty before tooke not effect, the two Moneths to begin from the 16th of October; then they took Articles for ce≈ø≈øation of Arms. So as now the ≈øtate and condition of things as they were acted, I have ≈øhortly and ≈øummarily delivered to you. I dare not adventure upon too many particulars, lea≈øt my memory ≈øhould faile; and if I have not done his Maie≈øties command, I beg his Maie≈øties pardon.

And my Lords, of what weight and importance this is to the whole Kingdome, what deepe con≈øideration it requires in our affections; what un≈øu≈øpected, and in≈øu≈øpected affections had we need bring with us, is ea≈øie to judge.

It is his Maie≈øties plea≈øure that you of the Hou≈øe of Commons, repaire to your owne Hou≈øe to chu≈øe your Speaker, whom his Maie≈øty expects you will pre≈øent to him on Thur≈øday next, at two of the clock in the afternoone.

div.head: Mr. SPEAKER his Speech to his Maie≈øty, in the High Court of Parliament, the fifth of November, 1640.
div.p: IN all ≈øubmi≈ø≈øive humblene≈ø≈øe, the Knights, Citizens, and Burge≈ø≈øes of the hou≈øe of Commons are here a≈ø≈øembled, who taking along with them your gracious inclination, have according to their ancient liberties de≈øigned me their Speaker. Whereas I cannot but lament to thinke how great a mi≈øt may overca≈øt the hopes of this ≈øe≈ø≈øions, yet a note of favour to mee, who cannot but judge my ≈øelfe unfit for ≈øo great imployment, which ≈øo appeares to the whole World.

Many there bee of deepe judgement, and ≈øad experience, that might have added lu≈øtre to this action an expedition to the worke, if they had plea≈øed to have left me in that meane condition they found me.

p.hi: Non mihitacui≈ø≈øe nocet, Nocet e≈ø≈øe locutum.

div.p: And then might your Sacred and pious intentions have had their full advancement.
But is it yet too late? may I not appeale to Ce≈øar?

Yes, I may, and in the lowe≈øt po≈øture of humilitie I humbly be≈øeech your ≈øacred Maje≈øty to interpo≈øe your royall authority to command a review of the hou≈øe, for there were never more then now fitted for ≈øuch imployments.

p.hi: My Lord Keeper approves of him by his Maje≈øties direction.
Then he goes on,

div.p: It plea≈øeth not your Sacred Maje≈øtie to vouch≈øafe a change.
Actions of Kings are not to bee by mee rea≈øoned.
Therefore beeing imboldened by this gracious approbation, give me leave a little, Dread Soveraigne, to expre≈ø≈øe my owne thoughts unto our gracious Lord the King.

I ≈øee before my eyes with admiration the Maje≈øtie of great Brittaine, the Glory of times, The Hi≈øtory of honour, CHARLES the fir≈øt, in his forefront placed by d ‚Ä¢ ≈øcent of antiquitie (Kings) ≈øetled by a long ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, and continued to us by a pious and peacefull government.
On the one ≈øide the Monument of Glory, the Progenie of valiant and pui≈ø≈øant Princes, the Queenes mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øtie.
On the other ≈øide, the hopes of po≈øterity, and joy of this Nation, tho≈øe Oliva branches ≈øet round your tables, Emblems of peace to po≈øterity.

Here ≈øhine tho≈øe Lights and Lamps placed in a
Mount, which attend your ≈øacred Maje≈øty as ≈øupreame head, and borrow from you the Splendor of their government.
There the true ≈øtate of Nobility, figures of prowe≈ø≈øe and Magnanimity, fitted by their long contracted honour in their blood, for the Coun≈øell of Princes.

In the mid≈øt of tho≈øe the Reverend Iudges, whither both parties (as to the Oracles of Iudgment and Iu≈øtice) may re≈øort. Ci≈øternes that hold faire waters, wherein each deviation, each wrinkle is di≈øcernable, and from thence (as from the Center) each crooked line ought to be levelled; The foot≈øtoole of your Throne is fixed there, which renders you glorious to all po≈øteritie.

Here wee the Knights, Citizens and Burge≈ø≈øes of the Commons hou≈øe, at your royall feete, contracted from all parts of your Kingdome, En≈øignes of obedience and humility, all the≈øe united by the law equally di≈øtributed, which cements this great body to the obedience of your ≈øacred Maje≈øty;
And compells a≈øwell the hearts as the hands to contribute for the pre≈øervation of your Maje≈øtie, and the Common intere≈øt.

Di≈ø≈øipates the Invaders of the Church and common wealth, and di≈øcovers the Impo≈øtures, but (give me leave dread Soveraigne) knits the Crowne to the Sacred Temples, and frees Maje≈øty from the Interpretation of mi≈ødoing.
Among≈øt the≈øe this great Coun≈øell is mo≈øt ≈øoveraigne again≈øt the di≈øtempers of this Nation.
Were they infe≈øted at Sea, troubled at home, or invaded from abroad, here was the Sanctuary of refuge, hither was the re≈øort, and no other way found for a foundation of peace.
It is reported of Constantine the great, that he accompted his Subjects pur≈øe his Exchequer, and ≈øo it is.

Subtile inventions may pick the pur≈øe, but nothing can open it but a Parliament; which lets in the eye of Soveraignty upon the publicke maladies of the State, and vigilancy for the pre≈øervation of our ancient Liberties; for this wee neede not ≈øearch into Antiquity; looke but a little backe, there wee ≈øhall ≈øee our ju≈øt liberties graciou≈øly confirmed by your mo≈øt ≈øacred Maje≈øty.
And is our happine≈ø≈øe ≈øhut up in the remembrance of times pa≈øt onely? No.
Tho≈øe gracious expre≈ø≈øions lately falne from your ≈øacred lips, as hony from the combe, make glad the hearts of your people.

So that now we doe more than promi≈øe to our ≈øelves a large and free con≈øideration of the wayes to compo≈øe the di≈øtempers of the≈øe Kingdomes, and then pre≈øent them to your royall hand for perfection.

And ≈øuch ≈øhall be our deportment, that as we ≈øhall labour the continuance of our Liberties, ≈øo ≈øhall wee carry a high regard to pre≈øerve that Soveraigne power wherewith your Maje≈øty is inve≈øted for the pre≈øervation of your Kingdome, and to render your ≈øacred Maje≈øty terrible to the Nations, and glorious at home.

Are the≈øe the fruits we have enjoyed by Parliaments? wee cannot then but wonder at that horrid invention in this place projected, Mon≈øtrum horrendum, informe ing ‚Ä¢ ns, but, the Lord bee thanked, Cui lumen ademptum e≈øt. Can this receive a Palliation? Men, Fathers, and Brethren, and all at one bla≈øt; no reverence to ≈øacred bones of Princes? were wee not all in a lumpe by them intended to bee offered up to Moloch?

Let us never forget this dayes ≈øolemnization (But whither?) It is too much boldne≈ø≈øe to pre≈øume longer on your Maje≈øties grace and goodne≈ø≈øe; and therefore
for the better expedition of this ≈øervice; Wee humbly de≈øire;

list.item: 1. That our ≈øelves and ≈øervants may obtaine freedome from arre≈øts of their per≈øons and goods.
2. That we may have free liberty of ≈øpeech without confinement, with a full and free debate.
3. That your Maje≈øty will vouch≈øafe our repaire to your ≈øacred per≈øon upon matters of importance, according to the ancient priviledges of the hou≈øe.

div.p: That with ≈øuch alacrity wee may now proceed to manife≈øt to the world, that our retirements were to reinforce a greater unity and duty, and to endeavour a ≈øweet violence which may compell (pardon dread Soveraigne the word Compell) your Maje≈øty to the love of Parliaments.

And thus God will have the honour, your ≈øacred Maje≈øty ≈øplendor, the Kingdome ≈øafety, and all our votes ≈øhall pa≈ø≈øe, that your ≈øacred Maje≈øty may long, long, long reigne over us; And let all the people ≈øay, Amen,

div.head: The Lord DIGBIES Speech the 9. of Novemb. 1640. Concerning Grievances, and the Trienniall Parliament.
div.p: YOu have received now a ≈øolemne accompt from mo≈øt of the Shires of England, of the ≈øeverall grievances and oppre≈ø≈øions they ≈øu≈øtaine, and nothing as yet from Dor≈øet ≈øhire; Sir, I would not have you thinke that I ≈øerve for a Land of Go≈øhen, that we live there in Sun-≈øhine, whil≈øt darkne≈ø≈øe and plagues over-≈øpread the re≈øt of the Land: As little would I have you thinke, that being under the ≈øame ≈øharp mea≈øure that the re≈øt, we are either in≈øen≈øible and benummed, or that, that Shire wanteth a ≈øervant to repre≈øent its ≈øufferings boldly.

It is true Mr. Speaker, the County of Dor≈øet hath not dige≈øted its complaints into that formall way of Petition, which others (I ≈øee) have done; but have intru≈øted them to my Partners and my delivery of them by word of mouth unto this Honourable Hou≈øe. And there was given unto us in the County Court, the day of our Election, a ≈øhort memoriall of the heads of them, which was read in the hearing of the Free-holders there pre≈øent, who all unanimou≈øly with one voyce ≈øignified upon each particular, that it was their de≈øire, that we ≈øhould repre≈øent them to the Parliament, which with your leave I ≈øhall doe, and the≈øe they are.

list.item:
1. The great and intollerable burthen of Ship-money,
touching the legality whereof they are un≈øatisfied.
2. The many great abu≈øes in pre≈ø≈øing of Souldiers, and rai≈øing moneys concerning the ≈øame.
3. The multitude of Monopolies.
4. The new Canon, and the Oath to be taken by Lawyers, Divines &c.
5. The Oath required to bee taken by Church-Officers to pre≈øent according to Articles new and unu≈øuall.

div.p: Be≈øides this, there was likewi≈øe pre≈øented to us by a very con≈øiderable part of the Clergy of that County, a note of remembrance containing the≈øe two particulars.
Fir≈øt, the impo≈øition of a new Oath required to bee taken by all Mini≈øters and others: which they conceive to be illegall, and ≈øuch as they cannot take with a good Con≈øcience.
Secondly, the requiring of a pretended Benevolence, but in effect a Sub≈øidie, under the penalty of ≈øu≈øpen≈øion, excommunication, and deprivation, all benefit of appeale excluded.
This is all wee had particularly in Charge: But that I may not appeare a remi≈ø≈øe ≈øervant of my Countrey, and and of this Hou≈øe; give me leave to adde ≈øomewhat of my owne ≈øence.

Truly Mr. Speaker, the injurious ≈øufferings of ≈øome worthy members of this Hou≈øe, ≈øince the di≈ø≈øolution of the two la≈øt Parliaments, are ≈øo fre≈øh in my memory, that I was re≈øolved not to open my mouth in any bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, wherein freedome and plaine dealing were requi≈øite, untill ≈øuch time, as the breach of our priviledges
were vindicated, and the ≈øafety of ≈øpeech ≈øetled.

But ≈øince ≈øuch excellent Members of our Hou≈øe, thought fit the other day to lay a≈øide that Caution, and to di≈øcharge their ≈øoules ≈øo freely in the way of zeale to his Maje≈øties ≈øervice, and their Countries good: I ≈øhall interpret that confidence of theirs for a lucky Omen to this Parliament, and with your permi≈ø≈øion licence my thoughts too, a little.

Mr. Speak r, under tho≈øe heads which I propo≈øed to you, as the grievances of Dor≈øet≈øhire, I ≈øuppo≈øe are compri≈øed the greate≈øt part of the mi≈øchiefs which have of late years layed battery either to our E≈øtates or Con≈øciences.

Sir, I doe not conceive this the fit ≈øea≈øon to ≈øearch and ventilate particulars, yet I profe≈ø≈øe I cannot forbear to adde ≈øomewhat, to what was ≈øaid the la≈øt day by a learned Gentleman of the long Robe, concerning the acts of that reverend new Synod, made of an old convocation. Doth not every Parliament mans heart ri≈øe to ≈øee the Prelats thus u≈øurpe to them≈øelves the Grand Preeminence of Parliament? The granting of Sub≈øidies, & that under ≈øo prepo≈øterous a name as of a Benevolence, for that which is a Malevolence indeed; A Malevolence I am confident in tho≈øe that granted it, again≈øt Parliaments: and a Malevolence ≈øurely in tho≈øe that refu≈øe it, again≈øt tho≈øe that granted it, for how can it incite le≈ø≈øe? when they ≈øee wre≈øted from them what they are not willing to part with, under no le≈ø≈øe a penalty then the lo≈ø≈øe both of Heaven and Earth: of Heaven, by excommunication; and of the Earth By Deprivation; & this without Redemption by appeal. What good Chri≈øtian can think with patience on ≈øuch an in≈ønaring Oath, as that which is by the new Canons enjoyned to be taken by all Mini≈øters, Lawyers, Phy≈øitians, and Graduates in the Vniver≈øities? where, be≈øides the ≈øwearing
≈øuch an impertinence, as that things nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øalvation are contained in Di≈øcipline; be≈øides the ≈øwearing tho≈øe to be of Divine right, which among≈øt the learned, never pretended to it, as the Arch things in our Hierarchy. Be≈øides, the ≈øwearing not to con≈øent to the change of that, which the State may upon great rea≈øon thinke fit to alter: Be≈øides the bottomele≈ø≈øe perjury of an &c. Be≈øides all this, Mr. Speaker, men mu≈øt ≈øweare that they ≈øweare freely and voluntarily what they are compelled unto: and la≈øtly, that they ≈øweare that Oath in the literall ≈øence, whereof no two of the makers them≈øelves, that I have heard of, could never agree in the under≈øtanding.

In a word, Mr. Speaker, to tell you my opinion of this Oath, it is a Covenant again≈øt the King, for Bi≈øhops and the Hierarchy; as the Scotti≈øh Covenants is again≈øt them, onely ≈øo much wor≈øe then the Scotti≈øh, as they admit not of the Supremacy in Eccle≈øia≈øticall affaires, and we are ≈øworne unto it.

Now Mr. Speaker, for tho≈øe particular heads of grievances whereby our E≈øtates and Properties are ≈øo radically invaded; I ≈øuppo≈øe (as I ≈øayd before) that it is no ≈øea≈øon now to enter into a ≈øtrict Di≈øcu≈ø≈øion of them; onely thus much I ≈øhall ≈øay of them, with application to the Countrey for which I ≈øerve, that none can more ju≈øtly complaine, ≈øince none can more ju≈øtly challenge exemption from ≈øuch burdens then Dor≈øet ≈øhire; whether you con≈øider its a Countrey ≈øub≈øi≈øting much by Trade; or as none of the mo≈øt populous; or as expo≈øed as much as any to Forraigne Inva≈øion.
But alas Mr. Speaker, particular lamentations are hardly di≈øtingui≈øhable in Vniver≈øall groanes.

Mr. Speaker, it hath beene a Metaphor frequent in Parlamant, and if my memory fayle me not, was made u≈øe of in the Lord Keepers Speech at the opening of the la≈øt, that what mony Kings ray≈øed from their Subjects,
they were But as ∆≤apors drawn up from the Earth by the Sunne, to bee di≈øtilled upon it againe in fructifying ≈øhowers. The Compari≈øon Mr. Speaker, hath held of late yeares in this Kingdome too unluckily: what hath bin rai≈øed from the Subject by tho≈øe violent attractions, hath beene formed, it is true, into Clouds, but how? to darken the Sunnes owne lu≈øtre, and hath fallen againe upon the Land only in Hail-≈øtones and Mildews, to batter and pro≈øt rate ≈øtill more and more our liberties, to bla≈øt and wither our affections; had the latter of the≈øe beene ≈øtill kept alive by our Kings owne per≈øonall vertues, which wil ever pre≈øerve him in ≈øpight of all ill Coun≈øellours, a ≈øacred object, both of our admiration and loves.

Mr. Speaker, It hath beene often ≈øayd in this Hou≈øe, and I thinke can never be too often repeated, That the Kings of England can do no wrong; but thogh they could Mr. Speaker, yet Princes have no part in the ill of tho≈øe actions which their Judges a≈ø≈øure them to be ju≈øt, their Coun≈øellours that they are prudent, and their Divines that they are con≈øcientious.

This Con≈øideration, M. Speaker, leadeth mee to that which is more nece≈ø≈øary farre, at this ≈øea≈øon, than any farther laying open of our mi≈øeries, that is, the way to the remedy, by ≈øeeking to remove from our Soveraign, ≈øuch unju≈øt Judges, ≈øuch pernicious Coun≈øellours, and ≈øuch di≈øcon≈øcient Divines, as have of late yeares, by their wicked practi≈øes, provoked a≈øper≈øions upon the government of the graciou≈øe≈øt and be≈øt of Kings.

Mr. Speaker, let me not be mi≈ø-under≈øtood, I levell at no man with a fore-layd de≈øigne, let the faults, and and tho≈øe well proved, lead us to the men: It is the onely true Parliamentary method, and the onely fit one to incline our Soveraigne. For it can no more
con≈øi≈øt with a gracious and righteous Prince to expo≈øe his ≈øervants upon irregular prejudices; then with a wi≈øe Prince to with hold Malefactors, how great ≈øoever, from the cour≈øe of orderly ju≈øtice.

Let me acquaint you M. Speaker, with an Aphori≈øme in Hippocrates, no le≈ø≈øe Authenticke, (I thinke) in the body Politicke, then in the Naturall Thus it is Mr. Speaker, Bodies to be throughly and effectually purged, must have their Humors fir≈øt made fluid and m ‚Ä¢ oveable.

The Humours that I under≈øtand to have cau≈øed all the de≈øperate maladies of this Nation, are the ill Mini≈øter. To purge them away clearely, they mu≈øt be fir≈øt loo≈øened, un≈øetled, and extenuated, which can no way bee effected with a gracious Ma≈øter, but by truely repre≈øenting them unworthy of his protection. And this leadeth mee to my Motion, which is; that a ≈øelect Committee may bee appointed to draw out of all that hath beene heere repre≈øented, ≈øuch a Remon≈øtrance as may be a faithfull and lively repre≈øentation unto his Maje≈øty of the deplorable e≈øtate of this his Kingdome, and ≈øuch as may happily point out unto his cleare and excellent judgment, the pernicious Authors of it. And that this Remon≈øtrance being drawne, wee may with all ≈øpeed repaire to the Lords, and de≈øire them to joyne with with us in it: And this is my humble motion.

div.head: THE LORD DIGBIES SPEECH IN THE HO∆≤SE OF Commons, to the Bill for trienniall Parliaments. Janu. 19. 1640.
div.p: I Ri≈øe not now with an intent to ≈øpeake to the frame and ≈øtructure of this Bill, nor much by way of an≈øwer to objections that may be made; I hope there will be no occa≈øion of that, but that we ≈øhall concurre all unanimou≈øly in what concerneth all ≈øo Univer≈øally.

Onely Sir, by way of preparation, to the end that we may not be di≈øcouraged in this great worke by difficulties that may appeare in the way of it, I ≈øhall deliver unto you my apprehen≈øions in generall of the va≈øt importance and nece≈ø≈øity that wee ≈øhould goe thorow with it.

The Re≈øult of my ≈øen≈øe is in ≈øhort this: That unle≈øse for the frequent convening of Parliaments there be ≈øome ≈øuch cour≈øe ≈øetled, as may not be eluded; neyther
the people can be pro≈øperous and ≈øecure, not the King him≈øelfe ≈øolidly happy. I take this to be the Vnum nece≈ø≈øarium: Let us procure this, and all our other de≈øires will effect them≈øelves: if this bill mi≈øcarry, I ≈øhall have left me no publike hopes, and once pa≈øt, I ≈øhall be freed of all publike feares.

The e≈ø≈øentialne≈ø≈øe Sir of frequent Parliaments to the happine≈ø≈øe of this Kingdome, might be inferr'd unto you by the rea≈øon of contraries, from the wofull experience which former times have had of the mi≈øchievous effects of any long intermi≈ø≈øion of them.

But Mr. Speaker, why ≈øhould we clime higher then the levell we are on, or thinke further then our owne Horizon, or have recour≈øe for examples in this bu≈øines, to any other promptuary then our owne memories; nay then the experience almo≈øt of the younge≈øt here?

The reflection backward on the di≈øtractions of former times upon intermi≈ø≈øion of Parliament, and the con≈øideration forward of the mi≈øchiefes likely ≈øtill to grow from the ≈øame cau≈øe if not remooved, doubtle≈øly gave fir≈øt life and being to tho≈øe two dormant Statutes of Edward the third, for the yearly holding of Parliament: And ≈øhall not the fre≈øh and bleeding experience in the pre≈øent age of mi≈øeries from the ≈øame ≈øpring, not to be paralleld in any other, obtaine a wakening, a re≈øurrection for them?

The Inte≈øtine di≈øtempers Sir, of former ages upon the want of Parliaments, may appeare to have had ≈øome other cooperative cau≈øes, as ≈øometimes, un≈øucce≈ø≈øefull Warres abroad; ≈øometimes, the ab≈øence of the Prince; ≈øometimes, Competitions of Titles to the Crowne; ≈øomtimes, perhaps the vices of the King him≈øelfe.

But let us but rightly weigh and con≈øider the po≈øture, the a≈øpect of this ≈øtate, both toward it ≈øelfe, and
the re≈øt of the world, the per≈øon of our Soveraigne, and the nature of our ≈øuffering ≈øince the third of his Reigne. And there can be no cau≈øe coulorable inventible, wherunto to attribute them but the intermi≈ø≈øion, or which is wor≈øe, the undue fru≈øtration of Parliament, by the unluckly u≈øe if not abu≈øe of Prerogative in the di≈ø≈øolving them.

Take in your view Gentlemen, a State in a ≈øtate of the greate≈øt quiet and ≈øecurity that can be fancied, not only in joyning the calme≈øt peace it ≈øelfe, but to improve and ≈øecure its happy condition, all the re≈øt of the world at the ≈øame time in Tempe≈øt, in Combu≈øtions, in uncompo≈øable Warres.

Take into your view Sir, a King Soveraigne to three Kingdomes, by a Concentring of all the Royall lines in his Per≈øon, as undi≈øputably as any Mathematical ones in Euclide. A King firme and knowing in his Religion, eminent in vertue; A King that had in his owne time given all the Rights and Liberties of his Subjects a more cleare and ample confirmation freely and graciou≈øly, then any of his Predece≈ø≈øors (when the people had them at advantage) extortedly, I meane in the Petition of Right.

This is one Mappe of England, Mr. Speaker, A man Sir, that ≈øhould pre≈øent unto you now, a Kingdome, groaning under that ≈øupreme Law, which Salus populi periclitata would enact. The liberty, the property of the Subject fundamentally ≈øubverted, ravi≈øht away by the violence of a pretended nece≈ø≈øity; a triple Crown ≈øhaking with di≈øtempers; men of the be≈øt con≈øcience ready to fly into the wilderne≈ø≈øe for Religion. Would not one ≈øweare that this were the Antipodes to the other; & yet let me tell you Mr. Speaker, this is a Mappe of England too, and both at the ≈øame time true.

As it cannot bee denyed, Mr. Speaker, that ≈øince the Conque≈øt there hath not been in this Kingdome a fuller concurrance of all circum≈øtances in the former Caracter, to have made a Kingdom happy, then for the≈øe 12. yeares la≈øt pa≈øt; ≈øo it is mo≈øt certaine, that there hath not beene in all that deduction of ages, ≈øuch a Con≈øpiracie, if one may ≈øo ≈øay of all the Elements of mi≈øchiefe thein ≈øecond Character, to bring a flouri≈øhing Kingdom, if it were po≈ø≈øible, to ≈øwift ruine and de≈øolation.
I will be bold to ≈øay, Mr. Speaker, and I thanke God, wee have ≈øo good a King, under whom wee may ≈øpeake boldly of the abu≈øe by ill Mini≈øters, without reflection upon his per≈øon.

That an Accumulation of all the publike Grievances ≈øince Magna Carta, one upon another, unto that houre in which the Petition of Right pa≈øt into an act of Parliament, would not amount to ≈øo oppre≈ø≈øive; I am ≈øure not to ≈øo de≈øtructive a height and magnitude to the rights and property of the Subject, as one branch of our be≈ølaving ≈øince the Petition of Right.
The branch I mean, is the judgment concerning ≈øhip-money. This beeing a true repre≈øentation of England in both a≈øpects.

Let him, Mr. Speaker, that for the unmatcht oppre≈ø≈øion and enthralling of free Subjects in a time of the be≈øt Kings raigne, and in memory of the be≈øt lawes enacted in favour of Subjects liberty, can find a truer Cau≈øe then the ruptures and intermi≈ø≈øion of Parliaments. Let him and him alone be again≈øt the ≈øetling of this inevitable way for the frequent holding of them.

'Tis true Sir, wicked Mini≈øters have beene the proximate
cau≈øes of our mi≈øeries, but the want of Parliaments the primary, the efficient Cau≈øe.
Ill Mini≈øters have made ill times, but that Sir, hath made ill Mini≈øters.

I have read among the Lawes of the Athenians, a form of recour≈øe in their Oaths and vows of greate≈øt & mo≈øt publique concernment of a three-fold Deity, Supplicium Exauditori, Purgatori, Malorum depul≈øori.
I doubt not but we here a≈ø≈øembled for the Commonwealth in this Parliament, ≈øhall meet with all the≈øe Attributes in our Soveraigne.
I make no que≈øtion but he will graciou≈øly heare our Supplications, purge away our Grievances, and expell Malefactors, that is, remove ill Mini≈øters, and put good in their places.
No le≈ø≈øe can be expected from his wi≈ødome and goodne≈ø≈øe.

But let me tell you Mr. Speaker, if we partake not of one Attribute more in him; if we addre≈ø≈øe not our ≈øelves unto that, I meane Bonorum Con≈øervatori; we can have no ≈øolid, no durable Comfort in all the re≈øt.
Let his Maje≈øty heare our Complaint never ≈øo Compa≈ø≈øionately.
Let him purge away our Grievances never ≈øo efficaciou≈øly.
Let him puni≈øh and di≈øpell ill Mini≈øters never ≈øo exemplarily.
Let him make choyce of good ones never ≈øo exactly.

If there be not a way ≈øetled to pre≈øerve and keepe them good; the mi≈øchiefes and they will all grow again like Samp≈øons Locks, and pull downe the Hou≈øe upon our heads. Beleeve it M. Speaker, they will.

It hath been a Maxime among≈øt the wi≈øe≈øt Legi≈ølators, that who≈øoever meanes to ≈øettle good Lawes, mu≈øt proceed in them, with a ≈øini≈øter opinion of all Mankinde; and ≈øuppo≈øe that who≈øoever is not wicked, it is for want only of the opportunity. It is that opportunity of being ill Mr. Speaker, that wee mu≈øt take away, if ever wee meane to be happy, which can never be done, but by the frequencie of Parliaments.
No ≈øtate can wi≈øely be confident of any publique Mini≈øters continuing good, longer then the rod is over him.

Let me appeale to all tho≈øe that were pre≈øent in this Hou≈øe at the agitation of the Petition of Right. And let them tell them≈øelves truly, of who≈øe promotion to the management of affaires doe they thinke the generality would at that time have had better hopes then of Mr. Noy, and Sir Thomas Wentworth, both having beene at that time, and in that bu≈øine≈ø≈øe as I have heard, mo≈øt keen and active Patriots, and the latter of them to the eternall aggravation of his Infamous treachery to the Common-wealth be it ≈øpoken, the fir≈øt mover, and in≈øi≈øter to have this clau≈øe added to the Petition of Right, that for the comfort and ≈øafety of his Subjects, his Maje≈øty would be plea≈øed to declare his will and plea≈øure, that all his Mini≈øters ≈øhould ≈øerve him according to the Lawes and Statutes of the Realme.

And yet Mr. Speaker, to whom now can all the inundations upon our liberties under pretence of Law, and the late ≈øhipwrack at once of all our property, be attributed more then to Noy, and tho≈øe and all other mi≈øchiefes whereby this Monarchie hath beene brought almo≈øt to the brinke of de≈øtruction, ≈øo much to any as to that Grand Apo≈øtate to the Common-wealth, the now Lieutenant of Ireland?
The fir≈øt I hope God hath forgiven in the other world; and the latter mu≈øt not hope to be pardoned in this, till he be di≈øpatcht to the other.
Let every man but con≈øider tho≈øe men as once they were.
The excellent Law for the ≈øecurity of the Subject enacted immediately before their comming to employment, in the contriving whereof them≈øelves were principall Actors.

The goodne≈ø≈øe and vertue of the King they ≈øerved, and yet the high and publique oppre≈ø≈øions that in his time they have wrought! And ≈øurely there is no man but will conclude with me, that as the deficience of Parliaments hath bin the Cau≈øa Cau≈øarum of all the mi≈øchiefes and di≈øtempers of the pre≈øent times; ≈øo the frequency of them is the ≈øole Catholicke Antidote that can pre≈øerve and ≈øecure the future from the like danger.

Mr. Speaker, let me yet draw my Di≈øcour≈øe a little nearer to his Maje≈øty him≈øelfe, and tell you, that the frequency of Parliament is mo≈øt e≈ø≈øentially nece≈ø≈øary to the power, the ≈øecurity, the glory of the King.

There are two wayes, Mr. Speaker, of powerfull
Rule, eyther by Feare, or Love, but one of happy and ≈øafe Rule, that is, by Love, that Firmi≈ø≈øinum Imperium quo obedientes ga ‚Ä¢ dent.

To which Camillus advi≈øed the Romans. Let a Prince con≈øider what it is that mooves a people principally to affection, and dearne≈ø≈øe, towards their Soveraigne. He ≈øhall ≈øee that there needs no other Artifice in it, then to let them injoy unmole≈øted, what belongs unto them of right: If that have beene invaded and violated in any kind, whereby affections are alienated: the next con≈øideration for a wi≈øe Prince that would be happy, is how to regaine them: To which three things are equally nece≈ø≈øary.

list.item: 1. Re-in≈øtating them in their former Libertie.
2. Revenging them of the Authors of tho≈øe violations.
3. And ≈øecuring them from Apprehen≈øions of the like againe.

div.p: The fir≈øt, (God be thanked,) wee are in a good way of.
The ≈øecond in warme pur≈øuit of.
But the third, as e≈ø≈øentiall as all the re≈øt, till we be certain of a Trienniall Parliament, at the lea≈øt, I profe≈ø≈øe I can have but cold hopes of.
I be≈øeech you then Gentlemen, ≈øince that ≈øecurity for the future is ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary to that ble≈ø≈øed union of affections, and this Bill ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary to that ≈øecurity:

Let us not be ≈øo wanting to our ≈øelves; let us not be ≈øo wanting to our Soveraigne, as to forbeare to offer unto him, this powerfull, this everla≈øting Philter, to Charme unto him the hearts of his people, who≈øe vertue can never evaporate.

There is no man, M. Speaker, ≈øo ≈øecure of anothers friend≈øhip, but will thinke frequent intercour≈øe and acce≈ø≈øe very requi≈øite to the ≈øupport, to the confirmation of it: E≈øpecially, if ill offices have beene done betweene them; if the ray≈øing of jealou≈øies hath beene attempted. There is no Friend but would be impatient to be debarred from giving his friend ≈øuccour and reliefe in his nece≈ø≈øities.

Mr. Speaker, permit mee the compari≈øon of great things with little: what friend≈øhip, what union can there be ≈øo comfortable, ≈øo happy, as betweene a gracious Soveraigne and his people? and what greater misfortune can there bee to both, then for them to bee kept from entercour≈øe, from the meanes of clearing mi≈ø under≈øtandings, from interchange of mutuall benefits?
The people of England, Sir, cannot open their Eares, their Hearts, their Mouthes, nor their Pur≈øes, to his Maje≈øty, but in Parliament.
We can neyther heare Him, nor Complaine, nor acknowledge, nor give, but there.
This Bill, Sir, is the ≈øole Key that can open the way to a frequency of tho≈øe reciprocall indearments, which mu≈øt make and perpetuate the happine≈ø≈øe of the King and Kingdome.

Let no man object any derogation from the Kings Prerogative by it. Wee doe but pre≈øent the Bill, 'tis to be made a Law by him, his Honour, his Power, will be as con≈øpicuous, in commanding at once that Parliament ≈øhall a≈ø≈øemble every third yeare, as in commanding a Parliament to be called this or that yeare: there
is more of his Maje≈øty in ordayning primary and Vniver≈øall Cau≈øes, then in the actua ‚Ä¢ ing particularly of ≈øubordinate effects.
I doubt not, but that glorious King Edward the Third, when he made tho≈øe Lawes for the yearely Calling of Parliament, did it with a right ≈øence of his dignity and honour.
The truth is, Sir, the Kings of England are never in their Glory, in their Splendour, in their Maje≈øticke Soveraignty, but in Parliaments.

Where is the power of impo≈øing Taxes? Where is the power of restoring from incapacities? Where is the legi≈ølative Authority? Marry in the King, Mr. Speaker. But how? In the King circled in, fortified and evirtuated by his Parliament.
The King out of Parliament hath a limitted, a circum≈øcribed jurisdiction. But waited on by his Parliament, no Monarch of the Ea≈øt is ≈øo ab≈øolute in di≈øpelling Grievances.

Mr. Speaker, in cha≈øing ill Mini≈øters, we doe but di≈ø≈øipate Clouds that may gather againe, but in voting this Bill, we ≈øhall contribute, as much as in us lyes, to the perpetuating our Sunne, our Soveraigne, in his verticall, in his Noone day lu≈øtre.

div.head: A Speech of the Honourable NATHANAEL FIENNES, In the Hou≈øe of Commons the 9. of Febr. 1640.
div.p: TWO things have fallen into debate this day.
The fir≈øt, concerning the Londoners Petition, whether it ≈øhould bee committed or no.
The other, concerning the government of the Church, by Arch-bi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, &c. whether it ≈øhould bee countenanced or no.
For the fir≈øt, I doe not under≈øtand by any thing that I have yet heard, why the Londoners Petition ≈øhould not be committed, or countenanced.
The exceptions that are taken again≈øt it, are from the irregularities of the delivery of it, and from the Subject matter contained in it.

For the fir≈øt, it is alledged that the long taile of this blazing ≈øtarre, is ominous, and that ≈øuch a number of Petitioners, and ≈øuch a number that brought the Petition to the Hou≈øe, was irregular. Hereunto I an≈øwer, that the fault was either in the multitude of the Petitioners, or in their carriages, and demeanours: if a multitude
finde them≈øelves agrieved, why it ≈øhould be a fault in them to expre≈ø≈øe their grievances more than in one, or a few, I cannot ≈øee; nay, to me it ≈øeemes rather a rea≈øon that their Petitions ≈øhould be committed, and taken into ≈øerious con≈øideration, for thereby they may receive ≈øatisfaction, though all bee not granted that they de≈øire. But if wee ≈øhall throw their Petition behind the door, and refu≈øe to con≈øider it, that it may ≈øeeme an act of will in us. And whether an act of will in us, may not produce an act of will in the people, I leave it to your con≈øideration. Sure I am, acts of will are more dangerous there than here, becau≈øe u≈øually they are more tumultuous. All Lawes are made, principally for the quiet and peace of a Kingdome; and a Law may be of ≈øuch indifferent nature many times, that it is a good rea≈øon to alter it, onely, becau≈øe a great number de≈øires it, if there were nothing el≈øe in it, and therefore I doe not ≈øee that the number of Petitioners is any good rea≈øon, why it ≈øhould not bee committed, but rather the contrary.

Now for their carriage, there came indeed, three or foure hundred of the 15000, ≈øome of the better ≈øort of them, and there might bee good rea≈øon for it. I have heard that there was brought a Petition to ≈øome privie Coun≈øellours, with a thou≈øand hands to it, and being brought onely with ≈øixe men, they were an≈øwered, that they ≈øixe might write tho≈øe thou≈øand hands; if there were a thou≈øand that joyned in the Petition, why did they not come too? And we heard it objected but the other day, in this hou≈øe again≈øt the Mini≈øters Petition, that there were indeed ≈øeven or eight hundred names to it, but two hands onely. Therefore it was not without cau≈øe, that a con≈øiderable number ≈øhould come with a Petition ≈øigned by ≈øo many; but for any di≈øorder in their carriage, I ≈øaw none; for upon an intimation in one word from this hou≈øe, they forthwith retired to their dwellings. As for the ≈øubject matter of the Petition,
three exceptions are taken again≈øt it.
Fir≈øt, that divers things are contemptible in it, as that about Ovid de Amore, ≈øet forth in Engli≈øh, and other ≈øuch things.

Secondly, that in many things their di≈øcour≈øe was altogether irrationall, for that they argue from per≈øonall faults of Bi≈øhops again≈øt the office it ≈øelfe of Bi≈øhops, and in other things argue from effects that proceed from it by accident, as if they did flie out of it.
And in the la≈øt place, that their prayer and conclu≈øion is bold and pre≈øumptuous, de≈øiring ≈øo boldly an abolition of ≈øtanding Lawes.

To the fir≈øt I an≈øwer, that ≈øome things may ≈øeeme contemptible in them≈øelves, which are not ≈øo in their cau≈øes, nor in their effects, as the ≈øuffering of ≈øuch la≈øcivious pamphlets to be printed and publi≈øhed, when other profitable writings are ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, doth di≈øcover a principle, that loo≈øene≈ø≈øe and prophane≈ø≈øe (which will helpe to bring in ≈øuper≈øtition) is more ≈øutable to their hierarchy than the contrary, which makes them connive at ≈øuch things as are apt to produce loo≈øene≈ø≈øe and lewdne≈ø≈øe, and this is no contemptible effect, nor doth it proceed from a contemptible cau≈øe.

In the next place, for that which ≈øeemes irrationall in the way of their di≈øcovery, divers things may ≈øeeme to bee per≈øonall faults, which indeed are derived unto the per≈øons from the office, or from the circum≈øtances thereof, I meane their revenues, and dignities on the one ≈øide, and the ceremonies on the other ≈øide. For mo≈øt of the things complained of, as ≈øilencing, and thru≈øting out of godly and painfull Preachers, bringing in Innovations in Doctrine, and wor≈øhip, and the like; although they may ≈øeeme per≈øonall and accidentall faults, yet if wee follow them to their la≈øt re≈øort, wee ≈øhall find that their worldly wealth and dignities ≈øtirre them up to doe this, that their ≈øole and arbitrary power
over the Clergy, and in matter Eccle≈øia≈øticall, enable them to effect it, and the ceremonies both new and old ≈øerve as in≈øtruments, and meanes, whereby they effect it.

In the la≈øt place, that their Prayer in the conclu≈øion of their Petition, is bold or pre≈øumptuous, I doe not ≈øee there is any rea≈øon ≈øo to e≈øteeme of it: for if they had taken upon them to have altered any thing upon their owne authority, or had imperiou≈øly required the Parliament to doe it, then it might de≈øerve ≈øuch a ≈øtile: but when they come as humble ≈øuppliants, by way of Petition, de≈øiring the altering of Lawes, that have been found burden≈øome unto them, and that of the Parliament, where, and wherein onely old lawes may bee repealed, and new Lawes may be made, they come in the right manner, to their right and proper place, and therefore have done nothing boldly, or pre≈øumptuou≈øly, but orderly, and regularly, and therefore ought not to receive any check or di≈øcouragement in the way that they have taken.

Now Sir, concerning the government of the Church, by Arch-Bi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, &c. which al≈øo hath beene ≈øpoken unto; whereas it is de≈øired, that the evills, and inconveniences ≈øhould be ≈øhewed which ari≈øe not from the per≈øons, but from the office it ≈øelfe of Bi≈øhops, I ≈øhall apply my di≈øcour≈øe particularly to that poynt. But fir≈øt, I ≈øhall crave leave to ≈øay a word or two, in an≈øwer to what hath beene alledged for the credit of the Government by Bi≈øhops. Fir≈øt, that it is as ancient as Chri≈øtian Religion, and that it hath continued ever ≈øince the time of Chri≈øt and his Apo≈øtles; as for this, I doe not pretend to have ≈øo much knowledge in antiquity, as to confute this out of the Fathers and Eccle≈øia≈øticall Hi≈øtories; (although there are that undertake that) onely one ≈øentence I have often heard cited out of Saint Ierome, that in the Primitive times, Omnia
communi Clericorum Concilio regebantur: and truely ≈øo farre as the Acts of the Apo≈øtles, and the New Te≈øtament goeth, which was the anciente≈øt, and mo≈øt primitive time of Chri≈øtianity, I could never find there any di≈øtinction betweene a Bi≈øhop and a Presbyter, but that they were one and the very ≈øame thing. In the next place, that which is alledged for the credit of Epi≈øcopacy, is, that our Reformers and Martyrs were many of them Bi≈øhops, and practi≈øed many of tho≈øe things now complai ‚Ä¢ ed of; and that in other Reformed Churches wh ‚Ä¢ re Bi≈øhops are not, they are de≈øired. For the Martyrs and Reformers of the Church that were Bi≈øhops, I doe not under≈øtand that that was any part of their Reformation, nor of their Martyrdome; I have read, that whereas Ridley and Hooper had ≈øome difference betweene them in their life time about the≈øe things, when they came both to their martyrdome, he that had formerly beene the Patron of this Hierarchy, and Ceremonies, told his brother, that therein his fooli≈øhne≈ø≈øe had contended with his wi≈øedome. As for that which is ≈øaid, that other Reformed Churches where they have not Bi≈øhops, yet they are de≈øired, I will not deny but ≈øome among them may de≈øire Bi≈øhopricks, I meane the Dignities and Revenues of Bi≈øhops, but that they de≈øire Bi≈øhops as thinking it the fitte≈øt and be≈øt Government of the Church, I cannot beleeve, for if they would have Bi≈øhops, why doe they not make them≈øelves Bi≈øhops? I know not what hindreth, why they might not have Bi≈øhops when they would. In the la≈øt place, for that which is alledged in relation to the government of this Kingdome, that Bi≈øhops are ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary, as that the King cannot well let them goe with the ≈øafety of Monarchy, and that if Bi≈øhops bee taken away, A≈ø≈øemblies, or ≈øomething mu≈øt come in the roome thereof. And if Kings ≈øhould bee ≈øubject thereunto, and ≈øhould happen to be excommunicated thereby, that after they would bee little esteemed, or obeyed as Kings: for
this, if it ≈øhall be cleared, as it is affirmed, or if any thing therein doe ≈øtrike at Monarchy, I ≈øhall never give my vote, nor con≈øent thereunto as long as I live. But to cleare that this is not ≈øo, I offer to your con≈øideration, that by the Law of this Land not onely all Eccle≈øia≈øticall Juri≈ødiction, but al≈øo all ≈øuperiority, and preheminence over the Eccle≈øia≈øticall ≈øtate, is annexed to the Imperiall Crowne of this Realme, and may bee granted by Commi≈ø≈øion under the great ≈øeale, to ≈øuch per≈øons as his Maje≈øtie ≈øhall thinke meet: now, if the King ≈øhould grant it to a certaine number of Commi≈ø≈øioners, equall in authority, as hee may doe, this were an abolition of Epi≈øcopacy, and yet not diminution of Monarchy; But the truth is, Epi≈øcopacy is a kind of Monarchy under a Monarchy, and is therein altogether unlike the Civill Government under his Maje≈øtie: for the King being a common head over the Eccle≈øia≈øticall ≈øtate and the Civill, we ≈øhall finde that in the exerci≈øe of Civill Juri≈ødiction, in all Courts under his Maje≈øty, it is Ari≈øtocraticall, and placed in many, and not in one, as appeareth in this high Court of Parliament, in the inferiour Courts of We≈øtmin≈øter Hall, and in the Sizes, and Se≈ø≈øions in the Countrey, which are held by many Commi≈ø≈øioners, and not onely by one, or his Deputies, and Commi≈ø≈øaries, as it is in the exerci≈øe of Eccle≈øia≈øticall government. As to the point of Excommunication, ≈øuppo≈øing that it did di≈ø≈øolve naturall and civill bonds of duty, as it doth not, it might indeed be as terrible to Princes, as it is repre≈øented. But I rea≈øon thus, either Princes are ≈øubject to Excommunication, or they are not: if they bee not, then they need as little to feare a Presbyterie or an a≈ø≈øembly, as a Bi≈øhop in that re≈øpect; if they bee, they have as much to feare from Bi≈øhops, at lea≈øtwi≈øe from Bi≈øhops in their Convocations, as from Presbyters in their A≈ø≈øemblies; and ≈øo much the more, becau≈øe they have formerly felt the thunderbolts of tho≈øe of
