that ≈øtampe, but never from this latter ≈øort. And now Sir, I proceede to repre≈øent unto you the evills, and inconveniences that doe proceede from the government and Ceremonies of the Church, and truely in my opinion, the chiefe and principall cau≈øe of all the evills which we have ≈øuffered, ≈øince the Reformation in this Church and State, hath proceeded from that divi≈øion which ≈øo unhappily hath ≈øprung up amongst us, about Church government, and the Ceremonies of the Church, and from which part in that divi≈øion, I beleeve, it will appeare in the particulars. I know well there is a great divi≈øion, and that upon great matters, betweene us and the Papi≈øts, and I am not ignorant that there have beene great and ≈øore breaches made upon our Civill Liberties, and the right of our proprieties.

But yet ≈øtill I returne to my former po≈øition, that the chiefe and mo≈øt active cau≈øe hath proceeded from the Government and Ceremonies of the Church, and that tho≈øe other cau≈øes have either fallen into it, and ≈øo acted by it, or i≈ø≈øued out of it, and ≈øo acted from it. As for Popery, I conceive that to have beene a cau≈øe that hath fallen into this, and acted by it; for at the Reformation it received ≈øuch a deadly wound by ≈øo many ≈øharpe Lawes enacted again≈øt it, that had it not beene enlivened by this divi≈øion among≈øt us, it could never have had influence upon our Church and State to have troubled them, as this day wee feele; but finding that in this divi≈øion among≈øt us, one party had need of ≈øome of their principalls to maintaine their Hierarchy, together with their worldly pompe and Ceremonies, which are appurtenances thereunto; from hence they fir≈øt conceived a ground of hope, and afterwards found meanes of ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, towards the introducing againe of their ≈øuper≈øtition and Idolatry into this Realme; and they wrought ≈øo diligently upon this foundation, that they have advanced their building very farre, and how neare they were to
≈øet up the Roofe, I leave it to your con≈øideration. As for the evills which we have ≈øuffered in our civill liberty, and the right of our proprieties, J conceive they have proceeded out of this, and ≈øo acted from it; for if there had beene no breaches of Parliaments, there would have bin no need to have had recour≈øe unto tho≈øe broken Ci≈øternes, that can hold no water; but there being a ≈øtoppage of Parlamentary ≈øupplyes, that was an occa≈øion of letting in upon us ≈øuch an inundation of Monopolies, and other illegall taxes, and impo≈øitions, accompanyed with many other heavy and ≈øore breaches of our Liberties. Now there needed not to have beene any breaches of Parliaments, had there not beene ≈øomething di≈øliked in them, and what was that? it could not bee any of the≈øe civill matters that bred the fir≈øt difference, for they have proceeded out of it, therefore I conceive it was this: The Prelates with their adherents (the Papi≈øts al≈øo concurring with them for their intere≈øt) did alwayes looke upon Parliaments with an evill eye, as no friends to their offices and functions, at lea≈øtwi≈øe to their Benefices and Dignities, and therefore (≈øome of them having alwayes had the grace to bee too neare to the Princes eates) they have alwayes endeavoured to breed a di≈ø-affection in Kings from Parliaments, as the Pre≈ø≈øe and Pulpit doe abundantly witne≈ø≈øe, and Ballads too, made by ≈øome of them upon the breaches of Parliaments. But wee have a fre≈øh and bleeding in≈øtance of this in the confirmation in his Maje≈øties name, which they procured to be prefixed before their new Booke of Canons, wherein they have endeavoured to make this impre≈ø≈øion upon his Maje≈øties Royall minde, that the Authors and Fomenters of the jealou≈øie in re≈øpect of the new Rites and Ceremonies lately introduced into the Church, which wee call innovations, did ≈øtrike at his Royall per≈øon, as if hee were perverted in his Religion, and did wor≈øhip God in a ≈øuperstitious way, and intended to bring in ≈øome Innovation in
matter of Religion. Now Sir, who are the authors of tho≈øe jealou≈øies? did they not come as complaints in the Petitions from the bodies of ≈øeverall Counties the la≈øt Parliament, and from more this pre≈øent Parliament? and who were the fomenters of tho≈øe jealou≈øies? did not the generall ≈øence of the la≈øt Parliament concurre in it, that they were Innovations, and that they were ≈øu≈øpitions, as introductory to ≈øuper≈øtition? Nay, I appeale to all tho≈øe that hear me, which are drawn from al parts of the Kingdom, whether this be not the generall ≈øence of the greate≈øt and mo≈øt con≈øiderable part of the whole Kingdom? I be≈øeech you then to con≈øider, what kind Offices the≈øe men have done between the King and the Parlament, between the King and Kingdom, I ≈øpeak of the greate≈øt and mo≈øt con≈øiderable par ‚Ä¢ s, as giving denomination to the whole. And now Sir, as we have ca≈øt our eye backwards, if wee will looke forwards, how doe the clouds thicken upon us, and what di≈øtractions, yea what dangers doe they threaten us withall, proceeding ≈øtill from the ≈øame root of Church Government and Ceremonies? and truely as things now ≈øtand, I ≈øee but two wayes, the one of De≈øtruction, the other of Satisfaction; Destruction I meane of the oppo≈øite partie to the Bi≈øhops, and the Ceremonies, and reducing of all to Canonicall obedience, by faire meanes or by foule: this way hath beene already tryed, and what effect it hath brought forth in our neighbour kingdome, wee well know, and it is like to produce no very good effect in this Kingdome, if mens ≈øcruples and rea≈øons in that behalfe ≈øhall bee onely an≈øwered with Pri≈øons, and Pillories, and hard Cen≈øures, that I may ≈øpeake most ≈øoftly of them. I hold therefore, that the other way of ≈øatisfaction is the ≈øafe≈øt, the ea≈øie≈øt, and the onely way. And that is to take into con≈øideration, the ≈øeverall heads of the evills, which are cau≈øes of the≈øe complaints, and to finde out, and apply the proper remedies thereunto. For the furtherance whereof, I ≈øhall make
bold with your patience (which I am very unwilling to tire, but mu≈øt tire my owne Con≈øcience if I ≈øhould not di≈øcharge it upon this occa≈øion) to repre≈øent a briefe Modell of the ≈øeverall heads and ≈øprings from whence the evills, which are cau≈øes of the≈øe complaints, doe naturally or occa≈øionally ari≈øe. The evils complained of, doe either ari≈øe from per≈øons, or from things; tho≈øe faults that are per≈øonall are be≈øides the poynt that I intend to ≈øpeake to, there is one onely remedy for them, that is, by puni≈øhment and removall of ≈øuch per≈øons, and the putting of better in their roome. As for tho≈øe evills which proceed from things, they al≈øo are remedied by a removall of ≈øuch things as are evill, and the putting of better in their roome; the evills and inconveniences of this kinde doe principally flow, either from the Clergies Offices and functions, or from their Benefices and Dignities; tho≈øe that ari≈øe from their Offices and functions, doe ari≈øe naturally either from the Lawes and Con≈øtitutions whereby, and according to which they exerci≈øe their Offices and functions, or from the Government it ≈øelfe, wherein they exerci≈øe tho≈øe functions. The faults that I note in the Eccle≈øia≈øticall Lawes are, that they hold too much of the Civill Law, and too much of the Ceremoniall Law: Of the Civill Law, in re≈øpect of all tho≈øe Titles concerning Wills, and Legacies, tithes, marriages, adulteries, which all belonging to the Civill juri≈ødiction, and are no more of ≈øpirituall con≈øideration, than rapes, thefts, fellonies, or trea≈øons may bee. Sir, it is good that every bird ≈øhould have his owne feather, and I remember when one came to our Saviour Chri≈øt, to de≈øire him that hee would cau≈øe his Brother to divide the inheritance with him, hee asked him; who made him a Iudge of ≈øuch things: and may not we aske, who made them that take them≈øelves to bee ≈øucce≈ø≈øours of Chri≈øt and his Apo≈øtles, Judges of ≈øuch
things? Many inconveniences ari≈øe from hence; Fir≈øt that the mindes of Clergie men are inured unto Civill Dominion, and to meddle with civill matters. Secondly, the manner of their proceedings, is turned from a Spirituall way into the fa≈øhion of Proce≈ø≈øes in Temporall Courts. And la≈øtly, which is wor≈øt of all, by this meanes the Spi ‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢ uall Sword comes to bee un≈øheathed about ≈øuch things as doe not at all fall under the ≈øtroake thereof. And here Mr. Speaker, give me leave to lament the condition of this our Church of England, beyond that of all other reformed Churches. A certaine number of Ceremonies in the judgement of ≈øome men unlawfull, and to bee rejected of all Churches, in the judgement of all other reformed Churches to bee rejected by them, and in the judgement of our owne Churches, but indifferent Ceremonies: and yet what difference? yea, what di≈øtractions have the≈øe indifferent Ceremonies rai≈øed among us? What hath deprived us of ≈øo many faithfull, able, and godly Mini≈øters ≈øince the Reformation, as able and as fit in all other re≈øpects to di≈øcharge that function, as any age ever produced in the Chri≈øtian Word ≈øince the time of the Apo≈øtles, I ≈øay what hath deprived us of them, but the≈øe indifferent Ceremonies? What hath deprived us of ≈øo many thou≈øand Chri≈øtians which de≈øired (and in all other re≈øpects de≈øerved) to hold communion with us; I ≈øay, what hath deprived us of them, and ≈øcattered them into I know not what places and corners of the World, but the≈øe indifferent Ceremonies? What hath cau≈øed ≈øo many hard cen≈øures, and harder executions, but the≈øe indifferent Ceremonies? What hath occa≈øioned tho≈øe calamities
and dangers, which we feele, and which wee feare, but tho≈øe indifferent Ceremonies? I ≈øhall ≈øay no more of them, but I pray God that now at length it may plea≈øe his Maje≈øty with th ‚Ä¢ his great Councell of Parliament, to take a view of them, and if there be a nece≈øsity to retaine them, let them be retained; but if not, then let us remove them, before they ruine us. As to the evills and inconveniences that ari≈øe out of the government it ≈øelfe, I ≈øhould have noted ≈øomething ami≈ø≈øe, as well in the legi≈ølative part, as in the executive part, but in the former I am prevented, by what hath beene already voted concerning the Power of making Canons: which votes if they bee brought to perfection, they will ≈øet us right in great part, in that re≈øpect; for ≈øurely, before the power was neither in the hands of ≈øuch as were repre≈øentative of that which is truely the Church of England, nor yet in the hands of tho≈øe that were truely repre≈øentative of the Clergy of England, if they were the whole Church, as indeed they are not. As to the executive part, which con≈øi≈øteth in the exerci≈øe of Eccle≈øia≈øticall Juri≈ødiction, therein I note al≈øo two di≈øorders, Confu≈øion, and Corruption; Confu≈øion of the Spirituall Sword with the Temporall; Laymen ≈øtrike with the Spirituall ≈øword, and Spirituall men with the Temporall ≈øword: nay, out of the ≈øame mouth, and at the ≈øame time proceedeth an Excommunication, and a fine, or commitment, or both: I will not ≈øay po≈øitively, that it is unlawfull for Clergie-men to exerci≈øe civill juri≈ødiction, becau≈øe I know it is a que≈øtion, but yet ≈øuch a que≈øtion as hath bin determined by divers Canons of generall Councels, and by ≈øome that were made in Synods of the Church of England, that it is unlawfull, and that upon grounds which are not contemptible.

As fir≈øt, that it is contrary to the precept and practice of Chri≈øt and his Apo≈øtles. And ≈øecondly, That it is not
po≈ø≈øible for one man to di≈øcharge two Functions, whereof either is ≈øufficient to imploy the whole man, e≈øpecially that of the Mini≈øtery ≈øo great, that they ought not to entangle them≈øelves with the affaires of this world. A third ground not ≈øo well ob≈øerved generally, as in one part thereof, is this, That Mini≈øters of the Go≈øpell, being ≈øent e≈øpecially to gaine the Soules of men, they are to gaine as great intere≈øt as po≈ø≈øible may be, in their minds and affections: Now we know that the nature of all men is ≈øuch, that they are apt to think hardly of tho≈øe that are any Authors of their pain and puni≈øhment, although it bee in a way of Iu≈øtice, and therefore as it is well knowne, that Clergy men are not to be pre≈øent in judicio ≈øanguinis; ≈øo the ≈øame rea≈øon extends it ≈øelfe to the admini≈øtration of all Civill juri≈ødiction, and therefore we may ob≈øerve that our Saviour Chri≈øt, as hee alwayes rejected all Civill judicature, ≈øo on the other ≈øide, he went up and downe healing mens bodies, and otherwi≈øe doing good to their outward e≈øtate, that his Doctrine might have a freer and fairer pa≈ø≈øage into their Soules. For the corruption that I ≈øpoke of in the exerci≈øe of Eccle≈øia≈øticall juri≈ødiction, I doe not meane any per≈øonall corruption, but a deviation or aberration from the pre≈øcript of the Divine Rule: And though it bee not ea≈øie to finde what that is in all particulars, yet it is not hard to ≈øay, what it is not, and that I doubt may prove our ca≈øe indivors things. Eccle≈øia≈øtical Juri≈ødiction we know extendes either to the Clergy onely, and con≈øi≈øteth in the Ordination, Admi≈ø≈øion, Su≈øpen≈øion, and deprivation of them, or el≈øe it extendeth to the whole Church, and con≈øi≈øteth in Excommunication and Ab≈øolution. As to the Ordination, Admi≈ø≈øion, Su≈øpen≈øion, and Deprivation of Mini≈øters; we ≈øee how it is wholy at the plea≈øure of one man, and that of one man proceeding in a manner Arbitrarily, and that of one man who≈øe intere≈øt is concerned in it, that the doore ≈øhall be ≈øhut again≈øt able and painful preaching Mini≈øters, and a wide doore ≈øet open to ≈øuch
as are unable, and unfit for that function: many and great and dangerous evills ari≈øe from hence. As fir≈øt, that there is a con≈øtant bate and fewd between the Eccle≈øia≈øticall State and the Civill, betweene Prelates and Parliaments, betweene the Canon Law and the Common Law, betweene the Clergy and the Common-wealth, ari≈øing from the Di≈øproportion and Di≈ø≈øimilitude which is betweene the Civill and Eccle≈øia≈øticall Government, however it may ≈øeeme to ≈øome to agree well enough, but the truth is, if we con≈øider his Maje≈øty as the Commonhead over the Eccle≈øia≈øticall State, as well as the Civill, wee ≈øhall finde that in the exerci≈øe of all Civill juri≈ødiction, in all Courts under his Maje≈øty, the power is not in any one, or his Deputies and Commi≈ø≈øaries, as it is in the Eccle≈øia≈øticall Government, in the ≈øeverall Dioce≈ø≈øes throughout this Kingdome: If wee looke fir≈øt upon the Highe≈øt and greate≈øt Court, the High Court of Parliament, wee know that is a Councell, and a great Councell too. And if we look into the Country, we ≈øhall find the Se≈ø≈øions and A≈ø≈øizes, and other Courts, held not by any one, but by divers Commi≈ø≈øioners. (Sir) untill the Eccle≈øia≈øticall government be framed ≈øomething of another twi≈øt, and be more a≈ø≈øimilated unto that of the Common-wealth, I feare the Eccle≈øia≈øticall government will bee no good neighbour unto the Civill, but will be ≈øtill a ca≈øting in of its leaven into it, to reduce that al≈øo to a ≈øole, ab≈øolute, and arbitrary way of proceeding: And herein (Sir) I doe not beleeve, that I utter Prophe≈øies, but what wee have already found and felt.

A ≈øecond, and that a great evill, and of dangerous con≈øequence, in this ≈øole and arbitrary power of Bi≈øhops over their Clergy, is this, that they have by that meanes, a power to place, and di≈øplace the whole Clergy of their Dioce≈ø≈øe at their plea≈øure: and this is ≈øuch a power, as for my part, I had rather they had the like power over the E≈øtate and per≈øons of all within their Dioce≈ø≈øe; for if I hold the one, but at the will and plea≈øure of one man, (I meane the Mini≈øtery under which I mu≈øt live) I can have but little, or at lea≈øt no certain joy nor comfort in the other. But this is not all, for if they have ≈øuch a power to mould the Clergy of their Dioce≈ø≈øes, according to their plea≈øure, wee know what an Influence they may have by them upon the people, & that in a ≈øhort time they may bring them to ≈øuch blindne≈ø≈øe, and ≈øo mould them al≈øo to their owne wills, as that they may bring in what Religion they plea≈øe: nay, having put out our eyes, as the Phili≈øtins did Samp≈øons, they may afterwards make us grinde, and reduce us unto what ≈ølavery they plea≈øe, either unto them≈øelves, as formerly they have done, or unto others, as ≈øome of them lately have beene forward enough to doe. Now whether it be ≈øafe to walke upon Stilts on the top of the pinacles of the Temple, upon ≈øo high precipices, as are the matters of Religion and Con≈øcience (which may have al≈øo a dangerous Influence upon our civill liberties) I leave it to your con≈øideration: for my part I
≈øhould not thinke it ≈øafe, that ≈øuch a power ≈øhould bee in any one man, though you ≈øuppo≈øe him to be a very good man.

A third evill, and that of dangerous con≈øequence, is that the doore is ≈øhut again≈øt able and painfull Preaching Mini≈øters, and a wide doore ≈øet open to tho≈øe that are unable, and unfit for that function, and the Bi≈øhops intere≈øt is concerned in it, that it ≈øhould bee ≈øo, Intere≈øt of honour, Intere≈øt of profit, and Intere≈øt of power, Intere≈øt of credit; for they ≈øee that tho≈øe painfull Preachers carry away all the credit from them, and they neither can nor will doe the like them≈øelves: they cannot by rea≈øon they are ≈øo intangled with the affaires of this world, and civill juri≈ødiction; they will not, their great Dignities and Honours make them ≈øo ≈øtately, that they thinke it is not Epi≈øcopall to preach often; and on the other ≈øide, they are ≈øo fat, and live ≈øo much at their ea≈øe, that through idlene≈ø≈øe they cannot bring their mindes unto it, and ≈øo fir≈øt ari≈øeth envy again≈øt tho≈øe that doe take paines, and thence after ≈øpringeth per≈øecution. La≈øtly, their Intere≈øt is concerned in it, in poynt of power, for they finde that neither ≈øuch preaching Mini≈øters, nor their Auditors, are ≈øo plyable to yield blinde Canonicall obedience, as others are: and ≈øo it concernes them in poynt of power to ≈øtop their mouthes.

And now it mu≈øt needes follow by the rule of Contraries, that it mu≈øt be for their profit, honour, and power, to ≈øet open a docre to idle and unfit Mini≈øters. But there are two particulars which I will note, wherein it concernes them in their profits, to ≈øet the doore very
wide open, where there is no ≈øu≈øpition of refractorine≈ø≈øe: Fir≈øt, we know Bi≈øhops have many times Livings in Commendum and Pluralities: but there is hardly any, but they have impropriations, whereof they are to ≈øee the Cure di≈øcharged, and therefore it is for their profit, that there may be good ≈øtore of cheap Curates, which cannot be very fit and able men; and with ≈øuch ordinarily they furni≈øh the Cures of ≈øuch places whereof they have the Impropriations. (Sir) In the next place we know, that orders are not given, but in a manner ≈øold, for not onely the Bi≈øhop, and his Regi≈øter, but al≈øo his U≈øher, his Chamberlaine, his Butler, and Porter, and almo≈øt all his meniall ≈øervants mu≈øt have their fees, before the poore Clerke with his Boxe full of Orders can pa≈ø≈øe the Porters Lodge. I heare much of the legall Simony, which con≈øi≈øteth in the buying and ≈øelling of Benefices, but whether this doth not approach nearer to the Evangelicall Simony, which con≈øi≈øteth in the buying and ≈øelling of the gifts of the holy Gho≈øt; I offer it to your con≈øideration. Now (Sir) for Excommunication and Ab≈øolution, all ≈øeemes to be out of poynt, for Excommunication is neither in right hands, nor exerci≈øed upon right grounds and matters, nor in a right forme and manner, nor to right ends, and then it is no marvell if it have not right effects. (Sir) we know our Saviour hath lodged it in the Church (for ≈øo runs the precept) dic Eccle≈øiae: now (Sir) that one man ≈øhould bee a Church, ≈øounds ≈øtrangely in my eares. In the next place (I bo≈øeech you Sir) con≈øider about what their Spirituall Sword is exerci≈øed, about things no way lying under the ≈øtroke thereof; A man ≈øhall be excommunicated for a Pig, or for an Apple, and ≈øuch like things: I heard once a Gentleman of the Civill Law an≈øwer hereunto in this hou≈øe, that the Excommunication was not for the thing, but for the contempt, and the le≈ø≈øe the thing was, that was commanded,
the greater was the contempt: If this were ≈øo, ≈øure the greater is the cruelty, to lay command upon ≈øo ≈ømall a matter, that draweth after it ≈øo deepe a cen≈øure, as to ca≈øt a man downe into Hell. Suppo≈øe a Magi≈øtrate ≈øhould command ≈øome triviall matter, ≈øome ceremony or other, under pain of trea≈øon, and ≈øhould proceed again≈øt the Infringers of his command as Traytors, it were much to be doubted, whether the command did not partake more of cruelty, than the di≈øobedience of contempt; for when authority ≈øhall ≈øo farre lo≈øe it ≈øelfe, as to lay ≈øo great a weight upon ≈øo ≈ømall a matter, it rend reth it ≈øelfe contemptible, and then it is no marvaile (I had almo≈øt ≈øayd) it is no fault, if it bee contemned, having made it ≈øelfe contemptible. Then Sir, for the forme of proceeding, it is no whit ≈øpirituall, there is no fa≈øting and prayer, no ≈øeeking to reclaime the ≈øinner, but rather it is after the fa≈øhion of a ≈øummary Proce≈ø≈øe in a civill Court, nay, Sir, it is accompanyed ≈øometimes with an intimation that no man ≈øhall buy or ≈øell with the per≈øon excommunicated, nor ≈øet him a worke, nor doe any civill or naturall offices unto him. As wee had a complaint brought in this Parliament, of a Sonne that was excommunicated onely for repeating a Sermon to his father, being an excommunicate per≈øon. Now Sir, for the ends for which this cen≈øure is executed, they are ordinarily to fetch in fees, or at the be≈øt to bring men under Canonicall obedience, which is the Ordinaries will and plea≈øure, and I have ≈øometimes ≈øeene a Mini≈øter pronounce an Excommunication, which he held in one hand, and pre≈øently after the ab≈øolution which he held in the other, ≈øo the end of the excommunication was the ab≈øolution, and the end of that was fees: (Sir) for the honour of God, for the honour of our nationall Church, and for the honour of the Chri≈øtian Religion, let the high and great cen≈øure of the Church no longer lackey after fees, let not
Chri≈øtians any longer be ea≈øt to Sathan, in the name of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, for the non payment of a groat. And now Sir, we may imagine what effects are like to follow upon ≈øuch premi≈øes, the great and dreadfull cen≈øure of Excommunication is thereby made contemptible, and were it not for the civill re≈øtraints, and penalties that follow upon it, no man would purcha≈øe an ab≈øolution, though he may have it for a halfe-peny. And I have heard of ≈øome that have thanked the Ordinaries for abating or remitting the fees of the Courts: but I never heard of any that thanked them, for reclaiming their ≈øoules to repentance, by their Excommunications; (Sir) for ab≈øolution, it is relative to excommunication, and ≈øo labours of the ≈øame di≈øea≈øes: onely one thing I ≈øhall particularly note concerning ab≈øolution, (Sir) it is called commutation of penance, but indeed it is a de≈øtruction of the Ordinance, making it voyd, and of none effect, and ≈øurely God never ≈øet his Mini≈øters to ≈øell indulgences in his Church. The oath that is to precede ab≈øolution, de parendo juri eccle≈øia, & ≈øtando, &c. hath already beene ≈øufficiently ≈øpoken unto, in the debate about the Canons, and therefore there will bee no need of ≈øpeaking more to that. Now Sir, I am come to my la≈øt head, wherein I ≈øhall be very briefe; and that is concerning the evills that ari≈øe out of the benefices and dignities of the Clergy, the common cau≈øe being from the inequality of the di≈øtribution of them, much re≈øembling a di≈øea≈øe very ordinary at this time among≈øt Children, which they call the Rickets, wherein the nouri≈øhment goeth all to the upper parts, which are over-great and mon≈øtrous, and the lower parts pine away: and ≈øo it is in the Clergy, ≈øome are ≈øo poore, that they cannot attend their Mini≈øtery, but are faine to keepe ≈øchooles, nay, Ale-hou≈øes ≈øome of them; and ≈øome others are ≈øo ≈øtately, they will not attend their Mini≈øtery, and ≈øo between them the flock ≈øtarves: but
our evills have more e≈øpecially proceeded from the exce≈ø≈øive worldly wealth, and dignities of one part of the Clergie, I meane ≈øuch as either are in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, or in hopes of Bi≈øhopricks, for the≈øe great places of profit and honour, fir≈øt, have beene the baites of ambition, and then they became the apples of contention, and la≈øt of all, the ≈øeeds of ≈øuper≈øtition, the one being a ≈øtep and degree unto the other, and all of them leading in the end to the corruption, (that I may not ≈øay ≈øubver≈øion) of our Religion. Sir, they are fir≈øt the baites of ambition, and I know not by what ≈øecret cau≈øe, but experience ≈øheweth us, that when Clergy men have once ta≈øted the ≈øweet of worldly wealth and honours, they are more eager and ambitious after them than any other ≈øort of men; here upon other godly Mini≈øters, that live more according to the ≈øimplicity of the Go≈øpell, and the example of Chri≈øt and his Apo≈øtles, cannot but beare witne≈ø≈øe again≈øt their wordly pomp and dignities, and ≈øo the fire of contention breaketh forth. And truely (Sir) the ≈øtate of the Clergy is very like to fire, which whil≈øt it keeps in the Chimney, it is of excellent u≈øe to warme tho≈øe that approach unto it, but if it once breake out into the hou≈øe, and get upon the hou≈øe top, it ≈øets all on fire: ≈øo whil≈øt the Clergy keepe them≈øelves within the pulpit, they are of great u≈øe to ≈øtirre up the zeale and devotion of Chri≈øtians, but if they once flye out into the hou≈øe, if they begin to meddle with Civill places and juri≈ødictions, and e≈øpecially if they once get up to the Coun≈øell-table, it is ≈øeldome ≈øeene, but that at length they ≈øet all on fire; and what is it that maketh the fire to breake out of the chimney, but too much fuell? if there be but a moderate proportion of fuell, the fire keepes it ≈øelfe within its bounds, but if you heape faggot upon faggot, a whole Cart load together, then it breaketh out: (So Sir) if there bee a competent maintenance for the Mini≈øtery, they will
keep them≈øelves within their bounds, but if Living be heaped upon Living, and Temporalities added to Spiritualities, the flame will ≈øoone breake out, and ≈øet the hou≈øe on fire. (Sir) I doe not envy the wealth or greatne≈ø≈øe of the Clergy, but I am very confident, if tho≈øe were le≈ø≈øe, they would be better, and doe more ≈øervice to Chri≈øt and his Church; and I am very clear in mine owne heart, that the livings of the Clergy being more equally di≈øtributed, the ≈øervice of God would be ≈øo farre from receiving any prejudice, that it would bee much advanced, and withall a good proportion of revenue might returne againe to the Crowne, from whence it was fir≈øt derived. (Sir) Bi≈øhopricks, Deanries, and Chapiters, are like to great wa≈øters in a Wood, they make no proofe them≈øelves, they cumber the ground whereon they ≈øtand, and with their great Armes and Boughes ≈øtreiched forth on every ≈øide, partly by their ≈øhade, and partly by their ≈øowre droppings, they hinder all the young wood under them from growing and thriving. To ≈øpeake plaine Engli≈øh, the≈øe Bi≈øhops, Deanes, and Chapiters, doe little good them≈øelves by preaching, or otherwi≈øe; and if they were felled, a great deale of good timber might be cut out of them, for the u≈øes of the Church, and Kingdome at this time. A fre≈øh ≈øtoole of three or foure able Mini≈øters might ≈øpring up in their ≈øtead to very good purpo≈øe in the≈øe great Townes, which are Ordinarily the Seats of tho≈øe Epi≈øcopall, and Collegiate Churches, and the private Congregations of divers Parochiall Churches might thrive and grow better, which now have the Sunne of Gods Word, I meane the cleare and ≈øpirituall preaching thereof kept from them, and live in the dangerous ≈øhade of ignorance, by rea≈øon that all the meanes is taken from them, and appropriated unto Bi≈øhops, or to Deanries, and Chaptiers, and other ≈øuch Collegiate Churches. Be≈øides, ≈øuch as doe begin to grow and ≈øtart up through the voluntary pains
of ≈øome among≈øt them, or‚ñ™ by ≈øuch preaching as they them≈øelves have procured by their voluntary contributions, ≈øhould not ≈øtill bee dropped on as they are from the armes and appendances of tho≈øe great wa≈øters, and kept downe continually by their bitter per≈øecutions. That which remaines now, is to ≈øhew how the≈øe great Revenues and Dignities, become the ≈øeedes of ≈øuper≈øtition, and that is this: The Clergy in the maintenance of their greatne≈ø≈øe, which they are neither willing to forgoe, nor yet well able to maintaine upon the principles of the Reformed Religion, finding that the popi≈øh principles, whereon the Bi≈øhop of Rome built his greatne≈ø≈øe, to ≈øuit well unto their ends, that maketh them to ≈øide with that party, and that mu≈øt needs bring in ≈øuper≈øtition: and as ambition allureth on the one ≈øide, ≈øo the principles they goe by, draw them on farther and farther, and happily at length farther than they them≈øelves at fir≈øt intended. Whether a reconciliation with Rome, were imagined or no by ≈øome I leave it to every one to judge within him≈øelfe: But ≈øure I am, if an accommodation could have beene made in ≈øome fa≈øhion or other, with the Church of Rome, the Clergy might againe be capable of forraigne preferments, and Cardinals Caps, and this is no ≈ømall temptation. Now Sir, I am at an end, onely I ≈øhall draw out three conclu≈øions, which I conceive may clearely be collected out of what I have ≈øaid. Fir≈øt, that civill juri≈ødiction in the per≈øons of Clergy-men, together with their great Revenues, and high places of dignity, is one great cau≈øe of the evills which we ≈øuffer in matter of Religion. Secondly, that the ≈øole and arbitrary power of Bi≈øhops in the ordaining and detriving of Ministers, and in Excommunication, and ab≈øolution, is another great cau≈øe of the evills we ≈øuffer in matter of Religion. Thirdly, the ≈øtrict urging of Sub≈øcription, and Conformity to the Ceremonies, and Canons of the Church is another great cau≈øe of evill, which wee ≈øuffer in matter of Religion.

And now my humble motion is, that we ≈øhould take a piece onely of this ≈øubject into our con≈øideration, but the whole matter, and that not onely that part of the Mini≈øters Remon≈øtrance, which hath beene read, ≈øhould be referred to the Committee which you are about to name, but Londons Petition al≈øo, and all other Petitions of the like nature, ≈øo ≈øoone as they ≈øhall bee read in the hou≈øe, and that the Committee may collect out of them all ≈øuch heads as are fit for the con≈øideration of this hou≈øe, and ≈øurely that is fit to bee con≈øidered, that happily will not be thought fit to be altered: con≈øideration is one thing, and alteration another: where there is a mixture of bad and good together, the whole mu≈øt bee con≈øidered, that we may know how to ≈øever the good from the bad, and ≈øo retaine the one, and reject the other, which is all that I de≈øire. And if any thing have fallen from me more incon≈øiderate (as in ≈øo long a di≈øcour≈øe many things may have done) I humbly crave the pardon of the hou≈øe, prote≈øting that I have ≈øpoken nothing but with a minde which is ready to ≈øacrifice the body it dwelleth in, to the peace and ≈øafety of his Maje≈øties Kingdomes, and the ≈øafety and honour of his Maje≈øty in the Government of them.

div.head: A Speech made before the Lords in the Upper Hou≈øe; by Mr. Francis Rous E≈øquire; March the 16th. 1640.
Again≈øt Dr. Co≈ø≈øens, Dr. Maynwaring, and Dr. Beale.
div.p: I AM commanded by the Hou≈øe of Commons to pre≈øent to your Lord≈øhips a Declaration and Impeachment again≈øt Dr. Co≈ø≈øens, and others, upon the complaint of Mr. Peter Smart; which Mr. Smart was a Proto-Martyr, or, fir≈øt Confe≈ø≈øor of note in the late dayes of per≈øecution. The whole matter is a Tree, whereof the branches and fruit are manife≈øt in the Articles of this declaration; which being read, I ≈øhall with your Lord≈øhips favour di≈øcover and lay open the root.

p.hi: The Declaration was read, and then He proceeded thus:

div.p: I AM now to di≈øcover the root of Mr. Smarts Per≈øecution.

Your Lord≈øhips have heard of a great De≈øigne to bring in Popery; you have heard of Armies of Souldiers, and particularly of the Popi≈øh Iri≈øh Armie, the burthen and Complaint of the Commons. But there is another Army not ≈øo much ≈øpoken of, and that is an Army of Prie≈øts: for ≈øince Altars came in (≈øo they delight to be called,) it is a ≈øaying of Gregory the Great, that when Antichri≈øt comes, Preparatus est exercitus Sacerdotum: There is an Armie of Priests ready to receive him: this is fulfilled in our time; for certainty this Army of Prie≈øts doth many wayes advance the de≈øigne and plot of Popery. A fir≈øt is by the ≈øubver≈øion of our Lawes, and Government: our Lawes and Popery cannot ≈øtand together; but either Popery mu≈øt overthrow our Lawes, or our Lawes mu≈øt over throw Popery: but to overthrow our Lawes they mu≈øt overthrow Parliaments; and to overthrow Parliaments, they mu≈øt overthrow property; thy mu≈øt bring the Subjects goods to be arbitrarily di≈øpo≈øed that ≈øo there may bee no need of Parliament; this hath bind done by Dr. Maynwaring, (whom we finde wanting yet not in the ≈øeats, but in the Bar of the Lords hou≈øe) and the like by Dr. Beale: and I think it was the intention of the late Canons.

A ≈øecond way, by which this Army of Prie≈øts advanceth the Popi≈øh De≈øigne, is the way of Treatie. This hath bind acted both by writings & conference: Sancta Clara him≈øelfe ≈øaith, Doct ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øimi eorum quibu≈øounque egi; ≈øo it ≈øeems they have had conferences together. And Sancta Clara on his part, labours to bring the Articles of our Church to Popery; and ≈øome of our ≈øide ≈øtrive to meete him in that way: we have a te≈øtimony that the great
Arch-Priest him≈øelfe hath ≈øaid; It were no hard matter to make a reconciliation, if a wi≈øe man had the handling of it. But I verily beleeve, that as the ≈øtate of Papacie ≈øtands, a farre wi≈øe man than bee cannot reconcile Us, without the lo≈ø≈øe of our Religion. For the Pope being fa≈øtned to his Errors, even by his Chaire of Inerrability, hee ≈øits ≈øtill unmoved, and ≈øo wee cannot meete, except we come wholly to him. A man ≈øtanding in a Boat tyed to a Rocke, when he drawes the Rope, doth not draw the Rocke to the Boat, but the Boat to the Rock. And Sancta Clara doth (in this ≈øomewhat hone≈øtly) confe≈ø≈øe it: for he ≈øaith he dealt in this way of Treatie, not to draw the Church to the Prote≈øtants; but the Prote≈øtants to the Church.

A third way is a way of violence, this violence they exerci≈øe partly by Secular Armes, and partly by Prie≈øtly Armes, which they call Spirituall: for Secular Armes we have their owne confe≈ø≈øion, that the late warre was Bellum Epi≈øcopale; and we have the Papi≈øts confe≈ø≈øion, that it was Bellum Papale; for in their motives, they ≈øay, That the warre concernes them not onely as ≈øubjects, but as Catholikes, for ≈øo they fal≈øely call them≈øelves: and if it be ≈øo, then Bellum Epi≈øcopale, is al≈øo Bellum Papale: in the Epi≈øcopall Warre, the Papall cau≈øe is advanced: For the Spirituall Armes, thus they come to execution.

When a great Man is comming, his Sumpters, his Furniture, his Provi≈øions goe before: the Popes Furniture, Altars and Copes, Pictures and Images are come before; (and if wee beleeve Dr. Co≈ø≈øens) the very ≈øub≈øtance of the Ma≈ø≈øe; a certaine ≈øigne that the Pope was not farre off. Now the≈øe fore-tunners being come, if any man re≈øi≈øt them, Fire comes out of the Brambles, and devoures the Cedars of Lebanon; the Army of the Prie≈øts falls upon him with their Armes of Su≈øpen≈øion, Seque≈øtration, Excommunication,
Degradation, and Deprivation. And by the≈øe Armes hath Mr. Smart beene oppre≈ø≈øed and undone. Hee falls upon their Super≈øtitions, and Innovations, and they fall upon him with their Armes, they beate him down, yea they pull him up by the rootes, taking away all his meanes of maintenance and living; yet they leave him life to feele his mi≈øeries; Ita feriunt, ut diu ≈øe ≈øentiat mori; there is no cruelty to Prie≈øty cruelty; the≈øe are they that did put our very Saviour to death: the Calling is Reverend, but the Corruption of it mo≈øt pernicious; Corruptio optimi pe≈øsima: I know no rea≈øon of this change, except it be that of the Apo≈øtle: Becau≈øe when they knew God, they did not wor≈øhip him as God, but made a God of the World, placing the excellency of Priesthood in worldly pompe and greatne≈ø≈øe, and gave the glory of the invi≈øible God, to Pictures, Images, and Altars: therefore God gave them up to vile affections, to be implacable, unmercifull, and without naturall affection. But what≈øoever the cau≈øe is of their Corruption; certainly their Armes have fallen heavily upon Mr. Smart, and Prie≈øtly cruelty hath ca≈øt him into a long mi≈øery, from which he could get no relea≈øe by any Prie≈øtly mercy.

And now it is prayed, that as the≈øe Delinquents by the cruell oppre≈øsions of Mr. Smart have advanced the Cau≈øe of Popery, ≈øo they may in ≈øuch a degree of Iustice bee puni≈øhed, that in them Prie≈øtly cruelty, and the very cau≈øe of Popery may appeare to be puni≈øhed and ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, and that Mr. Smart ≈øuffering for the Cau≈øe of Prote≈øtancy may bee ≈øo repaired, that in him pious Con≈øtancy, and the very Cau≈øe of Prote≈øtancy may appeare to be righted and repaired.

div.head: A ≈øecond Speech of the Honorable NATHANAEL FIENNES (≈øecond Son to the right Honourable the Lord Say) touching the Subjects Liberty again≈øt the late Canons and the new Oath.
div.p: NOW that we are about to brand the≈øe Canons in re≈øpect of the matter contained in them, it is the proper time to open the foulene≈ø≈øe thereof: and though much of this hath beene anticipated in the generall debate, yet if any thing hath beene omitted, or if any thing may bee farther cleared in that kinde, it is for the ≈øervice of the Hou≈øe, that it ≈øhould now be done.

Sir I conceive the≈øe Canons doe containe ≈øundry matters, which are not onely contrary to the Lawes of this Land, but al≈øo de≈øtructive of the very principall and fundamentall Lawes of this Kingdome. I ≈øhall begin with the fir≈øt Canon, wherein the framers of the≈øe Canons have a≈ø≈øumed unto them≈øelves a Parliamentary
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
power, and that too in a very high degree, for they have taken upon them to define what is the power of the King, what the liberty of the Subjects, and what propriety hee hath in his goods. If this bee not proper to a Parliament, I know not what is. Nay it is the highe≈øt matter that can fall under the con≈øideration of a Parliament, and ≈øuch a poynt as wherein they would have walked with more tenderne≈ø≈øe and circum≈øpection than the≈øe bold Divines have done. And ≈øurely, as this was an act of ≈øuch pre≈øumption as no age can parallell: ≈øo is it of ≈øuch dangerous con≈øequence as nothing can be more. For they doe not onely take upon them to determine matters of this nature, but al≈øo under great penalties, forbid all Par≈øons, Vicars, Curates, Readers in Divinity, &c. to ≈øpeake any other wayes of them then as they had defined, by which meanes having ≈øeized upon all the Conduites, whereby knowledge is convayed to the people, how ea≈øie would it bee for them in time, to undermine the Kings Prerogative, and to ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe the ≈øubjects liberty, or both.

And now (Sir) I be≈øeech you to con≈øider how they have defined this high and great poynt: they have dealt with us in matter of Divinity, as the Judges had done before in matter of Law: they fir≈øt tooke upon them to determine a matter that belonged not to their Judicature, but onely to the Parliament, and after by their judgement they overthrew our propriety, and ju≈øt ≈øo have the≈øe Divines dealt with us: they tell us that Kings are an Ordinance of God, of Divine Right, and founded in the prime Lawes of Nature, from whence it will follow that all other formes of government, as Ari≈øtocracies, and Democracies, are wicked formes of government, contrary to the Ordinance of God, and the Prime Lawes of Nature, which is ≈øuch new Divinitie as
never read in any Booke, but in this new Booke of Canons.

Mr. Speaker, We all know that Kings, and States, and Iudges, and all Magi≈øtrates are the Ordinances of God, but (Sir) give mee leave to ≈øay they were the Ordinances of men, before they were the Ordinances of God. I know I am upon a great and high poynt, but I ≈øpeake by as great and as high a warrant, if St. Peters chaire cannot erre (as St. Peters Epi≈øtles cannot) thus he teacheth us, Submit your ≈øelfe to-every Ordinance of man for the Lords ≈øake, whether it bee to the King as ≈øupreame, or to the Governour, as to him that is ≈øent by him, &c.

(Sir) It is worthy noting, that they are Ordinances of men, but that they are to be ≈øubmitted unto for the Lords ≈øake, and truely their power is as ju≈øt, and their ≈øubjects allegeance as due unto them, though we ≈øuppo≈øe them to bee fir≈øt ordinances of men, and then confirmed, and e≈øtabli≈øhed by Gods Ordinance, as if wee ≈øuppo≈øe them to bee immediate Ordinances of God, and ≈øo received by men. But there was ≈øomewhat in it, that the≈øe Divines aimed at, I ≈øuppo≈øe it was this. If Kings were of Divine Right, as the Office of a Pa≈øtor in the Church, or founded in the prime Lawes of Nature, as the power of a Father in a Family; then it would certainly follow, that they ≈øhould receive the fa≈øhion and manner of their government, onely from the Pre≈øcript of Gods Word, or of the Lawes of Nature, and con≈øequently, if there bee no Text, neither of the Old nor New Testament, nor yet any Law of Nature, that Kings may not make Lawes without Parliaments, they may make Lawes without Parliaments, and if neither in the Scripture, nor in the Law of Nature, Kings be forbidden to lay taxes or any kind of impo≈øitions upon their people without con≈øent in Parliament, they may doe it out of Parliament:
and that this was their meaning, they expre≈ø≈øe it after in plaine termes, for they ≈øay that Sub≈øidies and taxes, and all manner of ayds are due unto Kings by the Law of God, and of Nature. (Sir) if they bee due by the Law of God and of Nature, they are due, though there be no act of Parliament for them: nay (Sir) if they bee due by ≈øuch a right, a hundred acts of Parliaments cannot take them away, or make them undue. And (Sir) that they meant it of Sub≈øidies and aids taken without con≈øent in Parliament, is clearely that addition that they ≈øubjoyne unto it, that this doth not take away from the Subject the propriety hee hath in his goods, for had they ≈øpoken of Sub≈øidies and aydes given by con≈øent in Parliament, this would have been a very ridiculous addition, for who ever made any que≈øtion, whether the giving Sub≈øidies in Parliament did take away from the Subject the propriety hee hath in his goods, when as it doth evidently imply they have a propriety in their goods? for they could not give unle≈ø≈øe they had ≈øomething to give: but becau≈øe that was alledged as a chiefe rea≈øon again≈øt Ship-mens, and other ≈øuch illegall payments levied upon the people, without their con≈øent in Parliament, that it did deprive them of their right of propriety, which they have in their goods, the≈øe Divines would ≈øeem to make ≈øome an≈øwer thereunto, but in truth their an≈øwer is nothing el≈øe but the bare a≈ø≈øertion of a contradiction, and it is an ea≈øie thing to ≈øay a contradiction, but impo≈ø≈øible to reconcile it; for certainely if it bee a true rule (as it is mo≈øt true) quod meum e≈øt ≈øine con≈øen≈øu meo, non pote≈øt fieri alienum; to take my goods without my con≈øent mu≈øt needes de≈øtroy my propriety. Another thing in this fir≈øt Canon, wherein they have a≈ø≈øumed unto them≈øelves a Parliamentarie power, is in that they take upon them to define what is Trea≈øon, be≈øides what is determined in the ≈øtatute of Trea≈øons.
They ≈øay, to ≈øet up any coactive independent power is trea≈øonable both again≈øt God and the King, the que≈øtion is not whether it bee true they ≈øay or no, but whether they have power to ≈øay what is Trea≈øon, and what not? But now (Sir) that I am upon this point, I would gladly know what kinde of power that is, which is exerci≈øed by Arch-Bi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, Deanes, Arch-Deacons, &c. Coactive certainely it is, all the Kingdome feeles the la≈øh thereof, and it mu≈øt needs bee independant, if it be jure Divine, as they hold it, for they doe not meane by an independant power, ≈øuch a power as doth not depend on GOD. Be≈øides, if their power be dependant, of whom is it dependant? not of the King, for the Law acknowledgeth no way whereby Eccle≈øia≈øticall juri≈ødiction can bee derived from his Maje≈øtie, but by his Commi≈ø≈øion under the great-Scale, which as I am informed, they have not: I ≈øpeake not of the High Commi≈ø≈øion, but of that juri≈ødiction which they exerci≈øe in their Archiepi≈øcopall, Epi≈øcopall, Archidaconall Courts, &c. and therefore if their owne ≈øentence bee ju≈øt, wee know what they are, and what they have pronounced again≈øt them≈øelves. But (Sir) it were worth knowing what they aimed at in that independent coactive power, which they terme popular. I will not take upon me to unfold their meaning; but wee know Doctor Beale had a hand in the making of the≈øe Canons, and if wee apply his Paraphra≈øe to the Text, it may give us ≈øome clearene≈ø≈øe. I remember among≈øt other notes of his this was one, that he did acknowledge the Kings Supremacy, but would joyne unto him an a≈ø≈øi≈øtant (viz.) the people, meaning this Hou≈øe, which being the repre≈øentative body of the COMMONS of England, and claiming, as it is ≈øo, a ≈øhare in the Legi≈ølative power, Doctor Beale calleth this a joyning of an a≈ø≈øi≈øtant to the King, in whom ≈øoly hee placeth the power of making Lawes, and that it
is but of grace, that he a≈ø≈øumeth either the Lords, or Commons for the making of Lawes with him. Now (Sir) the Legi≈ølative power is the greate≈øt power, and therefore coactive, and it is the highe≈øt power, and therefore independent, and if every E≈øtate for the proportion it hath therein, ≈øhould not have ≈øuch a power, it ≈øhould not have it of right, as founded in the Fabricke and frame of the policy and government, but of Grace, or by Commi≈ø≈øion, as Dr. Beale affirmeth. I have done with the fir≈øt Canon, onely I ≈øhall adde this, that con≈øidering the principles and po≈øitions that are laid downe therein, and comparing them with a clau≈øe towards the end of the Canon, that in no ca≈øe imaginable it is lawfull for ≈øubjects to defend them≈øelves, we may judge how farre forth the≈øe Canons were to prepare mens mindes for the force that was to follow after; if the accu≈øation again≈øt my Lord of Strafford bee layed aright. For the matter it ≈øelfe, I hope there will never be any need to di≈øpute that que≈øtion, and I doe beleeve they had as little need, to have publi≈øhed that po≈øition, had it not beene upon de≈øigne. As for the ≈øecond Canon, therein al≈øo they have a≈ø≈øumed to them≈øelves a Parliamentary power, in taking upon them, to appoynt Holidayes, whereas the ≈øtatute ≈øaith in expre≈ø≈øe words, that ≈øuch dayes ≈øhall bee onely kept as Holy-dayes as are named in the Statute, and no other, and therefore though the thing may be bonum, yet it was not done bene, becau≈øe not ordained by Parliament, notwith≈øtanding what hath beene alledged to the contrary: it ≈øeemeth to mee to bee the appoynting of an Holy-day, to ≈øet a time a part for Divine ≈øervice, and to force menunder penalties to leave their labours, and bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, and to be pre≈øent at it. And of the ≈øame nature is that other clau≈øe, in the ≈øame Canon, wherein they take upon them without Parliament, to lay a charge upon the people, enjoyning two Bookes at lea≈øt for that
day, to be bought at the charge of the pari≈øh, for by the ≈øame right, that they may lay a penny on the Pari≈øh without Parliament, they may lay a pound or any greater ≈øumme.

As to the third Canon, I ≈øhall pa≈ø≈øe it over, onely the ob≈øervation that my neighbour of the long Robe made upon it, ≈øeemes unto me ≈øo good, as that it is worth the repeating, that whereas in the Canon again≈øt Sectaries there is an e≈øpeciall provi≈øo, that it ≈øhall not derogate from any Statute, or Law made again≈øt them (as if their Canons had any power to di≈øanull an act of Parliament) there is no ≈øuch provi≈øo in this Canon again≈øt Papi≈øts, from whence it may bee probably conjectured, that they might have drawne ≈øome colour of exemption from the penall Lawes e≈øtabli≈øhed again≈øt them from this Canon, becau≈øe it might ≈øeeme hard that they ≈øhould be doubly puni≈øhed for the ≈øame thing, as wee know in the poynt of ab≈øence from the Church; the Law provideth, that if any man be fir≈øt puni≈øhed by the Ordinary, he ≈øhall not be puni≈øhed againe by the Iu≈øtices.

For the fourth Canon again≈øt Sociniani≈øme, therein al≈øo the≈øe Canon-makers have a≈ø≈øumed to them≈øelves, a Parliament power, in determining an Here≈øie not determined by Law, which is expre≈ø≈øely re≈øerved to the determination of a Parliament. It is true, they ≈øay it is a complication of many here≈øies, condemned in the four fir≈øt Councells, but they doe not ≈øay what tho≈øe Here≈øies are, and it is not po≈øsible that Sociniani≈øme ≈øhould bee formally cond ‚Ä¢ mned in the≈øe Councells, for it is ≈øprung up but of late: Therefore they have taken upon them, to determine and damne a Here≈øie, and that ≈øo generally, as that it may bee of very dangerous con≈øequence, for condemning Sociniani≈øme for an here≈øie, and not declaring what is Sociniani≈øme, it is left in their brea≈øts whom they will judge and call a Socinian. I would not
have any thing that I have ≈øaid to be interpreted, as if I had ≈øpoken it in favour of Sociniani≈øme, wc (if it be ≈øuch as I apprehend it to be) is indeed a mo≈øt vile and damnable here≈øie, and therefore the framers of the≈øe Canons, are the more to blame in the next Canon again≈øt Sectaries, wherein be≈øides that in the preamble thereof, they lay it downe for a certaine ground, which the holy Synod knew full well, that other Sects (which they extend not onely to Browni≈øts and Separati≈øts, but al≈øo to all per≈øons, that for the ≈øpace of a month, doe ab≈øent them≈øelves without a rea≈øonable cau≈øe, from their owne pari≈øh Churches) doe equally endeavour the ≈øubver≈øion of the Di≈øcipline, and Doctrine of the Church of England with the Papi≈øts, although the wor≈øt of them doe not beare any proportion, in that re≈øpect to the Papi≈øts, I ≈øay be≈øides that they make them equall in crime and puni≈øhment to the Papi≈øts, notwith≈øtanding the great di≈øproportion of their Tenents: there is another pa≈ø≈øage in this Canon relative to that again≈øt Sociniani≈øme, which I ≈øhall e≈øpecially offer to your con≈øideration, and that is this. If a Gentleman comming from beyond Seas ≈øhould happen to bring over with him a Booke contrary to the Di≈øcipline of the Church of England, or ≈øhould give ≈øuch a Booke to his friend, nay if any man ≈øhould abett, or maintaine an opinion contrary thereunto, though it were but in Parliament, if hee thought it fit to be altered, by this Canon he is excommunicated ip≈øo facto, and lyeth under the ≈øame con≈øideration, and is lyable to the ≈øame puni≈øhment; as if he had maintained an opinion again≈øt the Deity of Chri≈øt, and of the Holy Gho≈øt, and of our Iu≈øtification by the ≈øatisfaction of Chri≈øt.

(Sir) if in things that are in their owne Nature indifferent, if in things di≈øputable it ≈øhall bee as hainous to abett or maintaine an opinion, as in the mo≈øt horrible and mon≈øtrous herefies, that can be imagined, what liberty is left to us as Chri≈øtians? What liberty is left
to us as men? I proceed to the ≈øixt Canon, wherein the≈øe Canoni≈øts have a≈øumed to then ≈øelves a Parliamentary power, and that in a very high degree, in that they have taken upon them to impo≈øe new Oathes upon the Kings Subjects. (Sir) under favour, of what hath beene alleaged to the contrary, to impo≈øe an Oath, if it be not an higher power, then to make a Law, it is a power of making a Law of mo≈øt high Nature, and of higher and farther con≈øequence then any other Law, and I ≈øhould much rather chu≈øe that the Convocation ≈øhould have a power to make Lawes, to binde my per≈øon and my e≈øtate, then that they ≈øhould have a power to make Oathes to binde my Con≈øcience: a Law bindes me no longer than till another Law bee made to alter it, but my Oath bindes mee as long as I live.

Againe, a Law bindes me either to obedience, or to undergoe the penalty inflicted by the Law, but my Oath bindes mee ab≈øolutely to obedience. And la≈øtly, a Law bindes me no longer than I am in the Land, or at the farthe≈øt no longer than I am a member of the State; wherein and whereby the Law is made, but my Oath once being taken doth binde mee in all places, and in all conditions ≈øo long as I live. Thus much I thought good to ≈øpeake, concerning the power of impo≈øing new Oathes: as to the matter of this new Oath, it is wholly illegall. Jt is again≈øt the Law of this Land, it is again≈øt the Law and light of Nature, it is again≈øt the Law of God, it is again≈øt the Lawes of this Kingdome; and that no ob≈øcure Lawes, nor concerning any meane or petty matters. It is again≈øt the Law of the Kings Supremacy, in that it maketh Arch-bi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, Deanes, Arch-Deacons, &c. to bee jure Divino, whereas the Law of this Land hath annexed to the Imperiall Crowne of this Realme, not onely all Eccle≈øia≈øticall Iuri≈ødiction, but al≈øo all ≈øuperioritie over the Eccle≈øia≈øticall State, and
it is to bee derived from him by C ‚Ä¢ mmi≈øsion under the Great Seale, and con≈øequently it is Jure humano. Again, it is again≈øt the Oath of Supremacy, e≈øtabli≈øhed by Law poynt blanke, for therein I am ≈øworne not onely to con≈øent unto, but al≈øo to a≈ø≈øi≈øt, and to the uttermo≈øt of my power, to defend all Iuri≈ødictions, Preheminences, &c. anne
‚Ä¢ ed to the Imperiall Crowne of this Realme, of which this is one, (and that which immediately precedeth this Oath in the Statute, and whereunto it doth e≈øpecially relate) That his Maje≈øty may exerci≈øe any Iuri≈ødictions, or Eccle≈øia≈øticall Government by his Commi≈øsion under the great Seale directed to ≈øuch per≈øons, as he ≈øhall thin „Äà‚óä„Äâ meet, ≈øo that if he ≈øhall thinke other per≈øons more meet, then Arch-bi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, &c. I am ≈øworne in the Oath of Supremacy not onely to a≈ø≈øent thereunto, but to a≈ø≈øi≈øt, and to the uttermo≈øt of my power to defend ≈øuch an appoyntment of his Maje≈øty, and in this new Oath I ≈øhall ≈øwear never to con≈øent unto ≈øuch an alteration.

In the like manner it is again≈øt the Law and Light of Nature, that a man ≈øhould ≈øweare to an≈øwer (&c.) to he knowes not what. It is again≈øt the Law and light of Nature, that a man ≈øhould ≈øweare never to con≈øent, to alter a thing that in its owne nature is alterable, and may prove inconvenient, and fit to bee altered. La≈øtly, it is again≈øt the Law of God: for whereas there are three rules pre≈øcribed to him that will ≈øweare aright, that he ≈øweare in Iudgement, in Truth, and righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe: hee that ≈øhall take this new Oath, mu≈øt needs breake all the≈øe three Rules. He cannot ≈øweare in Iudgement, becau≈øe this Oath is ≈øo full of ambiguities, that he cannot tell what he ≈øweares unto; not to ≈øpeak of the unextricable ambiguity of the &c. There is ≈øcarce one word that is not ambiguous in the principall parts of the Oath, as fir≈øt, What is meant by the Church of England, whether all the Chri≈øtians in England, or
wherher the Clergie onely, or onely the Arch-Bi≈øhop, Bi≈øhops, Deanes, &c. Or whether the Convocation, or what? In like manner it is as doubtfull what is meant by the Di≈øcipline, and what by the Dotirine of the Church of England, for what ≈øome call Super≈øtitions Innovations, if others affirme to be con≈øonant to the Primitive, and that the pure≈øt Reformation in the time of Edward the 6. and in the beginning of the Reigne of Queene Elizabeth: and ≈øo for the Doctrine of the Church of England; if all the Po≈øitions that of later yeares have beene challenged by ≈øome of Divines to bee Arminian and Popi≈øh, and contrary to the Articles of our Religion, and which on the other ≈øide have beene a≈ø≈øerted and maintained as con≈øonant to the Doctrine of our Church, and if the Articles of Religion were gathered together, they might make a pretty volume: Nay, Sancta Clara will maintaine it in de≈øpight of the Puritanes, that the Doctrine of the Church of Rome, is the Doctrine of the Church of England. Truely it were very fit that wee knew, what were the Doctrine and Di≈øcipline of the Church of England before we ≈øweare to it, and then (Sir) give me leave to ≈øay, that I ≈øhould be very loath to ≈øweare to the Di≈øcipline, or to the Doctrine and Tenents of the pure≈øt Church in the World, as they are collected by them, farther than they agree with the Holy Scriptures.

La≈øtly, it is as doubtfull what is meant, by the Doctrine and Di≈øcipline e≈øtabli≈øhed, and what by altering & con≈øenting to alter, whether that is accompted, or e≈øtabli≈øhed, which is e≈øtali≈øhed by a Act of ParliameÃÑt, or wether that al≈øo that is e≈øtabli≈øhed by Canons, Injunctions‚ñ™ &c. and whether it ≈øhall not extend to that which is publi≈øhed by our Divines with the allowance of authority & ≈øo for con≈øenting to alter whether it be only meant, that a man ≈øhall not bee active in altering, or whether it extend to any con≈øent, and ≈øo that a man ≈øhall not
≈øubmit to it, nor accept of it, being altered by the State.

More ambiguities might be ≈øhewne, but the≈øe are enough to make it cleare, that hee that ≈øhall t ‚Ä¢ k this Oath cannot ≈øweare in Iudgement. Nor can he ≈øweare in Truth, for it is full of untruths. It is not true, that Di≈øcipline is nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øalvation. It is not true, that Arch-Bi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, Deanes, Arch-Deacons, &c. are jure Divino, as they must needs bee, if the Law-mamakers ought of right to e≈øtabli≈øh them, as they are establi≈øhed: for the Law-makers are not bound as of right, to frame their Lawes to any other than the Lawes of God alone. Now whether Bi≈øh ‚Ä¢ ps be jure Divino, we know it is a di≈øpute among the Papi≈øts, and never did any Prote≈øtant hold it till of late yeares, but that Arch-bi≈øhops, Deanes, Arch-Deacons, &c. ≈øhould be jure Divino, I doe not know that ever any Chri≈øtian held it before, and yet he that taketh this Oath mu≈øt ≈øweare it. La≈øtly, as hee that taketh this Oath cannot ≈øweare in Iudgement nor in Truth, ≈øo neither can hee ≈øweare in Righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, for it is full of unrighteou≈øn ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øe, being indeed, as hath beene well opened, a Covenant in effect again≈øt the King and Kingdome; for if the whole State ≈øhould finde it nece≈ø≈øary to alter the Government by Arch-Bi≈øhops, Bi≈øhop, &c, a great part of the Kingdome, e≈øpecially of the Gentry (for not onely the Clergy, but all that take Degrees in the ∆≤niver≈øities are bound to take it) will be preingaged not to con≈øent to it, or admit of it. Againe it is a great wrong to tho≈øe that ≈øhall bee Parliament-men, that their freedome ≈øhall be taken away being bound up by an Oath, not to co ‚Ä¢ ≈øent to the altering of a thing, which it may befit and proper for a Parliament to alter. And ≈øuppo≈øe that for the pre≈øent it bee no hinderance to the ≈øervice of God, nor yet burden≈øome to the King and Kingdome, yet if it ≈øhould prove ≈øo hereafter, for
a man to bee bound by an Oath never to con≈øent to alter it, may bee a great wrong to God in his ≈øervice, and to the King and Kingdome in their peace and welfare, and therefore this Oath cannot be taken in Righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe. For the other Oath de parendo juri Eccli≈øiae, & ≈øtando mandatis Eccle≈øiae, though it make le≈ø≈øe noy≈øe than the other, yet it is not of le≈ø≈øe dangerous con≈øequence. If I remember well the Storie, this was the Oath that the Pope made King John to take, and when hee had ≈øworne ≈øtare mandatis Eccle≈øiae, the Pope commandid him to re≈øigne his Kingdome to him, and truely bee hee Gentle man or Nobleman, or what ever el≈øe, when hee hath once put his necke into this nou≈øe, his Ghostly Fathers may drag him whither they will, for they have the quantity and the quality of the penance in their owne brea≈øt, and if they ≈øhal enjoyne him to give any ≈øumme towards the building of a Church, or the adorning of a Chappell, he mu≈øt pay it; or if they ≈øhould enjoyne him any ≈øervile or ba≈øe action (as there are not wanting examples of that kinde in the time of Popery) they are ≈øworne ≈øtare mandatis Eccle≈øiae, and ≈øo cannot recede, but mu≈øt performe it. Nay, I dare not warrant any man from the rods of Henry the ≈øecond; or of Raymond of Tholouze; what hath beene done may bee done, I am ≈øure the power is the ≈øame. And that other Oath al≈øo (though more u≈øuall in practi≈øe, and more confirmed by the≈øe new Canons) which is admini≈øtred to Church-wardens, would bee looked into. For it is hardly po≈ø≈øible for them that take it not to be for≈øworne, being they ≈øweare to ≈øo many particulars, that they cannot minde, and to ≈øome that they cannot under≈øtand, as how many Church-wardens are there in England, that under≈øtand what Sociniani≈øme is, in ca≈øe they be ≈øworne, to pre≈øent the offenders again≈øt that Canon, which concernes that matter. I ≈øhall only adde a word or two concerning two Canons more, which ≈øeeme to be Canons of Reformation.

The fir≈øt is, concerning Excommunication, to bee pronounced onely by a Divine, wherein it is alledged for the framers of the≈øe Canons, that if they have not more Law on their ≈øides, yet they may ≈øeeme to have more rea≈øon. For my part, as in all other things, I thinke they have ≈øo mended the matter, that they have made it far wor≈øe, for before that which was found fault with was this, that a Lay-man did that which the grave Divine ≈øhould have done, and now the grave Divine mu≈øt doe what ever the Lay-man would have done, for the cogni≈øance of the cau≈øe, and the power of Iudic ‚Ä¢ ture is wholly in the Lay-man, onely the grave Divine is to be his ≈øervant, to execute his ≈øentences, and hath ≈øuch a kinde of managing the ≈øpiritual ≈øword allowed onely unto him as the Papi≈øts in ≈øome ca≈øes were wont to afford unto the civill Magistrate, in re≈øpect of the Temporal ‚Ä¢ ≈øword, ‚Ä¢ or as if the Civill ≈øword by an implicite Faith had been pinned to the Lawn-≈øleeves, they condemned men of Here≈øie, and then delivered them over to the Secular power: but what to doe? Not to have any cogni≈øance of the cau≈øe, nor to exerci≈øe any power of judicature, but onely to be their executioners, and to burne the Heretick whom they had condemned, and ≈øo they judged men excommunicate, and then the Civill power was to ≈øend out Writs de excommunicato capiendo again≈øt them, but one ≈øaid well, that the ≈øword without cogni≈øance of the cau≈øe, and judgement, was like Polyphemus without his eye, it became violence and fury. But being accompanyed with the eye of judgement, it is equity and ju≈øtice: and ≈øurely where the Spirituall or Civill Governour is called upon to ≈øtrike, hee mu≈øt be allowed to ≈øee and judge whom and wherefore he ≈øtrikes, otherwi≈øe he will be able to give but an ill accompt to God, of the managing of the ≈øword wherewith he is in≈øtructed.

The other Canon is the la≈øt Canon again≈øt vexatious Citations, wherein they ≈øeeme to have ≈øome ≈øence of
the great grievances that poore people lye under; by occa≈øion of vexatious citations, and mole≈øtations in Eccle≈øiasticall Courts, and I verily believe, that there is not a greater oppre≈ø≈øion in the whole Kingdome upon the poorer ≈øort of people, then that which proceedeth out of the≈øe Courts. But now (Sir) let us ≈øee what provi≈øion they have made again≈øt it by this Canon. They ≈øay becau≈øe great grievances may fall upon people by citations upon pretence onely, of the breach of that Law without any pre≈øentment, or any other ju≈øt ground, that no citations grounded onely as afore≈øaid, ≈øhall i≈ø≈øue out, except it be under the hand and Seale of the Chancellour, Commi≈ø≈øarie, Arch-Deacon, or other competent Judge, ≈øo that (if there be any ≈øence in the≈øe words) though there be no pre≈øentment at all, nor any other ju≈øt ground, yet a citation may i≈ø≈øue out, ≈øo it be under the hand and Seale of the Chancellour, Commi≈ø≈øary, or other competent Judge, and the partie ≈øhall not be di≈øcharged without paying his fees, nor have any reliefe by this Canon. But ≈øuppo≈øe the Citation be not under the hand and Seale of any competent Iudge, and that there was neither pre≈øentment nor any ju≈øt ground for it, ≈øhall he then bee di≈ømi≈ø≈øed without paying any fees? No, unle≈ø≈øe fir≈øt contrary to the Law of Nature, there being no pre≈øentment, nor ju≈øt ground of accu≈øation again≈øt him, he ≈øhall by his Oath purge him≈øelfe of pretended breaches of Law, and then too hee ≈øhall onely have the fees of the Court remitted, but ≈øhall have no ≈øatisfaction for his trouble≈øome and chargeable journey, and for the lo≈ø≈øe of his time, and being drawne away from his affaires‚ñ™ Nay, le≈øt they ≈øhould ≈øeeme to have beene too liberall of their favour, they adde a provi≈øo in the clo≈øe of the Canon, that this grace of theirs ≈øhall not extend to any ‚Ä¢ rievous crime, as Schi≈øme, Incontinency, misbehavious in the Church, or ob≈øtinate inconformity. And what do
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
they call misbehaviour in the Church? If a man doe not kneele at the Confe≈ø≈øion, or have his hat on, when the Le≈ø≈øons are reading. In like manner what doe they call ob≈øtinate inconformity? If a man will not thinke what they would have him thinke, if a man will not ≈øay what they would have him ≈øay, if a man will not ≈øweare what they would have him ≈øweare, if a man will not read what they would have him read, if a man wil not preach what they would have him preach, if a man will not pray what they would have him pray; In ≈øhort, if a man will not doe what ever they would have him doe, then hee is an inconformi≈øt, and after that they have duely admoni≈øhed him, primo, ≈øecundo, tertio, all in one breath, then hee is contumacious, then he is an ob≈øtinate Inconformi≈øt.

Now (Sir) my humble motion is, that in con≈øideration of all the premi≈ø≈øes, and what be≈øides hath beene well laid open by others; wee ≈øhould proceed to dam the≈øe Canons, not onely as contrary to the Lawes of the Land, but al≈øo as containing ≈øundry matters, de≈øtructive of the rights of Parliaments, and of the fundamentall and other principall Lawes of this Kingdome, and otherwi≈øe of very dangerous con≈øequence.

div.head: The Lord Digby's Speech to the Hou≈øe of Commons, concerning Bi≈øhops, and the City petition, the 9. of February. 1640.
div.p: I Know it is a tender ≈øubject I am to ≈øpeake of, wherein I beleeve ≈øome within the≈øe Walls are engaged with earne≈øtne≈ø≈øe in contrary opinions to mine; and therefore it will be nece≈ø≈øary, that in the fir≈øt place I be≈øeech the patience of this Hou≈øe, that they will bee plea≈øed to heare mee without interruption: though ≈øomewhat I ≈øay ≈øhould chance to be di≈øplea≈øing, I hope there will be ≈øomewhat from mee ere I conclude, that may be of Service to this Hou≈øe.

Sir, if I thought there were no further de≈øigne in the de≈øires of ≈øome, that this London Petition ≈øhould be committed, then meerely to make u≈øe of it, as an Index of grievance: I ≈øhould winke at the faults of it, and not much oppo≈øe it.

There is no man within the≈øe wals, more ≈øen≈øible of the heavy grievance of Church government, then my Selfe; nor who≈øe affections are keene to the clipping of tho≈øe wings of the Prelates, whereby they have mounted to ≈øuch in≈øolencies, nor who≈øe zeale is more ardent to the ≈øearing them, as that they may never ≈øpring againe.

But having rea≈øon to beleeve that ≈øome aime at a totall extirpation of Bi≈øhops, which is again≈øt my heart, and that the committing of this Petition, may give countenance to that De≈øigne, I cannot re≈øtraine my ≈øelfe from labouring
to divert it, or at least to ≈øet ≈øuch notes upon it, as may make it ineffectuall to that end.

Truely, Sir, when this Petition was fir≈øt brought into the Hou≈øe, I con≈øidered it in its nature, in the manner of the delivery in the pre≈øent conjuncture of aff ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ es, both Eccle≈øiasticall and Civill, to bee a thing of the highe≈øt Con≈øequence that any Age hath pre≈øented to a Parliament; and the ≈øame thoughts I have of it ≈øtill.

I profe≈ø≈øe, I looked upon it then with terrour, as upon a Comet or blazing ≈øtarre, ray≈øed and kindled out of the ≈øtench, out of the poy≈øonous exhalation of a corrupted Hierarchy: Mee thought the Commet had a terrible Tayle with it, Sir, and poynted to the North, the ≈øame feares dwell with mee ≈øtill concerning it, (and I be≈øeech God they may not prove Propheticall:) I feare all the Prudence, all the Fore-cast, all the Vertue of this Hou≈øe, how unitedly ≈øoever collected, how vigorou≈øly applyed, will have a hard worke of it. Yet to hinder this Meteor from cau≈øing ≈øuch Di≈øtempers and Combu≈øtions by its Influence, as it then portended by its appearance; what ever the Event bee, I ≈øhall di≈øcharge my Con≈øcience concerning it, freely and uprightly, as unbya≈øt by popularity, as by any Court re≈øpects.

Sir, I could never flatter the ≈øen≈øe of this Hou≈øe, which I Reverence ≈øo much, as to ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe a ≈øingle No, that my heart dictated, though I knew the venting of it might ca≈øt prejudices upon mee: had my Fortune plac ‚Ä¢ d mee neere a King, I could not have flattered a King; and I doe not intend now to flatter a multitude.

I ≈øhall de≈øire tho≈øe worthy Aldermen, and the re≈øt here of the City of London, not to take any thing I ≈øhall ≈øay, in the lea≈øt way of di≈øparagement or reflection on the City; I looke not upon this Petition, as a Petition from the City of London, but from I know not what, 15000.
Londoners, all that could be got to ≈øub≈øcribe.

When this Petition was fir≈øt pre≈øented, there might bee more rea≈øon for the Commitment of it, as being then the mo≈øt comprehen≈øive Catalogue wee had of Church grievance, but now that the Mini≈øters by their Remonstrance, have given us ≈øo faire and full an Index of them without tho≈øe mixtures of things contemptible, irrationall, and pre≈øumptuous, wherewith this Petition abounds; I do not know I profe≈ø≈øe to what good end it can be committed, being full of contemptible things, but fir≈øt let me recall to your minde the manner of its delivery: And I am confident, there is no man of judgement, that will thinke it fit for a Parliament under a Monarchy, to give countenance to irregular and tumultuous a≈ø≈øemblies of people, be it for never ≈øo good an end: Be≈øides, there is no man of the lea≈øt in≈øight into Nature, or Hi≈øtory, but knowes the danger, when eyther true or pretended ≈øtimulation of con≈øcience hath once given a multitude agitation.

Contemptible things (Sir) ≈øwarme in the 8.13.14.15, 16.17. Articles of this Petition. Did ever any body thinke that the gaites of Ovid, or Tom. Caryes mu≈øe, ≈øhould by 15000. have beene pre≈øented to a Parliament, as a motive for the extirpation of Bi≈øhops, the ≈øcandall of the Rochet, the Lawne-≈øleeves, the foure corner Cap, the Cope, the Surple≈ø≈øe, the Tippet, the Hood, the Canonicall Coat, &c. may pa≈ø≈øe with arguments of the ≈øune weight; onely thus much let me ob≈øerve upon it (Mr. Speaker) that one would ≈øweare the penners of the Article had the pluming of ≈øome Bi≈øhops already, they are ≈øo acquainted with every feather of them. In a word, I know not whether be more prepo≈øterous, to inferre the extirpation of Bi≈øhops from ≈øuch weake Arguments, or to attribute as they doe to Church government all the civill grievance; not a Patent, not a Monopoly, not the price of a commodity
moditie ray≈øed, but the≈øe men make Bi≈øhops the cau≈øe of it.

For the irrationall part (Mr. Speaker) fir≈øt they Petition us in a Method only allowable with tho≈øe, who≈øe Iudgement or Iu≈øtice is ≈øu≈øpected, that is Iniquum petere, ut aequum feras: There is no Logick, no rea≈øoning in their demands: It were want of Logick in mee to expect it from a multitude, but I con≈øider the multitude in this is led by implicite faith, to that which hath beene dige≈øted, and contrived but by a few, and in them truely I cannot but wonder at the want of Reconciliation here.

A Petition, Mr. Speaker, ought in this to bee a kinde of Syllogi≈øme, that the Conclu≈øion, the Prayer ought to hold proportion with the premi≈ø≈øes, that is, with the Allegations, and Complaints, and to beea≈øonably deduc't from them.

But what have we here? a multitude of Allegations, a multitude of in≈øtances, of abu≈øes, and depravations of Church Government: And what inferred from thence? let the u≈øe be utterly aboli≈øht for the abu≈øes ≈øake: As if they ≈øhould ≈øay, that becau≈øe Drunkenne≈ø≈øe and Adultery are growne ≈øo epidemicall, as is alledged in the Petition; Let there be no more u≈øe of Wine nor of Women in the Land.

Chri≈øts Di≈øcipline hath beene adulterated, 'tis true, the whole Church inebriated by the Prelates, therefore infer our Petitioners, let not ≈øo much as the cha≈øte, the ≈øober u≈øe of them be ≈øuffered.

Give me leave to continue one of the Compari≈øons a little further; ≈øhould it be demon≈øtrated unto us, that Wine could not be made u≈øe of without Drunkenne≈ø≈øe, and withall ≈øome ≈øuch Liquor pre≈øented, as healthy, and as nouri≈øhing, from which no di≈øtemper could ari≈øe; I ≈øhould not blame any man for de≈øiring to pluck up the Vine by the roots. But for the moveable ills-≈øake,
to take away the ≈øolid good of a thing, is ju≈øt as rea≈øonable in this, as to root up a good tree, becau≈øe there is a Canker in the branches.

For the bold part of this Petition, Sir, what can there be of greater pre≈øumption, than for petitioners, not onely to pre≈øcribe to a Parliament, what, and how it ≈øhall doe; but for a multitude to teach a Parliament, what, and what is not the government according to Gods word.

Be≈øides, what is the Petition again≈øt? is it not again≈øt the government of the Church of England, e≈øtabli≈øhed by Acts of Parliament? Is it not again≈øt the Liturgy, again≈øt ≈øeverall formes of Divine ≈øervice, ratified by the ≈øame Authority?

'Tis true, Mr. Speaker, the Parliament may mend, may alter, may repeale Lawes, may make new, and I hope, in due ≈øea≈øon wee ≈øhall doe ≈øo in poynt of Church-government: but in the meane time let me tell you, Sir, I cannot but e≈øteeme it an irreverence, an high pre≈øumption in any, to petition point blank again≈øt a Law, or Government in force.

Repre≈øentment of Inconvenience may bee made, (as the Mini≈øters have done) ≈øuch as may endure the wi≈øedome of a Parliament, to advi≈øe Lawes, to rectifie, to repeale them; but it imports the very e≈ø≈øence of Parliaments, to keepe up the honour of its former Acts, and not to ≈øuffer them to bee further bla≈øted from abroad.

Beleeve me, Mr. Speaker, all the reverence and authority, which we expect from future times to our owne Acts hereafter depends upon our upholding the dignity of what former Parliaments have done, even in tho≈øe things which in their due time we may de≈øire, and intend to rever≈øe.

Mr. Speaker, you ≈øee in what plaine language I have ≈øet forth unto you the faults of this Petition, notwith≈øtanding
as great as they are, ≈øo they may not obtaine any ≈øeeming countenance from us; I find my ≈øelfe willing to have them pa≈øt by, e≈øpecially when I con≈øider how naturally prone all mankinde is, when it findes it ≈øelfe oppre≈øt beyond patience, to flye unto extreames for ea≈øe. And indeed, I doe not think, that any people hath beene evermore provoked, then the generality of England, of late yeares, by the in≈øolencies, and exorbitances of the Prelates.

I prote≈øt ≈øincerely, Mr. Speaker, I cannot ca≈øt mine eye upon this Peti ‚Ä¢ ion, nor my thoughts on the practi≈øes of the Church-men, that have governed it of late; but they appear'd to me as a ≈øcourge imployed by God upon us for the ≈øinnes of the Nation; I cannot thinke of that pa≈ø≈øage in the Booke of Kings, He that e≈øcapes the Sword of Hazael, ≈øhal Jehu ≈ølay; and he that e≈øcapes Iehu, ≈øhall Eli≈øha ≈ølay.
Mee thinkes the vengeance of the Prelates hath bin ≈øo laid, as if 'twere meant, no generation, no degree, no complexion of mankinde ≈øhould e≈øcape it.

Was there a man of a nice and tender Con≈øcience? him have they afflicted with ≈øcandall in Adiaphoris, impo≈øing on him tho≈øe things, as nece≈ø≈øary, which hee thinks unlawfull, and they them≈øelves knew to bee but indifferent.
Was there a man of a legall con≈øcience, that made the e≈øtabli≈øhments by Law, the mea≈øure of his religion? him have they netled with Innovations, with fre≈øh Introductions to Popery.
Was there a man of a meek and humble ≈øpirit? him have they trampled to dirt in their pride.
Was there a man of a proud and arrogant nature? him have they bereft with indignation at their ≈øuperlative in≈øolence about him.

Was there a man peaceably affected, ≈øtudious of the quiet, and tranquillity of his Countrey? their incepdi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
ri≈øhip hath plagued him.
Was there a man faithfully addicted to the right of the Crowne, loyally affected to the Kings Supremacy? how hath he beene galled by their new Oath? a direct Covenant again≈øt it.
Was there a man tenacious of the liberty, and propriety of the Subject? have they not ≈øet forth Books, or Sermons, or Canons de≈øtructive to them all?
Was there a man of a pretty ≈øturdy con≈øcience, that would not blanch for a little? their pernicious Oath hath made him ≈øen≈øible, and wounded, or I feare prepared him for the Devill.

Was there a man that dur≈øt mutter again≈øt their In≈øolencies? hee may inquire for his Lugges, they have beene within the Bi≈øhops vi≈øitation; as if they would not onely derive their Brandi≈øhment of the ≈øpirituall ≈øword from St. Peter, but of the materiall one too, and the right to cut off Eares.

Mr. Speaker, as dully, as faintly, as unlively, as in Language, the≈øe actions of the Prelates have been expre≈ø≈øed unto you, I am confident, there is no man heares me but is brim-full of indignation.
For my part, I profe≈ø≈øe I am ≈øo enflamed with the ≈øence of them, that I finde my ≈øelfe ready to cry out with the loude≈øt of the 15000, downe with them, downe with them, even to the ground.

But M. Speaker, when I ca≈øt mine eye round upon this great and wi≈øe A≈ø≈øembly, and find my ≈øelfe a part too, (though the mo≈øt unworthy and incon≈øiderable) of that Senate, from who≈øe di≈øpa≈ø≈øionate and equall Con≈øtitutions, pre≈øent and future times mu≈øt expect their happines or infelicity:
