It obliges mee to the utmo≈øt of my power to dive≈øt my ≈øelfe and others of all tho≈øe di≈øturbances of Judgement which ari≈øe ever from great Provocations, and to ≈øettle my thoughts in that temper, which I thinke nece≈ø≈øary to all tho≈øe that
would judge clearely of ≈øuch things as have incen≈øt them.

p.hi: I be≈øeech you Gentlemen, let us not bee led on by pa≈ø≈øion to popular and vulgar Errors, it is naturall (as I told you before) to the multitude to flie into extreames; that ≈øeemes ever the be≈øt to them, that is mo≈øt oppo≈øite to the pre≈øente≈øt object of their hate.

div.p: Wi≈øe Councells (Mr. Speaker) mu≈øt ≈øquare their Re≈øolutions by another mea≈øure, by that's mo≈øt ju≈øt, mo≈øt honourable, mo≈øt convenient: Beleeve mee, Sir, great alterations of Government are rarely accompanyed with any of the≈øe.

Mr. Speaker, we all agree upon this; that a Reformation of Church Government is mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary, and our happy unity of opinions herein ≈øhould be one argument unto us to ≈øtay there; but, Sir, to ≈øtrike at the Roote, to attempt a totall Alteration, before ever I can give my vote unto that, three things mu≈øt be made manife≈øt unto me.

Fir≈øt, that the mi≈øchiefes which we have felt under Epi≈øcopall Government flow from the nature of the function, not from the abu≈øes of it onely, that is, that no Rules, no Boundaries can be ≈øet to Bi≈øhops able to re≈øtraine them from ≈øuch Exorbitances.
Secondly, ≈øuch a frame of Government mu≈øt be laid before us, as no time, no Corruption can make lyable to proportionable inconveniences with that which we aboli≈øh.
And thirdly, it mu≈øt be made to appeare that this Vtopia is practicable.

For the fir≈øt, Sir, that Epi≈øcopacy a function deduced through all ages of Chri≈øts Church, from the Apo≈øtles times, and continued by the mo≈øt venerable and ≈øacred Order Eccle≈øia≈øtical; and function dignified by the learning and Piety of ≈øo many Fathers of the Church, glorified by ≈øo many Martyrdomes in the Primitive times,
and ≈øome ≈øince our owne ble≈ø≈øed Reformation, a government admired (I ≈øpeak it knowingly) by the learned≈øt of the Reformed Churches abroad: and la≈øtly, a government under which (till the≈øe late yeares) this Church hath ≈øo flouri≈øhed, ≈øo fructified, that ≈øuch a government, ≈øuch a function, ≈øhould at the fagge end of 1640. yeares bee found to have ≈øuch a clo≈øe Devill in it, as no power can Exerci≈øe, no Law Re≈øtraine, appeares (Sir) to mee a thing very improbable: I profe≈ø≈øe, I am deceived Sir, if Trienniall Parliaments will not be a Circle able to keep many a wor≈øe Devill in order.

For the ≈øecond, I know not the ≈øtrength of other mens fancies, but I will confe≈ø≈øe unto you ingenuou≈øly the weakne≈ø≈øe of my faith in the poynt, that I doe not beleeve there can any other government bee propo≈øed, but will in time bee ≈øubject to as great or greater inconveniences than Epi≈øcopacy, I meane Epi≈øcopacy ≈øo ordered, reduced, and limitted, as I ≈øuppo≈øe it may bee by firme and ≈øolid Boundaries.
Tis true Sir, we cannot ≈øo well judge before-hand of future inconveniences, for the knowledge of the faults and mi≈øchiefes of Epi≈øcopall government, re≈øulting from fre≈øh and bleeding experience.

And the in≈øight into dangers of any new way that ≈øhall be propo≈øed being to ri≈øe onely from ≈øpeculation, the apprehen≈øion of the one is likely to be much more operative than of the other, though perh ‚Ä¢ ps in ju≈øt rea≈øon it ought to bee the weaker with us, it is hard in ≈øuch ca≈øes for us to pre≈øerve an equall and unpropen≈øe judgement; ≈øince being in things of this world ≈øo much too hard for faith and contemplation, yet as Divine as our in≈øpection is into things not experimented, if wee hearken to tho≈øe that would quite extirpate Epi≈øcopacy; I am confident that in ≈øtead of every
Bi≈øhops wee put downe in a Dioce≈ø≈øe, wee ≈øhall ≈øet up a Pope in every Pari ‚Ä¢ h.

La≈øtly, Mr. Speaker, whether the ≈øubver≈øion of Epi≈øcopacy, and the introducing of another kinde of Government be practiceable, I leave it to tho≈øe to judge who have con≈øidered the Connexion and Interweaving of the Church Government with the Common Law, to tho≈øe who heard the Kings Speech to us the other day, or who have looked into rea≈øon of ≈øtate.

For my part (though no State≈øman) I will ≈øpeake my minde freely in this. I doe not thinke a King can put downe Bi≈øhops totally with ≈øafety to Monarchy; not that there is any ≈øuch allyance as men talk of 'twixt the Myter and the Crowne, but from this rea≈øon; that upon the putting downe of Bi≈øhops, the Government of A≈ø≈øemblies is likely to ≈øucceed it, That (to bee effectuall) mu≈øt draw to it ≈øelfe the ≈øupremacy of Eccle≈øia≈øticall juri≈ødiction that (con≈øequently) the power of Excommunicating Kings as well as any other brother in Chri≈øt, and if a King chance to be delivered over to Sathan, judge whether men are likely to care much what becomes of him next.

The≈øe things con≈øidered M. Speaker, let us lay a≈øide all thoughts of ≈øuch dangerous, ≈øuch fundamentall, ≈øuch unaccompli≈øhed Alterations: and all thought of countenancing tho≈øe thoughts in others; let us all re≈øolve upon that cour≈øe wherein (with union) wee may probably promi≈øe our ≈øelves ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, happine≈ø≈øe, and ≈øecurity, that is in a through Reformation.
To that, no mans vote ≈øhall be given with more zeale, with more heartine≈ø≈øe than mine. Let us not de≈øtroy Bi≈øhops, but make Bi≈øhops ≈øuch as they were in the Primitive times.
Doe their large Terriories, their large Revenues offend? let them be retrencht, the good Bi≈øhops of Hippo had but a narrow Dioce≈ø≈øe.
Doe their Courts and ≈øubordinates offend? let them be brought to governe as in the Primitive times, by A≈ø≈øemblies of their Clergy.
Doth their intermedling in ≈øecular affaires offend? exclude them from the capacity, it is no more than what Rea≈øon, and all Antiquity hath interdicted them.

That all this may bee the better effected, M. Speaker my mottion is, that; Fir≈øt, we may appoynt a Committee to collect all grievances ≈øpringing from the mi≈øgovernment of the Church (to which the Mini≈øters head of Government will bee ≈øufficient without countenancing this Petition by a Commitment) and to repre≈øent it to this hou≈øe in a Body.

And in the next place that wee may (if it ≈øtand with the order of Parliaments) de≈øire that there may bee a ≈øtanding Committee of certain members of both Hou≈øes, who (with a number of ≈øuch learned Mini≈øters as the Hou≈øes ≈øhall nominate for A≈ø≈øi≈øtants) may take into con≈øideration all the≈øe grievances, and advi≈øe of the be≈øt way to ≈øettle peace and ≈øatisfaction in the Government of the Church, to the comfort of all good Chri≈øtians, and all good Common-wealths Men.

div.head: The Accu≈øation and Impeachment of John LORD Finch, Baron of Fordwich, Lord Keeper of the Great Seale of England, by the Hou≈øe of COMMONS.
div.p: IMprimis, That the ≈øaid Iohn Lord Finch, Baron of Fordwich, Lord Keeper, &c. hath traiterou≈øly, and wickedly, endeavoured to ≈øubvert the fundamentall Lawes, and e≈øtabli≈øhed Government of the Realme of England, and in ≈øtead thereof to introduce an arbitrary tyrann ‚Ä¢ call government again≈øt Law, which hee hath declared by trayterous and wicked words, coun≈øells, opinions, judgements, practices, and actions.

II. That in pur≈øuance of tho≈øe his trayterous and wicked purpo≈øes, hee did in the third and fourth yeare of his Maje≈øties reigne, or one of them, being then Speaker of the Commons Hou≈øe of Parliament, contrary to the commands of the Hou≈øe then a≈ø≈øembled, and ≈øitting,
denyed and hindred the reading of ≈øome things which the ≈øaid Hou≈øe of Commons required to bee read for the ≈øafety of the King and Kingdome, & pre≈øervation of the Religion of this Realme; and did forbid all the members of the hou≈øe to ≈øpeake, and ≈øaid, that if any did offer to ≈øpeake, he would ri≈øe and goe away, and ≈øaid nothing ≈øhould bee then done in the hou≈øe, and did offer to ri≈øe and goe away, and did thereby and otherwi≈øe, in as much as in him lay, endeavour to ≈øubvert the ancient and undeubted rights and cour≈øe of Parliaments.

III. That he being of his Maje≈øties Councell at the Iu≈øtice ≈øeate held for the County of E≈ø≈øex, in the moneth of October, in the tenth yeare of his now Maje≈øties reigne, at Strafford Langton in the ≈øame County being then of his Maje≈øties Councell, in that Service did practi≈øe by unlawfull meanes, to enlarge the Forre≈øt of that County, many Miles beyond the knowne bounds thereof, as they had beene enjoyed neere 300 yeares, contrary to the Law. and to the Charter of the liberties of the Fore≈øt; and other Charters, and divers Acts of Parliament: and for effecting the ≈øame, did unlawfully cau≈øe and procure undue returnes to be made of Iurors, and great numbers of other per≈øons who were un≈øworne, to be joyned to them of the Iury, and threatned and awed the ≈øayd Iurors to give a Verdict for the King, and by unlawfull means did ≈øurpri≈øe the County, that they might not make Defence, and did u≈øe ≈øeverall menacing wicked Speeches and Actions, to the Iury and others, for obtayning his unju≈øt purpo≈øe afore≈øaid, and after a Verdict obtained for the King in the Moneth of April following (at which time the ≈øayd Iu≈øtice Seate was called by adjournment)
the ≈øayd Iohn Lord Finch then Lord Chiefe Iu≈øtice of his Maje≈øties Court of Common Pleas, and was one of the Iudges a≈ø≈øi≈øtants for them; he continued by further unlawfull and unju≈øt practices, to maintaine and confirme the ≈øaid verdict, and did then and there being a≈ø≈øi≈øtant to the Iu≈øtice in Eyre, advi≈øe the refu≈øal of the traver≈øe offered by the County, and all their evidences, but onely what they ≈øhould verbally deliver, which was refu≈øed accordingly.

IV. That hee, about the Moneth of November, 1635. hee being then Lord Chiefe Iu≈øtice of the Common Pleas, and having taken an oath for the due admini≈øtration of Iu≈øtice to his Maje≈øties Liege people, according to the Lawes and ≈øtatutes of the Realme, contrived in opinion in haec verba, (when the good and ≈øafety, &c.) and did ≈øub≈øcribe his name to that opinion, and by per≈øwa≈øions, threats, and fal≈øe ≈øugge≈øtions, did ≈øolicite, and procure Sir Iohn Bram≈øtone Knight, then and now Lord Chiefe Iu≈øtice of England, Sir Humfrey Davenport Knight, Lord chiefe Baron of his Maje≈øties Court of Exchequer, Sir Richard Hutton Knight, late one of the Iu≈øtices of his Maje≈øties Court of Common Pleas, Sir Iohn Denham Knight, late one of the Barons of his Maje≈øties Court of Exchequer, Sir William lones Knight, late one of the Iu≈øtices of the ≈øaid Court of Kings Bench, Sir George Crock, then and now one of the Iudges of the ≈øaid Court of Kings Bench, Sir Thomas Trevor Knight, then and now one of the Barons of the Exchequer, Sir George Vernon Knight, late one of the Iu≈øtices of the ≈øaid Court of Common Pleas: Sir Robert Barkley Knight, then and now one of the Iu≈øtices of the ≈øaid Court of Kings Bench, Sir Francis Crawly Knight, then and now one of the Ju≈øtices
of the ≈øaid Court of Common Pleas, Sir Richard Weston Knight, then and now one of the Barons of the ≈øaid Court of Exchequer, ≈øome or one of them to ≈øub≈øcribe, with their names the ≈øaid opinion pre≈øently, and enjoyned them ≈øeverally ≈øome or one of them ≈øecre≈ø ‚Ä¢ upon their allegeance.

V. That he the fifth day of Iune, then being Lord Chiefe Iu≈øtice of the ≈øaid Court of Common Pleas, ≈øub≈øcribed an extrajudiciall opinion in an≈øwer to que≈øtions in a letter from his Maje≈øty, in haec verba, &c.

And that he contrived the ≈øaid que≈øtions, and procured the ≈øaid Letter from his Maje≈øty; and whereas the ≈øaid Iu≈øtice Hutton and Iu≈øtice Crook declared to him their opinions to the contrary; yet hee required and pre≈ø≈øed them to ≈øub≈øcribe, upon his promi≈øe that hee would let his Maje≈øty know the truth of their opinions; notwith≈øtanding ≈øuch ≈øub≈øcriptions, which neverthele≈ø≈øe he did not make knowne to his Maje≈øtie, but delivered the ≈øame to his Maje≈øty, as the opinion of all the Iudges.

VI. That hee being Lord Chiefe Iu≈øtice of the ≈øaid Court of Common Pleas, delivered his opinion in the Chequer Chamber again≈øt Ma≈øter Hampden in the ca≈øe of Ship-money; that hee the ≈øaid Ma≈øter Hampd ‚Ä¢ n upon the matter and ≈øub≈øtance of the ca≈øe was chargeable with the money then in que≈øtion: a Coppy of which proceedings the Commons will deliver to your Lord≈øhips, and did ≈øolicite and threaten the ≈øaid ≈øudges ≈øome or one of them to deliver their opinions in like manner again≈øt Ma≈øter Hampden: and after the ≈øaid Baron Denham had delivered his opinion
for Ma≈øter Hampden, the ≈øaid Lord Finch repaired purpo≈øely to the ≈øaid Baron Denhams Chamber in Serjeants Inne in Fleet≈øtreet, and after the ≈øaid Ma≈øter Baron Denham had declared and expre≈ø≈øed his opinion, urged him to retract the ≈øaid opinion, which hee refu≈øing, was threatned by the ≈øaid Lord Finch, becau≈øe hee refu≈øed.

VII. That hee then being Lord chiefe Ju≈øtice of the Court of Common Pleas, declared and publi≈øhed in the Exchequer Chamber, and we≈øterne circuit where he went Judge, that the Kings right to Ship-money, as afore≈øaid, was ≈øo inherent a right to the Crowne, as an Act of Parliament could not take it away; and with divers malicious ≈øpeeches inveighed again≈øt, and threatned all ≈øuch as refu≈øed to pay Ship-money; all which opinions contained in the foure, five, & ≈øixth Articles, are again≈øt the Law of the Realme, the Subjects right of property, and contrary to former re≈øolutions in Parliament, and to the petition of right: which ≈øaid re≈øolutions and petition of right, were well knowne to him, and re≈øolved and enacted in Parliament, when he was Speaker of the Commons hou≈øe of Parliament.

VIII. That hee being Lord chiefe Ju≈øtice of the Court of Common Pleas, did take the generall practice of that Court to his private Chamber; and that hee ≈øent warrants into all or many ≈øhires of England to ≈øeverall men, as to Francis Giles of the County of Devon, Rebert Ren≈øon of the County of Yorke, Attorneys of that Court, and to divers others, to relea≈øe all per≈øons arre≈øted on any utlawry about 40. ≈øhillings fees, whereas none by Law ≈øo arre≈øted, can be bailed or relea≈øed without Super≈øedeas under ≈øeale or rever≈øall.

IX. That hee being Lord Chiefe Iu≈øtice of the Court of Common pleas, upon a pretended ≈øuit begun in Michaelmas Terme, in the 11. yeare of his Maje≈øties Reigne, although there was no plaint or Declaration again≈øt him, did notoriou≈øly and contrary to all Law and Iu≈øtice, by threats, menaces, and impri≈øonment, compell Thomas Laurence, an Executor, to pay 19 pound 12 ≈øhillings, and likewi≈øe cau≈øed Richard Bernard, being onely over-≈øeer of the la≈øt Will of that Te≈øtator, to bee arre≈øted for the payment of the ≈øaid Money, contrary to the advice of the re≈øt of the Iudges of that Court, and again≈øt th ‚Ä¢ kn ‚Ä¢ wne and ordinary cour≈øe of Iu≈øtice, and his ≈øaid Oath and knowledge, and denyed his Maje≈øties Subjects the common and ordinary Iu≈øtice of this Realme, as to Mr. Li ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ rick, and others, and for his private benefit endammaged and ruined the e≈øtates of very many of his Maje≈øties Subjects, contrary to his oath and knowledge.

X. That hee being Lord Keeper of the great Seale of England, and ≈øworne one of his Maje≈øties Privie Coun≈øell, did by fal≈øe and malicious ≈ølanders labour to incen≈øe his Maje≈øtie again≈øt Parliaments, and did frame and advi≈øe the publi≈øhing the Declaration after the di≈ø≈øolution of the la≈øt Parliament.

All which Trea≈øons and mi≈ødemeanors above mentioned, were done and committed by the ≈øaid Iohn Lord Finch Baron of Fordwich, Lord Keeper of the great Seale of England, and thereby he the afore≈øaid Finch hath trayterou≈øly, and contrary to his allegiance laboured to lay Imputations and Scandalls upon
his Maje≈øties government, and to alienate the hearts of his Maje≈øties liege people from his Maje≈øtie, and to ≈øet a divi≈øion betweene them, and to ruine and de≈øtroy his Maje≈øties Realme of England, for which they doe impeach him the ≈øaid Lord Finch, Baron of Fordwich, Lord Keeper of the Great Seale of England, of high Trea≈øon again≈øt our Soveraigne Lord the King, his Crowne and Dignity, of the mi≈ødemeanours above mentioned. And the ≈øaid Commons by Prote≈øtation, ≈øaving to them≈øelves the libertie of exhibiting at any time hereafter, any other accu≈øation or impeachmens against the ≈øaid Lord Finch, and al≈øo of replying to the an≈øwer, that the ≈øaid Iohn Lord Finch ≈øhall make unto the ≈øaid Articles or to any of them, and of affering proofe of the premi≈ø≈øes, or any of their impeachments or accu≈øations that ≈øhall be exhibited by them, as the ca≈øe ≈øhall according to the cour≈øe of Parliaments require, doe pray, that the ≈øaid Iohn Lord Finch, Baron of Ford wich, Lord Keeper of the Great Seale of England, may be put to an≈øwer to all and every of the premi≈ø≈øes, and ≈øuch proceedings, examinations, tryalls, and judgements, as may be upon every of them, bad and u≈øed, as is agreeable to Law and Iustice.

div.head: The Lord FAULKLANDS ≈øecond Speech: Made the 14. of January, after the reading of the Articles again≈øt the Lord FINCH.
div.p: THe≈øe Articles again≈øt my Lord Finch being read, I may bee bold to apply that of the Poet, Nil refert tales ver≈øus qua voce legantur; and I doubt not but your Lord≈øhips mu≈øt be of the ≈øame opinion, of which the Hou≈øe of Commons appeares to have beene, by the choyce they have made of me, that the charge I have brought is ≈øuch, as needs no a≈ø≈øi≈øtance from the bringer, leaving not ≈øo much as the colour of a colour for any defence, including all po≈ø≈øible evidence, and all po≈ø≈øible aggravation (that addition alone excepted) which he alone could make, and hath made; I meane his Confe≈ø≈øion, Included in his flight.

Here are many and mighty Crimes, Crimes of Supererogation, (So that high Trea≈øon is but a part of his Charge) pur≈øuing him fervently in every ≈øeverall condition, (being a ≈øilent Speaker, an unju≈øt Iudge, and an uncon≈øcionable Keeper.) That his life appeares a perpetuall Warfare, (by Mines, and by Battery, by Batteil, and
by Stratagem) again≈øt our fundamentall Lawes (which by his own confe≈ø≈øion) ≈øeverall Conquests had left untoucht, again≈øt the excellent con≈øtitution of this Kingdome, which hath made it appeare unto ≈øtrangers rather an Idea, than a reall Common-wealth, and produced the honour and happine≈ø≈øe of this to be a wonder of every other Nation, and this wi ‚Ä¢ h unfortunate ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, that as he alwayes intended to make our Ruines a ground of his advancement; ≈øo his advancement the meanes of our further ruine.

After that, contrary to the further end of his place, and the end of that meeting in which he held his place, hee had as it were gagg'd the Common-Wealth, taking away, (to his power) all power of Speech from that body, of which he ought to have beene the Mouth, and which alone can perfectly repre≈øent the condition of the people, whom that onely repre≈øent, which if he had not done, in all probability, what ≈øo grave and judicious an A≈ø≈øembly might have offered to the con≈øideration of ≈øo gracious and ju≈øt a Prince, had occa≈øioned the redre≈ø≈øe of the grievances they then ≈øuffered, and prevented tho≈øe which we have ≈øince endured, according to the ancient Maxime of Odi≈ø≈øe quos laeferis: he pur≈øued this offence towards the Parliament, by inveighing again≈øt the Members by ≈øcandalizing their proceedings by trampling upon their Acts and Declarations, by u≈øurping and devolving the right by dimini≈øhing & abrogating the power, both of that & other Parliaments & making them (as much as in him ≈øay) both u≈øele≈ø≈øe and odious to his Maje≈øty, and pur≈øued his hatred to this fountain of Iu≈øtice by corrupting the ≈øtreames of it, the Lawes; and perverting the Conduit Pipes, the Iudges:

He practiced the annibilating of Ancient, and Notorious perambulations of particular Forre≈øts, the better to prepare him≈øelfe to annihilate the Ancient, and Notorious perambulation of the whole Kingdome, the meeres
and bounders betweene the liberties of the Subject and Soveraigne power; he endeauoured to have all tenures in durante bene placito, to bring all Law from his Maje≈øties Courts, into his Maje≈øties bre≈øt he gave our goods to the King our lands to the Deere, our liberties to his Sheriffes; ≈øo that there was no way by which wee had not beene oppre≈øt, and de≈øtroyed, if the power of this per≈øon had beene equall with his will: Or that the will of his Maje≈øtie had beene equall to his power.

He not onely by this meanes made us lyable to all the effect of an Inva≈øion from within (and by de≈øtruction of our Liberties, which included the de≈øtruction of our propriety, which included the de≈øtruction of our Indu≈øtry) made us lyable to the terrible≈øt of all Inva≈øions, that of want and poverty. So that if what hee plotted had taken Root (and he made it, as ≈øure as his Declaration could make it (what him≈øelfe was not) Parliament proofe) in this wealthy and happy Kingdome, there could have beene left, no aboundance but of grievances, and di≈øcontentment, no ≈øatisfaction but among≈øt the guilty. It is generally ob≈øerved of the plague, that the infection of others, is an earne≈øt, and con≈øtant de≈øire of all that are ≈øeized by it: and as this de≈øigne re≈øembles that di≈øea≈øe, in the ruine, de≈øtruction, and de≈øolation, it would have wrought ≈øo it ≈øeemes no le≈ø≈øe like it in this effect: he having ≈øo laboured to make others ≈øhare in that guilt, that his ≈øolicitation, was not onely his action, but his workes, making u≈øe both of his Authority, his Intere≈øt, and Importunity, to per≈øwade; and in his Maje≈øties Name (who≈øe Piety is knowne to give that Excellent prerogative to his per≈øon, that the Law gives to his place, not to be able to doe wrong) to threaten the re≈øt of the Iudges, to ≈øigne opinions contrary to Law, to a≈ø≈øigne an≈øwers contrary to their opinions, to give Iudgement which they ought not to have given, and to recant Iudgement, when they had given as they ought, ≈øo that
who≈øoever con≈øiders his care of, and concernment, both in the growth and the immortality of this project, cannot but by the ≈øame way by which the wi≈øe≈øt judgment found the true mother of the Child, di≈øcover him not onely to have beene the Fo≈øterer but the Father of this mo≈øt pernicious and envious de≈øigne.

I ≈øhall not need to ob≈øerve, that this was plotted and pur≈øued by an Engli≈øh man again≈øt England, (which encrea≈øeth the Crime in no le≈ø≈øe degree than parricide is beyond Murther) that this was done in the greate≈øt matter joyned to the greate≈øt Bond, being again≈øt the generall liberty, and publike propriety, by a ≈øworne Iudge (and if that ≈øalt it ≈øelfe, becau≈øe un≈øavory, the Go≈øpell it ≈øelfe hath de≈øign'd whither it mu≈øt be ca≈øt) that he poy≈øoned our very Antidotes, and turned our Guard into a de≈øtruction, making Law the ground of illegalitie: that he u≈øed this Law not onely again≈øt us, but again≈øt it ≈øelfe, making it as I may ≈øay, Felo de ≈øe, making the pretence, (for I can ≈øcarce ≈øay, the appearance of it) ≈øo to contribute the utter ruine of it ≈øelfe.

I ≈øhall not need to ≈øay, that either this (or more can be) of the highe≈øt kinde, and in the highe≈øt degree of Parliamentary Trea≈øon, a Trea≈øon which need not a computation of many ≈øeverall actions, which alone were not Trea≈øon, to prove a Trea≈øon altogether, and by that demon≈øtration of the intention, to make that formality Trea≈øon which were materially but a mi≈ødemeanor, a Trea≈øon as well again≈øt the King, as again≈øt the Kingdome, for what≈øoever is again≈øt the whole, is undoubtedly again≈øt the head, which takes from his Maje≈øty the ground of his Rule, the Lawes, (for if foundations bee de≈øtroyed, the Pinnacles are mo≈øt endangered) which takes from his Maje≈øty the principal honour of his Rule, the Ruling over Free-men, a power as much Nobler then over villaines, as that is that's over bea≈øts) which endevoured to take from his Maje≈øty the principall
≈øupport of his Rule, their hearts and affections over whom he rules (a better and ≈øurer ≈øtrength and wall to the King, than the Sea is to the Kingdome) and by begetting a mutuall di≈øtru≈øt, and by that a mutuall di≈øaffection between them, to hazard the danger even of the de≈øtruction of both.

p.hi: My Lords,

div.p: I ≈øhall the le≈ø≈øe need to pre≈ø≈øe this, becau≈øe as it were unrea≈øonable in any ca≈øe to ≈øu≈øpect your Iu≈øtice, ≈øo here e≈øpecially, where your intere≈øt ≈øo nearly unites you, your great ≈øhare in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, giving you an equall concernment in propriety, the care and paines u≈øed by your Noble Ance≈øtors in the founding and a≈ø≈øerting of our conmon Liberties, rendring the ju≈øt defence of them, your mo≈øt proper and peculiar inheritance, and both exciting to oppo≈øe and extirpate all ≈øuch de≈øignes as did introduce, and would have ≈øet led an Arbitrary, that is, an intollerable forme of Government, and have made even your Lord≈øhips and your po≈øterity but Right Honourarable ≈ølaves.
My Lords,

I will ≈øpend no more words, Luctando cum larva, in accu≈øing the Gho≈øt of a departed per≈øon, whom his Crimes accu≈øe more than I can doe; and his ab≈øence accu≈øeth no le≈ø≈øe than his Crime. Neither will I excu≈øe the length of what I have ≈øaid, becau≈øe I cannot adde to an Excu≈øe, without adding to the Fault, or my owne imperfections, either in the matter or manner of it, which I know must appeare the greater, by being compared with that learned Gentlemans great abilitie, who hath precoded me at this time: I will onely de≈øire by the Command, and in the behalfe of the Hou≈øe of Commons, that the≈øe proceedings again≈øt the Lord Finch, may be put in ≈øo ≈øpeedy away of di≈øpatch, as in ≈øuch ca≈øes the cour≈øe of Parliament will allow.

div.head: The fir≈øt Speech made by Sir Edward Deering, in the hou≈øe of Commons.
div.p: YE≈øterday, the affaires of this Hou≈øe did borrow all the time allotted to the great Committee of Religion; I am ≈øorry that (having but halfe a day in a whole week) we have lo≈øt that.

Mr. Speaker, The ≈øufferings that wee have undergone, are reduceable to two heads: The fir≈øt concerning the Church: The ≈øecond belonging to the Common-wealth. The fir≈øt of the≈øe mu≈øt have the fir≈øt fruites of the Parliament, as being the fir≈øt in weight and worth, and more immediately to the honour of God, and his Glory, every dramme whereof, is worth the whole weight of a Kingdome. The Common-wealth (it is true) is ful of apparent dangers, the Sword is come home unto us, and two Twinned Nations, united together under one regall Head, Brethren together in the Bowels and Bo≈øome of the ≈øame I≈øland, and which is above all, is imbanded together in the ≈øame Religion, (I ≈øay in the ≈øame Religion) by a divelli≈øh Machination, like to be fatally imbrewed in each others blood, ready to digge each others Graves, Quantillum abfuit.

For other grievances al≈øo, the poore di≈ø-hearted Suject ≈øadly grieves, not able to di≈øtingui≈øh betweene Power and Law, and with a weeping heart (no que≈øtion)
hath long prayed for this houre in hope to be relieved; and to know hereafter whether any thing hee hath (be≈øid ‚Ä¢ s his poore part and portion of the common Aire hee breatheth) may be truly called his owne.

The≈øe Mr. Speaker, and many other, doe de≈øerve, and mu≈øt ≈øhortly have our deepe regards, but ≈øuo gradis. Now in the fir≈øt place there is a unum nece≈ø≈øarium, above all our worldly ≈øufferings and dangers; Religion, the immediate Service due unto Almighty God; and herein let us all be confident, that all our con≈øultations wil be unpro≈øperous, if wee put any determination before that of Religion. For my part, let the Sword reach from the North to the South, and a generall perdition of all our remaining rights threaten us in an open view, it ≈øhall bee ≈øo farre from making mee to decline the fir≈øt ≈øetling of Religion, that I ≈øhall ever argue, and rather conclude it thus: That the more great and eminent our perils of this World are, the ≈øtronger and quicker ought our care to be for the glory of God, and the pure Law of our Soules.

If then, Mr. Speaker, it may pa≈ø≈øe with full allowance, that all our cares may give way unto the Treaty of Religion, I will reduce that al≈øo unto two heads: Fir≈øt of Eccle≈øia≈øticall per≈øons; Then of Eccle≈øia≈øticall Cau≈øes: Let no man ≈øtart or be affrighted at the imagined length of this Con≈øultation; it will not, it cannot take up ≈øo much Time as it is worth, This is God and the Kings, God and the Kingdomes, nay this is God and the two Kingdomes cau≈øe.

And therefore, Mr. Speaker, my humble motion is, that wee may all of us, ≈øeriou≈øly, ≈øpeedily, and heartily enter upon this, the be≈øt and the greate≈øt, and the mo≈øt important cau≈øe wee can treate on.

Now, Mr. Speaker, in pur≈øuite of mine owne motion, and to make a little entrance into the≈øe great
Affaires, I will pre≈øent unto you the Petition of a poore di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Mini≈øter in the Cou ‚Ä¢ ty of Kent, a man conformable in his practice, Orthodoxe in his Doctrine, laborious in his Mini≈øtery, as any wee have or I doe know, He is now a ≈øufferer (as all good men are) under the generall obloquy of a Puritan, as with other things was admirably delivered by that ≈øilver Trumpet at the Bar, the Pur≈øevant watched his doore, and divides him and his Cure a≈øunder to both their griefes; for it is not with him as perhaps with ≈øome, that ≈øet the Pur≈øevant at worke, glad of an excu≈øe to be out of th ‚Ä¢
Pulpit, it is his delight to Preach. About a week ≈øince I went over to Lambeth to moove that great Bi≈øhop (too great indeede) to take this danger from off this Mini≈øter and recall the Pur≈øevant: And withall did undertake for Mr. Wil≈øon (for ≈øo is your Petitioner called) that hee ≈øhould an≈øwere his Accu≈øers in any of the Kings Courts a ‚Ä¢
We≈øtmin≈øter: The Bi≈øhop made me this an≈øwere in His verbis, I am ≈øure that hee will not ab≈øent from his Cure a Twelve-moneth together, and then I doubt not but once in a yeare wee ≈øhall have him. This was all that I could obtaine, but I hope (by the helpe of this Hou≈øe) before this yeare of threats-be runne out, his Grace will eyther have more Grace, or no Grace at all. For our griefes are manifold, and doe fill a mighty and va≈øt Circumference, yet ≈øo that from every part, our lines of ≈øorrow doe lead unto him, and point at him, as the Center from whence our mi≈øeries doe grow.
Let the Petition be read, and let us enter upon the worke.

div.head: The ≈øecond Speech of Sir Edward Deering.
div.p: YOu have many private particular Petitions, give me leave by word of mouth to interpo≈øe one more generall, which thus you may receive: Gods true Religion is violently invaded by two ≈øeeming enemies, but indeed they are like Herod and Pilate, fa≈øt friends for the de≈øtruction of truth: I meane the Papists for the one part, and our Prelating Faction for the other; between the≈øe two in their ≈øeverall progre≈ø≈øe, I ob≈øerve the concurrence of ≈øome few parallells, fit as I conceive to bee repre≈øented to this Honourable Hou≈øe.

Fir≈øt, with the Papi≈øts there is a ≈øevere Inqui≈øition, and with us (as it is u≈øed) there is a bitter High Commi≈ø≈øion, both the≈øe Contra fas & ins are Iudges in their owne ca≈øe: yet herein their Inqui≈øitors are better than our High Commi≈øtio ‚Ä¢ ers, they (for ought I ever heard) doe not (Savir ‚Ä¢ in ≈øuos) puni≈øh for delinquents and offenders, ≈øuch as profe≈ø≈øe and practice Religion, according as it is e≈øtabli≈øhed by the Lawes of the Land where they live.

But with us, how many poore di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Mini≈øters?
nay how many ≈øcores of them in a few yeares pa≈øt, have beene ≈øu≈øpended, degraded, and excommunicated? not guil ‚Ä¢ y of the breach of any e≈øtabli≈øhed Lawes: The Petitions of many are here with us, more are comming, all their prayers are in Heaven for redre≈ø≈øe: Downe therefore with the≈øe Money-changers; They doe confe≈ø≈øe Commutation of Penance, and I may therefore mo≈øt ju≈øtly call them ≈øo.

Secondly, with the Papi≈øts there is a My≈øterious Artifice, I meane their Index Expurgatorius, whereby they clip the tongues of ≈øuch witne≈ø≈øes who≈øe evidence they doe not like: To the≈øe I parallel our late Imprimators, Licen≈øers for the Pre≈ø≈øe, ≈øo handled, that truth is ≈øuppre≈øt and popi≈øh Pamphlets flie abroad Cum privilegio, witne≈ø≈øe the audacious Libells again≈øt true Religion, written by Co≈ø≈øens, D we, Heylin, Pocklington, Mead, Shelford, Swan, Roberts, and many more, I name no Bi≈øhops, but I adde, &c.

Nay, they are already growne ≈øo bold in this new trade, that the mo≈øt learned Labourers of our ancient and be≈øt divines, mu≈øt bee new corrected, and defaced with a Delineatur, by the ≈øupercilious penne of my Lords young Chaplaine, fit perhaps for the Technicall Arts, but unfit to hold the Chaire for Divinity.

But herein the Roman Index is better than our Engli≈øh Licences, they thereby doe prove the current of their owne e≈øtabli≈øhed Doctrines, a point of wi≈øedome; but with us our Innovators by this Artifice do alter our ≈øetled Doctrines, nay they doe ≈øubinduce poynts repugnant and contrary: and this I doe affirme upon my ≈øelfe to prove.

One parallell I have more, and that is this: Among≈øt the Papists there is one acknowledged Pope, ≈øupreme in honour over all, and in power, from who≈øe judgement there is no appeale: I confe≈ø≈øe Mr. Speaker, I cannot
altogether match a Pope with a Pope, yet one of the ancient Titles of our Engli≈øh Primate, was Alterius orbis Papa, but thus farre I can goe (ex ore ≈øuo) it i ‚Ä¢ in Print; hee pleads faire for a Patriarchall, and for ≈øuch a one who≈øe Iudgement (he before hand profe≈ø≈øeth) ought to be finall, and then I am ≈øure it ought to bee unerring; put the≈øe two together, and you ≈øhall finde that the finall determination of a Patriarch, will want very little of a Pope, and then we may ≈øay, Munato nomine de te fabula narratur: he pleadeth Pope≈øhip, under the name of a Patriarch, and I much feare the end and top of his Patriarchall plea, may be as that of Cardinall Poole, his Predece≈ø≈øour, who would have two heads, one Caput Regale, the other Caput Sacerdotale, a proud parallell to ≈øet up the Myter above the Crowne.

But herein I ≈øhall bee free and cleare, if one there mu≈øt be, be it a Pope, be it a Patriarch, this I re≈øolve upon for mine own choyce, Procul a love, procul a fulmine, I had rather ≈øerve one as far as Tyber, then to have him come to mee ≈øo neare as the Thames, a Pope at Rome will doe mee le≈ø≈øe hurt, than a Patriarch may doe at Lambeth.

I have done, and for this third parallell, I ≈øubmit it to the wi≈øedome and con≈øideration of this grave Committee for Religion: In the meane time I doe ground my Motion upon the former two, and it is this in briefe.

That you would be plea≈øed to ≈øelect a ≈øub-Committee of 4.6.8.9. or 10. at the mo≈øt, and to impower them for the di≈øcovery of the great numbers of oppre≈ø≈øed Mini≈øters, under the Bi≈øhops tyranny for the≈øe ten yeares la≈øt pa≈øt, we have the complaints of ≈øome, but more are ≈øilent, ≈øome are patient and will not complaine, others are fearefull and dare not, many dead, and many beyond the Seas, and cannot complaine.

And in the ≈øecond place, that the ≈øub-Committee may examine the Printers, what Bookes by bad licence have beene corruptly i≈ø≈øued forth. And what good Bookes have beene (like good Mini≈øters) ≈øilenced, clipped, or cropped.
The worke I conceive, will not be difficult, but will quickly returne into your hands full of weight.

p.hi: And this is my Motion.

div.head: The third Speech of Sir Edward Deering.
div.p: THis Morning is de≈øigned for the con≈øideration of the late Canons, and the former; and of that which the Clergy have mi≈ø-called a benevolence; I ≈øhall for the pre≈øent, onely touch the fir≈øt of them, and that is the Roman Velites, wht did u≈øe to beginne the Battaile: ≈øo ≈øhall I but valitande, and skirmi≈øh, whil≈øt the maine Battaile is ≈øetting forwards.
The Pope as they ≈øay, hath a triple Crown, an≈øwerable thereunto, and to ≈øupport it, hee pretendeth to have a threefold Law.

list.item: 1. The fir≈øt that is Ius divinum, Epi≈øcopacy by Divine Right: and this he would have you thinke to bee the Crowne next his head, which doth circle and ≈øecure his power, our Bi≈øhops have in an unlucky time entred their Plea, and pre≈øented their title to this Crowne, Epi≈øcopacy by Divine Right.

2 The ≈øecond is Ius humanum Con≈øtantii donativum the gift of Indulgent Princes temporall power; this Law belongs to his ≈øecond or middle Crowne, this is already pleaded for, by our Prelates in print.

3. The≈øe two Crowne being already obtained, The Pope claimes, and makes the third him≈øelfe, and ≈øets it highe≈øt upon the top: This Crowne al≈øo hath its Law, and that is Ius Canonicum: This Canon Law is of more u≈øe unto his Pope≈øhip (if once admitted) than both the other.

div.p: Iu≈øt ≈øo our Prelates from the pretended Divinity of their Epi≈øcopacy, and from the temporall power granted them by our Princes, would now obtrude a new Canon Law upon us: They have charged the Canons to the full, and never fearing they would requoyle into a Parliament, they have rammed a prodigious and ungodly Oath into them: the illegality and invalidity of the≈øe Canons, is manife≈øted by one ≈øhort que≈øtion, (viz.) what doe you call the meeting wherein they were made?
Mr. Speaker, who can frame an argument aright, unle≈ø≈øe he can tell again≈øt what he is to argue?

Would you confute the Convocation-hou≈øe? they were a holy Synod; they were Commi≈ø≈øioners? will you di≈øpute their Commi≈ø≈øion? they will mingle all power together, and perhaps an≈øwer, they were ≈øomething el≈øe, that we neither knew nor imagined; unle≈ø≈øe they would unriddle them≈øelves, and owne what they were, wee may pro≈øecute non-concludent Arguments.

Mr. Speaker, I have conferred with ≈øome of the Founders of tho≈øe Canons, but I profe≈ø≈øe here, that I could never meet with any one of that a≈ø≈øembly, who could well an≈øwer to that fir≈øt que≈øtion of the Catechi≈øme, What is your name? Alas, they were parted before they knew what they were, when they were together.

The ≈øumme of all the ≈øeverall an≈øwers that I have received, do all together amount unto this: They were a Convocationall, Synodicall A≈ø≈øembly of Commi≈ø≈øioners; Indeed a threefold Chaemera, a Mon≈øter to our Lawes, a Cerberus to our Religion. A ≈øtrange Commi≈ø≈øion, where no Commi≈ø≈øioners name is to be found‚ñ™ A ≈øtrange Convocation that lived when the Parliament was dead. A ≈øtrange holy Synod, when the one part never ≈øaw nor conferred with the other.
But indeed, there needed no conference, if it be true of the≈øe Cannons which I read of the former, Quis ne≈øcit, Canones Lambethae formari priu≈øquam in Synode ventilentur?
Well Mr. Speaker, they have Innovated upon us; wee may ≈øay, it is Lex talionis to Innovate upon them, and ≈øo I hope we ≈øhortly ≈øhall doe.

In the meane time, my humble motion is, that every member of that a≈ø≈øembly, who voted their Cannons, may come ≈øeverally to the Barre of this Hou≈øe, with a Book of Cannons in his hand and there unle≈ø≈øe he can an≈øwer that Catechi≈øme que≈øtion, as I called it, better then I expect he can, conceptis verbis, in ≈øuch expre≈ø≈øe termes as this honourable hou≈øe ≈øhall then think fit, he ≈øhall abjure his owne I≈ø≈øue, and be commanded to give fire to his owne Canons.

p.hi: And this motion I take to be just.

div.head: The fourth Speech of Sir Edward Deering. Concerning the Arch-Bi≈øhop, and divers other Grievances.
div.p: YE≈øterday we did regulate the mo≈øt important bu≈øine≈ø≈øe before us: and gave them motion, ≈øo that our great and weighty affaires, are now on their feet in their progre≈ø≈øe, journying on towards their ≈øeveral periods, where ≈øome I hope will finde their late≈øt home.

Yet among all the≈øe I ob≈øerve one, a very maine one, to ≈øleepe ≈øine die: give me leave to awaken it; it is a bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of an immen≈øe weight, and worth; ≈øuch as de≈øerves our be≈øt care, and mo≈øt ≈øevere circum≈øpection. I meane the Grand Petition long ≈øince given in by many thou≈øand Citizens again≈øt the domineering Clergy.

Wherein (for my part) although I cannot approve of all that is pre≈øented unto you, yet I do clearely profe≈ø≈øe, that a great part of it, nay the greate≈øt part thereof, is ≈øo well grounded, that my heart goes cheerefully along therewith.
It ≈øeemes that my Countrey (for which I have the honour to ≈øerve) is of the ≈øame minde, and lea≈øt you ≈øhould thinke that all faults are included within the walls of Troy, they will ≈øhew you,

p.hi: Iliacos intra muros peccatur, & extrae.

div.p: The ≈øame grievances which the City groanes under, are provinciall unto us, and I much feare they are Nationall among us all.

The pride, the avarice the ambition, and oppre≈ø≈øion, by our ruling Clergie is Epidemicall, it hath infected them all. There is not any, or ≈øcarce any of them, who is not practicall in their own great cau≈øe in hand, which they impiou≈øly doe mi≈ø call, the Piety of the times, but in truth ≈øo wrong a Piety, that I am bold to ≈øay,
In facinus jura≈ø≈øe putes.‚Äî
Here in this Petition is the di≈øea≈øe repre≈øented, here is the cure intreated.

p.hi: The number of your Petitioners is con≈øiderable, being above five and twenty hundred names, and would have been foure times as many, if that were thought materiall.

div.p: The matter in the Petition is of high import: but your Petitioners them≈øelves are all of them quiet and ≈øilent at their owne hou≈øes, humbly expecting and praying the re≈øolution of this great Senate, upon the≈øe their earne≈øt and thrice hearty de≈øires.

p.hi: Here is no noy≈øe, no numbers at your doore: they will be neither your trouble nor your jealou≈øie; for I doe not know of any one of them this day in the towne: ≈øo much they doe affie in the ju≈øtice of their Petition, and in the goodne≈ø≈øe of this hou≈øe.
If now you want any of them here to make avowance of their Petition, I am their ≈øervant. I doe appeare for them, and for my ≈øelfe, and am ready to avow this Petition in their names, and in my owne.

div.p:
Nothing doubting, but fully confident that I may ju≈øtly ≈øay of the pre≈øent u≈øage of the Hierarchy in the
Church of England, as once the Pope (Pope Adrian as I remember) ≈øaid of the Clergy in his time: A vertice capitis ad plantam pedis, nihil e≈øt ≈øanum in toto ordine Eccle≈øiastico.

p.hi: I be≈øeech you read the Petition, regard us, and relieve us.

div.head: Ma≈øter BAGSHAWES Speech in Parliament Febr. 9th. 1640. Concerning Epi≈øcopacy, and the London Petition.
div.p:
I Was ye≈øterday and the time before, for the retaining of the London Petition and am in the ≈øame minde ≈øtill; and therefore doe now ri≈øe up again≈øt the propo≈øall of that que≈øtion which is now called for; Whether Epi≈øcopacy it ≈øelfe be to be taken into con≈øideration by the Committee: wherein I doe di≈øtingui≈øh of a twofold Epi≈øcopacy the fir≈øt, in Statu puro, as it was in the Primitive times: the ≈øecond, in Statu corrupto, as it is at this day, and is ≈øo intended and meant in the London Petition. Now I hold that Epi≈øtopacy in this latter ≈øence is to be taken into con≈øideration as a thing that trencheth not onely upon the right and liberties of the Subject; of which I ≈øhall have occa≈øion to ≈øpeake hereafter. But as it is now, it trencheth upon the Crowne of England in the≈øe foure particulars, wherein
in I know, this Hou≈øe will willingly heare me,

Fir≈øt, it is maintained by the Bi≈øhop of Exeter in a Booke which he hath writ to this purpo≈øe, that Epi≈øcopacy it ≈øelfe both in the office and in the juri≈ødiction is de Iure Divino, of Divine right; which po≈øition is directly contrary to the Lawes of England, of which I will cite but two or three in ≈øtead of many more. The Statute of Carli≈øle 35. Ed. 1. mentioned in Caudries ca≈øe; in the fifth Report, ≈øaith, that the Church of England is founded in the ≈øtate of Prelacie by the Kings of England and their Progenitors. Which likewi≈øe appeares by the fir≈øt Chapter in Magna Charta, in the≈øe words, Conce≈ø≈øimus Deo & Eccle≈øiae Anglicanae omnes libertates, &c. and in the twentie fifth yeare of Edward the third, in the French Roll which I have ≈øeene, there the Archbi≈øhop and Clergie petition the King for their liberties, in the≈øe words, thus Engli≈øhed, That for the reverence of God and holy Church, and of his grace and bounty, he will confirme all tho≈øe liberties, priviledges, and rights, granted and given by him and his noble Progenitors, to the Church by their Charters: which plainly ≈øheweth, that they have their Epi≈øcopall Juri≈ødiction from the Kings of England, and not Iure divino, by divine right: and this likewi≈øe is acknowledged by them≈øelves in the Statute of 37. H. 8. cap. 17. that they have their Epi≈øcopall juri≈ødiction, and all other Eccle≈øia≈øticall juri≈ødiction what≈øoever ≈øolely and onely, by, from, and under the King.

The ≈øecond thing that is trenching upon the Crowne, is this, that it is holden at this day, that Epi≈øcopacy is in≈øeparable to the Crowne of England; and therefore it is commonly now ≈øaid, No Bi≈øhop, no King: no Miter, no Scepter: which I utterly deny; for it is plaine and apparant, that the Kings of England were long before Bi≈øhops, and have a ≈øub≈øi≈øtance without them, and have done, and may ≈øtill depo≈øe them.

The third is likewi≈øe con≈øiderable, as trenching upon the Crowne, which is that was ≈øaid under the Gallery, that Epi≈øcopacy was a third e≈øtate in Parliament, and therefore the King and Parliament could not be without them. This I utterly deny, for there are three e≈øtates without them, as namely, the King, who is the fir≈øt e≈øtate; the Lords Temporall the ≈øecond, and the Commons the third; and I know no fourth e≈øtate. Be≈øides, the Kings of England have had many Parliaments, wherein there have beene no Bi≈øhops at all: as for example, Ed. 1.24 of his reigne held his Parliament at Edmundbury, exclu≈øo Clero; and in the Parliament 7. R. 2. c. 3. & 7. R. 2. c. 12. it doth appeare, that they were enacted by the King, with the a≈ø≈øent and agreement of the Lords Temporall, and Commons, where the e≈øtates of Parliamen are mentioned, and not the Clergie. Divers other ≈øtatutes might likewi≈øe be named to this purpo≈øe, which I omit.

The fourth and la≈øt thing is of the Bi≈øhops holding of the Eccle≈øia≈øticall Courts in their owne names, and not in the name of the King, nor by Commi≈ø≈øion from him, contrary to the Statute of 1 Edw. 6. cap. 2. and contrary to the practice of Bi≈øhop Ridley, Coverdale, and Ponnet, who tooke Commi≈ø≈øions from the KING for holding their Eccle≈øia≈øticall Courts, as may be ≈øeene at this day in the Rolles.

And although it will be objected, that by a late Proclamation, in the yeare of our Lord God, 1637. wherein the opinion of the Iudges mentioned, it is declared upon their opinion, that the act of 1 Edw. 6. was repealed, and that Bi≈øhops may now keep Courts in their owne names, and ≈øend proce≈ø≈øe under their owne Seales; yet it is well knowne, that the Statute of 1 Q. Mary, which repealed the Statute of 1 Ed. 6. was it ≈øelfe repealed by the Statute of 1 Iac. cap 25. Whereupon it was holden upon
a full debate of this poynt in Parliament, 7 Iac. which I have ≈øeene that upon con≈øideration of the Statutes of 1 Iac. and 1. Eliz. cap 1. and 8 Eliz. cap. 1. that the Statute of 1 Ed. 6. was revived‚ñ™ and that Bi≈øhops ought not to keepe Courts in their owne names: So that for the≈øe rea≈øons ≈øo nearely concerning the right of the Crowne of England in the poynt of Epi≈øcopacy, I am again≈øt the propo≈øall of that que≈øtion, and am for the retaining of the London Petition, and for a thorow Reformation of all abu≈øes, and grievances of Epi≈øcopacy mentioned in the Mini≈øters Remon≈øtrance, which Reformation may perhaps ≈øerve the turne without alteration of the Government of England, into a forme of Presbytery, as it is in other Kingdomes of Scotland, France, Gen ‚Ä¢ va, and the Low Countries, which for mine owne part, had I lived in the≈øe Kingdomes, I ≈øhould have bin of the opinion of the Prote≈øtant party in point of Presbytery, becau≈øe tho≈øe Kingdomes are governed by the Civill Law, which maintaines the juri≈ødiction of the Pope and Papall Epi≈øcopacy, which the ancient Lawes of England condemne, being likewi≈øe in them≈øelves oppo≈øite to the Civill and Canon Lawes. And if notwith≈øtanding all the Reformation that can be made by the Lawes of this Land, a better forme of government may evidently appeare to us, concerning which there is no forme now before us; it is to be taken by us into con≈øideration, according to that imperiall Con≈øtitution in the≈øe words, In rebus nobis con≈øtituendis evidens utilitas e≈ø≈øe debet, ut ab eo jure recedatur quod diu aequum vi≈øum e≈øt.
And ≈øo Mr. Speaker, I ≈øhortly conclude, that for the≈øe Rea≈øons, omitting divers more, the London Petition is to be retained.

div.head: The Speeches of Sir Benjamin Rudyer in the High Court of Parliament.
div.p: WEe are here a≈ø≈øembled to doe Gods bu≈øine≈ø≈øe and the Kings, in which our owne is included, as wee are Chri≈øtians, as wee are Subjects. Let us fir≈øt feare GOD‚ñ™ then ≈øhall wee honour the King the more: for I am afrayd wee have beene the le≈ø≈øe pro≈øperous in Parliaments, becau≈øe wee have preferred other matters before Him. Let Religion be our Primum Quarite, for all things el≈øe, are but Etcaetera's to it; yet we may have them too, ≈øooner and ≈øurer, if wee give God his precedence.

We well know what di≈øturbance hath been brought upon the Church, for vain petty trifles. How the whole Church, the whole Kingdome hath beene troubled, where to place a Metaphor, an Altar. Wee have ≈øeene Mini≈øters, their Wives, Children, and Families undone, again≈øt Law, again≈øt Con≈øcience, again≈øt all Bowells of Compa≈ø≈øion, about not dancing upon Sundayes. What doe the≈øe ≈øort of men think will become of them≈øelves, when the Ma≈øter of the hou≈øe ≈øhall come, and finde
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
them thus beating their fellow ≈øervants? The≈øe Inventions were but Sives made of purpo≈øe to winnow the be≈øt men, and that's the Devills occupation. They have a minde to worry preaching, for I never yet heard of any, but diligent preachers that were vext with the≈øe and the like devices. They de≈øpi≈øe prophe≈øie, and as one ≈øaid, They would faine be at ≈øomething were like the Ma≈ø≈øe, that will not bite. A muzzl'd Religion. They would evaporate and di≈ø-≈øpirit the power and vigour of Religion, by drawing it out into ≈øolemne, ≈øpecious formalities, into ob≈øolete, antiquated Ceremonies, new furbi≈øh'd up. And this (belike) is the good worke in hand, which Dr. Heylin hath ≈øo often celebrated in his bold Pamphlets. All their Acts, and actions are ≈øo full of mixtures, involutions and complications, as nothing is cleare, nothing ≈øincere in any of their proceedings: Let them not ≈øay, that the≈øe are the perver≈øe ≈øu≈øpitious malicious interpretations of ≈øome few factious Spirits among≈øt us, when a Romani≈øt hath bragged, and congratulated in print, That the face of our Church begins to alter, the Language of our Religion to change. And Sancta Clara hath publi≈øhed, That if a Synod were held, Non intermixtis Puritanis, ≈øetting Puritanes a≈øide, our Articles and their Religion would ≈øoone be agreed. They have ≈øo brought it to pa≈ø≈øe, that under the name of Puritans, all our Religion is branded, and under a few hard words again≈øt Ie≈øuites, all popery is countenanc'd.

Who≈øoever ≈øquares his actions by any rule, either Divine or Humane, hee is a Puritan. Who≈øoever would be governed by the Kings Lawes, he is a Puritan. Hee that will not doe what≈øoever other men would have him doe, he is a Puritan. Their great worke, their Ma≈øter-piece now is, To make all tho≈øe of the Religion, to be the ≈øu≈øpected party of the Kingdome.

Let us further reflect upon the ill effect the≈øe Courts have wrought, what by a defection from us, on the one ≈øide, a ≈øeparation on the other; Some imagining whither we are tending, made ha≈øte to turne, or declare them≈øelves Papi≈øts before hand, thereby hoping to render them≈øelves the more gracious, the more acceptable. A great multitude of the Kings Subjects, ≈øtriving to hold communion with us; but ≈øeeing how far we were gone, and ≈øearing how much further we wou ‚Ä¢ d goe, were forc'd to flye the Land, ≈øome into other inhabited Countries, very many into Savago wilderne≈ø≈øes, becau≈øe the Land would not bear them. Do not they that cau≈øe the≈øe things ca≈øt a reproach upon the government?

Mr. Speaker, let it be our principall care that the≈øe wayes neither continue, nor returne upon us. If wee ≈øecure our Religion, wee ≈øhall cut off and defeat many Plots that are now on foot by Them and Others. Beleeve it Sir, Religion hath beene for a long time, and ≈øtill is the great de≈øigne upon this Kingdome. It is a knowne and practic'd principle, That they who would introduce another Religion into the Church, mu≈øt fir≈øt trouble and di≈øorder the government of the State, that ≈øo they may worke their ends, in a confu≈øion which now lyes at the doore.

I come next Mr. Speaker, to the Kings bu≈øine≈ø≈øe more particularly; which indeed is the Kingdomes, for one hath no exi≈øtence‚ñ™ no being without the other, their relation is ≈øo neere; yet ≈øome have ≈øtrongly and ≈øubtilly laboured a divorce, which hath beene the very band both of King and Kingdome.

When foundations are ≈øhaken, it is high time to looke to the building. He hath no Heart, no Head, no Soule, that is not moved in his whole man, to look upon the di≈øtre≈ø≈øes, the mi≈øeries of the Common-wealth, that is not forward in all that he is, and hath, to redre≈ø≈øe them in a right way.

The King likewi≈øe is reduced to great ≈øtraights, wherein it were undutifulne≈ø≈øe beyond inhumanity, to take advantage for him: let us rather make it an advantage for him, to doe him be≈øt ≈øervice when he hath mo≈øt need. Not to ≈øeeke our owne good, but in Him, and with Him, el≈øe wee ≈øhall commit the ≈øame crimes our ≈øelves, which wee mu≈øt condemne in others.

His Maje≈øty hath clearely and freely put him≈øelfe into the hands of this Parliament, and I pre≈øume, there is not a Man in this Hou≈øe, but feeles him≈øelfe advanc't in this high tru≈øt; but if Hee pro≈øper no better in our hands than he hath done in theirs, who have hitherto had the handling of his affaires, wee ≈øhall for ever make our ≈øelves unworthy of ≈øo gracious a confidence.

I have often thought and ≈øaid, that it mu≈øt bee ≈øome great extremity, that would recover and certifie this ≈øtate, and when th ‚Ä¢ t extremity did come, Jt would be a great hazzard whether it might prove a remedy, or ruine. We are now Mr. Speaker upon that verticall turning poynt, and therefore it is no time to palliate, to foment our owne undoing.

Let us ≈øet upon the remedy, wee mu≈øt fir≈øt know the Di≈øea≈øe: But to di≈øcover the de≈øea≈øes of the State, is (according to ≈øome) to traduce the Government; yet others are of opinion, that this is the halfe way to the Cure.

His Maje≈øty is wi≈øer than they that have advi≈øed him, and therefore hee cannot but ≈øee and feele their ≈øubverting de≈øtructive Coun≈øells, which ≈øpeake lowder than I can ≈øpeak of them: for they ring a dolefull deadly knell over the whole Kingdome. His Maje≈øty be≈øt knowes who they are: for us, let the Matters bolt out the men; their actions di≈øcover them.

They are men that talke largely of the Kings
≈øervice, have done none but their owne, and that's too evident.
They ≈øpeake highly of the Kings power, but they have made it a mi≈øerable power, that produceth nothing but weakne≈ø≈øe, both to the King and Kingdome.
They have exhau≈øted the Kings revenew to the bottome, nay through the bottome, and beyond.
They have ≈øpent va≈øt ≈øummes of money wa≈øtefully, fruitle≈øly, dangerou≈øly: So that more money without other Coun≈øells will be but a ≈øwift undoing.

They have alwayes peremptorily pur≈øued one ob≈øtinate pernicious cour≈øe. Fir≈øt, they bring things to an extremitie, then they make that extremity of their owne making, the rea≈øon of their next action, ≈øeven times wor≈øe than the former, and there wee are at this in≈øtant.

They have almo≈øt ≈øpoyled the be≈øt in≈øtituted Government in the world, for Soveraignty in a King, liberty to the Subject; the proportionable temper of both which, makes the happie≈øt ≈øtate for power, for riches, for duration.

They have unmannerly and ≈ølubbringly ca≈øt all their Projects, all their Machinations upon the King: which no wi≈øe or good Mini≈øter of State ever did, but would ≈øtill take all har≈øh, di≈øta≈øteful things upon them≈øelves, to cleare, to ≈øweeten their Ma≈øter.
They have not ≈øuffered his Maje≈øtie to appeare unto his people, in his owne native goodne≈ø≈øe.

They have eclip≈øed him by their interpo≈øition: althogh gro≈ø≈øe conden≈øe bodies may ob≈øcure, and hinder the Sun from ≈øhining out, yet is hee ≈øtill the ≈øame in his owne ≈øplendor. And when they are removed, all Creatures under him are directed by his light, comforted by his beames: But they have framed a ≈øuper≈øtitious ≈øeeming Maxime of State for their owne turne; That if a King will ≈øuffer men to be torne from him, hee ≈øhall never have
any good ≈øervice done him. When the plaine truth is, that this is the ≈øure≈øt way to pre≈øerve a King from having ill ≈øervants ab ‚Ä¢ ut him. And the Divine Truth likewi≈øe is, Take away the wicked from the King, and his Throne ≈øhall be e≈øtabli≈øhed.

Mr. Speaker, Now wee ≈øee what the ≈øores are in generall: and when more particulars ≈øhall appeare; let us be very carefull to draw out the Cores of them; not to skin them over with a ≈ølight ≈øuppurating, f ‚Ä¢ ≈øtring Cure, le≈øt they breake out againe into a greater m ≈øchiefe; con≈øider of it, con≈øult and ≈øpeake your min es.

It hath heretofore beene boa≈øted, That the King ≈øhould never call a Parliament till he had no need of his people; The≈øe were words of Divi≈øion, and malignitie. The King mu≈øt alwaies according to his occa≈øions, have u≈øe of his peoples Power, Hearts, Hands, Pur≈øes. The People will alwayes have need of the Kings Clemencie, Iu≈øtice, Protection. And this Reciprocation is the ≈øtrongest, the ≈øweete≈øt union.

It hath bin ≈øaid too of late; That a Parliament will take away more from the King, then they will give him. It may well be ≈øaid, That tho≈øe things which will fall away of them≈øelves, will enable the Subject to give him more than can be taken any way el≈øe. Projects and Monopolies are but leaking Conduit-pipes; The Exchequer it ≈øelfe at the full ≈øt, is but a Cu≈øtome; and now a broken one; frequent Parliaments onely are the Fountaine: And I doe not doubt but in this Parliament, as wee ≈øhall bee free in our advi≈øes, ≈øo ≈øhall wee be the more free of our pur≈øes, that his Maje≈øtie may experimentally finde the reall difference of b ‚Ä¢ tter Coun≈øells, the true ≈øolid grounds of rai≈øing and e≈øtabli≈øhing his Greatne≈ø≈øe, never to be brought againe (by Gods ble≈ø≈øing ‚Ä¢ ) to ≈øuch dangerous, ≈øuch de≈øperate perplexities.

Mr. Speaker, I confe≈ø≈øe I have now gone in a way much again≈øt my Nature, and ≈øomewhat again≈øt my Cu≈øtome heretof ‚Ä¢ re u≈øed in this place. But the deplorable, di≈ømall condition both of Church and State have ≈øo far wrought upon my judgement, as it hath convinced my di≈øpo≈øition, yet am I not Vir Sanguinum; I love no mans ruine; I thanke God, I neither hate any mans per≈øon, nor envie any mans fortune, onely I am zealous of a thorow Reformation in a time that exacts, that extorts it. Which I humbly be≈øe ‚Ä¢ ch this Hou≈øe may bee done with as much lenity, as much moderation, as the publick ≈øafety of the King and Kingdome can po≈ø≈øibly admit.

div.head: Another Speech of Sir Benjamin Rudyer, in the High Court of Parliament.
div.p: IT will become us thankfully to acknowledge the prudent and painfull endeavours of my Lords, the Peeres, Commi≈ø≈øioners intreating with the Scots, in mediating with the King: whereby (God a≈ø≈øisting) wee are now probably drawing neare to a ble≈ø≈øed peace.

His Maje≈øty in his Wi≈øedome and Goodne≈ø≈øe, is graciou≈øly plea≈øed to give his royall a≈ø≈øent to their Acts of Parliament, wherein the Articles of their A≈ø≈øembly are likewi≈øe included: In≈øomuch as their Religion, their Lawes, their Liberties are ratified and e≈øtabli≈øhed: Be≈øides, their Grievances reliev'd, and redre≈øs'd; For which Wee u≈øe to give the King Money, and are ≈øtill ready to doe it. This (although it be a large) yet it is not received as a full ≈øatisfaction.

Be≈øides, when They came into England, they publi≈øhed in a Remon≈øtrance, That they would take nothing of the Engli≈øh, but what they would pay for, or give ≈øecurity. We have defrayed them hitherto, and are provided to doe it longer.

They did well remember, that we a≈ø≈øi≈øted them in the
time of their Reformation: And it is not to be forgotten; that we did beare our owne charges.
Concerning mutuall Restitution of Ships, and Goods, My Lords the Commi≈ø≈øioners have very fairely and di≈øcreetly accommodated that particular already.

As for inferentiall con≈øequentiall dammages, ≈øuch a Repre≈øentation would but mini≈øter unacceptable matter of Difference and Conte≈øtation, which among≈øt friends ought to be warily and wi≈øely avoyded.

We could alleadge and truely too, That Northumberland, New-Ca≈øtle, and the Bi≈øhoprick, will not recover their former ≈øtate the≈øe twenty yeares. Wee have heard it ≈øpoken here in this hou≈øe, by an under≈øtanding knowing member in the particular, that the Coale-Mines of New-Ca≈øtle will not bee ≈øet right againe for out hundred thou≈øand pounds; be≈øides the over-price of Co ‚Ä¢ les which all the while it hath, and will ca≈øt this City, and „Äà‚óä„Äâ parts of the Kingdome. A great ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ale more of this nature might be rehear≈øed; but I delight not to pre≈ø≈øe ≈øuch renter ≈øtretched Arguments. Let us on both ≈øides rather thanke God, by proceeding in the way he hath ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d before us, and not wry his way to ours. Time and his Ble≈øsing will repaire all our implicit Dammages, with many pro≈øperous explicite advantages.

They ≈øay that they doe not make any formall demand; But they doe make a ≈øumme to appeare; five hundred and foureteene thou≈øand pounds, more than „Äà‚óä„Äâ gave the King at once. Aportentous Apparition! which ≈øhewes it ≈øelfe in a very dry time, when the Kings revenue is totally exhau≈øted, his Debts exce≈ø≈øively multiplied, the Kingdom generally impoveri≈øhed, by grievous burthens, and di≈øordered Cour≈øes: All this ≈øupply is to be drawne out of us onely, without the lea≈øt helpe from any of his Majesties other Dominions: which to my ≈øeeming will be an utter draining of the people; unle≈ø≈øe England bee Puteus inexhau≈øtus as the Popes were wont to call it.

Notwith≈øtanding Sir, now that I have in part opened the ≈øtate we are in though nothing ≈øo exactly as they have done theirs: I ≈øhall mo≈øt willingly and heartily affoord the Scots what≈øoever is ju≈øt, Equitable and Honourable, even to a convenient, con≈øiderable round ≈øumme of Money, towards their lo≈ø≈øes and expences, That we may goe off with a friendly and hand≈øome loos. If they reject it, we ≈øhall improve our Cau≈øe.

It was never yet thought Mr. Speaker, any great wi≈øedome over-much to trust a ≈øucce≈ø≈øeful Sword. A man that walkes upon a ri≈øing ground, the further he goes, the larger is his Pro≈øpect. Succe≈ø≈øe inlarges mens de≈øires, extends their ambition, it breeds thoughts in them they never thought before; This is naturall and u≈øuall.

But the Scots being truely touched with Religion, according to their profe≈øsion, that onely is able to make them keep their word: for Religion is ≈øtronger and wi≈øer than Rea≈øon, or Rea≈øon of State.

Beyond all this, Mr. Speaker, the remarkable Traces of Gods wonderfull Providence in this ≈øtrange worke, are ≈øo many, ≈øo apparant, as I cannot but hope almo≈øt to beliefe: That the ≈øame all-governing mercifull hand, will conduct and lead us to a happy Conclu≈øion, will contract a clo≈øe ‚Ä¢ firmer union between the two Nations, than any meere humane Policy could ever have effected: which inestimable Ben fits to both, in advancing the truth of Religion, in exalting the greatne≈ø≈øe of the King, in ≈øecuring the peace of his Kingdomes, against all Malicious, Envious, Ambitious oppo≈øites, to Religion, to the King, to his Kingdomes; wherein I pre≈øume, all our de≈øires and prayers doe meet.

div.head: Another Speech of Sir Benjamin Rudyer in the High Court of Parliament.
div.p: J Doe verily believe, that there are many of the Clergie in our Church, who doe think the ≈øimplicity of the Go≈øpell, too mean a vocation for them to ≈øerve in: They mu≈øt have a ≈øpecious, pompous, ≈øumptuous Religion, with additionalls of Temporall greatne≈ø≈øe, Authority, Negotiation: Notwith≈øtanding, they all know better than I, what Fathers, Schoolemen, Councells are again≈øt their mixing them≈øelves in ≈øecular affaires.

This Roman Ambition will at length bring in the Roman Religion, and at la≈øt a haughty in≈øolence even again≈øt ≈øupreame power it ≈øelfe, if it bee not timely and wi≈øely pre
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nted.

They have among≈øt them an Apothegm of their owne making, which is, No Miter, no Scepter, when wee know by deare experience, that if the Mitre be once in danger, they care not to throw the Scepter after, to confound the whole Kingdome for their intere≈øt.

And Hi≈øtories will tell us, that when≈øoever the Clergie went high, Monarchy ≈øtill went lower: If they could
not make the Monarch the head of their owne Faction, they would be ≈øure to make him le≈ø≈øe: witne≈ø≈øe one example for all, The Popes working the Emperour out of Italy.

Some of ours, as ≈øoone as they are Bi≈øhops adepto fine, ce≈ø≈øant Motus, They will preach no longer, their office then is to governe. But in my opinion they governe wor≈øe than they Preach, though they preach not at all; for wee ≈øee to what pa≈ø≈øe their government hath brought us.

In conformity to them≈øelves, They ≈øilence others al≈øo, though Hierom in one of his Epi≈øtles ≈øaith, that even a Bi≈øhop, let him be of never ≈øo blamele≈ø≈øe a life, yet he doth more hurt by by his licence, then he can doe good by his example.

Mr. Speaker, It now behooves us, to re≈øtraine the Bi≈øhops to the duties of their Function, as they may never more hanker after heterogeneous extravagant employments: Not be ≈øo ab≈øolute, ≈øo ≈øingle and ≈øolitary in actions of Moment, as Excommunication, Ab≈øolution, Ordination, and the like: but to joyne ≈øome of the Mini≈øtry with them, and further to regulate them according to the u≈øage of Ancient Churches, in the be≈øt times, that by a well-temper'd Government, they may not have power hereafter, to corrupt the Church, to undoe the Kingdome.

When they are thus circum≈øcribed, and the publique ≈øecur'd from their Eruptions, then ≈øhall not I grudge them a liberall plentifull ≈øub≈øi≈øtence: el≈øe I am ≈øure they can nev ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ be given to Ho≈øpitality.
Although the calling of the Clergie be all glorious within, yet if they have not a large, con≈øiderable, outward ≈øupport, they cannot be freed from vulgar Contempt.

It will alwaies be fit, that the flouri≈øhing of the Church ≈øhould hold proportion with the flouri≈øhing of the Common-wealth, wherein it is. If we dwell in hou≈øes of Ceaar, why ≈øhould they dwell in skins? And I hope, I ≈øhall never ≈øee a good Bi≈øhop left wor≈øe than a Par≈øon without a Gleab.

Certainly Sir, this ≈øuperintendencie of eminent men, Bi≈øhops over divers Churches, is the mo≈øt Primitive, the most ≈øpreading, the mo≈øt la≈øting Government of the Church. Wherefore while≈øt we are earne≈øt to take away Innovations, let us beware wee bring not in the greate≈øt Innovation that ever was in England.

I doe very well know, what very many doe very ≈øervently de≈øire. But let us well bethinke our ≈øelves, whether a popular Democraticall Government of the Church (though fit for other places) will be either ≈øutable or acceptable to a Regall, Monarchicall Government of the State.

Every man can ≈øay, (It is ≈øo common and knowne a Truth) that ≈øuddaine and great changes both in naturall and Politick bodies have dangerous opperations: and give mee leave to ≈øay, that we cannot pre≈øently ≈øee to the end of ≈øuch a con≈øequence, e≈øpecially in ≈øo great a Kingdome as this, and where Epi≈øcopacie is ≈øo wrap'd and involv'd in the Lawes of it.

Wherefore Mr. Speaker, my humble Motion is, that we may puni≈øh the pre≈øent offenders, reduce and pre≈øerve the Calling for better men hereafter. Let us remember with fre≈øh thankfulne≈ø≈øe to God, tho≈øe glorious Martyr-Bi≈øhops who were burn'd for our Religion in the times of Popery, who by their learning, zeale, and con≈øtancy, upheld and convey'd it downe to us.

We have ≈øome good Bi≈øhops ≈øtill, who doe Preach every Lords Day, and are therefore worthy of double honour; they have ≈øuffered enough already in the Di≈øea≈øe: I ≈øhall bee ≈øorry we ≈øhould make them ≈øuffer more in the Remedy.

div.head: A me≈ø≈øage delivered from the Commons to the Lords of the Vpper Hou≈øe in Parliament, by Mr. Pym, Novemb. 11. 1640.
div.p: THe Knights, Citizens, and Burge≈ø≈øes, now a≈ø≈øembled for the Commons in Parliament, have received information of divers traiterous de≈øignes and practices of a great Peere of this Hou≈øe; and by vertue of a command from them, I doe here, in the name of the Commons now a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament, and in the name of all the Commons of England, accu≈øe Thomas Earle of Strafford, Lo. Lieutenant of Ireland, of high Trea≈øon: and they have commanded me further, to de≈øire your Lord≈øhips that he may be ≈øeque≈øtred from Parliament, and forthwith committed to pri≈øon. They have further commanded mee, to let you know that they will within a very few dayes re≈øort to your Lord≈øhips, with the particular Articles and grounds of this accu≈øation. And they doe further de≈øire, that your Lord≈øhips will thinke upon ≈øome convenient and fit way, that the pa≈ø≈øage betwixt England and Ireland, for his Majesties ≈øubjects of both Kingdomes, may be free, notwith≈øtanding any restraint to the contrarie.

p.hi: The Lord Lieutenant being required to withdraw, and after a debate thereof called in, kneeled at the Bar, and after ≈øtanding up, the L. Keeper ≈øpake as followeth.
My Lord of Strafford:

div.p:
THe Hou≈øe of Commons in their owne name, and in the name of the whole Commons of England, have
this day accu≈øed your Lord≈øhip to the Lords of the Higher Hou≈øe of Parliament of high trea≈øon. The articles they will within a very few dayes produce: In the meane time they have de≈øired of my Lords, and may Lords have accordingly re≈øolved, that your Lord≈øhip ≈øhall be committed to ≈øafe cu≈øtody to the Gentleman ∆≤≈øher, and be ≈øeque≈øtred from the Hou≈øe, till your Lord≈øhip ≈øhall cleare your ≈øelfe of the accu≈øations that ≈øhall be laid again≈øt you.

div.head: Articles of the Commons a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament, again≈øt Thomas Earle of Strafford, in maintenance of his accu≈øation, whereby he ≈øtands charged of High Trea≈øon.
div.p: 1. THat he the ≈øaid Thomas, Earle of Strafford, hath traiterou≈øly endevoured to ≈øubvert the fundamentall Lawes and government of the Realmes of England and Ireland, and in ≈øtead thereof to introduce on Arbitrary and Tyrannicall Government again≈øt Law, which hee hath declared by traiterous words, coun≈øels, and actions, and by giving his Maje≈øtie advice, by force of Armes to compell his loyall Subjects to ≈øubmit thereunto.

2. That hee hath traiterou≈øly a≈ø≈øumed to him≈øelfe Regall power over the lives, liberties, per≈øons, lands, and goods of his Maje≈øties Subject ‚Ä¢ in England and Ireland, and hath exerci≈øed the ≈øame tyrannically, to the ≈øubver≈øion
and undoing of many, both of Peeres and others of his Maje≈øties Liege people.

3. That the better to enrich and enable him≈øelfe to goe thorow with his traiterous de≈øignes, hee hath detained a great part of his Maje≈øties revenue, without giving legall account; and hath taken great ≈øummes out of the Exchequer, converting them to his owne u≈øe, when his Maje≈øtie was nece≈ø≈øitated for his owne urgent occa≈øions, and his Army had beene a long time unpaid.

4. That he hath traiterou≈øly abu≈øed the power and authoritie of his government, to the encrea≈øing, countenancing, and encouraging of Papi≈øts, that ≈øo hee might ≈øettle a mutuall dependance and confidence betwixt him≈øelfe and that partie, and by their help pro≈øecute, and accompli≈øh his malicious and tyrannicall de≈øignes.
5. That hee hath maliciou≈øly endevoured to ≈øtir up enmitie and ho≈øtilitie between his Majesties ≈øubjects of England, and tho≈øe of Scotland.

6. That he hath traiterou≈øly broken the great tru≈øt repo≈øed in him by his Maje≈øtie, of Lieutenant Generall of his Army, by wilfully betraying divers of his Maje≈øties Subjects to death, his Army to a di≈øhonourable defeat by the Scots at Newborn, and the Towne of New-Ca≈øtle into their hands, to the end, that by the effu≈øion of bloud, by di≈øhonour, and ≈øo great a lo≈ø≈øe of New-Ca≈øtle, his Maje≈øties Realme of England might be engaged in a Nationall and irreconciliable quarrell with the Scots.

7. That to pre≈øerve him≈øelfe from being que≈øtioned for tho≈øe and other his traiterous cour≈øes, hee laboured to ≈øubvert the right of Parliaments, and the ancient cour≈øe of Parliamentarie proceedings, and by fal≈øe and malicious ≈ølanders to incen≈øe his Maje≈øtie against Parliaments. By which words, coun≈øels, and actions, hee hath traiterou≈øly, and contrary to his allegiance, laboured to alienate the hearts of the Kings Liege people from his Majestie, to ≈øet a divi≈øion betweene them, and to ruine and de≈øtroy his
Maje≈øties Kingdomes, for which they impeach him of high Trea≈øon again≈øt our Soveraigne Lord the King, his Crown and dignitie.

8. And he the ≈øaid Earle of Strafford was Lord Deputie of Ireland, and Lieutenant Generall of the Army there, viz. His mo≈øt excellent Maje≈øtie, for his Kingdomes both of England and Ireland, and the L. Pre≈øident of the North, during the time that all and everie the crimes and offences before ≈øet forth were done and committed, and hee the ≈øaid Earle was Lieutenant Generall of all his Maje≈øties army in the North parts of England, during the time that the crimes and offences in the fifth and ≈øixth articles ≈øet forth were done and committed.

9. And the ≈øaid Commons by protestations, ≈øaving to them≈øelves the libertie of exhibiting at any time here after any other accu≈øation or impeachment again≈øt the ≈øaid Earle, and al≈øo of replying to the an≈øwers that hee the ≈øaid Earle ≈øhall make unto the ≈øaid articles, or to any of them, and of offering proves al≈øo of the premi≈ø≈øes, or any of them, or any other impeachment or accu≈øation that ≈øhall be exhibited by them, as the cau≈øe ≈øhall according to the cour≈øe of Parliaments require, doe pray that the ≈øaid Earle may be put to an≈øwer for all and every the premi≈ø≈øes, that ≈øuch proceedings, examinations, trials, and judgements may be upon everie of them had and u≈øed, as is agreeable to Law and Iu≈øtice.

div.head: The further impeachment of Thomas Earle of Strafford by the Commons a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament. 1640
div.p: WHereas the ≈øaid Commons have already exhibited Articles again≈øt the ≈øaid Earle formerly expre≈ø≈øed &c. Now the ≈øaid Commons doe further impeach the ≈øaid Earle as followeth, &c.
1. That he the ≈øaid Earle of Strafford the 21. day of March, in the 8. yeare of his now Maje≈øties Reigne, was pre≈øident of the Kings Coun≈øell in the Northerne parts of England.

That the ≈øaid Earle being pre≈øident of the ≈øaid Coun≈øell on the 21. day of March a Commi≈ø≈øion under the great Seal of England, with certaine Schedules of in≈øtructions thereunto annexed, was directed to the ≈øaid Earle, or others the Commi≈ø≈øioners therein named, wherby among≈øt other things power and authority is limited to the ≈øaid Earle, and others the Commi≈ø≈øioners therein named, to heare and determine all offences, and mi≈ødemeanors, ≈øuits, debates, controver≈øies and demaunds, cau≈øes, things and matters, what≈øoever therein contained, and within certaine precincts in the ≈øaid Northerne parts therein ≈øpecified, and in ≈øuch manner as by the ≈øaid Schedule is limited and appointed.

And in the ≈øaid twelfth yeare of his Maje≈øties reigne, the ≈øaid Earle of Strafford did trayterou≈øly cau≈øe certaine troops of Hor≈øe and Foot, armed in warlike manner, and in warlike aray, with force and Armes to expell Richard Butler from the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Ca≈øtle Cumber, in the Territory of Idough, in the ≈øaid Realme of Jreland, and did likewi≈øe and in like warlike manner, expell divers of his Maje≈øties Subjects from their hou≈øes, families, & po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, as namely Ed. Brenman, Owen Oberman, Patrick Oberman, Sir Cyprian Horsfield, & divers others, to the number of about an hundred families, and took and impri≈øoned them and their wives, and carryed them pri≈øoners to Dublin, and there detained them untill they did yield up, ≈øurrender, or relea≈øe their re≈øpective e≈øtates and rights.

And the ≈øaid Earle in like warlike manner, hath during his government of the ≈øaid Kingdome of Ireland, ≈øubdued divers others of his Maje≈øties Subjects ea≈øily to his will, and thereby, and by the meanes afore≈øaid, hath levied warre within the ≈øaid Realm again≈øt his Maje≈øty, and his liege people of that Kingdome.

16 That the ≈øaid Earle of Strafford, the two and twentieth of February, in the ≈øeventh yeare of his now Maje≈øties Reigne, intending to oppre≈ø≈øe the ≈øaid ≈øubjects of Ireland, did make a propo≈øition, and obtained from his Maje≈øtie an allowance, that no complaint of injustice or oppre≈øsion done in Ireland, ≈øhould be received in England again≈øt any, unle≈ø≈øe it fir≈øt appeared, that the party made first his addre≈ø≈øe to him the ≈øaid Earle: and the ≈øaid Earle having by ≈øuch u≈øurped, tyrannicall, and ex ‚Ä¢ rbitant power, expre≈ø≈øed in the former Articles, de≈øtroyed the Peeres and other Subjects of that Kingdome of Ireland, in their Lives, Con≈øciences, Land, Liberties, and E≈øtates, the ≈øaid Earle to the intent the better to maintaine and ≈øtrengthen his power, and to bring the people into a di≈øaffection of his Maje≈øtie, as afore≈øaid, did u≈øe his Maje≈øties name in the execution of his ≈øaid power.

And to prevent the Subjects of that Realme of all meanes of complaints to his Maje≈øty, and of redre≈ø≈øe again≈øt him and his agents, did i≈ø≈øue a Proclamation, bearing date the ≈øeventeenth day of Septmber, in the eleventh yeare of his Majesties Reigne, thereby commanding all the Nobility, undertakers, and others who held e≈øtates and offices in the ≈øaid Kingdome, (except ≈øuch as were imployed in his Maje≈øties ≈øervice, or attending in England by his ≈øpeciall command) to make their per≈øonall re≈øidence in the ≈øaid Kingdome of Ireland, and not to depart thence without licence of him≈øelfe.

p.hi:
