And the ≈øaid Earle hath ≈øince i≈ø≈øued other Proclamations to the ≈øame purpo≈øe, by meanes whereof the Subjects of the ≈øaid Realme are re≈øtrained from ≈øeeking reliefe again≈øt the
oppre≈ø≈øions of the ≈øaid Earle, without his licence: which Proclamation the ≈øaid Earle hath by ≈øeverall rigorous wayes, as by fine, impri≈øonment, and otherwi≈øe, put in execution on his Maje≈øties Subjects, as namely, one ‚Äî Parry and others, who came over onely to complain of the exorbitances and oppre≈ø≈øions of the ≈øaid Earle.

div.p: 17 That the ≈øaid Earle having by ≈øuch meanes as afore-≈øaid, ≈øubverted the Government and Lawes of the Kingdome of Ireland, did in March in the ≈øixteenth yeare of his Maje≈øties Reigne, in ≈øcandall of his Maje≈øty, of all his Kingdomes, and in further Execution of his wicked purpo≈øes afore≈øaid, ≈øpeaking of the Armies in Ireland, declare, that his Majesty was ≈øo well plea≈øed with the Army of Ireland, and the con≈øequence thereof, that his Maje≈øty would certainly make the ≈øame a patterne for all his three Kingdomes.

18 That the ≈øaid Earle of Strafford, for the better effecting of his traiterous de≈øignes, and wicked purpo≈øes, did indevour to draw dependency upon him≈øelfe of the Papi≈øts in both Kingdomes of England and Ireland, and to that end during the time of government in Ireland, he re≈øtored divers Frieries, and Ma≈ø≈øe-hou≈øes, (which had beene formerly ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed by precedent Deputies of that Kingdome, two of which hou≈øes were in the City of Dublin, and had beene a≈øsigned to the u≈øe of the Vniver≈øity there) to the pretended owners thereof, who have ≈øince imployed the ≈øame to the exerci≈øe of the Popi≈øh Religion.

And in the Moneth of May and Iune la≈øt, the ≈øaid Earle did rai≈øe an Armie in the ≈øaid Realme of England con≈øi≈øting of eight thou≈øand foot, all of which, except one thou≈øand, or thereabouts, were Papi≈øts, and the ≈øaid one thou≈øand were drawne out of the old Army there, con≈øi≈øting of two thou≈øand foote, and in their places there were a thou≈øand Papi≈øts, or thereabouts put into the ≈øaid old Army by the ≈øaid Earle.

And the more to ingage and tye the new Army of Papi≈øts to him≈øelfe, and to incourage them, and to di≈øcourage and weare out the old Armie, the ≈øaid Earle did ≈øo provide; That the ≈øaid new Army of Papi≈øts were du ‚Ä¢ ly paye ‚Ä¢ , and had all nece≈ø≈øaries provided for them, and permitted the exerci≈øe of their Religion, but the ≈øaid old Army were for the ≈øpace of one whole yeare and upwards unpaid.

And that the ≈øaid Earle being appoynted a Commi≈øsioner with eleven ≈øeverall Counties in the Northern parts of England, for compounding with Recu≈øants for their forfeitures due to his Maje≈øty; which Commi≈ø≈øion beareth date the eighth day of Iuly, in the fifth yeare of his Maje≈øties Reigne that now is, and being al≈øo Receiver of the Compo≈øition Money thereby ari≈øing, and of other debts, Duties, and penalties for his Maje≈øties u≈øe, by Letters Patents dated the 9. day of the ≈øaid Iuly: he, to engage the ≈øaid Recu≈øants to him, did compound with with them at low and under rates, and provided, that they ≈øhould bee di≈øcharged of all proceedings again≈øt them, in all his Maje≈øties Courts, both temporall and Eccle≈øia≈øticall, in manife≈øt breach of, and contrary to the Lawes and Statutes of this Realme, in that behalfe e≈øtabli≈øhed.

19 That the ≈øaid Earle having taxed and levied the ≈øaid impo≈øitions, and rai≈øed the ≈øaid Monopolies, and committed the ≈øaid oppre≈ø≈øions in his Maje≈øties name, and as by his Maje≈øties Royall command, he the ≈øaid Earle in May the 15 yeare of his Majesties Reigne, did of his owne authority contrive and frame a new and unu≈øuall oath, by the purport whereof among many other things, the party taking the ≈øaid oath, was to ≈øweare that he ≈øhould not prote≈øt again≈øt any of his Maje≈øties royall commands, but ≈øubmit them≈øelves in all obedience thereunto. Which oath he ≈øo contrived to enforce the ≈øame on the ≈øubjects of the Scotti≈øh Nation, inhabiting in Ireland, and out of a hatred to the ≈øaid Nation,
and to put them to a di≈øcontent with his Maje≈øty, & his government there, and compelled divers of his Maje≈øties ≈øaid ≈øubjects there to take the ≈øaid oath, ≈øome he grievou≈øly fined and impri≈øoned, and others he de≈øtroyed and exiled, and namely the 10 of October, Anno Dom. 1639. He fined Henry Steward and his wife, who refu≈øed to take the ≈øaid oath, 5000. pounds a piece, and their 2. daughters and Iames Gray, 3000. pounds a piece, and impri≈øoned them for not paying the ≈øaid fines. The ≈øaid Henry Stewards wife and daughters, and Iames Gray, being the Kings liege people of the Scotti≈øh Nation, and divers others he u≈øed in like manner, and the ≈øaid Earle upon that occa≈øion did declare, that the ≈øaid oath did not onely oblige them in point of allegiance to his Maje≈øty, and acknowledgement of his Supremacie only, but to the Ceremonies and governement of the Church e≈øtabli≈øhed; or to be e≈øtabli≈øhed by his Maje≈øties Royall authoritie; and ≈øaid, that the refu≈øers to obey, he would pro≈øecute to the blood.

20 That the ≈øaid Earle in the 15. and 16. yeares of his Maje≈øties Reigne, and divers yeares pa≈øt, laboured, and endevoured to beget in his Maje≈øtie an ill opinion of his ≈øubjects, namely, tho≈øe of the Scotti≈øh Nation, and diver≈øe and ≈øundry times, and e≈øpecially ≈øince the Pacification made by his Maje≈øtie with his ≈øaid Subjects of Scotland in Summer, in the 15 yeare of his Maje≈øties Reigne; he, the ≈øaid Earle did labour and endeavour to per≈øwade, incite, and provoke his Maje≈øtie to an offen≈øive warre again≈øt his ≈øaid Subjects of the Scotti≈øh Nation: And the ≈øaid Earle, by his coun≈øell, actions, and endeavours, hath beene and is a principall and chiefe incend ‚Ä¢ ary of the warre and di≈øcord betweene his Maje≈øtie and his Subjects of England, and the ≈øaid Subjects of Scotland, and hath declared and advi≈øed his Maje≈øty, that the demand made by the Scots in this Parliament were a ≈øufficient cau≈øe of warre again≈øt them

The ≈øaid Earle having formerly expre≈ø≈øed the height &
rancor of his minde towards his Subjects of the Scotti≈øh Nation, viz. the tenth day of October, in the 15. yeare of his Maje≈øties Re ‚Ä¢ gne, he ≈øaid that the Nation of the Scots were ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ b ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s, and traytors, and hee beeing then about to come to England, he then further ≈øaid, that if it plea≈øed his Master (meaning his Maje≈øty) to ≈øend him backe againe, hee would root cut of the ≈øaid Kingdome (meaning the Kingdom of Ireland) the Scotti≈øh Nation both root and branch.

Some Lords and others, who had taken the ≈øaid oath in the precedent Article onely excepted: and the ≈øayd Earle hath cau≈øed divers of the ≈øaid ≈øhips and goods of the Scots to bee ≈øtayed, ≈øeized, and mole≈øted, to the intent to ≈øet on the ≈øaid warre.

21. That the ≈øaid Earle of Strafford, ≈øhortly after his ≈øpeeches mentioned in the la≈øt precedent Article, to wit, in the fifteenth yeare of his Maje≈øties Reigne, came into this Realme of England, and was made Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, and continued his government of that Kingdome by a Deputy: At his arrivall here, finding that his Maje≈øtie with much wi≈øedome and goodne≈ø≈øe had compo≈øed the troubles in the North, and had made a Pacification with his Subjects of Scotland; he laboured by all meanes to procure his Maje≈øty to breake that Pacification, incen≈øing his Majesty again≈øt his Subjects of that Kingdome, and the proceedings of the Parliament there.

And having incen≈øed his Maje≈øtie to an offen≈øive war again≈øt his ≈øaid Subjects of Scotland, by Sea and by Land, and by pretext thereof, to rai≈øe Forces for the maintenance of that war, he coun≈øelled his Maje≈øty to call a Parlament in England, yet the ≈øaid Earle intended, if the ≈øaid proceedings of that Parliament ≈øhould not be ≈øuch as would ≈øtand with the ≈øaid Earle of Straffords mi≈øchievous de≈øignes he would then procure his Maje≈øtie to breake the ≈øame; and by wayes of force and power, to rai≈øe monies upon the ≈øaid ≈øubjects of this Kingdome.

And for the incouragement of his Maje≈øtie to hearken
to his advice, he did before his Maje≈øty and his privie Coun≈øell, then ≈øitting in Coun≈øell, make a large Declaration, that he would ≈øerve his Maje≈øty in any other way, inca≈øe the Parliament ≈øhould not ≈øupply him.

22 That in the moneth of March, before the beginning of the la≈øt Parliament, the ≈øaid Earle of Stafford went into Ireland, and procured the Parliament of that Kingdome to declare their a≈ø≈øi≈øtance in a war again≈øt the Scots. And gave directions for the rai≈øing of an Army con≈øi≈øting of 8000. foot, and 1000. hor≈øe, being for the mo≈øt part Papi≈øts, as afore≈øaid. And confederating with one Sir George R ‚Ä¢ dcliffe, did together with him the ≈øaid Sir George, trayterou≈øly con≈øpire to employ the ≈øaid Army for the ruine and de≈øtruction of the Kingdome of England, and of his Majesties Subjects, and of altering and ≈øubverting of the fundamentall Laws of this Kingdome.

And ≈øhortly after, the ≈øaid Earle of Strafford returned into England, and to ≈øundry per≈øons declared his opinion to be, that his Maje≈øty ≈øhould fir≈øt try the Parliament here, and if that did not ≈øupply him according to his occa≈øions, he might u≈øe then his Prerogative as he plea≈øed, to levie what he needed, and that he ≈øhould bee acquitted both of God and man, hee tooke ≈øome other cour≈øes to ≈øupply him≈øelfe, though it were again≈øt the will of his Subjects.

23. That upon the thirteenth day of Aprill la≈øt, the Parliament of England met, and the Commons hou≈øe (then being the repre≈øentative Body of all the Commons in the Kingdome) did according to the tru≈øt repo≈øed in them, enter into debate and con≈øideration of the great grievances of of this Kingdome, both in re≈øpect of Religion, and the publike libertie of the Kingdome, and his Maje≈øtie referring chiefly to the Earle of Strafford, and the Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, the ordering and di≈øpo≈øing of all matters concerning the Parliament: He the ≈øaid Earle of Strafford, with
the a≈øi≈øtance of the ≈øaid Archbi≈øhop, did procure his Maje≈øty by ≈øundry ≈øpeeches and me≈ø≈øages, to urge the ≈øaid Commons hou≈øe to enter into ≈øome re≈øolution for his Maje≈øties ≈øupply, for maintenance of his warre again≈øt his Subjects of Scotla ‚Ä¢ d, before any cour≈øe was taken for the reliefe of the great and pre≈ø≈øing grievances, wherewith this Kingdome was then afflicted. Whereupon, a demand was then made from his Maje≈øty, of 12. Sub≈øidies, for the relea≈øe of ≈øhip-money onely; and while the ≈øaid Commons then a≈ø≈øembled (with expre≈ø≈øions of great affection to his Maje≈øtie and his ≈øervice) were in debate and con≈øideration of ≈øome ≈øupply, before re≈øolution by them made, he the ≈øaid Earle of Strafford, with the helpe and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the ≈øaid Archbi≈øhop, did procure his Majesty to di≈ø≈øolve the la≈øt Parliament, upon the 5. day of May la≈øt: and upon the ≈øame day the ≈øaid Earle of Strafford did treacherou≈øly, fal≈øely, and maliciou≈øly endeavour to incen≈øe his Maje≈øty again≈øt his loving & faithfull Subjects, who had been members of the ≈øaid hou≈øe of Commons, by telling his Majesty, they had denyed to ≈øupply him. And afterward upon the ≈øame, did treacherou≈øly and wickedly coun≈øell and advi≈øe his Maje≈øty to this effects, viz. that having tryed the affections of his people, he was loo≈øe and ab≈øolved from all rules of government, and was to doe every thing that power would admit, and that his Maje≈øty had tryed all ways and was refu≈øed, and ≈øhould be acquitted both of God and man; & that he had an Army in Ireland (meaning the Army above mentioned, con≈øi≈øting of Papi≈øts, his dependants as is afore≈øaid) which he might imploy to reduce this Kingdome to obedience.

24 That in the ≈øame month of May, he the ≈øaid Earl of Strafford, fal≈øly, treacherou≈øly, and maliciou≈øly, publi≈øhed and declared before others of his Maje≈øties Privie Coun≈øell, that the Parliament of England had for≈øaken the King, and that in denying to ≈øupply the King, they had given him the advantage to ≈øupply him≈øelfe by other wayes:
and divers other times he did maliciou≈øly, wickedly, and fal≈øely publi≈øh and declare, that ≈øeeing the Parliament had refu≈øed to ≈øupply his Majesty in the ordinary and u≈øuall way, the King might provide for the Kingdome in ≈øuch waies, as he ≈øhould hold fit, and that he was not to ≈øuffer him≈øelfe to be ma≈øtered by the frowardne≈ø≈øe of the people.

And having ≈øo maliciou≈øly ≈ølandered the ≈øaid hou≈øe of Commons, he did with the helpe and advice of the ≈øaid Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury and the Lord Finch, late Lord Keeper of the great Seal of England: cau≈øe to be printed, and publi≈øhed in his Maje≈øties name, a fal≈øe and ≈øcandalous book entituled, his Maje≈øties Declaration of the cau≈øes that mooved him to di≈ø≈øolve the last Parliament, full of bitter and malicious invectives, and fal≈øe, and ≈øcandalous a≈øper≈øions again≈øt the ≈øaid hou≈øe of Commons.

25 That not long after the di≈ø≈øolution of the ≈øaid la≈øt Parliament, (viz. In the moneths of May and Iune) he the Earle of Strafford, did advi≈øe the King to goe on rigorou≈øly in leavying the Ship-money, and did procure the Sheriffes of ≈øeverall Countries to be ≈øent for for not leavying the Ship-money, divers of which were threatned by him to be ≈øued in the Starre-Chamber, and afterwards by his advice were ≈øued in the Star-chamber, for not leavying the ≈øame, and divers of his Maje≈øties loving Subjects were ≈øent for and impri≈øoned by his advice, about that and other illegall payments.

And a great loane of a hundred thou≈øand pounds was demanded of the City of London, and the Lord Major, and the Aldermen and the Sheriffes of the ≈øaid City, were often ≈øent for by his advice to the Councell Table, to give an account of their proceedings in rai≈øing of Ship-money, and furthering of that loane, and were required to certifie the names of ≈øuch Inhabitants of the ≈øaid City as were fit to lend, which they with much humility refu≈øing to doe, he the
≈øaid Earle of Strafford did u≈øe the≈øe or the like ≈øpeeches: viz. That they de≈øerved to be put to Fine and Ran≈øom, and that no good would be done with them, till an example were made of them, and they were laid by the heeles, and ≈øome of the Aldermen hanged up.

26 That the ≈øaid Earle of Strafford by his wicked Coun≈øell having brought his Maje≈øty into exce≈ø≈øive charges without any ju≈øt cau≈øe, he did in the month of Iuly la≈øt (for the ≈øupport of the ≈øaid great charges) coun≈øell and approve two dangerous and wicked Projects: viz.

p.hi: To ≈øeize upon the Bullion, and the money in the Mint.
And to imba≈øe his Maje≈øties Coyne with the mixtures of Bra≈ø≈øe.

And accordingly we procured one hundred and thirty thou≈øand pounds which was then in the Mint, and belonging to divers Merchants, Strangers, and others, to bee ≈øeized on, and ≈øtayed to his Maje≈øties u≈øe. And when divert Merchans of London, owners of the ≈øaid Bullion, came to his hou≈øe to let him under≈øtand the great mi≈øchiefe, that cour≈øe would produce here, and in other parts, what prejudice it would bee to the Kingdome, by di≈øcrediting the Mint, and hindring the importation of Ballion: hee the ≈øaid Earle told them, that the City of London dealt undutifully and unthankfully with his Maje≈øty; and that they were more ready to helpe the Rebell than to helpe his Maje≈øty: and that if any hurt came to them, they may thank them≈øelves: and that it was the cour≈øe of other Princes to make u≈øe of ≈øuch monies to ≈øerve their occa≈øions.

div.p:
And when in the ≈øame Moneth of Iuly, the Officers of his Maje≈øties Mint came to him and gave him divers rea≈øons again≈øt the imba≈øing the ≈øaid money, hee told them that the French King did u≈øe to ≈øend Commi≈ø≈øaries of Hor≈øe with Commi≈ø≈øion to ≈øearch into mens e≈øtates, and to peru≈øe their accounts, ≈øo that they may know what to levie
of them by force, which they did accordingly leavie: and turning to the Lord Conttington, then pre≈øent, ≈øaid; That this was a poynt worthy his Lord≈øhips con≈øideration.

27 That in or about the Moneth of Augu≈øt la≈øt he was made Lieutenant Generall of all his Maje≈øties Forces in the Northerne parts again≈øt the Scots, and being at York, did in the Moneth of September by his owne authority, and without any lawfull warrant, impo≈øe a Taxe on his Majesties Subjects in the County of Yorke of eight pence per ‚Ä¢ iem, for maintenance of every Souldier of the Trayned bands of that County, which Summes of money hee cau≈øed to bee leavied by force. And to the end to compell his Majesties Subjects out of feare and terrour to yeeld to the payment of the ≈øame, He did declare that hee would commit them that refu≈øed the payment thereof, and the Souldiers ≈øhould be ≈øatisfied out of their e≈øtates; and they that refu≈øed it, were in very little better condition than of High Trea≈øon.

28 That in the Moneth of September and October la≈øt, he the ≈øaid Earle of Strafford, being certe≈øild of the Scotti≈øh Army comming into the Kingdome, and hee the ≈øaid Earle of Strafford being Lieutenant Generall of his Maje≈øties Armie, did not provide to the defence of the Towne of New-Ca≈øtle, as he ought to have done but ≈øuffred the ≈øame to be lo≈øt, that ≈øo hee might the more incence the Engli≈øh again≈øt the Scots.

And for the ≈øame wicked purpo≈øe, and out of a malicious de≈øire to ingage the Kings kingdoms of England and Scotland in a Nationall and bloody Warre, he did write to the Lord Conway the Generall of the Hor≈øe, and under the ≈øaid Earles command, that hee ≈øhould fight with the Scotti≈øh Army at the pa≈ø≈øage over the Tyne, what≈øoever ≈øhould follow; notwith≈øtanding that the ≈øaid Lord Conway had formerly by Letters informed him the ≈øaid Earle, that his Maje≈øties Armie then under his command, was not of force ≈øufficient to encounter the Scots, by which advice
of his, hee did contrary to the duty of his place betray his Maje≈øties Armie then under his command, to apparent danger and lo≈ø≈øe.

All and every which Words, Coun≈øells and Actions of the ≈øaid Earle of Strafford traiterou≈øly and contrary to his allegeance to our Soveraigne Lord the King, and with an intention and endeavour to alienate and withdraw the hearts and affections of the Kings Liege people of all his Realmes from his Maje≈øty, and to ≈øet a divi≈øion betweene them, and to ruine and de≈øtroy his Maje≈øties ≈øaid Kingdomes. For which they doe further impeach him the ≈øaid Thomas, Earle of Strafford of High Trea≈øon against our Soveraigne Lord the King, his Crowne and Dignity.

div.head: The Earle of Bri≈øtowes Speech, the 7th of Decemb. 1640.
div.p: MAY this dayes Re≈øolution be as happy as the Propo≈øition (which now moves me to ri≈øe) ≈øea≈øonable and nece≈ø≈øary: for whether wee ≈øhall looke upon the King or the people, it did never more behoove us, the great Phy≈øitian the Parliament, to effect a true con≈øent towards all parts, than now: This debate carries with it a double a≈øpect, towards the Soveraigne, and towards the Subject; though both innocent, both injured, both to be cured.

In the repre≈øentation of Injuries, I ≈øhall crave your attention: In the Cures, I ≈øhall be≈øeech your equall cares, and better Iudgements: ≈øurely in the greate≈øt humility I ≈øpeake it, their illegall wayes are works and puni≈øhments of indignation.

The rai≈øing of Leavies, ≈øtrengthened by Commi≈ø≈øion, with un-heard of in≈øtructions, the billiting of Souldiers, and by Lieutenants, and their Deputies, without leave have beene as if they would have per≈øwaded Princes (nay worlds) the right of Empire had beene had to take away what they plea≈øe by ≈øtrong hands; and they have endeavoured as farre as it was po≈øsible for them to doe it.

This hath not beene done by the King under the plea≈øing ≈øhade of who≈øe Crowne I hope we ≈øhall ever gather the fruits of Iu≈øtice, but the Projectors have extended the Prerogative of the King beyond the limits, which mars that ≈øweete harmony.

They have rent from us the light of our eyes, enforced Companies of gue≈øts upon us, wor≈øe than the Ordinary of France, vitiated of wives and daughters before our faces, brought the Crowne to greater want, than ever it was by anticipating the Revenue: And can the ≈øhepheard be thus ≈ømitten, and the ≈øheepe not ≈øcattered?

They have introduced a Privie Councell, ravi≈øhing at once the ≈øpheares of all ancient government, impri≈øoning without Bayle or Bond. They have taken from us: what ≈øhall I ≈øay? indeed what have they left us? All meanes of ≈øupplying the King, and ingratiating our ≈øelves with him, taking the rootes of all propriety; which if it be ≈øea≈øonably ≈øet into the ground by his owne hand, we ≈øhall have in≈øtead of beauty baldne≈ø≈øe.

To the making of them whole, I ≈øhall apply my ≈øelfe, and propound a remedy to all the≈øe di≈øea≈øis by one and the ≈øame thing: Hath King and People beene hurt, and by one and the ≈øame thing mu≈øt they be cured; to vindicate what? new things? no our ancient ≈øober vitall libertie, by reinforming our ancient Lawes, made by our Ance≈øtors, by ≈øetting ≈øuch a Charter upon them as no licentious ≈øpirits ≈øhould dare hereafter to enter upon them: And ≈øhall wee thinke that a way to breake a Parliament? no, our de≈øires are mode≈øt and just; I ≈øpeake truely both for the intere≈øt of the King and people; if we enjoy not this, it will bee impo≈ø≈øible to relieve him: Therefore let us feare they ≈øhall not bee accepted by his goodne≈ø≈øe.

Therefore I ≈øhall di≈øcend unto my motions, which con≈øi≈øts of foure parts, two of which have relation to the per≈øons, two to the properties of goods. For the per≈øons, the freedome of them from impri≈øonment and from imployment abroad, contrary to the ancient cu≈øtomes: for our goods, that no leavies be made but in Parliament.
Secondly, no billiting of Souldiers.
It is mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary that the≈øe be re≈øolved, that the ≈øubject be ≈øecured in both: Then the manner in the ≈øecond place be fit to det-ermine it by a grand Committee.

div.head: Mr. MAINARDS Speech before both Hou≈øes in Parliament, on Wedne≈øday 24th. of March, in reply upon the Earle of Straffords an≈øwer to his Articles at the Barre.
div.p: I Shall repeat little of that which hath beene ≈øaid, onely this; That whereas my Lord of Strafford did an≈øwer to many particulars; yet hee did not an≈øwer to that which was particularly objected again≈øt him; that is, that you were to heare the complaints of the whole Kingdome: now the particular of our aime, is to take off the vizard, which my Lord hath put on; wherein the truth and honour which is due to his Maje≈øtie, he would attribute to him≈øelfe.
My Lords, there is one thing which I de≈øire your Lord≈øhips to remember, it being the maine of our complaints.

The alteration of the face of government, and tradacing of his owne Lawes; and this is the burthen upon all the Lords and Commons of Ireland. Concerning the breach of Parliament, he would put it on Sir George Ratcliffe; but i ‚Ä¢ me ≈øure, he cannot put off him≈øelfe: for Sir George Ratcliffe was not the man alone, but others joyned with him in that A≈ø≈øembly, and I am ≈øure my Lord of Strafford moved it for the breach of Parliament.
I ≈øhall addre≈ø≈øe my≈øelfe to the body of his an≈øwere: Now give me leave my Lords, that I may open the nature of this great offence.

My Lords, it is a charge of Trea≈øon, which is a Trea≈øon not ended, or expired by one ≈øingle Act; but a trade enured by this Lord of Strafford, ever ≈øince the Kings favor hath been bestowed upon him.

My Lords, it hath two parts: to deprive us that which was good. And ≈øecondly, to bring in a Tyrannicall government, it takes away the Lawes of the Land, and it hath an arbitrary government, bounded by no law, but what my Lord of Strafford plea≈øeth.
It is the law, my Lords, which we reverence, and cheerefully render to our gracious Soveraigne: The Law as it is the ground of our libertie, ≈øo it is the di≈øtribution of Iu≈øtice.

My Lords, in all this, my Lord of Strafford hath endeavoured to make them uncapable of any benefit: it is true my Lords; that Trea≈øon again≈øt the per≈øon of a Prince is high Trea≈øon, and the highe≈øt Trea≈øon that can be to man; but it falls ≈øhort of this Trea≈øon against the State.

When ble≈ø≈øed King Iames was taken to heaven, he commended the lawes to his ≈øonne, our gracious Soveraigne. But my Lords, if ≈øuch a de≈øign as this ≈øhould take effect, that the law of Iustice ≈øhouldbe taken from the Throne, we are without hope of ever ≈øeeing happy dayes: power is not ≈øo ea≈øily laid downe, unle≈ø≈øe it be by ≈øo good and ju≈øt a Prince as we have.

My Lord of Straffords accu≈øation is conveyed into twenty
eight Articles, and I ≈øhall but touch the heads, that wee ≈øhall in≈øi≈øt upon, and I thinke the be≈øt way to this, is to con≈øider what he did before he went into Ireland, what then, and what ≈øince.

He hath encroached juri≈ødiction where none was, taking upon him a power to repell the lawes, and to make new lawes, and in domineering over the lives and goods, and what ever el≈øe was the ≈øubjects.

My Lords, this he hath not done onely upon the meaner ≈øort, but upon the Peeres and auncient Nobilitie, and what may your Lord≈øhips expect, but the ≈øame mea≈øure at his hands here, as they have found there when he committed any to pri≈øon: if a Habeas Corpus were granted; the Officers mu≈øt not obey, and if any Fine were put upon the Officer, for refu≈øing them, there was a command that he ≈øhould bee di≈øcharged: ≈øo that he did not onely take power to him≈øelfe, but the Scepter of Iu≈øtice out of the Kings hand.
When he was a member of the hou≈øe of Commons, it was his owne motion, all Mini≈øters of ≈øtate ≈øhould ≈øerve the King, according to the lawes which he hath broken him≈øelfe.
He doth as much as ≈øay, that Fines ≈øhall not be payed by Officers, if in this they fulfill his commands, but tho≈øe that relea≈øe a pri≈øoner upon a Habeas Corpus ≈øhall finde his di≈øplea≈øure.
My Lords, if this had been a ≈øingle Act, we ≈øhould not have accu≈øed him of high Trea≈øon, but this hath beene his common cour≈øe, and this we pre≈øent to your Lord≈øhips con≈øideration.

The next thing is, that in the North the people attending for Iu≈øtice, you ≈øhall ≈øee what a di≈øhonour he flung upon the ≈øacred Maje≈øtie of the King, that did advance him: ≈øome of the Iu≈øtices (≈øaith he) are all for Law, but they ≈øhall finde that the Kings little fingers is heavier then the Loynes of the Law.

My Lords, what a ≈øad ≈øpeech was this, and what ≈øad Accidents
happened upon it, you all know, and he ≈øaid in a ≈øolemne ≈øpeech; That Ireland was a conquered Nation, and that the King might do with them what he would, their Charters were nothing worth, they did binde the King no longer then he plea≈øed. Surely you may ≈øee what hee would do if he had power, but we hope never ≈øuch coun≈øell ≈øhall have acceptation in ≈øo gracious an Eare as our Soveraignes, and he doth not ≈øtay in words, but proceeds to Actions, when a Peere of the Kingdome was expelled the Kingdome for ≈øuing at Law for recovering of his Right, he ≈øaith, he would have Ireland know that neither Law nor Lawyers ≈øhould que≈øtion any thing that he ordered.
My Lords, he goes higher, for when there was an occa≈øion to ≈øpeake of an Act of State, he ≈øaid it ≈øhould bee as binding as an Act of Parliament.
My Lords, he cannot goe higher then this, hee tells them in Parliament; they were a Conquered Nation, and they mu≈øt expect the u≈øage of a Conquered Nation.
The Lord Mountnorris for a few words that fell from his mouth ≈øpoken privately at his Table, had a Coun≈øell of warre called again≈øt him and was judged to death.
My Lords, it is no marvaile that he ≈øaie; That the Kings little finger ≈øhould be ≈øo heavie, when his little too was ≈øo heavie to tread downe a Peere under his foote.

My Lords, he makes Lawes of him≈øelfe, and hee makes a difference in matters of Iu≈øtice betweene the poore and the rich, but when he hath executed his power upon the poore, he will fall upon the rich.

My Lords, he hath made that which was worth but five ≈øhillings to the value of twenty, and my Lords, by this he doth in effect take away what ere this commoditie is worth, he ≈øaith he doth it for the Kings gaine, but we ≈øhall make it appeare, that the Crowne hath lo≈øt, and he hath gained.

And for the Commodity of Flax my Lords, it is but a
Womans Commodity, but yet it is the ≈øtaple Commodity of Ireland.

Now my Lords, this Commondity he hath gotten wholly into his owne hands, for he made ≈øuch a Proclamation, that it ≈øhould be u≈øed in ≈øuch wayes as the Women could not doe it, and if it were not u≈øed in ≈øuch ways, that it ≈øhould bee ≈øei≈øed upon, no he doth not onely put impo≈øitions upon the Subject, but take away the goods too, and thus he hath levyed warre again≈øt the Kings Subjects, and this is his cour≈øe, that if a Decree were made by him and not obeyed, there i≈ø≈øued a warrant to Souldiers, that they ≈øhould make Garri≈øon, and that they ≈øhould goe to the hou≈øes of tho≈øe that were pretended to be di≈øobedient.

My Lords they have killed their ≈øheep and their Oxen, and bound their hor≈øes and took them Captives till they have rendered obedience, which is expre≈ø≈øely contrary to Law, for it ≈øaith; If any man ≈øet hor≈øe or foot upon the Kings Subject, in a Military way, it is high Trea≈øon.

My Lords, it doth not onely oppre≈ø≈øe them in their e≈øtates, but provoke and incite his Maje≈øty to lay downe his mercy and goodne≈ø≈øe, and to fall into an offen≈øive war again≈øt his Subjects, and to ≈øay they are Rebels and Traytors.

p.hi: He tels his Coun≈øell that the Parliament having for≈øaken the King, and the King having tryed the Parliament, hee might u≈øe other wayes to procure money to ≈øupply his nece≈ø≈øities.

div.p: My Lords, the ≈øame day that the Parliament was broken, he tels the King, he had 8000, foot and 1000‚ñ™ hor≈øe to reduce this Kingdome to obedience.
My Lords, con≈øider in what a ≈øad time this man tooke to infu≈øe this ≈øad Coun≈øell into the Kings eare.

My Lords, he doth advi≈øe the King that he was ab≈øolved from all rules of government, but if no rule of government, what rule of obedience; Surely he meant to reduce us to a chaos and confu≈øion, &c. would have us without all rule of government or obedience.

My Lords, tho≈øe that he would have brought to reduce us were Papi≈øts, Enemies of our Religion. This ≈øtrikes us neer my Lords, and is the griefe of our hearts; that an Iri≈øh army ≈øhould be brought into England to reduce us.
My Lords, I hope we were nere ≈øo far gone, as to need an army to reduce us to obedience.
My Lords, he had rai≈øed this Army, and if ≈øuch Coun≈øell had taken effect in his Maje≈øties eare, he, like proud Haman, would have thought to have been Generall of the Army.
And thus my Lords, you ≈øee this Lord of Strafford falls upon a Coun≈øell, which might make an irreconcileable difference to ≈øubdue us by his power.

div.head: The Earle of Bri≈øtowes Speech in the High Court of Parliament upon the delivering of by him the Scotti≈øh Remon≈øtrance and Schedule of their charges.
div.p: OUr Ance≈øtors were accu≈øtomed to heare propo≈øitions in an other manner.
We repre≈øent unto you a very di≈øtre≈ø≈øed e≈øtate, ≈øad tidings and di≈øhonourable to our Nation.
That we ≈øhould ≈øuffer our Countrey to relieve an Army that is come again≈øt us.
This may ≈øeeme to withdraw from the greatnes and honor of this Nation, but I am ≈øorry it ≈øhould be thought a Nationall di≈øhonour as the ca≈øe now ≈øtandeth.

But I wi≈øh it may light upon tho≈øe that have been the ill in≈øtruments, by their imprudent Coun≈øells to bring this Kingdome into ≈øuch an unhappy bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, that hath produced mi≈øerable effects and Calamities.

But let us labour to build the honour of this Nation, and if ill and wicked men have brought this great di≈øhonour, great let the honour be when a ≈øtate is ≈øo di≈øtre≈ø≈øed, by wi≈ødom
and prudence to relieve it.

I doe remember when the Common-wealth of Rome was in great di≈øtre≈ø≈øe, after the great Battayle of Cannae, they gave thankes that the Coun≈øell did not de≈øpaire of the ≈øafety of the Common-wealth, and me thinkes there is no cau≈øe to de≈øpair, If tho≈øe ill Coun≈øels and ill ways have brought us to this Calamity, ≈øhall hereafter bee turned to wi≈øe, prudent and ≈øetled wayes, if God may ≈øo ble≈ø≈øe us that we again prove happy, for this Nation, the ≈øtrength and Scituation of it would hardly be brought to this condition, were it not for want of Vnity, and for di≈øcord among our ≈øelves.

When a happie Vnitie among our ≈øelves, I doubt not to ≈øee the honour of this Nation ≈øet vp againe by the wi≈øedome of his Maje≈øty and prudent endeavour of this a≈ø≈øembly, this whole Monarchy once reunited, I meane the 3. Kingdomes, will render us very con≈øiderable abroad.

His Maje≈øty hath granted our brethren in Scotland their demands in matter of Religion and liberty, and doubt not but with humility and duty may likewi≈øe obtaine what wee ≈øhall de≈øire concerning religion and libertie graciou≈øly from his Maje≈øties hands.
And I am mo≈øt confident his Maje≈øtie may expect from us all that duty, affection and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance as he hath ju≈øt cau≈øe to expect from good people.

If God ≈øhall ble≈ø≈øe us and this whole Monarchy with unity, love and concord, certainly the≈øe great Armies that do now trouble us, and are ready to offend one an other, may ≈øhew a capability with united mindes and well de≈øigned to effect great matters, and may by unity of Coun≈øell rai≈øe us up againe in the world to a good e≈øtimation, and as great an honour as ever. I hope God will ble≈ø≈øe us with good Coun≈øells, and that the King as a gracious good and prudent Prince, and all his Subjects joyning in this way no doubt but God will bring us againe to a convenient condition of con≈øi≈øtancie, yea ≈øince our armies are vnited under one King and Nation, and in one Iland from a ≈øtate ga≈øping it will bee ea≈øie thence to bring us to a condition of pro≈øperity: therefore let us procure and
maintaine a good corre≈øpondency among≈øt our ≈øelves, and for the propo≈øition, it much ≈øtarted us at fir≈øt, but I mu≈øt ≈øay thus much.

That where wars have fallen between Nations, it is not unlawfull nor great di≈øhonour to let men part upon rea≈øonble conditions, though with good con≈øideration our Kings pa≈ø≈øed many times into France, and returned with recompence, but this a friendly demon≈øtration, of one Nation to another there is great difference in point of honour, if we con≈øider the ≈øtate wherein wee now are, two Armies in the field, and con≈øider it was not through our default, nor the fault of the Kingdome, that we are brought into the≈øe calamities.

The In≈øtruments will bee made an example, and the di≈øhonour will light upon them, and then certainly we doe conceive a wi≈øe and prudent Senate, to apply them≈øelves to ≈øome things by nece≈ø≈øity is no di≈øhonour.
A State lying ga≈øping and bleeding to re≈øtore it is an e≈ø≈øentiall part of honour‚ñ™

p.hi: This is that I had in command to ≈øay unto you.

div.head: His Maje≈øties Speech to both the Hou≈øes of Parliament, February 3. 1640.
div.p: HAving taken into my ≈øerious con≈øideration the late Remon≈øtrance made unto mee by the Hou≈øe of Parliament, I give you this an≈øwer,

That I take in good part your care of the true Religion e≈øtabli≈øhed in this Kingdome, from which I will never depart, as al≈øo for the tenderne≈ø≈øe of my ≈øafety, and ≈øecurity of this State and Government: It is again≈øt my minde, that Popery or Super≈øtition ≈øhould any way encrea≈øe within this Kingdome, and will re≈øtraine the ≈øame by cau≈øing the Laws to be put in execution.

I am re≈øolved to provide again≈øt the Je≈øuites and Papi≈øts, by ≈øetting forth a Proclamation with all ≈øpeed, commanding them to depart the Kingdome within one Moneth, which if they faile, or ≈øhall returne, then they ≈øhall be proceeded again≈øt according to the Lawes.

Concerning Re≈øettie, I give you to under≈øtand, that the Queene hath alwayes a≈ø≈øured me, that to her knowledge hee hath no Commi≈ø≈øion, but onely to entertaine a per≈øonall corre≈øpondence betweene her and the Pope, in things requi≈øite for the Exerci≈øe of her Religion, which is warranted to her by the Articles of Marriage, which give her a full Liberty ‚Ä¢ f Con≈øcience; yet I have per≈øwaded her, that ≈øince the mi≈øunder≈øtanding of the Per≈øons condition gives offence, ≈øhee
will within a convenient time remove him.
Moreover, I will take a ≈øpeciall care to re≈øtraine my Subjects from re≈øorting to Ma≈ø≈øe at Denmark hou≈øe, St, James, and the Chappell of Amba≈ø≈øadors.

La≈øtly, concerning John Goodman the Prie≈øt, I will let you know the rea≈øon why I reprived him, that as I am enformed, neither Queene Elizabeth, nor my Father did ever avow, that any Prie≈øt in their times was executed meerely for Religion, which to me ≈øeemes to be this particular ca≈øe, yet ≈øeeing that I am pre≈ø≈øed by both Hou≈øes, to give way to his, becau≈øe I will avoid the inconveniencie of giving ≈øo great di≈øcontent to my people, as I conceive this Mercy may produce, therefore I doe remit this particular Cau≈øe to both the Hou≈øes: But I de≈øire them to take into their con≈øideration, the inconveniencies (as I conceive) may upon this occa≈øion fall upon my Subjects and other Prote≈øtants abroad, e≈øpecially ≈øince it may ≈øeeme to other States to be a ≈øeverity, which ≈øurpri≈øe having thus repre≈øented, I think my ≈øelfe di≈øcharged from all ill con≈øequence that may en≈øue upon the execution of this per≈øon.

div.head: To the Right Honourable the Commons Hou≈øe of Parliament.
The humble Petition of many of his Maje≈øties Subjects in and about the Citie of London and ≈øeverall Counties of the Kingdome.
div.p: THat wheras the government of Archbi≈øhops, and Lord-Bi≈øhops, Deanes, and Archdeacons, &c. with their Courts and mini≈øtrations in them hath proved prejudiciall and very dangerous both to the Church and Common-wealth, they them≈øelves having formerly held, that they have their juri≈ødiction or authority of humane Authority, till of the≈øe later times being further peru≈øed about the unlawfulne≈ø≈øe that they have claymed their calling immediatly from the Lord JESVS CHRIST, which is again≈øt the Lawes of this Kingdome, and Derogatory to his Maje≈øtie and his State Royall. And whereas the ≈øaid government is found, by wofull experience, to be a maine cau≈øe and occa≈øion of many foule evils, pre≈ø≈øures, and grievance of a very high nature unto his Maje≈øties Subjects, in their owne Con≈øciences, liberties, and ‚Ä¢ ≈øt tes; as in a Shedule of particulars hereunto annexed may in part appeare.

We therefore mo≈øt humbly pray and be≈øeech this Honourable
A≈ø≈øembly, the premi≈ø≈øes con≈øidered, that the ≈øaid government with all its depend ‚Ä¢ nces, roots and branches may be aboli≈øhed, and all lawes in their behalfe made voyd, and the government, according to Gods word, may be rightly placed among us, and we your humble Supplyants, as in duty we are bound, will daily pray for his Maje≈øties long and happy raigne over us, and for the pro≈øperous ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of this High and Honourable Court of Parliament, &c.

div.head: A Particular of the manifold Evils, Pre≈ø≈øures, and Grievances, cau≈øed, practized, and occa≈øioned by the Prelates and their Dependants.
div.p: I. FIr≈øt, the ≈øubjecting and enclining all Mini≈øters under them and their Authority, and ≈øo by degrees exempting of them from the Temporall power, whence followes:

II. The faint-heartedne≈ø≈øe of Mini≈øters to preach the truth of God, le≈øt they ≈øhould di≈øplea≈øe the Prelates, as namely the Doctrine of Prede≈øtination, of Free-grace, of Per≈øeverance, of Originall ≈øinne remaining after Bapti≈øme, of the Sabbath, the Doctrine again≈øt univer≈øall Grace, Election for Faith fore-≈øeene, Free-will, again≈øt Antichri≈øt, non-Re≈øidents, humane Inventions of Gods wor≈øhip, all which are generally with-held from the peoples knowledge, becau≈øe not reli≈øhing to the Bi≈øhops.

III. The encouragement of Mini≈øters to de≈øpi≈øe the temporall Magi≈øtracie, the Nobles, and Gentry of the Land, to abu≈øe the Subjects, & live contentiou≈øly with their neighbours, knowing that they being the Bi≈øhops creatures, they ≈øhall be ≈øupported.

IV. The re≈øtraint of many godly and able men from the Mini≈øtry, and thru≈øting out of many Congregations, their faithfull, diligent, and powerfull Mini≈øters, who lived peaceably with them and did them good, onely becau≈øe they cannot in Con≈øcience ≈øubmit unto, and maintaine the Bi≈øhops needle≈ø≈øe devices; nay ≈øometimes, for no other cau≈øe but for their zeale in Preaching, or great Auditories.

V. The ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing of that godly De≈øigne ≈øet on foot by certaine Sects, and ≈øugred with many great gifts by ≈øundry well-affected per≈øons, for the buying of Impropriations, and placing of able Mini≈øters in them, maintaining of Lectures, and founding of Free Schooles; which the Prelates could not endure, le≈øt it ≈øhould darken their glories, and draw the Mini≈øters from their dependance upon them.

VI. The great encrea≈øe of idle, lewd and di≈ø≈øolute, ignorant and erroneous men in the Mini≈øtry, which ≈øwarme like the Locu≈øts of Egypt over the whole Kingdome, and will they but weare a Canonicall Coat, a Surpli≈ø≈øe, a Hood, bow at the name of JESVS, and be zealous of Super≈øtitious Ceremonies, they may live as they li≈øt, confront whom they plea≈øe, preach and vent what errours they will, and neglect preaching at their plea≈øures, without controule.

VII. The di≈øcouragement of many from bringing up their Children in learning, the many Schi≈ømes, errors, and ≈øtrange opinions
which are in the Church, great Corruptions, which are in the Univer≈øities; the gro≈ø≈øe and lamentable ignorance almo≈øt every where among the people; the want of preaching Mini≈øters in very many places both of England & Wales, the loathing of the Mini≈øtry, and the generall defection to all manner of prophanene≈ø≈øe.

VIII. The ≈øwarming of la≈øcivious, idle, and unprofitable Books and Pamphlets, Play-books, and Ballads, as namely Ovids fits of Love; the Parliament of Women came out at the di≈ø≈øolving of the la≈øt Parliament, Barnes Poems, Parkers Ballads in di≈øgrace of Religion, to the encrea≈øe of all vice, and withdrawing of people from reading, ≈øtudying, and hearing the word of God, and other good Books.

IX. The hindring of godly Books to be Printed, the blotting out, or perverting tho≈øe which they ≈øuffer, all or mo≈øt of that which ≈øtrikes either at Poperie or Arminiani≈øme, the adding of what or where plea≈øeth them, and the re≈øtraints of reprinting Books formerly lycen≈øed without relycen≈øing.

X. The publi≈øhing and venting of Popi≈øh, Arminian, and other dangerous Books and Tenets, as namely; that the Church of Rome is a true Church, and in the wor≈øt times never erred in Fundamentals, that the Subjects have no propriety in their E≈øtates, but that the King may take from them what hee plea≈øeth, that all is the Kings, and that he is bound by no Law, and many other, from the former whereof hath ≈øprang,

XI. The growth of Popery and encrea≈øe of Papi≈øts, Prie≈øts and Je≈øuits in ≈øundry places‚ñ™ but e≈øpecially about London ≈øince the Reformation, the frequent venting of Crucifixes and Pop ≈øh
Pictures, both engraven and printed, and the placing of ≈øuch in Bibles.

XII. The multitude of Monopolies and Pattents, drawing with them innumerable Perjuries, the large encrea≈øe of Cu≈øtomes and Impo≈øitions upon Commodities, the Ship-monies, and many other great burthens upon the Common-wealth, under which all groane.

XIII. Moreover, the Offices and Juri≈ødictions of Arch-bi≈øhop ‚Ä¢ , Lord-Bi≈øhops, Deanes, Arch-Deacons, being the ≈øame way of Church Government which is in the Romi≈øh Church, and which was in England in the time of Poperie, little change thereof being made (except onely the head from whence it was derived) the ≈øame Arguments ≈øupporting the Pope, which doe uphold the Prelates, and overthrowing the Prelates, which doe pull downe the Pope, and other reformed Churches, having upon their rejection of the Pope, ca≈øt the Prelates out al≈øo as Members of the Bea≈øt: Hence it is, that the Prelates here in England by them≈øelves or their Diciples plead and maintaine, that the Pope is not Antichrist, and that the Church of Rome is a true Church, hath not erred in Fundamentall points, and that Salvation is attainable in that Religion, and therefore have re≈øtrained to pray for the Conver≈øion of our Soveraigne Lady the Queene. Hence al≈øo hath come,

XIV. The great Conformity and likene≈ø≈øe both continued and encrea≈øed of our Church to the Church of Rome, in Ve≈øtures, Po≈øtures, Ceremonies, and Admini≈øtrations, namely as the Bi≈øhops Rochets, and the Lawne ≈øleeves, the foure-cornerd Cap, the Cope and Surpri≈ø≈øe, the Tippet, the Hood, and the Canonicall Coat, the Pulpits clothed, e≈øpecially now of late, with the Je≈øuites Badge upon them every way.

XV. The ≈øtanding up at Gloria Patri, and at the reading the
Go≈øpell, praying towards the Ea≈øt, the bowing at the name of JESVS, the bowing to the Altar towards the Ea≈øt, Cro≈ø≈øe in Bapti≈øme, the Kneeling at the Communion.

XVI. The turning of the Communion Tables Altar-wi≈øe, ≈øetting Images, Crucifixes, and Conceits over them, and Tapers and Books upon them, and bowing, and adoring to or before them, the reading of the ≈øecond Service at the Altar, and forcing people to come up thither to receive, or el≈øe denying the Sacrament to them, tearming the Altar to be the mercie-≈øeat, or the place of God Almighty in the Church, which is a plaine device to u≈øher in the Ma≈ø≈øe.

XVII. The Chri≈øtning and Con≈øecrating of Churches and Chappells, the Con≈øecrating Fonts, Pulpits, Tables, Chalices, Churchyards, and many other things, and putting holine≈ø≈øe in them; yea, recon≈øecrating upon pretended pollution, as though every thing were uncleane without their Con≈øecrating, and for want of this ≈øundry Churches have beene interdicted and kept from u≈øe as polluted.
XVIII. The Liturgie for the mo≈øt part's framed out of the Romi≈øh Breviary Ritualium Ma≈ø≈øe-book, al≈øo the book of Ordination, for Archbi≈øhops and Mini≈øters, framed out of the Roman Pontificall.

XIX. The multitude of Canons formerly made, wherein among other things, Excommunication, ip≈øo facto is denounced for ≈øpeaking of a word again≈øt the devi≈øes above ≈øaid, or ≈øub≈øcription thereunto, though no Law enjoyned a re≈øtraint from the Mini≈øtry without ≈øuch ≈øub≈øcription, and Appeale is den ‚Ä¢ ed to any that ≈øhould refu≈øe ≈øub≈øcription or unlawfull conformity,
though he be never ≈øo much wronged by the inferiour Judge: al≈øo the Canons made in the late ≈øacred Synod, as they call it, wherein are many ≈øtrange and dangerous Devices to undermine the Go≈øpel, and the Subjects liberties, to propagate Popery, to ≈øpoyle Gods people, in≈ønare Mini≈øters and other Students, and ≈øo to draw all into an ab≈øolute ≈øubjection and thral dome to them and their government, ≈øpoyling both the King and the Parliament of their power.
XX. The countenancing plurality of Benefices, prohibiting of Marriages without their Lycence at certaine times, almo≈øt halfe the yeare, and lycen≈øing of Marriages without Banes asking.

XXI. Prophanation of the Lords day, pleading for it, and enjoyning Mini≈øters to read a Declaration, ≈øet forth, as 'tis thought, by their procurement for tolerating of ≈øports upon that day, ≈øu≈øpending and depriving many godly Mini≈øters, for not reading the ≈øame onely out of Con≈øcience, it was agai≈øt the Law of God ≈øo to doe, and no Law of the Land to enjoyne it.

XXII. The pre≈ø≈øing of the ≈øtrict ob≈øervation of Saints Dayes, whereby great ≈øummes of Moneyes are drawne out of Mens pur≈øes for working on them, a very high burthen on mo≈øt people, who getting their living by their dayly imployments, mu≈øt either omit them and be idle, or part with their money, whereby many poore families are undone, or brought behindhand, yea many Church-wardens are ≈øued, or threatned to be ≈øued by their trouble≈øome Mini≈øters, as per≈øured per≈øons, for not pre≈øenting their Pari≈øhioners, who ≈øay ‚Ä¢ ed in ob≈øerving Holy-dayes.

XXIII. The great encrea≈øe and frequencie of Whoredomes and
Adulteries, occa≈øioned by the Prelates corrupt admini≈øtration of Ju≈øtice, in ≈øuch Ca≈øes, who taking upon them the puni≈øhment of it, doe turne all into moneyes for the filling of their pur≈øes, and le≈øt their Officers ≈øhould defraud them of their gaine, they have in their late Canon, in ≈øtead of remedying their vices, decreed that the Commutation of Pennance ≈øhall not be without the Bi≈øhops privity.

XXIV. The generall abu≈øe of that great ordinance of Excommunication, which God hath left in his Church to be u≈øed as the la≈øt and greate≈øt puni≈øhment the Church can inflict upon ob≈øtinate and great Offenders, and that the Prelates and their Officers, who of right, have nothing to doe with it, doe daily excommunicate men either for doing that which is lawfull, or for vaine, idle, and triviall matters, as working or opening a ≈øhop on a Holiday, for not appearing at every beck upon their ≈øummons, not paying a fee or the like; yea, they have made it, as they doe all other things, a hook or in≈øtrument wherewith to empty mens pur≈øes, and to advance their owne greatne≈ø≈øe, and ≈øo that ≈øacred ordinance of God, by their preventing of it, becomes contemptible to all men, and ≈øeldome or never u≈øed again≈øt notorious offenders, who, for the mo≈øt part, are their favourites.

XXV. Yea further, the pride and ambition of the Prelates being boundle≈ø≈øe, unwilling to be ≈øubject to either man or Lawes, they claime their Office and Juri≈ødiction to be Iure divino, exerci≈øe Eccle≈øia≈øticall authority in their owne names and Rights, and under their owne Seales, and take upon them Temporall dignities, Places and Offices in the Common-wealth, that they may ≈øway both ≈øwords.

XXVI. Whence followes the taking Commi≈ø≈øions in their owne
Courts and Con≈øi≈øtories, and where el≈øe they ≈øit in matters determinable of Right at Common Law, the putting of Mini≈øters upon Pari≈øhes, without the Patrons & peoples con≈øent.

XXVII. The impo≈øing of Oathes of various and triviall Articles yearely upon Church-wardens, and Side-men, which without perjury, unle≈ø≈øe they fall at jarres continually with their Mini≈øters and Neighbours, and wholly neglect their owne calling.

XXVIII. The exerci≈øing of the Oath Ex Officio, and other proceedings by way of Inqui≈øition reaching even to mens thoughts, the apprehending, and detaining of men by Pur≈øivants, the frequent ≈øu≈øpending and depriving of Mini≈øters, fining and impri≈øoning of all ≈øorts of people, breaking up of mens Hou≈øes and Studies, taking away mens Books, Letters, and other writings, ≈øeizing upon their E≈øtates, removing them from their callings, ≈øeperating betweene them and their wives again≈øt both their wills, the rejecting of prohibitions with threatnings, and the doing of many other out-rages, to the utter infringing the Lawes of the Realme, and the Subjects liberties, and arraigning of them and their Families, and of latter time, the Judges of the Land are ≈øo awed with the power and greatne≈ø≈øe of the Prelates, and other wayes promoted, that neither prohibition, Habeas Corpus, or any other lawfull remedy can be had, or take place, for the di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Subjects in mo≈øt Ca≈øes, onely Papi≈øts, Ie≈øuits, Prie≈øts, and ≈øuch others as propagate Popery or Arminiani≈øme, are countenanced, ≈øpared, and have much liberty, and from hence followed among≈øt others the≈øe dangerous Con≈øequences.

I. FIr≈øt, the generall hope and expectation of the Romi≈øh part, that their ≈øuper≈øtitious Religion will ere long be fully planted in this Kingdome againe, and ≈øo they are encouraged to per≈øi≈øt
therein, and to practice the ≈øame openly in divers places, to the high di≈øhonour of God, and contrary to the Lawes of the Realme.

II. Secondly, the di≈øcouragement and de≈øtruction of all good Subjects, of whom all Multitudes both Ciothiers, Marchants, and others, being deprived of their Mini≈øters, and overburthen'd with the≈øe pre≈ø≈øures, have departed the Kingdome to Holland, and other parts, and have drawn with them a great part of manufacture of Cloth and Trading out of the Land into other places, where they re≈øide, whereby Wooll, the great ≈øtaple of the Kingdome, is become of ≈ømall value and vends not, Trading is decayed, many poore people want work, Sea-men lo≈øe imployment, and the whole Land much impoveri≈øhed, to the great di≈øhonour of this Kingdome, and blemi≈øhment to the government thereof.

III. The pre≈øent warres and Commotions happened betweene his Maje≈øty and his Subjects of Scotland, wherein his Maje≈øty and all his Kingdome are indangered, and ≈øuffer greatly, and are like to become a prey to the common Enemy, in ca≈øe the warres goe on, which we exceedingly feare, will not onely goe on, but al≈øo encrea≈øe to an utter Ruine of all, unle≈ø≈øe the Prelates with their dependancies be removed out of England, and al≈øo they and their practices, who, as we, under your Honours favour, doe verily beleeve and conceive, have occa≈øioned the Quarrell.

p.hi: All which wee humbly referre to the con≈øideration of this Honourable A≈ø≈øembly, de≈øiring the Lord of Heaven to direct you in the right way to redre≈ø≈øe all the≈øe evills.

div.head: The Re≈øolution of the Hou≈øe of Commons touching the ≈øix Demands of the Scots, for re≈øtitution of their Lo≈ø≈øes and Dammages.
div.p: THis Hou≈øe thinks fit that a friendly A≈ø≈øi≈øtance and reliefe be given towards ≈øupply of the lo≈ø≈øes and nece≈ø≈øities of the Scots, and in due time this Hou≈øe wil take con≈øideration both of the manner and mea≈øure of it.

div.head: The Scotti≈øh Commi≈øsioners An≈øwer to the re≈øolution of the Parliament.
div.p:
AS wee doe with all thankfulne≈ø≈øe receive the friendly and kindly re≈øolution of the Parliament concerning our Demands, wee doe therein acknowledge your Lord≈øhips noble dealing, for which we may a≈ø≈øure that the whole Kingdome of Scotland will at all occa≈øions expre≈ø≈øe them≈øelves on all re≈øpect and kindne≈ø≈øe; ≈øo doe we entreat your Lord≈øhips to pre≈øent unto the Parliament, our earne≈øt de≈øire, that they may be plea≈øed, how≈øoever their conveniencie may ≈øerve to con≈øider of the proportion, wi≈øhing ≈øtill that as wee expect from our friends the te≈øtimonies of their kindne≈ø≈øe & friendly A≈ø≈øi≈øtance, ≈øo the Ju≈øtice of the Parliament may be declared in making the burthen more ≈øen≈øible to the Prelates and
Papi≈øts our Enemies, and Authors of all our evills, then to others, who never have wronged us, which will not onely give unto us, and the whole Kingdome of Scotland the greater ≈øatisfaction, but will al≈øo (as wee can conceive) conduce much to the honour of the Kings Maje≈øtie, and Parliament. Wee doe al≈øo expect that your Lord≈øhips will be plea≈øed to report unto us the An≈øwer of the Parliament, that wee may in this as in the former Articles give Account to tho≈øe who ≈øent us.

div.head: The Peeres Demands upon the afore≈øaid An≈øwer.
div.p: VVEe de≈øire to under≈øtand ≈øince (as we conceive) the particulars are like to require much time, whether we may not from you let the Parliament know, that while≈øt they are debating of the proportion, and the wayes how they finde a≈ø≈øi≈øtance may be rai≈øed, you will proceed to the agreeing to the Articles of a firme and durable peace, that thereby both time may be ≈øaved, and both ≈øides proceed mutually with the more cheerefulne≈ø≈øe and alacrity.

div.head: The Scotti≈øh Commi≈øsioners An≈øwer to the Peeres Demands.
div.p:
AS wee de≈øire a firme Peace, ≈øo is it our de≈øire that this Peace may be with all mutuall Alacrity ≈øpeedily concluded; and therefore let's entreat you all to ≈øhew the Parliament from us, that how ≈øoon they ≈øhall be plea≈øed to make the proportion knowne to us, that wee may ≈øatisfie the expectation of tho≈øe who have in≈øtructed us, which wee doe
conceive may be done in a ≈øhort time, ≈øince they are already acquainted with all the particulars of our Demands, wee ≈øhall ≈øtay no longer upon the manner and wayes of rai≈øing the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, which may require a longer time, and yet we tru≈øt it will be with ≈øuch conveniencie as may ≈øerve for our two moneths reliefe, but remitting the manner and wayes to the oportunity of the Parliament, ≈øhall mo≈øt willingly proceed to the con≈øiderations of the following Articles, e≈øpecially to that which wee mo≈øt of all de≈øire, a firme and ≈øetled Peace.

div.head: Articles of the Hou≈øe of Commons in Parliament, again≈øt Secretary WINDEBANKE.
div.p: INprimis, Seventy foure Letters of grace to Recu≈øants, within this foure yeares, ≈øigned with Secretary Windebankes owne hand.
2 Sixty foure Prie≈øts in the Gate-hou≈øe, within this foure yeares di≈øcharged, for the mo≈øt part, by Secretary Windebanke.
3 Twenty nine di≈øcharged by a verball warrant of Secretarie Windebanke.
4 A warrant to protect one Muffon, a condemned Prie≈øt, and all the hou≈øes he frequented.
5 One committed by the Kings owne hand, and di≈øcharged by Secretarie Windebanke, without ≈øignification of the Kings plea≈øure therein.

6 A Petition of Saint Giles in the Fields, neere London, to the King, of the encrea≈øe of Popery in their Pari≈øh, wherein twenty one per≈øons were ≈øeduced and turned by two Prie≈øts, the which Priests were both di≈øcharged by Secretary Windebanke.

div.head: A Speech made by John Lord Finch, Lord Keeper of the great Seale of England, in the Commons hou≈øe of Parliament.
div.p: I Do fir≈øt pre≈øent my mo≈øt humble thanks to this Honourable A≈ø≈øembly, for this favour vouch≈øafed me, in granting me admittance to their pre≈øence, and doe humbly be≈øeech them to beleeve it is no de≈øire to pre≈øerve my ≈øelfe or my fortune, but to de≈øerve the good opinions of tho≈øe that have drawne mee hither.

I do profe≈ø≈øe in the pre≈øence of him that knoweth all hearts, that I had rather go from dore to dore, and crave Da obulum Belizario, &c. with the good opinion of this A≈ø≈øembly, then live and enjoy all the honours and fortunes I am capable of.

I doe not come hither with an intention to ju≈øtifie my words, my actions, or my opinions; but to make a plaine and cleare narration for my ≈øelfe, and then humbly to ≈øubmit to the wi≈øedome and ju≈øtice of this Hou≈øe my ≈øelfe, and all that concernes me.

I doe well under≈øtand (Ma≈øter Speaker) with what di≈øadvantage any man can ≈øpeake in his owne cau≈øe, and if I could have told how to have tran≈ømitted my thoughts and actions by a clearer repre≈øentation of another (I doe ≈øo much
defie my owne judgement in working, and my wayes in expre≈ø≈øing) that I ≈øhould have beene a mo≈øt humble ≈øuiter, another might have done it. But this Hou≈øe wil not take words, but with cleare and ingennous dealing, and therefore I ≈øhall be≈øeech them to think I come not hither with a ≈øet or ≈øtudied Speech, I come to ≈øpeake my heart, and to ≈øpeake it clearely and plainely, and then leave it to your clemencie and Ju≈øtice, and I hope if any thing ≈øhall ≈ølip from me, to work contrary to my meaning, or intention, di≈øorderly or ill placed, you will be plea≈øed to make a favourable con≈øtruction, and leave me the liberty of explanation, if there ≈øhall be any, but I hope there ≈øhall be no cau≈øe for it.

I hope for my affection in Religion no man doubteth me, what my education, what and under whom for many yeares, is well knowne; I lived neere 30 yeares in the Society of Grayes Inn: and if one that was a reverend Preacher in my time (Doctor Sibbs) were now alive, hee were able to give te≈øtimony to this Hou≈øe, that when a party ill affected in Religion ≈øought to weary him, and tyer him out, hee had his chiefe≈øt encouragement from me.
I have now (Master Speaker) been 15 yeares of the Kings Councell, from the fir≈øt houre to this minute, no man is able to ≈øay that ever I was Author, Advi≈øor, or Con≈øentor to any project.

It plea≈øed the King (my gracious Ma≈øter) after I had ≈øerved him divers yeares to preferre mee to two places; to be chiefe Ju≈øtice of the Common Pleas, and then Keeper of his great Seale, I ≈øay it in the pre≈øence of God, I was ≈øo far from the thought of the one, and from the ambition of the other, that if my Ma≈øter his grace and goodne≈ø≈øe had not been, I had never enjoyed tho≈øe Honours.

I cannot tell (Ma≈øter Speaker) nor I doe not know what particulars there are that may draw me into your disfavour or ill opinion, and therefore I ≈øhall come very weakly armed, yet to tho≈øe that either in my owne knowledge, or by ≈øuch knowledge as is given me, and not from any in this Hou≈øe, I ≈øhall ≈øpeake ≈øomewhat, that I hope being truth, and accompanied
with clearene≈ø≈øe and ingenuity, will at la≈øt procure ≈øome allay of that ill opinion which may perhaps be conceived of me.

Ma≈øter Speaker, I had once the Honour to ≈øit in the place that you doe: from the fir≈øt time I came thither, to the unfortunate time, I doe appeale to all that were here then, if I ≈øerved you not with candor. Ill office I never did to any of the Hou≈øe, good offices I have witne≈ø≈øes enough I did many, I was ≈øo happy that upon an occa≈øion which once happened, I received an expre≈ø≈øion and te≈øtimony of the good affection of this Hou≈øe towards me.

For the la≈øt unhappy day I had a great ≈øhare in the unhappine≈ø≈øe and ≈øorrow of it. I hope there are enough doe remember, no man within the walls of this Hou≈øe did expre≈ø≈øe more ≈øymptomes of ≈øorrow, griefe, and di≈øtraction then I did.

After an adjournment for two or three dayes, it plea≈øed his Maje≈øtie to ≈øend for me, to let me know that he could not ≈øo re≈øolve of things as hee de≈øired, and therefore was de≈øirous that there might be an adjournment for ≈øome few dayes more. I prote≈øt I did not then di≈øcerne in his Maje≈øtie, and I beleeve it was not in his thoughts to think of the di≈ø≈øolving of this A≈ø≈øembly, but was plea≈øed in the fir≈øt place to give me a command to deliver his plea≈øure to the Hou≈øe for an adjournment for ≈øome few dayes, till the Monday following, as I remember, and commanded me withall to deliver his plea≈øure, that there ≈øhould be no further ≈øpeeches, but forth with upon the delivery of the Me≈ø≈øage come and wait upon him: hee likewi≈øe commanded me if que≈øtions were offered to be put, upon my Alleageance I ≈øhould not dare to doe it, how much I did then in all humblene≈ø≈øe rea≈øon with his Maje≈øtie, is not for me here to ≈øpeake; onely thus much let me ≈øay, I was no Author of any coun≈øell in it, I was onely a per≈øon in receiving commi≈ø≈øion. I ≈øpeake not this as any thing I now produce or doe invent, or take up for my owne excu≈øe, but that Which is knowne to divers, and ≈øome Honourable per≈øons in this hou≈øe to be mo≈øt true. All that I will ≈øay for that is humbly to be≈øeech you all to con≈øider, That if it had beene
any mans cau≈øe as it was mine, betweene the di≈øplea≈øure of a gracious King, and the ill opinion of an Honourable A≈ø≈øembly. I be≈øeech you lay all together, lay my fir≈øt actions and behaviour with the la≈øt, I ≈øhall ≈øubmit to your Honourable and favourable con≈øtructions.

For the Shipping bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, my opinion of that cau≈øe hath layne heavy upon me, I ≈øhall clearely and truly pre≈øent unto you what every thing is, with this prote≈øtation, that if in reckoning up my owne opinion what I was of, or what I delivered, any thing of it be di≈øplea≈øing, or coÃÑtrary to the opinion of this Hou≈øe, that I am farre from ju≈øtifying of it, but ≈øubmit that and all other my actions to your wi≈øedomes and goodne≈ø≈øe.

Ma≈øter Speaker, the fir≈øt Writs that were ≈øent out about Shipping bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, I had no more knowledge of it, and was as ignorant as any one Member of this Hou≈øe, or any man in the Kingdome. I was never the Author nor Advi≈øor of it, and will boldly ≈øay from the fir≈øt to this houre, I did never advi≈øe nor coun≈øell the ≈øetting forth of any Ship-writs in my life.

Ma≈øter Speaker, it is true that I was made chiefe Ju≈øtice of the Common Pleas ≈øome foure dayes before the Ship-writs went out to the Ports and Maritine places, as I doe remember the 20 of October 1634. they doe beare Te≈øte, and I was ≈øworne Ju≈øtice the 16 of October, ≈øo as they went out in that time, but without my knowledge or privity, the God of heaven knowes this to be true.

Ma≈øter Speaker, afterwards his Maje≈øtie was plea≈øed to command my Lord chiefe Ju≈øtice of the Kings Bench, that then was, Sir Thomas Richard≈øon, and chiefe Baron of the Exchequer that now is, and my ≈øelfe then chiefe Ju≈øtice of the Common Pleas, to take into con≈øideration the Pre≈øidents then brought unto us, which we did, and after returned to his Maje≈øtie what we had found out of tho≈øe Pre≈øidents.

It is true, that afterwards his Maje≈øtie did take into con≈øideration, that if the whole Kingdome were concerned, that it was not rea≈øon to lay the whole burthen upon the Cinque Ports and Maritine Townes.
Thereupon, upon what ground his Maje≈øty took that into his con≈øideration, I doe confe≈ø≈øe I doe know nothing of it.

His Maje≈øty did command my Lord chief Ju≈øtice that now is, my Lord chiefe Baron, and my ≈øelfe, to returne our opinions; whether, when the whole Kingdome is in danger, and the Kingdome in generall is concerned, it be not according to Law and rea≈øon, that the whole Kingdome, and his Maje≈øtie, and all intere≈ø≈øed therein, ≈øhould joyne in defending and pre≈øerving thereof.
This was in time, about one 1634.
In Michaelmas Terme following, his Maje≈øty commanded ‚Ä¢ e to goe to all the Judges, and require their opinions in particular.
He commanded mee to doe it to every one, and to charge them upon their duty and allegiance, to keepe ‚Ä¢ t ≈øecret.

Ma≈øter Speaker, it was never intended by his Maje≈øty (≈øo profe≈ø≈øed by him) at that time, and ≈øo declared to all the Judges, that it was not required by him, to be ≈øuch a binding opinion to the Subject, as to hinder him from calling it in que≈øtion, nor to be binding to them≈øelves, but that upon better rea≈øon, and advi≈øe they may alter it; but de≈øired their opinions, for his owne private rea≈øon.
I know very well, that extrajudiciall opinions of Judges ought not to be binding.

But I did think, and ≈øpeake my heart and con≈øcience freely; my ≈øelfe, and the re≈øt of the Judges being ≈øworne, and by our Oaths tyed to coun≈øell the King when he ≈øhould require advi≈øe of us, that we were bound by our oaths and duties to returne our opinions.
I did obey his Maje≈øties command, and doe here before the God of heaven avow it.

I did never u≈øe the lea≈øt promi≈øe of preferment or reward to any, nor did u≈øe the lea≈øt menacy; I did leave it freely to their owne con≈øciences and liberty; for I was left the liberty of my owne by his Maje≈øty, and had rea≈øon to leave them the liberty of their owne con≈øciences.

And I be≈øeech you be plea≈øed to have ≈øome beliefe, that I
would not ≈øay this, but that I know the God of heaven will make it appeare; and I be≈øeech you that extravagant ≈øpeeches may not move again≈øt that which is a po≈øitive and cleare truth.

Ma≈øter Speaker, in the di≈øcour≈øe of this (as is betweene Judges, ≈øome ≈ømall di≈øcour≈øes ≈øometimes) yet never any cau≈øe wherein any Judges conferred, that were ≈øo little conference as between me and them.

Ma≈øter Speaker, again≈øt a Negative, I can ≈øay nothing, but I ≈øhall affirme nothing unto you, but by the grace of God, as I affirme it to be true, ≈øo I make no doubt of making it appeare to be ≈øo.
This opinion was ≈øub≈øcribed without Solicitation, there was not any man of us did make any doubt of ≈øub≈øcribing our opinion, but two, Ma≈øter Ju≈øtice Hutton, and Ma≈øter Iu≈øtice Crooke.
Ma≈øter Iu≈øtice Crooke made not a ≈øcruple of the thing, but of the introduction, for it was thus:
That whereas the Ports & the Maritine Towns were concerned; there according to the Pre≈øidents in former times, the charge lay on them.
So when the Kingdome was in danger, of which his Maje≈øty was the ≈øole Iudge; whether it was not agreeable to Law and rea≈øon, the whole Kingdome to beare the charge;
I left this ca≈øe with Iudge Crooke.

The next Terme I ≈øpake with him, hee could give me no re≈øolution, becau≈øe hee had not ≈øeene the Writs in former times, but did give his opinion, that when the whole Kings dome was in danger, they of the defence ought to be borne by all.
So of that opinion of his, there was no need of a Solicitation.
I ≈øpeake no more here, than I did openly in my argument in the Chequer Chamber.
This is the naked truth: for Ma≈øter Iu≈øtice Hutton, he did never ≈øub≈øcribe at all.

I will onely ≈øay this, that I was ≈øo farre from pre≈ø≈øing
him to give his opinion, becau≈øe he did ask time to con≈øider of it, that I will boldly ≈øay, and make it good, that when his Maje≈øty would have had him ≈øometimes ≈øent for, to give his opinion, I be≈øeeched his Maje≈øty to leave him to him≈øelfe and his con≈øcience; and that was the ill office I did.
The Iudges did ≈øub≈øcribe in November or December, 1635.

I had no conference (nor truly I think) by accident any di≈øcour≈øe with any of the Iudges touching their opinions; for till February 1636, there was no ≈øpeech of it, for when they had delivered their opinions, I did returne according to my duty to my Ma≈øter the King, and delivered them to him: in who≈øe cu≈øtody they be in.

In February 1636, upon a command that came from his Maje≈øty, by one of the then Secretaries of State, the Iudges all a≈ø≈øembled in Grayes-Inn, we did then fall into a debate of the ca≈øe then ≈øent unto us, and wee did then returne our opinion unto his Maje≈øty; there was then much di≈øcour≈øe and great debate about it.
Mine opinion and con≈øcience at that time was agreeable to that opinion I then delivered.
I did u≈øe the be≈øt arguments I could, for the maintainance of my opinion; and that was all I did.
It is true that then at that time, Ma≈øter Iu≈øtice Hutton, and Ma≈øter Ju≈øtice Crooke did not differ in the maine point, which was this;
When the Kingdome was in danger, the charge ought to be borne by the whole Kingdome.
But in this point, whether the King was the ≈øole Judge of the danger? they differed.
So as there was betweene the fir≈øt ≈øub≈øcription, and this debate, and con≈øultation, ≈øome 15 moneths difference.

It is true, that all of them did then ≈øub≈øcribe, both Ju≈øtice Hutton, and Ju≈øtice Crooke, which was returned to his Maje≈øtie, and after publi≈øhed by my Lord Keeper (my predece≈ø≈øour) in the Star-chamber.

For the manner of publi≈øhing it I will ≈øay nothing, but
leave it to tho≈øe, who≈øe memories wil call to mind what was then done.
The rea≈øon of the ≈øub≈øcription of Iu≈øtice Hutton, and Iu≈øtice Crooke, (though they differed in opinion) grew from this that was told them, from the re≈øt of the Iudges,
That where the greater number did agree in their vote, the re≈øt were involved and included.

And now I have faithfully delivered, what I did in that bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, till I came (which was afterwards) to my argument in the Exchequer Chamber, for the que≈øtion was, A ≈øcire facias i≈ø≈øued out of the Exchequer, in that ca≈øe of Ma≈øter Hampdens; of which I can ≈øay nothing, for it was there begun, and afterwards rejourned, to have advice of all the Iudges.
Ma≈øter Speaker, among the re≈øt (according to my duty) I argued the ca≈øe.
I ≈øhall not trouble you, to tell you what my argument was, I pre≈øume there are Copies enough of it; onely I will tell you there are foure things, very briefly, what I then declared.
Fir≈øt, concerning the matter of danger, and nece≈ø≈øity of the whole Kingdome.
I profe≈ø≈øe that there was never a Judge in the Kingdome did deliver an opinion, but that it mu≈øt be in a ca≈øe of apparant danger.
When we came to an argument of the ca≈øe, it was not upon a matter or i≈ø≈øue, but it was upon a demurrer.
Whether the danger was ≈øufficiently admitted in pleading, and therefore was not the thing that was in di≈øpute, that was the fir≈øt degree and ≈øtep that led unto it.

I did deliver my ≈øelfe as free and as cleare as any man did, that the King ought to governe by the po≈øitive Lawes of the Kingdome‚ñ™ that hee could not alter nor change, nor innovate in matters of Law, but by common con≈øent in Parliament.

I did further deliver, that if this were u≈øed to make a further revenue or benefit to the King, or in any other way but in ca≈øe of nece≈ø≈øity, and for the pre≈øervation of the Kingdome,
The judgement did warrant no ≈øuch thing:
My opinion in this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, I did in my conclu≈øion of my argument ≈øubmit to the judgement of this Hou≈øe.
I never delivered my opinion, that mony ought to be rai≈øed, but Ships provided for the defence of this Kingdome, and in that the Writ was performed.
And that the charge ought not to be in any ca≈øe, but where the whole Kingdome was in danger.
And Ma≈øter Ju≈øtice Hutton, and Ma≈øter Iu≈øtice Crooke, were of the ≈øame opinion with me.

I doe humbly ≈øubmit, having related unto you my whole carriage in this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, humbly ≈øubmitting my ≈øelfe to your grave and favourable cen≈øures, be≈øeeching you not to think that I delivered the≈øe things with the lea≈øt intention to ≈øubvert or ≈øubject the common Law of the Kingdome, or to bring in, or to introduce any new way of government, it hath bin farre from my thoughts, as any thing under the heavens.

Ma≈øter Speaker, I have heard too that there hath bin ≈øome ill opinion conceived of me about Forre≈øt bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, which was a thing farre out of the way of my ≈øtudy, as any thing I know towards the Law.
But it plea≈øed his Maje≈øty, in the ≈øickne≈ø≈øe of Ma≈øter Noy, to give ≈øome ≈øhort warning to prepare my ≈øelfe for that imployment.

When I came there, I did both the King and Commonwealth acceptable ≈øervice, for I did and dare be bold to ≈øay, with extreame danger to my ≈øelfe and fortune, (≈øome doe under≈øtand my meaning herein) run through that bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, and left the Forre≈øt as much as was there.
A thing in my judgement con≈øiderable for the advantage of the Common-wealth, as could be undertaken.
When I went downe about that imployment, I ≈øatisfied my ≈øelfe about the matter of perambulation.
There were great difficulties of opinions, what perambulation was.
I did arme my ≈øelfe as well as I could, before I did any thing in it,
I did acquaint tho≈øe that were then Iudges, in the pre≈øence of the noble Lords, with ≈øuch objections as I thought it my duty to offer unto them.
If they thought they were not objections of ≈øuch waight, as were fit to ≈øtirre them, I would not doe the King that di≈ø≈øervice.

They thought the objections had ≈øuch an≈øwers as might well induce the like upon a conference with the whole Country, admitting mee to come and conferre with them, the Country did unanimou≈øly ≈øub≈øcribe.

It fell out afterwards, that the King commanded me, and all this before I was chiefe Iu≈øtice, to goe into E≈ø≈øex, and did then tell me he had beene enformed, that the bounds of the Forre≈øt were narrower, then in truth they ought to be; and I did according to his command.

I will here profe≈ø≈øe that which is knowne to many, I had no thought or intention of enlarging the bounds of the Forre≈øt, further then H. and that part about it, for which there was a perambulation about 26 Edward 4.

I de≈øired the Country to confer with me about it, if they were plea≈øed to doe it; and then according to my duty, I did produce tho≈øe Records which I thought fit for his Maje≈øties ≈øervice, leaving them to di≈øcharge them≈øelves as by Law and Ju≈øtice they might doe.
I did never in the lea≈øt kind, goe about to overthrow the charter of the Forre≈øt.
And did publi≈øh and maintaine Charta de Fore≈øta, as a ≈øacred thing, and no man to violate it, and ought to be pre≈øerved for the King and Common-wealth.
I doe in this humbly ≈øubmit, and what I have done, to the goodne≈ø≈øe and Ju≈øtice of this Hou≈øe.

div.head: Mr. Herbotle Grim≈øtones ≈øecond Speech in Parliament the 18. of December. 1640.
div.p: THere hath been pre≈øented to the hou≈øe a mo≈øt faithfull and exact report of the conference wee had with the Lords ye≈øterday, together with the opinion of the Committees that we imployed in the ≈øervice, that they conceaved it fit, that the Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury ≈øhould be ≈øeque≈øtred, and I mu≈øt ≈øecond the motion. And with the favour of this Hou≈øe, I ≈øhall be bold to offer my rea≈øons, why I conceive it more nece≈ø≈øary wee ≈øhould proceed a little further then the de≈øire of a bare ≈øeque≈øtration onely.

Ma≈øter Speaker, long Introductions are not ≈øuitable to wa ‚Ä¢ ghty bu≈øine≈ø≈øes: wee are now fallen upon the great man, the Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, looke upon him as hee is in highne≈ø≈øe, and he is the Stye of all pe≈øtilentiall filth that hath infected the State and Government of this Common wealth: Looke upon him in his dependances, and he is the man, the onely man that hath rai≈øed and advanced all tho≈øe, that together with him≈øelfe have beene the Authors and Cau≈øers of all our ruines, mi≈øeries, and calamities wee row groane under. Who is it but he only that hath brought the Earle of Strafford
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
to all his great places and imployments; a fit ≈øpirit and in≈øtrument to act and execute all his wicked and bloudy De≈øignes in the≈øe Kingdomes.
Who is it but hee onely that brought in Secretary Windibank into this place of ≈øervice of tru≈øt, the very Broker and Pander to the Whore of Babylon.

Who is it Ma≈øter Speaker, but hee onely that hath advanced all our Popi≈øh Bi≈øhops, I ≈øhall name but ≈øome of them, Bi≈øhop Manering, the Bi≈øhop of Bath and Wells, the Bi≈øhop of Oxford, and Bi≈øhop Wren, the lea≈øt of all the≈øe birds, but one of the mo≈øt uncleane ones. The≈øe are the men that ≈øhould have fed Chri≈øts Flock, but they are the Wolfes that have devoured them; the Sheepe ≈øhould have fed upon the Mountaines, but the Mountaines have eaten up the Sheepe. It was the happine≈ø≈øe of our Church, when the Zeale of Gods hou≈øe eat up the Bi≈øhops, glorious and brave Martyrs, that went to the Stake in defence of the Prote≈øtant Religion: but the Zeale of the Bi≈øhops hath beene onely to per≈øecute and eat up the Church.

Who is it Ma≈øter Speaker but this great Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, that hath ≈øitten at the helme, to ≈øteere and to mannage all the projects that have beene ≈øet on foot in this Kingdome this tenne yeares la≈øt pa≈øt: and rather then hee would ≈øtand out, he hath mo≈øt unworthily trucked and chafered in the meane≈øt of them; as for in≈øtance, that of Tobacco, wherein thou≈øands of poore people have beene ≈øtripped and turned out of their Trades, for which they have ≈øerved as Apprentizes: wee all know he was the Compounder and Contracter with them for the Licences, putting them to pay Fines, and a fee Farme rent to u≈øe their Trade certainly. Ma≈øter Speaker, hee might have ≈øpent his time much better, and more for his Grace in the Pulpit, then thus ≈øherking and raking in the Tobacco-≈øhops. Ma≈øter Speaker, we all know
