what he hath been charged withall here in this hou≈øe, crimes of a dangerous, con≈øequence, and of a tran≈øcendent nature, no le≈ø≈øe then the ≈øubver≈øion of the Government of this Kingdome, and the alteration of the Prote≈øtant Religion: and this is not upon bare information onely, but much of it is come before us already upon cleare and minife≈øt proofes, and there is ≈øcarce any grievance or complaint come before us in this Place, wherein we do not find him intermentioned, and as it were twi≈øted into it, like a bu≈øie angry Wa≈øpe, his ≈øting is in the tayle of every thing, wee have likewi≈øe this day heard the report of the conference ye≈øterday, and in it the accu≈øation which the Scotti≈øh Nation hath charged him withall, and we doe all know he is guilty of the ≈øame, if not more herein this Kingdome.

Master Speaker, hee hath beene the great and common enemie of all goodne≈ø≈øe, and good men, and it is not ≈øafe that ≈øuch a Viper ≈øhould be neare his Maje≈øties per≈øon, to di≈øtill his poy≈øon into his ≈øacred eares, nor is it ≈øafe for the Common-wealth, that he ≈øit in ≈øo eminent a place of government being thus accu≈øed; wee know what we did in the Earle of Straffords ca≈øe: this man is the corrupt fountaine that hath infected all the ≈øtreames, and till the Fountaine be purged, we can never expect or hope to have cleare channels, I ≈øhall be therefore bold to offer my opinion, and if Jerre, it is the error of my judgement, and not my want of zeale and affection to the publique good. I conceive it is mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary and fit, that we ≈øhould now take up a re≈øolution to doe ≈øomwhat, to ≈øtrike while the iron is hot, and to goe up to the Lords in the names of the Commons of this Hou≈øe, and in the names of the Commons of England, and to accu≈øe him of high Trea≈øon, and to de≈øire their Lord≈øhips his per≈øon may be ≈øeque≈øted, and that in convenient time wee may bring up his charge.

div.head: A Me≈ø≈øage ≈øent from the Queenes Maje≈øtie to the Hou≈øe of Commons by Mr. Comptroller. 5o. Febr. 1640.
div.p: THat her Maje≈øtie hath beene ready to u≈øe her be≈øt endeavours for the removing of all mi≈øunder≈øtanding between the King and people. That at the reque≈øt of the Lords, who petitioned the King for a Parliament, her Maje≈øtie at that time writ effectually to the King, and ≈øent a Gentleman expre≈øly to per≈øwade the King to the holding of a Parliament.

That ≈øhee hath ≈øince beene mo≈øt willing to doe all good Offices betweene the King and his People, which is not unknowne to divers of the Lords, and ≈øo ≈øhall ever continue to doe, as judging it the onely way of happine≈ø≈øe to the King, her ≈øelfe, and Kingdome,
That all things be ju≈øtly ≈øetled betweene the King and his people, and all cau≈øe of mi≈øunder≈øtanding taken away and removed.

That her Maje≈øtie having taken a knowledge, that having one ≈øent to her from the Pope, is di≈øta≈øtfull to this Kingdome, She is de≈øirous to give ≈øatisfaction to the Parliament, which is convenient time ≈øhee will doe, and remove him out of the Kingdome.

That under≈øtanding likewi≈øe that Exception had beene taken to the great re≈øort to the Chappell of Denmark Hou≈øe, ≈øhee will be carefull not to exceed that which is convenient and nece≈ø≈øary for the Exerci≈øe of her Religion.

Shee further taketh notice, that the Parliament is not ≈øatisfied
with the manner of rai≈øing mony, for the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the King in his Journey to the North, in the yeare 1639, at her entreaty from the Catholiques. Shee was moved thereunto meerely out of her deere and tender affection to the King, and of the Example of other his Maje≈øties Subjects, She ≈øeeing the like forwardne≈ø≈øe, ≈øhee could not but expre≈ø≈øe her forwardne≈ø≈øe to the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the King.

If any thing be illegall, ≈øhee was ignorant of the Law, and was carried therein onely out of a great de≈øire to be a≈ø≈øi≈øting to the King in ≈øo pre≈ø≈øing an occa≈øion, but promi≈øeth to be more cautious hereafter, not to doe any thing, but may ≈øtand with the e≈øtabli≈øhed Lawes of the Kingdome.

Her Maje≈øtie being de≈øirous to imploy her whole power to unite the King and people, de≈øireth the Parliament to looke forwards, and pa≈ø≈øe by ≈øuch mi≈øtakes and errors of her Servants, as may be formerly committed. And this your re≈øpect ≈øhee promi≈øeth, ≈øhall be repayed with all the good Offices ≈øhee can doe to the Hou≈øe, which you ≈øhall finde with reall effects, as often as there ≈øhall be occa≈øion.

div.head: The Report of the Kings Me≈ø≈øage by the Lords to the Hou≈øe of Commons. January 25. 1640.
div.p: THat the occa≈øion of his Maje≈øties taking knowledge of the Conviction of John Goodman the Prie≈øt lately reprived, was upon the con≈øtant order that hath been taken for divers yeares, that the Recorder hath at the end of every Se≈ø≈øions attended his Maje≈øtie with the names of the per≈øons convicted, with an expre≈ø≈øion of their offences, to the end that his Maje≈øtie might be truly enformed of the Natures of their Crimes, and con≈øequently not to be enduced by information, to reprive ≈øuch as were fit for grace and mercy: And thereupon that he was lately Condemned for being in order of a Prie≈øt meerely, and was acquited of the Charge of perverting the Kings people in their beliefe, and had never beene Condemned or Bani≈øhed before, His Maje≈øtie is tender in matter of blood in Ca≈øes of this nature, In which Queene Elizabeth and King James have beene often mercifull: but to ≈øecure his people that this man ≈øhall doe no more hurt, Hee is willing that he be impri≈øoned or bani≈øhed as their Lord≈øhips ≈øhall advi≈øe. And if he returne into the Kingdome, to be put to Execution without delay. And Hee will take ≈øuch fit cour≈øe for the expul≈øion of other Prie≈øts and Je≈øuites, as Hee ≈øhall be councelled unto by your Lord≈øhips, And that Hee doth not intend by this particular Mercie, to le≈ø≈øen the force of the Lawes.

div.head: SIR THOMAS ROE his Speech in Parliament, 1640.
div.p: IT is a generall opinion that the trade of England was never greater; and it may be true, that if it be ≈øo, yet it will not ab≈øolutely conclude that the Kingdome doth increa≈øe in riches: for the Trade may by very aboundant, and yet, by con≈øumption and importance of more then is expected, the ≈øtocke may wa≈øte.
The Ballance would be a true ≈øolution of the Que≈øtion, if it could be rightly had: but by rea≈øon it mu≈øt be made up by a Medium of the Books of Rates, it will be very uncertaine.

Therefore we mu≈øt ≈øeeke another rule that is more ≈øen≈øible, upon which wee may all judge, and that may be by the plenty or ≈øcarcity of money; for it is a true rule, If money increa≈øe, the Kingdome doth gaine by Trade; if it be ≈øcarce, it lo≈øeth.

Let us therefore con≈øider, fir≈øt, whether our Gold and Silver be not decrea≈øed, and then by what meanes it is drayned, and la≈øtly, how it may be prevented, and what Remedies are appliable to effect it.

It is out of doubt our Gold is gone to travaile without Licence, that is vi≈øible beyond Seas, and every receiver
of ≈øummes of money mu≈øt find it privately: and I feare the ≈øame of Silver; for, ob≈øerving the ≈øpecies of late Coyning, many halfe Crownes were ≈øtamped which are no more to be ≈øeene; and by this mea≈øure I conclude the Kingdome growes poore.
The cau≈øes of this decay of Money may be many: It may be ≈øtolne out for profit, going much higher beyond Seas, e≈øpecially in France and Holland.

Much hath been drawn away by the Stranger upon feares of our Troubles, of which I have experience by Exchanges, and Exchanges are the great my≈øtery, e≈øpecially ≈øuch as are u≈øed as a Trade, and governed by Bankers, who make many returnes in a yeare, and gaine by every one more then the intere≈øt of a yeare; and the greate≈øt danger to a State is, when money is made Merchandize, which ≈øhould be but the mea≈øure thereof.

And here I will propo≈øe a Probleme, Whether it were profitable to a Kingdome or not, that the Stranger for many yeares had a great ≈øtock here at intere≈øt, and ≈øtill hath ≈øome. I confe≈ø≈øe it hath ≈øupplyed the nece≈ø≈øities of Merchants, and helped to drive Trade: But my Quaere is this, Suppo≈øe the fir≈øt principall were truely brought in by the Stranger, yet, doubling every tenne yeares, what becomes of the increa≈øe? Have they not lived by our Trade and the Merchant-adventurers, and ≈øoaked the Kingdome of as many times principall as they have practi≈øed this U≈øury many times ten yeares, and in the end drawne or carried all away? This is a point to a State very con≈øiderable.

Much Coyne hath beene drawne away without doubt by the French, who have brought in Wares of little bulke, perhaps without cu≈øtome, but of deare price; and having turned them into Gold, have returned without inve≈øting any part thereof; and ≈øuch petty Merchants cannot bee reached by the Statute of imployments.

Another cau≈øe of ≈øcarcity of Coine may be the over ≈øtrict rule of the uncurrentne≈ø≈øe of any good Coine, and that it mu≈øt bee ≈øold here as bullion: in that ca≈øe what Stranger will bring in money? Whereas, if every good ≈øpecies were current according to his allay and weight in proportion to our Coyne, or rather a little higher, it would draw (namely) money by degrees into England, as lower grounds doe water from higher, though they ≈øee not the Channels. And wee ≈øee France, Holland, and Germany, admit all good Coynes, though forraigne, for and above their intrin≈øique value.
But I will end this ≈øearch by propo≈øing ≈øome generall Remedies, for I doe now but make E≈ø≈øayes and give occa≈øion to more ≈øubtill and particular di≈øqui≈øition.

1. To the fir≈øt leake of ≈øteading away Coyne, I would make it felony by an Act: for if a man may justly ≈øuffer death for robbing of a private man, I ≈øee no inju≈øtice nor cruelty to inflict the ≈øame puni≈øhment upon him that robs a Kingdome.

2. That the neighbour Princes and States doe cry up our money, and ≈øo entice it from us, This in my judgement ought to be provided for by our Treaties, which was the old way, e≈øpecially of Commerce, by agreeing and publi≈øhing of Placarts according to a true Par: For that Prince that will make a treatie of Commerce, doth it for the u≈øe of the commoditie; which certainly I would deny any Prince that would not con≈øent to keep moneyes even by their true values, at lea≈øt, that would ≈øet a higher price upon our money then the King hath done: And if our Coyne did either keep beyond the Sear the Engli≈øh value, or were bullion and uncurrent, the ≈øtranger ≈øhould have as little of our money, as we have of theirs.

How to recover the ≈øtrangers money, drawne away ≈øince our troubles, is a hard endeavour, and can no wayes be brought to pa≈ø≈øe but by peace and Trade: and
the re≈øolution of this will fall into the generall remedy which I ≈øhall propo≈øe.

The pedling French Trade mu≈øt bee met with by diligent ≈øearch at the landing of the≈øe Creamers, what they bring in, and by ≈øuffering none of them to pa≈ø≈øe any goods by private Warrants: but that according as they ≈øhall be valued, they give bond to inve≈øt it in Engli≈øh Commoditie, naturall, or naturalized, and that with ≈øurety: Nay in this Ca≈øe not to allow them exchange by bills; for it will not hurt the Common-wealth if by any rigour they were beaten out of their private toyi≈øh traffique.

I ≈øhall not doubt to offend any but the Mint, which may be recompenced to his Maje≈øty in his cu≈øtomes, if money bee plentifull; for all goods will follow money. If I did propo≈øe the currentne≈ø≈øe of all goods, and great ≈øpecies of forraigne Coins, for their true intrin≈øique value, according to the pay with ours, and if I ≈øay a little higher, according to occa≈øions, keeping our owne Coine pure and con≈øtant to bee cryed downe as much under according to occa≈øions, I thinke it will bee a policy both rea≈øonable and profitable, by experience tryed in other States.

But leaving the≈øe Empiricall practi≈øes, I come now to the great and infallible Rule and Remedy, which is, in plaine Engli≈øh, to ≈øettle and a≈ø≈øure the ground of Trade upon ≈øtaple Commodities; then, like the Lady of Whit≈øontide to her Pipe, money will dance after that; for as Merchandize doth follow money, ≈øo doth money Commodity.

I ≈øaid at fir≈øt, it was a generall opinion, that Trade never flouri≈øhed more then now, and it may be ≈øo; but wee mu≈øt con≈øider this be not accidentall and changeable, and depending more upon the iniquity or mi≈øery of the times, then upon our owne Foundation and indu≈øtry; and if that bee ≈øo, then it is no ≈øute ground for
a ≈øtate to rely upon; for if the cau≈øes change, the effects will follow.

Now it is true, that our great Trade depends upon the troubles of our Neighbours, and wee enjoy almo≈øt the Trade of Chri≈øtendome; but if a peace happen betwixt France, Spaine, and the united Provinces, all the≈øe will ≈øhare what wee now po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe alone, and therefore wee mu≈øt provide for that day; for nothing ≈øtands ≈øecure but upon his owne foundation.

To make then our owne Trade ≈øecure, wee mu≈øt con≈øider our own ≈øtaple commodities‚ñ™ whereof Wooll is the chiefe≈øt, and ≈øeeke the way to both, to keepe up the price at home, and the e≈øtimation of all commodity made of that, and to be vented abroad.

Some other helpes we have, as Tynne Lead, and ≈øuch like; but I dare confidently affirme, That nothing exported of our owne growth hath ballanced our Riotous con≈øumption at home, but tho≈øe forraigne commodities, which I call naturalized, that is, that ≈øurplus of our Ea≈øt-India Trade, which being brought home in greater quantity then are ≈øpent within the Kingdome, are exported againe, and become in value and u≈øe as naturall commodities and therfore by the way, I hold it ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary to maintaine that Trade by a Regulation with the Dutch; of which more rea≈øon ≈øhall be given, when that particular ≈øhall be taken into con≈øideration.

We have yet another great helpe which is our owne, and wants onely our indu≈øtry to gather the harve≈øt, which is ou ‚Ä¢ Fi≈øhing and erecting of Bu≈øtes, both for the enriching of our Kingdome, and the breeding of Mariners; and this by private indu≈øtry (though to private le≈ø≈øe) is beaten out ready, and ≈øhall bee offered to the Commonwealth, if they plea≈øe to accept of it: and to give you one onely encouragement, I doe avow that before the Dutch were lately interrupted by the Dunkerks, by their industry, and our fi≈øh, they made as great Returnes betweene Dan≈øick and Naples as the value of our Cloth, which is one million yearely:
and this in a due place I de≈øire ≈øhould have his due weight and con≈øideration.

We have one helpe more, if we knew how to u≈øe it, that is, by the new drained Lands in the Fens, mo≈øt fit for Flax and Hempe, to make all ≈øorts of Linnen for the body, for the hou≈øe, and ≈øayles for ≈øhips, that is a Dutch and French Trade; but in Holland one Acre of Ground is rented at three pounds, which if the Hollanders may have in the Fens for 10. s. or 12. s. it will bee ea≈øie to draw the manufacture into England, which will ≈øet infinite people aworke, and we may be able to ≈øerve other Nations with that which we buy deare from them, and then the ≈øtate and Kingdome will be happy and rich, when the Kings cu≈øtomes ≈øhall depend upon commodities exported, and tho≈øe able to returne all things which wee want; and then our money mu≈øt ≈øtay within our Kingdome, and all the trade returne in money. To incourage you to this, I give you one Example,

That, if the ≈øeverall ≈øorts of Callicoes, made of Cotton-Woolls in the Moguls and Dans Dominions, doth cloathe from head to foot all A≈øia, a part of Europe, Aegypt, much of Africa, and the Ea≈øterne I≈ølands as farre as Sumatra, which makes that Prince without Mines the riche≈øt Prince in the world; by his Maje≈øties Grace and Priviledges granted to the Dutch, I am confident wee may make an under≈øell in all Linnen cloath in all the Nations in Europe.
But I have now wandred far from my Theme, which was the decay of Trade and of Woollen commodity.
I mu≈øt fir≈øt therefore pre≈øent to your con≈øideration the cau≈øes thereof in my ob≈øervations; whereof ≈øome are internall, and ≈øome externall.

The internall have proceeded from her owne fal≈øe making, as ≈øtretching, and ≈øuch like practi≈øes, whereby indeed our Cloath is di≈øcredited: I ≈øpeake by experience,
from Dan≈øick and Holland, Northward, to Con≈øtantinople; as I will in≈øtance in due time.

This fal≈øe Lucre of our owne, and the interruption in the dying and dre≈øsing (projected and not overcome) gave the fir≈øt wound, though, could it have been compa≈ø≈øed, it had doubled the value of our Commodity.
This hath cau≈øed the Dutch, Sile≈øians and Venetians to attempt the making of Cloath, and now, by experience (as I am informed) the halfe is not vented, that was in the former Age.

p.hi: Another internall cau≈øe hath ri≈øen from ≈øuch Impo≈øitions, as hath made our cloth too deare abroad, and con≈øequently taught others to provide for them≈øelves.

Another internall cau≈øe hath ≈øprung from pre≈ø≈øaries upon tender Con≈øciences, that many of our Clothiers and others have for≈øaken the Kingdome, and carried their Arts with them, to the unexpre≈ø≈øible detriment of the Commonwealth.

div.p: The externall cau≈øes have beene the want of perfection, and countenance to our Merchants e≈øtabli≈øhed abroad in Factories by the State and by the Treaties, whereby the Capitulations have not beene kept nor a≈ø≈øured unto them, neither in Pru≈ø≈øia, nor in the Sound, nor Hamburgh, nor Holland, nor in the Ea≈øt: And this I dare ≈øay, that Laban never changed Jacobs wages, ≈øo often as the Hollanders have forced our Merchants to change their re≈øidences, and the very cour≈øe of this Trade by Lawes and Tricks for their own advantage; of which the Merchant-adventurers will more fully informe you.

Another externall cau≈øe is lamentable, Report, the increa≈øe of the Pyrates, and the in≈øecurity of the Mediterranean Seas; whereby Bri≈øtow and the We≈øterne Ports, that cannot have ≈øo great ≈øhipping as London, are beaten out of Trade and fi≈øhing: and if once tho≈øe Theeves ≈øhall find
the way to Banke and new-found Land, they will undoe the We≈øt parts of England.

I will trouble you with a Con≈øideration very con≈øiderable in our Government, Whether indeed London doth not monopolize all Trade. In my opinion it is no good ≈øtate of a body to have a fat Head, thin Guts, and leane Members.

But to bring ≈øomething before you of Remedy, I ≈øay thus for my fir≈øt ground, That if our Cloth be not vented as in former yeares, let us imbrace ≈øome other way to ≈øpend and vent our Wools. Cloth is a heavy and hot wearing, and ≈øerves but one cold corner of the World: But if we imbrace the new Draperies, and encourage the Wallons and others, by Priviledges and Naturalizations, wee ≈øhall imploy all the wooll wee have, ≈øet more people a worke then by Cloth, and a pound of wooll in tho≈øe ≈øtuffes true made, will out-≈øell two pounds in Cloth. And thus wee may ≈øupply France, Italy, Spain, Barbary, and ≈øome parts of A≈øia, by ≈øuch light and fine ≈øtuffes as will fit tho≈øe warmen Regions, and et have ≈øufficient for the cold Clymates to be ≈øpent and adventured in true made Cloth, by the reputation both of our Nation and commodity.

But in this cour≈øe, I mu≈øt ob≈øerve, that the≈øe ≈øtrangers ≈øo fit to be nouri≈øhed, and being Prote≈øtants, may have priviledges to u≈øe their owne rights in Religion, ≈øo as they be not ≈øcandalous, as the Dutch and French had granted unto them by Queen Elizabeth. And certainly the ≈øetling of Religion ≈øecure in England, the feare whereof made many weake minds to waver and abandon this Countrey, is, and will be a great meanes to re≈øettle both the great and le≈ø≈øer manufactures of woollen commodities.

For the externall cau≈øes, wee mu≈øt flye to the Sanctuary of his Maje≈øties gracious goodne≈ø≈øe and protection, who, I am confident, when the whole bu≈øine≈ø≈øe
≈øhall be prepared for him, and that we have ≈øhewed him our duty and love and ≈øettled his cu≈øtoms in ≈øuch a bountifull way as hee may reape his part of the fruit of Trade; I am confident, I ≈øay, that he will vouch≈øafe you all favour fit to be conferred upon good Subjects, and not onely protect you abroad by his forces and authority, and by treaties with his neighbours, but by increa≈øing the priviledges of Merchants at home, and confirming all their Charters; the breach whereof hath beene a great di≈øcouragement unto them, and without which duely ob≈øerved, they cannot regulate their Trade.

There are ≈øome particulars in the Spani≈øh Trade, perhaps worthy of animadver≈øion, as under-≈øelling good commodity to make money, or barter for Tobacco, to the imba≈øement of our owne Staple for Smoake, which in a due place ought to bee taken into Regulation.

Another con≈øideration for a ground for Trade, ought to be the nature of it, with whom, and for what wee trade, and which Trade is more principally to bee nouri≈øhed, which, out of doubt, are the Northern Trades, which are the root of all other, becau≈øe the materials brought from tho≈øe parts, as from Wx, Mu≈øcove, Norway, Pru≈ø≈øia, and Livonia, are fundamentall and of ab≈øolute nece≈øsity; for from the≈øe Trades we get the materials of Shipping, as Pitch, Tarre, Cordage, Ma≈øts, and ≈øuch like, which inable us to all the Southerne Trades of them≈øelves, of le≈ø≈øe u≈øe, being onely Wine, Fruit, Oranges and Curio≈øities for Sauces or effeminacy; but by the≈øe, we ≈øayle to the Ea≈øt-Indies, and may erect a Company of the We≈øt-Indies, for the golden fleece, which ≈øhall bee prepared for you, when≈øoever you are ready for ≈øo great a Con≈øultation.

The right way to nouri≈øh the≈øe North ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e Trades, is
by his Maje≈øties favour to pre≈ø≈øe the King of Denmarke to Ju≈øtice, not to come as his intolerable. Taxes newly impo≈øed upon Trade in the pa≈ø≈øage of the Sound; in Examples whereof, the Elector of Brandenburgh joyning with the King of Poland, hath likewi≈øe more then trebled the ancient and capitulated Duties; which if that they ≈øhall continue, I pronounce all the Commerce of the Baltique Sea ≈øo over-burthened, That the Ea≈øt-land Company cannot ≈øub≈øi≈øt, nor without them and the Mu≈øcovie Company the Navigation, but that the materials for ≈øhipping will be doubled, which will eat out all Trades. I have given you but E≈ø≈øayes, and ≈øtrooke little ≈øparkes of fire before you. My intention is but to provoke the wit and ability of others; I have drawn you a Map, wherein you cannot ≈øee things clearely and di≈øtinctly, onely I introduce matter before you: and now I have done, when I have ≈øhewed you the way how to enlarge and bring every particular thing into debate.

To which end, my motion and de≈øire is this, That we may ≈øend to every ≈øeverall Company of Merchants trading in Companies, and under Government and Priviledges, and to aske of them, what is their Grievances in their generall Trade (not to rake into private Complaints, what are the cau≈øes of decay or abu≈øes in their Trades, and of the want of money, which is vi≈øible and of the great lo≈ø≈øes, both to the Kingdome and to every particular, by the late high exchanges; and to de≈øire every one of the≈øe Companies to ≈øet downe their judgement in writing to the Committee by a day appointed; and having from them all the generall ≈øtate of the complaints ≈øeverally, we ≈øhall make ≈øome judgements of the≈øe relations one to another this done I de≈øire to require all the ≈øame ≈øeverall Companies, upon their owne papers, to propo≈øe to us in writing the Remedies appliable in their judgement; which materials having all together, and comparing one with
another we ≈øhall di≈øcover that truth which we ≈øeeke; that is, whether Trade and Money decay or not, and how to remedy it.

But I have one reque≈øt more and ≈øo I will ea≈øe you of my lo≈ø≈øe of your time: That when from all the≈øe Merchants we ≈øhall have before us ≈øo much matter and without ≈øuch variety and perhaps not without private and partiall ends, that then you will give me leave to repre≈øent to you the names of ≈øome generall and others di≈ø-intere≈ø≈øed and wel experienced in many particulars, who may a≈ø≈øi≈øt our judgements in all the premi≈ø≈øes, particularly in moneys and exchanges, and give us great light to prepare our re≈øult and re≈øolution to bee by the whole Hou≈øe of Commons repre≈øented to his Maje≈øty, and for expedition, that a ≈øub-Committee, may be named to direct this Information from the Merchants.

div.head: THE LORD FAUKLAND His SPEECH, Concerning EPISCOPACY.
div.p: MASTER SPEAKER, he is a great ≈øtranger in I≈ørael who knowes not that this Kingdome hath long laboured under many and great oppre≈ø≈øions, both in religion and liberty: and his acquaintance here is not great, or his ingenuity le≈ø≈øe, who doth not both know and acknowledge that a great, if not a principall, cau≈øe of both the≈øe have beene ≈øome Bi≈øhops and their adherents.

Ma≈øter Speaker, a little ≈øearch will ≈øerve to find them to have beene the de≈øtruction of unitie; under pretence of uniformity, to have brought in ≈øuper≈øtition and ≈øcandall; under the titles of reverence and decency, to have defil'd our Church; by adorning our Churches, to have ≈ølackned the ≈øtrictne≈ø≈øe of that union which was formerly betweene us and tho≈øe of our religion beyond the ≈øea; an action as unpoliticke as ungodly.

Ma≈øter Speaker, wee ≈øhall finde them to have Tith'd Mint and Ani≈øe, and have left undone the weightier works of the Law; to have been le≈ø≈øe eager upon tho≈øe who damne our Church, then upon tho≈øe who, upon weake con≈øcience, and perhaps as weake rea≈øons (the di≈ølike of ≈øome commanded garment, or ≈øome uncommanded po≈øture) onely ab≈øtained from it. Nay, it hath been more dangerous for men to goe to ≈øome neighbours Pari≈øh, when they had no ≈øermon in their owne, then to be ob≈øtinate and perpetuall Recu≈øants; while Ma≈ø≈øes have been ≈øaid in ≈øecurity, a conventicle
hath beene a crime, and which is yet more, the conforming to ceremonies hath beene more exacted then the conforming to Chri≈øtianity; and while≈øt men for ≈øcruples have beene undone, for attempts upon Sodomie they have onely beene admoni≈øhed.

Ma≈øter Speaker, we ≈øhall find them to have beene like the hen in E≈øop, which laying every day an egge upon ≈øuch a proportion of barly, her Mi≈øtre≈ø≈øe increa≈øing her proportion in hope ≈øhee would encrea≈øe her egges, ≈øhee grew ≈øo fat upon that addition, that ≈øhee never laid more: ≈øo though at fir≈øt their preaching were the occa≈øion of their preferment, they after made their preferment the occa≈øion of their not preaching.

Ma≈øter Speaker, we ≈øhall find them to have re≈øembled another fable, the dog in the manger; to have neither preached them≈øelves, nor employ'd tho≈øe that ≈øhould, nor ≈øuffered tho≈øe that would: to have brought in catechi≈øing only to thru≈øt out preaching, cryed downe Lectures by the name of Factions, either becau≈øe their indu≈øtry in that duty appeared a reproofe to their neglect of it, (not unlike to that we read of him, who in Nero's time and Tacitus his ≈øtory was accu≈øed, becau≈øe by his vertue he did appeare Exprobrare vitia Principis) or with intention to have brought in darkne≈ø≈øe, that they might the ea≈øier ≈øow their tares, while it was night; and by that introduction of ignorance, introduce the better that Religion which accompts it the Mother of devotion.

Ma≈øter Speaker, in this they have abu≈øed his Maje≈øty, as well as his people, for when they had with great wi≈øedome (≈øince u≈øually the children of darkne≈ø≈øe are wi≈øer in their generation then the children of light; I may gue≈ø≈øe not without ≈øome eye upon the mo≈øt politicke action of the mo≈øt politicke Church) ≈øilenced on both parts tho≈øe opinions which have often tormented
the Church, and have, and will alway trouble the ≈øchooles, they made u≈øe of this declaration to tye up one ≈øide, and let the other loo≈øe, whereas they ought either in di≈øcretion to have beene equally re≈øtrained, or in ju≈øtice to have beene equally tolerated. And it is ob≈øervable, that that party to which they gave this licence, was that who≈øe doctrine, though it were not contrary to law, was contrary to cu≈øtome, and for a long while in this Kingdome was no oftner preached then recanted.

The truth is, Ma≈øter Speaker, that as ≈øome ill Mini≈øters in our ≈øtate fir≈øt tooke away our mony from us, and after indeavoured to make our mony not worth the taking, by turning it into bra≈ø≈øe by a kind of Antiphilo≈øophers-≈øtone: ≈øo the≈øe men u≈øed us in the point of preaching, fir≈øt depre≈øsing it to their power, and next labouring to make it ≈øuch, as the harme had not beene much, if it had beene depre≈ø≈øed, the mo≈øt frequent ≈øubjects even in the mo≈øt ≈øacred auditories, being the Jus divinum of Bi≈øhops and tithes, the ≈øacredne≈ø≈øe of the clergie, the ≈øacriledge of impropriations, the demoli≈øhing of puritani≈øme and propriety, the building of the prerogative at Pauls, the introduction of ≈øuch doctrines, as, admitting them true, the truth would not recompence the ≈øcandall; or of ≈øuch as were ≈øo far fal≈øe, that, as Sir Thomas Moore ≈øayes of the Ca≈øui≈øts, their bu≈øine≈ø≈øe was not to keepe men from ≈øinning, but to enforme them Quam prop√®‚ñ™ ad peccatum ≈øine peccato liceat accedere: ≈øo it ≈øeemed their worke was to try how much of a Papi≈øt might bee brought in without Popery, and to de≈øtroy as much as they could of the Go≈øpell, without bringing them≈øelves into danger of being de≈øtroyed by the Law.

Ma≈øter Speaker, to goe yet further, ≈øome of them have ≈øo indu≈øtriou≈øly laboured to deduce them≈øelves from Rome, that they have given great ≈øu≈øpition that
in gratitude they de≈øire to returne thither, or at lea≈øt to meet it halfe way: Some have evidently labour'd to bring in an Engli≈øh, though not a Roman popery: I meane not onely the out≈øide and dre≈ø≈øe of it, but equally ab≈øolute; a blind dependance of the people upon the Clergie, and of the Clergie upon them≈øelves; and have oppo≈øed the papacy beyond the ≈øea, that they might ≈øettle one beyond the water. Nay, common fame is more then ordinarily fal≈øe, if none of them have found a way to reconcile the opinions of Rome to the preferments of England; & be ≈øo ab≈øolutely directly and cordially Papi≈øts, that it is all that fifteene hundred pounds a yeare can doe to keep them from confe≈øsing it.

Ma≈øter Speaker, I come now to ≈øpeake of our liberties; and con≈øidering the great intere≈øt the≈øe men have had in our common Ma≈øter, and con≈øidering how great a good to us, they might have made that intere≈øt in him, if they would have u≈øed it to have informed him of our generall ≈øufferings; and con≈øidering how little of their freedome of Speech at Whitehall might have ≈øaved us a great deale of the u≈øe wee have now of it in the Parliament-hou≈øe, their not doing this alone were occa≈øion enough for us to accu≈øe them as the betrayers, though not as the de≈øtroyers of our rights and liberties: Though, I confe≈ø≈øe, if they had been onely ≈øilent in this particular, I had beene ≈øilent too; But, alas, they who≈øe Ance≈øtors in the darke≈øt times excommunicated the breakers of Magna charta, did now by them≈øelves, and their adherents, both write, preach, plot, and act again≈øt it, by encouraging Doctor Beale, by preferring Doctor Mannering, appearing forward for Monopolies and ≈øhip-mony: and if any were ≈ølow and backeward to comply, bla≈øting both them and their preferment, with utmo≈øt expre≈øsion of their hatred, the title of Puritans.

Ma≈øter Speaker, wee ≈øhall find ≈øome of them to have labour'd to exclude both all per≈øons, and all cau≈øes of the Clergy, from the ordinary juri≈ødiction of the temporall Magi≈øtrate, and by hindring prohibitions (fir≈øt by apparent power again≈øt the Judges, and after by ≈øecret agreements with them) to have taken away the onely legall bound to their arbitrary power, and made as it were a conque≈øt upon the common law of the Land, which is our common inheritance; and after made u≈øe of that power to turn their brethren out of their free-holds, for not doing that which no law of man required of them to doe; and which (in their opinions) the law of God required of them not to doe. Wee ≈øhall finde them in generall to have encouraged all the Clergy to ≈øuites, and to have brought all ≈øuites to the Councell-table, that having all power in Eccle≈øia≈øticall matters, they laboured for equall power in Temporall, and to di≈øpo≈øe as well of every Office, as of every Benefice; which lo≈øt the Clergy much revenew, and much reverence, (whereof the la≈øt is never given when it is ≈øo asked,) by encouraging them indi≈øcreetly to exact more of both then was due; ≈øo that indeed the gaine of their greatne≈ø≈øe extended but to a few of that order, though the envy extended upon all.

We ≈øhall find of them to have both kindled & blown the common fire of both nations, to have both ≈øent and maintained that booke, of which the Author no doubt hath long ≈øince wi≈øh'd with Nero, ∆≤tinam ne≈øci≈ø≈øem literas! and of which more then one Kingdome hath cau≈øe to wi≈øh, that when hee writ that, hee had rather burnd a Library, though of the value of Ptolomie's. We ≈øhall finde them to have beene the fir≈øt and principall cau≈øe of the breach, I will not ≈øay of, but ≈øince the pacification at Berwike. We ≈øhall find them to have beene the almo≈øt ≈øole abettors of my Lord of
Strafford, while≈øt hee was practi≈øing upon another Kingdome that manner of government which hee intended to ≈øettle in this, where he committed ≈øo many, ≈øo mighty, and ≈øo manife≈øt enormities and oppre≈ø≈øions, as the like have not beene committed by any Governour in any government, ≈øince Verres left Sicily. And after they had called him over from being Deputy of Ireland, to bee in a manner Deputy of England, (all things here being govern'd by a Juntillo, and that Juntillo govern'd by him) to have a≈øi≈øted him in the giving of ≈øuch Councells, and the pur≈øuing of ≈øuch cour≈øes, as it is a hard and mea≈øuring ca≈øt, whether they were more unwi≈øe, more unju≈øt, or more unfortunate, and which had infallibly beene our de≈øtruction, if by the grace of God, their ≈øhare had not beene as ≈ømall in the ≈øubtilty of Serpents, as in the innocency of Doves.

Ma≈øter Speaker, I have repre≈øented no ≈ømall quantity, and no meane degree of guilt; and truly I beleeve that wee ≈øhall make no little complement to tho≈øe, and no little apologie for tho≈øe to whom this charge belongs, if wee ≈øhall lay the faults of the men upon the order of the Bi≈øhops, upon the Epi≈øcopacy. I wi≈øh we may di≈øtingui≈øh betweene tho≈øe, who have beene carried away with the ≈øtreame, and tho≈øe who have beene the ≈øtreame that carry'd them; betweene tho≈øe who≈øe proper and naturall motion was towards our ruine and de≈øtruction, and tho≈øe who have beene whirl'd about to it, contrary to their naturall motion, by the force and ≈øwinge of ≈øuperiour Orbes: and as I wi≈øh wee may di≈øtingui≈øh betweene the more and le≈ø≈øe guilty; ≈øo I yet more wi≈øh wee may di≈øtingui≈øh betweene the guilty and the innocent.

Ma≈øter Speaker, I doubt, if we con≈øider that if not the fir≈øt Planters, yet the fir≈øt Spreaders of Chri≈øtianity,
and the fir≈øt and chiefe Defenders of Chri≈øtianity again≈øt Here≈øies within, and Pagani≈øme without, both with their inke and with their bloud; and the maine conducers to the re≈øurrection of Chri≈øtianity, (at lea≈øt) here in the reformation (and we owe the light of the Go≈øpell, wee now enjoy to the fire they then endur'd for it,) were all Bi≈øhops: and that even now in the greate≈øt perfection of that order, there are yet ≈øome who have conduc'd in nothing to our late innovations, but in their ≈øilence; ≈øome, who in an unexpected and mighty place and power, have expre≈ø≈øed an equall moderation and humility, being neither ambitious before, nor proud after, either of the Cro≈øiers ≈øtaffe, or white ≈øtaffe: ≈øome who have beene learned oppo≈øers of Popery, and zealous oppo≈øers of Arminiani≈øme‚ñ™ betweene whom, and their inferiour Clergy, in frequency of preaching hath been no di≈øtinction; who≈øe lives are untouched, not onely by guilt, but by malice; ≈øcarce to be equall'd by tho≈øe of any condition, or to be excell'd by tho≈øe in any Calendar. I doubt not, I ≈øay, but if wee con≈øider this, this con≈øideration will bring forth this conclu≈øion, That Bi≈øhops may be good men, and let us give but good men good rules, we ≈øhall have both good governours and good times.

Ma≈øter Speaker, I am content to take away all tho≈øe things from them which, to any con≈øiderable degree of probability, may againe beget the like mi≈øchiefes, if they be not taken away. If their temporall titles, power and employment, appeare likely to di≈øtract them from the care of, or make them looke downe with contempt upon their Spirituall duty, and that the too great di≈øtance betweene them and tho≈øe they governe will hinder the free and fit recour≈øe of their inferiours to them, and occa≈øion in≈øolence from them to their inferiours; let that be con≈øidered, and car'd
for; I am ≈øure neither their Lord≈øhips, their judging of tythes, wills and marriages, no nor their voyces in Parliaments are Jure divino; and I am as ≈øure that the≈øe titles, and this power are not nece≈ø≈øary to their authority, as appeares by the little they have had with us by them, and the much that others have had without them.

If their revenew ≈øhall appeare likely to produce the ≈øame effects, (for it hath beene anciently ob≈øerv'd that Religio peperit divitias, & Filia devoravit matrem;) let ≈øo much of that, as was in all probability intended for an attendant upon their temporall dignities, wait upon them out of the doors: Let us onely take care to leave them ≈øuch proportions, as may ≈øerve in ≈øome good degree to the dignity of learning, and the encouragement of ≈øtudents; and let us not invert that of Jeroboam, and as he made the meane≈øt of the people Prie≈øts, make the highe≈øt of the Prie≈øts the meane≈øt of the people.

If it be feared that they will againe employ ≈øome of our Lawes with a ≈øeverity beyond the intention of tho≈øe Lawes again≈øt ≈øome of their weaker Brethren; that we may be ≈øure to take away that power, let us take away tho≈øe Lawes, and let no ceremonies which any number counts unlawfull, and no man counts nece≈ø≈øary (again≈øt the rules of Policy, and Saint Paul) be impo≈øed upon them. Let us con≈øider, that part of the rule they have hitherto gone by, that is, ≈øuch Canons of their owne making as are not confirm'd by Parliament, have beene, or, no doubt, ≈øhortly will bee by Parliament taken away: that the other part of the rule (≈øuch Canons as were here received before the reformation, and not contrary to any law,) is too doubtfull to be a fit rule, exacting an exact knowledge of the Canon-law, of the Common-law, of the Statute-law knowledges, which tho≈øe who are thus to governe
have not, and it is ≈øcarce fit they ≈øhould have. Since therefore wee are to make new rules, and ≈øhall, no doubt, make tho≈øe new rules ≈øtrict rules, and bee infallibly certaine of a trienniall Parliament, to ≈øee tho≈øe rules ob≈øerv'd as ≈øtrictly as they are made, and to encrea≈øe or change them upon all occa≈øions; wee ≈øhall have no rea≈øon to feare any innovation from their tyranny, or to doubt any defect in the di≈øcharge of their duty: I am confident, they will not dare, either ordaine, ≈øu≈øpend, ≈øilence, excommunicate, or deprive otherwi≈øe, then we would have them. And if this be beleeved, I am as confident, we ≈øhall not think it fit to aboli≈øh, upon a few dayes debate, an Order which hath la≈øted (as appeares by ≈øtory) in mo≈øt Churches the≈øe ≈øixteene hundred yeares, and in all from Chri≈øt to Calvin; or in an in≈øtant change the whole face of the Church, like the ≈øcene of a Maske.

Ma≈øter Speake ‚Ä¢ , I doe not beleeve them to be Jure divino, nay, I beleeve them not to be Jure divino, but neither doe I beleeve them to be Injuri√¢ humari√¢. I neither con≈øider them as nece≈ø≈øary, nor as unlawfull, but as convenient or inconvenient: but ≈øince all great mutations in government are dangerous, (even where what is introduc'd by that mutation, is ≈øuch as would have beene very profitable upon a primary foundation) and ≈øince the greate≈øt danger of mutations is, that all the dangers and inconveniences they may bring are not to be fore≈øeene; and ≈øince no wi≈øe man will undergoe great danger but for great nece≈ø≈øity; my opinion is, that we ≈øhould not root up this ancient tree, as dead as it appeares, till we have tryed whether by this, or the like lopping of the branches, the ≈øap which was unable to feed the whole, may not ≈øerve to make what is left, both grow and flouri≈øh. And certainely, if we may at once take away both
the inconveniences of Bi≈øhops and the inconvenience of no Bi≈øhops, that is of an almo≈øt univer≈øall mutation; this cour≈øe can onely bee oppo≈øed by tho≈øe who love mutation for mutations ≈øake.

Ma≈øter Speaker, to be ≈øhort (as I have rea≈øon to be after having bin ≈øo long,) that this triall may be ≈øuddenly made, let us commit as much of the Mini≈øters remon≈øtrance, as we have read, that tho≈øe heads both of abu≈øes and grievances which are there fully collected, may be mar≈øhal'd and ordered for our debate: if upon that debate it ≈øhall appeare, that tho≈øe may be taken away, and yet the Order ≈øtand, wee ≈øhall not need to commit the London Petition at all: for the cau≈øe of it will be ended; if it ≈øhall appeare, that the abolition of the one cannot be but by the de≈øtruction of the other, then let us not commit the London Petition; but let us grant it.

div.head: Mr. PYM His SPEECH, After the Articles of the Charge again≈øt the Earle of STRAFFORD were read.
div.p: THe≈øe Articles have expre≈øt the Character of a great and dangerous Trea≈øon; ≈øuch a one as is advanced to the highe≈øt degree of malice and of mi≈øchiefe: It is enlarged beyond the limits of any de≈øcription or definition: it is ≈øo hainous in it ≈øelfe, as that it is capable of no aggravation: a Trea≈øon again≈øt God, betraying his Truth and Wor≈øhip; again≈øt the King, ob≈øcuring the glory, and weakning the foundation of his Throne; again≈øt the Common-wealth, by de≈øtroying the principles of Safetie and Pro≈øperitie. Other Trea≈øons are again≈øt the Rule of the Law; this is again≈øt the beeing of the Law: It is the Law that u ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ es the King and his People; and the Author of this Trea≈øon hath endeavoured to di≈ø≈øolve that Union, even to breake the mutuall, irrever≈øall, indi≈ø≈øoluble band of protection and Allegiance, whereby they are, and I hope ever will bee, bound together.

If this Trea≈øon had taken effect, our Soules had been inthralled to the Spirituall Tyranny of Sathan, our Con≈øciences to the Eccle≈øia≈øticall Tyranny of the Pope; our Lives, our Per≈øons and E≈øtates to the Civill
Tyranny of an arbitrary, unlimited, confu≈øed Government.

Trea≈øon in the lea≈øt degree, is an odious and a horrid Crime: other Trea≈øons are particular; if a Fort bee betrayed, or an Army, or any other trea≈øonable fact committed, the Kingdome may out-live any of the≈øe: this Trea≈øon would have di≈ø≈øolved the frame and beeing of the Common-wealth; it is an Univer≈øall, a Catholike Trea≈øon; the venome and malignity of all other Trea≈øons are ab≈øtracted, dige≈øted, ≈øublimated into this.

The Law of this Kingdome makes the King to be the fountaine of Ju≈øtice, of Peace, of Protection; therefore we ≈øay, the Kings Courts the Kings Judges, the Kings Lawes. The Royall Power and Maje≈øtie ≈øhines upon us in every publique ble≈ø≈øing and benefit wee enjoy: but the Author of this Trea≈øon would make him the fountaine of Inju≈øtice, of Confu≈øion, of publike mi≈øery and calamitie.

The Gentiles by the light of Nature had ≈øome ob≈øcure apprehen≈øions of the Deity, of which they made this expre≈øsion, that hee was Deus optimus maximus, an infinite goodne≈ø≈øe, and an infinite greatne≈ø≈øe. All ≈øoveraigne Princes have ≈øome Characters of Divinity imprinted on them; they are ≈øet up in their dominions to bee Optimi, Maximi, that they ≈øhould exerci≈øe a goodne≈ø≈øe proportionable to their greatne≈ø≈øe.

That Law terme, Lae≈øa Maje≈øtas, whereby they expre≈ø≈øe that which wee call Trea≈øon, was never more thorowly fulfilled then now: there cannot bee a greater lae≈øion or diminution of Maje≈øtie, then to bereave a King of the glory of his goodne≈ø≈øe. It is goodne≈ø≈øe (My Lords) that can produce, not onely to his people, but likewi≈øe to him≈øelf honour and happine≈øs. There are Principalities, Thrones and Dominions among≈øt the Divels, greatne≈øs enough; but being uncapable
of goodne≈øs, they are made uncapable both of honour and happine≈ø≈øe.

The Lawes of this Kingdome have inve≈øted the Royall Crowne with power ≈øufficient for the manife≈øtation of his goodne≈øs and of his greatne≈øs: if more bee required, it is like to have no other effects but povertie, weakne≈ø≈øe, and mi≈øerie, whereof of late wee have had very wofull experience. It is farre from the Commons to de≈øire any abridgement of tho≈øe great Prerogatives which belong to the King; they know that their own Liberty & Peace are pre≈øerved and ≈øecured by his Prerogative, & they will alwayes be ready to ≈øupport and ≈øupply his Maje≈øty with their lives and fortunes, for the maintenance of his ju≈øt and lawfull Power.

This (My Mords) is in all our thoughts, in our prayers, and I hope will ≈øo be manife≈øted in our indeavours, that if the proceedings of this Parliament bee not interrupted as others have beene, the King may within a few moneths bee put into a cleare way, of as much greatne≈ø≈øe, plenty and glory, as any of his Royall Ance≈øtors have enjoyed.

A King and his People make one Body: the inferiour parts conferre nouri≈øhment and ≈øtrength, the ≈øuperiour ≈øen≈øe and motion: If there be an interruption of this nece≈ø≈øary intercour≈øe of bloud and ≈øpirits, the whole Body mu≈øt needs bee ≈øubject to decay and di≈øtemper; therefore ob≈øtructions are fir≈øt to bee removed, before re≈øtoratives can be applyed. This (My Lords) is the end of this Accu≈øation, whereby the Commons ≈øeeke to remove this per≈øon, whom they conceive to have beene a great cau≈øe of the ob≈øtructions betwixt his Maje≈øty and his People: for the effecting whereof, they have commanded mee to de≈øire your Lord≈øhips, that their proceedings again≈øt him
may bee put into as ≈øpeedy a way of di≈øpatch, as the cour≈øes of Parliaments will allow.

Fir≈øt, that hee may bee called to an≈øwer, and they may have liberty to reply; that there may bee a quick and ≈øecret examination of witne≈ø≈øes, and they may from time to time bee acquainted with the depo≈øitions; that ≈øo when the cau≈øe ≈øhall bee ripe for Judgement, they may collect the ≈øeverall Examinations, and repre≈øent to your Lord≈øhips in one entire Body the ≈øtate of the Proofes, as now by mee they have pre≈øented to you the ≈øtate of the Charge.

div.head: Mr. PYM his SPEECH, After the Articles of the Charge again≈øt Sr. GEORGE RATCLIFFE were read.
div.p: BY hearing this Charge, your Lord≈øhips may perceive what neere conjunction there is betweene this Cau≈øe and the Earle of STRAFFORDS: the materials are (for the mo≈øt part) the ≈øame in both: the offences of the Earle moving from an higher Orb, are more comprehen≈øive, they extend both to England and Ireland; the≈øe (except in one particular of reducing of England by the Iri≈øh Army) are confined within one Kingdome; the Earle is charged as an Authour, Sir GEORGE RATCLIFFE as an In≈øtrument and ≈øubordinate Actor.

The influences of ≈øuperiour Planets are often augmented and inforced, but ≈øeldome mitigated by the concurrence of the inferiour, where merit doth ari≈øe not from well-doing, but from ill; the officiou≈øne≈ø≈øe of mini≈øters will rather adde to the malignity of their In≈øtructions, then dimini≈øh it, that ≈øo they may more fully ingratiate them≈øelves with tho≈øe upon whom they depend.

In the crimes committed by the Earle there appears more haughtine≈ø≈øe and fiercene≈ø≈øe, being acted by his owne principles; tho≈øe motions are ever ≈øtronge≈øt which are neere≈øt the Primum mobile: But in tho≈øe of
Sir GEORGE RATCLIFFE there ≈øeemes to be more ba≈øene≈ø≈øe and ≈øervility, having re≈øigned and ≈øubjected him≈øelfe to bee acted by the corrupt will of onother.

The Earle of STRAFFORD hath not beene bred in the ≈øtudy and practice of the Law, and having ≈øtronger lu≈øts and pa≈øsions to incite, and le≈ø≈øe knowledge to re≈øtraine him, might more ea≈øily be tran≈øported from the Rule; Sir GEORGE RATCLIFFE in his naturall temper and di≈øpo≈øition more moderate, and by his education and profe≈øsion better acquainted with the grounds and directions of the Law, was carried into his offences by a more immediate Concurrence of will, and a more corrupt ≈øuppre≈øsion of his owne Rea≈øon and Judgement.

My Lords, as both the≈øe have beene partners in offending: ≈øo it is the de≈øire of the Commons, they may bee put under ≈øuch tryall and examination, and other proceedings of ju≈øtice as may bring them to partake in a de≈øerved puni≈øhment, for the ≈øafety and good of both Kingdomes.

div.head: Mr SPEAKERS SPEECH, At the pre≈øenting of the≈øe three BILLS, viz.

An Act
For the ≈øhortning of Michaelmas Terme.
For the pre≈ø≈øing of Mariners for the Kings Ships.
For the remainder of the ≈øix entire Sub≈øidies.

opener.salute: May it plea≈øe your mo≈øt excellent Maje≈øty,

div.p: THE great ≈øecurity of the Kingdome re≈øts in the happy concurrence of the King and people in the unity of their hearts.
The≈øe joyned, ≈øafety and plenty attends the Scepter; but divided, di≈øtraction and confu≈øion, as Bryers and Thorns, over≈øpreads, and makes the Land barren.
The duties and affections of your ≈øubjects are mo≈øt tran≈øparent, mo≈øt cleare, in the cheerfull and mo≈øt‚ñ™ liberall contributions, given to knit fa≈øt this union with the bond of peace.

The trea≈øures of the privie Pur≈øe, are but the ≈øupplies of Fancies, warranted by a common Intere≈øt; But the publick Tribute given by common a≈ø≈øent, ≈øupports Royall Dignity, is ≈øheltred under the wings of Prerogative, and by that power covered from the eyes, from the touch of deceivers.
In the≈øe wee render Cae≈øar what is due to Cae≈øar, and tribute to whom tribute belongeth.

The proper in≈øcription of the Crown is born here, and cen≈øures tho≈øe malignant ≈øpirits that dare whi≈øper into the eares of ≈øacred Maje≈øty, that our ≈øelves onely, not your ≈øacred per≈øon, not your Royall po≈øterity, are the ≈øupreme objects of the givers.

The pre≈øervation of the publick union, the ≈øupply of your Armies, the di≈øtre≈ø≈øes, mi≈øerable di≈øtre≈ø≈øes of the Northern parts, the common calamities of the times begat the con≈øideration of this Bill (the remainder of the ≈øix entire Sub≈øidies happily pre≈øented to your ≈øacred Maje≈øty by this unworthy hand) the fir≈øt vote advanced a credit to us to i≈ø≈øue them for the u≈øe of your ≈øacred Maje≈øty.
The full perfection adds growth to that credit, and enables us to returne to your ≈øacred Maje≈øty, as to the Ocean the Tribute due to Ju≈øtice and Soveraignty.
The≈øe are the va≈øt earne≈øts of our de≈øires, which take their ri≈øe from the due regard, from the ≈øafety of your Throne, of your po≈øterity.
Your Royall a≈ø≈øent ≈øtamps your image here, and makes this yours, and yours onely, which I (by the commands of the Commons) humbly be≈øeech of your ≈øacred Maje≈øty.

div.head: THE SPEECH OF Ma≈øter Plydell, ESQUIRE.
div.p: I Have heard, ≈øince I had the honour to ≈øit here, many grievances pre≈øented, and truly Sir, my heart bleeds within mee when I thinke of them, e≈øpecially tho≈øe that concerne Religion. But what ≈øhould I ≈øpeake of grievances concerning Religion, when Religion it ≈øelfe is become a grievance, nay the very Nur≈øe and Mother of all grievances, all ≈øcandalls, all reproaches?
SIR,

Not to trouble you with any long di≈øcour≈øe, if I have any ≈øight, that Bark both of Church and State hath a long time floated betwixt Scylla and Charibdis, Popery on the one ≈øide, and I know not what to call it on the other; in many re≈øpects both alike dangerous, unle≈ø≈øe the Italian Proverb may alter the Ca≈øe; God defend me from my reputed friends, and I will defend my ≈øelfe from my profe≈øt enemies.

Sir, Wee are intru≈øted by God, the King and the Countrey, with the managing of this Bark, fraught
with the fortunes of three great Kingdomes: Now, ≈øhould wee ≈øo decline the former Rock, that wee da≈øh on the other ≈øide. I humbly offer it to this Honourable A≈ø≈øembly, whether ≈øhee might not have ju≈øt cau≈øe to ≈øay, ≈øhee had changed her Pilot rather then her condition, and onely ≈øhifted places to finde her ruine: For Sir, there is as much beyond Truth, as on this ≈øide it; and would wee ≈øteere a right cour≈øe, wee mu≈øt be ≈øure to keepe the channell, le≈øt wee fall from one extreme to another; from the dotage of Super≈øtition, to the frenzie of Profanene≈ø≈øe; from bowing to Idols, to wor≈øhip the Calves of our owne imaginations.

Sir, I be≈øeech you con≈øider what libellous Pamphlets are now printed, what Sermons are preached, not building hay and ≈øtubble, but utterly ≈øubverting the foundations of Truth; what irreverence in Churches, what profanation of Gods Service, to the ≈øcandall of Chri≈øtianity, the reproach of Religion, and the intolerable griefe of all good men; of which I may take up the words of Petrus de Aliaco to the Councell of Con≈øtance, Ni≈øi celeriter fiat Reformatio, audeo dicere qu√≤d lic√®t magna ≈øint quae videmus, tamen in brevi incomparabilia majora videmus, & post i≈øta tam horrenda majora alia audiemus.

Sir, I take God to record, I am no mans Advocate, no mans enemy; but a faithfull lover of truth and peace, and a dutifull Son of our di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Mother, the Church of England; in who≈øe behalfe, and our owne, my motion ≈øhall bee ≈øhortly this, That the Mini≈øters Petition, with ≈øo much of their Remon≈øtrance as hath been read, may be committed, and the re≈øt of it, concerning matter of Doctrine, may bee referred to ≈øome learned and approved Divines, who have ≈øpent their time in that noble ≈øtudy. For, give me leave to tell you, there is a vulgus among the Clergy, as among the Laity, Et in utroque nil modicum; and for the≈øe and all things which ≈øtrike
at the roote and branch, as they plea≈øe to call it, I ≈øhall humbly move, that wee rather con≈øider how to ≈øatisfie the Petitioners with ≈øome timely declaration from both Hou≈øes of the lawfulne≈ø≈øe and conveniency of Epi≈øcopall Government, derived from the Apo≈øtles, and ≈øo long e≈øtabli≈øhed in this Kingdome, rather then to venture upon any alteration, the con≈øequence whereof the wi≈øe≈øt man cannot fore-≈øee. And in truth, Sir, ≈øhould we once begin (for my owne part) I know not how, or where wee ≈øhould ≈øtay. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, if any one doubt the ≈øuperiority of Bi≈øhops over Prie≈øts and Deacons in Eccle≈øia≈øticall government, or in ordination, I ≈øhall be ready, when≈øoever this Hou≈øe ≈øhall command mee, to make it good, and I think, by as pregnant te≈øtimonies as wee are able to prove the difference betwixt Canonicall and Apocryphall Scripture, the nece≈øsity of Infants bapti≈øme, or that the Apo≈øtles were the Authors of their owne Creed. But, Sir, I hope you will ≈øave your ≈øelfe and mee that labour, and rather devi≈øe of ≈øome ≈øet way to bind up the Churches wounds, which (God knowes) are too wide already, that ≈øo the Clergy and Laity being made friends, and all reduced to the modell of our Ance≈øtors ≈øince the Reformation, we may altogether pre≈øerve the unity of the Spirit in the bond of peace; and ≈øo his Maje≈øty having gratiou≈øly and prudently expre≈øt him≈øelfe, I am the more confident wee ≈øhall not onely put an end to all mi≈ø-intelligence betwixt Prince and People, but al≈øo highly advance the Prote≈øtant cau≈øe, and give a deadly blow to the See of Rome.

closer.signed: I humbly crave the favour of the Hou≈øe, for God is my witne≈ø≈øe, Non potui aliter liberare animam meam.

div.head: Sir THOMAS ROVVES REPORTS, To the COMMONS HOUSE of PARLIAMENT. 1640.
div.p: I Am to make a Report of what was delivered at the conference of a Committee of both Hou≈øes of Parliament upon Thur≈øday la≈øt.

I hope, Ma≈øter Speaker, ≈øo much upon the favour of this Hou≈øe that they will give mee leave to be a Reader, and that they will not expect from my age and weakne≈ø≈øe a particular repetition of the ≈øame words, a taske too great for my memory unpracti≈øed for many yeares in ≈øuch exactne≈ø≈øe; neither am I able to repre≈øent without diminution, that life, and grace, that tho≈øe relations received from ≈øo great abilities, de≈øiring their Lord≈øhips pardon, and your acceptance of the ≈øub≈øtance and matter, wherein I hope I ≈øhall omit nothing ≈øub≈øtantiall; and if I could repeate every word, yet would it want as much lu≈øter as copies of ordinary hands, doe of the be≈øt originals.

My Lord Keeper did fir≈øt let us know, that his Maje≈øty had commanded the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners of the great Councell, to give an account of their Treaties at Yorke and Rippon, to both Hou≈øes; and of his Maje≈øties gracious intentions, in a bu≈øine≈ø≈øe ≈øo much importing the honour and ≈øafety of the Kingdome, that there might be made a faithfull relation with all
candor and clearne≈ø≈øe, which was the ≈øumme of his Maje≈øties in≈øtructions.

His Lord≈øhip declaring that my Lords of the upper Hou≈øe, for the ≈øaving of time, had thought fit to give this account to a Committee of both Hou≈øes, which hath occa≈øioned the meeting at this Conference; and election being made of the Earle of Bri≈øtoll by the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners, he began his Narration, directed to the Lords of the upper Hou≈øe, and to the Knights, Citizens and Burge≈ø≈øes of the hou≈øe of Commons: and thus the Earle of Bri≈øtoll began;
That the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners intended not to looke further back into the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, then the Acts of their own imployments.

They did intend to give no account of the pacification interrupted, nor war renewed; no account how the Armies in England, Ireland, and by Sea were de≈øigned, nor of any occa≈øion: They purpo≈øed not to lay fault upon any man, nor to enquire into the cau≈øe why the Scots (as they pretended from nece≈øsity) were drawne to enter this Kingdome, nor why the Kings Army, when ≈øervice was to be done, was out of the way; But that tho≈øe through who≈øe hands the≈øe have pa≈ø≈øed, might hereafter give their own account.
His Lord≈øhip told us, that his Maje≈øty was plea≈øed to call his great Councell at Yorke, to whom he made two propo≈øitions.
The fir≈øt was, how his Army, which ≈øeemed to be in di≈øtre≈ø≈øe for want of pay, ≈øhould be relieved and maintained.
To this, to ≈øhew their duties to the King, the Lords re≈øolved to ingage them≈øelves, and to that purpo≈øe to ≈øend cho≈øen Deputies to London, to negotiate a ≈øupply.

The ≈øecond propo≈øition was, that after the Scots had pa≈ø≈øed Northumberland, taken Newca≈øtle, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed the Bi≈øhopricke of Dure≈øme, they ≈øent a Petition
to his Maje≈øty, which containeth, in generall termes, a de≈øire to have their grievances taken into con≈øideration.
Which Petition and An≈øwer thereunto was read unto us,A. N. A. and pre≈øented for our clearer under≈øtanding.

Upon receipt of his Maje≈øties An≈øwer, the Scoti≈øh Lords ≈øent his Maje≈øty a ≈øecond Petition, directed in a Letter to the Earle of Lanrick,K. Q. in which they made their particular demands, and declared, that, according to his Maje≈øties command, they would advance no further; and this Petition was al≈øo read and delivered unto us, of which his Lord≈øhip de≈øired that great A≈ø≈øembly to take e≈øpeciall notice, for that much of the future di≈øcour≈øe would depend upon it.

The bu≈øine≈ø≈øe thus ≈øtated at the great Councell, the ≈øecond propo≈øition was, what An≈øwer ≈øhould be made to that Petionary Letter, and in what manner it ≈øhould be carried; In which his Maje≈øty required their Councell.
Whereupon the Lords replyed, that it was impo≈øsible for them to give any well grounded advice, unle≈ø≈øe the true ≈øtate of his affaires, and the Condition of his Army were laid before them.

Whereupon his Maje≈øty commanded the Earle of Traquaire,N. L. to make the Narration of the Scoti≈øh bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, and their late Acts of Parliament, and the Lord Lievtenant generall, to give an account in what condition the Army ≈øtood, and what was an≈øwered by my Lord Lievtenant, was read in his owne words.
Be≈øides this declaration, the Earle of Bri≈øtoll delivered upon a further enquiry, how the ≈øtate of the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe then ≈øtood:

That the Scots Army had pa≈ø≈øed Northumberland without re≈øi≈øtance; that they had di≈øputed the pa≈ø≈øage
of the River of Tyne at Newburne, where our hor≈øe retyred in di≈øorder; that his Maje≈øties foot Army con≈øi≈øting of twelve or fourteene thou≈øand men in Newca≈øtle, likewi≈øe retired to Yorke, whereby the Towne of Newca≈øtle, a place of great con≈øideration, was without one ≈øtroke ≈øtrucken, fallen into the Scots hands, and the Bi≈øhopricke of Dure≈øme drawn under Contribution.

That in this ≈øtate, the Gentry of the Bi≈øhopricke repayred to Ma≈øter Trea≈øurer, who carryed them to his Maje≈øty, from whom they were referred to my Lord Lievtenant of the Army, who gave them this an≈øwer po≈øitively; That they could looke for no help nor protection from the King, and therefore they might u≈øe the be≈øt meanes they could to pre≈øerve their lives and e≈øtates. Whereby tho≈øe di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Provinces, the ancient Bulwarks of this Kingdome, full of brave and valiant men, being now fallen into the power of an Army, which of nece≈øsity mu≈øt live, were forced to con≈øent to a contribution by Treaty, and a very heavy one, though ≈øuch without which the Scoti≈øh Army could not ≈øub≈øi≈øt.

The agreement was 350. l. a day for the Bi≈øhopricke of Dure≈øme, 300. l. a day for Northumberland, 200. a day for the Towne of Newca≈øtle, in all 850. l. a day; which, ≈øhould it continue, would amount unto 300000. l. for one yeare.
The≈øe Gentlemen much lamented their e≈øtates that the Scots ≈øhould be irritated (as they call it) by being proclaimed Traytors.

His Lord≈øhip made a little digre≈øsion, and asked leave to ≈øpeake truth in ≈øuch language, as the Scots had pre≈øented their ≈øtate unto them: That having proclamation made again≈øt them, being threatned with a great Army of thirty or forty thou≈øand men; another of ten thou≈øand out of Ireland, and by Parliament
declared Traytors and Rebels, and having heard of another Army providing, of eight or ten thou≈øand by ≈øhipping to hinder their Trade, at lea≈øt their Commerce with England, that they were drawne together by nece≈øsity, as they pretended, of defence; further alledging that it was a common di≈øcour≈øe, of which they had ≈øeene papers, that they ≈øhould bee reduced into a Province, which would be but one Summers worke; and therefore they having drawne their power together, as any Nation would doe, and being a≈ø≈øembled, and their Country being poore, taking advantage of the time, and that all tho≈øe Armies that ≈øhould oppo≈øe them were out of the way, and tho≈øe unfortunate Provinces left like a li≈øt of Cloath; they were forced to enter in England; that thus they had lamented, and thus the ≈øtate ≈øtood before the Lords, when it was examined in the great Councell.

Thus their Lord≈øhips found, that the Scots had increa≈øed their confines neere foure≈øcore miles in England, and had pa≈ø≈øed the Rivers of Tweed and Tyne; and that the River of Tees the boundary of Yorke≈øhire, (Dure≈øme being po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed) was not to be defended, being foordable in many places by forty hor≈øe a front; that if the Scots ≈øhould pa≈ø≈øe that River, there was no po≈øsibility to hinder them from comming to Yorke, or to any part of England, without hazarding a Battell, which my Lord Lievtenant had declared unto them he would not advi≈øe, for though the Kings Army con≈øi≈øted of ≈øeventeene or eighteene thou≈øand good bodies of men; yet being untrained and unu≈øed to Armes, he would be loath to hazzard ≈øuch an Adventure upon them; but if they ≈øhould advance to Yorke, hee might make good that Citie: This being the ca≈øe as it was pre≈øented, my Lords advi≈øed his Maje≈øty that they conceived the fitte≈øt way
was, that the Scots and their grievances might bee heard.

And whereas their maine Complaint had beene, that their Petitions to his Maje≈øty had beene conveyed by Conduits of an evill relli≈øh, that there might be cho≈øen ≈øuch Lords Commi≈øsioners, of who≈øe integrity they could not doubt.

Whereupon, his Maje≈øty was plea≈øed to referre the choyce of the Commi≈øsioners to the great Councell, who made the election with the a≈ø≈øent of his Maje≈øty,The Commi≈ø≈øioners names N. B. to whom power was given, under the great ≈øeale of England, to heare what≈øoever the Scots would lay before them; and to enter into Treatie with them, and to give ≈øafe conducts, and to do all things preparatory to a Treaty.
The fir≈øt place of meeting was appointed at North-Allerton, but ≈øome inconveniences being found, it was by con≈øent transferred to Rippon.
For the inducement of this meeting,N. B. a Letter of the Lord Lanricks to the Scots Commi≈øsioners was read and given unto us.

The Treaty thus ≈øettled, the Lords to be imployed receiving in≈øtructions from his Maje≈øty, by the con≈øent of the great Councell; it was agreed they ≈øhould treat upon the whole bu≈øine≈ø≈øe propounded by the Scots, and left to their di≈øcretion to treate of a Ce≈ø≈øation of Arms, as the ordinary fore-runner of all Treaties of Peace.

When their Lord≈øhips came to Rippon, the Ce≈ø≈øation of Armes was the fir≈øt propo≈øed, but being entered upon it, the Scots Commi≈øsioners did let their Lord≈øhips know, that there was ≈øomething nece≈ø≈øary fir≈øt to be done, that the Countreys where they lay were become poore; that they could not thinke, as their affaires ≈øtood, of returning home; that his Maje≈øty had re≈øtrayned them from pa≈øsing further: ≈øo
that a Treaty in this Exigent was wor≈øe then a Warre, unle≈ø≈øe meanes might be thought upon how they might ≈øub≈øi≈øt; and hereupon they did propound, that if it were expected that they made no further progre≈ø≈øe therein, obeying his Maje≈øties command, which nothing but invincible nece≈øsity ≈øhould force them to tran≈øgre≈ø≈øe, by plundring the Countreys, they mu≈øt have maintenance for their Army.

This motion ≈øeemed very ≈øtrange to their Lord≈øhips, that it ≈øhould be demanded to provide a maintenance for the Scots, when the Kings owne Army was in great di≈øtre≈ø≈øe; yet the nece≈øsity ≈øeemed to be ≈øuch on both ≈øides, that the Lords appointed ≈øome of their Company to repaire to the King at Yorke, to acquaint his Maje≈øty with the Scots demand.

Upon debate of the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, though it were of hard dige≈øtion to his Maje≈øty, the Lords, and the whole Kingdome, that they, who≈øe Ance≈øtors had been called to advi≈øe upon the Ran≈øome of Kings, ≈øhould now come to con≈øult how to maintaine an Army got into our owne bowels; Therefore, their Lord≈øhips would not proceed without the knowledge of his Maje≈øty and the great Councell; where it was found nece≈ø≈øary, not for maintaining the Scots Armies (for they might ea≈øily ≈øupply their owne wants by plundring, in which cour≈øe they might get a million, whereas five thou≈øand pounds would ≈øerve but for two months) but to pre≈øerve the Countreys from utter ruine, and the Scots from further advancing, to give to their Lord≈øhips Commi≈øsion to treate for a competency of maintenance during the Treaty.

The fir≈øt demand was forty thou≈øand pounds a moneth, which by Treaty was reduced thus: That in≈øtead of giving them any allowance, they ≈øhould bee left to their proportion of that contribution already agreed upon by the Counties, as le≈ø≈øe di≈øhonourable
then to a≈øsigne them maintenance.

This point being thus ≈øettled,N. D. E. their Lord≈øhips proceeded to the Treaty of Se≈øsions, and both were agreed and concluded, his Lord≈øhip propo≈øing the Articles them≈øelves to bee read for more ≈øatisfaction.

His Lord≈øhip proceeded, that the≈øe preparatives being ≈øettled at Rippon, twenty miles from Yorke, and the time far ≈øpent, and the Parliament approaching, their Lord≈øhips re≈øolved to bee humble ≈øuitors to his Maje≈øty, that the generall Treaty might be tran≈øferred to London, by con≈øent of both parties thereunto agreeing.
Here his Lord≈øhip propo≈øed the reading of a Letter whereby this tran≈ølation of the Treaty was moved, which was done and delivered unto us.

To this Letter his Maje≈øty made a gracious an≈øwer, and con≈øented to transferre the Treaty to London, where ≈øome of the Scots Commi≈øsioners are already arrived, and the re≈øt within a day or two expected.

Their Lord≈øhips having proceeded in the Treaty as far as they could goe, repaired to Yorke, and both Articles concluded were read in his Maje≈øties pre≈øence; and that they declared that they had in all things punctually ob≈øerved their In≈øtructions, whereupon his Maje≈øty required them to give their coun≈øell, whether he ≈øhould ratifie and ≈øigne the≈øe Articles or not.

To which the Lords made an≈øwer, that they had ≈øerved his Maje≈øty in quality of Commi≈øsioners Amba≈ø≈øadours and had duly ob≈øerved their In≈øtructions; but now He being plea≈øed to aske their advice, they would bee glad to ≈øerve him according to their con≈øciences, and therefore be≈øought his Maje≈øty for leave to retire them≈øelves, and con≈øult of the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe; to
which his Maje≈øty was graciou≈øly plea≈øed to con≈øent.

Upon re≈øolution, con≈øidering the great ≈øtrait into which his Maje≈øties affaires were reduced, they concluded to advi≈øe his Maje≈øty to ≈øigne, and craved leave to pre≈øent unto his Maje≈øty a declaration of their rea≈øons; which were accepted and read in the great Councell.
And their Lord≈øhips held it nece≈ø≈øary to bee read againe in that great A≈ø≈øembly,N. G. as the re≈øt of their Councell.
The≈øe rea≈øons being read, his Maje≈øty was plea≈øed to ratifie the Articles in expre≈ø≈øe words al≈øo read unto us.

His Lord≈øhip concluded this Narrative as the full account of the Treaty,N. D. and proceeding in it to his Maje≈øties ratification; and craved leave in the next place, to pre≈øent the hard and wofull condition in which his Maje≈øties affaires then ≈øtood in the North:
Fir≈øt, that by con≈øent a contribution of 850. l. a day was agreed.
That there was already ≈øome doubt that the Countries were not able to beare it.

On the other ≈øide, it was objected by the Scots, that it was impo≈øsible if the payment ≈øhould faile, to keepe their promi≈øe, or to obey his Maje≈øty, but that they ≈øhould be nece≈øsitated again≈øt their will to plunder the Country.

The≈øe doubts con≈øidered, it was declared by my Lord Lievtenant, that the Counties of Cumberland and We≈øtmerland being at plea≈øure under the Scots power, it was rea≈øonable that in ≈øub≈øidium they ≈øhould contribute ≈øome helpe to their Neighbours: But hee declared ≈øince their Lord≈øhips coming away, the Commi≈øsioners left at Dure≈øme had written, that it
was impo≈øsible for them to proceed in the agreement; which if it were broken on their part, the Scots would alledge an impo≈øsibility to con≈øent to ≈øtarve; ≈øo that if ≈øome meanes were not found, by which tho≈øe Counties engaged might bee relieved, hee was affraid all their labour and Treaty would come to nothing: and this letter was read and pre≈øented unto us.
His Lord≈øhip repre≈øented,N. H. that the Commi≈øsioners and all the Lords had engaged them≈øelves faithfully and truly to declare to the Parliament the di≈øtre≈ø≈øe of the Counties.

Hee declared that it was far from their Lord≈øhips purpo≈øe to move any ≈øupply of money from the Hou≈øe of Commons, but to lay the cau≈øe before them, and to leave it to their wi≈øedome; averring certainly that if ≈øome cour≈øe were not taken, the whole kingdome would be put into di≈øorder; Armies would not ≈øtarve, retiring was not yet as hee thought in the thoughts of the Scots: Therefore they mu≈øt plunder and de≈øtroy, or advance into Yorke≈øhire, and ≈øo into England to ≈øeeke ≈øub≈øi≈øtence; the prevention whereof did highly import the King and kingdome.

His Lord≈øhip propo≈øed another, no le≈ø≈øe worthy of con≈øideration to the whole kingdome: But if the Scots Army were provided of a competency for the ea≈øe of tho≈øe Counties, it were very ≈øtrange there ≈øhould not an equall care be had for mainteining the Kings Army that ≈øtands before them. He ≈øaid the Scots Army was ≈øtrong and powerfull, and little other re≈øi≈øtance again≈øt it, but the impediments of an Army marching in winter: But whether it were fit for a kingdome to bee tru≈øted to accidents of Fro≈øts, with a people bred in Swedland
and cold Countreys, hee left to their di≈øcretion.

His Lord≈øhip confe≈ø≈øed, that the Scots had made great prote≈øtations, and with great execrations averred, that they had no intent to advance forward, but returne when they ≈øhall have received ≈øatisfaction.
Yet their Lord≈øhips did not conceive that the kingdome ≈øhould relye upon promi≈øes or prote≈øtations.

Many accidents might happen when a Nation, come from a farre Countrey to a better, ≈øhould bee told the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe they come about was ju≈øt and their quarrell good; who finding them≈øelves in a fat pa≈øture, may pick quarrells which their Leaders, if they ≈øhould goe about to prevent them of the reward of their vertue and valour.

Upon the≈øe grounds his Lord≈øhip pre≈øented to the generall con≈øideration the ≈øupply of his Maje≈øties Army, that it bee not disbanded; which if it ≈øhould come to pa≈ø≈øe. Yorke≈øhire and other parts of England were left to the Scots di≈øcretion.

His Lord≈øhip ≈øaid, Hee dur≈øt not ≈øay the Scots would not come forward, but that it was in their power if they would; and therefore hee recommended this repre≈øentation to the whole body of the kingdome, to prevent furture dangers.

Hee concluded with a prayer to Almighty God, to direct the hearts of all the kingdome, and to give a ble≈øsing onely able to remove the great di≈øtractions, ≈øo many and ≈øo grievous, as under which, ≈øince the Conque≈øt, this kingdome never laboured.

There were pre≈øented unto mee two papers more, the one being In≈øtructions from Newca≈øtle to Sir Thomas Hope and others, concerning the contribution; the other an account of Arreers from the eleventh of September to the twentieth of November, which were all read unto us; nor doe I know how or to what u≈øe to imploy them.

div.head: Mr. RIGBYES SPEECH, In an≈øwer to the LORD KEEPERS la≈øt SPEECH, 1640.
div.p: THough my Judgement prompts mee to fit ≈øtill and be ≈øilent, yet the duty I owe to my King, my Countrey and my Con≈øcience, moves me to ≈øtand up and ≈øpeake.

Ma≈øter Speaker, had not this Syren ≈øo ≈øweet a tongue, ≈øurely hee could never have effected ≈øo much mi≈øchiefe to this kingdome: you know Sir, optimorum putrefactio pe≈øsima, the be≈øt things putrefied become the wor≈øt: and as it is in the naturall, ≈øo in the body politick; and whats to be done then Ma≈øter Speaker, wee all know, en≈øe recidendum e≈øt, the ≈øword, Ju≈øtice mu≈øt ≈øtrike, n√® ≈øinceratruhatur.

Ma≈øter Speaker, it is not the voice, non vox ≈øed votum, not the tongue, but the heart and actions that are to be ≈øu≈øpected: for doth not our Saviour ≈øay it, Shew mee thy faith by thy workes, O Man? Now, Ma≈øter Speaker, hath not this kingdome ≈øeene, (≈øeene ≈øay I?) nay felt and ≈ømarted under the cruelty of this mans Ju≈øtice? ≈øo malicious as to record it in every Court of We≈øtmin≈øter; as if hee had not beene contented with the en≈ølaving of us all, unle≈ø≈øe hee entailed it to all
po≈øterity. Why ≈øhall I beleeve words now, cum factum videam? Shall we be ≈øo weake men, as when wee have beene injured and abu≈øed, will be gained againe with faire words and complements? Or, like little children, when we have beene whipt and beaten, bee plea≈øed againe with ≈øweet meats? Oh no: there be ≈øome birds in the Summer of Parliament will ≈øing ≈øweetly, who in the Winter of Per≈øecution will for their prey ravenou≈øly fly at all, upon our goods, nay ≈øeize upon our per≈øons; and hath it not beene with this man ≈øo, with ≈øome in this a≈ø≈øembly?

Ma≈øter Speaker, it hath beene objected unto us, that in Judgement wee ≈øhould thinke of mercy, and Bee yee mercifull as your heavenly Father is mercifull; now God almighty grant that we may be ≈øo, and that our hearts and Judgements may be truly rectified to know truly what is mercy, I ≈øay to know what is mercy; for there is the point Ma≈øter Speaker: I have heard of fooli≈øh pitty, fooli≈øh pitty: doe we not all know the effects of it? and I have met with this Epithete to mercy, Crudelis mi≈øericordia; and in ≈øome kind I thinke there may be a cruell mercy: I am ≈øure that the ≈øpirit of God ≈øaid, Be not pitifull in Judgement, nay it ≈øaith, Bee not pitifull of the poore in Judgement; if not of the poore, then a Latiori, not of the rich; there's the Empha≈øis. We ≈øee by the ≈øett and ≈øolemne appointments of our Courts of Ju≈øtice, what provi≈øion the wi≈øedome of our Ance≈øtors hath made for the pre≈øervation, honour and e≈øteeme of Ju≈øtice, witne≈ø≈øe our frequent Termes, Se≈ø≈øions and A≈øsi≈øes, and in what pompe and ≈øtate the Judges in their Circuits, by the Sheriffes, Knights, and Ju≈øtices, and all the Countrey, are attended oft-times for the hanging of a poore thiefe for the ≈øtealing of a hog or a ≈øheep, nay in ≈øome Ca≈øes for the ≈øtealing of a penny, and Ju≈øtice too, in terrorem; and now ≈øhall not ≈øome of them be hanged
that have rob'd us of all our propriety, and ≈øheered at once all our ≈øheepe and all we have away, and would have made us all indeed poore Bellizara≈ø≈øes to have begged for halfe-pennies, when they would not have left us one penny that wee could have called our owne?

Let us therefore now, Ma≈øter Speaker, not be ≈øo pitifull as that wee become remi≈ø≈øe; not ≈øo pitifull in Judgement, as to have no Judgement; but ≈øet the deplorable e≈øtate of Great Brittain now before our eyes, and con≈øider how our mo≈øt gracious Soveraigne hath beene abu≈øed, and both his Maje≈øty and all his Subjects injured by the≈øe wicked In≈øtruments; for which my humble motion is, that with the≈øe particulars wee become not ≈øo mercifull, as to the generality (the whole kingdome) wee grow mercile≈ø≈øe.

div.head: Mr. VVALERS SPEECH, In the HOUSE of COMMONS, 1640.
div.p: I Will u≈øe no preface, as they u≈øe to doe who appeare men for ≈øome thing to which they would per≈øwade and move their affections: I will onely propo≈øe what I conceive fit for the Hou≈øe to con≈øider, and ≈øhall be no more concerned in the event then they that ≈øhall heare mee.
Two things I ob≈øerve in his Maje≈øties demands:

list.item: Fir≈øt, the ≈øupply,
Secondly, our ≈øpeedy di≈øpatch thereof.
