div.p: Touching the fir≈øt, his Maje≈øties occa≈øions for mony are but too evident; for to ≈øay nothing how wee are neglected abroad, or di≈øtracted at home, the calling of this Parliament and our ≈øitting here (an effect which no light cau≈øe could in the≈øe times have produced) is enough to make any rea≈øonable man beleeve that the Exchequer abounds not ≈øo much in money, as the State in occa≈øions to u≈øe it; and I hope we ≈øhall all appeare willing to di≈øprove tho≈øe who have thought to di≈ø≈øwade his Maje≈øty from this way of Parliament, as doubting and uncertaine, and to let him ≈øee that it is as ready and more ≈øafe for the advancement of his affaires, then any new or pretended old way what≈øoever.

Now (Ma≈øter Speaker) for the ≈øpeedy di≈øpatch required, which was the ≈øecond thing, not onely his Maje≈øtie but Res ip≈øa loquitur; the occa≈øion ≈øeemes to importune no le≈ø≈øe: nece≈øsity is come upon us like an armed man, and yet the u≈øe of Parliaments heretofore, (which appeare by the writs that call us hither) was to advi≈øe with his Maje≈øty of things concerning the Church and common-wealth.

And, Ma≈øter Speaker, it hath ever been the cu≈øtome of Parliaments, by good and whole≈øome lawes to refre≈øh the Common-wealth in generall, yea and to de≈øcend into the remedies of particular grievances, before any mention made of ≈øupply. Looke backe upon the be≈øt Parliaments, and ≈øtill you ≈øhall finde that the la≈øt Acts are the free gift of the Sub≈øidies on the peoples part, and generall pardons on the Kings part; even the wi≈øe≈øt Kings have acquainted their Parliaments with their de≈øignes, and the rea≈øons thereof, and then demanded the a≈øsi≈øtance both of their coun≈øell and their pur≈øes: But (Ma≈øter Speaker) Phy≈øicians (though they be called of the late≈øt) mu≈øt not ≈øtomach it, or talke what might have beene, but apply them≈øelves roundly to the cure; let us not ≈øtand too nicely upon circum≈øtances, nor too rigidly po≈øt po≈øe the matter of ≈øupply, to the healing of our lighter wounds. Let us doe what po≈øsibly may be done with rea≈øon and hone≈øty on our parts to comply with his Maje≈øties de≈øires, and to prevent the imminent ills which threaten us: but con≈øider (Ma≈øter Speaker) that they that thinke them≈øelves undone can never apprehend them≈øelves in danger, and they that have nothing left can never give freely, nor ≈øhall we ever di≈øcharge the tru≈øt of tho≈øe that ≈øent us hither, or make them beleeve that they contribute to their owne defence and ≈øafety, unle≈ø≈øe his Maje≈øty be plea≈øed, fir≈øt to re≈øtore them to the propriety of their goods and lawfull liberties,
whereof they e≈øteeme them≈øelves now out of po≈ø≈øe≈øsion. One need not tell you that the propriety of goods is the mother of courage, and nur≈øe of indu≈øtry, makes us all valiant in war, and good husbands in peace: the experience I heare of former Parliaments, and my pre≈øent ob≈øervation of the care the Countrey hath had to choo≈øe per≈øons of worth and courage, makes mee thinke this Hou≈øe like the Spartans, who≈øe forward valour required ≈øome ≈øofter mu≈øicke to allay and quiet their ≈øpirits, too much moved with the ≈øound of martiall In≈øtruments. 'Tis not the feare of impri≈øonment, or, if need be, of death it ≈øelfe that can keepe a true hearted Engli≈øh-man from the care to leave this part of his inheritance as intire to po≈øterity as hee received it from his Ance≈øtors.

This therefore let us fir≈øt doe, (and the more ≈øpeedily,) that we may come to the matter of ≈øupply; let us give new force to the many lawes which have beene heretofore made for the mainteining of our rights and priviledges, and to re≈øtore this Nation to the fundamentall and vitall liberties, the propriety of our goods, and freedome of our per≈øons; no way doubting but we ≈øhall find his Maje≈øty as gracious and ready, as any of his Royall progenitors have beene, to grant our ju≈øt de≈øires therein: for, not onely the people doe thinke, but the wi≈øe≈øt doe know, that what wee have ≈øuffered, wee have ≈øuffered from his Mini≈øters. That the per≈øon of no King was ever better beloved of his people, and that no people were ever more un≈øatisfied with the wayes of levying moneys, are two truths which may ≈øerve one to demon≈øtrate the other; for ≈øuch is their acce≈øsion to the pre≈øent cour≈øes, that neither the admiration they have of his Maje≈øties native inclination to Ju≈øtice and Clemency, nor the pretended con≈øent of the Judges, could make them
willingly ≈øubmit them≈øelves to this late tax; and ≈øuch is their naturall loves, and ju≈øt e≈øteeme of his Maje≈øties goodne≈ø≈øe, that no late pre≈ø≈øure could provoke them, not any example invite them to di≈øloyalty or di≈øobedience. But what is it then hath bred this mi≈øunder≈øtanding betwixt the King and his people? How is it that having ≈øo good a King, wee have ≈øo much to complaine of? Why (Ma≈øter Speaker) wee are told of the ≈øonne of Solomon that hee was a Prince of a tender heart, and yet we ≈øee, by the advice of violent coun≈øels, how rough an an≈øwer he gave to his people. That his finger ≈øhould bee as heavy as his fathers loynes, was not his owne, but the voyce of ≈øome per≈øons about him, that wanted the gravity of moderation requi≈øite for the Coun≈øellors of a young King. I love not to pre≈ø≈øe Allegories too far; but the re≈øemblance of Jobs ≈øtory with ours holds ≈øo well that I cannot but ob≈øerve it to you. It plea≈øed God to give his Enemy leave to afflict him more then once or twice, and to take all hee had from him, and yet he was not provoked to rebell ≈øo much as with his tongue, (although hee had no very good example of one that lay very neere him,) and felt not halfe that which he ≈øuffered. I hope his Maje≈øty will imitate God in the benigner part too, and as he was ≈øevere to Job onely while hee di≈øcour≈øed with another concerning him, but when hee vouch≈øafed to ≈øpeake him≈øelfe unto him, began to rebuke tho≈øe who had mi≈øtaken and mi≈ø-judged his Ca≈øe, and to re≈øtore the patient man to his former pro≈øperity: ≈øo now, that his Maje≈øty hath admitted us to his pre≈øence, and ≈øpoken face to face with us, I doubt not but wee ≈øhall ≈øee fairer dayes, and be as rich in the po≈ø≈øe≈øsion of our owne as ever wee were. I wonder at tho≈øe that ≈øeeme to doubt the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of this Parliament, or that the mi≈øunder≈øtanding betwixt the King and his People ≈øhould la≈øt any longer, now
they have ≈øo happily met. His Maje≈øties wants are not ≈øo great, but that we may find meanes to ≈øupply him; nor our de≈øires ≈øo unrea≈øonable, or ≈øo incompetible with government, but that his Maje≈øty may well ≈øatisfie them. For our late experience (I hope) will teach us what rocks to ≈øhunne and how nece≈øtary the u≈øe of moderation is: And for his Maje≈øty, he hath had experience enough how that pro≈øpers which is gotten without the concurrent good will of his people: never more money taken from the Subject, never more want in the Exchequer. If we looke upon what we have payd, it is more then ever the people of England did in ≈øuch a time; if we looke upon what hath beene effected therewith, it ≈øhewes as if never King had beene wor≈øe ≈øupplyed; ≈øo that we ≈øeeme to have acted Belids part, who≈øe puni≈øhment was to endevour the filling of a Sive with water. Who≈øoever gave advice for the≈øe cour≈øes, hath made good the ≈øaying of the wi≈øe man, Qui conturbat domum ≈øuam po≈øsidebit ventum. By new wayes they think to accompli≈øh wonders, but in truth they gra≈øpe the winde, and are in the meane time ≈øaevus ambobus Achilles, cruell to us, and to the King too: for if the Common-wealth flouri≈øh, then hee that hath the Soveraignty can never want nor doe ami≈ø≈øe, ≈øo as hee governe not according to the intere≈øt of others, but goe the ≈øhorte≈øt and the ≈øafe≈øt wayes to his owne and the common good, with regard how they ≈øtand in order to any private mans de≈øires, or a pre≈øervation. The Kings of this Nation have alwayes governed by Parliaments: And if wee looke upon the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of things ≈øince Parliaments were layd by, it re≈øembles that of the Grecians, Ex illo fluere & vetito ≈øublap≈øa referri Rex Danaum, e≈øpecially on the Subjects parts; for though the King hath gotten little, they have lo≈øt all: but his Maje≈øty ≈øhall heare the truth from us, and wee ≈øhall
make to appeare the errors of Divines, who would per≈øwade us that a Monarch can be ab≈øolute, and that he may doe all things, ad libitum, receding not onely from their text, (though that be a wandring too) but from the way which their owne profe≈øsion would teach them, Stare ≈øuper vias antiquas, and remove not the ancient bounds and land-markes which our Fathers have ≈øet. If to be ab≈øolute were to be re≈øtrained by no lawes, then can no King in Chri≈øtendome be ≈øo, for they all ≈øtand obliged to the Lawes Chri≈øtian, and we aske no more: For to this Pillar are our priviledges fixt, our Kings at their Coronation taking a ≈øacred oath not to infringe them. I am ≈øorry the≈øe men take not more care of informing our faith of tho≈øe things which they tell us for our ≈øoules health, whiles we know them ≈øo manife≈øtly in the wrong, in that which concerns the liberties & priviledges of the Subjects of England: But they gaine preferment, and then 'tis no matter, though they never beleeve them≈øelves nor are beleeved of others. But ≈øince they are ≈øo ready to let loo≈øe the Con≈øcience of our Kings, we are the more carefully to provide for our protection again≈øt this Pulpit-Law, by declaring and re inforcing the Municipall Lawes of this kingdome. It is worth the ob≈øerving how new this opinion is, or rather this way of ri≈øing, even among≈øt them≈øelves. For, Ma≈øter Hooker, who ≈øure was no refractory man (as they terme it) thinkes that the fir≈øt Government was arbitrary, untill it was found, that to live by one mans will became the cau≈øe of all mens mi≈øeries, (the≈øe are his words;) and that this was the originall of inventing Lawes. And (Ma≈øter Speaker.) if we looke furtner back, our Hi≈øtories will tell us that the Prelates of this kingdome have often beene the mediators betweene the King and his Subjects, to pre≈øent and pray redre≈ø≈øe of their grievances, and had reciprocally
then as much love and reverence from the People: but the≈øe Preachers, more active then their Predece≈ø≈øors, and wi≈øer then the Lawes, have found out a better forme of Government; the King mu≈øt bee more ab≈øolute Monarch then any of his Predece≈ø≈øors, and to them hee mu≈øt owe it, though in the meane time they hazzard the hearts of his people, and involve him into a thou≈øand difficulties. For, ≈øuppo≈øe this forme of Government were inconvenient, and yet (Ma≈øter Speaker) this is but a ≈øuppo≈øition, for the≈øe five hundred yeares it hath not onely mainteined us in ≈øafety, but made us victorious over other Nations; but (I ≈øay) ≈øuppo≈øe they have another Idea of one more convenient, wee all know how dangerous Innovations are, and what hazzard tho≈øe Princes runne, that enterpri≈øe the change of a long e≈øtabli≈øhed Government. Now (Ma≈øter Speaker) of all our Kings that have gone before, and of all that are to ≈øucceed in this happy race, why ≈øhould ≈øo pious and ≈øo good a King bee expo≈øed to this trouble and hazzard? be≈øides that, Kings ≈øo diverted can never doe any great matter abroad. But (Ma≈øter Speaker) whiles the≈øe men have thus bent their wits again≈øt the Lawes of their Countrey, whether they have neglected their owne Province, and what Tares are growne up in the field which they ≈øhould have tilled, I leave it to a ≈øecond con≈øideration; not but that Religion ought to bee the fir≈øt thing in our purpo≈øes and de≈øires, but that which is fir≈øt in dignity is not alwayes to precede in order of time; for, well-being ≈øuppo≈øes a being, and the fir≈øt impediment which men naturally indevour to remove, is the want of tho≈øe things without which they cannot ≈øub≈øi≈øt. God fir≈øt a≈ø≈øigned unto Adam maintenance of life, and gave him a title to the re≈øt of the Creatures before he appointed a Law to ob≈øerve. And let me tell you (if our adver≈øaries have any ≈øuch
de≈øigne) as there is nothing more ea≈øie then to impo≈øe Religion on a People deprived of their Liberties, ≈øo there is nothing more hard then to doe the ≈øame upon Freemen. And therefore (Ma≈øter Speaker) I conclude with this motion, that an order may bee pre≈øently made, that the fir≈øt thing this Hou≈øe will con≈øider of, ≈øhall be the re≈øtoring this Nation in generall to the fundamentall and vitall Liberties, the propriety of our goods, and freedome of our Per≈øons: and that then wee will forthwith con≈øider of the ≈øupply de≈øired; and thus wee ≈øhall di≈øcharge the tru≈øt repo≈øed in us by tho≈øe that ≈øent us hither, his Maje≈øty will ≈øee that wee make more then ordinary ha≈øte to ≈øatisfie his demands, and wee ≈øhall let all tho≈øe know that ≈øeeke to ha≈øten the matter of ≈øupply, that they will ≈øo far delay it, as they give interruption to the former.

div.head: A Speech made by the Honourable DENZELL HOLLES, E≈øquire, at a Conference by a Committee of both Hou≈øes of Parliament in the painted Chamber, May 4. 1641. in the pre≈øenting of the Prote≈øtation.
div.p: THe Knights, Citizens and Burge≈ø≈øes of the Hou≈øe of Commons, having taken into their ≈øerious con≈øideration the pre≈øent e≈øtate and condition of this Kingdome, they find it ≈øurrounded with variety of pernitious and de≈øtructive de≈øignes, practices, and plots again≈øt the well-being of it, nay, the very being of it, and ≈øome of the≈øe de≈øignes hatched within our owne bowels, and, viper-like, working our de≈øtruction.
They finde Je≈øuites and Prie≈øts con≈øpiring with ill Mini≈øters of State to de≈øtroy our Religion: they find ill Mini≈øters conjoyned together to ≈øubvert our Lawes and Liberties.

They find ob≈øtructions of Ju≈øtice, which is the life bloud of every State, and (having a free pa≈ø≈øage from the Soveraigne Power, where it is primarily
≈øeated, as the life bloud in the heart, and thence derived through the ≈øeverall Judicatories, as through ≈øo many veines, into all the parts of this great collective Body) doth give warmth and motion to every part and member, which is nouri≈øhed and enlivened by it: but being once precluded, ≈øtopped, and ≈øeared up, as the particular mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øity faint and langui≈øh, ≈øo mu≈øt the whole frame of Government bee di≈ø≈øolved: and con≈øequently Soveraignty it ≈øelfe, which as the heart in the body, is Primum vivens, & ultimum moriens, mu≈øt dye and peri≈øh in the generall di≈ø≈øolution, and all things returne, as in the beginning, in antiquum Chaos.

They find the propriety of the ≈øubject invaded and violated, his e≈øtate rent from him by illegall Taxations, Impo≈øitions, Monopolies and Projects (almo≈øt upon every thing which is for the u≈øe of man) not onely upon ≈øuperfluities, but nece≈ø≈øaries; and this to enrich the vermine and caterpillers of the Land, and to impoveri≈øh the good ≈øubjects, to take the meate from the children, and give it to dogges.

My Lords, If we find the≈øe things ≈øo, wee mu≈øt conceive, they mu≈øt bee ill coun≈øels which have brought us into this condition: The≈øe coun≈øels have put all into a combu≈øtion, have di≈øcouraged the hearts of all true Engli≈øh men, and have brought two Armies into our bowels, which (as the Vulture upon Prometheus) eate through our ≈øides, and gnaw our very hearts.

p.hi: Hinc dolor: ≈øed unde medicina?

div.p: Heretofore Parliaments were the Catholicon, the Balme of Gilead which healed our wounds, re≈øtored our Spirits, and made up all the breaches of the Land; But of late yeeres they have beene like the Fig-tree in the Go≈øpel, without efficacy, without fruit, onely de≈øtructive to the particular members, who di≈øcharge their duties and con≈øciences, no way beneficiall to the Common-wealth; Nobis exitiabile, nec Reipub. profuturum, as he ≈øaid in Tacitus; commonly taken away, as Elias was, with a whirle-winde, never coming to any maturity, or to their naturall end; whereas they ≈øhould bee like that ble≈ø≈øed old man, who dyeth (plenus dierum) in a full age, after hee hath fought a good fight, and overcome all his enemies; as the ≈øhock of wheat which cometh in in due ≈øea≈øon, to fill our Granaries with Corne, uphold our lives with the ≈øtaffe of bread.
For, Parliaments are our panis quotidianus, our true bread; all other wayes are but Quelques cho≈øes, which yeeld no true nouri≈ø≈øhment, breede no good bloud.
This very Parliament which hath ≈øate ≈øo long, hath all this while but beaten the ayre, and ≈øtriven again≈øt the ≈øtreame; for I may truely ≈øay, winde and tide have ≈øtill been again≈øt us.

The ≈øame ill coun≈øels which fir≈øt rai≈øed the ≈øtorme, which almo≈øt ≈øhipwrackt the Common-wealth, do ≈øtill continue; they blow ≈øtrong like the Ea≈øt-wind that brought the Locu≈øts over the land.

The≈øe coun≈øels cro≈ø≈øe our de≈øignes, ea≈øt difficulties in our way, hinder our proceedings, and make all that we doe to be fruitle≈ø≈øe and ineffectuall; they make us to bee not ma≈øters of our bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, and ≈øo not ma≈øters of money, which hath been the great bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of this Parliament, that we might pay the Armies according to our promi≈øes and engagements.
For, (My Lords) our not effecting of the good things which wee had undertaken for the good of the Church and Common-wealth, hath wounded our reputation, and taken off from our credit.

Is it not time then (my Lords) that wee ≈øhould unite and concentrate our ≈øelves in regard of this Antiperi≈øta≈øis and circumvallation of hurtfull and malitious intentions and practices again≈øt us? (My Lords) it is mo≈øt agreeable to nature, and I am ≈øure, mo≈øt agreeable to rea≈øon, in re≈øpect of the pre≈øent conjuncture of our affaires: for one maine engine by which our enemies work our mi≈øchiefe, is by infu≈øing an opinion and belief into the world, that wee are not united among≈øt our ≈øelves; but that, like Samp≈øons Foxes, we draw ≈øeverall waies, and tend to ≈øeverall ends.

To defeate then the coun≈øels of tho≈øe Achitophels, which would involve us, our Religion, our King, our Lawes, our Liberties, all that can bee neere and deare unto an hone≈øt ≈øoule, in one univer≈øall and generall de≈øolation; to defeate (I ≈øay) the coun≈øels of ≈øuch Achitophels, the Knights, Citizens, and Burge≈ø≈øes of the Hou≈øe of Commons
(knowing them≈øelves to bee ≈øpecially intru≈øted with the pre≈øervation of the whole, and in their con≈øciences per≈øwaded that the dangers are ≈øo imminent that they will admit of no delay) have thought fit to declare their united affections, by entring into an A≈ø≈øociation among≈øt them≈øelves, and by making a ≈øolemne Prote≈øtation and Vow unto their God, that they will unanimou≈øly endevour to oppo≈øe and prevent the coun≈øels, and the Coun≈øellors which have brought upon us all the≈øe mi≈øeries, and feares of greater; to prevent the ends, and bring the Authors of them to condign puni≈øhment, and thereby di≈øcharge them≈øelves both before God and man.

The Prote≈øtation your Lord≈øhips ≈øhall have read unto you, together with the grounds and rea≈øons which have induced the Hou≈øe of Commons to make it, which are prefixed before it by way of Preamble.

div.head: The PREAMBLE.
div.p:
WEe the Knights, Citizens, and Burge≈ø≈øes of the Commons hou≈øe in Parliament, finding, to the great griefe of our hearts, that the de≈øignes of the Prie≈øts and Je≈øuites, and other Adherents to the See of Rome, have of late beene more boldly and frequently put in practice then formerly, to the undermining and danger of the ruine of the true reformed Prote≈øtant Religion in His
Maje≈øties Dominions e≈øtabli≈øhed: And finding al≈øo that there have beene, and having ju≈øt cau≈øe to ≈øu≈øpect that there ≈øtill are, even during this ≈øitting in Parliament, indeavours to ≈øubvert the fundamentall Lawes of England and Ireland, and to introduce the exerci≈øe of an Arbitrary and Tyrannicall Government, by mo≈øt pernicious and wicked Coun≈øels, Practices, Plots, and Con≈øpiraces: And that the long intermi≈ø≈øion, and unhappy breach of Parliaments hath occa≈øioned many illegall Taxations, whereupon the Subject hath been pro≈øecuted and grieved: And that divers Innovations and Super≈øtitions have beene brought into the Church, multitudes driven out of His Maje≈øties Dominions, Jealou≈øies rai≈øed and fomented betwixt the King and His people, a Popi≈øh Army levied in Ireland, and two Armies brought into the bowels of this Kingdome, to the hazzard of His Maje≈øties Royall Per≈øon, the con≈øumption of the Revenues of the Crowne, and Trea≈øure of this Kingdome: And la≈øtly, finding great cau≈øe of Jealou≈øie, that indeavours have been, and are u≈øed to bring the Engli≈øh Army into a mi≈øunder≈øtanding of this Parliament, thereby to incline that Army, with force to bring to pa≈ø≈øe tho≈øe wicked Coun≈øels, Have therefore thought good to joyne our ≈øelves in a Declaration of our united affections and re≈øolutions.

NOte, That becau≈øe ≈øome doubts were rai≈øed by ≈øeverall per≈øons out of the Commons Hou≈øe, concerning the meaning of the≈øe words contained in the Prote≈øtation lately made by the Members of that Hou≈øe, viz. The true Reformed Prote≈øtant Religion, expre≈ø≈øed in the Doctrine of the Church of England again≈øt all Popery and Popi≈øh Innovations within this Realme, contrary to the ≈øame Doctrine; The Hou≈øe of Commons did declare, That by tho≈øe words, was and is meant only the publick Doctrine profe≈ø≈øed in the ≈øaid Church, ≈øo farre as it is oppo≈øite to Popery and Popi≈øh Innovations; And that the ≈øaid words are not to be extended to the maintaining of any forme of Wor≈øhip, Di≈øcipline, or Government, nor of any Rites or Ceremonies of the Church of England.

MY Lords, The Hou≈øe of Commons have commanded me to pre≈øent unto your Lord≈øhips this Prote≈øtation: Every member in that Hou≈øe hath made it, not one refu≈øing it; and they have ≈øent it unto your Lord≈øhips, with an a≈ø≈øurance of your Lord≈øhips concurrence in the ≈øame zeale and affection for the publick ≈øafety. And it is their de≈øire your Lord≈øhips would likewi≈øe make the ≈øame Prote≈øtation, which I humbly leave to your Lord≈øhips wi≈ødomes.

div.head: Directions for more orderly making of the fore≈øaid Prote≈øtation.
div.p: IT is thought fit that the Prote≈øtation which the Parliament late y made be taken by the Citie of London, in the ≈øeverall Pari≈øh Churches, in the afternoon of ≈øome Lords day, after Sermon, before the Congregation bee di≈ø≈øolved, by all Ma≈øters of Families, their ≈øons, and men-≈øervants, in manner and forme following, viz.

Fir≈øt, That forthwith notice of this intention bee given to the Mini≈øter, Church-wardens, and ≈øome other mee per≈øons of each Pari≈øh in London, Liberties, and adjacent Pari≈øhes, and ≈øome of them to give notice to the re≈øt of the Pari≈øhioners.

Secondly, That the Mini≈øter be entreated (if he plea≈øe) to acquaint his Pari≈øh in his Sermon, either forenoon or aftternoon, with the nature of the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, more or le≈ø≈øe, as hee ≈øhall think fit, for the better and more ≈øolemne taking of the ≈øaid Prote≈øtation; or if the Mini≈øter refu≈øe it, that ≈øome other bee intreated to preach that will promote the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe; or if neither of the≈øe may bee had, that ≈øome other convenient cour≈øe bee taken by ≈øome well affected to the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, to ≈øtay the Pari≈øh, and communicate the matter to them.

Thirdly, That the Mini≈øter or Mini≈øters of every
Congregation fir≈øt take it in his or their owne per≈øon, reading the ≈øaid Prote≈øtation in ≈øo di≈øtinct a voyce, that all pre≈øent may conveniently hear it, and that all the A≈ø≈øembly pre≈øent doe make the ≈øame Prote≈øtation di≈øtinctly after this manner, every man taking this Prote≈øtation into his hand.
IA. B. doe in the pre≈øence of Almighty God freely and heartily promi≈øe, vow, and prote≈øt the ≈øame which the leading per≈øon took, naming the per≈øon.

Fourthly, That there be a Regi≈øter Book wherin every man taking this vow or Prote≈øtation ≈øub≈øcribe his name, with his owne hand or mark, and that the names bee taken of ≈øuch as doe refu≈øe the ≈øame.

Fifthly, That all the Pari≈øhioners above≈øaid, whether in Towne, or out of Towne, be earne≈øtly reque≈øted to bee pre≈øent at their owne Pari≈øh Church in the afternoon of that Lords day whereon it ≈øhall be taken, that every man may take it in their owne place; and if any bee nece≈ø≈øarily ab≈øent, that they may bee de≈øired to take it the next Lords day after, or ≈øo ≈øoon as may bee with conveniency.
Sixthly, and la≈øtly, That all whom it doth not immediately concerne, bee earne≈øtly reque≈øted to depart.

div.head: Mr. Grimstons Speech in the High Court of Parliament.
div.p: THe≈øe Petitions which have beene now read, they are all Remon≈øtrances of the generall and univer≈øall grievances & di≈øtempers that are now in the State and Government of the Church and Commonwealth: and they are not them alone, But his Maje≈øties gracious Expre≈ø≈øions the fir≈øt day of Parliament, that calls me up to ≈øpeak at this pre≈øent, contrary to my owne Intentions.

Mr. Speaker, his Maje≈øtie, who is the head of the body politique, and the Father of the Common-wealth, hath complained fir≈øt, declaring his ≈øen≈øiblene≈ø≈øe of our ≈øufferings, and among≈øt other things, hath put us in mind of our grievances, and hath freely left it to our ≈øelves (for our redre≈ø≈øe and repaire therein) to begin and end, as we ≈øhall think fit. And this drawes mee on with much cheerefulne≈ø≈øe and zeale to contribute my poore endeavours to ≈øo great a work.

And Mr. Speaker, I conceive it will not be altogether impertinent for your direction and guidance in that great place, which by the favour of his Maje≈øtie, and this Hou≈øe you now po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe, a little to recollect our ≈øelves in the remembrance of what was done the la≈øt Parliament, and where we ended.

It will likewi≈øe be very con≈øiderable what hath bin done ≈øince that Parliament, and who they are that have beene the Authors and Cau≈øers of all our mi≈øeries and di≈øtractions, both before and ≈øithence.

Mr. Speaker, the la≈øt Parliament, as ≈øoone as the Hou≈øe was ≈øetled, a Sub≈øidiarie ayd and ≈øupply was propounded, and
many Arguments u≈øed to give the precedencie before all other matters and Con≈øiderations what≈øoever.

On the other ≈øide, a multitude of Complaints and Grievances of all ≈øorts, a≈øwell concerning our Eternall as our Temporall e≈øtates were pre≈øented and put in the other ballance: The wi≈øedome of that great Councell waighing both indifferently, and looking not onely upon the dangers then threatne ‚Ä¢ from Scotland (which are now upon us) but likewi≈øe taking into their con≈øideration the Condition and Con≈øtitution of the pre≈øent government here at home, concluded that they were in no capacity to give, unle≈ø≈øe their grievances were fir≈øt red re≈ø≈øed and removed.

For Mr. Speaker, it then was, and ≈øtill is, mo≈øt manife≈øt and apparent, that by ≈øome judgements lately obtained in Court of Ju≈øtice, and by ≈øome new wayes of Government lately ≈øt rted up among≈øt us; the Law of property is ≈øo much ≈øhaken, that no man can ≈øay he is Ma≈øter of any thing: But all that we have, wee hold as Tenants by courte≈øie, and at will, and may be ≈øtripped of it at plea≈øure.

Yet Mr. Speaker, de≈øirous to give his Maje≈øtie all po≈ø≈øible ≈øatisfaction and contentment, as well in the manner of ≈øupply for expedition, as in the ≈øub≈øtance and matter of it, wee confined and limitted our ≈øelves but to three particulars onely, and to ≈øuch matters as properly and naturally ≈øhould have reference and relation to tho≈øe three heads.

list.item: 1. The fir≈øt was the priviledges of Parliament.
2. The ≈øecond matters of Religion.
3. The third, the propriety of our goods and E≈øtates.

div.p: And we began with the fir≈øt, as the great Ark, in which the other two, Religion and property are included and pre≈øerved.
Mr. Speaker, the violations complained of the la≈øt Parliament, touching our priviledges, were of two ≈øorts; either ≈øuch as had beene done in Parliament or out of Parliament.

Concerning the violations of the fir≈øt ≈øort, it was re≈øolved
by vote, that the Speaker refu≈øing to put a que≈øtion, being thereunto required by the Hou≈øe,
Or to adjourne the Hou≈øe upon any command what≈øoever, without the con≈øent and approbation of the Hou≈øe it ≈øelfe, were breaches and violations that highly impeached our priviledges.

And having pa≈ø≈øed the vote, I conceive it were fit wee ≈øhould now proceed a little further, and con≈øider of a way how to be repaired again≈øt them that have beene the violaters: For Execution does animare Legem. The putting of an old Law in Execution, you know Mr. Speaker, does oftentimes doe more good then the making of a new one.

As concerning the violations of the other ≈øort, done out of Parliament in Courts of Ju≈øtice, and at the Councell board, where neither our per≈øons nor our proceeding ought to have beene controlled or medled withall: And as concerning matters of Religion, and the property of our goods and e≈øtates, there were divers things then likewi≈øe agreed upon by vote, whereupon a conference was de≈øired to have ‚Ä¢ eene with the Lords: But what interjections and rubs wee met withall by the way, and how the Lords countervoted the precedency of our grievances, and how our Speaker was taken away from among≈øt us, and what an unhappy conclu≈øion we had at the la≈øt, the remembrance of it were a ≈øubject too ≈øad to begin another Parliament wi hall.
Therefore Mr. Speaker, I ≈øhall pa≈ø≈øe from what was done the la≈øt Parliament, and come to what hath beene done ≈øince that Parliament ended.

M. Speaker, there are ≈øome worthy Gentlemen now of this Hou≈øe that were members of the la≈øt Parliament, that carried them≈øelves in the matters and bu≈øine≈ø≈øes then and there agitated and debated, with great Wi≈øedome, and unexampled
moderation. But what had they at la≈øt for all their paines, in attending the publique ≈øtrince of the Common-wealth, As ≈øoone as ever the Parliament was ended, their Studies and Pockets were ≈øearched, as if they had beene Fellons and Traytors, and they committed to ≈øeverall Goales, with an intention I am confident of their utter ruine and de≈øtruction, had they not fore-≈øeene a danger approaching; For Ma≈øter Speaker, if I be truly informed, an information was drawne, or at lea≈øt, directions given for the drawing of it, again≈øt them in the Starre-Chamber.
Ma≈øter Speaker, there hath beene ≈øince the la≈øt Parliament a Synod, and in that Synod a new Oath hath beene made and framed, and enjoyned to be taken.

Ma≈øter Speaker, they might as wel have made a new Law, and enjoyned the execution of that, as enjoyned and urged the taking of the other, not being e≈øtabli≈øhed by Act of Parliament, and in point of mi≈øchiefe, the ≈øafety of the Common-wealth, and the freedome and liberties of the Subject are more concerned in the doing of the one, then if they had done the other.
The next exception I ≈øhall take to it, is to the matter contained in the Oath it ≈øelfe.
Ma≈øter Speaker, they would have us at the very fir≈øt da≈øh ≈øweare in a damnable Here≈øie, that matters nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øalvation are contained in the Di≈øcipline of our Church.

Whereas Ma≈øter Speaker, it hath ever beene the tenet of our Church, that all things nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øalvation are comprehended and contained in the Doctrine of our Church only; And that hath alwayes beene u≈øed as an Argument untill this very pre≈øent, again≈øt Antidi≈øciplinarians, to ≈øtop their mouthes withall; And therefore that for that rea≈øon they might with the le≈ø≈øe regret and offence, conforme and ≈øubmit
them≈øelves to the Di≈øcipline of our Church.

And Ma≈øter Speaker, for prevention in ca≈øe the Wi≈øedome of the State in this great Councell, ≈øhould at any time think fit to alter any thing in the government of our Church, they would anticipate and fore-≈øtall our judgements, by making us ≈øweare before-hand, that wee would never give our con≈øent to any alteration.

Nay Ma≈øter Speaker, they goe a little further, for they would have us ≈øweare, that the government of the Church by Archbi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, Deanes, Archdeacons, &c. is Jure divino, Their words are, as of right it ought to ≈øtand; Whereas Ma≈øter Speaker, wee meet not with the name of an Archbi≈øhop, or a Deane, or an Arch-deacon in all the new Te≈øtament. And what≈øoever may bee ≈øaid of the Function of Bi≈øhops it is one thing: But for their Juri≈ødiction it is meerely Humana institutione, and they mu≈øt thank the King for it.

As for their gro≈ø≈øe, ab≈øurd, &c. wherein they would have men ≈øweare they know neither what, nor how many fathome deepe: There is neither Divinity nor charity in it, and yet they would put that upon us.

Ma≈øter Speaker, what they meant and intended by this new Oath, and their Booke of Canons, and their Booke of Articles, which they would have our Church-wardens ≈øworne unto, to enquire of, and to pre≈øent thereupon, I mu≈øt confe≈ø≈øe I know not, unle≈ø≈øe they had a purpo≈øe therein to blow up the Prote≈øtant Religion, and all the faithfull profe≈ø≈øors of it, and to advance their Hierarchie a ≈øtep higher, which I ≈øuppo≈øe we all feare is high enough already.

Ma≈øter Speaker, they have likewi≈øe in this Synod granted a benevolence, but the nature of the things agrees not with the name, for in plaine Engli≈øh it is ≈øix Sub≈øidies to be paid
by the Clergie in ≈øix yeares: And the penalty they have impo≈øed upon the refu≈øers, for none-payment, is to be deprived of their Functions, to be ≈øtripped of their free-hold, and to be excommunicated, and this Act of their Synod is not publi≈øhed among≈øt their Canons, for which they might have ≈øome colourable ≈øeeming authority: But it comes out, in a Booke alone by it ≈øelfe in the Latine tongue, ≈øuppo≈øing as I conceiue that Lay-men are as ignorant as they would have them; And thus they think they dance in a Net.

And as in this, ≈øo in mo≈øt of their new Canons if they bee throughly con≈øidered, any judicious man may ea≈øily di≈øcerne and perceive, that they doe therein like Water-men that looke one way and rowe another, they pretend one thing, but intend nothing le≈ø≈øe; And certainly Mr. Speaker in this they have flowne a high pitch; For a Synod called together upon pretence of reconciling and ≈øetling Controver≈øies and matters in Religion, to take upon them the boldne≈ø≈øe thus out of Parliament, to grant Sub≈øidies, and to meddle with mens Free-holds, I dare ≈øay the like was never heard of before, and they that dur≈øt doe this, will doe wor≈øe if the current of their raging Tyrannie be not ≈øtopped in time.
Who are they (Ma≈øter Speaker) that have countenanced and cheri≈øhed Popery and Armiani≈øme to that growth and height it is now come to, in this Kingdome?
Who are they (Ma≈øter Speaker) that have given encouragement to tho≈øe that have boldly preached tho≈øe damnable Here≈øies in our Pulpits?
Who are they (Ma≈øter Speaker) that have given authoritry, and licence to them that have publi≈øhed tho≈øe Here≈øies in Print?

Who are they (Ma≈øter Speaker) that of late dayes have
beene advanced to any dignity or preferment in the Church, but ≈øuch as have beene notoriou≈øly ≈øu≈øpitious in their Di≈øciplines, corrupt in their Doctrines, and for the mo≈øt part, vitious in their lives?
And who are they (Ma≈øter Speaker) that have overthrown our two great Charters, Magna Charta, and Charta de Forre≈øta?
What impo≈øition hath beene laid downe, or what Monopoly hath beene damned in any Court of Ju≈øtice ≈øince the la≈øt Parliament?

Hath not ≈øhip-money, Coale and conduct money, and money for other Military charges, beene collected and leavied, with as great violence as ever they were, in violation of our liberties, confirmed unto us in our Petition of Right; notwith≈øtanding all our ≈øupplications and complaints the la≈øt Parliament?
And who are they Ma≈øter Speaker, that have cau≈øed all tho≈øe dangerous Convul≈øions, and all the de≈øperate unnaturall bloudy di≈øtempers, that are now in our body politique?

Ma≈øter Speaker, I will tell you a pa≈ø≈øage, I heard from a Judge in the Kings-Bench. There was a poore man committed by the Lords, for refu≈øing to ≈øubmit unto a project, and having attended a long time at the Kings-Bench Barre, upon his Habeas Corpus, and at la≈øt pre≈ø≈øing very earne≈øtly to be bayled, The Judge ≈øaid to the re≈øt of his brethren, Come Brothers (≈øaid he) let us Baile him, for they begin to ≈øay in the Towne, that the Judges have overthrowne the Law, and the Bi≈øhops the Go≈øpell.

Ma≈øter Speaker, I would not be mi≈øunder≈øtood in what I have ≈øaid; for there are ≈øome of both functions and profe≈ø≈øions, that I highly honour and reverence in my heart, for their wi≈øedomes and integrities. But Ma≈øter Speaker, I may
≈øay it; for I am ≈øure we have all felt it, that there are ≈øome of both functions and profe≈ø≈øions, that have beene the Authors and cau≈øers of all the Mi≈øeries, Ruines, and Calamities that are now upon us.

Ma≈øter Speaker, This is the Age; This is the Age (Ma≈øter Speaker) that hath produced and brought forth Achitophells, Hammans, Wool≈øies, Emp≈øons, and Dudlies, Tricilians, and Belknapps, Vipers and Mon≈øters of all ≈øorts. And I doubt not, but when his Maje≈øtie ≈øhall be truly enformed of ≈øuch matters, as we are able to charge them withall, wee ≈øhall have the ≈øame Ju≈øtice again≈øt the≈øe, which heretofore hath beene again≈øt their Predece≈ø≈øors, in who≈øe wicked ≈øteps they have trodden.

And therefore Ma≈øter Speaker, to put our ≈øelves into a way for our redre≈ø≈øe and reliefe, I conceive it were fit that a Committee might be named to take the≈øe Petitions, that have now beene read, and all others of the like nature, into their con≈øiderations, to the end, that the parties grieved, may have ju≈øt repaire for their grievances; and that out of them, Lawes may be contrived, and framed for the preventing of the like mi≈øchiefs, for the future.

div.head: THE LORD DIGBYES SPEECH IN THE HOVSE of Commons, to the Bill of Attainder of the Earle of STRATFORD, the 21. Aprill. 1641.
div.p: WE are now upon the point of giving (as much as in us lies) the finall Sentence unto death or life, on a great Mini≈øter of State and Peere of this Kingdome, Thomas Earle of Strafford; a name of hatred in the pre≈øent age by his Practices, and fit to be made a terror to future Ages by his puni≈øhment.

I have had the honour to bee imployed by the Hou≈øe in this great bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, from the fir≈øt houres that it was taken into con≈øideration: it was a matter of great tru≈øt, (and I will ≈øay with confidence) that I have ≈øerved the Hou≈øe in it with indu≈øtry, according to my ability, but with mo≈øt exact faithfulne≈ø≈øe and ≈øecrecie.

And as I have hitherto di≈øcharged my duty to this Hou≈øe
and to my Country, in the progre≈ø≈øe of this great Cau≈øe; ≈øo I tru≈øt I ≈øhall doe now in the la≈øt period of it, to God and to a good con≈øcience.

I doe wi≈øh the peace of that unto my ≈øelfe, and the ble≈ø≈øings of Almighty God to mee and my po≈øterity, according as my judgement on the life of this man ≈øhall be con≈øonant with my heart, and the be≈øt of my under≈øtanding, in all integrity.

p.hi: I know well Ma≈øter Speaker, that by ≈øome things I have ≈øaid of late, while≈øt this Bill was in agitation, I have rai≈øed ≈øome prejudices upon me in the cau≈øe.

div.p: Yea ≈øome (I thank them for their plaine dealing) have beene ≈øo free as to tell me, that I ≈øuffered much by the backwardne≈ø≈øe I have ≈øhewne in this Bill of Attainder of the Earle of Strafford, again≈øt whom I had beene formerly ≈øo keene, ≈øo active.
Mr. Speaker, I beg of you and the re≈øt but a ≈øu≈øpen≈øion of judgement concerning me, till I have opened my heart unto you freely and clearly in this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe.

Truely Sir, I am ≈øtill the ≈øame in my opinions and affections, as unto the Earle of Srafford, I confidently beleeve him the mo≈øt dangerous Mini≈øter, the mo≈øt in≈øupportable to free Subjects, that can be character'd.

I beleeve his practi≈øes in them≈øelves as high, as tyrannicall, as any Subject ever ventured on, and the malignity of them hugely aggravated by tho≈øe rare abilities of his, whereof God hath given him the u≈øe, but the Devill the application. In a word, I beleeve him ≈øtil that grand Apo≈øtate to the Common-wealth, who mu≈øt not expect to be pardoned it in this world, till hee be di≈øpatch'd to the other. And yet let mee tell you Ma≈øter Speaker, my hand mu≈øt not be to that di≈øpatch.
I prote≈øt, as my Con≈øcience ≈øtands enformed, I had rather it were off.

p.hi: Let me unfold unto you the Mysterie, Ma≈øter Speaker.

div.p: I will not dwell much upon ju≈øtifying unto you my ≈øeeming variance at this time from what I was formerly, by putting you in mind of the difference betweene Pro≈øecutors and Judges,
How misbecomming that fervour would be in a Judge, which perhaps was commendable in a Pro≈øecutor. Judges we are now, and mu≈øt put on another Per≈øonage.
It is hone≈øt and noble to be earne≈øt in order to the di≈øcovery of Truth, but when that hath beene brought as farre as it can to light, our judgement thereupon ought to be calme and cautious.

In pro≈øecution upon probable grounds, we are accountable onely for our indu≈øtry or remi≈øne≈ø≈øe, but in judgement, we are deeply re≈øpon≈øable to God Almighty, for its rectitude or obliquity. In ca≈øes of life, the Judge is Gods Steward of the parties bloud, and mu≈øt give a ≈øtrict account for every drop.
But as I told you Ma≈øter Speaker, I will not in≈øi≈øt long upon this ground of difference in mee now, from what I was formerly.

The truth on't is, Sir the ≈øame ground whereupon I (with the re≈øt of the five, to whom you fir≈øt committed the con≈øideration of my Lord of Strafford) brought downe our opinion, that it was fit he ≈øhould be accu≈øed of Trea≈øon, upon the ≈øame ground I was engaged with earne≈øtne≈ø≈øe in his pro≈øecution, and had the ≈øame ground remained in that force of beliefe with me, which till very lately it did, I ≈øhould not have beene tender in his condemnation. But truly Sir, to deale
plainly with you, that ground of our accu≈øation, that ≈øpurre to our pro≈øecution, and that which ≈øhould be the ba≈øis of my judgement, of the Earle of Strafford, as unto Trea≈øon, is to my under≈øtanding quite vani≈øht away.
This it was, Ma≈øter Speaker.
His advi≈øing the King to employ the Army of Ireland, to reduce England.

This I was a≈ø≈øured would be proved, before I gave my con≈øent to his accu≈øation. I was confirmed in the ≈øame beliefe, during the pro≈øecution, and fortified in it mo≈øt of all ≈øince Sir Henry Vaines preparatory examinations, by the a≈ø≈øurances which that worthy member Mr. Pymme gave me, that his Te≈øtimony would be made convincing by ≈øome notes of what pa≈ø≈øed at the Junto concurrent with it, which I ever under≈øtanding to be of ≈øome other Coun≈øellour, you ≈øee now prove but a Copie of the ≈øame Secretaries notes, di≈øcover'd and produc't in the manner you have heard, and tho≈øe, Such di≈øioynted fragments of the venemous part of di≈øcour≈øes, no re≈øults, no conclu≈øions of Coun≈øels, which are the onely things that Secretaries ≈øhould regi≈øter, there being no u≈øe at all of the other, but to accu≈øe and to bring men into danger.
But Sir, this is not that which overthrowes the evidence with mee, concerning the Army of Ireland; nor yet that all the re≈øt of the Iunto upon their oathes remember nothing of it.

But this Sir, which I ≈øhall tell you, is that which works with mee under favour, to an utter overthrow of his evidence, as unto that of the Army of Ireland: Before, whil'≈øt I was a pro≈øecutor, and under tye of Secrecie, I might not di≈øcover any weakene≈ø≈øe of the cau≈øe, which now as a Judge I mu≈øt. Ma≈øter Secretary was examined thrice upon Oath, at the preparatory Committee.

The fir≈øt time he was que≈øtioned to all the Interrogatories, and to that part of the ≈øeventh which concernes the Army of Ireland, he ≈øaid po≈øitively in the≈øe words, I cannot charge him with that. But for the re≈øt, he de≈øires time to recollect him≈øelfe, which was granted him.

Some dayes after, he was examined a ≈øecond time, and then depo≈øes the≈øe words concerning the Kings being ab≈øolved from rules of government, and ≈øo forth very clearely. But being pre≈øt to that part, concerning the Iri≈øh Army, againe can ≈øay nothing to that.

Here wee thought wee had done with him, till divers weeks after, my Lord of Northumberland and all others of the Junto, denying to have heard any thing concerning tho≈øe words of reducing England by the Iri≈øh Army, it was thought fit to examine the Secretary once more, and then he depo≈øes the≈øe words to have beene ≈øaid by the Earle of Strafford to his Maje≈øtie: You have an Army in Ireland, which you may imploy here to reduce, (or ≈øome word to that ≈øence) this Kingdome.

Mr. Speaker, the≈øe are the circum≈øtances which I confe≈ø≈øe with my Con≈øcience, thru≈øt quite out of dores that grand Article of our charge, concerning his de≈øperate advice to the King, of employing the Iri≈øh Army here.

Let not this, I be≈øeech you, be driven to an a≈øper≈øion upon Ma≈øter Secretary, as if he ≈øhould have ≈øworn otherwi≈øe then he knew or beleeved, hee is too worthy to doe that; onely let thus much be inferr'd from it, that hee who twice upon Oath with time of recollection, could not remember any thing of ≈øuch a bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, might well a third time mi≈øremember ≈øomewhat: and in this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe the difference of one Letter, here for there, or that for this, quite alters the ca≈øe, the latter al≈øo being the more probable, ≈øince it is confe≈øt of all hands, that the debate then was concerning a warre with
Scotland, and you may remember that at the Bar he once ≈øaid to employ there. And thus Mr. Speaker, I have faithfully given you an account what it is that hath blunted the edge of the Hatchet or Bill with me towards my Lord of Strafford.

This was that whereupon I accu≈øed him with a free heart, pro≈øecuted him with earne≈øtne≈ø≈øe, and had it to my under≈øtanding beene proved, ≈øhould have condemned him with innocence. Whereas now I cannot ≈øatisfie my con≈øcience to doe it.

I profe≈ø≈øe I can have no notion of any bodies intent to ≈øubvert the Lawes trea≈øonably, or by force; and this de≈øigne of force not appearing, all his other wicked practi≈øes cannot amount ≈øo high with me.

I can finde a more ea≈øie and more naturall ≈øpring, from whence to derive all his other Crimes, then from an intent to bring in Tyrannie, and to make his owne po≈øterity as well as us, Slaves, as from revenge, from Pride, from Avarice, from Pa≈ø≈øion, and in≈øolence of Nature.

But had this of the Iri≈øh Army been proved, it would have diffu≈øed a complexion of Trea≈øon, over all, it would have beene a With indeed, to bind all tho≈øe other ≈øcattered and le≈ø≈øer branches, as it were into a Faggot of Trea≈øon.

I doe not ≈øay but the re≈øt may repre≈øent him a man as worthy to dye, and perhaps worthier then many a Traytor. I doe not ≈øay, but they may ju≈øtly direct us to Enact that they ≈øhall be Trea≈øon for the future.
But God keepe mee from giving judgement of death on any Man, and of ruine to his innocent Po≈øterity, upon a Law made √¢ po≈øteriori.
Let the mark be ≈øet on the dore where the Plague is, and then let him that will enter dye.

I know Ma≈øter Speaker, there is in Parliament a double power of life and death by Bill, a judiciall power, and a Legi≈ølative: the mea≈øure of the one, is what's Legally ju≈øt, of the other, what is prudentially and politickly fit for the good and pre≈øervation of the whole. But tho≈øe two, under favour, are not to be confounded in Judgement. Wee mu≈øt not peece up want of Legality with matter of convenience, nor the defailance of prudentiall fitne≈ø≈øe, with a pretence of legall Ju≈øtice.
To condemne my Lord of Strafford judicially as for Trea≈øon, my con≈øcience is not a≈ø≈øured that the matter will bear it.

And to doe it by the Legi≈ølative power, my rea≈øon con≈øultively cannot agree to that, ≈øince I am per≈øwaded, neither the Lords nor the King will pa≈ø≈øe the Bill, and con≈øequently that our pa≈ø≈øing it will be a cau≈øe of great divi≈øions and combu≈øtions in the State.

And therefore my humble advice is, that laying a≈øide this Bill of Attainder, we may think of another, ≈øaving only life, ≈øuch as may ≈øecure the State from my Lord of Strafford, without endangering it, as much by divi≈øion concerning his puni≈øhment, as he hath endangered it by his practices.

If this may not be hearkned unto, let me conclude in ≈øaying that unto you all, which I have throughly inculcated to mine owne con≈øcience upon this occa≈øion. Let every man lay his hand upon his heart, and ≈øadly con≈øider what we are going to doe, with a breath, either ju≈øtice or murther; justice on the one ≈øide, or murther heightned and aggravated to its ≈øupreame≈øt extent. For as the Ca≈øui≈øts ≈øay, that he who lyes with his ≈øi≈øter commits ince≈øt, but he that marries his ≈øi≈øter ≈øinnes higher, by applying Gods Ordinance to his crime: So doubtle≈ø≈øe he that commits murther with the ≈øword of Ju≈øtice, heightens that crime to the utmo≈øt.

The danger being ≈øo great, and the ca≈øe ≈øo doubtfull, that I ≈øee the be≈øt Lawyers in diametrall oppo≈øition concerning it,
Let every man wipe his heart, as he does his eyes, when hee would judge of a nice and ≈øubtile object. The eye, if it be pretincted with any colour, is vitiated in its di≈øcerning. Let us take heed of a blood-≈øhotten-eye of Judgement.

Let every man purge his heart cleare of all pa≈ø≈øions, (I know this great and wi≈øe body politick can have none, but I ≈øpeak to inviduals from the weakne≈ø≈øe which I finde in my ≈øelfe.) Away with per≈øonall animo≈øities, away with all flatteries to the people, in being the ≈øharper again≈øt him, becau≈øe he is odious to them; away with all feares, le≈øt by the ≈øparing his bloud they may be incen≈øt; away with all ≈øuch con≈øiderations, as that it is not fit for a Parliament, that one accu≈øed by it of Trea≈øon ≈øhould e≈øcape with life.

p.hi: Let not former vehemence of any again≈øt him, nor feare from thence, that he cannot be ≈øafe while that man lives, be an ingredient in the ≈øentence of any one of us.

div.p: Of all the≈øe corruptives of judgement, Mr. Speaker, I doe before God di≈øcharge my ≈øelf to the uttermo≈øt of my power,
And doe with a cleare Con≈øcience wa≈øh my hands of this mans blood, by this ≈øolemne prote≈øtation, that my Vote goes not to the taking of the Earle of Straffords life.

div.head: The Two la≈øt SPEECHES of Thomas Wentworth, Late Earle of Strafford, and Deputy of Ireland.
His ≈øpeech in the Tower, to the Lords.
div.p: RIght Honourable, and the re≈øt, you are now come to convey me to my death, I am willing to dye, which is a thing no more than all our Predece≈ø≈øors have done, and a debt that our Po≈øterity mu≈øt in their due time di≈øcharge, which ≈øince it can be no way avoyded, it ought the le≈ø≈øe to be feared; for that which is common to all, ought not to be intollerable to any: It is the Law of Nature, the tribute of the fle≈øh, a remedie from all worldly cares and troubles; and to the truly penitent, a perfect path to ble≈ø≈øedne≈ø≈øe. And there is but one death, though ≈øeverall wayes unto it: mine is not naturall, but inforced by the Law and Iu≈øtice: it hath been ≈øayd that the Lawes vex only the meaner ≈øort of people, but the mighty are able to with≈øtand them: it is not ≈øo with me, for to the Law I ≈øubmit my ≈øelf, and confe≈ø≈øe that I receive nothing but Iu≈øtice: for he that politikly intendeth good to a Common-weale, may be called a ju≈øt man, but he that practi≈øeth either for his own profit, or any other ≈øini≈øter ends, may be well termed 2 delinquent per≈øon; neither is delay in puni≈øhment any privilege for pardon. And moreover I ingenuou≈øly confe≈ø≈øe with Cicero, That the death of the bad is the ≈øafety of the good that be alive.

Let no man tru≈øt either in the favour of his Prince, the friend≈øhip and con≈øanguinity of his Peeres, much le≈ø≈øe in his own wi≈øedome and knowledge, of which I ingeniou≈øly confe≈ø≈øe I have been too confident. Kings, as they are men before God, ≈øo they are Gods before men, and I may ≈øay with a great man once in this kingdome, Had I ≈øtrived to obey my God as faithfully, as I ≈øought to honour my King fraudulently, I had ≈øtood, and not fallen. Mo≈øt happie and fortunate is that Prince, who is as much for his ju≈øtice feared, as for his goodnes beloved: For the greater that Princes are in power above other, the more they ought in verrue to excell other; and ≈øuch is the royall Soveraign whom I late ≈øerved.

For my Peeres, the corre≈øpondence that I had with them during my pro≈øperity, was to me very delightfull and plea≈øing, and here they have commi≈øerated my ruine, I have plentifully found, who (for the mo≈øt generous of them) I may boldly ≈øay, though they have dete≈øted the fact, yet they have pitied the per≈øon delinquent; the fir≈øt in their loyaltie, the la≈øt in their charitie: ingenuou≈øly confe≈ø≈øing, that never any Subject, or Peere of my rank, had ever that help of Coun≈øell, that benefit of time, or a more free and legall tryall than I have had: of the like to which, none of my Predece≈ø≈øors hath had ≈øo much favor from his Prince, ≈øo much ≈øufferance from the people; in which I comprehend the under≈øtanding Commons, not the many headed mon≈øter, Multitude: but I have offended, and ≈øentenced, and mu≈øt now ≈øuffer me.

And for my too much confidence in my ≈øuppo≈øed wi≈ødome and knowledge, therein have been the mo≈øt deceived: For he that is wi≈øe to him≈øelf, and knowes by others faults to correct his own offences, to be truly wi≈øe is to be Secretaries to our ≈øelves; for it is meere folly to reveale and intimate thoughts to ≈øtrangers: wi≈ødome is the mo≈øt precious Gem with which the minde can be adorned, and learning the mo≈øt famous thing for which a man ought to be e≈øteemed, and true wi≈øedome teacheth us to do well, as to ≈øpeak well: in the fir≈øt I have failed, for the wi≈øedome of man in fooli≈øhne≈ø≈øe with God.

For knowledge, it is a thing indifferent both to good and evill, but the be≈øt knowledge, is for a man to know him≈øelf; he that doth ≈øo ≈øhall e≈øteem of him≈øelf but little, for he con≈øidereth from whence he came, and whereto he mu≈øt, he regardeth not the vain plea≈øures of this life, he exaiteth God, and ≈øtrives to live in his fear; but he that knoweth not him≈øelf is wilfull in his own wayes, unprofitable in his life, unfortunate in his death, and ≈øo am I. But the rea≈øon why I ≈øought to attain unto it was this: I have read that he th ‚Ä¢ t knoweth not that which he ought to know, is a bruit bea≈øt among≈øt men: he that knoweth more then he ought to know, is a man among≈øt bea≈øts: but he that knoweth all that may be known, is a God among≈øt men. To this I much a≈øpired, in this I much failed; Vanitie of Vanities, all is but vanity.

I have heard the people clamour and cry out, ≈øaying, That through my occa≈øion the times are bad, I wi≈øh that when. I am dead they may prove better: mo≈øt true it is, that there is at this time a
great ≈øtorm in ending (God in his mercie avert it.) And ≈øince it is my particular lot, lik Jonab, to be ca≈øt into the ≈øea, I ≈øhall think my life well ≈øpent, to appea≈øe Gods wrath, and ≈øatisfie the peoples malice.

O what is eloquence more than air? fa≈øhioned with an articulate and di≈øtinct ≈øound, when it is a ≈øpeciall vertue to ≈øpeak little and well, and ≈øilence is oft the be≈øt oratory; for ≈øools in their dumbne≈ø≈øe may be accounted wi≈øe: It hath power to make a good matter ≈øeem bad, and a bad cau≈øe appear good: but mine was to me unprofitable, and like the Cypre≈ø≈øe trees, which are great and tall, but altogether without fruit.

What is honour, but the fir≈øt ≈øtep to di≈øquietne≈ø≈øe? and power is ≈øtill waited on by envy, neither hath it any priviledge again≈øt infamy. It is held to be the chiefe part of honour, for a man to joyn to his office and calling, courte≈øie and affability, commi≈øeration and pity: for thereby he draweth to him with a kinde of compul≈øion, the hearts of the multitude. But that was the lea≈øt part of my ≈øtudy, which now makes me call to minde, that the greater the per≈øons are in authority, the ≈øooner they are catcht in any delinquency, and their ≈ømalle≈øt crimes are ≈øtriven to be made capitall, the ≈ømalle≈øt ≈øpot ≈øeems great in the fine≈øt linnen, and the lea≈øt flaw is ≈øoone≈øt found in the riche≈øt Diamond. But high and noble ≈øpirits finding them≈øelves wounded, grieve not ≈øo much at their own pain and perplexity, as at the deriding and ≈øcoffing of their enemy: but for mine own part, though I might have many in my life, I hope to finde none in my death.

Among≈øt other things which pollute and contaminate the mindes of great ≈øpirits, there is none more haynous than Ambition, which is ≈øeldome unaccompanied without A varice: Such, to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe their ends, care not to violate the Laws of Religion and Rea≈øon, and to break the bonds of mode≈øty and equity, which the neere≈øt tyes of Con≈øanguinity and Amity; of which as I have been guilty, ≈øo I crave at Gods hands forgivene≈ø≈øe. It is a Maxime in Philo≈øophy, that ambitious men can be never good Coun≈øellors to Princes; the de≈øire of having more is common to great Lords, and a de≈øire of Rule a great cau≈øe of their Ruine.

My Lords, I am now the hopele≈ø≈øe Pre≈øident, may I be to you all an huppy example: For Ambition devoureth gold, and drinketh blood, and climbeth ≈øo high by other mens heads, that at the
length in the fall it breaketh its own neck: therefore it is better to live in humble content, than in high care and trouble: For more precious is want with hone≈øty, than wealth with infamy: For what are we but meer vapours, which in a ≈øerene Element a≈øcend high, and upon an in≈øtant, like ≈ømoke, vani≈øh into nothing: or like Ships without Pilots, ‚Ä¢ o≈øt up and down upon the Seas by contrary windes and tempe≈øts. But the good husbandman thinks better of tho≈øe ears of Corn, which bow down, and grow crooked, than tho≈øe which are ≈øtraight and upright, becau≈øe he is a≈ø≈øured to finde more ≈øtore of grain in the one than in the other. This all men know, yet of this, how few make u≈øe? The defect whereof mu≈øt be now my pain: may my ≈øuffering prove to others profit.

For what hath now the favour of my Prince, the familiarity with my Peers, the volubility of a tongue, the ≈øtrength of my memory, my learning, or knowledge, my honours, or Offices, my power and potency, my riches and trea≈øure (all the≈øe e≈øpeciall gifts, both of Nature and Fortune) what have all the≈øe profitted me? Ble≈ø≈øings I acknowledge, though by God be≈øtowed upon man, yet not all of them together upon many: yet by the Divine providence the mo≈øt of them met in me: of which had I made happy u≈øe, I might ≈øtill have flouri≈øh't, who now am forc'd immaturely to fall.

I now could wi≈øh (but that utinam is too late) that God with his outward goodne≈ø≈øe towards me had ≈øo commixed his inward grace, that I had chu≈øed the Medium path, neither inclining to the right hand, nor deviating to the left; but like Icarus with my waxen wings, fearing by too low a flight to moi≈øten them with the Waves: I ≈øoared too high, and too neer the Sun, by which they being melted; I ayming at the highe≈øt, am precipitated to the lowe≈øt: and am made a wretched prey to the Waters: But I who before built my hou≈øe upon the ≈øand, have now ≈øetled my hopes upon the Rock my Saviour: by who≈øe onely merits my ≈øole tru≈øt is, that what≈øoever becomes of my body, yet in this bo≈øome my ≈øoul may be Sanctuaried.

Nintrod would have built a Tower to reach up to heaven, and call'd it Babel; but God turned it to the confu≈øion of Languages, and di≈ø≈øipation of the people. Pharaoh kept the Children of I≈ørael in bondage, and after having freed them, in his great pride would have made them his prey; but God gave them a dry and
miraculous pa≈ø≈øage, and Pharaoh and his boa≈øt a watry Sepulcher. Bel≈øhazzer fea≈øted his Princes and Pro≈øtitutes, who drunk healths in the Ve≈ø≈øels taken from the Temple, but the hand of God writ upon the wall, Mene, Tekel, Phoras, and that night before morning was both his Kingdom and life taken from him: Thus God lets men go on a great while in their own devices, but in the end it prove their own ruine and de≈øtruction, never ≈øuffering them to effect their de≈øired purpo≈øes: therefore let none pre≈øume upon his power, glory in his greatne≈ø≈øe, or be too confident in his riches: The≈øe things were written for our In≈øtruction, of which the living may make u≈øe, the dying cannot; but wit and unfruitfull wi≈øedome are the next neighbours to folly.

There can be no greater vanity in the world, than to e≈øteem the world, which regardeth no man; and to make ≈ølight account of God, who greatly re≈øpecteth all men; and there can be no greater folly in man, than by much Travell to increa≈øe his goods, and pamper his body, and in the interim with vain delights and plea≈øures, to lo≈øe his ≈øoul. It is a great folly in any man to attempt a bad beginning, in hope of a good ending; and to make that proper to one, which was before common to all, is meer indi≈øcretion, and the beginning of di≈øcord, which I po≈øitively wi≈øh may en ‚Ä¢ in this my puni≈øhment.

O how ≈ømall a proportion of earth will contain my body, when my high minde could not be confined within the ≈øpacious compa≈ø≈øe of two Kingdoms? But my hour draweth on, and I conclude with the P≈øalmi≈øt, not ayming at any one man in particular, but ≈øpeaking for all in generall: How long will you Judges be corrupted? how long will ye cea≈øe to give true judgement? &c. Ble≈ø≈øed is the man that doth not walk in the Councell of the wicked, nor ≈øtand in the way of ≈øinners, nor ≈ø ‚Ä¢ t in the ≈øeat of the ≈øcornfall, therefore they ≈øhall not ≈øtand in the Judgement, nor ≈øinners in the A≈ø≈øembly of the righteous, &c.

About the hours of 10 and 11 a Clock the fore≈øaid Lord of Strafford was conveyed to the Scaffold on Tower-Hill, where was a Court of Guard made by the ≈øeverall Companies of Souldiers of the City of London, and the Hamlets of the Tower on each ≈øide as he pa≈ø≈øed to the Scaffold: before marched the Mar≈øhals men to make way, then the Sheriffs of Londons Officers with their Halberds; after them the Kings Guard, or Warders of the Tower: Next came one of his Gentlemen, bare h ‚Ä¢ aded, in mourning Habit, the Lord Strafford following him clad in black cloth, with divers others in the ≈øame habit, which were his atten ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ts; then the Lord Bi≈øhop of Armagh, and other good Divines, with the
Sheriffs of London, and divers honorable per≈øonages.
When he came upon the Scaffold, he there ≈øhewed him≈øelf on each ≈øide to all the people, and made this ≈øhort ≈øpeech, with as much alacrity of Spirit as could be expre≈ø≈øed. Viz.

div.head: The Lord Wentworths ≈øpeech on the Scaffold.
div.p: MY Lord Primate of Ireland, and my Lords, and the re≈øt of the≈øe noble Gentlemen, It is a great comfort to me to have your Lord≈øhips by me this day, becau≈øe I have been known to yours long time, and I now de≈øire to be heard a few words:
I come here my Lords to pay my la≈øt debt to ≈øin, which is death; and through the mercies of God, to ri≈øe again in eternall glory.

My Lords, if I may u≈øe a few words, I ≈øhall take it as a great curte≈øie from you: I am come here my Lords, to ≈øubmit to the judgement that is pa≈ø≈øed again≈øt me, I do it with a very quiet and contented minde; I do freely forgive all the world, a forgivene≈ø≈øe not from the teeth outwards (as they ≈øay) but from my heart; I ≈øpeak it in the pre≈øence of Almighty God, before whom I ≈øtand, that there is not a di≈øplea≈øing thought that arifeth in me again≈øt any man; I thank God, I ≈øay truely, my con≈øcience bears me witne≈ø≈øe, that in all the honour I had to ≈øerve his Maje≈øty, I had not any intention in my heart, but did aime at the joynt and individuall pro≈øperity of the King and his people, although it be my ill hap to be mi≈øcon≈øtrued: I am not the fir≈øt man that hath ≈øuffered in this kinde, it is a common portion that befalls men in this life, righteous judgement ≈øhall be hereafter; here we are ≈øubject to errors and mi≈øiudging one another.

One thing I de≈øire that I might be heard, and do hope that for Chri≈øtian charities ≈øake I ≈øhall be beleeved: That I was ≈øo farre from being again≈øt Parliaments, that I alwayes did think Parliaments in England to be the happy con≈øtitutions of the Kingdome and Nation, and the be≈øt means under God, to make the King and his people happy: As for my death I do hear acquit all the world, and be≈øeech God to forgive them: In particular, I am very glad his Maje≈øty conceives me not meriting ≈øo ≈øevere and heavy a puni≈øhment, as the utmo≈øt execution of this ≈øentence, I do infinitely rejoyce in it, and in the mercy of his, and do be≈øeech God to return to him the ≈øame, that he may finde mercy when he hath mo≈øt need of it. I wi≈øh this Kingdom all
pro≈øperity and happine≈ø≈øe in the world, I did it living, and now dying it is my wi≈øh.

And I profe≈ø≈øe heartily, and do humbly recommend it to you, and wi≈øh that every man would lay his hand on his heart, and con≈øider ≈øeriou≈øly, whether the beginning of the peoples happine≈ø≈øe ≈øhould be written in letters of bloud. I fear they are in a wrong way: I de≈øire Almighty God, that no one drop of my bloud ri≈øe up in judgement again≈øt them. I have but one word more, and that is for my Religion.

My Lord of Armagh, I do profe≈ø≈øe my ≈øelf ≈øeriou≈øly, faithfully, and truly, to be an obedient ≈øonne of the Church of England: in that Church I was borne and bred, in that Religion I have lived, and now in that I dye, pro≈øperity and happine≈ø≈øe be ever to it.

It hath been ≈øaid I was inclined to Popery: if it be an obiection worth the an≈øwering, let me ≈øay truly from my heart, that ≈øince the time that I was 21. yeers of age, unto this day, going on 49. yeers, I never had thought or doubt of the truth of this Religion, nor had ever any the boldne≈ø≈øe to ≈øugge≈øt to me the contrary (to my be≈øt remembrance,) and ≈øo being reconciled to the mercies of Chri≈øt Je≈øus my Saviour, into who≈øe bo≈øome I hope ≈øhortly to be gathered, to enioy eternall happine≈ø≈øe, which ≈øhall never have end. I de≈øire heartily to be forgiven of every man, if any ra≈øh or unadvi≈øed words or deeds hath pa≈ø≈øed, and de≈øire all your prayers; and ≈øo my Lord farewell, and farewell all things in this world.

The Lord ≈øtrengthen my faith, and give me confidence and a≈ø≈øurance in the merits of Chri≈øt Je≈øus, I tru≈øt in God we ≈øhall all meete to live eternally in Heaven, and receive the accompli≈øhment of all happine≈ø≈øe, where every fear ≈øhall be wiped from our eyes, and ≈øad thought from our hearts: And ≈øo God ble≈ø≈øe this Kingdome, and Je≈øus have meroy on my ≈øoul.
Then turning him≈øelf about, he ≈øaluted all the Noblemen, and took a ≈øolemne leave of all con≈øiderable per≈øons on the Scaffold, giving them his hand:

And after that he ≈øaid, Gentlemen, I would ≈øay my prayers, and I intreat you all to pray with me, and for me; then his Chaplain laid the book of Common-prayer upon the chair before him as he kneeled down, on which he praied almo≈øt a quarter of an houre, then he prayed as long or longer without a book, and ended with the Lords prayer; then ≈øtanding up he ≈øpies his brother Sir George Wentworth,
and cals him to him, and ≈øaith, brother we mu≈øt part, remember me to my ≈øi≈øter, and to my wife, and carry my ble≈ø≈øing to my eld ‚Ä¢ ≈øt ≈øonne, and charge him from me, that he fear God and continue an obedient ≈øonne of the Church of England, and that he ≈øhould approve him≈øelf a faithfull ≈øubject to the King, and tell him that he ≈øhould not have any private grudge or revenge towards any concerning me, and bid him beware that he medle not with Church livings, for that will prove a moth and canker to him in his e≈øtate, and wi≈øh him to content him≈øelf to be a ≈øervant to his Country, as a Ju≈øtice of peace in his County, and not aiming at higher preferments; carry my ble≈ø≈øing al≈øo to my daughters Anne, and Arrabella, charge them to fear and ≈øerve God, and he will ble≈ø≈øe them, not forgetting my little Infant that yet knowes neither good nor evill, and cannot ≈øpeak for it ≈øelf, God ≈øpeak for it and ble≈ø≈øe it; then ≈øayd he, now I have nigh done, one ≈øtroke will make my wife husbandle≈ø≈øe, my dear children fatherles, and my poore ≈øervants ma≈øter le≈ø≈øe, and ≈øeperate me from my dear brother and all my friends, but let God be to you and them, all in all.

After that, going to take off his doublet, and to make him≈øelfe unready, he ≈øayd, I thank God I am no more afraid of death, nor daunted with any di≈øcouragements ri≈øing from any fears, but do as cheerfully put off my doublet at this time, or ever I did when I went to bed. Then he put off his doublet; and wound up his hair with his hands, and put on a white cap.

Then he called, where is the man that ≈øhould do this la≈øt office? (meaning the Executioner) call him to me. When he came and askt him forgivene≈ø≈øe, he told him he forgave him and all the World. Then kneeling down by the block, he went to prayer again him≈øelf, the Bi≈øhop of Armagh kneeling on the one ≈øide, and the Mini≈øter on other; to the which Mini≈øter after prayer he turned him≈øelf, and ≈øpoke ≈øome few words ≈øoftly, having his hands lifted up: this Mini≈øter clo≈øed his hands with his; then bowing him≈øelf to the earth to lay his head on the blocke, he told the Executioner that he would fir≈øt lay down his h ‚Ä¢ ad to try the fitne≈ø≈øe of the block, and take it up again before he would lay it down for good and all, and ≈øo he did: and before he layd it dow again, he told the Executioner that he would give him warning when to ≈øtrike, by ≈øtretching forth his hands; and then laid down his neck on the block, ≈øtretching out his hands, the Executioner ≈øtruck off his head at one blow, then took the head up in his hands, and ≈øhewed it to all the people, and ≈øaid, God ≈øave the King.

div.head: SIXTEENE QVERIES Propounded by the Parliament of Ireland, to the Judges of the ≈øame Kingdome.
div.p: THat the Judges may ≈øet forth and declare, whether the Inhabitants of this kingdome be a free people, or whether they be to be governed onely by the antient common lawes of England.

II. Whether the Judges of the Land doe take the Oath of Judges, and if ≈øo, whether under pretext of any Acts of State, Proclamation, Writ, Letter, or direction under the great or privie Seale, or privie Signet, or Letter, o ‚Ä¢ other commandement from the Lord Lieutenant, Lord Deputie, Ju≈øtice, Ju≈øtices, or other chiefe Governor, or Governors of this Kingdome they may hinder, ≈øtay or delay the ≈øuite of any ≈øubject, or his judgement, or execution thereupon, if ≈øo, in what ca≈øes, and whether, if they doe hinder, ≈øtay or delay ≈øuch ≈øuite, judgement or execution, what puni≈øhment they incurre by the Law for their deviation and tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion therein.

III. Whether the Kings Maje≈øties privie Coun≈øell, either together, or with the chiefe Governor or Governors of this Kingdome, without him or them be a place of Judicature, by the common Lawes, where in ca≈øe between party and party for Debts, Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes, Accounts, Covenants, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, and title of Land, or any of them, and with them may be heard, and determined, and of what civill Cau≈øes they have juri≈ødiction, and by what Law, and of what force is their order or Decree, in ≈øuch ca≈øes or any of them.
IV. The like of the chiefe Governors alone.

V. Whether Grant of Monopolies be warrantable by the Law, and of what, and in what Ca≈øes, and how, and where, and by whom, are the Tran≈øge≈ø≈øors again≈øt ≈øuch Grantees puni≈øhable, and whether by Fine and mutilation of Members, impri≈øonment, lo≈ø≈øe, and forfeiture of goods, or otherwi≈øe, and which of them.

VI. In what Ca≈øes the Lord Deputie, or other chiefe Governors of this Kingdome and Coun≈øell, may puni≈øh by Fine, impri≈øonment, Mutilation of Members, Pillory, or otherwi≈øe, they may ≈øentence any to ≈øuch the ≈øame, or the like puni≈øhment, for infrigeing the commands of any Proclamation, or Monopolie, and what puni≈øhment doe they incurre, that doevote for the ≈øame.

VII. Of what force is an Act of ≈øtate or Proclamation in this
Kingdome to bind the liberty, goods, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, or inheritance of the natives thereof, whether they or any of them can alter the common Law, or the infringers of them lo≈øe their Goods, Chattels, or Lea≈øes, or forfeit the ≈øame by infringing any ≈øuch Act of State or Proclamation, or both, and what puni≈øhment doe the ≈øworne Judges of the Law, that are privie Coun≈øellors, incurre that vote for ≈øuch Act and execution of it.

VIII. Whether the ≈øubjects of this Kingdome be ≈øubiect to the Mar≈øhall Law, and whether any man in time of peace, no enemy being in the fields, with di≈øplayed colours can be ≈øentenced to Death, if ≈øo, by whom, and in what ca≈øes, if not, what puni≈øhment doe they incurre that in time of peace, execute Mar≈øhall Law.

IX. Whether voluntary Oathes taken freely before Arbitrators, or others for affirmance, or di≈øaffirmance of any thing, or for the true performance of any thing, be puni≈øhable in the Ca≈øtle-Chamber, or in any other Court, and why and wherefore.

X. Why, and by what Law, and upon what Rule of policie is it, that none is admitted to reducement in the Ca≈øtle-chamber, untill he confe≈ø≈øe the offence for which he is cen≈øured, when as Revera he might be innocent therof, though ≈øubordined proofes or circum≈øtances, might induce him to be cen≈øured.

XI. Whether the Judges of the Kings Bench, and by what law, doe or can deny, the copies of Indictments, of Fellony, or Tyea≈øon to the parties accu≈øed of Trea≈øon, contrary to the ≈øtatute of 42. Edw. 3.

XII. Whether the ≈øtatute of Baltingla≈øe take from the Subi ‚Ä¢ cts, out-lawed for Trea≈øon, though erroniou≈øly, the benefit of his Writ of Error, and how and by what meanes, that blin ‚Ä¢ clau≈øe not warranted, by the body of that Act came to be interted, and by what Law is it countenanced to the diminution of the liberty of the ≈øubject.

XIII. What power have the Barons and the Court of Exchequer, to rai≈øe the re≈øpite of homage Arbitrarily to what value they plea≈øe, and to what value they may rai≈øe it, and by what law they may di≈øtingui≈øh betweene re≈øpite of homage, upon the diver≈øities of the true value of the Fees, when as all E≈øcuage is the ≈øame for great and ≈ømall Fees, and they apportionable by Parliament.

XIIII. Whether it's cen≈øurable in the ≈øubjects of this Kingdome, to repaire into England to appeale to his Maje≈øty for Redre≈ø≈øe of Jnjuries, or for other their accu≈øers, if ≈øo, why, and in what condition of per≈øons, and by what law.

XV. Whether Deanes and other Dignitanies of Cathedrall Churches, be properly de mero jure donative, by this King, or not elective or collative, if ≈øo, why, and by what law, and whether the confirmation of a Deane de facto of the Bi≈øhops Grantee be good, and valid in the law, or no, if not, by what law.

XVI. Whether the i≈ø≈øuing of Quo Warranto's again≈øt Burroughes, that antiently, and recently ≈øent Burge≈ø≈øes to the Parliament, to ≈øhew cau≈øe why they ≈øent Burge≈ø≈øes to the Parliament be legall.

div.head: CAPTAINE AVDLEY MERVINS SPEECH To the Hou≈øe of Commons in Ireland.
div.p: IT was equall care and policy in our Predece≈ø≈øours. Fir≈øt to lay a foundation, and then by a continued indu≈øtry to build and perfect ≈øo glorious a fabrique as the hou≈øe of Commons lawfull ≈øummoned by the Kings writ repre≈øents it ≈øelfe unto us at this day. In which ≈øo elaborate and exqui≈øite a ≈øtructure being fini≈øhed and crowned with tho≈øe fruitfull and peace-≈øpeaking events, may challenge by right the title of a Jubile.

To ≈øo great a modell with neate and provident husbandry they intend no le≈ø≈øe then ≈øutable furniture (which allowed pride) di≈ødaine to cloath it with any other, but with what by his Maje≈øties favour they had procured out of his owne ≈øtore; I meane tho≈øe great and large priviledges, which by ≈øeverall acts of royall favor have bin di≈øpen≈øed, annexed, nay hypo≈øtatically united, to the ≈øame Priviledges are the ≈øoule, by which we move the Sinnes and Nerves, by which we are compacted, they are them,
by which we breath. Priviledges for their birth allyed to the Kings Prerogative, for their antiquity ≈øacred, for their ≈øtrength ≈øo re-intrenched by common law, fortified by ≈øtatutes, in≈øcon≈øed by precedents of all times, that no man ever attempted their violation with impunity, ≈øo that now and then it may be truly ≈øaid, The Kings hou≈øe is all glorious within. If we which are Heires to their lawes, as unto their lands, will ≈øtrive to make no addition to the rich inventurie of tho≈øe priviledges they have bequeathed unto us, yet with united ≈øpirits, let us all at lea≈øt prevent the dilapidation, nay the diminution of the lea≈øt of them.

This pre≈øent occa≈øion of debating Mr. Fitz-Gerralds petition exhibited to this honorable hou≈øe, ≈øets before us ble≈ø≈øings and cur≈øings, and is the fir≈øt leafe (as wee may terme it) of the hou≈øe of commons Almanak, not made to ≈øerve for one, but for many yeers, and calculated to ≈øerve indifferently for all latitudes, in which, our carriage makes this and all ≈øucceeding dayes but ≈øervil and working daies, or otherwi≈øe imprints this day and our priviledges in a con≈øpicuous, plau≈øive rubrique to po≈øterity; while≈øt the Palladium was in Troy, neither the power nor the long ≈øiege of the Grecians, could prevaile again≈øt it, while≈øt Minoes purple lockes curled from their native roots, Creete was unvanqui≈øhed. The Morall of the≈øe (affictions) emphatically preach and teach us this Doctrine, that the ≈øafety, pregnancy, glory, and ≈øtrength of this hou≈øe, is but only ≈øent us upon this condition, while≈øt we keepe, pre≈øerve, and defend our liberties, our rights, our priviledges unbetrayed, un≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, and uncontrolled: if any more allyed to the corruptions of our owne di≈øtempers, then challenging an intere≈øt in us by a legitimate birth, could involve this grave and great a≈ø≈øembly, in ≈øuch epidemicall liturgie, as directly to ≈ønore, or at le≈øt to wink while≈øt our priviledges cloathed in a purple robe of glory (like a word never to be recalled) e≈øcape from among us, I ≈øay if ungratefull, I ≈øhould out off the inheritance of the≈øe immunities entailed upon
us, and confirmed as a monument all portion upon this younger brother of ≈øtate this Hou≈øe of Commons, what can we expect, but that our Fathers Gho≈øts apparelled with indignation, ≈øhould appear unto us with this or the liking branding phra≈øe. Mo≈øt ungratefull and unfortunate po≈øterity. O aetas parentum pejor Avis; better had it bin for you not to live then to out-live your owne infamie. If there had been a nece≈ø≈øity, you ≈øhould involve your ≈øelves in a general-guilt, the election ought to have beene of ≈øuch a one as might have died with your ≈øelves; but this like originall ≈øinne, binds your po≈øterity to ≈øigh for a redemption.
