Did we bequeath unto you tho≈øe faire ornaments to be ≈øtolne or ≈ønatched from you? Oh, where, where was your vigilancy and boldne≈ø≈øe to pre≈øent ≈øo di≈øa≈øterous and fatall a con≈øequence. Did we with no better ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of imitation by your labour, and even unto hoar≈øene≈ø≈øe contend in the Parliament held 39. Hen. 6. as Prophecying your weakene≈ø≈øe, leave you a record to build upon? Where we admitted and priviledged one Walter Clarke a Burge≈ø≈øe of Chepengham, though at that time in execution ad ≈ø ‚Ä¢ ct. Reg. Did we for this purpo≈øe recommend unto you Ferrars ca≈øe and our proceecings again≈øt the di≈øturbers of his right? Did we for this purpo≈øe recommend unto you Belgraves ca≈øe 43. of the Queene. Who notwith≈øtanding be procured his election in Winche≈øter by collu≈øion, yet Maugre the great oppo≈øition rai≈øed by the Earle of Huntington upon the ≈øight of the Sheriffes returne (a ≈øufficient amerment to ≈øatisfie us) we admitted and c ‚Ä¢ nfirm ‚Ä¢ d him in the protection of our hou≈øe, did we for this purpo≈øe exemplifie unto you the ca≈øe of Richard Chidder, 5. Henry 4 who being arre≈øted in his journey towards the Parliaments (where note that the date of the election is the date of the priviledge.) They are twins of one birth, wee ingraft them as a twig to bee writh'd by our common roote, and quickly lopt off that ≈øo perilous authority which would prunne our branches. Nay Mr. Speaker, our fellowes labouring Parliament in
England, with their hearty commendation have tran≈ømitted unto us a precedent from each hou≈øe. The hou≈øe of the Lords opening the gates of the Tower to prepare an entry to the cen≈øured Bi≈øhop of Lincolne, and the hou≈øe of Commons with like imitation and like ≈øucce≈ø≈øe having performed the ≈øame in Sir John Elliot and innumerable others. But now I will endeavour to allay the di≈øtempered ≈øpirits of our Fathers, while≈øt with more patience and duty we attend the mode≈øt corrections of our indulgent King. And ≈øo exeunt Patres, and Intr. H. 8. in his owne per≈øon commending the re≈øolution and zeale of the hou≈øe of Commons in pre≈øerving the lu≈øtre of their owne Priviledges from being Eclip≈øed, aledging him≈øelfe to be intere≈ø≈øed in them, ≈øince that he and they, knit together, compleated one body, who in this our de≈øerved calamities, would not rather imitate us by ≈øcofs, then qualifie our untimely repentance by ab≈øence of our owne murdering wrongs. What may not E. 4. exprobrate unto us, who in the 3. yeare of his raigne, records his regall plea≈øure to po≈øterity? That all Acts, Suites, judgements, cen≈øures & qui dicit omne excludit nullum, awarded again≈øt any Member of Parliament, ≈øhould be utterly void and fru≈øtrate, crowning the Act with an Emphaticall epiphonema, and this act to endure for ever. And ≈øurely common rea≈øon is pregnant in the ju≈øtification thereof. That where the publique ≈øervice and good is primarily intended, a ≈øuper≈øedias mu≈øt i≈ø≈øue to private re≈øpects, ≈øince they cannot ≈øtand in competition, and inhabit our ≈ø ‚Ä¢ heare. If their judgements are not yet calmed and ≈øetled, behold his Maje≈øty, that now is, cloathed in his royall Robes, and thus ≈øpeaking unto you from underneath his ≈øtate. Gentlemen, why ≈øtagger you thus, that are your ≈øelves the pillars of the commonweale, you are not upon breaking the Ice, nor bound upon the di≈øcovery of the unknowne world, each leafe reports your precedents that are like Maps that ≈øecure and expedite your fortunate Navigation. From me you can
expect no more ≈øatisfaction, then what I have declared in the third yeer of my Raign, in an≈øwer to the Petition of Right in Parliament, that I am intere≈øted in the maintaining of the Priviledges of this Hou≈øe, being a main Pillar of the liberty of my Subject, the goods of one _____ being ≈øei≈øed in my name, and for my u≈øe, for denying Tonnage and pondage, they rea≈ø≈øumed, he being at the time of that ≈øei≈øure a Member of the Hou≈øe, and whether I di≈øta≈øted, ≈øure I am, I had no redre≈ø≈øe. As for the tender care of my intere≈øt in the fine of 10000l. and that you admitted my Atturney generall to a favourable hearing in my behalf, though again≈øt your ≈øelves (a Parliamentary cu≈øtome not to be written in ≈ømall Print) I thank you Gentlemen, yet I think you know, as well as I, that the≈øe great ≈øounding Fines to me, have in their effects, but ≈øhort and little accounts, if there be 3. bags, the little one is mine: the 5000l. dammages to the party (a ≈øumme equall) or more to the defendants e≈øtate) is as much as Magna Charta, by tho≈øe words of ≈øalvo contenemento, would warrant: Therefore my Judges, by dividing it, might have con≈øidered me ≈øomewhat, whereas now the old proverbe binds me, Where there is nothing left, the King lo≈øes his right.

The fir≈øt that u≈øhers in the train, is a ≈øentence cloathed in ≈øable, ≈øtanding on tip-toe, and with a ru≈øty dagger thru≈øting at a ≈øtarre, I mean a ≈øentence ≈øpeaking errour, a ≈øentence vi≈øitng the third and fourth generation, a ≈øentence ≈øtriving to leap over the bounds of Magna
charta, thirty times confirmed, a ≈øentence awarded again≈øt a Judge of a higher Court, than from which it i≈ø≈øued. The cau≈øe in que≈øtion is to nullifie this ≈øentence, which if he appear a per≈øon capable of his priviledge, more ≈øua vivit, and then neither it, nor any thing derivatory, or collaterall to it, may be admitted again≈øt him by the rules of common, civill, or common Law, it being a maxime con≈øonant to them all. Non potest adduci eju≈ødam rei excepio cujus petitur di≈ø≈øolutio. Now to prove this ≈øentence void (Mr. Speaker) I being no profe≈ø≈øor of the Law, yet a Di≈øciple of rea≈øon, and the body of the audient Subject to the like guilt: I will couch my ≈øelf in arguments, quae probant & non probantur, leaving precedents and Book-ca≈øes to the learned long Robe: Then thus I argue. By the Star. 3. E. 4. All judgements, cen≈øures, ≈øentences, &c. awarded again≈øt a member of Parliament are void, ≈øo was this government: ≈øome may ≈øay, the King is not here included, I ≈øay (qui dicit omne, excludit nullum) And experience, the mother of knowledge, teacheth the ≈øame in precedents afore rehear≈øed, and one I will adde for all, which Trewman, 38. Hen. 8. who was in execution upon a writ of exigent after a Capias ad≈øatis faciend. at the Kings ≈øuit, and yet priviledged, be≈øides this is not at the Kings ≈øuit, for the King is intere≈ø≈øed here but ≈øecondarily both in name and profit. Now I mu≈øt make good my minor, that he is a member of this hou≈øe: he that was duely elected and truely returned, is a member of this hou≈øe, ≈øo was he. Ergo, &c. My minor will be que≈øtioned, I confirm it thus, where the Kings writ for election is duly pur≈øued, according to the mo≈øt u≈øed and received form, there ≈øuch an election is good, ≈øo was this. Ergo. Here (Mr. Speaker) falls the weight of their objection, which we will ma≈øter, and an≈øwer with equall ≈øpeed, and fir≈øt vellicat mibi aurem ne≈øcio quis, and ≈øaith the writ is Burgen≈øis de Burgo. but he is not Burgen≈øis de Burgo. Fir≈øt I ≈øay
quomodo con≈øtat, here is none to offer in proof he is not ≈øo, be≈øide I offer it in Quaere, whether the election doth not ip≈øofacto make him a Burge≈ø≈øe, & in omni in≈øtanti, again I ≈øay the writ is directive not po≈øitive. v. g. in a venire facias, the Sheriff commanded to return 12. yet if he return not 24. he ≈øhall be fined, in re≈øpect experience and practice proves, ≈øome of the 12. may be que≈øtioned and challenged, be≈øides the writ explains it ≈øelf, the Knights mu≈øt be Comitatus tui, but the Burge≈ø≈øes and Citizens de qualibet Civitate & Burgo, which can admit of no other con≈øtruction, but the≈øe two Burge≈ø≈øes out of every Burrough, & not as Comitatus tui, is, which were then of every Burrough, and certainly the Law provided this with great rea≈øon, as not doubting every Shire could afford two Knights, re≈øident, yet jealous, whether every Burrough could provide two re≈øident Burge≈ø≈øes qualified with the≈øe nece≈ø≈øary adjuncts, as could befit a member of ≈øo noble a place; Again the writ commands duos milites, and yet exception was never taken upon returning of E≈øquires, ≈øo that the writ expounds it ≈øelf, it is not literally to be taken. Next there is Thunder and Lightning ≈øhot out of the Statute, 33. H. 8. being a Stat. to regulate election, and ab≈øolutely commanding every Knight and Burge≈ø≈øe to be re≈øident and have a certain Fee-≈øimple in every burrough and County, out of which they are elected; Here they ≈øuppo≈øe our Priviledge will cry quarter as ready to be murthered by the Statute, but it is ominous ante victoriam canere. For fir≈øt, we an≈øwer, that the di≈øu≈øe of a Statute antiquates a Statute, as is ob≈øerved upon the Statute of Merton, and cu≈øtome applauded by fortunate experience, hath in all Parliaments ever prevailed; a hou≈øe of Commons would rather pre≈øent Babell in it's confu≈øion, if the Tincker would ≈øpeak his Dialect, the Cobler his, and the Butcher conclude a grea≈øie Epilogue, then the writ were well pur≈øued, the≈øe were Idonei homines to take and give coun≈øell de rebus arduis;
but even to cut off the head of their own argument by a Sword of their own, this Stat. of 33. H. 8. ≈øeems by the preamble to be made in repeal of all former Statutes, by which, election not qualified with re≈øidency, was made void, and ≈øo became a grievance to the Common-wealth, and therefore this Statute makes the election not ob≈øerved ut ≈øupra, onely penall, ≈øo that there is nothing offered in objection, either from the writ or Statute to avoid this election. Now I have placed him and dayly elected him, and then his priviledge grows by con≈øequence, yet we have other objections minoris magnitudinis, and to repeat them is to confute them; Fir≈øt, ≈øay they, every Libeller is de jure, excommunicated; I an≈øwer, every Libeller mu≈øt be Scriptis, Pictis, or Cantilenis, our member is guilty of none of them, no, he is not tearmed, ≈øo neither in the cen≈øure, nor in any pre≈øent proceeding. Another flouri≈øh is, that he pleaded not his priviledge in the Ca≈øtle-Chamber, in which very objection, they confe≈ø≈øe him priviledged, and make them≈øelves guilty, that they would proceed again≈øt a known member of our Hou≈øe. But ≈øee the Roman ≈øpirit of Mr. Fitz-Gerald, who would rather undergo the hazard of being a Starre-Chamber Martyr, than to ≈øubmit our Priviledge to an extrajudiciall debate. It was in our honour he did this, and for his eternall applau≈øe: ≈øome body ≈øayes the Ca≈øtle-Chamber will think it ≈øelf injured, there being Lords of the hou≈øe of Parliament at and in the cen≈øure. As for the Lords, humanum e≈øt errare, but the Judges are rather involved in the≈øe words Premeditata malitia, for his election was the 11 of November ≈øitting then in Parliament; and his cen≈øure the 13 of December, ≈øo they had 22 or 23 dayes to repent of their ill-grounded re≈øolution, a greater affront never offered to the hou≈øe of Commons, being comparative, as if the Recorder of the Tol≈øell ≈øhould ≈øentence the Lord chief Ju≈øtice of Ireland, a member of our hou≈øe is a walking Record,
and needs not to melt the Kings picture in his pocket. Others alleadge, it was an election purcha≈øed by collu≈øion, but de non exi≈øtentibus & non apparentib, cadem e≈øt ratio. And ≈øince the end of his election is in it ≈øelf and per ‚Ä¢ ≈øe, for the advancing of the publike ≈øervice, as well to prove a ≈øentence not then in rerum natura, both Law and charity in a benigne con≈øtruction of the≈øe two ends will allow the more favourable. Another objection is whi≈øpered, that the entrance is not found in the Clerk of the Parliaments Role; This is no matter to the validity of his election, for his priviledge commenced 40 dayes before the Parliament, therefore this and the like are to be judged of as accidentia quae po≈ø≈øunt abe≈ø≈øe & ade≈ø≈øe ≈øine ≈øubjecti interitu. Truely (Mr. Speaker) my memory and lungs begin to prove Traytors to me; Another objection, if omitted, may be judged by the≈øe of what ≈øtrength and maturity they, even as by the coynage of a penny, one may iudge of a ≈øhilling; What hinders then, ≈øince here is wa ‚Ä¢ er, but that he may be baptized? Here are no non ob≈øtant's to be admitted in his new Pattent of Denization, the common law, the Statute law, the Canon, the Civill law plead for his admittance, the writ of election, the exemplification of the Sheriffs return, all pre≈øidents of all ages, all reports plead for his admittance, our fore-fathers Gho≈øts, the pre≈øent practice of Parliaments in England plead for his admittance, the Kings ≈øucce≈ø≈øive commands, command and confirm his admittance; Away then Serieant, and with the hazarding power of our Mace touch the Mar≈øhals gates,, and (as if there were Divinity in it) they will open and bring us our Olive branch of peace, wre≈øted from our ≈øtock, that with welcome Art we may ingraft him to be nouri≈øhed by a common root. Thus the King ≈øhall receive the benefit of an able ≈øubject, who is otherwi≈øe, civiliter mortuus, we enjoy the participation of his labour, and po≈øterity, both ours and this.

div.head:
CAPTAINE AVDLEY MERVINS Speech to the Lords in the Upper hou≈øe in the Parliament
March 40. 1640.

argument.p: Concerning the impeachment of Sir Richard Bolton Knight, Lord Chancellor of Ireland; Iohn Lord Bi≈øhop of Derry, Sir Gerrard Lowther Lord Chief Ju≈øtice of the Common Pleas, and Sir George Ratcliffe Knight, with high Trea≈øon by the Knights, Citizens, and Burge≈ø≈øes of the Commons Hou≈øe.

div.p:
I Am commanded by the Knights, Citizens, and Bur-Burge≈ø≈øes of the Commons Hou≈øe to pre≈øent unto you Irelands Tragedie, the gray headed Common Lawes funerall, and the Active Statutes death and ob≈øequies; this dejected ≈øpectacle an≈øwers but the prefiguring Type of Cae≈øars murther, wounded to the death in the Senate; And by Brutus his bo≈øome friend, our Cae≈øars image by reflexion, even the fundamentall Lawes and Statutes of this Kingdome, the ≈øole means by which our e≈øtates are confirmed, our liberties pre≈øerved, our lives ≈øecured, are wound to death in the Senate, I mean in the Courts of Ju≈øtice, and by Brutus too, even by tho≈øe per≈øons
that have received their beings and ≈øub≈øi≈øtence from them, ≈øo that here enters tho≈øe in≈øeparable fir≈øt Twins, Trea≈øon, and Ingratitude.
In a plain phra≈øe (My Lords) I tender unto you Trea≈øon, High Trea≈øon; ≈øuch a Trea≈øon that wants nothing but words to expre≈ø≈øe it.
To counterfeit the Kings Seale, to counterfeit the Kings money it is Trea≈øon; but this dyes with the individuall partie.
To betray a Fort is Trea≈øon, but it dies with a few men.
To betray an Army is a Trea≈øon, but it dyes with a limited number, which may be reinforced again by politique indu≈øtry.

To blow up both Hou≈øes of Parlament is Trea≈øon, but ≈øucceeding ages may replant Branches by a fruitfull po≈øterity; but this High Trea≈øon which I do move in the name of the Hou≈øes of Commons, charge and impeach Sir Richard Bolion Knight, Lord Chancellour of Ireland, and Sir Gerard Lowther Knight, Lord Chief Iu≈øtice of the Common Pleas, Iohn Lord Bi≈øhop of Derry, Sir George Ratcliffe Knight; is in its nature ≈øo far tran≈øcending any of the former that the re≈øt ≈øeem to be but petty Larcenies in re≈øpect of this.
What is it to ≈øubvert the fundamentall Lawes of this Kingdome, (High Trea≈øon?)
What is it with a contumacious malice to trample under feet the rich legacies of our forefathers purcha≈øed with ≈øweat and expence, I mean the Statute lawes, what is it but High Trea≈øon?

What is it through an Innate Antipathie to the publick good to incarcerate the liberty of the Subject under the Iron and weighty chains of an arbitrary Government (High Trea≈øon?) What is it (≈øince his Maje≈øtie the mo≈øt amiable and delightful portraiture of flouri≈øhing and indulgent Ju≈øtice to his Subjects) to pre≈øent him per≈øonated in their extrajudiciall cen≈øures and judgements;
but to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe (it po≈ø≈øible) the hearts of his loyall Subjects of this Kingdome: That he is a bloody and devowring Tyrant, and to provoke their never dying alleageance into a fatall and de≈øperate Rebellion.

What is it to violate the ≈øacred Graunts of many of his Maje≈øties Progenitors Kings and Queenes of England confirmed under the broad Seale, being the publique faith of this Kingdome by an extrajudiciall breath grounded upon no record?

What is it to in≈øent a ≈øurreptitious clau≈øe forged by ≈øome ≈øervile brain in the preamble of our la≈øt Act of Sub≈øidies by which the Kings mo≈øt excellent Maje≈øty, and the Earl of Stofford are placed in one and the ≈øame ≈øphear, allowing them but equall influencies to nouri≈øh the alleageance of this Kingdome, what is this but to extoll other then Regall Authority, and to crucifie the Maje≈øtie of our mo≈øt gracious Soveraign betwixt the two Theeves of Government, Tyranny and Trea≈øon.

My Lords, having ≈øuch a full and la≈øting Gale to drive me into the depth of the≈øe accu≈øations, I cannot hereby ≈øteere and confine my cour≈øe within the compa≈ø≈øe of patience, ≈øince I read in the fir≈øt volumes of their browes, the lea≈øt of the≈øe to be the certain ruine of the Subject, and if prov'd, a mo≈øt favorable Prologue to u≈øher in the Tragedie of the Actors, Councellers and Abetters herein.

What was then the fir≈øt and main que≈øtion, it was the ≈øubvertion of the fundamentall Lawes of this Kingdome, let then magna Charta that lies pro≈øtrated, be≈ømeared and groveling in her own gore, di≈øcount her wounds as ≈øo many pregnant and undeniable proofs, mark the Epethite Magna
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ confirmed by 30. Parliaments in the ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of eight Kings, the violation of which hath ≈øeverall times ingaged the Kingdome of England in a voluntary ≈øacrifice: a Charter which impo≈øeth that plea≈øant and welbecomming oath upon all Soveraigntie, to vindicate and pre≈øerve the Immunitie thereof; before the
Crown incircle their Royall Temples in this oath of ≈øo high con≈øequence and generall intere≈øt his Maje≈øty doth in a manner levie a fine to his Subjects u≈øe for avoiding all fraudulent conveyances in the Admini≈øtration of Ju≈øtice. And this oath is tran≈øplanted unto the Judges as the Feoffees in tru≈øt, appointed between his Maje≈øtie and the Subject, and ≈øealed by his Maje≈øties provident care with that imphaticall penalty, that their e≈øtates and lives ≈øhall be in the Kings mercy upon the violation of the ≈øame, either in whole or in part, neither hath the de≈øerved puni≈øhment for the breach of this oath enacted as fulgura ex vitrio, or as bugbears to inforce the obedience of Children; no my Lords, the ju≈øt execution of it upon their Predece≈ø≈øors though in breaches not ≈øo capitall, might have warned them to have ≈øtrangled their ill born re≈øolutions in the Cradle, before they now proclaim their infancie and petition for their puni≈øhment. Witne≈ø≈øe Sir Thomas Weyland his bani≈øhment, confi≈øcation of his goods and lands only for his mercenarie Ju≈øtice contrary to his oath, who was Chief Ju≈øtice of the Common Pleas in the time of Edward the fir≈øt. Witne≈ø≈øe Sir William Thorpe, Cheif Iu≈øtice of the Kings Bench, in the time of Edward the third, who was adjudged to be hanged, becau≈øe he had broken the Kings oath made unto the people wherewith he was intru≈øted in the Roll.

Now my Lords, though Magna Charta be ≈øacred for antiquity, though its confirmation be ≈øtrengthned by oath, though it be the proper Dictionarie that expounds meum & tuum, and a≈ø≈øignes a Subiect his birth right; yet it only ≈øurvives in the Rolls, but now mi≈øerable rent and torn in the practice.
The≈øe words Salvo cantenemento, live in the Rolls, but they are dead in the Ca≈øtle Chamber.

The≈øe words; Nullus liber bujus ejicitur √® libero ≈øue tenemento, in praejudicium parium, live in the Rolls, but they are dead where property and free-hold are determined
by paper Petitions.

The≈øe words; Nulli vendemus, nulli differemus Ju≈øtitiam, live in the Rolls, but they are dead when the Suites, Iudgements, and excecution of the Subiect are wittingly and illegally ≈øu≈øpended, retarded and avoyded.

Shall we de≈øire to ≈øearch the mortall wounds inflicted upon the Statute Lawes, who ≈øees them not lying upon their death bed ≈øtab'd with Proclamations, their primitive and genuine tenures e≈øcheated by Acts of State, and ≈øtrangled by Monoplies.

Will you ≈øurveigh the liberties of the Subiects, every pri≈øon ≈øpues out illegad attachments and commitments, every Pillory is dyed with the forced bloud of the Subiects, and hath ears, though not to hear, yet to witne≈ø≈øe this complaint.

Do you doubt of the defacement of the amiable Offices of his Maie≈øties mo≈øt tran≈øplendent and renowned Iu≈øtice, and grace, let then that Microco≈øme of Letters Patents confirmed under his Maie≈øties and his Predece≈ø≈øors broad Seale of the Kingdome, being the publique faith thereof, and yet unchri≈øtened by frivolous and private opinions, ri≈øe up in iudgement, let the abortive Iudgement of the tenure in Capite, where no tenure was expre≈øt, nay let the Hereticall and Traiterous opinions where the Tenure was expre≈øt, yet to draw in all by Markets and Faires granted in the ≈øame Patents ri≈øe up in Iudgements. What gla≈ø≈øe hath this unhappy divided Kingdome from his Maie≈øties pre≈øence and andience, to contemplate the fair and ravi≈øhing form of his royall intentions in, but in the cleer and diaphanous admini≈øtration of his Iu≈øtice, and what do the≈øe traytrous and illegall practi≈øe ayme at but in affront to his Maie≈øty (which we mo≈øt tenderly re≈øent) and di≈øcontent to his Subiects, to multiply as by a Magick gla≈ø≈øe the royall di≈øpen≈øation of his favours into the ugly and deformed vi≈øage of their ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion of the liberties, deva≈øtations of the e≈øtates, and
the deprivation of the lives of his loyall Subiects, ≈øo that it may be ≈øayd; Regali Capiti cervicem con≈øul equinan ‚Ä¢ Jungere ≈øic vellet varia≈øque inducere plumas.
My Lords, the≈øe ought to be con≈øidered with as ≈øerious an eare, as they were practi≈øed by mi≈øchievous experiments.

Inquire of the Netherlands why their fields are growne fertile, by the inundation of bloud, why the pen≈øive Matrons ≈øolemnize too too frequent funeralls of their Hu≈øbands and i≈ø≈øue, and they will an≈øwer you it was for the pre≈øervation of their hereditary Lawes, which Tyranny would have innovated.

This Kingdome per≈øonated in the ≈øable habit of a widdow with di≈øhelved hayrs ≈øeems to Petition your Lord≈øhips, that ≈øince ≈øhe is a Mother to mo≈øt of us, yet cer ‚Ä¢ ainly a Nur≈øe unto us all, that you would make ≈øome other for redre≈ø≈øe of her Tyrannicall oppre≈ø≈øion.
The≈øe per≈øons impeached, re≈øemble the opacious body of the earth interpo≈øed to eclip≈øe that light and vigour, which the ≈øolar a≈øpect of Maie≈øty would communicate unto his Subiects.
They imitate the fi≈øh Sepia, that vomits a darke liquor out of her mouth to cloud the waters for her ≈øecurer e≈øcape.
They are tho≈øe to whom the keyes have been committed, yet they have barred the door to them that knoc't.

They are tho≈øe unnaturall Parents, that give their children ≈øtones, in ≈øtead of bread, and ≈øcorpions for fi≈øh. Was it for this purpo≈øe that the royall authority ≈øcituated them in the≈øe eminent places, that like Beacons upon high Hills, they ≈øhould di≈øcover and proclaim each innovation and ≈øtratagem again≈øt the publique weale; while≈øt they in the mean time imploy therein fire to publique Incendiary, or, like Ignes fatui, ≈øeduce the ea≈øie and beleeving Traveller into pits and unexpected Myres?

Were they ≈øworne to ≈øeale their damnation, and not
their confirmation of our libertie, e≈øtates, and lives? Shall a man be cen≈øured for perjury, in that breach of his private Faith, and tho≈øe be ju≈øtifiable in Trea≈øon, aggravated by perjury again≈øt the dignity of the Crownes, and publique faith of the Kingdomes? No my Lords, the grave, judicious, and mature examination, and de≈øerved puni≈øhment of the≈øe traiterous proceedings, will ≈øpeak the≈øe times as glorious to po≈øterity in their information, as they are now lamented in their per≈øecution.
The bloud-thir≈øting ≈øword of an ho≈øtile enemy, by a timely union, and a defen≈øive preparation may be prevented.
The thin rib'd Carca≈ø≈øe of an univer≈øall famine, may have his con≈øumption re≈øtored by a ≈øupply from our neighbouring Nations.

The quick ≈øpreading venome of infectious pe≈øtilence may be prevented by Antidotes, and qualified by phi≈øicall remedies. But this Catholick grievance, like a ≈ønake in the mo≈øt verdant walks, (for ≈øuch are the unblemi≈øhed lawes truly practi≈øed) ≈øtings us to death, when we are mo≈øt ≈øecure; and like the Kings evill, can only be cured by his Maje≈øties free and gracious permi≈ø≈øion of our mode≈øt and gentle proceedings, for his vindication and our pre≈øervation therein concluded.

Spencer, and Gam≈øton who have left their names monumentally odious for the evill coun≈øell they fed the Kings ear with, yet did po≈ø≈øibly advantage their own friends, while the≈øe dart their envie and Trea≈øon for a common Center, equally touching the bounds of every ≈øuperficies: for as concerning the valide e≈øtates they have illegally overthrown, when the Lawes by your Lord≈øhips indu≈øtry receive their native vigour, they will re-a≈ø≈øume their confirmation: but the e≈øtates happily in them≈øelves legall, that they have in an extrajudiciall forme e≈øtabli≈øhed, will ha≈øte as ≈øpeedily to their di≈ø≈øolution, ≈øo that Judas-like they betray their be≈øt friends with a ki≈ø≈øe.

My Lords, I cannot finde any ≈øurviving Cronologie of times, this ≈øea≈øon to be parallel'd with all circum≈øtances, which makes me view the Records among≈øt the infernall ≈øpirits to finde, if match't there I might extenuate their facts: where 1. they appear like the fal≈øe ≈øpirit ≈øent into the mouth of the Prophet to Abab to ≈øpeak delu≈øions to ≈øubvert the ho≈øt of God.

The mo≈øt vehement and trayterous encounter of Sathan, is lively deci hered in the true example of Job: where fir≈øt, I ob≈øerve the di≈ømologie, he overthrowes not Jobs. Magna Charta, he d ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øeizes him not of his inheritance, nor di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øes him of his Lea≈øes; but only di≈ørobes him of ≈øome part of his per≈øonall e≈øtate: when he proceeds to infringe Jobs liberty, he doth not pillorie him, nor cut off his ears, nor bore him through the tongue; he only ≈øpots him with ≈øome ulcers; here Sathan ≈øtains, when the≈øe per≈øons by their traiterous combinations, envie the very bloud that runs un≈øpilt in our veines; and by obtruding bloody Acts, damn'd in the la≈øt Parliament, will give Sathan ≈øize ace, and the Dice at Iri≈øh, in inthralling the lives of the Subjects by their arbitrary Judicature.

I would not my Lords be under≈øtood to impute to the Judges, and infallibilitie of error: nor in impeaching the≈øe, to traduce tho≈øe, who≈øe candor and integrity, ≈øhine with more admired lu≈øtre, then their white furres, who like trophees of virgin-ju≈øtice, ≈øtood fixt and unmov'd in the rapid torrent of the times, while the≈øe like ≈øtrawes and chips plai'd in the ≈øtreams, untill they are devolv'd in the Ocean of their de≈øerved ruine.

No my Lords, humanum e≈øt errare, and the Law allowes Writs of Error, and arre≈øt of Judgement: but where there is cra≈ø≈øa ignorantia again≈øt their Oath, again≈øt the Fundamentall, Elementary, and known Lawes of the Kingdome: Nay (my Lords where it is rather praemedita ‚Ä¢ a malitia, where there is an emulating policie
who ≈øhould raze and embe≈ø≈øell the Records in the practique, that are for the tender pre≈øervation of our liberties, e≈øtates, and lives, ≈øeeking only to be glorious in a nationall de≈øtruction, as if their ≈øafety were only involved in our ruine, there I have command to pitty, but not excu≈øe them.

To kill a Judge, quatenus a Judge, is not Trea≈øon, but to kill a Judge ≈øitting in the place of Iudicature, is Trea≈øon; not for that the Law intends it out of any malice again≈øt the party, but for the malice again≈øt the Law: where then can an inten≈øive, or an exten≈øive malice be expre≈øt or implyed again≈øt the Law, then the practicall dialect of the≈øe per≈øons impeach't, ≈øpeaks with a known and crying accent.

The Benjamites ≈ølang ≈øtones with their left hands, yet they would not mi≈ø≈øe a hairs breadth; the≈øe extrajudiciall proceedings are ≈ølung with the left, I meane they are ≈øini≈øtrious, and imprint their blacke and blew marks, more certaine, and more fatall; for that they may ≈øay, Quae regio in terris no≈øtri non plena laboris? Though the≈øe things be familiar unto us, yet I cannot but admire how this unproportionable body of Iudicature ≈øhould ≈øwell up into ≈øuch a va≈øt and ulcerous dimen≈øion, but why ≈øhould I con≈øidering this excentrick motion of the body of the Law had his birth ob≈øcure, re≈øembling the tares that were ≈øowed in the night time, but here is the difference; they were ≈øowne by the enemy in the ab≈øence of the Ma≈øter: but the≈øe are ≈øowne by the Grand-ma≈øters them≈øelves, purpo≈øely to overtop and choak the expected Harve≈øt.
Innovations in Law, and con≈øequently in government, creep in like here≈øies in Religion, ≈ølily and ≈ølowly, pleading it the end a ≈øawcy and u≈øurp't legitimacy, by uncontrol'd pre≈øcription.

My Lords, this is the fir≈øt ≈øitting, and I have onely chalked out this deformed body of high Trea≈øon: I have
not drawn it at length, lea≈øt it might fright you from the further view thereof: in conclu≈øion, it is the humble defire of the Commons, that the parties impeached, may be ≈øecured in their per≈øons, ≈øeque≈øtred from this Hou≈øe, from the Coun≈øell Table, and all places of Iudicature, as being Civiliter mortui; that they may put in their an≈øwers to the Articles ready now to be exhibited again≈øt them: and that all ≈øuch further proceedings may be ≈øecretly expedited, as may be ≈øutable to Iu≈øtice, and the precedents of Parliaments, ≈øo his Maje≈øty may appeare in his triumphant goodne≈ø≈øe, and indulgency to his people: and his people may be ravi≈øht in their dutifull and cheerefull obedience, and loyalty to his Maie≈øty: your Lord≈øhips may live in Records to Po≈øterity, as the in≈øtrumentall reformers of tho≈øe corrupted times, and that the Kingdome and Common-wealth may pay an amiable ≈øacrifice in retribution, and acknowledgement of his Maie≈øties multiplyed providence for our pre≈øervation herein.

div.head: Articles of the Knights, Citizens, and Burge≈ø≈øes in the Parliament a≈ø≈øembled, again≈øt Sir Ric: Bolton, Kt. Lord Chancellor of Ireland, John, Lord B. of Derry, and Sir Gerard Lowther Kt. L. Chief Ju≈øtice of his Maje≈øties Court of Common-Pleas, and Sir George Radcliffe, Kt. in maintenance of the accu≈øation, whereby they, and every of them, ≈øtand charged with high Trea≈øon.
div.p: FIr≈øt, that they the ≈øaid Sir Richard Bolton, Knight, Lord Chancellor of Ireland, John, L. Bi≈øhop of Derry, Sir Ger. Lowther, Kt. Lord Chief Ju≈øtice of his Maje≈øties Court of Common-Pleas, and Sir George Radcliffe, Knight, intending the de≈øtruction of the Common-wealth of this Realm, have trayterou≈øly confederated and con≈øpired together, to ≈øubvert the Fundamentall Laws and Government of this Kingdom, and in pur≈øuance thereof, they and every of them, have trayterou≈øly contrived, introduced, and exerci≈øed an arbitrary and tyrannicall Government again≈øt Law, thorowout this Kingdom, by the countenance and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of Thomas, Earl of Strafford, then chief Governour of this Kingdom.

II. That they and every of them, the ≈øaid Sir Richard Bolton, Kt. L. Chancellor of Ireland, John, L. Bi≈øhop of Derry, Sir Gerard Lowther, Kt. L. chief Ju≈øtice of the Common Pleas, and Sir George Radcliffe, Kt. have trayterou≈øly a≈ø≈øumed to them≈øelves, and every one of them, regall power over the goods, per≈øons, lands, and liberties of his Maje≈øties
Subjects in this Realm; and likewi≈øe have maliciou≈øly, perfidiou≈øly, and trayterou≈øly given, declared, pronounced, and publi≈øhed, many fal≈øe, unju≈øt, and erroneous opinions, Judgements, Sentences, and Decrees, in extrajudiciall manner again≈øt Law, and have perpetrated, practi≈øed, and done many other trayterous and unlawfull acts and things, whereby as well divers mutinies, ≈øeditions, and rebellions have been rai≈øed, as al≈øo many thou≈øands of his Maje≈øties liege people of this Kingdom, have been ruined in their goods, lands, liberties, and lives, and many of them being of good quality and reputation, have been utterly defamed by Pillory, mutilation of members, and other infamous puni≈øhments: By means whereof his Maje≈øty and the Kingdom have been deprived of their ≈øervice in Juries, and other publike imployments, and the generall trade and traffique of this I≈øland for the mo≈øt part de≈øtroyed, and his Maje≈øty highly damnified in his cu≈øtomes and other revenues.

III. That they the ≈øaid Sir Rich. Bolton. John, L.B. of Derry. Sir Ger. Lowther, K. and Sir G. Radcliffe, and every of them, the better to pre≈øerve them≈øelves, and the ≈øaid Earl of Strafford, in the≈øe and other trayterous cour≈øes, have laboured to ≈øubvert the rights of Parliament, and the ancient cour≈øe of Parliamentary proceedings: all which offences were contrived, committed, perpetrated, and done at ≈øuch time, as the ≈øaid Sir Richard Bolton, Sir Gerard Lowther, and Sir George Radcliffe, Knights, were privy Coun≈øellors of State within this Kingdom, and again≈øt their and every of their oathes of the ≈øame, at ≈øuch times as the ≈øaid Sir R. Bolton, Kt. was Lord Chancellor of Ireland, or chief Baron of his Maje≈øties Court of Exchequer, within this Kingdom, and Sir Gerard Lowther, Knight, was Lord chief Ju≈øtice of the ≈øaid Court of Common Pleas, and again≈øt their Oathes of the ≈øame, and at ≈øuch time as the ≈øaid John, L. Bi≈øhop of Derry, was actuall Bi≈øhop of Derry, within this Kingdom, and were done and ≈øpeciated contrary
to their and every of their allegiance, ≈øeverall and re≈øpective oathes taken in that behalf.

IV. For which the ≈øaid Knights, Citizens and Burge≈ø≈øes, do impeach the ≈øaid Sir Richard Bolton, Lord Chancellor of Ireland, Iohn, L. B. of Derry, Sir Gerard Lowther, Kt. L. chief Ju≈øtice of his Maje≈øties ≈øaid Court of Common Pleas, and Sir George Radcliffe, Kt. afore≈øaid, and every of them of high Trea≈øon, again≈øt our Soveraign Lord the King, his Crown and Dignity.

The ≈øaid Knights, Citizens, and Burge≈ø≈øes, by Prote≈øtation, ≈øaving to them≈øelves the liberty of exhibiting at any time hereafter, any accu≈øation or impeachment again≈øt the ≈øaid Sir Rich. Bolton, Iohn, L. Bi≈øhop of Derry, Sir Gerard Lowther, and Sir George Radcliffe afore≈øaid, and every of them, and al≈øo of replying to them, and every of their an≈øwers, which they and every of them, ≈øhall make to the ≈øaid Articles, or any of them, and of offering proof al≈øo of the premi≈ø≈øes, or of any other impeachment, or accu≈øation, as ≈øhall be by them exhibited; as the ca≈øe ≈øhall according to the cour≈øe of Parliament require.

And the ≈øaid Knights, Citizens, and Burge≈ø≈øes do pray, that the ≈øaid Sir Richard Bolton, Knight, Lord Chancellor of Ireland, Iohn, Lord Bi≈øhop of Derry, Sir Gerard Lowther, Knight, Lord chief Ju≈øtice of his Maje≈øties ≈øaid Court of Common Pleas, and Sir George Radcliffe, Knight, and every of them, be put to an≈øwer to all and every of the premi≈ø≈øes, and that all ≈øuch Proceedings, Examinations, Triall, and Iudgement, may be upon them and every of them, had and u≈øed, as is agreeable to Law and Ju≈øtice.

p.hi: Copia vera.

div.head: Sir Thomas Wentworths ≈øpeech, XXijd. Martij, 1627.
div.p: MAy this dayes re≈øolution be as happy, as I conceive the propo≈øition (which now moves me to ri≈øe) is ≈øea≈øonable and nece≈ø≈øary, for whether we ≈øhall look upon the King or the people, it did never more behove this great Phy≈øitian the Parliament, to effect a true con≈øent towards the parties then now; This debate carryes with it, a double a≈øpect, towards the Soveraign, towards the Subject, though both innocent, both injured, both to be cured.

In the repre≈øentation of injuries, I ≈øhall crave your attention in the Cures; I ≈øhall be≈øeech your equall cares, and better judgements (≈øurely in the greate≈øt humility, I ≈øpeak it) the≈øe illegall waies are marks and puni≈øhments of indignation.

The rai≈øing of Leavies ≈øtrengthned by Commi≈ø≈øion, with unheard of in≈øtructions, the billetting of Souldiers by Lievetenants without leave, have been, as if they could have per≈øwaded Chri≈øtian Princes (nay Worlds) the right of Empire had been to take a way by ≈øtrong hand; and they have endeavoured, as far as was po≈ø≈øible for them to do it.

This hath not been done by the King (under the plea≈øing ≈øhade of who≈øe Crown I hope we ≈øhall ever gather the fruits of Ju≈øtice) but by Projectors, They have extended the prerogative of the King, beyond the ju≈øt Center, which was the ≈øweet harmony of the whole.

They have rent from us the light of our eyes‚ñ™ inforced a company of Gue≈øts, wor≈øe than the Ordinaries of
France, vitiated our wives and daughters before our faces, brought the Crown to greater want than ever it was, by anticipating the Revenue, and can the Shephard be thus ≈ømitten, and the flock not ≈øcattered?

They have introduced a Privie Coun≈øell ravi≈øhing at once the Spheers of all ancient government, impri≈øoning us without Bail or Bond. They have taken from us what ≈øhall I ≈øay (indeed what have ‚Ä¢ hey left us) all mean of ≈øupplying the King, and ingratiating our ≈øelves with him, taking up the roots of all propriety, which if it be not ≈øea≈øonably ≈øet into the ground by his Maie≈øties hand, we ≈øh ‚Ä¢ ll have in≈øtead of beauty, baldne≈ø≈øe.

To the making of them whole I ≈øhall apply my ≈øelf, and propound a remedy, to all the≈øe di≈øea≈øes, by one and the ≈øame thing hath the King and people been hurt, and by the ≈øame mu≈øt they be cured, to vindicate what? New things? No. Our ancient, ≈øober, vitall liberties, by reinforcing of the ancient Lawes made by our Ance≈øtors, by ≈øetting ≈øuch a Character upon them, as no licentious ≈øpirit ≈øhall dare hereafter to enter upon them. And ≈øhall we thinke this away to break a Parliament? N ‚Ä¢ . Our de≈øires are mode≈øt and iu≈øt, I ≈øpeak truly, both for the intere≈øt of the King and People. If we enjoy not tho≈øe, it will be impo≈ø≈øible to relieve him; Therefore let us never fear that they ≈øhall not be accepted by his goodne≈ø≈øe.

Wherefore I ≈øhall de≈øcend to my motions, which concon≈øi≈øts of four parts, two of which have relation to the per≈øons two to the propriety of goods, for the per≈øons, the freedome of them from impri≈øoning.

Secondly from employments abroad, contrary to the ancient cu≈øtomes for our goods, that no leavies may be made but in Parliament. Secondly, no billetting of Souldiers: It is mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary, that the≈øe be re≈øolved, that the Subiects may be ≈øecured in both.
Then for the manner in the ≈øecond place, it will be fit to determine it by a Grand Committee.

div.head: Sir Thomas Wentworths Speech 21. of Aprill, Anno, 1628.
div.p: TOo many in≈øtigations importune the ≈øequell of my words; Fir≈øt, the equitie of your proceedings. Secondly, the hone≈øty of my reque≈øt, for I behold in all your intendments a ≈øingularity grounded upon di≈øcretion and goodne≈ø≈øe, and your con≈øultations ≈øteered as well by Charity as extremity of ju≈øtice.

This order and method I ≈øay of your procedings, together with the importunity offered of the Subject in hand, have emboldned me to ≈øolicite an exten≈øion of the late granted protections in generall. The lawfulne≈ø≈øe and hone≈øty of the propo≈øitions depends upon the≈øe two particulars.

list.item: I. The pre≈øent troubles of the parties protected, having run them≈øelves into a further and almo≈øt irrecoverable hazards, by pre≈øuming upon, and feeding them≈øelves with the hopes of a long continuing Parliament.

II. Let the ≈øecond be this con≈øequence; That that which is prejudiciall to mo≈øt, ought to mini≈øter matter of advantage to the re≈øt; ≈øith then our interpellations and di≈øturbances among≈øt our ≈øelves are di≈øplea≈øing almo≈øt to all, if any benefit may be collected, let it fall upon tho≈øe, for I think the breach of our Se≈ø≈øion can befriend none but ≈øuch, nor ≈øuch neither, but by means of the grant before hand. And becau≈øe it is probable, that his Maje≈øty may cau≈øe a Remeeting this next Michaelmas, Let thither al≈øo reach their pre≈øcribed time for liberty. And that till then their protections ≈øhall remain in as full vertue and authority, as if the Parliament were actually ≈øitting.

div.head: To the Right Honorable, the LORD Deputie.
div.p:
SHewing that in all ages pa≈øt, ≈øince the happy ≈øubiection of this Kingdome, to the imperiall Crown of England; it was and is a principall ≈øtudy, and Princely care of his Maie≈øty, and his mo≈øt Noble Progenitors, Kings and Queens of England, and Ireland, to the va≈øt expence of Trea≈øure and bloud, that their loyall and dutifull people of this land of Ireland, being now for the mo≈øt part derived from the Britti≈øh Ance≈øtor, ≈øhould be governed according to the municipiall and fundamentall lawes of England, that the Statute of Magna Charta, or the great Charter for the liberties of England, and other laudable lawes and Statutes, were in ≈øeverall Parliaments here enacted and declared, that by the means thereof, and of the mo≈øt prudent and benigne government of his Maie≈øtie and his royall Progenitors, this Kingdome was (untill of late) in its growth to a flouri≈øhing e≈øtate, whereby the ≈øaid people were hertofore enabled to an≈øwer their humble and naturall de≈øires, to comply with his Maie≈øties Royall and Princely occa≈øions, by the free gift of 150000 l. ≈øter. and likewi≈øe by another gift of 120000 l. ≈øter. more during the government of the Lord Vi≈øcount Faulk-land, and after by the gift of 40000. l. and their free and chearfull gift of 6. entire Sub≈øidies, in the 10. year of his Maie≈øties Reign, which to comply with his Maie≈øties then occa≈øions ≈øignified to the then H. of Commons they did allow ≈øhould amount in the collections unto 250000. l. although as they confidently beleeve, if the ≈øayd Sub≈øidies had not been levied in a moderate Parliamentary way, they would not have amounted to much
more than half the ≈øaid ≈øum, be≈øides the four entire Sub≈øidies, granted in this pre≈øent Parliament. So it is, may it plea≈øe your Lord≈øhip, that by the occa≈øion of the en≈øuing and other grievances and innovations, though to his Maie≈øtie no con≈øiderable profit, this Kingdome is reduced to that extreme and univer≈øall poverty, that the ≈øame is now le≈ø≈øe able to pay a Sub≈øidie, then it was heretofore to ≈øatisfie all the before recited great payments, and his Maie≈øties mo≈øt faithfull people of the ≈øame, do conceive great fears that the grievances and the con≈øequences therof may hereafter be drawn into precedents to be perpetuated upon their po≈øterity, which in their great hopes and ≈øtrong belief, they are per≈øwaded is contrary to his Maie≈øties Royall and Princely intention towards his ≈øaid people, ≈øome of which ≈øaid grievances, are as followeth.

I. Fir≈øt, the generall and apparent decay of Trades, occca≈øioned by the new and illegall ray≈øing of the book of Rates and Impo≈øitions, as xii, d. a piece, cu≈øtome for Hides bought for 3.4. or 5. s. and many other heavie Impo≈øitions upon native and other commodities exported and imported, by rea≈øon thereof and of the extream u≈øage, and ≈øen≈øures, Marchants are beggered, and both di≈øinabled and di≈øcouraged to trade; and ≈øome of the honorable per≈øons who gain thereby, are often Iudges, and parties, and that in conclu≈øion his Maie≈øties profit therby is not con≈øiderably advanced.

II. Secondly, the arbitrary deci≈øion of all civill cau≈øes and controver≈øies, by paper petitions before the Lord Lievetenant, and Lord Deputy, and infinite other Iudicators upon references from them derived in the nature of all actions, determinable at the Common-law, not limited unto certain times, ≈øea≈øons, cau≈øes, and things what≈øoever, and the con≈øequence of ≈øuch proceedings, by receiving imomoderate and unlawfull fees by Secretaries, Clerkes, Pur≈øivants,
Serjants at Armes, and otherwi≈øe, by which kinde of proceedings, his Maje≈øty lo≈øeth a con≈øiderable part of his Revenue, upon originall writs, and otherwi≈øe; and the Subject lo≈øeth the benefit of his writ of error, Bill of rever≈øall, vouchers, and other legall and ju≈øt advantages, and the ordinary cour≈øe and Courts of Ju≈øtice declined.
III. Thirdly, the proceedings in civill cau≈øes at the Councell boord, contrary to the law and great Charter, and not mitted to any certain time or ≈øea≈øon.

IV. Fourthly, that the Subject is in all the materiall parts thereof, denyed the benefit of the principall graces, and more e≈øpecially of the Statute of Limitations, of the 21. Jan. granted by his Maje≈øty in the 4 year of this Reign, upon great advice of the Coun≈øell of England, and Ireland, and for great con≈øideration; and th n publi≈øhed in all the Courts of Dublin, and in all the Courts of this Kingdome in open A≈ø≈øizes, whereby all per≈øons do take notice, that contrary to his Maje≈øties plous intention, his Subiects of this Land have not enioyed the benefit of his Maie≈øties Princely promi≈øe thereby made.

V. Fiftly, the extraiudiciall avoyding of Letters Patents of e≈øtates of a very great part of his Maie≈øties Subiects under the great Seale (the publique faith of the Kingdome) by private opinions delivered at Councell Boord, without legall Evictions of their e≈øtates, contrary to the Law and without precedent or example of any former age.

VI. Sixtly, the Proclamation for the ≈øole exemption and uttering of Tobacco, which is bought at very low Rates, and uttered at high and exce≈ø≈øive Rates, by means wherof thou≈øands of Families within this Kingdome and of his Maie≈øties ≈øubiects in ≈øeverall I≈ølands, and other parts of
the We≈øt Judies (as your Petitioners are informed) are de≈øtroyed, and the mo≈øt part of „Äà‚óä„Äâ Coyne of this Kingdome is ingro≈ø≈øed into particular hands: In≈øomuch that your Petitioners do conceive that the profit ari≈øing and ingro≈ø≈øed thereby, doth ≈øurmount his Maie≈øties Revenues certaine and ca≈øuall within this Kingdome, and yet his Maie≈øtie receiveth but very little profit by the ≈øame.
VII. Seventhly, the unu≈øuall and unlawfull increa≈øing of Monopolies to the advantage of few, to the di≈øprofit of his Maie≈øty, and the impoveri≈øhment of his people.

VIII. Eighthly, the extream and cruell u≈øage of certain late Commi≈ø≈øioners and other, towards the Britti≈øh Farmers and Inhabitants of the City and County of London-derry, by meanes whereof the worthy plantation of that Country is almo≈øt de≈øtroyed, and the Inhabitants are reduced to great poverty, and many of them forced to for≈øake the Country, the ≈øame being the fir≈øt and mo≈øt u≈øefull Plantation in the large Province of ∆≤l≈øter, to the great weakning of the Kingdome, in this time of danger, the ≈øayd Plantation being the principall ≈øtrength of tho≈øe parts.

IX. Ninthly, the late erection of the Court of high Commi≈ø≈øion for cau≈øes Eccle≈øia≈øticall in the≈øe nece≈ø≈øitous times, the proceedings of the ≈øayd Court in many cau≈øes without legall warrant, and yet ≈øo ≈øupported as prohibitions have not been obtained, though legally ≈øought for, and the exce≈ø≈øive fees exacted by the mini≈øters thereof, and the incroaching of the ≈øame upon the iuri≈ødiction of other Eccle≈øia≈øticall Courts of this Kingdome.
X. Tenthly, the exorbitant and Barbarous Fees and pretended Cu≈øtomes exacted by the Clergie again≈øt the Law, ≈øome of which have beene formerly repre≈øented to your Lord≈øhip.

XI. Eleventhly, the Petitioners do mo≈øt heartily bemone that his Maie≈øties ≈øervices and profits are much more impaired than advanced by the grievances afore≈øaid. And the Sub≈øidies granted in the la≈øt Parliament having much increa≈øed his Maie≈øties Revenue by the buying in of Grants, and otherwi≈øe, and that all his Maie≈øties debts then due in this Kingdome were ≈øatisfied out of the ≈øayd Sub≈øidies, and yet his Maie≈øty is of late (as your Petitioners have beene inform'd) in the Hou≈øe of Commons become indebted in this Kingdome in great ≈øums, and they do therefore humbly be≈øeech that an exact account may be ≈øent to his Maie≈øty, how and in what manner his trea≈øure i≈ø≈øued.

XII. Twelfthly, the Petitioners do humbly co ‚Ä¢ ceive great and iu≈øt fears, at a Proclamation publi≈øhed in this Kingdome in Anno Dom. 1635. prohibiting men of quality or e≈øtate for to depart this Kingdome into England, without the Lord Deputies Licen≈øe, whereby the Subiects of this Kingdome are hindered and interrupted from free acce≈ø≈øe and addre≈ø≈øe to his ≈øacred Maie≈øty and Privie Coun≈øell of England, to declare their iu≈øt grievances, or to obtaine remedie for them, in ≈øuch ≈øort as their Ance≈øtors have done in all ages, ≈øince the Reigne of King Henry the ≈øecond, and great Fees exacted for every of the ≈øaid Licen≈øes.

XIII. Thirteenthly, that of late his Maie≈øties late Attourny generall hath exhibited informations again≈øt many ancient Burroughs of this Kingdome into his Mai ≈øties Court of Exchequer, to ≈øhew by what warrant the ≈øayd Burroughes, who heretofore ≈øent Burge≈ø≈øes to the Parliament, ≈øhould ≈øend the ≈øayd Burge≈ø≈øes to the Parliament. And thereupon for want of an an≈øwer, the ≈øayd Priviledge
of ≈øending Burge≈ø≈øes was ≈øeized by the ≈øayd Court, which proceedings were altogether Coram non Judice, and contrary to the Lawes and Priviledges of the Hou≈øe of Parliament (and if way ≈øhould be given thereunto) might tend to the ≈øubver≈øion of Parliaments, and by con≈øequence to the ruine and de≈øtruction of the Common-wealth, and that the Hou≈øe of Commons hath hitherto in this pre≈øent Parliament bin deprived of the advice and Coun≈øell of many profitable and good members by means thereof.
XIV. Fourteenthly, that by the powerfulne≈ø≈øe of ≈øome mini≈øters of State in this Kingdome, the Parliament in its members and actions hath not his naturall freedome.

XV. Fifteenthly, that the fees taken in all the Courts of Iu≈øtice in this Kingdome, both Eccle≈øia≈øticall, and Civill, and by other inferiour Officers and Mini≈øters, are ≈øo immoderately high, that it is an un≈øpeakable burthen to all his Maie≈øties Subiects of this, who are not able to ≈øub≈øi≈øt, except the ≈øame be ≈øpeedily remedied and reduced to ≈øuch a moderation as may ≈øtand with the condition of this Realme.

And la≈øtly, That the Gentry, Merchants, and other his Maie≈øties Subiects of this Kingdome, are of late by the grievances and pre≈ø≈øures afore≈øayd and other the like, very neere to ruine and de≈øtruction. And Farmers of Cu≈øtomes, Cu≈øtomers, Waiters, Searchers, Clearks of unwarrentable proceedings, Pur≈øevants, and Gaolers, and ≈øundry others very much inriched, whereby, and by the ≈ølow redre≈ø≈øe of the Petitioners grievances, his Maie≈øties mo≈øt faithfull and dutifull people of this Kingdome, do conceive great feares that their readine≈ø≈øe approved upon all occa≈øions, hath not been of late rightly repre≈øented to his Maie≈øty.

For Remedy whereof, the ≈øaid Petitioners do humbly and of Right be≈øeech your Lord≈øhip, that the grievances and pre≈ø≈øures may be ≈øpeedily redre≈ø≈øed. And if your Lord≈øhip ≈øhall not think ≈øit to afford us pre≈øent relief therein, that your Lord≈øhip may admit a ≈øelect Committee of this Hou≈øe of per≈øons un intere≈ø≈øed in the benefit ari≈øing, the afore≈øaid grievances to be licen≈øed by your Lord≈øhip, to repaire to his ≈øacred Maie≈øty in England for to pur≈øue the ≈øame, and to obtain fitting Remedies for their afore≈øaid and other iu≈øt grievances and oppre≈ø≈øions, and upon all iu≈øt and honorable occa≈øions, they will without re≈øpect of particular intere≈øt or profit to be rai≈øed thereby, mo≈øt humbly and readily in Parliament, extend their utmo≈øt indeavours to ≈øerve his Maie≈øty, and comply with his Royall and Princely occa≈øions,
And ≈øhall pray, &c.

div.head: A Speech again≈øt the Judges, per Ignotum quendam.
div.p:
IT was a cu≈øtome among the Romans (who as by their power they once gave laws, ≈øo by the happy ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of their long flouri≈øhing Government, might they well give examples to all the world) that in their Senates the yonge≈øt men ≈øpake fir≈øt: partly that they might not have their weaker notions anticipated by the more knowing Senators. And partly that the Senate might not be diverted from the mature re≈øolutions of the more ancient by the interpo≈øition of the younger men; They as all free States ever allowing free members to expre≈ø≈øe them≈øelves according to their ≈øeverall capacities. And me
thinks 'twas a happy Method. So your opinions and inclinations of the A≈ø≈øembly, being di≈øcovered and ripened to re≈øolution by ≈øuch gradations, the ≈øentences of the Sages ≈øounded as Iudgements, not orations, their wi≈øedome and gravity put a ≈øea≈øonable Period to others, perhaps otherwi≈øe endle≈ø≈øe di≈øcour≈øes.

Their precedent encourges me (who wor≈øt may) to break the Ice: Children can lay their fingers on the Sore, point out their pain; and Infant Graduates in Parliament, may groan out the grievances of a di≈øea≈øed Commonwealth, but they mu≈øt be Doctors in the Art of Government that can apply apt remedies to recover it.

Mr. Speaker, Ancient and approved hath been that parallell of the body politique with the body naturall: 'Tis the part of their Patients in either di≈øtempered, to impart freely their griefs to the Phy≈øitians of the body or ≈øtate, if they expect a cure.

This Common-wealth is (or ≈øhould be) but one body. This hou≈øe, the great Phy≈øitian of all our maladies, and alas, Mr. Speaker, of what afflicted part ≈øhall we poor Patients complain fir≈øt? Or rather of what ≈øhall we not complain?

Are we not heart-≈øick? Is there in us that which God requires, unity, purity, and ≈øingulari y of heart? Nay is not Religion (the ≈øoul of this body) ≈øo mi≈øerably di≈øtracted, that, I ≈øpeak it with terrour of heart, 'tis to be feared, there is more confu≈øion of religions among≈øt us, then there was of tongues at the ≈øubver≈øion of Babell: And is it not then high time that we under≈øtand one another, that we were reduc'd to one Faith, one Government.

Sir, Is the Head whole: The ≈øear of Government and Ju≈øtice, the Fountain from who≈øe ≈øweet influence, all the inferiour members of this body ≈øhould receive both vigour and motion: Nay, hath not rather a generall Apoplexy, or Pal≈øie, taken, o ‚Ä¢ ≈øhaken all our members? Are not ≈øome dead? Others buried quick? Some di≈ømembred, all di≈øordered
by the diver≈øion of the cour≈øe of Ju≈øtice.

Is the Liver (Natures Exchequer) open; from who≈øe free di≈øtribution each limb may receive his proper Nutriment, or rather is it not wholly ob≈øtructed? Our property taken from us? So that it may properly be ≈øaid of us, Sic vos non vobis fertis aratra, our Ance≈øtors drunk the juyce of their own Vines, reap'd and eat the fruit of their own harve≈øt. But now the poor mans Plough goes to ≈øurrow the Seas, to build Ships: we labour not for our ≈øelves but to feed the excre≈ø≈øions of Nature, things grown up out of the ruines of the naturall members. Monopolists.

Sir, the≈øe are Maxima vitalia; Religion, Iu≈øtice, property; The Heart, the Head, the Liver of this great body, and the≈øe di≈øtempered or ob≈øtructed, can the ≈øubordinate parts be free? No ≈øir, the truth is; all is ≈øo farre out of frame, that to lay open every particular grievance were to drive us into de≈øpair of cure; In ≈øo great confu≈øion where to begin fir≈øt, requires not much le≈ø≈øe care than what to apply.

Mr. Speaker, I know 'tis a plau≈øible motion to begin with ≈øetting Gods Hou≈øe in order fir≈øt: who pre≈ø≈øes that, moves with ≈øuch advantage, that he is ≈øure no man will gain-≈øay him. 'Tis a welbecoming zeal to prefer Religion before our own affairs, and indeed 'tis a duty not to be omitted; where they are in equall danger: But in cure of the body, politique or naturall, we mu≈øt prefer the mo≈øt pre≈ø≈øing exigents.

Phy≈øitians know that Con≈øumptions, Drop≈øies, and ≈øuch like lingering di≈øea≈øes are more mortall, more difficult to cure then ≈ølight externall wounds: yet if the lea≈øt Vein be cut, they mu≈øt neglect their greater cures to ≈øtop that, which if neglected, mu≈øt needs exhau≈øt the ≈øtock of nature, and produce a di≈ø≈øolution of the whole man.

A Defection from the duties of our Religion is a Con≈øumption to any State, no foundation is firm that is not
laid in Chri≈øt.
The Deniall of Iu≈øtice, the abridgement of our liberties, is ≈øuch an ob≈øtruction as renders the Common-wealth Leprous; but the wounds in our property lets out the life-blood of the people.

The Reformation of Church-Government mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily be a work of much time, and God be thanked the di≈øea≈øe is not de≈øperate; We ≈øerve one God, we believe in one Chri≈øt, and we all acknowledge and profe≈ø≈øe one Go≈øpel. The difference is onely de modo, we vary but in Ceremonies to reduce which, to the Primitive Practice, mu≈øt be a work of great debate, is not a work for us alone to ≈øettle.

The ≈øtop of Iu≈øtice can yet injure but particulars, 'Tis true, there may be many, too many in≈øtances of ≈øtrange oppre≈ø≈øions, great oppre≈ø≈øors, but 'twill be hard to judge the Conclu≈øion. Et ≈øic de caeteris.

But take from us the propriety of our e≈øtates, our ≈øub≈øi≈øtence, we are no more a people. This is that veyn which hath bin ≈øo deep cut, ≈øo farre exhau≈øt, that to pre≈øerve our being, we mu≈øt doubtle≈ø≈øe ≈øtop this current: Then ≈øettle Rules to live by, when we are ≈øure to live.

Mr. Speaker, he that well weighes this little word Property, or propriety in our e≈øtates, will finde it of a large extent; The Leeches that have ≈øuckt this blood, have bin Exci≈øe, Benevolences, Loans, Impo≈øitions, Monopolies, Military, Taxes, Ship-money (cum multis aliis) all which ≈øpring from one Root.

And is it not high time to grub up that root that brings forth ≈øuch fruit? Shall we fir≈øt ≈øtand to lop the branches one by one, when we may down with all at once? He that to correct an evill tree, that brings forth bad fruit, ≈øhall begin at the ma≈øter bough, and ≈øo lop downwards, is in danger to fall him≈øelf before the tree falls. The ≈øafer and ≈øpeedier way is to begin at the root, and there, with ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to better judgements, would I lay the Axe

The Root of mo≈øt of our pre≈øent mi≈øchiefs, and the ruine
of all po≈øterity, do I hold, to be that extraiudiciall (Iudgement I cannot ≈øay, but rather) doom, delivered by all the Iudges under their hands out of Court, yet recorded in all Courts, to the ≈øubver≈øion of all our Fundamentall Laws, Liberties, and Annihilation, if not Confi≈øcation of our e≈øtates. That in ca≈øe of danger, the King may impo≈øe upon his ≈øubiects, and that he is the ‚Ä¢ ole Iudge of the danger, nece≈ø≈øity, and proportion, which in brief, is to take what, when, and where he will, which though delivered in the time of a gracious and mercifull Prince, who we hope will not wre≈øt it beyond our abilities, yet left to the Interpretation of a ≈øucceeding Tyrant, if ever this Nation be ≈øo fortunate to fall into the hands of ≈øuch; it is a Record wherein every man might reade him≈øelf a ≈ølave that reades it, having nothing he can call his own, all pro≈øti≈øtute to the will of another.

What to do in ≈øuch a ca≈øe, we are not to ≈øeek for precedents, our Honorable Ance≈øtors taught us in the ju≈øt and exemplar puni≈øhments of chief Iu≈øtice, Tre≈øilian and his Complices (for giving their judgements out of Parliament again≈øt the e≈øtabli≈øhed Laws of Parliament) how tender they were of us, how carefull we ought to be to continue tho≈øe Laws, to pre≈øerve the Liberty of our Po≈øterity.

I am far from maligning the per≈øon, nor in my heart wi≈øh I the Execution of any man, but certainly it ≈øhall be a Iu≈øtice well becoming this Hou≈øe, to lay their Heads at his Maie≈øties mercy, who laid us under his feet, who had made us but tenants at will of our Liberties and E≈øtates.
And though I cannot but approve of Mercy, as a great Vertue in any Prince, yet I heartily pray it may prove a Precedent as ≈øafe and u≈øefull to this oppre≈ø≈øed State, as that of Ju≈øtice.

Mr. Speaker, bla≈øted may that tongue be, that ≈øhall in the lea≈øt degree derogate from the glory of tho≈øe Halcyon
dayes our fathers enjoyed, during the Government of that ever ble≈ø≈øed, never to be fogot, Royall Elizabeth. But certainly I may ≈øafely ≈øay (without detraction) it was much advantage to the peace and pro≈øperity of her Raign, that the great examples of Emp≈øon and Dudley were then fre≈øh in memory: The Civility of our Laws tell us, that Kings can do no wrong, and then is the State ≈øecure, when Judges (their Mini≈øters) dare do none. Since our times have found the want of ≈øuch examples, 'tis fit we leave ≈øome to po≈øterity. God forbid all ≈øhould be thought or found guilty, there are doubtle≈ø≈øe ≈øome Ring-leaders, let us ≈øift them out. In publique Government to pa≈ø≈øe by the Nocent, is equall inju≈øtice, as to puni≈øh the Innocent. An omi≈ø≈øion of that duty now, will be a guilt in us, render us ≈øham'd in Hi≈øtory, cur≈øt by Po≈øterity, our gracious and (in that act of voluntary Ju≈øtice) mo≈øt glorious King, hath given up to the ≈øatisfaction of his afflicted People, the authors of their Ruines: the power of future pre≈øervation is now in us. Et qui non ≈øervat patriam, cum pote≈øt, idem facit de≈øtruenti patriam.

What though we cannot re≈øtore the damage of the Common-wealth, we may yet repair the breaches in the bounds of Monarchy. Though it be with our lo≈ø≈øe and charge, we ≈øhall ≈øo leave our childrens children, fenced as with a wall of ≈øafety, by the re≈øtauration of our Laws, to their ancient vigor and lu≈øtre.

'Tis too true, and 'tis to be feared, the Revenues of the Crown, ≈øold out-right, would ≈øcarce remunerat the iniuries, repay the lo≈ø≈øes of this ≈øuffering Nation, ≈øince the pronouncing of that fatall ≈øentence. What proportionable ≈øatisfaction then can this Common-wealth receive, in the puni≈øhment of a few incon≈øiderable Delinquents? But 'tis a Rule valid in Law, approved in equity, that Qui non habent in crumen Luant in Corpore. And 'tis without all que≈øtion in policy, exemplar puni≈øhments conduce more to the ≈øafety of a State, than pecuniary reparations;
Hope of impunity lulls every bad-great-officer into ≈øecurity for his time, and who would not venture to rai≈øe a Fortune, when the allurements of honour and wealth are ≈øo prevalent, if the wor≈øt is can fall, be but Re≈øtitution.

We ≈øee the bad effects of this bold-erroneous opinion; what was at fir≈øt but corrupt Law; by encouragement taken from their impunity, is ≈øince become fal≈øe Doctrine, the people taught in Pulpits, they have no property, Kings in≈øtructed in that de≈øtructive principle, that all is theirs, and is thence deduc'd into nece≈ø≈øary ≈øtate-policy, whi≈øpered in coun≈øell, That he is no Monarch, who is bounded by any Law.

By which bad con≈øequences, the be≈øt of Kings, hath bin by the infu≈øion of ≈øuch poy≈øonous po≈øitions diverted from the ≈øweet inclinations of his own Naturall Equity and Ju≈øtice, the very e≈ø≈øence of a King taken from him, which is pre≈øervation of his people: and whereas Salus populi is, or ≈øhould be, Suprema Lex, the power of undoing us, is ma≈øqu'd under the ≈øtile of what ≈øhould be Sacred Royall Prerogative.
And is it not high time for us to make examples of the fir≈øt authors of this, ≈øubverted Law, bad Coun≈øell, wor≈øe Doctrine?

p.hi: Let no man think to divert us from the pur≈øuit of Iu≈øtice, by poy≈øoning the clear ≈øtreams of our affections, with jealous ≈øears of his Maje≈øties Interruption, if we look too high. Shall we therefore doubt of Iu≈øtice, becau≈øe we have need of great Ju≈øtice? We may be confident the King well knows, That his Iu≈øtice is the Band of our Allegiance: That 'tis the ≈øtaffe, the proof of his Soveraignty.

div.p:
'Tis a happy a≈ø≈øurance of his intentions of grace to us, that our loyalty hath at la≈øt won him to tender the ≈øafety of his people: and certainly (all our pre≈ø≈øures weighed this 12 yeers la≈øt pa≈øt) it will be found the pa≈ø≈øive loyalty of this ≈øuffering Nation, hath our-done the active duty of all Times and Stories. As the Poet hath it, fortiter
ille facit, qui mi≈øer e≈ø≈øe pote≈øt: I may as properly ≈øay, Fideliter fecimus, we have done loyally to ≈øuffer ≈øo patiently.

Then ≈øince our Royall Lord hath in mercy vi≈øited us, let us not doubt, but in his Ju≈øtice he will redeem his people. Qui timid√® rogat docet negare. But when Religion is innovated, our Liberties violated, our Fundamentall Laws abrogated, our modern Laws already ob≈øoleted, the propriety of our E≈øtates alienated. Nothing left us, we can call our own, but our mi≈øery and our patience: if ever any Nation might iu≈øtifiably, this certainly may now, now mo≈øt properly, mo≈øt ≈øea≈øonably cry out, and cry aloud, vel Sacra Regnet Iu≈øtitia, vel Ruat Coelum.

Mr. Speaker, the ≈øumme of my humble motion, is, that a ≈øpeciall Committee may be appointed, to examine the whole carriage of that Extraiudiciall iudgement. Who were the Coun≈øellors, Soliciters, and ≈øub≈øcribers to the ≈øame: the rea≈øons of their Sub≈øcription, whether according to their opinions; by importunity or pre≈ø≈øure of others, whether proforma tantum. And upon report thereof to draw up a charge again≈øt the guilty, and then Lex Currat, Fiat Iu≈øtitia.

div.head: A brief Di≈øcour≈øe, concerning the power of the Peers and Commons of Parliament, in point of Iudjcature.
div.p: SIR, to give you as ≈øhort an account of your de≈øires as I can, I mu≈øt crave leave to lay you as a ground, the frame or fir≈øt modell of this State.

When after the period of the Saxon time, Harold had lifted him≈øelf into the Royall Seat; the Great men, to whom but lately he was no more equall either in fortune
or power, di≈ødaining this act, of arrogancy, called in William then Duke of Normandy, a Prince more active than any in the≈øe We≈øtern parts, and renowned for many victories he had fortunately atchieved again≈øt the French King, then the mo≈øt potent Monarch in Europe.

This Duke led along with him to this work of glory, many of the younger ≈øons of the be≈øt families of Normandy, Picardy, and Flanders, who as undertakers, accompanied the undertaking of this fortunate man.

The U≈øurper ≈ølain, and the Crown by war gained, to ≈øecure certain to his po≈øterity what he had ≈øo ≈øuddenly gotten, he ≈øhared out his purcha≈øe, retaining in each County a portion to ≈øupport the Dignity Soveraign, which was ≈øtyled Demenia Regni; now the ancient Demeans, and a≈ø≈øigning to others his adventures ≈øuch portions as ≈øuited to him≈øelf dependancy of their per≈øonall ≈øervice, except ≈øuch Lands as in free Almes were the portion of the Church, the≈øe were ≈øtyled Barones Regis, the Kings immediate Freeholders, for the word Baro imported then no more.

As the King to the≈øe, ≈øo the≈øe to their followers ≈øubdivided part of their ≈øhares into Knights fees, and their Tenants were called Barones Comites, or the like; for we finde, as in the Kings Writ in their Writs Baronibus ≈øuis & Francois & Anglois, the Soveraigne gifts, for the mo≈øt part extending to whole Counties or Hundreds, an Earl being Lord of the one, and a Baron of the inferiour donations to Lords of Town-≈øhips or Mannors.

And thus the Land, ≈øo was all cour≈øe of Iudicature divided, even from the meane≈øt to the highe≈øt portion, each ≈øeverall had his Court of Law, pre≈øerving ≈øtill the Mannor of our Ance≈øtors the Saxons, who jura per pages reddebant; and the≈øe are ≈øtill tearmed Court-Barons, or the Freeholders Court, twelve u≈øually in number, who with the Thame or chief Lord were Iudges.

The Hundred was next, where the Hundredus or Aldermanus, Lord of the Hundred, with the chief Lord of
each Town≈øhip within their limits iudged; Gods people ob≈øerved this form in the publike Centureonis & decam Judicabant plebem omni tempore.

The County or Generale placitum was the next, this was ≈øo to ≈øupply the defect, or remedy the corruption of the inferiour, ∆≤bi Curiae Dominorum probantur defeci≈ø≈øe, pertinet ad vice comitem Provinciarum; the Iudges here were Comites, vice comites & Barones Comitatus qui liberas in hoc terras babeant.

The la≈øt and ≈øupreme, and proper to our que≈øtion, was generale placitum apud London univer≈øalis Synodus in Charters of the Conquerour, Capitalis curia by Glanvile, Magnum & Commune con≈øilium coram Rege & magnatibus ≈øuis.

In the Rolles of Henry the 3. It is not ≈øtative but ≈øummoned by Proclamation, Edicitur generale placitum apud London, ≈øaith the book of Abingdon, whether Epium Duces principes, Satrapae Rectores, & Cau≈øidici ex omni parte confluxerunt ad i≈øtam curiam, ≈øaith Glanvile: Cau≈øes were referred, Propter aliquam dubitationem quae emergit in comitatu, cum Comitatus ne≈øcit dijudicare. Thus did Ethelweld, Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter, transferre his ≈øuit again≈øt Leo≈øtine, from the County ad generale placitum, in the time of King Etheldred, Queen Edgine again≈øt Goda; from the County appealed to King Etheldred at London. Congregatis principibus & ≈øapientibus Angliae, a ≈øuit between the Bi≈øhops of Winche≈øter and Durham, in the time of Saint Edward. Coram Epi≈øcopis & principibus Regni inpre≈øentia Regis ventilate & finita. In the tenth yeer of the Conqueror, Epi≈øcopi, Comites & Barones Regni potestate adver≈øis provinciis ad univer≈øalem Synodum pro cau≈øis audiendis & tractandis Convocati, ≈øaith the book of We≈øtminster. And this continued all along in the ≈øucceeding Kings raigne, untill towards the end of Henry the third.

AS this great Court or Councell con≈øi≈øting of the King and Barons, ruled the great affairs of State, and controlled all inferiour Courts, ≈øo were there certain Officers, who≈øe tran≈øcendent power ≈øeemed to be ≈øet to bound in the execution of Princes wills, as the Steward, Con≈øtable, and Mar≈øhall, fixed upon Families in Fee for many ages: They as Tribunes of the people, or explori among the Athenians, grown by unmanly courage fearfull to Monarchy, fell at the feet and mercie of the King, when the daring Earle of Leice≈øter was ≈ølain at Eve≈øham.

This chance and the deare experience H the 3. him≈øelfe had made at the Parliament at Oxford in the 40. yeare of his Raign, and the memory of the many ≈øtraights his Father was driven unto, e≈øpecially at Rumny-mead neere Stanes, brought this King wi≈øely to begin what his Succe≈ø≈øour fortunately fini≈øhed, in le≈ø≈øoning the ≈øtrength and power of his great Lords; and this was wrought by ≈øearching into the Regality they had u≈øurped over their peculiar Soveraigns, whereby they were (as the booke of St. Albans termeth them.) Quot Domini tot Tiranni. And by the weakning that hand of power which they carried in the Parliaments by commanding the ≈øervice of many Knights, Citizens, and Burge≈ø≈øes to that great Councell.

Now began the frequent ≈øending of Writs to the Commons, their a≈ø≈øent not only u≈øed in money, charge, and making Lawes, for before all ordinances pa≈ø≈øed by the King and Peeres, but their con≈øent in judgements of all natures whether civill, or criminall: In proofe-whereof I will produce ≈øome few ≈øucceeding Pre≈øidents out of Record.

When Adamor that proud Prelate of Winche≈øter the Kings half brother had grieved the State by his daring power,Liber S. Alban, fol. 20.7. An 44. H. 3. he was exiled by joynt ≈øentence of the King, the Lords, and Commons, and this appeareth expre≈ø≈øely by
the Letter ≈øent to Pope Alexander the fourth, expo≈øtulating a revocation of him from bani≈øhment, becau≈øe be was a Church-man, and ≈øo not ≈øubject to any cen≈øure, in this the an≈øwer is, Si Dominus Rex & Regnimajores hoc vellent, meaning his revocation, Communit as tamen ip≈øius ingre≈ø≈øum in Angliam jam nullatenus ≈øu≈øtineret. The Peers ≈øub≈øign this an≈øwer with their names and Petrus de Mountford vice totius Communitatis, as Speaker or Proctor of the Commons.

For by that ≈øtile Sir John Tiptofe, Prolocutor,Charta orig. ≈øub figil An. 8. H. 4. affirmeth under his Arms the Deed of Intaile of the Crowns by King Henry the 4. in the 8. year of his Raign for all the Commons.

The bani≈øhment of the two Spencers in the 15. of Edward the ≈øecond, Prelati Comites & Barones & les autres Peeres de la terre & Communes de Roialme give con≈øent and ≈øentence to the revocation and rever≈øement of the former ≈øentence the Lords and Commons accord, and ≈øo it is expre≈ø≈øed in the Roll.

In the fir≈øt of Edw. the 3. when Elizabeth the widdow of Sir John de Burgo complained in Parliament,Rot. Parl. 15. E. 3 vel. 2. that Hugh Spencer the younger, Robert Boldock, and William Cliffe his in≈øtruments, had by dure≈ø≈øe forced to make a Writing to the King, wherby ≈øhe was di≈øpoyled of all her inheritance, ≈øentence is given for her in the≈øe words, Pur ceo que avis e≈øt al Eve≈øques Counts, & Barones, & autres grandes & a tout Cominalte de la terre, que le dit e≈øcript e≈øt fait contre ley, & tout manere de rai≈øon ≈øi fui≈øt le det e≈øcript per agard del Parliam. dampue elloquens al livre a ladit Eliz.

In An. 4. Edw. 3. it appeareth by a Letter to the Pope,Prel ‚Ä¢ . Parliam. 1. Ed. 3. Rot. 11 that to the ≈øentence given again≈øt the Earle of Kent, the Commons were parties, as well as the Lords and Peeres, for the King directed their proceedings in the≈øe words, Comitibus, Magnatibus, Baronibus, & aliis de Communitate dicti Regni ad Parliamentum illud congregatis injunximus ut ≈øuper his di≈øcernerent & judicarent quod rationi &
ju≈øtitiae, conveniret, habere prae oculis, ≈øolum Deum qui eum concordi unanimi ≈øententia tanquam reum criminis lae≈øae Maje≈øtatis morti adjudicarent ejus ≈øententia, &c.

When in the 50 yeere of Edw. 3. the Lords had pronounced the ≈øentence again≈øt Richard Lions, Parl An. 5. Edw. 3. otherwi≈øe then the Commons agreed, they appealed to the King, and had redre≈ø≈øe, and the ≈øentence entred to their de≈øires.

When in the fir≈øt yeere of Richard the ≈øecond, William We≈øton,
Parl. An. 1. Rich. 2 11 3.8. & 3.5. and John Jennings were arraigned in Parliament for ≈øurrendring certain Forts of the Kings, the Commons were parties to the ≈øentence again≈øt them given, as appeareth by a Memorandum annexed to that Record. In the fir≈øt of Hen. the 4. although the Commons refer by prote≈øtation, the pronouncing of the ≈øentence of depo≈øition again≈øt King Rich. the 2. unto the Lords‚ñ™ yet are they equally intere≈ø≈øed in it, as it appeareth by the Record, for there are made Proctors or Commi≈ø≈øioners for the whole Parliament, one B. one Abbot, one E. one Baron, and 2. Knights, Gray, and Erpingham for the Commons, and to infer that becau≈øe the Lords pronounced the ≈øentence, the point of judgement ≈øhould be only theirs, were as ab≈øurd as to conclude, that no authority was be≈øt in any other Commi≈ø≈øioner of Oyer, and Terminer then in the per≈øon of that man ≈øolely that ≈øpeaketh the ≈øentence.

In 2. Hen. 5. the Petition of the Commons importeth no le≈ø≈øe than a right they had to act and a≈ø≈øent to all things in Parliament,Rot. Parl. An. 2. H, 6. and ≈øo it is an≈øwered by the King; and had not the adjourned Roll of the higher Hou≈øe beene left to the ≈øole entry of the Clark of the upper Hou≈øe; who, either out of the neglect to ob≈øerve due forme, or out of purpo≈øe to ob≈øcure the Commons right, and to flatter the power of tho≈øe who immediately ≈øerved, there would have been frequent examples of all times to cleere this doubt, and to pre≈øerve a ju≈øt intere≈øt to the Common-wealth, and how conveniently it ≈øuites with Monarchy to maintaine this forme, le≈øt others of that well framed bodie
knit under one head, ≈øhould ≈øwell too great and mon≈øtrous. It may be ea≈øily thought for; Monarchy againe may ≈øooner groan under the weight of an Ari≈øtocracie as it once did, then under Democracie which it never yet either felt or fear'd.

div.head: Sir John Hollands Speech in Parliament, 1640.
div.p: THe time of actions are not for rethorick and elocution which emboldens me to ri≈øe; And though I mu≈øt acknowledge my ≈øelfe to be one of the yonge≈øt Schollers, and meane≈øt proficients in this great Sch ‚Ä¢ ole of wi≈øedome, yet I conceive it a great part of my duty at this time both to deliver my ≈øuit and con≈øcience. We are called hither Ma≈øter Speaker by the Royall power, we ≈øit here by the Kings Maje≈øties grace and favour, and ≈øince his Maje≈øty hath beene graciou≈øly plea≈øed to leave the government of all in our hands, I doubt not but we ≈øhall lay ≈øuch a foundation in the beginning of this Parliament, that we ≈øhall make it a happy Age, a long la≈øting one ≈øince the dangers of the≈øe times, the pre≈øent di≈øtempers of this State, and therein both his Maje≈øtie, and our nece≈ø≈øities, yea and the whole Kingdomes ≈øafety do require it.

We are called now, Ma≈øter Speaker, as I conceive from the reports you have made of his Maje≈øties gracious Declaration, for foure principall cau≈øes. Fir≈øt, for ≈øupply of his Maje≈øties wants. Secondly, for the relief of our Brethren in the Northern parts. Thirdly, for the remove
of the Scots forces. Fourthly, for redre≈ø≈øe of ourowne grievances. That his Maje≈øties wants are great and many, Ma≈øter Speaker, I thinke there is no man doubts it; and it is as cer ‚Ä¢ ain out grievances are ≈øo to, they are great and many both in Church and Common-wealth; I ≈øhall but touch them in either, ≈øince they have been ≈øo fully remon≈øtrated in both.

Fir≈øt in the Church, by the u≈øurping power of ≈øome Prelates and their adherents, by which means many great dangers, innovations of doctrines, of di≈øcipline, of government have been thru≈øt upon us.

Secondly in the Church, by publique ≈øufferances of Prie≈øts and Je≈øuits, not only to come into the land, by which means the number of Romi≈øh Catholiks are dangerou≈øly multiplied, Idolatry increa≈øed, and Gods heavie judgements highly provoked.

Thirdly in the Common-wealth, by the late inundations of the Prerogative Royall, which have broken out, and almo≈øt overturned all our liberties, even tho≈øe which have been be≈øt and ≈øtronge≈øt fortified, the Grand Chartea it ≈øelf. Mr. Speaker, that which hath been ≈øo oft, ≈øo ≈øolemnly confirmed in the Succe≈ø≈øion of ≈øo many Princes, ratified in his Maje≈øties name, founded by the wi≈øedome of former ages, purpo≈øely to keepe the beame over and between Soveraignty.

Even this Ma≈øter Speaker, the deare≈øt and chiefe≈øt part of our inheritance hath been infringed, broken, and ≈øet at nought in the Common-wealth by the over-potencie of ≈øome faire great ones, ≈øacred Councellors of State; by who≈øe advices it is thought the greate≈øt part of the≈øe pre≈øent di≈øtempers, under which the body of this Common-wealth at this time labours, doe deprive their originalls.

Fourthly in the Common-wealth, by the mi≈øchievous practi≈øes and policies of ≈øome ≈øubtill Projectors, and under the title of the Kings profit, and the publique good;
they have entitled them≈øelves to great and va≈øt e≈øtates, and that by the dammage of the whole Kingdome.
