They are Ma≈øter Speaker, the very moths and cankers that have fretten and eaten out all Trade and commerce, the very beauty, ≈øtrength, and health of this famous I≈øland.

In the Common-wealth, by the entertainment of Forraigners and ≈øtrangers, and that at his Maje≈øties exce≈ø≈øive charge, by which means his Maje≈øties Coffers are emptied, his Revenues ≈øhortned, and the whole Kingdome many other wayes oppre≈ø≈øed. But Ma≈øter Speaker, I ≈øhall not trouble my ≈øelfe any further in ≈øo va≈øt, ≈øo large a field; I ≈øhall now repre≈øent my owne weak apprehen≈øions for our progre≈ø≈øions in all the particulars for which we have been called, and in all humility ≈øubmit unto them.

Fir≈øt, of ≈øupply in his Maje≈øties wants, I do humbly de≈øire we may proceed there within its due time; and that with as much loyall dutie and liberality, as ever any people expre≈ø≈øed towards their Prince, I think I may ≈øay the pre≈øent affairs of the Kingdome require it.

For the reliefe of our Brethren in the Northern parts, with a ≈øen≈øe of charity, and fellow feeling of the mi≈øeries, afflictions, and lo≈ø≈øes, In the removing of the Scotti≈øh Armie with a ≈øoft and gentle hand of mediation, purification, and reconciliation, if po≈ø≈øible it may be wrought with his Maje≈øties honor, and the Kingdomes ≈øafety (if not) then to repell and repul≈øe them with ≈øtout and re≈øolute ≈øpirits, with valiant and united hearts and hands, ≈øuch as ≈øhall be≈øt ≈øuite with our duty to God, our King, our Country; ≈øuch as ≈øhall be≈øt become his honor, and ancient renowne of this Engli≈øh Nation.

In redre≈ø≈øe of our grievances in tho≈øe of the Church, which ought to have priority in our con≈øultation; as well in re≈øpect of nece≈ø≈øity, as dignity. In the≈øe Ma≈øter Speaker, I do humbly de≈øire, and doubt not but we ≈øhall
proceed with all true piety, and well grounded on each guiding Helve towards Gods Hou≈øe, and his truth. In tho≈øe of the Communalty, with a religious care of our Countries freedom, in the faithfull performance of the tru≈øt repo≈øed in us, by them that ≈øent us, in the pre≈øervation of our rights, our ancient rights, the rights of our inheritance, our liberties, our priviledges, our properties.

Yet in all, Mr. Speaker, I do humbly de≈øire we may proceed, as be≈øt ≈øuiting the matter and condition of the≈øe di≈øtempered times, or as be≈øt becoming the honour, dignity, and wi≈øedom of this ≈øo great a Court, ≈øo great Councell, with all temper, mode≈øty, and all due moderation.

div.head: SIR EDWARD HALE HIS SPEECH.
div.p:
HIs Maje≈øty hath been graciou≈øly plea≈øed to call us together again, to con≈øider freely of all matters of grievances, both of this Church and Common-wealth of England, and for to be a≈ø≈øi≈øtants in our Coun≈øels and helps unto him, about the Scotti≈øh Nation, that forceably have entred into our Kingdom, ≈øo as they may be ordered into their own Country, or cha≈øed away out of this, without any di≈øhonour to the Kings Maje≈øty and this Kingdome;
all which matters are of great importance, moment, and con≈øequence, and will crave great con≈øideration and debating, in our be≈øt wills, wi≈øedoms, and di≈øcretions, and that mu≈øt be freely to give us leave.

Fir≈øt therefore, under your favour, I do conceive it fit to make this a happy Parliament, to begin at home; For better it were the Scots come unto us, than the devill ≈øhould rai≈øe his Army, to overthrow us both in Church and Common-wealth‚ñ™

For it is too pla ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , he is come with great power, and his malice is great, and his policy ≈øtrong, put into the heads of the Papi≈øts (no mean ones) and Prelates, Schi≈ømaticks, and Athei≈øts, in ≈øeverall Bands, which hath and ≈øeeketh to prevail ≈øo much by their ≈øeverall de≈øignes. Carefully, lovingly, and dutifully mentioned, and rightly too by the Lords Petition at York, and by a Petition of the Citizens at London, and al≈øo by a Petition of worthy Gentlemens ≈øons, Apprentices thereof, ≈øo reputed to be. All which ≈øhow the whole e≈øtate of our Church and Common-wealth to be grievou≈øly di≈øea≈øed of a Pluri≈øie, and mu≈øt have a pre≈øent and good cure, or el≈øe England is overthrown, which is the mother and Almoner of the Kings well-fare, and his po≈øterity. Which di≈øea≈øe, the King not fearing nor knowing, he had ≈øome ill coun≈øell to let it run ≈øo farre in jeopardy of trouble and di≈øtre≈ø≈øe: And herein give me leave to tell you the ≈øtory of Noah, a King in the the Ark; yet after he was over-≈øhot, and taken by the Vines of his own planting, and brought him≈øelf to ≈øome di≈øhonour thereby, as ≈øome u≈øe our Engli≈øh Kings heretofore have done by their favourites, untill they ≈øaw it, and this is it that made the Papi≈øts and Prelates rejoyce in their own wi≈øedom and honour, like Chams, that ≈øaw his father ≈øo deceived; but ≈øuch de≈øerve a cur≈øe for it, both of God and man, in re≈øpect of the matters contained in the fore≈øaid Petitions of our Engli≈øh Lords, as al≈øo for that the former Parliament might have ≈øettled all things in
quiet, enriched the Kings Coffers, enabled to with≈øtand all powerfull pretences, and no doubt, but to have qualified the humour of the Scots, to all our contents. Therefore the≈øe de≈øerve the cur≈øe of Cham that were movers and ≈øtoppers, and hinderers of it.

But now our Proverb is drawn fr ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ thence, we mu≈øt make a vertue of nece≈ø≈øity, a hard ca≈øe for a good take heed and coun≈øell; For ≈øince the plot of an after intended warre, had an ill policy, that would wrong good Noah their father, and his children, in ≈øuch a manner of proceeding, and then in glory and defence of it, again≈øt this Hou≈øe of Commons, cau≈øe a booke to be publi≈øhed again≈øt our proceedings, the≈øe men which were the cau≈øe of publi≈øhing of it, are fit to publi≈øh't as Noahs cur≈øed ≈øon Cham, ≈øhamele≈ø≈øe. And we for our parts in the Hou≈øe of Commons, together with the higher Hou≈øe of Lords, I hope will not ≈øo leave them, but be rejecters of them, as good Shem and Japheth, acknowledging them to be vain members, that go about to ≈øupplant our wrong, the Vineyard, our ju≈øt King and his Kingdom.

Now therefore con≈øider the former, it ≈øhall be fit before we enter upon conference, to be ≈øtrengthened and enabled for di≈øcharge of our well meaning both to our King and Country, an≈øwerable to his late ≈øpeech, to gain and obtain his free love, con≈øent, power on the≈øe three points and cautions, handled and moved the la≈øt meeting.

list.item: Fir≈øt, free liberty of ≈øpeech.
Secondly, each ones right to our ≈øelves.
Thirdly, for reformation of Religion.

div.p: And the≈øe things granted to proceed freely without delay of time or matters, to the cure of ≈øuch deadly di≈øea≈øes if they be let alone.

Fir≈øt, I would conceive, under favour of bette judgements, to begin with Sathans Roots of evill, viz. All Papi≈øts, becau≈øe they are of the mo≈øt dangerous ≈øeed of the Serpent, to the hurt of the Church and Common-wealth herein; that we agree with a generall con≈øent of Parliament, to ≈øearch, ≈øee, and finde out all the Je≈øuits, Prie≈øts, Friars, Cappuchines, and all ≈øuch Romi≈øh factions; and by order to all the Ju≈øtices of Peace in England, to impri≈øon them, or to ≈øend them all to ≈øome out-Townes, to bani≈øh them all out of the Land ≈øpeedily, while you be in other Councell here ≈øitting, and thence to ≈øhip them away at their owne chages, and upon good bonds and ≈øecurity, that they never return into England, Scotland, or Ireland; and if they ≈øhould, both the bonds and the Lawes to be executed upon them.

And for other long Inhabitants, Papi≈øt, and Recu≈øants, ≈øuch as may ≈øeeme hone≈øt Subjects (only for Religion) the old orders and Statutes to be put in execution, without the abatement of the penalties, till they ≈øhall conforme to our Religion; and if any have wincked, or underhand compounded for the time pa≈øt, to be puni≈øhed, and made pay ≈øo much unto the Kings Cofers, as ju≈øtly due by the Statute ever ≈øince King Charles his Raigne.

The fir≈øt cour≈øe and Act of Parliament being ≈øpeedily put in execution while≈øt we ≈øit here, will not only excu≈øe the pretended charity that Papi≈øts hope for from the King and Queen, but will al≈øo manife≈øt the true piety again≈øt their here≈øies for ever, and will be a good ≈øatisfaction to the Scots, which make the≈øe one of the chiefe≈øt intents and cau≈øes of their comming into this Kingdome, which we wi≈øh they had no wor≈øe intents; and ≈øure it will be a means to try their intents, and our owne too, and then we have hope to entreat the Scots to ≈øtay our lei≈øures.

div.head: Sir John Wray his Speech touching the Canons the 15. of December, 1640.
div.p: A Man may ea≈øily ≈øee to what tend all the≈øe innovations and alterations in Doctrine and Di≈øcipline, and (without per≈øpect time) di≈øcover a farre off the active toyl≈øomene≈ø≈øe of the≈øe ≈øpirituall Ingineeres to undermine the old and true foundation of Religion, and e≈øtabli≈øh their tottering here≈øie in Rome thereof, which lea≈øt it ≈øhould not hold being built with untempered morter: You ≈øee how carefull they are by a pa≈øt oath to force mens con≈øciences not to alter their government Archiepi≈øcopall.

And Ma≈øter Speaker, the thoughts of the righteous are right, but the coun≈øells of the wicked are deceits, and nothing el≈øe in their hearts but de≈øtructions and deva≈øtations, but to the coun≈øellors of peace is joy, ≈øo long as they kept them≈øelves within the circle of the ≈øpirituall commerce, and ≈øtudied to keepe mens hearts upright to God, and his Truth; there was no ≈øuch complaining in our Streets of them, nor had we never ≈øeene ≈øo many thou≈øand hands again≈øt them as now there are come in. And no marvell though God withdrawes ≈øo many hearts and hands from them, who had turned ≈øo many out of the way of truth, (vita tuta) they have ≈øtopt up but (via devia) they have enlarged and layd open, as appears by their crooked Canons,

Ma≈øter Speaker, I ≈øhall not goe about to overthrow their government in the plurall, but to limit it, and qualifie it in ≈øome particulars. For Sir Francis Bacon long ≈øince well ob≈øerved there two things in the government of Bi≈øhops, of which he could never be ≈øatisfied, no more can I; the fir≈øt was the ≈øole exerci≈øes of the authorities.
And ≈øecondly, by the deputation of that authority.

But Ma≈øter Speaker, I ≈øhall not now di≈øpute of either, for mine own part Ma≈øter Speaker, I love ≈øome of them ≈øo well, and am ≈øo charitable to the re≈øt, that I wi≈øh rather their reformation, then their ruine.

But let me tell you withall, that if we ≈øhould finde among≈øt them any proud Becket, or Wol≈øey Prelates, who ≈øtick not to write Ego & Rex meus. Or if there ≈øhall be ≈øound any cruell Bonners, &c. ≈øuch I confe≈ø≈øe I would not ≈øpare, for they will ≈øpare none. But in the counterballance, if there may be found but one good Cranmer, or one good Latimer, or Ridley, I would e≈øteeme and prize them as ≈øuch jewels to be ≈øet in the Kings own Cabinet; for ≈øuch I am ≈øure will pray for the peace of Jeru≈øalem, and for the peace of King Charles, and his three Kingdomes, which God long pre≈øerve in concord and unity.

But Ma≈øter Speaker, we mu≈øt al≈øo be Actors in the pre≈øervations of Religions concordance, which wil never be ≈øafe, nor well at quiet, untill the≈øe heavy dro≈ø≈øie Canons with all their ba≈øe mettall be melted and di≈ø≈øolved; let us then di≈ømount them, and de≈øtroy them, which is my humble motion.

div.head: A SECOND SPEECH made by Sir John Wray, in the Commons-Hou≈øe, 24. November, 1640.
div.p: BY the report made from the Committee of Religion, you may ≈øee to what exorbitant height Poperie is growne, and yet how ≈ølowly we go on to ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe it. I feare God is di≈øplea≈øed with us, or el≈øe no di≈øa≈øter ≈øhould have prevented the ≈øealing of our Covenant, when intended, and I hope it ≈øhall be performed the next Sabbath.

Had our Fa≈øt beene accepted, and our Humiliation Cordiall, no blow ≈øhould have di≈øtracted our preparation. Ma≈øter Speaker, if we had taken the good Coun≈øell of our Teachers at the Fa≈øt, and beleeved their Report, we had done well; and by this time (no doubt) we might have found out Achan with his Wedge of Godl, and Babiloni≈øh garment. But we have ≈øpent our time onely in peeling of the Barke,
and ≈ønatching the boughes and branches of Poperie, and that will doe us no good, for they will prove, and grow thicker and harder.

What mu≈øt we do then, Ma≈øter Speaker, to pre≈øerve our Religion ≈øafe and ≈øound to us and to our Po≈øterity, that our Candle≈øticke be not removed. The only way is to fall to our worke in earne≈øt, and lay the Axe to the Root, to unloo≈øe the long and deepe fangs of Poperie and Super≈øtition, which being once done, the bodie will ≈øoone fall downe.

Let us then Ma≈øter Speaker, endeavour a through Reformation; for if it be imperfect, it will prove the ≈øeed of di≈ø≈øolution, if not di≈ø≈øolutions, which God forbid. and to prevent it, I ≈øhall humbly move that the Groves and High-places of Idolatry may be removed and put down, and then Gods wrath will be appea≈øed, and till then never.

div.head: Mr. GRIMSTONS SPEECH, In the Hou≈øe of Commons IN PARLIAMENT, CONCERNING EPISCOPACY, In Feb. 1640.
div.p:
THe≈øe two honorable Lords, Lord Digby, Lord Faulkland, that ≈øpake la≈øt, have not only prevented me in much I intended to have ≈øpoken my ≈øelf, but they have likewi≈øe taught me much I knew not before; Therefore it is not much you can expect from me: All that I ≈øhall ≈øay at this time, is rather to prepare the matter for the que≈øtion, which hath already been ≈øo learnedly debated by them, than to ≈øpeak any thing of the matter it ≈øelf. I mu≈øt confe≈ø≈øe, when I look upon the Bi≈øhops, or at lea≈øt, upon ≈øome of them, and the way of their Government, and the ≈øufferings of the people, under their Tyranny: I wonder not at all at the multitude of Petitioners and Petitions, that have this Parliament been preferred again≈øt them, and that they all cry out, Crucifie Crucifie, or that they would have been up by the roots, but it
is nece≈ø≈øary we ≈øhould di≈øtingui≈øh between the per≈øons of the Bi≈øhops, which are ≈øo obnoxious, and their Functions and Offices; for there is no more weight in the Argument, that becau≈øe the Bi≈øhops have done ami≈ø≈øe, therefore take away Epi≈øcopacy, than there is in it, becau≈øe the Judges of the Common Law are in fault, therefore take away Judges, and take away the Common Law: For my own part; I conceive it an ea≈øier matter, and ≈øafer for us, (Addere Inventis) to reform what is ami≈ø≈øe in them and their Government, then (Creare Novum) to ≈øet up a new form of Goverment, wch we have had no experience of, nor do we know how it ≈øhould ≈øuit either with the humours of the people, or with the Monarchiall Government; And it may be the new Government which is ≈øo much de≈øired, if it be brought in upon the grounds and foundations that ≈øome would have it, it will be out of our powers ever to mini≈øter it again. Whereas on the other ≈øide, the Government which is already e≈øtabli≈øhed, if the Governours exceed their bounds, they may fall into a Premunire, and other penalties which the Law hath provided in that Ca≈øe; and if that be not ≈øufficient, we have yet another hanck upon them, for our Parliaments have continually a command over them.
Then, Sir, It may be demanded of me of their being ≈øo much ami≈ø≈øe, what is that I would have done?
Truely Sir, I am of opinion, that much mu≈øt be done, or el≈øe we had as good do nothing.

Therefore I come to the particulars, Church Government may be compared to a Ca≈øtle, let a Ca≈øtle be never ≈øo ≈øtrong, once in four-≈øcore yeers (for ≈øo long it is ≈øince the fir≈øt reformation) it may need repair, and it is not the Ca≈øtle alone, I mean the Government, that needs repair, but likewi≈øe the Governours them≈øelves, who mo≈øt wickedly and trayterou≈øly have turned their Canons upon us, which ≈øhould have been u≈øed for our defence.

In the fir≈øt place therefore I conceive it not onely convenient,
but of ab≈øolute nece≈ø≈øity, and the payring of their excre≈øcences, I mean their temporall Juri≈ødiction: I mu≈øt confe≈ø≈øe, I know not to what purpo≈øe they ≈øhould ≈øit upon our Benches at our Se≈ø≈øions of the Peace, and Goal-Deliveries, or in the Starre-Chamber, for by wofull experience, we finde that their Judgements are guided there more by their boundle≈ø≈øe wills, and fiery tran≈øported pa≈ø≈øions, than by rea≈øon, and the rule of Law, which ought to have been their director. I conceive that of le≈ø≈øe u≈øe their ≈øitting at the Councell boord, to be there at the Helm to guide and ≈øteer the temporall affairs of the Common-wealth, certainly that is not the Plough they ought to follow, and by the neglecting of it, that is the rea≈øon that ≈øo many briers, brambles, and ≈øtinking weeds, are ≈øprung up in Gods Hou≈øe, the Church, to the great de≈øtruction of all his Maje≈øties Kingdoms here at home, and the great wonder and amazement of all the reformed Churches abroad.

And I conceive it of the lea≈øt u≈øe of all their ≈øitting in Parliaments, as powers to give their voices in the making of Laws; and yet I would not utterly exclude them. For I conceive it might be convenient that all, or at lea≈øt, ≈øome of them might alway be pre≈øent there as A≈ø≈øi≈øtants, to give their advice in Spirituall matters when they are thereunto required by the Lords, as the Ju≈øtices do in Temporall.

In the next place I conceive it of, as ab≈øolute nece≈ø≈øity, the robbing of the Juri≈ødiction of the high Commi≈ø≈øion Court, or at lea≈øt, to limit and bound it, that it may (quadrare) with the great Charter of our liberties, and the Laws of this Kingdom.

This Court hath for many yeers together, ridden upon the back of the common Law Courts, which ought to have been ≈øub≈øervient to them. Each river mu≈øt be kept within its, own bounds, and it is unpo≈ø≈øible to have two Suns ≈øhine together in one Firmament.

They have likewi≈øe many ≈øuperfluous Courts, which I
conceive might very well be ≈øpared, as their Officiall Courts, and Commi≈ø≈øary Courts. Sir, they are no better than cozening Lotteries, where the Kings Subjects are detained of their moneyes, and where their Judges and inferiour Officers do, like Phy≈øitians that alway cure them≈øelves, though they de≈øtroy their patients. I confe≈ø≈øe, I could willingly give my con≈øent that they ≈øhould keep their Chancellors Court, and an Archdeacon Court, if ≈øuch limits and bounds were put upon them, as by the wi≈øedom of this Hou≈øe may ea≈øily be done.

The Chancellor is (cu≈øtos con≈øciencie) the Keeper of the Bi≈øhops con≈øcience, and the Archdeacon is (oculus Epi≈øc.) the Bi≈øhops eye; And as I would not take away their con≈øciences or their eyes, ≈øo I would not have them like Briarius have their finger in every bu≈øine≈ø≈øe. This Sir, I have ≈øhortly pre≈øented you with my opinion, that is, that I am not willing it that ≈øhould be referred to, or committed upon the point of ≈øubver≈øion, but I am willing it ≈øhould be referred upon the point of reformation. And if the ≈øence of the Hou≈øe ≈øhall run that way, I doubt not but at the Commitree I ≈øhall make it manife≈øt, that my heart ≈øtands affected with as much zeal, for the having a reformation, as any man that ≈øits within the≈øe walls.

div.head: DENSELL HOLLIS E≈øquior, His ≈øpeech at the deliverie of the Prote≈øtation to the LORDS, May the fourth, 1641.
div.p: THe Kuights, Citizens and Burge≈ø≈øes of the Hou≈øe of Commons, having taken into their con≈øideration the pre≈øent e≈øtate and condition of this Kingdome, they finde it ≈øurrounded with variety of pernicious dangers, and de≈øtructive de≈øignes, practi≈øes and plots, again≈øt the well being of it, and ≈øome of tho≈øe de≈øignes, hatched within our owne bowells, and Viper-like working our own de≈øtruction.

They finde Je≈øuits, and Prie≈øts con≈øpiring with ill mini≈øters of State, to de≈øtroy our Religion; they finde ill mini≈øters conioyn'd together to ≈øubvert the Lawes and liberties. They finde ob≈øtructions of Ju≈øtice, which is the life-bloud of every State, and having a free pa≈ø≈øage from the Soveraign power, where it is as primarily ≈øeated as the life-bloud in the heart, and there derived from the ≈øeverall Judicatories, or through ≈øo many veins, into all the parts of this great collective Bodie, doth give warmth
and motion, to every part and member, which is nouri≈øhed and inlivened by it. But being once precluded ≈øtoppd, and reared as the particular mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øity faint and langui≈øh, ≈øo mu≈øt the whole frame of government be di≈ø≈øolved.

And con≈øequently Soveraignty it ≈øelfe (which as the heart in the body, is primum movens, & ultimum moriens, mu≈øt dye and peri≈øh in the generall di≈ø≈øolution, and all things as in the beginning in antiquum Chaos.

p.hi: My Lords,

div.p: They finde the property of the Subject invaded and violated, his e≈øtate rent from him by illegall taxations, Monopolies and proiects almo≈øt upon every thing that is for the u≈øe of man, not only upon ≈øuperfluities, but nece≈ø≈øaries? and that enrich the Vermine and Caterpillers of the Land, and impoveri≈øhing good Subiects, to take the meat from the Children, and give it to Dogs.
My Lords, if the Commons finde the≈øe things, they conceive they mu≈øt needs be ill coun≈øels, that have brought us into this condition.

The≈øe Coun≈øels have put all into a combu≈øtion, have di≈øcouraged the hearts of all true Engli≈øh men, and brought two Armies into our bowels, which is the Unlture upon Prometheus, eats through, and ≈øucks and gnaws our very hearts out.

p.hi: Hic Dolor, ≈øed ubi Medicina?

div.p: Heretofore Parliaments were the Catholicall, the balm of Gilead, which healed our wounds, re≈øtored our ≈øpirits, and made up the breaches of the Land.

But of late years they have been like the Fig-tree in the Go≈øpel, without effecacie, without fruit, onley de≈øtructive to their particular members, who di≈øcharged their duties and con≈øciences no way beneficiall to the Common-welth. Nohis exitiale, nec Reipublico profuturum. As he ≈øaith in Tacitus, being taken away ≈øtill as Elias was with a whirle-wind, never comming to any maturity, or
to their naturall end, whereas they ≈øhould be like the ble≈ø≈øed old ma ‚Ä¢ , who dieth, plenus dier ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , in a full ago, after he had fought a good fight, and overcom ‚Ä¢ all his enemies, Or as the ≈øh ‚Ä¢ cke of wheat, w ‚Ä¢ ich commeth in due ≈øea≈øon to fill our Garnaries with corn, uphold our lives with the ≈øtaffe of bread; for Parliaments are our panis quotidianus, our true bread, all other waies are but Quelkachees which yeeld no true nouri≈øhment, bread, nor good blood.

The very Parliament which hath ≈øate ≈øo long, hath but beat the Ayre, and ≈øtrive again≈øt the ≈øtreame, I may truly ≈øay the wind and tyde hath ≈øtill been again≈øt us. The ≈øame ill coun≈øell which fir≈øt rai≈øed the ≈øtorm, and almo≈øt ≈øhipwrackt the Common-wealth, they ≈øtill continue, they blow ≈øtrong like the Ea≈øt wind that brought the Locu≈øts over their Coun≈øells, cro≈ø≈øe our de≈øignes, ca≈øt difficulties in our way, hinder our proceedi ‚Ä¢ gs, and make all that we do to be fruitle≈ø≈øe and ineffectuall: They make us not ma≈øters of our bu≈øines, and ≈øo not ma≈øters of many, which have been the great bu≈øines of this Parliament, that we might pay the Armies, according to our promi≈øes and engagements.
For my Lords, our not effecting of the good things which we have undertaken for the good of the Church and of the Common-wealth, hath wounded our Reputation, and taken off from our credit.
Is it not time then, my Lords, that we ≈øhould unite, and concentrate our ≈øelves, in regard of this Antepari≈øia≈øis, of hurtfull and malicious intentions and practi≈øes again≈øt us.

My Lords, it is mo≈øt agreeable to nature, and I am ≈øure mo≈øt agreeable to rea≈øon, in re≈øpect of the pre≈øent coniuncture of our affairs, for one main Engine by which our enemies work our mi≈øchief, is by infu≈øing an opinion and b ‚Ä¢ lei ‚Ä¢ into the world, that we are not united among our ≈øelves. But like Samp≈øons Foxes, we draw ≈øeverall wayes, and tend to our ≈øeverall ends.

To defeat the Coun≈øels of the≈øe Achitophels which would involve us. Our Religion, our being, our Lawes, our liberties, all that can be neere and deere unto an hene≈øt ≈øoule, in one univer≈øall and generall de≈øolation, to defeat I ≈øay, the Coun≈øels of evill Achitophels, the Knights, Citizens and Burge≈ø≈øes of the Hou≈øe of Commons (knowing them≈øelves to be ≈øpecially entru≈øted with the pre≈øervation of the whole, and in their Con≈øcience are per≈øwaded that the dangers are ≈øo eminent, as they will admit of no delay) have thought fit to declare their united affections, by entring into an a≈ø≈øo≈øciation among≈øt them≈øelves, and by making a ≈øolemne Prote≈øtation and vow unto their God, that they will unanimou≈øly endeavour to oppo≈øe and prevent the Coun≈øels and Coun≈øellours which have brought upon us all the≈øe mi≈øeries, and the fears of greater, to prevent the ends, and bring the Authors of them to condigne puni≈øhment, and thereby di≈øcharge them≈øelves better before God and man.

The Prote≈øtation your Lord≈øhips ≈øhall have read unto you, together with ground and rea≈øons which have induced the Hou≈øe of Commons to make it, which are prefixed before it by way of Preamble. Then the Prote≈øtation was read by Ma≈øter Maynard.

div.head: Die Mercurii 5 May, 1641.
div.p: IT is this day ordered by the Hou≈øe of Commons now a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament, that the Preamble, togtheer with the Prote≈øtation which the Members of this Hou≈øe made the third of May, ≈øhall be forthwith Printed, and the Copies printed, brought to the Cleark of the ≈øaid Hou≈øe, to Atte≈øt under his hand, to the end that the Knights, Citizens, and Burge≈ø≈øes may ≈øend them down to the Sheriffes, and Ju≈øtices of Peace of the ≈øeverall Shires, and to the Citizens and Burge≈ø≈øes of the ≈øeverall Cities, Boroughes, and Cinque Ports re≈øpectively. And the Knights, Citizens, and Burge≈ø≈øes are to intimate unto the Shires, Cities, and Boroughes, and Cinque Ports, with what willingne≈ø≈øe all the Members of this Hou≈øe made this Prote≈øtation. And further to ≈øignifie, that as they ju≈øtifie the taking of it in them≈øelves, ≈øo the cannot but approve it in all ≈øuch as ≈øhall take it.

div.head: A Preamble with the Prote≈øtation made by the whole Hou≈øe of Commons the third of May, 1641. and a≈ø≈øented unto by the Lords of the upper Hou≈øe the fourth of May la≈øt pa≈øt.
div.p:
WE the Knights, Citizens, and Burge≈ø≈øes of the Commons Hou≈øe in Parliament, finding to the griefe of our hearts, that the de≈øignes of the Prie≈øts and Je≈øuits, and other adherents to the See of Rome, have of
late more boldly and frequently put in practice then formerly, to the undermining and danger of the Ruine of the true reformed Religion, in his Maje≈øties Dominions e≈øtabli≈øhed, and finding al≈øo that there hath bin, and having cau≈øe to ≈øu≈øpect there ≈øtill are, even during the ≈øitting in Parliament, endeavours to ≈øubvert the fundamentall Lawes of England, and Ireland, and to introduce the exerci≈øe of an Arbitrary and tyrannicall government, by mo≈øt pernicious and wicked coun≈øells, practi≈øes, plots, and con≈øpiracies, and that the long intermi≈øion, and unhappier breach of Parliaments, hath occa≈øioned many illegall Taxations; whereupon the Subjects have beene pro≈øecuted and grieved, and that divers Innovations and Super≈øtitions have been brought into the Church, Multitudes driven out of his Maie≈øties Dominions, Jealou≈øies rai≈øed and Fomented between the King, and his people, a Popi≈øh Armie leavied in Ireland, and two Armies brought into the bowels of this Kingdome, to the hazard of his Maje≈øties Royall Per≈øon, the Con≈øumption of the Revenue of the Crown, and the trea≈øure of this Realme. And la≈øtly, finding the great cau≈øes of Jealou≈øie, endeavours have beene and are u≈øed to bring the Engli≈øh Armie into mi≈ø-under≈øtanding of this Parliament; thereby to encline that Armie by force, to bring to pa≈ø≈øe tho≈øe wicked coun≈øells, have therefore thought good to ioyn our ≈øelves in a Declaration of our united affections, and re≈øolutions, and to make this en≈øuing Prote≈øtation.

div.head: The Prote≈øtation.
div.p: I A.B. Do in the pre≈øence of Almighty God, promi≈øe, vow, and prote≈øt to maintain and defend, as farre as lawfully I may, with my life, power, and e≈øtate, the true Reformed Prote≈øtant Religion, expre≈ø≈øed in the Doctrine of the Church of England, again≈øt all popery and popi≈øh Innovation within this Realm, contrary to the ≈øaid Doctrine, and according to the duty of my Allegiance, I will maintain and defend his Maje≈øties Royall Per≈øon, Honor, and E≈øtate.

As al≈øo the power and priviledge of Parliaments, the lawfull Rights and Liberties of the Subjects. And every per≈øon that ≈øhall make this Prote≈øtation, in what≈øoever he ≈øhall do in the lawfull pur≈øuance of the ≈øame, and to my power, as farre as lawfully I may, I will oppo≈øe, and by all good wayes and means endeavour to bring condigne puni≈øhment on all ≈øuch as ≈øhall by force, practice, coun≈øels, plots, con≈øpiraces, or otherwi≈øe, do any thing to the contrary in this pre≈øent prote≈øtation contained, and further, that I ≈øhall in all Ju≈øt and Honorable wayes, endeavour to pre≈øerve the union and peace betwixt the three Kingdoms of England, Scotland, and Ireland. And neither for hope, fear, or any other re≈øpects, ≈øhall relinqui≈øh this promi≈øe, vow, and Prote≈øtation.

div.head: The Bill of Attainder, that pa≈ø≈øed again≈øt Thomas, Earl of STAFFORD.
div.p: WHereas the Knights, Citizens, and Burge≈ø≈øes of the Hou≈øe of Commons, in this pre≈øent Parliament a≈ø≈øembled, have, in the name of them≈øelves, and of all the Commons of England, impeached Thomas, Earl of Strafford of high Trea≈øon, for endeavouring to ≈øubvert the Ancient and Fundamentall Laws and Government of his Maje≈øties Realms of England, and Ireland, and to introduce an Arbitrary and Tyrannicall Government again≈øt Law in the ≈øaid Kingdoms; and for exerci≈øing a Tyrannous and exorbitant power, over and again≈øt the Laws of the ≈øaid Kingdoms, over the Liberties, E≈øtates, and Lives of his Maje≈øties Subjects; and likewi≈øe for having by his own authority, commanded the laying and a≈ø≈øei≈øing of ≈øouldiers upon his Maje≈øties Subjects in Ireland, again≈øt their con≈øents, to compell them to obey his unlawfull commands and orders made upon pap ‚Ä¢ r Petitions, in cau≈øes between party and party, which accordingly was executed upon divers of his Maje≈øties Subjects in a Warlike manner, within the ≈øaid Realm of Ireland; and in ≈øo doing, did levie Warre again≈øt the Kings Maje≈øty and his liege people in that Kingdome; And al≈øo for that he upon the unhappy Di≈ø≈øolution of the la≈øt Parliament, did ≈ølander the Hou≈øe of Commons to his Maje≈øty, and did coun≈øell and advi≈øe his Maje≈øty, that he was loo≈øe and ab≈øolved from the rules of Government, and that he had an Army in Ireland, by which he might reduce this Kingdom; for which he de≈øerves to undergo the pains and forfeitures of high Trea≈øon.

And the ≈øaid Earl hath been al≈øo an Incendiary of the
Warres between the two Kingdoms of England and Scotland: all which offences have been ≈øufficiently proved again≈øt the ≈øaid Earl upon his impeachment.

Be it therefore enacted by the Kings mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty, and by the Lords and Commons in this pre≈øent Parliament a≈ø≈øembled, and by authority of the ≈øame, That the ≈øaid Earl of Strafford for the haynous crimes and offences afore≈øaid, ≈øtand, and be adjudged and attainted of high Trea≈øon, and ≈øhall ≈øuffer ≈øuch pain of death, and incurre the forfeitures of his Goods, and Chattels, Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments of any e≈øtate of Free-hold or Inheritance in the ≈øaid Kingdoms of England and Ireland, which the ≈øaid Earl, or any other to his u≈øe, or in tru≈øt for him, have or had the day of the fir≈øt ≈øitting of this pre≈øent Parliament, or at any time ≈øince.

Provided that no Judge or Judges, Ju≈øtice or Iu≈øtices what≈øoever, ≈øhall adiudge or interpret any Act or thing to be Trea≈øon, nor in any other manner than he or they ≈øhould or ought to have done before the making of this Act, and as if this Act had never been had or made. Saving alwayes unto all and ≈øingular per≈øons and bodies, politique and corporall, their Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, others than the ≈øaid Earl and his heirs, and ≈øuch as claim by, from, or under him, all ≈øuch right, title, and intere≈øt, of, in, and to all and ≈øingular, ≈øuch of the ≈øaid Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments, as he, they, or any of them, had before the fir≈øt day of this pre≈øent Parliament, any thing herein contained to the contrary notwith≈øtanding.

Provided that the pa≈ø≈øing of this pre≈øent Act, and his Maie≈øties a≈ø≈øent thereunto, ≈øhall not be any determination of this pre≈øent Se≈ø≈øions of Parliament, but that this pre≈øent Se≈ø≈øions of Parliament and all Bills and matters what≈øoever depending in Parliament, and not fully enacted or determined. And all Statutes and Acts of Parliament, wch have their continuance untill the end of this pre≈øent Se≈ø≈øion of Parliament, ≈øhall remain, continue, and be in full force, as if this Act had not been.

div.head: The fir≈øt Speech concerning the the right of Bi≈øhops to ≈øit in Parliament, May 21. 1641.
div.p: I Shall take the boldne≈ø≈øe to ≈øpeak a word or two upon this ≈øubject, fir≈øt as it is in it ≈øelf, then as it is in the con≈øequence: For the former I think he is a great ≈øtranger in Antiquity, that is not well acquainted with that of their ≈øitting here, they have done thus and in this manner, almo≈øt ≈øince the conque≈øt, and by the ≈øame power and the ≈øame right the other Peers did, and your Lord≈øhips now do, and to be put from this their due, ≈øo much their due, by ≈øo many hundred yeers ≈øtrengthned and confirmed, and that without any offence, nay pretence of any, ≈øeems to me to be very ≈øevere; if it be jus, I dare boldly ≈øay it is ≈øummum. That this hinders their Ecclefia≈øticall vocation, an argument I heare much of, hath in my apprehen≈øion more of ≈øhadow, then in ≈øub≈øtance in it: if this be a rea≈øon, ≈øure I am it might have been one ≈øix hundred yeers ago.

A Bi≈øhop, my Lords, is not ≈øo circum≈øcribed within the circumference of his Dioce≈ø≈øe, that his ≈øometimes ab≈øence can be termed, not in the mo≈øt ≈øtrict ≈øen≈øe a neglect or hindrance of his duty, no more than that of a Zievetenant from his Count y, they both have their ≈øubordinate Mini≈øters, upon which their influences fall, though the di≈øtance be remote.

Be≈øides my Lords, the le≈ø≈øer mu≈øt yeeld to the greater
good, to make whole≈øome and good Lawes for the happy and well regulating of the Church and Common-wealth, is certainly more advantagious to both, then the want of the per≈øonall execution of their office, and that but once in three years, and then peradventure but a moneth or two, can be prejudiciall to either. I will go no further to this, which experience hath done ≈øo fully, ≈øo demon≈øtratively.

And now my Lords, by your Lord≈øhips good leave, I ≈øhall ≈øpeak to the con≈øequence, as it reflects both on your Lord≈øhips, and my Lords the Bi≈øhops. Dangers and inconveniencies are ever be≈øt prevented √® longinquo; this pre≈øident comes neer to your Lord≈øhips, and ≈øuch a one, mutato nomine de vobis. Pretences are never wanting, nay, ≈øometimes the greate≈øt evils appeare in the mo≈øt faire and ≈øpecious out-≈øides, witne≈ø≈øe the Shipmony, the mo≈øt abominable, the mo≈øt illegall thing that ever was, and yet this was painted over with colour of the Law; what Bench is ≈øecure, if to alleage be to convine, and which of your Lord≈øhips can ≈øay then he ≈øhall continue a member of this Hou≈øe, when at one blow twenty ≈øix are cut off. It then behoves the Neighbour to look about him, cum proximus ardet Vcalegon.

And for the Bi≈øhops, my Lords, in what condition will you leave them? The Hou≈øe of Commons repre≈øents the meane≈øt per≈øon, ≈øo did the Ma≈øter his ≈ølave, but they have none to do ≈øo much for them, and what ju≈øtice can tie them to the ob≈øervation of tho≈øe Lawes, to who≈øe con≈øtitution they give no con≈øent, the wi≈ødome of former times, gave proxies unto this Hou≈øe meerly upon this ground, that every one might have a hand in the making of that, which he had an obligation to obey: This Hou≈øe could not repre≈øent, therefore proxies in roome of per≈øons were mo≈øt ju≈øtly allowed.

And now my Lords, before I conclude, I be≈øeech your Lord≈øhips to ca≈øt your eyes upon the Church, which I
know is mo≈øt dear and tender to your Lord≈øhips, you will ≈øee her ≈øuffer in her principall members, and deprived of that honor which here and throughout all the Chri≈øtian World, ever ≈øince Chri≈øtianity ≈øhe con≈øtantly hath enjoyed; for what Nation or Kingdome is there, in who≈øe great and publike a≈ø≈øemblies, and that from her beginning, ≈øhe had not ≈øome of hers if I may not ≈øay as e≈ø≈øentiall; I am ≈øure I may ≈øay as integrall parts thereof; and truly my Lords, Chri≈øtianity cannot alone boa≈øt of this, or challenge it only as hers, even Heatheni≈øme claims an equall ≈øhare.
I never read of any of them, Civill, or Barbarous, that gave not thus much to their Religion, ≈øo that it ≈øeems to me to have no other originall, to flow from no other ≈øpring than Nature it ≈øelfe.

But I have done, and will trouble your Lord≈øhips no longer, how it may ≈øtand with honor and ju≈øtice of this Hou≈øe to pa≈ø≈øe this Bill, I mo≈øt humbly ≈øubmit unto your Lord≈øhips, the mo≈øt proper and only Juges of them both.

div.head: The ≈øecond Speech about the lawfulne≈ø≈øe and convenieny of their intermedling in Temorall Affaires.
div.p:
I Shall not ≈øpeake to the Preamble of the Bill, that Bi≈øhops, and Clergie men ought not to intermeddle in temporall offairs. For, truly my Lords, I cannot bring it under any re≈øpect to be ≈øpoken of. Ought is a word of relation, and mu≈øt either refer to humane or divine Law
to prove the lawfulne≈ø≈øe of their intermedling by the former, would be to no more purpo≈øe, than to labour to convince that by rea≈øon, which is evident to ≈øen≈øe. It is by all acknowledged. The unlawfulne≈ø≈øe by the latter, the bill by no means admits of, for, it excepts Univer≈øities and ≈øuch per≈øons as ≈øhall have honour de≈øcend upon them. And your Lord≈øhips know, that circum≈øtance and chance alter not the nature and e≈ø≈øence of a thing, nor can except any particular from an univer≈øall propo≈øition by God him≈øelf delivered. I will therefore take the≈øe two as granted, fir≈øt that they ought by our Law to intermeddle in temporall affairs, ≈øecondly, that from doing ≈øo they are not inhibited by the Law of God, it leaves it at lea≈øt as a thing indifferent. And now my Lords, to apply my ≈øelf to the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of the day, I ≈øhall con≈øider the conveniency, and that in the ≈øeverall habitudes thereof, but, very briefly; fir≈øt, in that which it hath to them meerly as men; qua tales, then as parts of the Common-wealth, Thirdly, from the b ‚Ä¢ ≈øt manner of con≈øtituting laws, and la≈øtly, from the practice of all times both Chri≈øtian and Heathen.

Homo ≈øum nihil humanum √† me alienum puto, was indeed the ≈øaying of the Comedian, but it might well have becom'd the mouth of the greate≈øt Philo≈øopher. We allow to ≈øen≈øe all the works and operations of ≈øen≈øe, and ≈øhall we re≈øtrain rea≈øon? mu≈øt onely man be hindered from his proper actions? They are mo≈øt fit to do rea≈øonable things that are mo≈øt rea≈øonable. For, Science commonly is accompanied with con≈øcience; So is not ignorance: they ≈øeldome or never meet. And why ≈øhould we take that capacity from them, which God and nature have ≈øo liberally be≈øtowed?

My Lords, the politike body of the Common-wealth is analogicall to the body naturall: every member in that contributes ≈øomething to the contribution of the whole, the ≈øuperfluity or defect which hinders the performance of that duty, your Lord≈øhips know what the Philo≈øopher calls „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , Natures ≈øin. And truely my
Lords, to be part of the other body, and do nothing beneficiall thereunto, cannot fall under a milder term. The common-wealth ≈øub≈øi≈øts by laws and their execution: and they that have neither head in the making, nor hand in the executing of them, conferre not any thing to the being or well being thereof. And can ≈øuch be called members, unle≈ø≈øe mo≈øt unprofitable ones? onely fruges con≈øumere nati.

Me thinks it ≈øprings from nature it ≈øelf, or the very depths of Ju≈øtice, that none ≈øhould be tied by other Laws than him≈øelf makes, for, what more naturall or ju≈øt, than to be bound onely by his own con≈øent? to be ruled by anothers will, is meerly tyrannicall. Nature there ≈øuffers violence, and man degenerates into bea≈øt. The mo≈øt flouri≈øhing E≈øtates were ever governed by Laws of an univer≈øall con≈øtitution; witne≈ø≈øe this our Kingdom, witne≈ø≈øe Senatus populu≈øque Romanus, the mo≈øt glorious Common-wealth that ever was, and tho≈øe many others in Greece, and el≈øewhere, of eternall memory.

Some things, my Lords, are ≈øo evident in them≈øelves, that they are difficult in their proofs. Among≈øt them I reckon this inconveniency I have ≈øpoken of: I will therefore u≈øe but a word or two more in this way. The long experience that all Chri≈øtendom hath had hereof for the≈øe 1300 yeers, is certainly, argumentum ad bominem. Nay my Lords I will go further (for the ≈øame rea≈øon runs thorow all Religions) never was there any Nation that employed not their religious men in the greate≈øt affairs. But to come to the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe that lies now before your Lord≈øhips, Bi≈øhops have voted here ever ≈øince Parliaments began, and long before were imployed in the publike. The good they have done, your Lord≈øhips all well know, and at this day enjoy for this I hope ye will not put them out, nor for the evill they may do, wch yet your Lord≈øhips do not know, and I am confident never ≈øhal ≈øuffer. A po≈øition ought not to be de≈øtroyed by a ≈øuppo≈øition, & √†po≈ø≈øe ad
e≈ø≈øe non valet con≈øequentia. My Lords, I have done with proving of this po≈øitively, I ≈øhall now by your good favours do it negatively in an≈øwering ≈øome inconveniences that may ≈øeem to ari≈øe.

Object. 1 For the Text, No man that warres, intangles him≈øelf with the affairs of this life; which is the full ≈øen≈øe of the word both in Greek and Latine, it makes not at all again≈øt them, except to intermeddle and intangle be tearms equivalent. Be≈øides my Lords, though this was directed to a Church-man, yet it is of a generall nature, and reaches to all, Clergy and Laity, as the mo≈øt learned and be≈øt expo≈øitors unanimou≈øly do agree. To end this, Argumentum ≈øymbolicum non e≈øt argumentativum.

Object. 2 It may be ≈øaid that it is incon≈øi≈øtent with a ≈øpirituall vocation; truely, my Lords, Grace and Nature are in ≈øome re≈øpects incompo≈ø≈øible, but in ≈øome others mo≈øt harmoniou≈øly agree, it perfects nature, and rai≈øes it to a heighth above the common altitude, and makes it mo≈øt fit for tho≈øe great works of God him≈øelf, to make Laws, to do Iu≈øtice. There is then no incon≈øi≈øtency between them≈øelves, it mu≈øt ari≈øe out of Scripture, I am confident it doth not formally out of any place there, nor did I ever meet with any learned Writer of the≈øe or other times, that ≈øo expounded any Text.

Object. 3 But though in ≈øtrict tearms this be not incon≈øi≈øtent, yet it may peradventure hinder the duty of their other calling. My Lords, there is not any that ≈øits here, more for preaching than I am. I know it is the ordinary means to ≈øalvation, yet, I likewi≈øe know, there is not that full nece≈ø≈øity of it as was in the primitive times. God defend that 1600 yeers acquaintance ≈øhould make the Go≈øpel of Chri≈øt no better known unto us. Neither, my Lords, doth their office meerly and wholly con≈øi≈øt in preaching, but partly in that, partly in praying, and admini≈øtring the ble≈ø≈øed Sacraments, in a godly and exemplary life, in whol≈øome
admonitions, in exhortations to vertue, dehortations from vice, and partly in ea≈øing the burdened con≈øcience. The≈øe, my Lords, compleat the office of a Churchman. Nor are they altogether tied to time or place, though I confe≈ø≈øe they are mo≈øt properly exerci≈øed within their own verge, except upon good occa≈øion, nor then the omi≈ø≈øion of ≈øome can be tearmed the breach of them all. I mu≈øt adde one more, an e≈ø≈øentiall one, the very form of Epi≈øcopacy, that di≈øtingui≈øheth it from the inferiour Mini≈øtry, the orderly and good government of the Church, and how many of the≈øe, I am ≈øure, not the la≈øt, my Lords, is interrupted by their ≈øitting here, once in 3 yeers, and then peradventure but a very ≈øhort time: and can there be a greater occa≈øion than the common good of the Church and State? I will tell your Lord≈øhips what the great and good Emperour Con≈øtantine did, in his expedition again≈øt the Per≈øians, he had his Bi≈øhops with him whom he con≈øulted with about his military affairs, as Eu≈øebius has it in his life, lib. 4. c. 56.

Object. 4 Reward and puni≈øhment are the great negotiators in all worldly bu≈øine≈ø≈øes; the≈øe may be ≈øaid to make the Bi≈øhops ≈øwim again≈øt the ≈øtream of their con≈øciences, and may not the ≈øame be ≈øaid of the Laity? Have the≈øe no operations, but onely upon them? Has the King neither frown, honour, nor offices, but onely for Bi≈øhops? Is there is nothing that an≈øwers their tran≈ølations? Indeed, my Lords, I mu≈øt needs ≈øay that in charity, it is a ≈øuppo≈øition not to be ≈øuppo≈øed; no, nor in rea≈øon, that they will go again≈øt the light of their under≈øtanding. The holine≈ø≈øe of their calling, their knowledge, their freedoms from pa≈ø≈øions and affections to which youth is very obnoxious, their vicinity to the gates of death, which, though not ≈øhut to any, yet alwayes ≈øtand wide open to old age: the≈øe, my Lords, will ≈øurely make them ≈øteer aright.

But, of matter of fact there is no di≈øputation, ≈øome of them have done ill, Crimine ab uno di≈øce omnes, is a poeticall, not a logicall argument. Some of the Judges have done ≈øo, ≈øome of the Magi≈øtrates and Officers; and ≈øhall there be therefore neither Iudge, Magi≈øtrate nor Officer more? A per≈øonall crime goes not beyond the per≈øon that commits it, nor can anothers fault be mine offence. If they have contracted any filth or corruption through their own, or the vice of the times, clean≈øe and purge them thorowly. But ≈øtill remember the great difference between reformation and extirpation. And he plea≈øed to think of your Triennall Bill which will ≈øave you this labour for the time to come; fear of puni≈øhment will keep them in order, if they ≈øhould not them≈øelves through the love of vertue. I have now, my Lords, according to my poor ability, both ≈øhewed the conveniences, and an≈øwered tho≈øe inconveniences that ≈øeem to make again≈øt them. I ≈øhould now propo≈øe tho≈øe that make for them. As their falling into a condition wor≈øe than ≈ølaves, not repre≈øented by any; and then the dangers and inconveniences that may happen to your Lord≈øhips; but I haue done this heretofore, and will not offer your Lord≈øhips Grambenbis coctam.

div.head: A Speech in Parliament delivered by Mr. PEARD, again≈øt the Oath Ex Officio. 1640.
div.p:
I A≈ø≈øure my ≈øelfe, we are here met to di≈øcover, and reforme (as much as in us lyeth) all abu≈øes of the Church and Common-wealth; many and great ones have been ≈øpoken again≈øt, ≈øome contrary to all Law, and ≈øome e≈øtabli≈øhed by new Lawes, contrary to all Law: The Wolfe having put on the Lions skinne, and rapine, pre≈øuming to pa≈ø≈øe undi≈øcovered under the robe of Ju≈øtice. But I ≈øhall not neede to light a candle to ≈øearch out that, which already the ≈øunne hath made manife≈øt; That which I ≈øhall ≈øpeak, hath not been ≈øpoken, but if I ≈øhall ≈øpeak that. that ≈øhall ≈øeeme to be again≈øt Law, I humbly crave the pardon of this Hou≈øe, ≈øince if it be law, it is ≈øummum jus, Law without con≈øcience: That which I ≈øhall ≈øpeake again≈øt, is the Oath Ex Officio. It is acknowledged by them≈øelves, that Admini≈øter this Oath that it is unju≈øtly done to tender it to any man, unle≈ø≈øe there be a publique Fame, or particular Pre≈øentment or Articles te≈øtified again≈øt him: I make no que≈øtion, but the practice of this confe≈øt Injunction wil be found coÃÑmon among≈øt them, And I hope it ≈øhalbe ≈øeverely cen≈øured, ≈øince unju≈øt proceedings upon unju≈øt grounds, are double Inju≈øtice; I ≈øhall therefore leave that as a plaine ca≈øe, and examine their be≈øt grounds; Fir≈øt, Fame (they ≈øay) is a ju≈øt cau≈øe for them to take Cognizance of a matter to proceed again≈øt it; Fame we
know may ari≈øe upon very ≈ømall and groundle≈ø≈øe ≈øu≈øpitions, by ≈øecret whi≈øperings, creeping at fir≈øt, but quickly gets it wings; And as the Po√´t ≈øaith, Cre≈øeit eundo.

This is the manner of all Fame; if this be Fame, their Court ≈øhall never want worke, as long as a Promooter hath an ill tongue, or a knave can ≈ølander an hone≈øt man; Therefore I thinke Fame no good ground to proceed upon.
If Fame be ju≈øt, what mo≈øt men ≈øpeake, certainly ≈øome men will te≈øtifie; No man will te≈øtifie it is fal≈øe.

Let no accu≈øation then ≈øtand, but out of the mouthes of two or three witne≈ø≈øes, of Pre≈øentments, are a ju≈øt ground of proceedings in all Courts, and upon all cau≈øes: But neither witne≈ø≈øes nor pre≈øentments are or can be a ju≈øt ground of the Oath Ex officio; For if the partie accu≈øed be examined no further then is te≈øtified, then the Oath Ex Officio is ≈øuperfluous.
If he be examined further, or upon other matters then is te≈øtified, then a man is made to betray him≈øelfe, which is unju≈øt.
Mr. Speaker, ≈øuch is the Mercy of the Common Law, that Murderers and Poy≈øoners are not examined upon the rack, but the Civill law upon every occa≈øion racketh the Con≈øcience.
The≈øe are the Lyme-twigs which were ≈øet to catch the poore Martyrs in Queene Maries daies; And in our daies, I dare beleeve it will appeare that ≈øome good men are fallen into this ≈ønare.

Mr. Speaker, If the foundations faile, what ≈øhall the buildings doe? If the conformity of good men ≈øhall undoe them, who ≈øhall ≈øtand? I de≈øire nothing but that evill men may ≈øuffer, I de≈øire the Law may puni≈øh, not make offenders, I de≈øire that our words and actions at this time, and at other times, may be ≈øubject to the Law, I would have thought free.

div.head: Mr. Speakers Letter to Sir Jacob A≈øhley.
div.p: WEE have had cau≈øe to doubt, that ≈øome ill affected per≈øons have endeavoured to make a mi≈ø-under≈øtanding in the Army, of the intentions of the Parliament towards them; To take away all mi≈øtaking in that kinde, the hou≈øe of Commons have Commanded me to a≈ø≈øure you that they have taken the affaires of the Army into their ≈øerious Care; And though for the pre≈øent their moneys have not come as they wi≈øhed, and as was due, by rea≈øon of the many di≈øtractions, and other Impediments which this Hou≈øe could no wayes avoid, yet they re≈øt mo≈øt a≈ø≈øured that they ≈øhall not onely have their full pay, but the Hou≈øe will take their merits into their further con≈øideration, in regard they take notice that notwith≈øtanding their want, and endeavours of tho≈øe ill-affected per≈øons, they have not demeaned them≈øelves otherwi≈øe, then as men of honor, and well affected to the Common-wealth, which this Hou≈øe takes in ≈øo good part, that we have already found out a way to get money for a good part of their pay, and will take the mo≈øt ≈øpeedy cour≈øe, we po≈ø≈øibly may for the re≈øt.

dateline.date: the 4th of this pre≈øent Moneth of May. 1641.

closer.signed: So I remain; Your very Loving Friend.

postscript.p: 'Tis the plea≈øure of the Hou≈øe, that this Letter be Communicated to the Army, to the end their Intentions may be cleerly under≈øtood by them.

div.head: Sir BENJAMIN RUDYERDS Speech. Tue≈øday the 29. Decem.
div.p: THe principall part of this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, is Moneys, and now we are about it, I ≈øhall be glad we may give ≈øo much, as will not only ≈øerve the turn for the pre≈øent, but likewi≈øe to provide that it come not quick upon us againe, I beleeve that the two ≈øub≈øidies are ≈øpent already. Wee know how much time this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe hath co≈øt us, if we be but halfe as long about another, it may co≈øt more then money: For if two Armies ≈øhould be driven to extreame nece≈ø≈øitie, and they will be Judges of their owne nece≈ø≈øitie, we ≈øhall not be able to ≈øit here, and give more, though we would.

Believe it Sir; this is the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of all the bu≈øine≈ø≈øes in the Hou≈øe, of all the bu≈øine≈ø≈øes in the Kingdom; If we ≈øtand hacking for a little money, wee may very thriftily lo≈øe all we have, this being a bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of ≈øo peremptory and de≈øtructive a nature.

Wherefore Mr. Speaker, my humble and earne≈øt motion is, that we may di≈øpatch it fully, and at once; If there ≈øhould be an overplus of money remaining, wee can ≈øoone re≈øolve how to di≈øpo≈øe of it.

Foure ≈øub≈øidies will doe the worke, if they be given pre≈øently, for every day tells us that we are not ≈øo much Ma≈øters of our owne time, and occa≈øions as to doe nothing when we would; Let us doe this while≈øt we may, though I dwell not in the North, yet I dwell in England.

div.head: Sir BENJAMIN RUDYERDS Speech concerning the QUEENS Joynture. Jan. 1640.
div.p: GOD hath ble≈ø≈øed the Queens Maje≈øtie with a ble≈ø≈øed Progeny already, whereby ≈øhe hath relieved and fortified this Kingdome, which may put us in minde in a fit time to provide according to their birth, and intere≈øt.

Shee is the daughter of a great and famous King, ≈øhe is the wife of our King, which to us includes all expre≈ø≈øions. But in one thing, Mr. Speaker, her Maje≈øtie is ≈øingular in that ≈øhe is the Mother to the greate≈øt Prince that hath beene borne among≈øt us above the≈øe hundred yeers, which cannot but work a tenderne≈ø≈øe in us.

The Queene likewi≈øe may be another In≈øtrument of happine≈ø≈øe to us in her good affection to Parliaments, by a good han≈øell in this. And I beleeve we ≈øhall ≈øee effects of it, for it neerly and wi≈øely concernes her Maje≈øtie, even in all the Relations that are mo≈øt deare to her to contribute her be≈øt A≈ø≈øi≈øtance to Uphold the Government and greatne≈ø≈øe of the kingdome. By which meanes al≈øo the king will be better enabled to make a further enlargement of his bounty towards her, in ≈øome degree proportionable.
Wherefore, Mr. Speaker, it will become this Hou≈øe to ≈øhew our cheerfulne≈ø≈øe in pa≈ø≈øing of the Bill.

div.head: Articles again≈øt Doctor Piercie, Bi≈øhop of Bath and Wells; exhibited by Mr. James Mini≈øter within his Dioce≈ø≈øe.
div.p: 1 HEE hath Ex officio convented mee before him, for having two Sermons preached in my Church on Michaelmas day, to the great di≈øturbance & hinderance of the ≈øale of the Church Ale, as his Lord≈øhip pretended, and further examined me upon Oath, whether I had not the ≈øaid Sermons preached for the ≈øame purpo≈øe and intent, admoni≈øhing me for the future, neither to preach my ≈øelfe, nor ≈øuffer any other to preach in my Cure, in the afternoon, of either the Lords-day, or holy dayes.

2 I heard him ≈øay to his Regi≈øter, That whereas Information had been given concerning certain Mini≈øters, that they expounded upon the Catechi≈øme, this Information was too narrow to catch them, and therefore it ≈øhould have runne thus, that they Catechi≈øed or expounded upon the Catechi≈øme Sermon-wi≈øe, and then they would have been obnoxious to cen≈øure.

3 At the meeting to elect Clerks of the Convocation he threatned to ≈øend forth Cen≈øures of the Church, again≈øt all that would not pay in the Benevolence, late granted, in the late Synod, within a fortnight after the ≈øecond day of November la≈øt pa≈øt; And further at the ≈øaid election, his ≈øonne gave eight ≈øingle voyces; two, as Arch-Deacon of Bath; two, as Prebend of the Church of Wells; two, as Par≈øon of Buckland Saint
Mary; two, as Vicar of Kingsbury: and many others al≈øo there pre≈øent, gave as many double voyces, as they had Benefices and Dignities; again≈øt which one Mr. Ro≈ønell prote≈øted, ≈øaying, that it was illegall; The Bi≈øhop replyed, that they gave in ≈øeverall capacities, and thereupon commanded him ≈øilence, ≈øaying, that he was a young man.

4. That upon the meer Information of Mr. Humphry Sydenham Rector of Buckington, that in a certain Sermon Preached at the Vi≈øitation of the Arch Deacon of Taunton, I be≈øpattered the Clergie; The Bi≈øhop ≈øummoned me before him down to Wells, and there objected unto mee, that I had preached a ≈øcandalous Sermon, wherein I had ca≈øt ≈øome a≈øper≈øions on ≈øome of the Clergy. Upon which charge I proferd to bring in an exact Copy of the Sermon I preacht, and to depo≈øe, that I ≈øpake neither more nor le≈ø≈øe, then was contained in the ≈øaid Copy; This the Bi≈øhop would not accept of, ≈øaying that he would not have the Mini≈øters, who came to witne≈ø≈øe again≈øt mee, troubled with a ≈øecond journey: One of my Proctors de≈øired time, till the next Court day for me to give in my an≈øwer; the Bi≈øhop commanded him to hold his Peace, and the other Proctor though he was retained by me, & had received a Fee, never opened his mouth, pretending unto me, that becau≈øe the Bi≈øhop was ≈øo highly di≈øplea≈øed with mee, he dur≈øt not appeare in my behalf, being denyed time to give in my an≈øwer at the next Court day; I de≈øired re≈øpit untill the afternoon, this al≈øo was denyed; In fine contrary to the rules of their own Court, he examined witne≈ø≈øes again≈øt me, and proceeded to Cen≈øure me, before he received my full an≈øwer, he would not heare the an≈øwer, which I could give to the Articles objected to me, which I proferd to give, and which he had by oath required me to give; further by vertue of the oath he admini≈øtred unto me, he que≈øtioned me not only concerning
matters of outward fact, but al≈øo concerning my mo≈øt ≈øecret thoughts, intentions and aymes. Moreover whereas the witne≈ø≈øes confe≈ø≈øed that I only ≈øaid, in the fore≈øaid Sermon, that ≈øome put the Scriptures into a ≈øtaged dre≈ø≈øe; the Bi≈øhop per≈øwaded them, that, that expre≈ø≈øion was equivalent with the Article objected, that ≈øome mens Sermons were Stage Playes, and they by his per≈øwa≈øion, ≈øwore down right, that I ≈øaid≈øome mens Sermons were Stage Playes; The Doctor made an Act and Order, that I ≈øhould make publique retractation, which I refu≈øed to doe, and appeald unto the Arches; But upon either the Bi≈øhops, or M. Sidenhams Information my Procter Hunt renounced my appeale, and Sir John Lambe di≈ømi≈ø≈øed the ≈øame cau≈øe, without hearing, unto the Bi≈øhop againe.

5 The Churchwardens of my Pari≈øh, by order from the Bi≈øhop, were enjoyned to turn the Communion Table, and place it Altar-wi≈øe, &c. Now they, that they might neither di≈øplea≈øe the Bi≈øhop, nor tran≈øgre≈ø≈øe again≈øt the Rubrick of the Liturgie, made it an exact ≈øquare Table, that ≈øo notwith≈øtanding the Bi≈øhops order, the Mini≈øter might ≈øtill Officiate at the North ≈øide of the Table; M. Humphry Sydenham informed again≈øt this, and upon Information, the Bi≈øhop ≈øent to view it; and upon his view he certified the Bi≈øhop, that it was like an Oy≈øter Table, whereupon the Bi≈øhop ordered the Churchwardens to make a new one.

6 Upon M. Humphry Sydenhams Information that M. John Pym was a Parliamenteer, the Bi≈øhop would not ≈øuffer me any longer to ≈øojourn in his hou≈øe, although before ≈øuch Information he gave me leave: And when I demanded of ≈øome of his ≈øervants, the rea≈øon why his Lord≈øhip had thus changed his minde, they told me that his Lord≈øhip was informed by M. Sydenham that M. Pym was a Puritane.

div.head: The Lord Andevers ≈øpeech in March 1640. concerning the Star-Chamber.
div.p: MY Lords, ≈øince your Lord≈øhips have already looked ≈øo farre into priviledges of Peers, as to make a ≈øtrict inqui≈øition upon forraign honours: Let us not de≈øtroy that among our ≈øelves, which we de≈øire to pre≈øerve from ≈øtrangers.

And if this greivance I ≈øhall move again≈øt, have ≈ølept till now; It is very con≈øiderable le≈øt cu≈øtome make it every day more apparent than other: your Lord≈øhips very well know, there was a Statute framed, 3 Hen. 7. Authorizing the Chancellor, Trea≈øurer and Privy Seale, and the two Chiefe Ju≈øtices calling to them one Bi≈øhop, and a temporall Lord of the Kings Councell, to receive complaints upon Bill or information, and Cite ≈øuch parties to appeare as ≈øtand accu≈øed of any mi≈ødemeanour, and this was the Infancy of the Starchamber, but afterwards the Starchamber was by Cardinall. Wool≈øey 8 H. 8. rai≈øed to mans E≈øtate, from whence (being now altogether unlimited) it is grown a Mon≈øter, and will hourely produce wor≈øe effects, unle≈ø≈øe it be reduced by that hand which laid the foundation; for the Statutes that are ratified by Parliament admit of no other than a repeale.
Therefore I offer humbly unto your Lord≈øhips the≈øe en≈øuing Rea≈øons, why it ≈øhould be repealed.

Fir≈øt the very words of the Statute cleerly ≈øhew that it was a needle≈ø≈øe in≈øtitution, for it ≈øayes they who are to Judge, can proceed with no delinquent otherwi≈øe,
then if he were convicted of the ≈øame crime by due proces of Law.
And doe your Lord≈øhips holdth is a rationall Court that ≈øends us to the Law, and calls us to the Law, and calls us back from it againe.
Secondly, divers Judicatories confound one another, & in pe≈ø≈øima republica plurimae Leges.

The ≈øecond rea≈øon is from circum≈øtance, or rather √† Con≈øuetudine, and of this there are many examples both dome≈øtique and forain; but more particularly by the Parliaments of France abbreviated into a ≈øtanding Committee by Philip the King, and continued according to his In≈øtitution untill Lewis the eleventh came to the Crown, who being a ≈øubtill Prince buried the volume in the Epitome, for to this day, when ever the three E≈øtates are called, either at the death of the old King, or to Crown the new, It is a common Proverb Allons voire Le van des E≈øtates; My Lords Arbitrary judgements de≈øtroy the Common Laws, and in them the two great Charters of the Kingdome, which being once lo≈øt, we have nothing left but the name of liberty.

Then the la≈øt rea≈øon is (though it was the fir≈øt cau≈øe of my ≈øtanding up) the great Eclip≈øe it hath ever been to the whole Nobility; For who are ≈øo frequently vexed there as Peers and Noblemen, and notwith≈øtanding their appeale to this A≈ø≈øembly, is ever good whil≈øt that famous Law of the 4 Ed. 3. remaines in force for the holding of a Parliament once a year or more if occa≈øion require, yet who dur≈øt a year ago mention ≈øuch a Statute, without the incurring the danger of M. Kilverts per≈øecution? Therefore I ≈øhall humbly move your Lord≈øhips that a ≈øelect Commitee of a few may be named to con≈øider of the act of Parliament it ≈øelfe, and if they ≈øhall thinke it of as great prejudice as I doe, that then the hou≈øe of Commons in the mo≈øt u≈øuall manner
may be made acquainted with it either by Bill or conference, who al≈øo happily thinke it a burthen to the Subject, and ≈øo when the whole body of Parliament ≈øhall joyne in one ≈øupplication, I am confident his Maje≈øtie will de≈øire that nothing ≈øhall remaine in force which his people doe not willingly obey.

div.head: Lunae, the 10. of May, 1641.
div.p: IT is this day ordered by the Hou≈øe of Commons now a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament, that the Lord Maior of London, the Ju≈øtices of Peace of Midle≈øex, We≈øtmin≈øter, and the Liberties of the Dutchie of Lanca≈øter, and tho≈øe of Surrey, that are for the Burrough of Southwarke, and the place adjoyning, doe imploy their be≈øt endeavors to prevent that none of the Kings Subjects doe frequent the hou≈øes of any the Emba≈ø≈øadors, Somer≈øet-hou≈øe, or St. James, to heare Ma≈ø≈øe, And that they give an accompt to this Hou≈øe, of the Execution of this Order, at all ≈øuch times, as by the ≈øaid Hou≈øe they ≈øhall be required.

div.head: My Lord Finch his Letter to my Lord CHAMBERLAINE.
div.p:
THe Intere≈øt your Lord≈øhip hath ever had in the be≈øt of my fortunes, and affections, gives me the Priviledges of troubling your Lord≈øhip with the≈øe few lines, from one that hath now nothing left to ≈øerve you withall but his Prayers; Tho≈øe your Lord≈øhip ≈øhall never faile, with an heart as full of true affection to your Lord≈øhip, as ever any was. My Lord, it was not the lo≈ø≈øe of my place, and with that of my fortunes, nor being exiled from my deare Countrey and friends (though many of them were cau≈øe of ≈øorrow) that afflicts, but that which I mo≈øt ≈øuffer under, is that di≈øplea≈øure of the Hou≈øe of Commons conceived again≈øt me; I know a true heart I have ever borne towards them, and your Lord≈øhip can witne≈ø≈øe in part, what wayes I have gone in, but Silence and patience be≈øt becomes me, with which I mu≈øt leave my ≈øelfe, and my Actions to the favourable con≈øtruction of my Noble Friends, in which number your Lord≈øhip hath a prime place; I am now at the Hague, where I arrived on Thur≈øday the la≈øt of the la≈øt moneth, where I purpo≈øe to live in a fa≈øhion agreeable to the poorene≈ø≈øe of my fortunes, for my humbling in this world, I have utterly ca≈øt off the thoughts of it, and my aime ≈øhall be to learne to number my daies, that I may apply my heart unto wi≈ødome, that wi≈ødome that ≈øhall wipe all teares from mine eyes, and heart, and lead me by the hand to true happine≈ø≈øe,
which can never be taken from me. I pray God of heaven ble≈ø≈øe this Parliament with a happy, both progre≈ø≈øe and conclu≈øion: if my ruine may conduce but the lea≈øt to it, I ≈øhall not repine at it; I truly pray for your Lord≈øhip, and your Noble Family, that God would give an increa≈øe of all worldly ble≈ø≈øings, and in the fulne≈ø≈øe of dayes, to receive you to his glory; if I were capable of ≈øerving any body, I would tell your Lord≈øhip, that no man ≈øhould be readier to make knowne his devotion, and true gratitude to your Lord≈øhip, then

closer.signed: Your Lord≈øhips mo≈øt humble, and affectionate poore kin≈øman and ≈øervant, J.F.

div.head: The Lord KEEPERS Speech TO HIS MAJESTIE, at the Banquetting-hou≈øe at White-hall, in the name of both Hou≈øes.
div.p:
I Am to give your Maje≈øtie mo≈øt humble and heartie thanks in the name of both hou≈øes of Parliament, and this whole Kingdome, for the ≈øpeedy and gracious Royall a≈ø≈øent unto the Bill, Entitled, An act for preventing of inconveniences happening by the long intermi≈ø≈øion
of Parliaments, which as it is of ≈øingular comfort and ≈øecuritie for all your Subjects for the pre≈øent, ≈øo they are confident it will be of infinite honor and ≈øetlement of Your Maje≈øties Royall Crowne and dignitie, as well as comfort to their po≈øtiritie.

div.head: The Declaration of the Scots Commi≈ø≈øioners to the Hou≈øe of Parliament, touching the maintenance of their Army. March, the 16th, 1640.
div.p:
IN the mid≈øt of other matters, nece≈ø≈øitie con≈øtraineth us to ≈øhew your Lord≈øhips that foure≈øcore thou≈øand pounds and above of the Moneys appointed for reliefe of the Northerne Countreys, there is no more paid but 18000 l. the Country people of tho≈øe Countreys have tru≈øted the ≈øouldiers ≈øo long as they are become weary and unable to furni≈øh them, their cattell and victuall being ≈øo farre exhau≈øted and wa≈øted, as it is ≈øcarce able to entertain them≈øelves; The Markets are decayed becau≈øe there is no mony to buy their Commodities, and are become ≈øo deare, that no ≈øort of victuall is ≈øold, but at a double rate; And which is harde≈øt of all, the Army is ≈øtinted by the Articles of Ce≈ø≈øation to ≈øtay within the≈øe two Countyes, who≈øe provi≈øions are all ≈øpent, expecting from time to time the payment of tho≈øe moneys, which
were promi≈øed for their reliefe, and are reduced to ≈øuch extremity, as they mu≈øt either ≈øtarve, or (≈øore again≈øt their will) breake their limited bounds, unle≈ø≈øe ≈øome ≈øpeedy cour≈øe bee taken for their more timous payment, that ≈øo ≈øoone as may be, the Arreers may be paid; And becau≈øe the continued payment of that monethly ≈øumme, for reliefe of the Northerne Countreyes, is a Burthen to the Kingdome of England, our Army is a trouble to the Country where they re≈øide, our charges of entertaining our Army (be≈øides what is allowed from England) is exceeding great; And our lo≈ø≈øes and prejudice through ab≈øence and neglect of our affaires not ≈ømall, Therefore that all evills, and troubles of both Kingdomes may be removed, it is our earne≈øt de≈øire that the Parliament may be plea≈øed to determine the time and manner of Payment of the 300000 l. which they were plea≈øed to grant towards reliefe of their Brethren, that there may be no let about this, when matters ≈øhall be drawing towards an end, And that his Maje≈øty and they may give order for Accelerating matters in the treaty, that the peace being concluded, England may be ea≈øed of the burthen of two Armies, and we may returne to our owne homes, which is our earne≈øt de≈øire.

div.head: The Remon≈øtrance of both the Hou≈øes of Parliament unto the King, delivered by the Lord Keeper, January the 29th 1640.
div.p: YOUR loyall Subjects, the Lords and Commons, now a≈ø≈øembled by your Maje≈øties Writ in the high Court of Parliament, humbly repre≈øent unto your gracious con≈øideration that Je≈øuits and Prie≈øts ordained by authority from the Sea of Rome, remaining in this Realme, by a Statute made in the 27 year of Queen Elizabeth are declared Traytors, and to ≈øuffer as Traytors.

That this law is not ≈øo rigorous,27 Eliz. cap. 2. as ≈øome apprehend, or would have others to beleeve, for that it is re≈øtrayned to the naturall born Subjects only, and doth not extend to any ≈øtrangers at all.
That it is enacted in the fir≈øt year of King James, 1 Jac. cap. 4. that all Statutes made in the time of Queen Elizabeth, again≈øt Prie≈øts and Je≈øuits, be put in due and exact execution.

And for further a≈ø≈øurance of the due execution of the≈øe laws, the Statute of the third year of King James invites men to the di≈øcovery of the offenders, by rewarding them with a con≈øiderable part of the forfeiture of the Recu≈øants e≈øtate.

So that the Statute of Queen Elizabeth is not only approved, but by the judgement of ≈øeverall Parliaments in the time of King James of happy memory adjudged fit and nece≈ø≈øary to be put in execution.

That con≈øidering the ≈øtate and condition of this pre≈øent time, they conceive this law to be more nece≈ø≈øary to be put in ≈øtrict execution, then at any time before; & that for divers weighty and con≈øiderable rea≈øons, viz. For that by divers Petitions from the ≈øeverall parts of this Kingdome, complaints are made of the great increa≈øe of Popery and Super≈øtition, and the people call earne≈øtly to have the laws again≈øt Recu≈øants put in execution; Prie≈øts and Je≈øuits ≈øwarme in great abundance in this Kingdome, and appeare here with ≈øuch boldne≈ø≈øe, and confidence, as if there were no laws again≈øt them.

That it appeares unto the Hou≈øe of Commons by proofe, that of late years about the City of London Prie≈øts and Je≈øuits have been di≈øcharged out of Pri≈øon, many of them being condemned of high Trea≈øon.
They are credibly informed that at this pre≈øent the Pope hath a Nunci ‚Ä¢ , or Agent re≈øident in the City, and they have a ju≈øt cau≈øe to believe the ≈øame to be true.

The Papi≈øts, as publiquely, and with as much confidence and importunity re≈øort to Ma≈ø≈øe at Denmark hou≈øe, and St. James, and the Emba≈ø≈øadors Chappels, as others doe to their Pari≈øh Churches: They conceive the not putting of the≈øe Statutes in execution again≈øt Prie≈øts and Je≈øuits, is a principall cau≈øe of increa≈øe of Popery.

That the putting of the≈øe laws in execution, tendeth not only to the pre≈øervation and advancement of the true Religion e≈øtabli≈øhed in this Kingdome; but al≈øo the ≈øafety of your Maje≈øties per≈øon, and ≈øecurity of the State & Government, which were the principall cau≈øes of the making of the Laws again≈øt Prie≈øts and Je≈øuits, as is manife≈øtly declared in the preamble of the laws them≈øelves,
which are the be≈øt interpreters of the mindes of the makers of them.

And becau≈øe the words being penned by the advi≈øe and wi≈ødome of the whole ≈øtate, are much more full and clear then any particular mans expre≈ø≈øion can be, they were therefore read, as they are vouched, tho≈øe of the 27 year of Queen Elizabeth, being thus, viz.

That the Prie≈øts and Je≈øuits come hither, not only to draw the Subjects from their true obedience to the Queen, but al≈øo to ≈øtir up Sedition, Rebellion, and open ho≈øtility within the Realme; to the great endangering of the ≈øafety of her Royall Per≈øon, and to the utter ruin, de≈øolation, and overthrow of the whole Kingdom, if not timely prevented; and the tenor of the words of the third year of King James are in this manner, viz.

Whereas divers Je≈øuits and Prie≈øts doe withdraw many of his Maje≈øties Subjects from the true ≈øervice of Almighty God, and the Religion e≈øtabli≈øhed within this Realme, to the Romi≈øh Religion, and from their loyall obedience to his Maje≈øtie; and have of late ≈øecretly per≈øwaded divers Recu≈øants, and Papi≈øts, and encouraged and imboldned them to commit mo≈øt damnable Trea≈øons tending to the overthrow of the whole State and Common Wealth; if God of his goodne≈ø≈øe and mercy had not within few houres of the intended time of the execution thereof, revealed and di≈øclo≈øed the ≈øame.

The Hou≈øes did further informe, that ≈øome Je≈øuits and Prie≈øts had been executed in the time of Queen Elizabeth, and King James of happy memory; and when any of them have received mercy, it was in ≈øuch time, and upon ≈øuch circum≈øtance, as that the ≈øame might be extended unto them without dangers, whereas now of late, there hath been a great apprehen≈øion of endevours by ≈øome ill agents, to ≈øubvert Religion;
and at this pre≈øent both Kingdomes have a generall expectation of a through reformation.

And there is already found ≈øo ill a con≈øequence of the the late reprieve of John Goodman the Prie≈øt; that the Hou≈øe of Commons having ≈øent to the Citizens of London for their a≈ø≈øi≈øtance in the advancement of money, for the pre≈øent and nece≈ø≈øary ≈øupply of his Maje≈øties army, and reliefe of the Northern Counties: upon this occa≈øion, they have ab≈øolutely denyed to furni≈øh the ≈øame: and how far the like di≈øcontent may be effu≈øed into other parts of the Kingdom, to the interruption of the levying of the Sub≈øidies, the hou≈øes leave to your Maje≈øties con≈øideration. It is found that Goodman the Prie≈øt hath been twice formerly committed and di≈øcharged. That his re≈øidence now about London, was in ab≈øolute contempt of your Maje≈øties Proclamation, as the Hou≈øes are credibly informed, that he hath been ≈øometimes a Mini≈øter in the Church of England, and con≈øequently is an Apo≈øtate; both Hou≈øes are very ≈øen≈øible that any man ≈øhould pre≈øume to intercede with your Maje≈øty in a ca≈øe of ≈øo high a nature.

They humbly de≈øire that a ≈øpeedy cour≈øe may be taken for the due execution of the laws again≈øt the Prie≈øts and Je≈øuits, that all mi≈øchiefes before mentioned may be timely remedied by your Maje≈øties great wi≈ødome.
And la≈øtly, that Goodman the Prie≈øt be left to the ju≈øtice of the law.

div.head: The Earle of Straffords Letter, to his mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty, dated from the Tower the 4th of May, 1641.
div.p: IT hath been my greate≈øt griefe in all the≈øe troubles, to be taken as a per≈øon which ≈øhould endeavour to repre≈øent and ≈øet things ami≈ø≈øe between your Maje≈øty and your People; and to give coun≈øels tending to the di≈øquiet of the three Kingdomes.

Mo≈øt true it is, that this mine own private Condition con≈øidered, it had been a great madne≈ø≈øe, ≈øince through your grations favour I was ≈øo provided, as not to expect in any kind to mend my fortune or plea≈øe my mind more, then by re≈øting where your bounteous hands had placed me.

Nay, it is mo≈øt mightily mi≈øtaken, for unto your Maje≈øty it is well known, my poore, and humble advi≈øes concluded ≈øtill in this, That your Maje≈øty and your people could never be happy, till there were a right under≈øtanding betwixt you and them: no other means to effect, and ≈øettle this happine≈ø≈øe, but by the Coun≈øell, and a≈ø≈øent of the Parliament; or to prevent the growing Evils upon this ≈øtate, but by intirely putting your ≈øelf in the la≈øt re≈øort, upon the loyalty, and good affections of your Engli≈øh ≈øubjects.

Yet ≈øuch is my misfortune, this truth findeth little
credit, the contrary ≈øeemeth generally to be believed, and my ≈øelfe reputed, as ≈øome thing of Separation between you, and your people; under a heavier cen≈øure then which, I am per≈øwaded no Gentleman can ≈øuffer.

Now, I under≈øtand the minds of men are more incen≈øed again≈øt me, notwith≈øtanding your Maje≈øty hath declared, that in your princely opinion, I am not guilty of Trea≈øon, nor are you ≈øatisfied in your con≈øcience to pa≈ø≈øe the Bill.

This bringeth me into a very great ≈øtraight, there is before me the ruine of my Children, and family hitherto untouched in all the branches of it with any foule Crimes. Here is before me the many ills, which may befall your Sacred per≈øon, and the whole Kingdome, ≈øhould your ≈øelfe, and Parliament part le≈ø≈øe ≈øatisfied one with the other, then is nece≈ø≈øary for the pre≈øervation both of King and People. Here are before me the things mo≈øt valued, mo≈øt feared, by mortall man, Life, or Death.

To ≈øay Sir, that there hath not been a ≈øtrife in me, were to make me le≈ø≈øe man, then God knoweth my infirmities give me. And to call a de≈øtruction upon my ≈øelfe, and young Children, where the intentions of my heart at lea≈øt have been innocent of this great offence may be believed, will find no ea≈øie con≈øent from Fle≈øh and blood.

But with much ≈øadne≈ø≈øe, I am come to a re≈øolution of that which I take to be be≈øt becomming me, to look upon that which is mo≈øt principall in it ≈øelfe; which doubtle≈ø≈øe is the pro≈øperity of Your ≈øacred Per≈øon, and the Common-Wealth, infinitely before any private mans intere≈øt.

And therefore in few words, as I put my ≈øelfe wholly upon the honour, and ju≈øtice of my Peers ≈øo clearly, as to be≈øeech your Maje≈øty might plea≈øe to have ≈øpared that declaration of yours on Saturday la≈øt, and intirely
to have left me to their Lord≈øhips, ≈øo now, to ≈øet your Maje≈øties con≈øcience at liberty, I doe mo≈øt humbly be≈øeech your Maje≈øty, in prevention of mi≈øtakes which may happen, by your refu≈øall, to pa≈ø≈øe this Bill; And by this means remove (prai≈øed be God) I cannot ≈øay, this accur≈øed, (but I confe≈ø≈øe) this unfortunate thing forth of the way, towards that ble≈ø≈øed agreement, which God, I tru≈øt, ≈øhall ever E≈øtabli≈øh between you, and your ≈øubjects.

Sir my con≈øent ≈øhall more acquit you herein to God, then al ‚Ä¢ he world can do be≈øides. To a willing man there is no injury done. And as by Go ‚Ä¢ s grace I forgive all the world with a calmnes and meeknes of infinite Contentment to my di≈ølodging ≈øoule; So, Sir, to you can I give the life of this world, with all the cheerfulne≈ø≈øe imaginable; in the ju≈øt acknowledgement of your exceeding favours.
