And only beg that in your goodne≈ø≈øe, you would vouch≈øafe to ca≈øt your gratious regard upon my poor Sonne, and his three Si≈øters, le≈ø≈øe, or more, and no otherwi≈øe, then as their (in pre≈øent) unfortunate Father, may hereafter appeare more, or le≈ø≈øe guilty of this death.

p.hi: God long pre≈øerve your Maje≈øty.

closer.signed: Your Maje≈øties mo≈øt faithfull, and humble Subject, and Servant. STRAFFORD.

div.head: The Petition of the EARLE of STRAFFORD unto the Lords before he Dyed.

opener.salute: To the Right Honourable the Lords Spirituall and Temporall, in this pre≈øent Parliament a≈ø≈øembled.

div.p: THE humble Petition of Thomas late Earle of Strafford; Sheweth that ≈øeeing it is the good will and plea≈øure of God that your Petitioner is now ≈øhortly to pay that duty which we allow to our fraile nature; He ≈øhall in all Chri≈øtian Patience and Charity conform, and ≈øubmit him≈øelfe to your Ju≈øtice, in a comfortable a≈ø≈øurance of the great Hope, laid up for us in the Mercy and Merits of our Saviour ble≈ø≈øed for ever.

Only he humbly craves, to return your Lord≈øhips mo≈øt humble thanks for your Noble Compa≈ø≈øion towards tho≈øe innocent Children; whom now with his la≈øt ble≈ø≈øing he mu≈øt commit to the protection of Almighty GOD, be≈øeeching Your Lord-≈øhips to fini≈øh your Pious intentions towards them: And de≈øiring that the reward thereof may be fulfill'd in You, by him that is able to give above all we are able either to aske or think. Wherein I tru≈øt the Honourable Hou≈øe of Commons will afford their Chri≈øtian a≈ø≈øi≈øtance.

And ≈øo be≈øeeching your Lord-≈øhips charitably to forgive all his omi≈ø≈øions and infirmities, he doth very heartily and truly recommend Your Lord≈øhips to the Mercies of Our Heavenly Father, and that for his goodne≈ø≈øe he may perfect you in every good work. Amen.

div.head: Lord FAULKLANDS fir≈øt ≈øpeech in Parliament.
div.p: I Rejoyce very much to ≈øee this day; and the want hath not lain in my affections, but my lungs. If to all that hath bind pa≈øt, I have not been as loud with my voice as any mans in the hou≈øe, yet truly my opinion is; we have yet done nothing, if we doe no more: I ≈øhall add what I humbly conceive ought to be added, as ≈øoone as I have ≈øaid ≈øomething, with references to him that ≈øaies it: I will fir≈øt de≈øire the forgivene≈ø≈øe of the Hou≈øe, if ought I ≈øay ≈øeem to entrench upon anothers profe≈ø≈øion, and enter upon the work of another robe.
Since I have bin intru≈øted by the report of a learned Committee, and confirmed by the uncontradicted rule of the Hou≈øe, ≈øince I ≈øhall ≈øay nothing of this kind, but in order to ≈øomewhat further.

And which moves me mo≈øt to venture my opinion, and to expect your pardon, ≈øince I am confident, that Hi≈øtory alone is ≈øufficient to ≈øhew this judgement contrary to our Laws, and Logick alone ≈øufficient to prove it de≈øtructive to our propriety, which every free, and noble per≈øon values more then his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion. I will not profe≈ø≈øe I know of my ≈øelfe, and all tho≈øe who know me, know that my naturall di≈øpo≈øition is to decline from ≈øeverity, much more from cruelty.
That I have no particular provocations from their per≈øons, and have particular Obligations to their calling again≈øt whom I am to ≈øpeak.

And though not ≈øo much, yet far more then I have, ≈øo I hope it will be believed, that only publick intere≈øt
have extorted this from me, and that which I would not ≈øay, if I conceived it not ≈øo true, and ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary that no undige≈øted meat can lie havier upon the ≈øtomach, then this un≈øaid would have lain upon my Con≈øcience.

Mr. Speaker, the con≈øtitution of this Commonwealth hath E≈øtabli≈øhed, or rather endeavored to E≈øtabli≈øh to us the ≈øecurity of our goods, and the ≈øecurity of tho≈øe Laws which would ≈øecure us and our goods, by appointing for us Judges ≈øo ≈øettled, ≈øo ≈øworn, that there can be no oppre≈ø≈øion, but they of nece≈ø≈øity mu≈øt be acce≈ø≈øary; ≈øince if they neither deny, nor delay us Ju≈øtice, which neither for the great nor little ≈øeale, they ought to doe; the greate≈øt Per≈øon in this Kingdome cannot continue the lea≈øt violence upon the meane≈øt; But this ≈øecurity, Mr. Speaker, hath been almo≈øt our ruine, for it hath been turned, or rather turned it ≈øelf into a Battery again≈øt us: And tho≈øe per≈øons who ≈øhould have been as Dogs to defend the Sheep, have been as Wolves, to worry them.

The≈øe Judges, M. Speaker, to in≈øtance not them onely, but their greate≈øt crime, have delivered an opinion, and judgement in an extrajudiciall manner, that is, ≈øuch as came not within their cognizance, they being Judges, and neither Philo≈øophers, nor Politicians; In which when that is ≈øo ab≈øolute and evident, the law of the land cea≈øes, and of generall rea≈øon and equity, by which particular laws at fir≈øt were framed, returnes to his throne and government, where ≈øalus populi becomes not only ≈øuprema, but ≈øola lex; at which, and to which end, what≈øoever ≈øhould di≈øpence with the King, to make u≈øe of any mony, di≈øpences with us, to make u≈øe of his, and one anothers. In this judgement they contradicted both many and learned Acts and Declarations of Parliaments; and tho≈øe in this very ca≈øe, in this very reign, ≈øo that for them they needed to have con≈øulted
with no other record, but with their memories.

2 They have contradicted apparent evidences by, ≈øuppo≈øing mighty and eminent dangers, in the mo≈øt Cerene, quiet, and halcian dayes that could po≈ø≈øibly be imagined, a few conceptible pirats, being our mo≈øt formidall enemies, and there being neither Prince nor State, with whom we had either Alyance, or Amity, or both.

3 They contradict the writ it ≈øelfe, by ≈øuppo≈øing that ≈øuppo≈øed danger to be ≈øo ≈øuddaine, that it would not ≈øtay for a Parliament, which required but forty daies. ≈øtay, and the writ being in no ≈øuch ha≈øte, but being content to ≈øtay ≈øeventimes over.

Mr. Speaker, it ≈øeemed generally ≈øtrange, that they ≈øaw not the Law which all men el≈øe ≈øaw, but them≈øelves. Yet though this begot the more generall wonder, three other particulars begot the more generall indignation.

The fir≈øt of all the rea≈øons for this judgement, was ≈øuch that they needed not any from the adver≈øe party to help them to convert tho≈øe few, who before the la≈øt ≈øu≈øpition of the legallity of that mo≈øt illegall writ, there being fewer that approved of the judgement, then there were that judged it, for I am confident they did not that them≈øelves.

Secondly, when they had allowed to the King, the ≈øole power in nece≈ø≈øity, the ≈øole judgement of nece≈ø≈øity, and by that enabled him to take both from us, what he would, when he would, and how he would, they yet continued to per≈øwade us that they had left us our liberties and proprieties.

The third and la≈øt is, and which I confe≈ø≈øe moved mo≈øt, That by the transformation of us from the ≈øtate of free ≈øubjects (a good phra≈øe Mr. Speaker, under Doctor Heylens favor) unto that of Villeins, they di≈øable us by Legall and voluntary ≈øupplies to expre≈ø≈øe our affections
to his Maje≈øty, and by that to cheri≈øh his to us, that is by Parliaments.

M. Speaker, the cau≈øe of all the mi≈øeries we have ≈øuffered, and the cau≈øe of all our jealou≈øies we have had, that we ≈øhould yet ≈øuffer; is, That a mo≈øt excellent Prince hath been mo≈øt infinitely abu≈øed by his Judges, telling him that by policy he might doe what he plea≈øed; with the fir≈øt of the≈øe we are now to deale, which may be a leading to the re≈øt. And ≈øince in proving of the≈øe Laws, upon which the≈øe men have trampled, our Ance≈øtours have ≈øhewed their urmo≈øt care and wi≈ødome, for our unaffected ≈øecurity, words having done nothing, and yet have done all their words can doe, we mu≈øt now be forced to think of aboli≈øhing of our grievances, & of taking away this judgement, and the≈øe Judges together, and of regulating their ≈øucce≈ø≈øors by their examplary puni≈øhment.

I will not ≈øpeak much; I will only ≈øay we have accu≈øed a great Per≈øon of high Trea≈øon, for intending to ≈øubvert our fundamentall Laws, and to introduce arbitrary Government, which we ≈øuppo≈øe he meant to doe, we are ≈øure the≈øe have done it, there being no Law more fundamentall, than that they have already ≈øubverted, and no government more ab≈øolute, than they have really introduced: Mr. Speaker; not only the ≈øevere puni≈øhment, but the ≈øuddaine removall of the≈øe men, will have a ≈øuddain effect in one very con≈øiderable con≈øideration.

We only accu≈øe, and the Hou≈øe of Lords condemn; In which condemnation they u≈øually receive advi≈øe (though not direction) from the Judges, And I leave it to every man to imagine how prejudiciall to us, that is, to the Common wealth, and how partiall to their fellow malefactors, the advice of ≈øuch judges is like to be. How undoubtedly for their own ≈øakes, they will conduce to their power, that every action be judged to be a le≈ø≈øe fault, and every per≈øon to be le≈ø≈øe faulty, then in
Ju≈øtice they ought to doe; Among≈øt the≈øe, Mr. Speaker, there is one that I mu≈øt not lo≈øe in the crowd, whom I doubt not but we ≈øhall finde when we examine the re≈øt of them, with what hopes they have been tempted: by what fears they have been a≈ø≈øaid, and by what, and by who≈øe importunity they have been pur≈øued, before they con≈øented to what they did; I doubt not I ≈øay, but wee ≈øhall then finde him to have been a mo≈øt admirable ≈øolicitor, but a mo≈øt abominable Judge; hee it is who not only gave away with his breath, what our Ance≈øtors had purcha≈øed for us by ≈øo large an expence of their time, their care, their trea≈øure, and their blood, and imployed their indu≈øtry, as great as his inju≈øtice, to per≈øwade others to joyne with him in that deed of gift, but ≈øtrove to root up tho≈øe liberties which they had cut downe; and to make our grievances immortall, and our ≈ølavery irreparable, le≈øt any part of our po≈øterity might want occa≈øion to cur≈øe him; He declared that power to be ≈øo inherent to the Crowne, as that it was not in the power even of Parliaments to divide them.

I have heard, Mr. Speaker, and I thinke here that common Fame is ground enough for this Hou≈øe to accu≈øe upon; And then undoubtedly enough to be accu≈øed upon in this Hou≈øe: She hath reported this ≈øo generally, that I expect not that you ≈øhould bid me name him whom you all know, nor doe I looke to tell you newes, when I tell you it is my Lord Keeper. But this I think ≈øit to put you in minde, That his place admits him to his Maje≈øtie, and tru≈øts him with his Maje≈øties con≈øcience, and how pernicious every moment, whil≈øt one gives him means to infu≈øe ≈øuch unju≈øt opinions of this Hou≈øe, as are expre≈øt in a Libell, rather then a Declaration, of which many believe him to be the principall Secretary, and th' other puts the va≈øte and mo≈øt unlimited power of the Chauncery into his hands, the ≈øafe≈øt of which will be dangerous; for my part, I thinke no man ≈øecure, that he ≈øhall thinke him≈øelfe worth any thing when he ri≈øes,
whil≈øt all our e≈øtates are in his brea≈øt, who hath ≈øacrificed his Countrey to his ambition, whil≈øt hee who hath pro≈øtracted his owne con≈øcience, hath the keeping of the Kings, and he who hath undone us already by whole≈øale, hath a power left in him by retaile.

Mr. Speaker, in the beginning of the Parliament he told us, and I am confident, every man here believes it before he told it, and never the more for his telling, though a ≈øorry witne≈ø≈øe is a good te≈øtimony again≈øt him≈øelfe; That his Maje≈øtie never required any thing from any his Mini≈øters but Ju≈øtice, and Integrity. Again≈øt which, if any of them have tran≈øgre≈øt, upon their heads, and that de≈øervedly, it ought to fall; It was full and truly; but he hath in this ≈øaying pronounced his owne condemnation; we ≈øhall be more partiall to him then he is to him≈øelf, if we be ≈ølow to pur≈øue it. It is therefore my ju≈øt and humble motion, That wee may chu≈øe a ≈øelect Committee to draw up his and their charge, and to examine their carriage in this particular, to make u≈øe of it in the charge, and if he ≈øhall be found guilty of tampering with Judges again≈øt the publike ≈øecurity, who thought tampering with witne≈ø≈øes in a private cau≈øe, worthy of ≈øo great a Fine, if he ≈øhall be found to have gone before the re≈øt to this Judgement, and to have gone beyond the re≈øt in this Judgement, that in the puni≈øhment for it, the Ju≈øtice of this Hou≈øe may not denie him the due honor both to preceed and exceed the re≈øt.

div.head: Sir JOHN CULPEPPERS Speech in the Commons Hou≈øe of Parliament. 9o. Novemb. 1640.
div.p: I ≈øtand not up with a Petition in my hand. I have it in my mouth, and have it in charge from them that ≈øent me hither, humbly to pre≈øent to the con≈øideration of this Hou≈øe the grievances of the County of Kent; I ≈øhall only ≈øumme them up; they are the≈øe,

Fir≈øt, the great increa≈øe of Papi≈øts by the remi≈ø≈øe execution of tho≈øe lawes which were made to ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe them: the life of the law is execution; without this, they become a dead letter; this is wanting, and a great grievance.

The ≈øecond, is the obtruding and countenancing of divers new Ceremonies in matters of Religion, as placing the Communion Table Altar-wi≈øe, and bowing or cringing to, or towards it, the refu≈øing of the holy Sacrament to ≈øuch as refu≈øe to come to the Rayles, The≈øe carry with them ≈øome ≈øcandall, and much offence.

The third, is Military charges, and therein fir≈øt, that of Coate and Conduct money, required as a loane, pre≈ø≈øed as a due, in each re≈øpect equally a grievance. The ≈øecond is the enhancing the price of Powder, whereby the Trayned Bands are much di≈øcouraged in their exerci≈øing: how≈øoever this may appeare prima facie, upon
due examination it will appeare a great grievance. The third is more particular to our County: It is this; The la≈øt Summer was twelvemonth, 1000. of our be≈øt Arms were taken from the owners, and ≈øent into Scotland: The compul≈øary way was this; If you will not ≈øend your Arms you ≈øhall goe your ≈øelves. M. Speaker, the trayned Band is a Militia of great ≈øtrength and honor, without charges to the King, and de≈øerves all due encouragement.

The fourth, is the Canons, I a≈ø≈øigne the≈øe to bee a grievance; Fir≈øt, in re≈øpect of the matter, be≈øides the &c. Oath. Secondly, in re≈øpect of the makers, they were cho≈øen to ≈øerve in a Convocation; that falling with the Parliament, the Scene was altered; The ≈øame men without any new election, ≈øhufled into a ≈øacred Synod, Thirdly, in re≈øpect of the con≈øequence, which in this age, when the ≈øecond ill pre≈øident becomes a Law, is full of danger. The Clergy, without confirmation of a Parliament, have a≈ø≈øumed unto them≈øelves power to make Lawes, to grant Reliefe by the name of benevolence, and to intermeddle with our free-hold by ≈øu≈øpen≈øions and deprivation, This is a grievance of a high nature.

The next grievance is the Ship-money; This cries aloud, I may ≈øay, I hope without offence, This ≈øtrikes the fir≈øt born of every family, I meane our inheritance; If the Lawes give the king power, in any danger of the kingdom, whereof hee is Judge, to impo≈øe what and when hee plea≈øe; wee owe all that is left, to the goodne≈ø≈øe of the King, not to the Law, M. Speaker, this makes the Farmors faint, and the Plough to goe heavy.

The next is the great decay of cloathing and fall of our woolls; The≈øe are the golden Mines of England which gives a foundation to that trade which we drive with all the World; I know there are many ≈øtarres concurre in this con≈øtellation, I will not trouble you with more than one cau≈øe of it, which I dare affirme to
be the greate≈øt. It is the great cu≈øtomes and impo≈øitions laid upon our Cloath, and new Draperies: I ≈øpeak not this with a wi≈øh to le≈ø≈øen the King revenews, ≈øo it be done by Parliament; I ≈øhall give my voice to lay more charge upon the ≈øuperfluities, due regard being had to trade, which we import from all other Nations: ≈øure I am that tho≈øe impo≈øitions upon our native commodities are dangerous, give liberty to our neighbours to under≈øell; And I take it for a rule, that be≈øides our lo≈ø≈øe in trade, which is five times as much as the King receiveth, what is impo≈øed upon our Cloaths, this it taken from the rent of our lands. I have but one grievance more to offer unto you: But this one compri≈øeth many, It is a nea≈øt of wa≈øpes, or ≈øwarm of vermine, which have overcrept the land, I mean the Monopoles and Polers of the people; The≈øe like the Frogs of Aegypt have gotten po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of our dwellings, and have ≈øcarce a room free from them: They ≈øup in our Cup, they dip in our Di≈øh, they ≈øit by our fire, we finde them in the Dy fat, wa≈øh-boule, and Poudering tub, they ≈øhare with the Butler in his box, they have marked and ≈øealed us from head to foot. Mr. Speaker, they will not bate us a Pin: we may not buy our own Cloathes without their brokage; The≈øe are the Leeches that have ≈øuckt the Common wealth ≈øo hard, that it is almo≈øt become hecticall: And Mr. Speaker, ≈øome of the≈øe are a≈øhamed of their right names; they have a vizard to hide the brand made by that good law in the la≈øt Parliament of King James; They ≈øhelter them≈øelves under the name of a Corporation, they make by-laws which ≈øerve their turns to ≈øquee≈øe us, and fill their pur≈øes; unface the≈øe and they will prove as bad Cards as any in the pack; The≈øe are not petty Chapmen, but whole≈øale men. Mr. Speaker, I have ecchoed to you the cryes of the kingdome, I will tell you their hopes: they look to Heaven for a ble≈ø≈øing upon this Parliament, they hang upon his Maje≈øties
exemplary piety and great ju≈øtice, which renders his eares open to the ju≈øt complaints of his Subjects; we have had lately a gratious a≈ø≈øurance of it, they are the wi≈øe conduct of this, whereby the other great affaires of the Kingdome, and this our grievance of no le≈ø≈øe import; And this may go hand in hand, in preparation and re≈øolution; Then by the ble≈ø≈øing of God we ≈øhall return home with an Olive branch in our mouths, and full confirmations of the priviledges, which we received from our Ance≈øtors, and ow to our po≈øterity, which every freeborn Engli≈øh man hath received with the aire he breathed in.
The≈øe are our hopes, The≈øe are our prayers.

div.head: Mr. BAGSHAW his ≈øpeech in Parliament, 7 die Novemb. 1640.
div.p:
I Had rather Act then ≈øpeak in tho≈øe weighty bu≈øine≈ø≈øes of the Kingdome, which have been ≈øo excellently handled by the≈øe foure worthy Gentlemen, that ≈øpake la≈øt, and therefore I ≈øhall be ≈øhort. For when I look upon the Body of this goodly and flouri≈øhing Kingdom in matters of Religion, and of our laws, (For like Hippocrates Twins, they live and dye together) I ≈øay when I behold the≈øe in that ≈øtate and plight, as they have been repre≈øented to us, Flere magis libet quam dicere; But this is our comfort, Mr. Speaker, that we are all met together for the welfare and happine≈ø≈øe of Prince and People; And who knows whether this may not be the appointed
time, wherein God will re≈øtore our Religion as at the fir≈øt, and our laws as at the beginning.

The honour of a King con≈øi≈øteth in the weale of his people: this undoubted maxime his Maje≈øty hath made good by his late gracious ≈øpeech and promi≈øe to us to redre≈ø≈øe all our grievances, to de≈øtroy the enemies of our Peace, and plenty.

To make a people rich, they mu≈øt have ea≈øe & ju≈øtice. Ea≈øe in their Con≈øciences from the bane of Super≈øtition, from the intolerable burthen of innovation in Religion, and from the racks and tortures of ≈øtrange and new fangled Oaths. They mu≈øt be ea≈øed in their per≈øons, being liberi homines, and not Vilanes; All illegall arre≈øts and impri≈øonment again≈øt Magna Charta, being our greate≈øt liberties. They mu≈øt be ea≈øed in their lands from Forre≈øt, where never any Deer fed, from depopulations, where never any Farm was decayed, and from inclo≈øures, where never any hedges were ≈øet. But mu≈øt la≈øtly be ea≈øed in their goods from their exactions and expilations of Pur≈øevants and Apparitors, of Projectors and Monopoli≈øts, Humanarum Calamitatum mercatores, as an ancient finely calls them: and if the people have all the≈øe ea≈øements, yet if they have not Ju≈øtice, they cannot ≈øub≈øi≈øt; ju≈øtice is to the Civill body, as food to the naturall; If the ≈øtreams of Ju≈øtice be by unrighteou≈øne≈ø≈øe turned into Gall and Wormword, or by cruelty, like the Aegyptian waters, be turned into blood, tho≈øe which drink of the≈øe brooks mu≈øt needs dy and peri≈øh.

The Law ≈øaith that all Ju≈øtice is in the King, who is ≈øtiled in our book Fons Ju≈øtitiae, and he commits it to his Judges, for the execution wherein he tru≈øts them with two of the chiefe≈øt flowers, which belong to his crown: The admini≈øtration of his ju≈øtice, and the expo≈øition of his laws: but he will not tru≈øt them without an Oath required of them, by the Statute of 18 E. 31. Which is ≈øo ≈øtrict and ≈øevere, that it made a Judge
whom I know, though hone≈øt and ≈øtrict, yet to quake and tremble at the very mention of it. The effect of the Oath is, that they ≈øhould doe equall law, and execution of right to all the Kings Subjects, poore a≈øwell as rich, without regard of any per≈øon.

That they ≈øhould not deny to doe common right to any man by the Kings letters; and for any other cau≈øe: And in ca≈øe ≈øuch letters do, that they proceed to do come the law notwith≈øtanding ≈øuch letters, or for any other cau≈øes, as they will an≈øwer to the King, in bodies, goods, and lands: how this Oath hath been performed, we have ≈øeen and felt; I need ≈øay no more. But when I ca≈øt mine eyes upon the inferiour Courts of Ju≈øtice, wherein no ≈øuch oath is required; I meane, the High Commi≈ø≈øion, and other Eccle≈øia≈øticall Courts, my ≈øoule hath bled for the wrong pre≈ø≈øures which I have ob≈øerved to have been done and committed in the≈øe Courts, again≈øt the Kings good people; e≈øpecially for the mo≈øt mon≈øtrous abu≈øe of the Oath Ex Officio; which, as it is now u≈øed, I can call no other than Carnificina Con≈øcientiae: I have ≈øome rea≈øon to know this, that have been an Attendant to the Court the≈øe five yeeres for my ≈øelfe, and a deare friend of mine, ≈øometimes Knight of our Shire, for a meer triviall bu≈øine≈ø≈øe; that the mo≈øt that could be proved again≈øt him, was the putting on his hat in the time of Sermon. Of which Court I ≈øhall ≈øay more, and make good what I ≈øay, when tho≈øe ulcers come to be opened.

Mr. Speaker, I ≈øay the≈øe foure worthies that ≈øpake before me, have told you of our mi≈øeries; but I cannot tell you of the remedies: For things are come to that height, that I may ≈øay, as Livy ≈øayd of the Roman ≈øtate in his time, Nec Vitia no≈øtra ≈øcire po≈ø≈øumus ne ‚Ä¢ Remedia; for no Laws will now doe us good; Better Laws could not have been made, then the Stat. of Monopolies, again≈øt Projectors, and the Petition of right again≈øt the infringers of liberties; and yet as if the Law had bin the Author
of them, there hath been within the≈øe few years more Monopolies and infringment of liberties, than hath been in any age ≈øince the Conque≈øt: and if all tho≈øe vile Harlets, as Queen Elizabeth called them, that have been the Authors of tho≈øe Evils and the Troublers of our I≈ørael doe go unpuni≈øhed; it will never be better with us; for now during Parliament, like frozen Snakes their poy≈øon dryes up, but let the Parliament di≈ø≈øolve, and then their poy≈øon melts and ≈øcatters abroad, and doth more hurt then ever. What then mu≈øt be done? Why? what the Play≈øter cannot doe, mu≈øt be done by the Law: En≈øe recidendum e≈øt, ne pars ≈øincera trahatur. I can not better Engli≈øh it, then in the words of a King, Let them be cut of in their wickedne≈ø≈øe, that have framed mi≈øchiefe as a Law. My conclu≈øion, Mr. Speaker, is this; Let the wofull violation of the State of Monopolies, and the Petition of Right be made Felony, or Premunire at the lea≈øt, but yet in the interim let them be made examples of puni≈øhment, who have been the Authors of all tho≈øe mi≈øeries, according to the Coun≈øell of Salomon, Take away the wicked from before the King, and his Throne ≈øhall be E≈øtabli≈øhed in Righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe.

div.head: To the right Honorable the Lords Spirituall and Temporall in the high Court of Parliament a≈ø≈øembled, The humble Petition of Thomas Earle of Strafford his Maje≈øties Lievtenant Generall of Ireland
div.p:
THat in obedience to your Lord≈øhips order, and in due re≈øpect and acknowledgment of your noble
ju≈øtice you vouch≈øafed this your Petitioner the other day, he now expre≈ø≈øeth in writing that humble reque≈øt that he then made, concerning the examining of witne≈ø≈øes; which, with your Lord≈øhips favor, was this,
1 That there might be no admi≈ø≈øion of any examination of witne≈ø≈øes in the cau≈øe, till your Petitioner hath put in his an≈øwer to the charge of Trea≈øon, exhibited again≈øt him.

2 That after an≈øwer, no witne≈ø≈øes ≈øhould be examined, before your Petitioner had the names of ≈øuch witne≈ø≈øes delivered unto him by your Lord≈øhips order, to the intent (as by his Councell he ≈øhould be advi≈øed) he might either except again≈øt ≈øuch witne≈ø≈øes, or cro≈ø≈øe-examine them.

3 That before either of the≈øe two points ≈øhould be over-ruled again≈øt your Petitioners, your Lord≈øhips would be honorably plea≈øed to heare him by his Councell, at the Barre, to ≈øhew cau≈øe why he humbly conceives his de≈øires herein to be ju≈øt and rea≈øonable.

Finally, your Petitioner humbly craves your Lord≈øhips remi≈ø≈øion, if his Petition be not ≈øo formall as it ought, and might be, had he the help of Councell: And ≈øhall ever with all expre≈ø≈øion of duty and thankfulne≈ø≈øe, retaine in full memory your Lord≈øhips mo≈øt honourable Ju≈øtice, and noble re≈øpects to your Petitioner the other day; and pay your Lord≈øhips the duties of this whole life for the ≈øame; and alwayes, and unfainedly pray for your mo≈øt noble Lord≈øhips increa≈øe of all everla≈øting honour and happine≈ø≈øe.

div.head: Concerning the Prices of Wine, &c. Die Mercurii, Maii 26. 1641.
div.p: UPon the whole matter of the Report,
It was re≈øolved upon the que≈øtion,
1 That the Patent for the payment of 40 ≈øhillings per Tun on the Wines by the Merchants, is illegall in the creation, and a grievance.
2 That the impo≈øition of a penny on a quart on French Wines, and two pence on a quart on Spani≈øh Wines, is a grievance.
3 That the Patent of the impo≈øition of 40 ≈øhillings per Tun, is a grievance in the execution.
4 That Alderman Abel, and Ma≈øter Richard Kilvert are the principall Projectors both in the creation and execution of this illegall impo≈øition of 40 ≈øhill. per Tun.

p.hi: Re≈øolved upon the que≈øtion,

div.p: That there ≈øhalbe a Bill prepared, declaring the offences of Alderman Abel, and Richard Kilvert, to the end they may be made exemplary.

p.hi: Re≈øolved, &c

div.p: That a ≈øelect Committee be named, to examine who were the Referrers Advi≈øers, Sharers, Complotters and Contractors, and tho≈øe that have received any bribe or benefit by this Patent, and who drew the Patent.

p.hi: Re≈øolved, &c.

div.p: That the Proclamation dated the 15th of July, in the 14th yeare of the King, prohibiting the Wine-Coopere to buy and ≈øell Wine, is illegall, and again≈øt the liberty of the Subject.

p.hi: Re≈øolved, &c.

div.p: That the Decree-made in the Star-chamber in December 1633. prohibiting retailing Vintners to dre≈ø≈øe meat in their own hou≈øes, to ≈øell againe to gue≈øts, is illegall, and again≈øt the liberty of the Subject.

div.head: Sir Thomas Rowe his Speech at the Councell Table, touching Bra≈ø≈øe-Mony, or again≈øt Bra≈ø≈øe-Money, with many notable ob≈øervations thereupon, July, 1640.
div.p: MY Lords, ≈øince it hath plea≈øed this Honorable table, to command among≈øt others my poore opinion concerning this waighty propo≈øition of money, I mu≈øt humbly crave pardon, if with that freedome that becometh my duty to my good and gracious Ma≈øter, and my obedience to your great commands, I deliver it ≈øo.
I cannot my Lords, but a≈ø≈øuredly conceive this intended project of infeobling the Coyn, will trench very far both into the honor of Ju≈øtice, and profit of my Royall Ma≈øter.

All e≈øtates do ≈øtand Magis fa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ a quam vi as Tacitus ≈øaith of Rome; And wealth in every Kingdome is one of the e≈ø≈øentiall marks of their greatne≈ø≈øe, and is be≈øt expre≈ø≈øed in the mea≈øures and purity of their moneys. Hence it was that ≈øo long as the Romane Empire, a pattern of the be≈øt Government held up their glory, or greatne≈ø≈øe, they ever maintained with little or no change the ≈øtandard of their Coyn, but after the loo≈øe time of Commodus had led in need by exce≈ø≈øe, and ≈øo by that ≈øhift of changing the ≈øtandard, the Maje≈øty of that Empire fell by degrees. And as Vopi≈øcus ≈øaith, the ≈øteps by which that State de≈øcended, were vi≈øible mo≈øt by the generall alteration of their Coynes; and there is no ≈øurer ≈øimptomes of con≈øumption in State, then the corruption of the Money.

What Renowne is left to the Po≈øterity of Edw. 1. in amending
the ≈øtandard both in puritie and weight, from that of elder and barbarous times; it mu≈øt needs ≈øtick as a blemi≈øh upon Princes that do the contrary.

Thus we ≈øee it was with Hen. 6. who after he had begun with abaiting the mea≈øures, he afterwards fell to aba≈øing the matter; and gr ‚Ä¢ nted Commi≈ø≈øion to Mi≈ø≈øend, and others to practi≈øe Alcamie to ≈øerve his Mint.

The extremity the State in generall felt by this agrievance, be≈øides the di≈øhonor it layd upon the per≈øon of the King, was not the lea≈øt di≈øadvantage his di≈øloyall kin≈øman tooke, to ingrace him≈øelfe into the peoples favours, to his Soveraigns Reign.
When Hen. the 8th. had gained as much of power and glory abroad, of love and obedience at home as ever any, he ≈øuffered a lo≈ø≈øe by this Rock.

When his Daughter Queene Elizabeth came to the Crowne, ≈øhe was happier in Councell to amend that error of her Father, for in a memoriall of the Lord Trea≈øurer Burleighs his hand, I finde that he and Sir Thomas Smith, a grave and learned man, advi≈øed the Queen that it was the Crown, and the true wealth of her ≈øelfe and people, to reduce the ≈øtandard to the antient party, and purity of her great Grandfather Edward the 4th. and that it was not the ≈øhort end of wits, nor ≈øtarting holes of devi≈øes, that can ≈øu≈øtain the expence of a Monarchy, but ≈øound and ≈øolid cour≈øes, for ≈øo are the words; She followed their a devi≈øe, and began to reduce the money the moneys to their elder goodne≈ø≈øe, ≈øtiling this worke in her fir≈øt Proclamation Anno 30. a famous Act. The next year following, Anno 30. having perfected, as it after ≈øtood, She telleth her people by another Edict; That She had conquered now that mon≈øter that had ≈øo long devoured them, meaning the variation of the ≈øtandard. And ≈øo long as that ≈øad advi≈øer lived, She never (though often by Projectors importuned) could be drawne to any ≈øhift or change in her Moneys.

To avoyd the trouble of permutation, Coyners devi≈øed as a rule and mea≈øure of Marchandize and Manufactaries, which if mutable, no man can tell either what he hath, or what he oweth, no contract can be certain, and ≈øo all commerce both publike and private de≈øtroyed, and men again enforced to permutation
with things not ≈øubject to will and fraud.

The Regulating of Coyn hath been left to the care of Princes, who have ever beene pre≈øumed to be the Fathers of the Common-wealth, upon their honors they are debtors and warrants to the ≈øubjects in that behalfe.

They cannot ≈øaith Bodin, alter the price of moneys to the preiudice of the ≈øubiect, without incurring the reproach of Faux moneyars. And therefore ≈øtories terme Phillip le Belle fal≈øificator de monet. omnino monet. integritas debet quaeri ubi vultiis no≈øter Imprimatur, ≈øaid Theodoret the Goth to his Mint-ma≈øter. Quidnam erit tutum ≈øi no≈øtra peccetur effigie, Princes mu≈øt not ≈øuffer their faces to warrant fal≈øhood.

Although I am not of opinion with the Minor des Ju≈øtices, the anciente≈øt books of the Common-Law, That Le Roy ne poit ≈øa money impaire ne a mander ≈øaus La≈ø≈øent des touts les Counties, which was the great coun≈øell of the Kingdome. Yet cannot I pa≈ø≈øe over the goodne≈ø≈øe and grace of many other our Kings, as Edw. 1. Edw. 3. Hen. 4. and the 5th. and others; who out of the rule of their Ju≈øtice. Quod ad omnes ≈øpecrat, ob omnibus debet approbari, have often advi≈øed with their people in Parliament, both for the Allay, weight, number of peeces, rate of Coynage and exchange, and mo≈øt with infinite goodne≈ø≈øe acknowledg the care and Ju≈øtice now of my good Ma≈øter, and your Lord≈øhips wi≈øedomes, that would not upon the information of ≈øome few officers of the Mint, before a free and carefull debate, put in execution this Proiect. Yet I mu≈øt under your Lord≈øhips favour ≈øu≈øpect it would have taken away the tenth part of every mans due debt or rent alreadie re≈øerved throughout the Realm, not ≈øparing the King, which could have been little le≈ø≈øe then a ≈øpecies of that which the Roman ≈øtories call Tabula nova, from whence every ≈øedition hath ≈øprang, as that of Marius Grantidianus in Livio, who pretending in his Con≈øul≈øhip, thatt the currant money was wa≈øted by us, called it in, and altered the Standard, which grew ≈øo heavie and grievous to the people, as the Author ≈øayth, becau≈øe thereby no man knoweth certainly his wealth, that it cau≈øed a tumult.

In this la≈øt part which is the di≈øprofit that the enfeobling the Coyn, will bring both to his Maie≈øty, and to the Common-wealth.
I mu≈øt di≈øtingui≈øh the moneyes of gold and ≈øilver as they are bullion and commodities, and as they are mea≈øures, the one of the extrin≈øique quality, which is at the Kings plea≈øure, as all other mea≈øures to name, the other the intrin≈øique quality, of pure mettall, which is in the Merchant to value as their mea≈øure, ≈øhall be either to be le≈ø≈øened or enlarged, ≈øo is the quantity of the commodity that is to be exchanged, if then the King ≈øhall cut his ≈øhilling or pound in money le≈ø≈øe than it was before, a le≈ø≈øe portion of ≈øuch commodities as ≈øhall be exchanged, for it, mu≈øt be received, it mu≈øt then of force follow, that all things of nece≈ø≈øity, as victualls, apparell, and the re≈øt as well as tho≈øe of plea≈øure, mu≈øt be inhaun≈øed. If then all men ≈øhall receive in their ≈øhillings and pounds a le≈ø≈øe proportion of ≈øilver and gold than they did before this projected alteration, and pay for what they buy at a rate enhaun≈øed, it mu≈øt ca≈øt upon all a double lo≈ø≈øe, what the King will ≈øuffer by it in the Rents of his lands, is demon≈øtrated enough by the alteration ≈øince the 18 of Ed. 3. when all the Revenues of the Crown came unto the receipts pondere & numero, after 5 Groats the Ounce, which ≈øince that time by ≈øeverall changes of the Standard is come to 5 s. whereby the King hath two third parts of his ju≈øt Revenues.

In his Cu≈øtomes, the book of rates being regulated by pounds and ≈øhillings, his Maje≈øty mu≈øt lo≈øe alike, and ≈øo in all and what≈øoever moneyes, that after this he mu≈øt receive the profits of his Coynage, cannot be much more permanent in the lo≈ø≈øe la≈øting, and ≈øo long as it reacheth to little le≈ø≈øe than yeerly, to accept part of his Revenue, for in every pound tale of gold is 7 Ounces, 1 d. weight, and 19 grains lo≈ø≈øe, which 25 l. in accompt, and in 700 l. tail of ≈øilver, which is 14 l. 17 s. more. And his Maje≈øty ≈øhall undergo all this lo≈ø≈øe hereafter, in all his receipts, ≈øo ≈øhall he no le≈ø≈øe in all his dibur≈øments, the wages of his ≈øouldiers mu≈øt be ratably advanced, as the money is decrea≈øed. This Edward the 3, as appeareth by the accounts of the Wardrobe and Exchequer, as all the Kings after him were inforced to do, as often as the le≈ø≈øened Standard of the moneyes of what ≈øhall be bought for his Maje≈øties ≈øervice, mu≈øt in like manner be inhaun≈øed on him. As his Maje≈øty hath the greate≈øt profits of receipts and i≈ø≈øues, ≈øo mu≈øt be of nece≈ø≈øity ta≈øte of the mo≈øt lo≈ø≈øe by this device.

It will de≈øtroy or di≈øcourage a great proportion of the trade in England, Impair his Maie≈øties Cu≈øtomes for that part, being not the lea≈øt that pa≈ø≈øeth upon tru≈øt and credit will be overthrown, for all men being doubtfull of diminution hereby of there per≈øonall e≈øtates will call in their moneys, already out, and no man will part with that which is lying by him uppon apparant lo≈ø≈øe, as this mu≈øt bring; what dammage may befall the State by ≈øuch a ≈øudden ≈øtand of Trade I cannot gue≈ø≈øe.

The moneys both of gold and ≈øilver formerly Coyned and abroad, richer then tho≈øe intended, will be made of the mo≈øt nereby Bulloin and ≈øo tran≈øported; which I conceive will be none of the lea≈øt inducements that hath drawn ≈øo many Gold≈ømithes to ≈øide this Proiect, that they may be thereby Factors for the Strangers, who by the Law of Mintage bring but two ≈øhillings ≈øilver to the pound waight, and 4 ≈øhillings for gold; whereas with us the one is _____ and the other 5 ≈øhillings, many make that profit beyond the Sea, they cannot here, and ≈øo his Maie≈øties Mint un≈øet of worke.

And as his Maie≈øties lo≈ø≈øe appeareth in the alteration of many a 14th in the ≈øilver, and a 25th part in all the gold they after ≈øhall receive; ≈øo ≈øhall the Nobilitie, Gentry, and all other landed men in all their former ≈øetled Rents, Annuities, Pen≈øions, and ≈øums of money, the like will fall upon the labourers and workemen in their ≈øtatute wages. And as their receipts are le≈ø≈øened hereby, ≈øo are their i≈ø≈øues increa≈øed either by improving all prices, or di≈øfurni≈øhing the Market, which mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily follow; for in the 5th of Edw. 6th. 3o Mary, 4to Eliz. as appeareth by their Proclamations. That a Rumour only of alteration cau≈øed ≈øuch effects, puni≈øhing the author of ≈øuch reports, with Impri≈øonment, and Pillory. It cannot be doubted, but the proiecting of ≈øuch a change, mu≈øt be of far greater con≈øequence and danger to the State, and would be wi≈øhed that the Actors, and authors of ≈øuch di≈øturbances in the Common-wealth at all times hereafter, might undergo a puni≈øhment proportionable.

It cannot be held, I pre≈øume, an advi≈øe of be≈øt iudgement that layeth the lo≈ø≈øe upon our ≈øelves, and the gain upon our enemies, for who are like to be in this the greate≈øt thrivers, is not vi≈øible that the ≈øtrangers who ≈øupport, or money for bullion, our own Gold-≈ømiths, who are their Brokers, and the Hedgminters of the
Netherlands, who tearmed them well, will have a fre≈øh and full trade by this aba≈øements. And we do not the Spani≈øh King, our greate≈øt enemy, a greater favour than by his, who being Lord of the≈øe commodities by his We≈øt-Indies, we ≈øhall ≈øo advance them to our impoveri≈øhment, for it is not in the power of any State to rai≈øe of the price of their own, but the value that their neighbours, ≈øet upon them, experience hath taught us that the enfoebling of Coyn is but a ≈øhift for a while, as drinke to one in a drop≈øie, to make him ≈øwell the more, but the ≈øtate was never thorowly cured, as we ≈øaw in Henry the Eighths time, and the late Queens, untill the Coyn was made rich again.

I cannot but then conclude my honorable Lords, that if the proportion of Gold and Silver to each other be wrought to that purity, by the advice of the Arti≈øts that neither may be too rich for the other, that the Mintage may be reduced to ≈øome proportion of neighbour parts, and that the i≈ø≈øue of native commodities may be brought to over-ballance the entrance of the forraigne, we need not ≈øeek any ≈øhift, but ≈øhall again ≈øee our trade to flouri≈øh, the Mint as, the pul≈øe of the Common-wealth, again to bear, and our Materialls by Indu≈øtry, to be Mynes of Gold and Silver, which we all wi≈øh and work for, ≈øupported unto us, and the honor of Ju≈øtice, and Profit of his Maie≈øty.

div.head: Certain general Rules collected concerning Money and Bullion, out of the late Con≈øultation at Court.
div.p: GOld and ≈øilver hath a two fold e≈øtimation in the extrin≈øique, as they are moneys, and Princes mea≈øures given to his people, and this is a Prerogative of Kings in the Intrin≈øique, they are commodities valewing each other according to the plenty or ≈øcarcity; and ≈øo all other commodities by them, and that is the ≈øole power of Trade.

The mea≈øure in a Kingdome ought to be con≈øtant, It is the Ju≈øtice and honor of the King; for if they be altered, all men at that time are deceived in the precedent contracts, either for lands or moneys, and the King mo≈øt of all; for no man knoweth either what he hath, or what he oweth.

This made the Lord Trea≈øurer Burleigh in Anno 1573. when ≈øome Projectors had ≈øet on foot a matter of that nature, to tell them that they were worthy to ≈øuffer death, for attempting to
put ≈øo great a di≈øhonor upon the Queen, and detriment and di≈øcontent on the people; for to alter this publike mea≈øure is to leave all the Markets of the Kingdome unfurni≈øhed: and what will be the mi≈øchiefe the Proclamation of 5. and 6. 3o. Mary, and 4th. of Eliz. will manife≈øt, when but a rumor produced that effect ≈øo farre, that be≈øides the faith of the Princes to the contrary delivered in their Edicts, they were inforced to cau≈øe the Magi≈øtrates in every Shire re≈øpectively, to con≈øtrain the people to furni≈øh the Market, to prevent a mutiny.

To thinke then this mea≈øure at this time ≈øhort, is to rai≈øe all prices, or to turn the mea≈øure or money now current into di≈øu≈øe and Bullion; for who will depart with any, when it is by ≈øeven more in the hundred in the ma≈ø≈øe, then the now moneys, and yet of no more value in the Market.

Hence the nece≈ø≈øitie of it will follow, that there will not of a long time be Minted of the new to drive the exchange of the Kingdome, and ≈øo all trade at one in≈øtance at a ≈øtand; and in meane time the Markets unfurni≈øhed, and thus far as money is a mea≈øure.
Now as it is a commoditie, it is re≈øpected and valued, by the intrin≈øique qualitie, and fir≈øt the one mettall to the other.

All commodities are priced by plenty or ≈øcarcity, by dearene≈ø≈øe or cheapne≈ø≈øe, the one to the other. If then we de≈øire our ≈øilver to buy gold as it hath lately been, we mu≈øt let it it be the cheaper and le≈ø≈øe in proportion valued, and ≈øo contrary for one equivalent proportion in both, will bring in neither; we ≈øee the profit there of the unu≈øuall quantitie of gold brought lately to the Mint by rea≈øon of the price, we rate it at above all other Countries, and gold may be bought too dear; to furni≈øh then this way the Mint with both, is impo≈ø≈øible.

And at this time it was apparantly proved both by the be≈øt Arti≈øts, and marchants mo≈øt acquainted with the Exchange, in both the examples of the Mint-ma≈øters, in the Rix-dolor, and Royall of Eight, that ≈øilver here is of equall valew, and gold above with forreine parts in the intrin≈øique, but that the fallacie pre≈øented to the Lords by the Mint-ma≈øters, is only in the nomination of extrin≈øique qualitie.

But if we de≈øire both it is not the ray≈øing the valew that doth it, but the balancing the Trade, for we buy more then we ≈øell of
all other commodities, be the money never ≈øo high priced, we mu≈øt part with it to make the di≈øproportion even, if we ≈øell more then the contrary will follow.

And this is plain in Spani≈øh nece≈ø≈øities, for ≈øhould that King advance to a double his Royall of Eight, yet needing it by rea≈øon of the barrenne≈ø≈øe of his Country, more of forreign wares, then can countervaile by exchange with his wares, he mu≈øt then part with his money, and gain the more by enhaun≈øing his coyn, but he payeth a higher price for the commodities he buyeth, if this work of ray≈øing be his own.
But if we ≈øhall make improvement of gold and ≈øilver being the Staple-commodities of this Kingdome, we then advancing the the price of his aba≈øe to him our own commodities.

To ≈øhape this kingdome to the fa≈øhion of the Netherlands, were to frame a Royall Monarchie by a ≈øociety of Marchants, their Country is a continuall Faire, and ≈øo price of moneys mu≈øt ri≈øe and fall to fit their occa≈øions; we ≈øee this by rai≈øing the Exchange of Franckford, and other places, of their u≈øuall time of the Marts.

This frequent and daily change in the Low-Countries of their moneys is no ≈øuch inju≈øtice to any there, as it would be here, for there they being all Merchants, or mechanicks, they can rate accordingly their labour and their Ware, whether it be Coyne, or other merchandize, to the pre≈øent condition of their own money in Exchange.

And our Engli≈øh Merchants to who≈øe profe≈ø≈øion it properly belongeth, do ≈øo according to their ju≈øt intrin≈øique valew of their forreign Coyn in all barter of commodities or Exchange, except u≈øance which we that are rated and tyed by the extrin≈øiques mea≈øure of moneys in all our con≈øtant reckonigs, and annuall bargains at home cannot do.

And for us then to rai≈øe our Coyn at this time, to equall their proportions were but to render our ≈øelves to a perpetuall incertainty, for they will rai≈øe upon us daily them again, which we of cour≈øe ≈øhall follow, el≈øe receive no profit by this pre≈øent change; and ≈øo de≈øtroy the Policie, Ju≈øtice, honor, and tranquilitie of our State for ever.

div.head: To the Right Honourable the Lord Deputy.
The ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ mble and ju≈øt Remon≈øtrance of the Knights, Cittizens and Burge≈ø≈øes in Parliament a≈ø≈øembled.
div.p:
SHewing that in all ages ≈øince the happy ≈øubjection of this Kingdome to the Imperiall Crowne of England it was and is a principall ≈øtudy and Princely care of his Maje≈øty and his mo≈øt noble Progenitors, Kings and Queens of England, and Ireland, to the va≈øt expence of trea≈øure and blood; That their loyall and dutifull people of this Land of Ireland, beeing now for the mo≈øt part derived from Britti≈øh Ance≈øtors, ≈øhould be governed according to the municipall and fundamentall Lawes of England; That the ≈øtatute of Magna Charta, or the great Charter of the liberties of England, and other laudable lawes and ≈øtatutes were in ≈øeverall Parliaments heere enacted and declared; that by the means thereof & of the mo≈øt prudent & benign government of his Maje≈øtie & his Royall Progenitors, this Kingdome was untill of late in its growth a flouri≈øhing e≈øtate, whereby the ≈øaid people were heretofore enab ‚Ä¢ ed to a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ iver their humble and naturall de≈øires, to comply with his Maje≈øties Princely and royall occa≈øions, by their free gift of 150. thou≈øand pounds ≈øterling: and likewi≈øe by another free gift of 120. thou≈øand pounds more, during the government of the Lord Vi≈øcount Faulkland, and after by the gift of 40. thou≈øand pounds, and their free and cheerefull gift of ≈øi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ intire Sub≈øidies, in the tenth yeare of his Maje≈øties Reign ‚Ä¢ , which to comply with his Maje≈øties then occa≈øions, ≈øignified to the then hou≈øe of Commons they did allow ≈øhould ammount
in the Collections unto 2 hundred and fifty thou≈øand pounds (although as they confidently believe) if the Sub≈øidies had been levyed in a moderate Parliamentary way, they would not have amounted to much more then halfe the ≈øum afore≈øaid, be≈øides the foure intire Sub≈øidies graunted in this pre≈øent Parliament.

Soe it is, may it plea≈øe your Lord≈øhip, by the occa≈øion of in≈øuing and other grievances and Innovations, though to his Maje≈øty no con≈øiderable profit this Kingdome is reduced to that extreame and univer≈øall poverty, that the ≈øame is le≈ø≈øe able to pay 2 Sub≈øidies then it was hertofore to ≈øatisfie all the before-recyted great payments & his Maje≈øties mo≈øt faithfull people of the Land, do conceive great fears, that the ≈øaid grievances and con≈øequences thereof, may be hereafter drawne into pre≈øidents, to be perpetuated upon their po≈øterity which in their great hopes and ≈øtrong beliefe, they are per≈øwaded is contrary to his Royall and Princely intention towards his ≈øaid people, of which greivances are as followeth:

1, Fir≈øt, the generall apparant decay of Trades, occa≈øioned by the new and illegall rai≈øing of the booke of rates, and impo≈øitions upon native, and other Commodities, exported and imported, by rea≈øon whereof and of extreame u≈øage and cen≈øures, Merchants are beggered both, and di≈øinabled and di≈øcouraged to Trade; and ≈øome of the honourable per≈øons who gaine thereby often Iudges and parties. And that in the conclu≈øion his Maje≈øties profit thereby is not con≈øiderably advanced.

2. The arbitrary deci≈øion of all civill cau≈øes and controver≈øies by paper petitions, before the Lord Lieutenant and Lord Deputy, and infinite other Iudicatories upon references from them derived in the nature of all actions determinable at the Common Law, not limited into certaine time, cau≈øe ≈øea≈øon or thing what≈øoever: And the con≈øequences of ≈øuch exceeding by immoderate and unlawfull fees, by Secretaries Clarkes, Pur≈øivants, Serjeants at Armes, and otherwi≈øe, by which kinde of proceedings his Maje≈øty loo≈øeth a con≈øiderable
part of his revenue upon originall writs, and other wi≈øe: and the Subject loo≈øeth the benefit of his writ of Error, bill of rever≈øall, vouchees, and other legall and ju≈øt advantages and the ordinary cour≈øe and Courts of Iu≈øtice declined.
3. The proceedings in civill cau≈øes at Coun≈øell board, contrary to the Law and great Charter, not limited to any certaine time or ≈øea≈øon.

4 That the Subject is in all the materiall parts thereof denyed the benefit of the Princely graces, and more e≈øpecially of the ≈øtatute of limitations of 21. of Iac. Graunted by his Maje≈øty in the fourth yeare of his Raigne, upon great advice of Coun≈øell of England and Ireland, and for great con≈øideration, and then publi≈øhed in all the Courts of Dublin, and in all the Counties of this Kingdome in open a≈ø≈øizes, whereby all per≈øons doe take notice, that contrary to his Maje≈øties pious intentions, his Subjects of this land have not enjoyed the benefit of his Maje≈øties Princelie promi≈øe thereby made.

5. The extrajudiciall avoyding of Letters Pattents of e≈øtates; of a very great part of his Maje≈øties ≈øubjects under the great Seale (the publique faith of the Kingdome) by private opinions, delivered at the Coun≈øell board without legall evictions of their e≈øtates, contrary to the law, and without pre≈øident or example of any former age.

6. The Proclamation for the ≈øole emption and uttering of Tobacco, which is bought at every low rates, and uttered at high and exce≈ø≈øive rates, by meanes whereof thou≈øands of families within this Kingdome, and of his Maje≈øties Subjects, in ≈øeverall Ilands, and other parts of the We≈øt Indies (as your Petitioners are informed) are de≈øtroyed; and the mo≈øt part of the coyn of this Kingdome is ingro≈ø≈ø ed into particular hands: In≈øomuch as the petitioners do conceive that the proffit ari≈øing and engro≈ø≈øed thereby doth ≈øurmount his Maje≈øtyes revenue, certain or co≈øuall, within this Kingdome, and yet his Maje≈øty receiveth but very little profit by the ≈øame.
7. The univer≈øall and unlawfull increa≈øing of Monopolies, to the advantage of a few, to the di≈øprofit of his Maje≈øty, and Impoveri≈øhment of his people.

8. The extream and cruell u≈øage of certain late Commi≈ø≈øioners, and other ≈øtewards, the Britti≈øh Farmers and Inhabitants of the City and County of London Derry, by meanes whereof the worthy Plantation of that Country is almo≈øt de≈øtroyed, and the Inhabitants are reduced to great poverty, and many of them forced to for≈øake the Countrey, the ≈øame beeing the fir≈øt and mo≈øt u≈øefull Plantation in the large Province of that Ul≈øter, to the great weakning of the Kingdome, in in this time of danger, the ≈øaid plantation being the principall ≈øtrength of tho≈øe parts.

9. The late erection of the Court of high Commi≈ø≈øion, for cau≈øes‚ñ™ Eccle≈øia≈øticall in tho≈øe nece≈ø≈øitous times, the proceedings of the ≈øaid Court, in many cau≈øes without legal warrant, and yet ≈øo ≈øupported as prohibitions have not been obtained, though legally ≈øought for: And the exce≈ø≈øive fees exacted by the Mini≈øters thereof, and the encroaching of the ≈øame upon the juri≈ødiction of other Eccle≈øia≈øticall Courts of this Kingdome.
10. The exorbitant fees and pretended Cu≈øtomes exacted by the Clergy again≈øt the Law, ≈øome of which have been formerly repre≈øented to your Lord≈øhip.

11. The Petitioners doe mo≈øt heartily bemone that his Maje≈øties ≈øervice and profit are much more impaired then advanced, by the grievances afore≈øaid; & the Sub≈øidies graunted in the la≈øt Parliament, having much increa≈øed his Maje≈øties revenue, by the buying of graunts, and otherwi≈øe: and that all his Maje≈øties debts then due in this Kingdome, were ≈øatisfied out of the ≈øaid Sub≈øidies; and yet his Maje≈øty is of late, (as the petitioners have been informed, in the hou≈øe of Commons) become indepted in this Kingdome, in great ≈øomes; And they doe therefore humbly be≈øeech, that an exact accompt may bee ≈øent to his Maje≈øty, how and in what manner his trea≈øure i≈ø≈øued.

12. The Petitioners doe humbly conceive ju≈øt and great feares, at a Proclamation publi≈øhed in this Kingdome, in Anno Domini 1635. Prohibiting men of quality or e≈øtates, to depart this Kingdome into England, without the Lord Deputies Licence, wherein the Subjects of this Kingdome are hindered and interrupted from free acce≈ø≈øe, to addres to his ≈øacred Maje≈øty, and privie Coun≈øell of England, to declare their ju≈øt grievances, or to obtaine remedies for them in ≈øuch fort as their Ance≈øtors have done, in all ages ≈øince the Reigne of King Henry the ≈øecond, and great fees exacted, for every of the ≈øaid Licen≈øes.

13. That of late his Maje≈øties late Atourney generall, hath exhibited Informations again≈øt many Boroughs of this Kingdome, into his Maje≈øties Court of Exchequer, to ≈øhew cau≈øe, by what warrant the ≈øaid Burge≈ø≈øes (who heretofore ≈øent Burge≈ø≈øes to the Parliament) ≈øhould ≈øend the Burge≈ø≈øes to the Parliament, and thereupon for want of an an≈øwere, the ≈øaid priviledges of ≈øending Burge≈ø≈øes was ≈øei≈øed by the ≈øaid Court, which proceedings were altogether Coram non Iudice, and contrary to the lawes and priviledges of the hou≈øe of Parliament; (and if way ≈øhould be given thereunto) would tend to the ≈øubver≈øion of Parliaments, and by con≈øequence to the ruine and de≈øtruction of the Common-wealth.
And that the hou≈øe of Commons, hath hitherto in this pre≈øent Parliament, been deprived of the advice and Coun≈øell of many profitable and good members by means thereof.
14. By the powerfulne≈ø≈øe of ≈øome Mini≈øters of ≈øtate in this Kingdome, the Parliament in its members, and actions, hath not his naturall freedome.

15. And la≈øtly, that the Gentry, and Merchants, and other his Maje≈øties Subjects of this Kingdome, are of late by the grievances, and pre≈ø≈øures before ≈øaid, & other the like brought very neere to ruine, and de≈øtruction: And Farmers of Cu≈øtomes, Cu≈øtomers, Waiters, Searchers, Clarkes of unwarrantable proceedings, Pur≈øivants, and Goalers, and ≈øundry others, very much enriched, whereby and by the ≈ølow redre≈ø≈ø
of the petitioners, his Maje≈øties mo≈øt faithfull and dutifull people of this Kingdome, doe conceive great feares, that their readine≈ø≈øe approved upon all occa≈øions, hath not beene of latere pre≈øented to his ≈øacred Maje≈øty: For remedy whereof the ≈øaid Petitioners doe humbly and of right be≈øeech your Lord≈øhip, that the ≈øaid grievances and pre≈ø≈øures may bee ≈øpeedily redre≈ø≈øed, and if your Lord≈øhip ≈øhall not thinke fit to afford pre≈øent reliefe, that your Lord≈øhip might admit a ≈øelect Committee of this hou≈øe of Per≈øons unintere≈ø≈øed in the benefit a ri≈øing of the afore≈øaid grievances to be licen≈øed by your Lord≈øhip, to repaire to his ≈øacred Maje≈øty in England, for to pur≈øue the ≈øame and to obtaine fitting remedy for their afore≈øaid and other ju≈øt grievances and expre≈ø≈øions, and upon all ju≈øt and honourable occa≈øions, they will without re≈øpect of particular intere≈øt or profit, to be rai≈øed thereby mo≈øt humbly and readily in Parliament extend their uttermo≈øt endeavour to ≈øerve his Maje≈øty and comply with his royall and princely occa≈øions, And ≈øhal pray, &c.

div.head: Mr. Secretarie Windebancks Charge in Parliament 7. December 1640.
div.p: 1 SEventie fower Letters of grace to Recu≈øants within this fowr yeares ≈øigned with his owne hands.
2. Sixtie foure Prie≈øts di≈øcharged from the Gatehou≈øe at We≈øtmin≈øter within the≈øe 4. years, and for the mo≈øt part by him.
3. Twenty nine di≈øcharged by a verball warrent from him.
4. Awarrant to protect one Musket a condemned Prie≈øt, and al ‚Ä¢ the hou≈øes he frequented.
5. One committed by the Kings own hand, and di≈øcharged by him without ≈øignifying the Kings plea≈øure.

6. The Retition of the pari≈øh of St. Gyles in the fields to the King of the increa≈øe of Poperie and that 21. were turned by two Prie≈øts Mo≈ø≈øe and Souther, which being committed were ≈øuddenly di≈øcharged by Secretary Windebanck,

div.head: A me≈ø≈øage from the Hou≈øe of Commons to his Maje≈øty 15. December 1640
div.p: IS intreated from this hou≈øe to acquaint his Maje≈øty with the great care and affection of the hou≈øe to advance and ≈øettle his Maje≈øties Revenue, and for that purpo≈øe we humbly de≈øire his Maje≈øty will give us leave to enter into debate of his revenue and his expence.

div.head: His Maje≈øties an≈øwere thereto by Mr. Trea≈øurer.
div.p: HIs Maje≈øty being by me acquainted with the great care and affection of the hou≈øe of Commons to advance and ≈øettle his Maiesties Revenew, doth very graciously interpret the ≈øame, and hath commanded me to give the Hou≈øe thankes for it in his name; and his Maje≈øty doth give the Hou≈øe free leave to enter into debate of his Revenews and Expences, as is de≈øired, and hath given order that all his Officers and Mini≈øters from time to time, ≈øhall a≈ø≈øi≈øt the Hou≈øe therein, as there ≈øhall be occa≈øion.

div.head: Vote concerning the Cannons in the Hou≈øe of Commons. 15. Decem. 1640.
div.p: THat the Clergy of England Convented in any Convocation or Synod, or otherwi≈øe have no power to make any Con≈øtitutions, Cannons or Acts what≈øoever in matter of Doctrine, or otherwi≈øe to bind the Clergy or Laity of this Land without the Commons con≈øent of Parliament.

That the ≈øeverall Con≈øtitutions and Cannons Eccle≈øia≈øticall, Treated upon by the Arch-bi≈øhop of Canterbury, and Yorke, Pre≈øidents of the Convocation for the re≈øpective Provinces of Canterbury and Yorke, and the re≈øt of the Bi≈øhops and Clergy of the≈øe Provinces, and agreed upon by the Kings Maie≈øtics lycence in their ≈øeveral Synods began at London and York 1640. do not bind the Clergy or Laity of this Land, or either of them.

div.head: An Order concerning Monopolers. 19. November 1640.
div.p: JT is ordered that upon the que≈øtion that all Projectors and Monopolizers what≈øoever, or that have had any ≈øhare in any Monopolies, or that doe receive or lately have received any benefit by any Monopolies or Patten, or that have procured any warrant or command, for the re≈øtraynt or mole≈øting of any that have refu≈øed to conforme them≈øelves to any Proclamation or project are di≈øabled by order of this Hou≈øe, and if any man have been known to have been a Monopolizer or Pattentee ≈øhall repaire to have beene a Monopolizer, that he ≈øhall nominate him; that ony member of this Hou≈øe that is a Monopolizer, or Pattentee, ≈øhall repayre to Mr. Speaker, that a new warrant may i≈ø≈øue forth or other wi≈øe that he be dealt with as a ≈øtranger that hath no power to ≈øit here.

div.head: Order again≈øt Monopolies and Pattens 25. Nov. 1640.
div.p: IT is this day ordered in the Commons Hou≈øe now a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament that all Pattens and Grants of Monopolies that have been complained of in this hou≈øe.

div.head: The Scotti≈øh Commi≈ø≈øioners thanks to his Maje≈øty 30. Decemb. 1640.
div.p: WEE doe in the Name of the PARLIAMENT and whole Kingdome of Scotland acknowledge in all humility and thankfulne≈ø≈øe, in granting our fir≈øt demand beving fully a≈ø≈øured that the Parliament will leave nothing undone that may ≈øerve for his Maje≈øties honour & the whole Kingdome, is Te≈øtimony of their thankfulne≈ø≈øe, will earne≈øtly pray, that God will graunt his Maje≈øty a long and pro≈øperous Reigne. Adam Blaire.

The humble Declaration of the Ma≈øter and Wardens of Vintners, William Abel Alderman of London, and the re≈øt of the Court of A≈ø≈øi≈øtants of that Company, how in what manner the ≈øaid Company, Farmers and Adventurers have proceeded in the Farmes of 40. ≈øhillings per tunne and wine Licence.

IN the yeare 1632. The Lord We≈øton beeing then high Trea≈øurer of England ≈øent for the Ma≈øter and Wardens of the Company of Vintners, and demanded of them the Vent and con≈øumption of Wines, one peny a quart, which is 4 pound per tun, which they utterly refu≈øed, alleadging it would be the utter undoing of the retayling Vintners.

In Anno 1633. a Decree was made by the advice of the Judges of England in the Star-chamber: That the Retaylers of wines might not ≈øell or dre≈ø≈øe Victuals in their hou≈øes, which time out of mind they were accu≈øtomed to doe. And this done without any information or bill, or any called to defend or Iu≈øtifie their trade or u≈øage of it.

In Anno 1634. his Maje≈øty que≈øtioned the Vintners, and Retaylers of Wine, for the breach of the ≈øaid Decree, and drew 6000. pounds from the Vintners to be lent him: And thereon his Maje≈øty did by order give way to the Retaylers of Wines, to dre≈ø≈øe and ≈øell Victuals till December then next following; at which time his Maje≈øty promi≈øed to ≈øettle it as he thought fit for him to ≈øigne, and then to have the Vintners relying upon that Temporary Lycence, and of his Maje≈øties gracious Declaration continued to dre≈ø≈øe meate beyond the tyme.

In Anno 1635. The retaylors of Wines were again que≈øtioned for breach of the former Decree by his Maje≈øty, and the Lord Cottington, then propounded to yeeld to pay ≈øomewhat on their vent of Wines, to his Maje≈øty, which the Retayling Vintners utterly refu≈øed to doe.

In Anno 1636. many retaylors of Wynes were by information in Ma≈øter Attourneys name que≈øtioned in Star-chamber, for breach of the decree, and ≈øo farre proceeded again≈øt as that they were ≈øerved with Proce≈ø≈øe of that Court to hear judgment.

That things thus depending Sir Richard Kilvert repayred to Alderman Abell, then Ma≈øter of the Company, beeing a meere ≈øtranger to Ma≈øter Kilvert, and told him his Maje≈øty bid him command by warrant, to pro≈øecute the Vintners in the Star-chamber, for ≈øelling above the price, and breach of the Decree, for dre≈ø≈øing of meat, and again≈øt the Merchants ≈øcopers, and others; Intimating further it was his Maje≈øties plea≈øure that ≈øome of the Company of Vintners ≈øhould attend the Right Honourable Marquis Hambleton concerning the ≈øame.

In October Anno 1637. at Vintners Hall London, William Abell Alderman beeing then Mr. of that Company, imparted to the Company, that Ma≈øter Richard Kilvert had been lately with him, and acquainted him with the former pa≈ø≈øages.

At this court the company of vintners taking their bu≈øines into their ≈øerious con≈øiderations, & weighing how they might hazard the utter undoing of ≈øuch as had tran≈øgre≈ø≈øed the Decree, if they ≈øhould be brought to a ≈øentence in Star-chamber made choy≈øe and did intreate Alderman Abell, then their ma≈øter, Edward Kinaston, Robert Shawe, Ralph Moore, George Hubburt, and Michaell Gardiner. For the Committee, to waite upon the ≈øaid Lord Marques Hambleton, by whom Ma≈øter Killvert had intimated his Maje≈øties plea≈øure ≈øhould bee made knowne, and to impart the ≈øame againe unto the Company.

That Alderman Abell, and the re≈øt, did attend the Marque≈ø≈øe who told them, that his Maje≈øty had given him the Fines of all the Vintners to be impo≈øed in Star-chamber, but yet if the Vintners would conde≈øcend to pay his Maje≈øty 4, pound a Tunne, upon Con≈øumption of wines, he could forbeare the fines, and all pro≈øecutions ≈øhould be ≈øtayed, and him≈øelfe would depend upon his Maje≈øties favour in ≈øome other thing.

And after many attendances and ≈øeverall rea≈øons offered by them on the behalfe of the Company, again≈øt paying any thing on the Con≈øumption of Wines, and not prevailing, beeing then by the Lord Marque≈ø≈øe promi≈øed ≈øome advancing price and other priviledges, and beeing advi≈øed by Coun≈øell that wine beeing a forraygn Commodity, his Maje≈øty might prohibite the comming of it, and impo≈øe what he plea≈øed on it, thereupon and upon the afore≈øaid threats and promi≈øes after the ≈øame was imparted, and often debated by the Companie, they ≈øubmitted to the payment of 40. ≈øhillings per Tunne, 4. pound beeing demanded; And ≈øoon the 11. of Iune 1638. together with the French and Spani≈øh Merchants, they the ≈øaid Company of Vintners, contracted by Indenture Quadrupartite with his Maje≈øty, to pay him fourtie ≈øhillings per Tunne on all ≈øuch wines as they bought and Vented, and the Company of Vintners beeing enformed that the Farmers of his Maje≈øties Cu≈øtomes, and ≈øome particular Merchants of the Company of Coopers,

London moved and ≈øued to his Maje≈øty to farme the ≈øayd Duties, and the Company of Vintners well knowing what great hinderance it would bee to them, if ≈øtrangers ≈øhould come in & ≈øearch their ≈øellers, & know the particular of what they had bought and ≈øould, the Company to prevent many inconveniences, de≈øired rather to Farme the duty from his Maje≈øty, his Maje≈øtic declaring that he would not contract with a generality of company for the ≈øame, but with ≈øome particular members.

The Company did de≈øire Alderman Abell, and nine others freemen of their Company, to performe the contract with his Maje≈øty for the ≈øame duty, who tooke it to farme at 3000. Pounds Per Annum for eight yeares.

And it was agreed by the Company, that the farmers ≈øhould have no more ≈øhare of profit and lo≈ø≈øe in the Farme then other brethren had, which ≈øhould be plea≈øed to undertake, and goe adventure with them: And it was ordered by the Company, that if that Farmer or adventurer ≈øhould decea≈øe, that then that partyes adventure ≈øhould bee tran≈øferred to ≈øome other free Vintner, and to none other, and not to de≈øcend either
to the Executors or Admini≈øtrators of ≈øuch Vintners, ≈øo decea≈øing; the ≈øaid ten Farmers, being nominated by the Company, and adventured in the ≈øame farme of forty ≈øhillings per Tunne on Wine and Farme of Wine Licences, which they likewi≈øe took by direction of the Company, on the ≈øecond of January 1640. Humbly Petitioned his Maje≈øty to accept of the ≈øaid Farmes, they accounting to his Maje≈øty for all moneys received from the beginning, they having allowance for what they di≈øbur≈øed, and ≈øtand engaged for, for his Maje≈øties ≈øervice, with intere≈øt and nece≈ø≈øary charges, without any profit to them≈øelves.

And Ma≈øter Alderman Abell and divers others, the Contractors never dealt in gro≈ø≈øe nor benefitted them≈øelves by the Advance upon Retayle of wine, ≈øo that he in all this hath bin but a per≈øon intreated into this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe for the Company, and no whit for him≈øelfe, nor hath otherwi≈øe or in any other manner as for other cau≈øe acted any thing at all in or concerning this bu≈øines.

div.head: To the High and Honourable Court of PARLIAMENT, The humble Petition of the ∆≤niver≈øity of OXFORD,
div.p: THAT whereas the ∆≤niver≈øitie hath been informed of ≈øeverall Petitions concerning the pre≈øent Government of this Church, and maintenance of the Clergie, which have of late been exhibited to this Honourable A≈ø≈øembly; We could not but think our Selves bound in duty to God, and this whole Nation, in charity to our Selves and Succe≈ø≈øors, who have and are like to have more then ordinary intere≈øt in any re≈øolution that ≈øhall be taken concerning Church-affaires, in all humility, to de≈øire the continuance of that form of Government, which is now e≈øtabli≈øhed here, and hath been pre≈øerved in ≈øome of the Ea≈øtern and We≈øtern Churches, in a continued Succe≈ø≈øion of Bi≈øhops, downe from the very Apo≈øtles to this pre≈øent time; the like whereof cannot be affirmed of any other form of Government in any Church. Upon which con≈øideration, and ≈øuch other motives as have been already repre≈øented to this Honourable Parliament from other Per≈øons and places (with whom we concurr) in behalf of Epi≈øcopacy, We earne≈øtly de≈øire, that you would protect that ancient and Apo≈øtolicall Order from ruine or diminution.
And become farther Suiters for the continuance of tho≈øe pious Foundations of Cathedrall Churches, with their Lands and Revenues,
As dedicate to the Service and Honour of God, ≈øoon after the plantation of Chri≈øtianity in the Engli≈øh Nation:

As thought fit and u≈øefull to be pre≈øerved for that end, when the Nur≈øeries of Super≈øtition were demoli≈øhed, and ≈øo continued in the la≈øt and be≈øt times ≈øince the ble≈ø≈øed Reformation, under King Edw. 6. Q Elizabeth & K. James, Princes renowned through the world for their piety and wi≈ødome:
As approved and confirmed by the Laws of this land, ancient and modern:
As the principall outward motive and encouragement of all Students, e≈øpecially in Divinity, and the fitte≈øt reward of ≈øome deep and eminent Scholars:

As producing or nouri≈øhing in all ages many godly and learned men, who have mo≈øt ≈øtrongly a≈ø≈øerted the truth of that Religion we profe≈ø≈øe, again≈øt the many fierce oppo≈øitions of our Adver≈øaries of Rome.
As affording a competent portion in an ingenuous way to many younger Brothers of good Parentage, who devote them≈øelves to the Mini≈øtery of the Go≈øpell:
As the onely means of ≈øub≈øi≈øtence to a multitude of Officers and other Mini≈øters, who with their Families depend upon them and are wholly maintained by them:
As the main Authors or upholders of diver≈øe Schools, Ho≈øpitalls, High-wayes, Bridges, and other publique and pious works:

As ≈øpeciall cau≈øes of much profit and advantage to tho≈øe Cities where they are ≈øcituate, not only by relieving their poore, and keeping convenient Ho≈øpitality, but by occa≈øioning a frequent re≈øort of Strangers from other parts, to the great „Äà‚óä„Äâ of all Trade≈ømen, and mo≈øt Inhabitants in tho≈øe places:
As the goodly Monuments of our Predece≈ø≈øors Piety, and pre≈øent Honour of this kingdome in the eye of forreine Nations:
As the chiefe ≈øupport of many thou≈øand Families of the Laity, who enjoy faire e≈øtates from them in a free way:
As yeelding a con≈øtant and ample revenue to the Crown:
And as by which many of the learned Profe≈ø≈øours in our ∆≤niver≈øity are maintained.

The ≈øubver≈øion or alienation whereof mu≈øt (as we conceive) not only be attended with ≈øuch con≈øequences as will redound to the ≈øcandall of many well affected to our Religion, but open the mouths of our Adver≈øaries, and of Po≈øterity again≈øt us; and is likely in time to draw after it harder conditions upon a con≈øiderable part of the Laity, an univer≈øall cheapne≈ø≈øe and contempt upon the Clergie, a lamentable drooping and defection of indu≈øtry and knowledge in the ∆≤niver≈øities; which is ea≈øie to fore≈øee, but will be hard to remedy.

May it therefore plea≈øe this Honourable A≈ø≈øembly, upon the≈øe and ≈øuch other Con≈øiderations as your great wi≈ødomes ≈øhall ≈øugge≈øt, to take ≈øuch pious care for the continuance of the≈øe Religious Hou≈øes, and their Revenews, according to the be≈øt intentions of their Founders, as may be to the mo≈øt furtherance of Gods glory and ≈øervice, the Honor of this Church and Nation, the advancement of Religion and Learning, the encouragement of the mode≈øt hopes and hone≈øt endeavours of many hundred Students in the Univer≈øities
div.closer:
Who doe and ≈øhall ever pray, &c.
Dat. An. Dom. mille≈øimo ≈øexcent' quad' primo √® Domo Convocationis,
in celebri Conventu Doctorum ac Magi≈øtrerum, omnibus & ≈øingulis a≈ø≈øentientibus.

div.head: The Speech of Sergeant Glanvill in the upper Hou≈øe of Parliament, for the Redre≈ø≈øe of the pre≈øent Grievances.
His Maje≈øty being ≈øeated on his Throne, Sergeant Glanvill was called to the Barre, being repre≈øented by the Hou≈øe of Commons for their Speaker; who ≈øpake as followeth.
div.p:
THE Knights, Citizens, and Burge≈ø≈øes, of your Commons Hou≈øe of Parliament in conformity to ancient and mo≈øt con≈øtant u≈øage (the be≈øt guide in great ≈øolemnities) according to their well known priviledges (a ≈øure warrant for their proceedings) and in obedience to your Maje≈øties mo≈øt gratious commands (a duty well becomming loyall Subjects) have met together, and cho≈øen a ≈øpeaker, one to be the mouth, indeed the ≈øervant of all the re≈øt to ≈øteare watchfully and prudently in all their weighty con≈øultations and debates, to collect faithfully and readily the Votes and genuine ≈øen≈øe of that numerous a≈ø≈øembly, to propound the ≈øame ≈øea≈øonably & in apt que≈øtions for their finall re≈øolution, and to pre≈øent them and their conclu≈øions, their declarations with truth and light, with life and lu≈øtre, and with full advantage to your mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty. With what Judgement, with what temper, ≈øpirit, and elocution he ought to be endued, your Maje≈øty in your great wi≈øedome is be≈øt able to di≈øcern, both as it may relate to
your own peculiar and important affairs of State, to the proper work and bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of this Hou≈øe of Commons, which was never ≈ømall or mean, and now like to be exceeding weighty.

It is a learned age wherein we live under your Maje≈øties mo≈øt peacefull government; and your Hou≈øe of Commons is not only the repre≈øentative body, but the ab≈øtracted quinte≈ø≈øence of the whol Communalty of this your noble Realme.

I mo≈øt humbly therefore be≈øeech your Maje≈øtie as the father of the Commonwealth, and hope of the whole nation, to whom the care of all our welfares appertains, to have re≈øpect to your own intere≈øt, have regard to your Hou≈øe of Commons, have compa≈ø≈øion upon me the unworthie≈øt member of that body, ready to faint with fear, before the burthen lights on me, I have only a hearty affection to ≈øerve you and your people, little abilities for performance; In the fulne≈ø≈øe therefore of your Royall power, your piety, goodne≈ø≈øe, be gratiou≈øly plea≈øed to command the Hou≈øe of Commons to deliberate upon a better choice who may be worthy of their choo≈øing, and your Maje≈øties acceptations.

div.head: My Lord Keeper having by his Maje≈øties direction confirmed him as Speaker, he addre≈øt him≈øelfe to his Maje≈øty as followeth.
div.p:
My profe≈ø≈øion hath taught me, that from the highe≈øt Judge there lies no writ of error, no appeale; what then remains, but that I fir≈øt be≈øeech Almighty God the author and fini≈øher of all good works, to enable me to di≈øcharge hone≈øtly and effectually ≈øo great a taske, ≈øo great a tru≈øt; and in the next place humbly to acknowledge your Maje≈øties favor? Some enemies I might feare, the common enemy of ≈øuch ≈øervices, expectation and jealou≈øy;
I am unworthy the former, and I contemn the latter. Time the touch≈øtone of truth ≈øhall teach the babling world, I am and will be found an equall freeman, zealous to ≈øerve my Soveraign, zealous to ≈øerve my deare≈øt Country.

Monarchy Royall of all governments the mo≈øt illu≈øtrious and excellent, whether we regard the glory, wealth, or ≈øafety of the governours or people; I hope none of this Nation are of Antimonarchicall ≈øpirits, nor friends to ≈øuch, if there be, I wi≈øh no greater honour to this Parliament, then to di≈øcover them and to a≈ø≈øi≈øt your Maje≈øty to ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe and confound them.
To behold your Maje≈øty in peace and ≈øafety affords compleat joy to all Loyall Subjects, who cannot but conclude with me in this de≈øire.

England is your ≈øeat of re≈øidency, Scotland is your native place, and herein hath the advantage; Ireland imitates England by a great and quick progre≈ø≈øion in civility and conver≈øation, in improvement of the ≈øoile and plantation.

France is ≈øtill attendant on your Royall ≈øtile; A Kings Prerogative is as needfull as great, without which he ≈øhould want that Maje≈øty which ought to be in≈øeparable from his Crown, nor can any danger re≈øult thereby to ≈øubjects liberties, ≈øo long as both admit the temperament of Law and Ju≈øtice, ≈øpecially under ≈øuch a Prince, who to your immortall Honor hath publi≈øhed this to the whole world for your maxime, that the peoples liberties ≈øtrengthen the Kings Prerogative, and the Kings Prerogative is to defend the peoples liberties; Apples of gold in pictures of ≈øilver.

Kings as Kings are never ≈øaid to Erre, only the be≈øt may be abu≈øed by mi≈øinformation; this the highe≈øt point of Prerogative that the King can doe no wrong; if then
by the ≈øubtilty of mi≈øinformers, by the ≈øpecious fal≈øe pretences of publique good, by a cunning and clo≈øe contrivance of their waies to ≈øeduce the Sacred Royall Per≈øon, it be ≈øurprized and overwrought to command contrary to law, and be executed accordingly; the≈øe commands will be void, and this King innocent even in his very per≈øon, and the authors of ≈øuch mi≈øinformations, the actors of ≈øuch abu≈øes ≈øtand expo≈øed to ju≈øt cen≈øure, having nothing to defend them≈øelves but the colour of a void command, made void by ju≈øt Prerogative, and the fundamentall rea≈øons of ≈øtate.

Touching ju≈øtice, there is not a more certain ≈øigne of an upright Judge, then by his patience to be well informed before ≈øentence given, and I may boldly ≈øay, all the Judges in your Kingdome may take example by your Maje≈øty and learn their duties by your practi≈øe, my ≈øelfe have often been a witne≈ø≈øe thereof to my no little admiration.

From your patience, plea≈øe you give me leave to pre≈ø≈øe to your righteous judgement, and exemplifie it but in one in≈øtance. When your Lords and people in your la≈øt Parliament pre≈øented your Maje≈øty a Petition concerning their rights and liberties, the Petition being of no ≈ømall weight, your Maje≈øty after mature deliberation, in few but mo≈øt effectuall words; (≈øoit droict faict come e≈øt de≈øire) made ≈øuch an an≈øwer, as ≈øhall renown you for ju≈øt Judgement to all po≈øterity.

Let us heartily pray that this Parliament may be famous for the advancement of Sacred Religion, and to that end that the mo≈øt Reverend Prelates, ≈øitting on the right hand of your Kingly ≈øide, be mo≈øt forward therein, to whom it is mo≈øt proper.

That the Nobles girt with their ≈øwords in their creation, and mo≈øt e≈øpecially rewarded and honored for actions military: call to minde the mo≈øt renowned Acts of their Ance≈øtors, who≈øe lands and honours they inherite,
and how renowned this Land hath been through the whole World for Art and Armes, and labor to re≈øtore it to its ancient ≈øplendor: The be≈øt way to pre≈øerve peace, is to be well fitted for War.

But were this Nation never ≈øo valiant or wealthy, if Unity be not among us, what good will riches doe us, or your Maje≈øty, but inrich the conqueror? he that commands all hearts by love, he onely commands a≈ø≈øuredly; greatne≈ø≈øe without goodne≈ø≈øe can at be≈øt but command bodies.
