It ≈øhall therefore be my hearty prayer, That ≈øuch a knot of love may be knit betwixt the Head and members that like Gordius knot it never be loo≈øed: That all Je≈øuited forrain States who look a≈øquint upon our Hieru≈øalem may ≈øee them≈øelves defeated of all their ≈øubtill plots and combinations, of all their wicked hopes and expectations, to render us, if their mi≈øchiefe might take effect, a people incon≈øiderable at home, and contemptible abroad.

Religion hath taught us (Si Deus nobi≈øcum, quis contra nos?) and experience I tru≈øt will teach us (Si ≈øumus in≈øeparabiles ≈øumus in≈øuperabiles.) It was found, and I hope it ≈øtill ≈øhall and will be the Tenet of the Hou≈øe of Commons; That the King and peoples good cannot be ≈øevered: And cur≈øed be every one that goes about to divide them.

div.head: Secretarie Windebankes Letter to my Lord Chamberlain, from Callis, January 11.
div.p: MY Lord, I ow my ≈øelfe to your Lord≈øhip, for your late favors; and therefore, much more the account of my ≈øelf, though the debt in either re≈øpect, be of little con≈øideration, and the calling of both may be of greater advantage to you, then to continue be Obligation.

This account had been pre≈øented to your Lord≈øhip, at my fir≈øt arrivall here with my fir≈øt di≈øpatches, but I was ≈øo mortified with my hazardous pa≈ø≈øage in an open ≈øhallop, and ≈øo perplext with the thoughts to mi≈øeries, into which I finde my ≈øelfe plunged, and be≈øides, the departure of the me≈ø≈øenger that carried tho≈øe letters, was ≈øo ≈øuddaine, that it was not po≈ø≈øible to perform this dutie to your Lord≈øhip ≈øooner; For the which I do mo≈øt humbly crave pardon: your Lord≈øhip may now plea≈øe to accept the expre≈ø≈øions, from the ≈øadde≈øt and mo≈øt wounded ≈øoule in the whole World, who am a ≈øpectacle of mi≈øery in my ≈øelfe, in my di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Wife and Children, and in my whole fortunes, who have left the attending of my Soveraigne and Ma≈øter, and acce≈ø≈øe to the be≈øt Prince in the world, who am become a ≈øcorne and by-word to all the world, both at home and abroad, a wanderer, an Exile from mine own Country, now in the declination of my years, and likely to end my dayes, in a remote Country, and far from the comfort of all my friends; What I am guilty of none knows ≈øo well as his Maje≈øty whom
I have ≈øerved faithfully, diligently, painfully, and with as true and loyall an heart, according to my poore abilities, as any other what≈øoever, and if I found my Con≈øcience charged with any crime of ba≈øene≈ø≈øe, corruption, infidelity, or any thing el≈øe unworthy of a Gentleman, I ≈øhould not venture to addre≈ø≈øe the≈øe complaints to your Lord≈øhip, or to any other per≈øon of Honour, in this di≈øcon≈øolate e≈øtate, being an object not altogether unworthy of your Lord≈øhips compa≈ø≈øion, be it for no other re≈øpect, but that I have long ≈øerved the King and Queens Maje≈øties, I doubt not but your Lord≈øhip, in your genero≈øity and goodne≈ø≈øe, will have a lively ≈øen≈øe and f ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ling of my ≈øufferings, and vouch≈øafe me ≈øuch reliefe as in your Honour you may; and if my ≈øelf, who by cour≈øe of Nature cannot be now of long continuance, be not con≈øiderable, I mo≈øt humbly be≈øeech your Lord≈øhip to have pity upon my poore innocent wife, and children, that they receive ≈øuch comfort and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance from you in my ab≈øence, that they may be pre≈øerved from peri≈øhing. And to that end I mo≈øt humbly crave your Lord≈øhips favour to this Bearer my Sonne, and to give him the honour of acce≈ø≈øe when≈øoever he ≈øhall make his addre≈ø≈øes to you, wherein you ≈øhall doe a worke of ≈øingular charity; and becau≈øe there is an opinion in the world, that I have much improved my fortunes by the Romane party; and there hath beene ≈øome de≈øigne by my mini≈øtery to introduce Popery into England, I ≈øhall mo≈øt humbly crave your Lord≈øhips patience in giving me leave to clear tho≈øe two great mi≈øunder≈øtandings, which if they were true, were ≈øufficient to render me uncapable of his Maje≈øties favours, or of the compa≈ø≈øion of any per≈øon of honour what≈øoever: For the fir≈øt, it is notorious to all the world that having now ≈øerved his Maje≈øtie in the place of a Secretary above eight years, I have not added one foot of Land to the inheritance left me by my father, which in Land and
Lea≈øe was not above 500. pounds per annum, a poore and incon≈øiderable e≈øtate for a Secretary, and ≈øuch an one as mo≈øt Secretaries have more than trebled in a ≈øhort time; for my manner of living, it hath been much under the dignity of a Secretary; and if I had not been very frugall, I could not have ≈øub≈øi≈øted; where then this concealed Ma≈ø≈øe of Trea≈øurie is (I wi≈øh tho≈øe that ≈øpeak ≈øo liberally of it) would let me know; for I doe prote≈øt to God I am utterly to ≈øeek where to di≈øcover it, and at this pre≈øent, I am ≈øo unfurni≈øhed with monies, that if his Maje≈øtie cau≈øe me not to be ≈øupplied, I am unable to ≈øub≈øi≈øt in the≈øe parts without expo≈øing my Family in England to the danger of ≈øtarving, and yet neither my purpo≈øe nor inclination is to live otherwi≈øe here, than in the greate≈øt ob≈øcurity and clo≈øene≈ø≈øe that po≈ø≈øibly I may. I a≈ø≈øure your Lord≈øhip that tho≈øe of the Roman party that pa≈ø≈øed my hands by his Maje≈øties commandement; were poore di≈øtre≈ø≈øed creatures, and farre from being able to inrich me, and be≈øides, how little I have attended my own private, and how freely and like a Gentleman, I hope I may ≈øpeak the truth without o≈øtenation, I have done curte≈øies to all, I wi≈øh it ≈øhould rather appeare by the te≈øtimonie of ≈øuch as have made u≈øe of my ≈øervices, then by mine own. My Father and I have ≈øerved the Crown of England neare 80. years together, in which time, if a greater e≈øtate had been rai≈øed it might well have been ju≈øtified, confidering the great imployments neer the per≈øons of Queen Elizabeth, King James, and his Maje≈øty that now is, we both have had; and your Lord≈øhip may believe it (for I avow it upon the faith of a Chri≈øtian) that it is no more then I have above mentioned, and whether there are not many from le≈ø≈øe imployments have ri≈øen to be Noblemen, and made their fortunes accordingly, I leave to the world to judge.

For the other ≈øu≈øpition of my being a favourer or an advancer of Popery, I prote≈øt before the Almighty God,
and as I ≈øhall an≈øwer at the la≈øt dreadfull day, that I know no ground for the lea≈øt ≈øu≈øpition thereof, neither am I my ≈øelfe, nor is any other to my knowledge guilty of the lea≈øt thought of any ≈øuch purpo≈øe; For my ≈øelf I received my Bapti≈øme in the Church of England, and I know nothing in the Church of Rome that can win me from that Church wherein I was made a Chri≈øtian; I doe therefore hold this Church of England, not onely a true and Orthodox Church, but the mo≈øt pure, and neer the primitive of any in the Chri≈øtian world, and this I will be ready to ≈øeale with my blood, when≈øoever there ≈øhall be occa≈øion (with this further prote≈øtation) that if I did not hold it ≈øo, I would not continue in it for any worldly re≈øpects what≈øoever.

For that which hath pa≈ø≈øed my hands for favor of that party, it hath been meerly mini≈øteriall, as his Maje≈øty be≈øt knows, and I mu≈øt be bold to ≈øay that his Maje≈øty hath not been deceived by it, but hath received many greater advantages; be≈øides that, if a Secretary of State ≈øhould not hold intelligence with the party, is ab≈øolute to di≈øable him for the ≈øervice of the State, and that hath been done alwaies more or le≈ø≈øe, and ≈øo mu≈øt alwaies continue, Kings and their Mini≈øters of State, have ever had, and might ever have a Latitude according to time and occa≈øion, and cannot be ≈øo tied according to ≈øtrictne≈ø≈øe of law as others are, without perill to the government, therefore when the Roman party were practique and bu≈øie about the State, there was rea≈øon to be more ≈øtrict, but now by the wi≈øedome of the Queen and her good Officers, they are better tempered, le≈ø≈øe ≈øeverity hath been u≈øed, it being the prerogative of the Prince to u≈øe moderation according to accu≈øation: further than this I have not had to doe with the Roman party, nor thus far but in obedience to my Ma≈øters commandement, which I hope ≈øhall not be cen≈øured a crime, this being my condition; I mo≈øt
humbly ≈øubmit it to your Lord≈øhips wi≈ødome and goodne≈ø≈øe, and ≈øeeing there is no malignity in it, nor prejudice to the ≈øtate, That your Lord≈øhip would vouch≈øafe me your favour and protection, and pre≈øerve me from peri≈øhing.

closer.signed: Your Lord≈øhips mo≈øt humble and faithfull, though much di≈øtre≈ø≈øed ≈øervant, Fran. Windebanck.

div.head: The Lord Andevers ≈øpeech concerning the pacification, the 6 of March.
div.p:
I Did lately move your Lord≈øhips that the breach of the pacification might be ≈øpeedily reviewed, as the
‚Ä¢
num nece≈ø≈øarium; and truly my opinion at that time is yet nothing altered, although upon better thoughts (me thinks) it would fir≈øt be known who did actually engage us in the≈øe fruitles di≈ø≈øentions, and ≈øo derive the mi≈øchiefe from ≈øome originall. For my Lords, the kingdome cannot now long ≈øtant at gaze or undergoe new burthens.

Wherefore what is to be done (if you intend it ≈øhould pro≈øper) mu≈øt pre≈øently receive life from the whole people, otherwi≈øe we ≈øhall expire in a dream; and when the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe differs from expectation, it is not enough to
cry, quod non put ar am. My Lords, the wi≈øeman ≈øaies, there is a proper ≈øea≈øon for all things under the Sun, and we often finde the experiment in naturall bodies, which are voluntarily weakned, to recover ≈øtrength, yet with a re≈øtriction to ≈øuch bounds, and limits, as the Phy≈øitian pre≈øcribes him≈øelf; and truly, I think it is your Lord≈øhips ca≈øe at this point, either to con≈øider what ≈øhould further be done then is already, or el≈øe how to get out of tho≈øe labyrinths we now are in, le≈øt the words of the P≈øalmi≈øt come home to our ≈øelves, Vendidi≈øti populum ≈øinepretio.

My Lords, I am confident the Hou≈øe of Commons doth throughly ≈øee, both into the prejudice, and va≈øt expence that the≈øe two armies lay upon the land, and undoubtedly ≈øo many Gentlemen of worth, as ≈øit there, will have tender eyes upon the Commonweale. It will therefore become your Lord≈øhips to ≈øecond them in your way, and while≈øt they apply to publique wounds, the care of this hou≈øe may ≈øearch the inte≈øtines, for if they be not clean≈øed, it will be but a ≈øuperficiall Cure, and break out againe.

My Lords, it ≈øeems the Earle of Strafford, and the Archbi≈øhop of Cant. have gone the high waies of iniquity, and every one knows how to trace them, but Mines under ground are mo≈øt con≈øiderable, which (unle≈ø≈øe they be likewi≈øe found out) may at any time ≈øpring and ≈øupplant the whole fabrick of all our labours. Let us then examine this fanta≈øtick warre ab initio; le≈øt, as the Duke of Burgundy made a few Sheepskins the cau≈øe of his quarrel, ≈øo we ≈øhall find tho≈øe ≈øheets of paper ≈øent under the name of a Liturgy, and book of Canons, were but the Mop≈øas of the ≈øtory to divert our eyes from the main de≈øigne.

Therefore my humble motion ≈øhall be for a ≈øelected Committee of no great number, who may have power from the Hou≈øe to begin ab origne mali, revi≈øe every mans negotiations, who was either an Actor or Coun≈øellor
≈øince the fir≈øt appearance of tho≈øe troubles in Scotland, and that they may examine the Scotti≈øh Coun≈øell upon ≈øuch Articles, as the heavy pre≈ø≈øure of this Kingdome ≈øhall upon common fame admini≈øter unto them.

div.head: The Order of the Hou≈øe of Commons to the Lord Major, for the due ob≈øerving the Sabbath day.
div.p: IT is this day ordered by the Hou≈øe of Commons, the Aldermen and Citizens that ≈øerve for the City of London, ≈øhall intimate to the Lord Major, from this Hou≈øe, that the Statutes, for the due ob≈øerving of the Sabbath be put in execution. And it is further ordered that the like intimation from this Hou≈øe be made to the Ju≈øtices of Peace in all the Counties of England and Wales. And the Knights of the Shire of the ≈øeverall Counties, are to take care that the Copies of this Order be accordingly ≈øent to the Ju≈øtices of Peace in the ≈øeverall Counties.

FOa≈ømuch as the Lords Day, commonly called Sunday is of late much broken and prophaned by a di≈øorderly ≈øort of People in frequenting Taverns, Ale-hou≈øes, and the like, and putting to ≈øale victuall and other things, and exerci≈øing unlawfull games and pa≈øtimes, to the great di≈øhonor of God, and reproach of Religion,
whereof the Hou≈øe of Commons now a≈ø≈øembled hath been plea≈øed to take notice, and by their order, intimation hath been given unto me, that the Statutes for the due ob≈øerving of the Sabbath be put in execution. The≈øe are therefore in his Maje≈øties name to will and require you forthwith, upon the ≈øight hereof, that you give ≈øtrict charge and command unto all and every the Churchwardens and Con≈øtables within your Ward, that from henceforth they doe not permit or ≈øuffer any per≈øon or per≈øons, in the time of divine ≈øervice or at any other time upon the Sunday, to be drinking or playing in any Tavern, Inne, Tobacco-≈øhop, Ale-hou≈øe or other victualling hou≈øe what≈øoever, nor ≈øuffer any Fruiterer, Milkwoman, or Hearbwomen to ≈øtand with fruit, milk, herbs, or any other Victuall or Wares, in any the ≈øtreets, lanes, or allies within your ward, or any other wayes to put tho≈øe things or any other to ≈øale upon the Sunday at any time of the day or in the evening, not to permit or ≈øuffer any Per≈øon or Per≈øons to u≈øe or exerci≈øe upon that day any unlawfull exerci≈øes and Pa≈øtimes within your ward, and that expre≈ø≈øe charge be given to every keeper of any Tavern, Inne, Cookshou≈øe, Tobaccohou≈øe, Alehou≈øe, or any other tipler or victualler what≈øoever within your ward, that hereafter they receive not or ≈øuffer to remain any per≈øon or per≈øons what≈øoever as their gue≈øts or cu≈øtomers to tiple, eate, drinke, or take Tobacco in their hou≈øes upon any Sunday, other then that Inholders may receive their ordinary gue≈øts, or Travellers and ≈øuch like, who come to remain for a time in their Inne for di≈øpatch of their nece≈ø≈øary bu≈øine≈ø≈øe. And if any per≈øon or per≈øons ≈øhall be found offending in the premi≈ø≈øes, that then they be brought before me the Lord Major, or ≈øome other of his Maje≈øties Ju≈øtices of Peace, to the end they may receive ≈øuch puni≈øhment as to ju≈øtice ≈øhall appertaine. And hereof not to faile, as you will an≈øwer the contrary at your perill.

div.head: Occa≈øionall Speeches, made in the Hou≈øe of Commons, this Parliament. 1641.
Concerning Religion. Novemb. 12. 1640.
div.p: IT was well ob≈øerved by my Lord Keeper, that a multiplying Gla≈ø≈øe may deceive; but the right Engli≈øh Gla≈ø≈øe of the Common-wealth, never. In which I di≈øcern ≈øo comely and active a Motion, that out of all que≈øtion, ≈øome great work is here to be done, ≈øome thing extraordinary is here to be decreed; or el≈øe God and the King beyond all our expectations, at the la≈øt breath, would never ≈øo ≈øoon have cemented us again, to meet in in this great Councell.

Mr. Speaker, What an happy ≈øight will it be to ≈øee the King and his People accord? A threefold cord is not ea≈øily broken; and I hope King Charles his threefold Kingdomes ≈øhall never be ≈øo divided, as to breake in peeces.

Mr. Speaker, God knows, the divi≈øions of great Brittain have halfe untwi≈øted our long Union; and I feare that God is angry with our Nationall lukewarme temper: The zeale of his hou≈øe hath not kindled that flame
in our hearts; which our ≈øeeming good actions, have blown abroad; much like the walking of a Gho≈øt, or livele≈ø≈øe body which affrights many, but plea≈øeth no beholder. Omnia hone≈øta opera, voluntas inchoat; It is the heart or will which gives the beginning to every good action; and I hope our con≈øtant re≈øolutions will be to ≈øettle religion in his ≈øplendor and purity, by pulling Dagon from the Altar; and whipping the Buyers and Sellers out of the Temple; Pars prima bonitatis e≈øt velle fieribonum. The fir≈øt part of goodne≈ø≈øe is to have the will of being good.

God knows all our hearts, and takes notice of our inward re≈øolutions, and for what ends we come hither, if to propagate and advance his glory and Go≈øpel, ble≈ø≈øed ≈øhall this Parliament and Nation be, and then mo≈øt happy we, who≈øe God is the Lord, all things ≈øhall work together for our good. For Mr. Speaker, he that turns the hearts of Kings like the rivers of waters, will make the King and his kingdomes all of one mind: Long live King Charles the Great, and his numerous Royall I≈ø≈øue, to defend the true faith, which will protect and keep him and his, ≈øafe in his fathers Throne. Never King gave more full content to his people, than his Maje≈øty now hath done, and I hope never ≈øubjects came with better hearts and affections to their King and Countrey then we doe: let it then appeare M. Speaker, by our outward actions and practi≈øe, that our inward obedience both of heart and hand, is true, loyall, and currant coyn, not fal≈øe nor counterfeit; for, Nemo veraciter dicit, volo, qui non facit illud quod pote≈øt; no man truly ≈øaies, I am in will and heart re≈øolved, unle≈ø≈øe according to his ability, he endeavor to perform his re≈øolution, which, to ≈øpeak the hearts of us all in this renowned Senate, I am confident, is fully fixed upon the true reformation of all di≈øorders & innovations in Church or religion, and upon the well uniting, and clo≈øe rejonting
of the now di≈ø-located great Brittaine: For let me tell you Mr. Speaker, that, God be thanked, it is but out of joynt, and may be yet well ≈øet, by the skilfull Chirurgions of this Honorable Hou≈øe, to who≈øe loving and Chri≈øtian care, and to who≈øe tender and upright hands I leave it, onely with this Avi≈øo, let brotherly love continue, and be con≈øtant and of good courage; for the keeper of I≈ørael, who neither ≈ølumbers nor ≈øleeps, who delivered us from Romes November powder-bla≈øt, will no doubt ≈øtill pre≈øerve his Annoynted our gracious King, and us his loyall Subjects from all dangers of fire, or ≈øword; For, Si Deus nobi≈øcum, quis contra nos?

div.head: Upon the Scotch Treaty. January 21. 1640.
div.p:
THere is no malady more de≈øtructive to the naturall, or politick body, than the mal Caduque, or falling ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, nor is there any Phy≈øitian or compound more to be e≈øteemed than that which can cure it in either. M. Speaker, this unknown remedy, if we be wi≈øe to apply it, and take the receipt with all the ingredients, without any ≈øcruple of di≈øta≈øt; I am confident the recovery will be perfect, and the whole body of great Britaine ≈øafe and ≈øound. Mr. Speaker, the happy Union of Scotland and England, hath thus long ever ≈øince flouri≈øhed in interchangeable ble≈ø≈øings of plenty, and mutuall love and friend≈øhip. But of late by what fatall di≈øa≈øters, and dark underminings we are divided, and ≈øevered into
Scoti≈øh and Engli≈øh Armies; let their well compo≈øed preambles ≈øpeake for mee, which I wi≈øh were printed as an excellent embleme of brotherly love, that di≈øcovers who hath wounded us both, and how each ≈øhould ≈øtrive to help the other in di≈øtre≈ø≈øe, ≈øeeing their and our Religion and Lawes lie both at ≈øtake together. Thinke of it what you will, (Noble Senate) their ≈øub≈øi≈øtence is ours, we live or die, ri≈øe or fall together. Let us then finde out the Boutefaux of this Prelaticall warr, and make them to pay the ≈øhot for their labour, who no doubt, long for nothing more than that we ≈øhould breake with them, who wor≈øhip but one God, and ≈øerve but one Ma≈øter with us: Nor need we feare that they intend to di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe the Engli≈øh of their inheritance or freehold, being ready to withdraw their forces upon rea≈øonable terms, referring their demands of reparation for lo≈ø≈øes, to the ju≈øtice and courte≈øie of this Hou≈øe, which I a≈ø≈øure my ≈øelf will give both a bountifull, cheerfull, and ≈øpeedy ≈øupply in this ca≈øe of nece≈ø≈øity; for, Bis dat, qui cit√≤ dat, is the be≈øt motto, or motion at this time.

div.head: Upon the Impeachment of the Lord Strafford, and Canterbury, &c. February 26. 1640.
div.p:
I Take it we have now ≈øate in this great Councell 15. or 16. weeks, a longer time than any Parliament hath done the≈øe many yeers; God hath given us a faire and ble≈ø≈øed opportunity, if we lay hold of it; and call to
minde the be≈øt Motto for a Parliament, which is, Non quam diu, ≈øed qu√†m ben√®

Mr. Speaker, We have had thus long under our Feathers many E≈øtriges Egges, which as ≈øome ob≈øerve are longe≈øt in hatching, but once hatched, can dige≈øt Iron; and we have many Irons in the fire, and have hammered ≈øome upon the anvill of ju≈øtice into nayles; but we have not ≈øtruck one ≈øtroak with the right hammer, nor riveted one nayle to the head.

Mr. Speaker, God forbid we ≈øhould be cruell or vindicative to any; but let us take heed we be not ≈øo to our ≈øelves, and them the ≈øent us; if we doe not mend our pace, and ≈øo run as we may obtaine.

Mr. Speaker, I hope we ≈øhall make good the work we have undertaken, and win that prize and goale we aime at; el≈øe if we faile in this our pur≈øuit of ju≈øtice, it is time to look about us: for then I feare that we our ≈øelves ≈øhall hardly ≈øcape ≈øcot-free. It will not be our fixe Sub≈øidies that will help us, unle≈ø≈øe we be good husbands, and cut off all ≈øuperfluous charges, disband all needle≈ø≈øe Armies, and di≈ø-arme all Papi≈øts, and bani≈øh all Prie≈øts, and Je≈øuits; and then we ≈øhall thrive and pro≈øper.

Provided alwayes that we deny our ≈øelves, and tru≈øt not too much in the arme of fle≈øh, but be carefull to pre≈øerve brotherly love and concord, le≈øt di≈øcord and faction break, divide, and ruine us: but I hope God will make us all of one minde and one publick ≈øpirit, that as we are de≈øcended from that ancient and noble Engli≈øh quiver, we may prove our ≈øelves a right ≈øheafe of Engli≈øh Arrows well united, well feathered, and ≈øharply piled for publick u≈øe, ≈øtoutly to defend and pre≈øerve the publick good and ≈øafety of this famous Iland of great Britaine, and that is my humble prayer and motion.

div.head: Upon the Straffordian knot. March 10. 1640.
div.p: IN this great and waighty cau≈øe, we ought ≈øeriou≈øly to con≈øider,
Fir≈øt, what we our ≈øelves have done already in the accu≈øation and impeachment of this great Earle, of high Trea≈øon.
Secondly, let us remember what we now are, not only Parliament men, but publick men, and Engli≈øh-men.
As Parliament men, let us follow the ≈øteps of our ance≈øtours, and be con≈øtant to that rule of Law which was their guide, and ≈øhould be ours.
As publick men, forget not whom we here repre≈øent, and by how many cho≈øen and tru≈øted.

As Engli≈øh men let us call to minde the undanted ≈øpirits, & ≈øtout hearts of tho≈øe ancient Heroes, from whom we are de≈øcended, how free they were from Pu≈øillanimity, and how they ≈øcorned all Flattery, and Slavery; let us then now or never, Mr. Speaker, ≈øhew the ≈øame blood runs in our veines.

Thirdly, let us be well advi≈øed what to doe, if in ca≈øe we ≈øhall be denied ju≈øtice in this particular, upon which depends not only the happine≈ø≈øe, but the ≈øafety of this Parliament, of this Kingdome, of our ≈øelves, and of our Po≈øterities: and this is my Avi≈øo.

div.head: Upon the ≈øame Subject. Aprill 9. 1641.
div.p: TRuth is the daughter of time, and experience the be≈øt Schoolma≈øter, who hath long ≈øince taught many men and e≈øtates the ≈øad and woefull effects of an halfdone worke; tho≈øe convul≈øions and renting paines, which the body of great Britain now feels, ≈øhews us that the ill humours and ob≈øtructions are not yet fully purged, nor di≈ø≈øolved.

Mr. Speaker, God will have a through work done; if in ≈øtead of redre≈ø≈øing evils, we think to tran≈øact all, by removing of per≈øons, and not things, well may we hu≈øh our troubles for a ≈øea≈øon, but they will returne with a greater violence.

For believe it, Mr. Speaker (let us flatter our ≈øelves as we plea≈øe) a dim ≈øighted eye may ≈øee, that although we thinke we have now pa≈ø≈øed the equinoctiall of the Straffordian line, and ≈øeem to have gone beyond Canterbury; yet their faction and undermining agents (of all Religions) grow daily more and more powerfull; and no doubt doe labour an extirpation of all Parliaments, and men that will not think, ≈øay, and ≈øwear to their opinions and practice.

Have we not then, Mr. Speaker, a wolfe by the cares? is there any way to goe Scot-free, or wolfe-free, but one? then let us take, and not for≈øake, that old Engli≈øh Parliamentary Road, which is Via tuta, and will bring us ≈øafely to our journeys end: that is my humble motion.

div.head: A ≈øea≈øonable motion for a loyall Covenant May 3. 1641.
div.p: IF ever we intend to perfect and fini≈øh the great works we have begun, and come to our journeys end, let us take and ≈øollow the right way, which is Via tuta; and that is in a word to become holy Pilgrims, not Popi≈øh, and to endeavour to be loyall Covenanters with God and the King; fir≈øt binding our ≈øelves by a Parliamentary and Nationall Oath, (not a Straffordian, nor a Prelaticall one) to pre≈øerve our Religion emire and pure, without the lea≈øt compound of Super≈øtition, or Idolatry: next, to defend the defender of the Faith, his Royall per≈øon, Crown, and dignity, and maintain our Soveraigne in his glory and ≈øplendor, which can never be Eclip≈øed, if the ballance of ju≈øtice goe right, and his laws be duly executed.

Thus doing, Mr. Speaker, and making Jeru≈øalem our chiefe≈øt joy, we ≈øhall be a ble≈ø≈øed Nation, and a happy People. But if we ≈øhall let goe our Chri≈øtian hold, and lo≈øe our Parliament proofe, and old Engli≈øh well-tempered mettle: Let us take heed that our Buckler break not, our Parliaments melt not, and our golden Candle≈øtick be not removed; which let me never live to ≈øee, nor England to feele the want of: that is my prayer conclude my former motion.

div.head: Mr. Hides Argument before the the Lords in the upper Hou≈øe of Parliament. April. 1641.
div.p: MY Lords, I am commanded by the Knights, Citizens, and Burge≈ø≈øes of the Hou≈øe of Commons to pre≈øent to your Lord≈øhips a great and crying grievance, which though it be complained of in the pre≈øent pre≈ø≈øures, but by the Northern parts, yet by the Logick and Con≈øequence of it, it is the grievance of the whole Kingdome. The Court of the Pre≈øidents, and Councell of the North, or as it is more u≈øually called, the Courts of York, which by the ≈øpirit and ambition of the Mini≈øters, tru≈øted there, or by the naturall inclination of Courts to enlarge their own power and juri≈ødiction, hath ≈øo prodigiou≈øly broken down the bankes of the fir≈øt Councell, in which it ran, hath almo≈øt overwhelmed that Countrey under the Sea of Arbitrary power, and involved the people in a Labyrinth of di≈øtemper, oppre≈ø≈øion and poverty.

Your Lord≈øhips will give me leave not with pre≈øumption to informe your great under≈øtandings, but that you may know what moved the Hou≈øe of Commons to their re≈øolutions to remember your Lord≈øhips of the foundation, and erecting this Court, and of the progre≈ø≈øe and growth of it.

Your Lord≈øhips well know, that upon the ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion of all religious hou≈øes to ≈øuch a value in the 27. yeere of H. 8. from that time to the thirtieth yeare of that Kings raigne, many (not fewer than ≈øix In≈øurrections)
and Rebellions were made in the Northern parts, under pretence of that quarrell, mo≈øt of theÃÑ under the coÃÑmand of ≈øome eminent per≈øon of that country, the which being quieted before the end of the 13. year, that great King well knowing his own minde, and what he meant to doe with the great Hou≈øes of Religion; in the year following for prevention of any inconvenience that might en≈øue to him upon ≈øuch di≈øtemper, in the 31. year of his reign granted a Commi≈ø≈øion to the Bi≈øhop of Landaffe, the fir≈øt Pre≈øident, and others for the quiet government of the County of Yorke, Northumberland, Cumberland and We≈øtmoreland, the Bi≈øhoprick of Durham, the County of the Cities of Yorke, King≈øton upon Hull, and New-Ca≈øtle upon Tyne. But my Lords this Commi≈ø≈øion was no other then a Commi≈ø≈øion of Oyre and Terminer, only it had a clau≈øe at the end of it, for the hearing of all cau≈øes reall and per≈øon, quando ambae partes, vel altera pars ≈øit gravata paupertate fuerit, quod quomodo vis ≈øuum ≈øecundum legem Regni no≈øtri, aliter per≈øequi non po≈ø≈øit, which clau≈øe how illegall ≈øoever, for that it is illegall and void in Law, little doubt can be made, yet whether they exerci≈øe that part of the Commi≈ø≈øion at all, or ≈øo ≈øparingly exerci≈øed it, that poore people found ea≈øe and benefit by it, I know not; but at that time I finde no complaint again≈øt it, till the comming in of King James the Commi≈ø≈øion continued ≈øtill the ≈øame, and that in the fir≈øt year of his Reigne to the Lord Sheffeild varied no otherwi≈øe from the former ≈øame, onely it had reference to In≈øtructors which ≈øhould be ≈øent, though any new ≈øent or no is uncertaine, but we can finde none.

In June, in the ≈øeventh yeare of the Reigne of King James a new Commi≈ø≈øion was granted to the ≈øame man (the Lord Sheffeild) very differing from all that went before, it being left out, that they ≈øhould enquire per ≈øacramentum bonorum & legalium hominum, and to heare and determine ≈øecundum leges Angliae; Relation being had
only to the in≈øtructions which were the fir≈øt in≈øtructions, we can finde were ≈øent thither, though I told your Lord≈øhips there were ≈øome mentions of ≈øome In 1. Jac. I ≈øhall not trouble your Lord≈øhips with the≈øe In≈øtructions, nor with the other that followed in 14. Jacobi to the ≈øame man, nor in 16 Jacobi, when a new Commi≈ø≈øion was granted to my Lord Sunderland, nor indeed with any till we come to the≈øe pre≈øent In≈øtructions, and Commi≈ø≈øions under which that part of the Kingdome groans and langui≈øheth.

My Lord of Strafford came to that government in Decemb. 4. Caroli, and ≈øince the Commi≈ø≈øion hath been three ≈øeverall times removed, in the fi≈øt year in March, in the eighth in Novemb. in the thirteenth year of his Maje≈øties reigne into that Commi≈ø≈øion of 8. and 13. a new clau≈øe ≈øerved in for the granting, ≈øeque≈øtring, and e≈øtabli≈øhing Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions according to in≈øtructions, crowded in a Ma≈ø≈øe of new exorbitant and intolerable power, though our complaint be again≈øt this Commi≈ø≈øion it ≈øelfe, and again≈øt the whole body of tho≈øe in≈øtructions: I ≈øhall not mi≈øpend your Lord≈øhips pretious time in de≈øiring to have the whole read, but ≈øhall pre≈øume to trouble your Lord≈øhips only with five or ≈øix of the in≈øtructions, that by the va≈øt irregularity of tho≈øe your Lord≈øhips may judge; how in≈øupportable the whole burthen is. I ≈øhall not trouble your Lord≈øhips with the nineth In≈øtruction, though it be but ≈øhort, which introduceth that, mi≈øeram ≈øervitutem, ubi jus e≈øt vagum, & incognitum, by requiring an obedience to ≈øuch ordinances, and determinations, as be or ≈øhall be made by the Councell Table, or high Commi≈ø≈øion Court. A grievance my Lords, how≈øoever con≈øuetudo & peccantum claritas nobilitaverit hanc culpam, of ≈øo tran≈øcendent a nature, that your Lord≈øhips noble Ju≈øtice will provide a remedy for it, with no le≈ø≈øe care, then you would re≈øcue the life and blood of the Common-wealth.
Read the 19.22, 23, 24.29. and 30: I will not trouble your Lord≈øhips with reading more, there being among them in the whole 58. In≈øtructions, ≈øcarce one that is not again≈øt, or be≈øides the Law.

Whether His Maje≈øty may caution out a part of his Kingdome to be tryed by Commi≈ø≈øion, though according to the rules of Law, ≈øince the whole Kingdome is under the Laws and government of the Courts e≈øtabli≈øhed at We≈øtmin≈øter, and by this rea≈øon the ≈øeverall parts of the kingdome may be deprived of that priviledge, will not be now the que≈øtion; that his Maje≈øty cannot by Commi≈ø≈øion erect a new Court of Chancery, or aproceeding according to the rules of the Star-chamber, is mo≈øt cleare to all who have read Magna Charta; which allowed no proceedings, ni≈øiper legale judicium Parium & per legem terrae: for our Court of Chancery here by long u≈øage and pro≈øcription is grown to be as it were lex terrae. But my Lords, the thircieth In≈øtruction goes further, and erects ≈øuch an Empire, ≈øuch a Dominion, as ≈øhall be lyable to no contrary.

The Courts of We≈øtmin≈øter, my Lords, have ≈øuperintendences over all inferiours Courts to regulate their juri≈ødictions, if they exceed their limits. As to hold Plea of greater value, or the like in his exerci≈øe of Juri≈ødiction, the Judges are ≈øworn to grant, and ≈øend prohibitions, and to ≈øtop the granting of the≈øe prohibitions, or to neglect them, when they are granted, is the greate≈øt and bolde≈øt ≈øcorn of the Law, and the Law-makers that can be imagined.

The Kings Courts at We≈øtmin≈øter, having been alwaies of that awfull and reverent e≈øteem, with inferiour Judges, that the in≈øtances of ≈øuch contempts again≈øt them are very rare and exemplary in the puni≈øhment.

The Bi≈øhop of Norwich in Trinity Term, in the twentieth year of Edward the third, in Rot. 289. in the common
Pleas in Hilary Terme 21. in the Kings Bench, was attached for di≈øobeying a Prohibition at the ≈øuit of Stracill, upon full and ≈øolemne di≈ø≈øen≈øion of the whole matter, the Court re≈øolved, that the proceedings of the Bi≈øhop were inobedientiam & diminutionem Domini, & pote≈øtatis Regiae authoritatis ≈øuae lectionem & coronae ≈øuae exhereditationem manife≈øtam, &c. As the words of the Records are, and therefore adjudged the temporall tyes of the Bi≈øhop to be ≈øei≈øed into the Kings hand, and great, very great dammages to be paid to Plaintiffes: And who≈øoever gave directions for the≈øe ≈øtout In≈øtructions, might have remembred that no longer ≈øince then Michaelmas, in the ≈øeventh year of Eliz. Rot. 31. an Attachment was granted again≈øt the Archbi≈øhop of Yorke then Pre≈øident of that Councell, for forbidding the Goaler of Yorke to deliver one Lambert his Pri≈øoner, who was ≈øent for by a habeas corpus from the Kings Bench; and if they would have believed the re≈øolution of all the Judges in England, in Trinity Term, in the 6 yeare of King James, they would have known how unfit it had been to enlarge that Juri≈ødiction, ≈øince mo≈øt of their proceedings being of an inferiour nature to what they are now grown, were then declared to be illegall and incon≈øi≈øtent with the liberty of the Subject.

And can ≈øuch a Court, as this my Lords, de≈øerve to live? what a compendious abridgement hath Yorke gotten of all the Courts in We≈øtmin≈øter Hall? what≈øoever ≈øals within the cognizance, or juri≈ødiction of either Courts here, is compleatly determinable within that one Court at York, be≈øides the power it hath with the Eccle≈øia≈øticall and high Commi≈ø≈øion Courts.

What hath the good Northern people done, that they only mu≈øt be disfranchi≈øed of all their priviledges by Magna Charta, and the Petition of Right; for to what purpo≈øe ≈øerve the≈øe Statutes, if they may be fined and impri≈øoned without Law, according to the di≈øcretion of the
commi≈ø≈øioners? what have they done, that they, and they alone of all the people of this happy Iland mu≈øt be di≈øinherited of their birth-right, of their Inheritance? For prohibitions, writs of Habeas Corpus, writs of errour are the birth-right, the inheritance of the Subjects.

And 'tis here worth your Lord≈øhips ob≈øervation, that to tho≈øe many prohibitions, which have been granted from above, for till of late, the court of Yorke had not the courage to di≈øpo≈øe prohibitions, nor indeed till our Courts here, had not the courage to grant them. Twas never known, that Court pleaded the Juri≈ødiction of their Councell, which without doubt they would have done upon the advantage of many great per≈øons, in who≈øe protection they have alwayes been, had they not known the Law, could not be mi≈øinterpreted enough to allow it.

Your Lord≈øhips remember the directions I mentioned of Magna Charta, that all proceedings ≈øhall be per legale Judicium Parium, & per legem terrae, now the≈øe Juri≈ødictions tell you, you ≈øhall proceed according to your di≈øcretion, that is, you ≈øhall doe what you plea≈øe, onely that we may not ≈øu≈øpect this di≈øcretion will be gentler and kinder to us then the Law, ≈øpeciall provi≈øion is made no fine, no puni≈øhment ≈øhall be le≈ø≈øe then by the law is appointed, by no means, but as much greater, as your di≈øcretion ≈øhall think ≈øit; and indeed in this improvement we find, Arbitrary Courts are very pregnant: if the Law require my good behaviour, this di≈øcretion makes me clo≈øe Pri≈øoner, if the Law ≈øets me upon the Pillory, this di≈øcretion appoints me to leave my cares there.

But this proceeding according to di≈øcretion is no new expre≈ø≈øion, 'twas in the fir≈øt Commi≈ø≈øion I told your Lord≈øhips of in the 31. Hen. 8. that they ≈øhould proceed ≈øecundum legem & con≈øuetudinem Regni Angliae, vel aliter ≈øecundum ≈øanos di≈øcretiones ve≈øtras, which in the interpretation of the Law, and that is the be≈øt interpretation,
≈øignifies the ≈øame thing, to proceed according to di≈øcretion, is to proceed according to Law, which is ≈øumma di≈øcretio, but not according to their private conceit or affection: For talis di≈øcretio (≈øaies the law) di≈øcretionem confundit: and ≈øuch a confu≈øion hath this di≈øcretion in the≈øe In≈øtructions produced, as if di≈øcretion were onely removed from rage and fury: no inconvenience, no mi≈øchiefe, no di≈øgrace, that the malice, or in≈øolence, or curio≈øity of the≈øe Commi≈ø≈øioners had a minde to bring upon that people, but through the latitude and power of this di≈øcretion the poore people have felt, this di≈øcretion hath been the quicke≈øand which hath ≈øwallowed up their property, their liberty: I be≈øeech your Lord≈øhips re≈øcue them from this di≈øcretion.

Be≈øides, the charge that this Court is to his Maje≈øty, which is neer 1300. l. per annum, your Lor ‚Ä¢ ≈øhips will ea≈øily gue≈ø≈øe, what an un≈øupportable burthen the many officers (who≈øe places are of great value) the Atturnies, Clarks, Regi≈øters, and above 1000. Sollicitors that attend the Courts, mu≈øt be to that people (in≈øomuch) that in truth the Country ≈øeems to be divided into officers and dependants upon that Court: And the people upon whom the≈øe officers of that Court prey and commit rapines, as he ≈øaid in Petronius, Omnes hic aut captantur, aut captant; aut cadavere quae laterentur, aut corni quae laterunt. Truly my Lords, the≈øe vexed worn-people of the North are not ≈øutors to your Lord≈øhips, to regulate this Court, or to reform the judges of it, but for extirpating the≈øe Judges, and the utter aboli≈øhing this Court; they are of Catoes minde, who would not ≈øubmit to Cae≈øar for his life, ≈øaying, he would not be beholding to a Tyrant for inju≈øtice, for it was inju≈øtice in him to take upon him to ≈øave a mans life, over whom he had no power.

So the≈øe Gentlemen de≈øire not to be beholding to this Court hereafter for inju≈øtice. The very admini≈øtration
of inju≈øtice, founded upon ≈øuch illegall principles being a grievance and oppre≈ø≈øion to the ≈øubject.

Fir≈øt upon the whol matter the Hou≈øe of Commons is of opinion, that the Commi≈ø≈øion and In≈øtructions whereby the Pre≈øident and Councell of the North exerci≈øe a Juri≈ødiction, is illegall, both in the creation and execution.

Secondly, that it is improfitable to his Maje≈øty, for be≈øides ≈øo much, neer thirteen hundred pound taken out of his Maje≈øties revenues every year, his Maje≈øty lo≈øeth the great benefit would accrew to him upon writs and upon Fines, upon Out-laws, and other profits, which redound to his Maje≈øty out of his Court here.

And which I had almo≈øt forgot to tell your Lord≈øhips of, that his Maje≈øty may be ≈øure to have benefit from that Court notable care is taken, by the fiftty three In≈øtructions, And if any money remaines over and above all disbur≈øements, it ≈øhall be be≈øtowed in providing Hou≈øhold-≈øtuffe, and furniture for the hou≈øe, where the Lord Pre≈øident and Councell u≈øe to be.
And la≈øtly, that it is inconvenient and grievous to His Maje≈øties ≈øubjects of tho≈øe parts.

And therefore they are humble Sutors to your Lord≈øhips, and the hou≈øe of Commons, on this behalfe, that ≈øince this people doe, and have, in all matters of duty and affection contend with the be≈øt of His Maje≈øties ≈øubjects, that they may not be di≈øtingui≈øhed from them in the manner of His Maje≈øties Ju≈øtice and protection, ≈øince this Court originally in≈øtituted & continued by his Maje≈øty, for the ea≈øe and benefit of his ≈øubjects, is apparently inverted to the burthen and di≈øcomfort of them, that your Lord≈øhips will joyn with the Hou≈øe of Commons in be≈øeeching His Maje≈øty, that the pre≈øent Commi≈ø≈øion may be revoked, and no more ≈øuch granted for the future.

div.head: A Speech of Ma≈øter John White Coun≈øellour, concerning Epi≈øcopacy.
div.p: EPi≈øcopacy as it ≈øtands in this kingdom, comprehends in it in linea recta, the≈øe foure degrees, the Deacon, the Presbyter, the Bi≈øhop and the Archbi≈øhop, Every Archbi≈øhop wades through every of the≈øe ordinarily.

Of the fir≈øt and la≈øt we have no ve≈øtigium in the holy ≈øcriptures. This Deacon may Preach and Baptize & help the Presbyter to admini≈øter the Lords Supper,Book of ordering of Deacons. but may not con≈øecrate the Elements in the Lords Supper: contrary to the Scriptures, by which Preach and Baptize, is a full Commi≈ø≈øion for the exerci≈øe of all the mini≈øteriall function. Mat. 28.19.
The Deacon mentioned in holy Scripture, is the ≈øame in Office with our Church-warden, to looke to the Church goods and the poore, Acts 6. 1 Tim. 3.
The Presbyter is of all hands acknowledged to be, Jure Divino.
The Bi≈øhop is con≈øiderable in re≈øpect of his trayn, and ≈øecondly, in re≈øpect of him≈øelf.

His trayn are the≈øe, fir≈øt the Dean and Chapter (called Prebends, quia praeherent auxilium Epi≈øcopo,) and were originally ordained for his Coun≈øell to advi≈øe him in difficulties in Religion, and to advi≈øe him in, and con≈øent unto his di≈øpo≈øitions of his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, Cok. r. 3. Dean and Chapter of Norwiches ca≈øe.

Secondly, the Archdeacon is the oculus Epi≈øcopi to di≈øcover and puni≈øh offences ≈øpirituall and Eccle≈øia≈øticall
within his limits, & manus Epi≈øcopi, to pre≈øent unto him ≈øuch as are to be made Deacons and Presbyters, and to induct ≈øuch as he admits and in≈øtitutes into Benefices.
Thirdly, his Chancellors, Vicars Generall, Commi≈ø≈øaries, Officials, Surrogates, Regi≈øters, Promotors, and others belonging to his Cathedrals.
The≈øe be all meerly humane, and may be taken away without offence to God or con≈øcience, if there appeare ju≈øt cau≈øe for it.
The Bi≈øhop in re≈øpect of him≈øelfe is con≈øiderable in his Barony and temporalties, and his ≈øpiritualties.

The fir≈øt, is meerly Exgratia Regis, and in this kingdome began 4. of William the Conquerour:Ca≈øe of tenures 35. a. And by vertue hereof, they have had place in the hou≈øe of Peers in Parliament. 7. H. 8.1846. Kel. it is re≈øolved by all the Judges of England, that the King may hold his Parliament by him≈øelfe, his temporall Lords and Commons, without any Bi≈øhop, for a Bi≈øhop hath not any place in Parliament by rea≈øon of his ≈øpiritualties, but meerly by rea≈øon of his Baronry, and accordingly acts of Parliament have been made, 2 Rich. 3. cap. 3. and at divers other times.
They have u≈øurped the name of Spirituall Lords but of late, and were fir≈øt called ≈øo 16 Rich. 2. c. 1. in our Statutes.

By his ≈øpiritualties, I mean tho≈øe wherein he is more then a Presbyter, and therein I con≈øider his authority over Presbyters by the Oath of Canonicall Obedience, by which he may command them to collect tenths granted in Convocation, &c. 20 Hen. 6.13. p. 25.

Secondly, his Office which is partly Judiciall, and partly mini≈øteriall; Judiciall, by which he is Judge in his Courts of all matters Eccle≈øia≈øticall and ≈øpirituall within his Dioce≈ø≈øe, Cok. Rep. 8. Trollops. C. Secondly, he is Judge of the fitne≈ø≈øe of ≈øuch as are pre≈øented unto him to be in≈øtituted into Benefices, Cok. rep. 5. Specots. cap.

Mini≈øteriall, and thereby he is to Sacred places Dedicate to Divine Service. 9. H. 6.17. pag. 8. Secondly, he is to provide for the officiating of Cures in the avoydance of Churches on neglect of the Patrons, pre≈øenting thereunto. Thirdly, he is to certifie loyall Matrimony, generall ba≈øtardy and excommunication. Fourthly, to execute Judgements given in quare impedit, upon the writ Ad admittendum Clericum, and other, &c.
Fiftly, to attend upon tryals of life, to report the ≈øufficiency or in≈øufficiency of ≈øuch as demand Clergy. Sixtly, to ordaine Deacons and Presbyters.
All the≈øe I conceive to be Jure humano, given to the≈øe Bi≈øhops, and may upon cau≈øe be taken away from them.
Ob. Bi≈øhops have been in the Primitive Church, and are Apo≈øtolicall and from the beginning.

Sol. To this I an≈øwer, fir≈øt, that in the pure primitive times of the Church the Hi≈øtory whereof is recorded in the Acts and Epi≈øtles of the Apo≈øtles, (in which the fir≈øt and be≈øt patterns of Church government is expre≈ø≈øed) there is no mention of other Bi≈øhops then the Presbyters, as appeares.

Fir≈øt, the holy Scriptures declare the duties and office of Presbyters and Bi≈øhops to be one & the ≈øame. The Bi≈øhop is to teach and rule his Church or Congregation 1 Tim. 3.2.5. and the Presbyter is to teach and feed his flock, and to over≈øee, care for, and rule them, 1 Pet. 5.2.3.

Secondly, the Presbyters are in holy Scriptures, ≈øaid to be the Bi≈øhops of the holy Gho≈øt, Acts 20.28. Paul charges the Presbyters of Ephe≈øus to take heed to the flock whereof the Holy Gho≈øt had made them Bi≈øhops. And other Bi≈øhops the Holy Gho≈øt never made.

Thirdly, Ephe≈øians 4.11. God is ≈øaid to have given to his Church for the perfecting of the Saints, for the work of the Mini≈øtery, and for the edifying of the body of Chri≈øt, Apo≈øtles, Prophets, Evangeli≈øts, Pa≈øtors and Teachers; here is an expres enumeration of the officers God
hath given, whereof the fir≈øt three are extraordinary and cea≈øed: and the la≈øt only remains, and is to remain untill we all come to perfection, as it is ver. 13. and this perpetuall Officer is called Pa≈øtor, in relation to his flock whom he is to govern in Spiritualibus, and Teacher in re≈øpect of his duty to feed them with the word of truth, and is the very ≈øame with the Presbyter, as appeares above. Argumentum √† divi≈øione e≈øt forti≈ø≈øimum. The Bi≈øhop as he is any more then a Presbyter, is none of the≈øe, no Officer given by God, and therefore ought not to be in the Church; Chri≈øt the King of his Church was faithfull in his Hou≈øe, not only as a ≈øervant, as Mo≈øes was, but as the Son in an excellency and eminency, Heb. 3.5. and to his kingly Office it pertains to appoint the Officers he will u≈øe for the government of his Church in ≈øpiritualibus, and it agrees not with his faithfulne≈ø≈øe to neglect or omit the appointment of them, and leave his Hou≈øe, his Church, without ≈øuch Officers. He is only wi≈øe, and therefore be≈øt knows what Officers are u≈øefull for his Church, and infinitly loving of his Church, and therefore hath not left her without any Officer fit for her.

Ob.
Titus in the end of Pauls Epi≈øtle unto him, is ≈øaid to be the fir≈øt Bi≈øhop of Crete, and Timothy in the end of the Epi≈øtles unto him, to be the fir≈øt Bi≈øhop of Ephe≈øus.

Sol. Tho≈øe additions are ≈øpurious, and no part of the holy Scriptures,Derk. upon Gal. 6. infine. For Tim. See 1 Cor. 4.17. & 16.10. Acts 17.13.15 & 19.22. & 20.4.5 1 The≈ø. 3.1.6. Heb. 13.25. Colo≈ø. 1.1. Phil. 1.1. & 2.19. For Titus See 2 Cor. 7.13 & 8.6.16.23, and 12.18. Gal 2.1. 2 Tim. 4.10. Tim. 1.5. and ‚Ä¢ .3.12. and as Beza ob≈øerves, are not in many greek ancient copies to be found, and this is ≈øo evident as it is granted by mo≈øt Divines. 2. And as they be no part of the Scriptures of God, ≈øo they be apparently contrary unto them, for by them it appears, that they, namely Titus & Timothy, were Evangeli≈øts, extraordinary officers, a≈ø≈øociats and fellow-helpers of the Apo≈øtles in their generall and Univer≈øall function, attendant upon them, and ≈øent by them (as occa≈øion required) from one Church to another, never keeping any fixed re≈øidence any where, and if they had been Bi≈øhops of any place,
Paul would never have ≈øuffered, much le≈ø≈øe forced them to be non-re≈øidents.

Saint John Revel. 12.3. writing to the 7 Churches of A≈øia directs his ≈øpeech to the Angel of each Church, Ob. 2. and in each of tho≈øe Churches there were then ≈øeverall Congregations and Presbyters, therefore the Angel was the Bi≈øhop over them.

To this I an≈øwer, that as Angel is a name common to all Presbyters who are Chri≈øts Me≈ø≈øengers and Amba≈ø≈øadors: So it appears to be u≈øed here by the very context cap. 2. v. 10. Where ≈øpeaking to the Angel of the Church of Smyrna, the holy Gho≈øt ≈øaith, Feare none of the things thou ≈øhalt ≈øuffer, the Devill ≈øhall ca≈øt ≈øome of you into pri≈øon, but be thou faithfull, &c. Angel (being nomen multitudinis) is taken in the≈øe chapters collectively for all the Presbyters (≈øome of whom the adver≈øaries ≈øhould impri≈øon,) and not for any one above or before the re≈øt. The ≈øame appears in the like manner, ver. 13.23.

Seeing then the Epi≈øcopacy may be taken away in all, wherein it exceeds the Presbyters office, and that the office of the Presbyter is cleerly jure divino; I conceive we are fir≈øt to re≈øtore the Presbyter to his due, and to him it belongs to teach and feed his flock and to over≈øee, care for, and rule them in ≈øpiritualibus, Act. 20.17. 1 Tim. 3.2.5. 1. Pet. 5.2.3. So ≈øaith the holy Scripture.

And ≈øo ≈øaith our Law al≈øo. He is to mini≈øter the Doctrine and the Sacraments, and the di≈øcipline of Chri≈øt, as the Lord hath commanded, and as this Realme hath received the ≈øame according to the commandements of God: See the book of Ordering of Prie≈øts in the 3. que≈øtion, And he is called in our Law Rector Eccle≈øiae, and the words of his in≈øtitution be, Te ‚Ä¢ octorem Eccle≈øiae in≈øtituimus curamque & regimen animarum parochianorum tibi ‚Ä¢ in Domino committimus.

The Bi≈øhops have taken by u≈øurpation from the Pre≈øbyter divers rights: fir≈øt, contrary to his Ordination
and in≈øtitution, they will not ≈øuffer him to preach in his own Cure without a licen≈øe.

Secondly, they re≈øtrain him from preaching ≈øome doctrines, as of prede≈øtination and others that overthrow Arminian tenets, when his faithfulne≈ø≈øe in his Office requires he ≈øhould keep nothing back,This is read to the Presbyter upon his Ordination, and his charge then given him is remarkable See the booke of ordering Prie≈øts. but to ≈øhew them all the coun≈øell of God, Acts 10.27. Thirdly, they will not ≈øuffer him to intermeddle in the di≈øcipline. The≈øe u≈øurpations I conceive are to be taken away, and the Pre≈øbyter to be left free from them.
Secondly, for the Epi≈øcopacy, I conceive, that fir≈øt their Baronies and the intermedling of the Clergy in Civill Councels, affaires, and imployments, ought to be taken from them.

Fir≈øt, I conceive ≈øuch Bar ‚Ä¢ and intermedling is again≈øt the Law of God, Chri≈øt refu≈øed to intermeddle in dividing inheritances (though more able and fit for it then any Bi≈øhop) Luke 12.13. and ≈øaith his Kingdome is not of the world, John 18.36. and the Di≈øciple is not above his Ma≈øter, Mat. 10.24. and Acts 6. The Apo≈øtles refu≈øe to intermeddle in the Deacon or Churchwardens office, though of all earthly imployments the neere≈øt to the Church; and the rea≈øon they give is remarkable for this purpo≈øe, becau≈øe they were to attend to Prayer and Admini≈øtration of the word, and therefore not meet for them to attend ≈øuch ≈øecular matters, and 2 Tim. 2.4. The Apo≈øtles laies down a rule in this ca≈øe, that nemo militans Deo ≈øe implicat negotiis hujus ≈øeculi, and upon this ground, even the Popes Canon-laws are again≈øt the≈øe things, as incon≈øi≈øtent with the mini≈øteriall function. And the due execution of the commi≈ø≈øion, Goe preach and baptize, is of it ≈øelfe burthen and work enough for any man what≈øoever his gifts and parts be, and made Paul though of a more excellent and able ≈øpirit, cry out under the ≈øen≈øe of the waight of it, Who is ≈øufficient for the≈øe things? 2 Cor. 2.16.

Secondly, it is again≈øt the fundamentall Laws of this Land, whereby they that are within holy Orders,Non e≈øt con≈øonum quod ille qui ≈øalubri ≈øtatui animarum & piis operibus continue de≈øervit ad in≈øi≈øtendum in ≈øecularibus neg ‚Ä¢ tiis compellatur, vide the writ. that they may the better attend upon, and di≈øcharge their duties, are not to be intangled with temporall bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, and therefore if any ≈øuch be cho≈øen to any temporall office, the Law hath ordained a writ to di≈øcharge them thereof, Reg. 187.6.
The King may command the ≈øervice of men in orders, and then it is to be given him by naturall allegiance.

This rule admits two exceptions and both are in this ca≈øe: fir≈øt, except the ≈øervice from that per≈øon be again≈øt the Law of God as here it is, and then it is better obey God then man, in prae≈øentia majoris ce≈ø≈øat pote≈øtas minoris.

Secondly, if the ≈øervice concern the Common-wealth, and the per≈øon of whom it is required, be not ≈øufficient for it, nor brought up unto it, the command is again≈øt Law, and the ≈øervice not to be done, if the King grant the Office of the Clarke of the Crown to one not brought up to it, it is void, and the ≈øervice not to be intermedled withall by him, 9 Ed. 4.56. Winters ca≈øe.
Secondly, that part of the Bi≈øhops ≈øpirituall office by which he claimeth ≈øuperiority over Presbyters ought to be taken as I conceive from them as being again≈øt the will of God.

The Apo≈øtles que≈øtioning among them≈øelves which ≈øhould be the Superior, are ≈øharply reproved by our Saviour for it, and he tels them plainly it ≈øhall not be ≈øo among them, Mark 10.42. Luke 22.25. and Diotrophes, 3 Job. 9. is branded for it, that he ≈øought prehominence in the Church. The my≈øtery of iniquity in the Popi≈øh Hierarchy, in the Presbyters exalting them≈øelves, began to work in the pure≈øt primitive times, (as we ≈øee in Diotrophes, and Peters cavear, 1 Pet. 5.3.) and never left till it came to the Pope,2 The≈ø. 2.4.7. the highe≈øt degree and top thereof; By which it ≈øeems to me evident, that to leave the pattern of Church government ≈øet down in the word of
God to follow the examples of after ages upon a fal≈øe cry of primitive times, is to for≈øake the pure fountain, and wallow in the muddy and corrupted ≈øtreams of antichri≈øtian ambition.

Thirdly, that part of the ≈øpirituall office of the Bi≈øhop whereby he is to in≈øtruct the people committed to his charge, with the holy Scriptures, as upon the 2 que≈øtion put unto him at his Con≈øecration, he undertakes to doe, ought (as I conceive) to be reduced to a po≈ø≈øibility for him to performe it. It is impo≈ø≈øible for him to doe it to a whole Dioce≈ø≈øe, therefore he ≈øhould be limited to ≈øome particular Congregation, unto which he might perform this tru≈øt, which requires ≈øufficiency, attendance and diligence.

Fourthly, Ordination in the ≈øcriptures is ever expre≈ø≈øed to be by them in the Church, that had authority and were officers in the Church, as Apo≈øtles, Evangeli≈øts and after by the Presbytery, 1 Tim. 4.14. 2 Tim. 1.6. And a ≈øhadow of this remains in our Law,Acts 14.23. Titus 1.5, 6, 7. for the Bi≈øhop only is not to lay hands upon the party to be ordained, but the Presbyters there attending are to joyn with the Bi≈øhop therein.Books of orde ring Prie≈øts. This I conceive is not fit to be in the hands of any one ordinary officer in the Church, the di≈øcerning of the gifts, abilities and faithfulne≈ø≈øe of per≈øons to be ordained Presbyters, requiring great judgement, care, and circum≈øpection. Plus vident oculi quam oculus. The like I ≈øay of deprivation.

Fiftly, Excommunication by the Scriptures ought to be only in ca≈øe of enormous offences and ob≈øtinacy in them, and onely in the Congregation whereof the party to be Excommunicate is a member, 1 Cor. 5.4. Tell the Church cannot be meant of one man, Mat. 18.17. Diotrophes is branded for taking upon him alone to ca≈øt any out of the Church. This al≈øo abu≈øed as well as u≈øurped by the Bi≈øhop is to be reformed.

Sixtly, In≈øtitution and induction are u≈øurped by the
Bi≈øhops upon the fundamentall Laws of this Kingdome, by which the Patron after his Clerk was ordained, did without any more inve≈øt him into the Church. See Selden of tithes 86. And a relick of this we retain ≈øtill in Churches that be donatives.

Seventhly, The juri≈ødiction of tithes, cau≈øes matrimoniall, and cau≈øes te≈øtamentary in the times of the increa≈øing power of the Pope, when the Bi≈øhops thereby grew more formidable, were taken from the Civill Magi≈øtrate to whom originally they belonged, upon pretence, that the tithes were Jure divino, the Churches patrimony and Mariage a Sacrament, and that the di≈øpo≈øing the goods of the dead, mo≈øt properly belonged to him for the good of the ≈øoule in Purgatory to redeem it thence, to whom the cure of the Soule appertained in his life time, vide 2 R. 3. Te≈øtaments 4.11 H. 7.12 B. Plowden 279. B. Foxes c. Cok. rep. 9.37. B. Heu≈øtoes ca≈øe. Dames rep. 97. B. Lalors c. Selden of tithes, 415.

Eighthly, The matters which are meerly and only ≈øpirituall, (which are properly of Eccle≈øia≈øticall cognizance) were anciently by the Lawyers of this Kingdome, heard and determined in the County and hundred Courts by the Sheriffe and the Bi≈øhop, and by William the Conquerour the≈øe matters were taken thence and appropriated to the Bi≈øhop alone, 2 R. 2. Rotul. Parliament, num. 12. Selden of tithes 412. Book of Martyrs, 154.

And by the Law of God (as I conceive) they ought to be heard & determined by them that have rule in the particular congregations and Churches, Mat. 18.17. 1 Cor. 5. which if it were ≈øo among us would be a wonderfull ea≈øe, and ≈øave great charges to the ≈øubject.

And where the difficulty of ca≈øe or greatne≈ø≈øe of the per≈øons whom it may concern, or where the Governors in particular Congregations demean not them≈øelves as they ought, it ought to be referred to a Synod of Presbyters, ≈øo many as ≈øhall be thought meet, as Acts 15. a
que≈øtion of difficulty ari≈øing in the particular Church of Antioch, and the di≈ø≈øention growing great about the ≈øame, they ≈øent to Hieru≈øalem, and there the Apo≈øtles and Presbyters convened, debated, concluded, and decreed the matter, and impo≈øed the ob≈øervation thereof upon Antioch and other Churches, ver. 1.2.6.28. The Apo≈øtles would not meddle in the que≈øtion without the Presbyters, and other Bi≈øhops there were none there, nor in the Churches. And faelicius expediuntur negotia commi≈ø≈øa pluribus, in the multitude of Coun≈øellors there is ≈øafety, Proverb. 11.14.

And the change of our Laws (in ca≈øe this Hou≈øe ≈øhall ≈øee cau≈øe for it) will not be ≈øo great or difficult as is conceived by ≈øome. For ordination, admonition, ≈øu≈øpen≈øion and deprivation of Presbyters, and the judgement of the fitne≈ø≈øe of per≈øons to be inve≈øted into Benefices Eccle≈øia≈øticall, and the care of providing for the ≈øerving of Cures during the vacancy and avoydance of Churches, and taking of the ≈øub≈øcription of Mini≈øters to the Articles of Religion:13 Eliz. cap. 12.14 Eliz. cap. 5. and the vi≈øiting of Ho≈øpitals, who≈øe Founders have appointed no vi≈øitors, which are now in the Bi≈øhop, may be ≈øettled in a convention of Presbyters, to be appointed for every hundred, from whom appeale may be had upon every gravamen to a greater A≈ø≈øembly of them, and tho≈øe Presbyters, or any one of them, may be inabled to give the Oathes of Supremacy and alleageance, where the Bi≈øhop is authori≈øed to give the ≈øame. And Excommunication may be ordered to be certified by the Par≈øon,3 Eliz. c. 1.7. Jac. cap. 6. Vicar or Stipendary of that Church where the party is excommunicate. And all Churches pre≈øentative, may be filled by inve≈øture of the Patrons, and all que≈øtions concerning them be determined by the ≈øame rules of law as Donatives are, And loyall Matrimony be tryed by a Jury where the woman is party to the ≈øuit, as now it is where ≈øhe is not party, ≈øo E. 3.15. P. 5.11. H. 4.4. B. 30. and as it is now, where the i≈ø≈øue is
Nient ≈øa femme, 12. E. 3. Briefe 481.50. E. 3.15. B. 7. H. 6.12. June 35. H. 6.9. P. 10. Coke 8. E. 4.12. a Laton: And Ba≈øtardy generall & Ba≈øtardy beyond Sea, within the Stature, 25 E. 3. De natis ultra mare, may be made tryable by Jury, as now ≈øpeciall Ba≈øtardy is 11 A≈ø≈ø. 20.38. a≈ø≈ø. 24.39. E. 3.31.6. & 7. Ed. 6. Dier. 79. P. 52. So tithes may be reduced to the Common Law and be ≈øued for there, as it was ever in the ca≈øe of the King or his Debtor 38. a≈ø≈ø. 20. Cok. r. 5.16. a Cawdreis ca≈øe, and as it is by the Statute of 2 and 3 E. 6. cap. 13. And for the Bi≈øhops attendance on tryals of life, it is needle≈ø≈øe, he being no Judge in it, but the Court, who may appoint any other, or doe it them≈øelves. And for Sacring of Churches and other dead things, it is fit to be neglected and left off, being a Popi≈øh vaine ≈øuper≈øtition, and without colour of countenance from the word of God, the Leviticall con≈øecrations being typicall and ≈øhadows of the good things we enjoy under the Go≈øpel, Heb. 9.19, &c.
The Bi≈øhop being thus reformed and reduced to a condition and ≈øtate agreeable to the word of God, the only right rule of reformation:

The Deans, Chapters, Vicars Generall, Chancellors,25 Exod. 9 40. 1 Chron. 28.11.19. Ezek. 4.10. 2 Cor. 4 6. and the re≈øt of his Traine, qua tales (being tellaris inutile pondus) are to be removed and taken away al≈øo as ≈øuperfluous and u≈øele≈ø≈øe.

We have intru≈øted the Epi≈øcopacy the≈øe foure≈øcore and two years with the cure of Soules, a tru≈øt of the highe≈øt concernment, if we con≈øider the price of Souls. Our Saviour is at a ≈øtand in it, What ≈øhall a man give in recompence for his Soule? Mat. 16.26. the price of it is be≈øt ≈øeen in the price given for it, God and man mu≈øt become a cur≈øe to redeem it.

How have they di≈øcharged this tru≈øt? Survay the Churches throughout the Kingdome, and you ≈øhall finde neer eight parts of tenne of them filled with Idoll,
idle, or ≈øcandalous Mini≈øters, whom the Bi≈øhops might have by law refu≈øed, if di≈øcovered unto them beforehand, and ought to have removed being di≈øcovered unto them afterwards. And it hath aboundantly appeared this Parliament upon examinations taken in this Hou≈øe of Commons and the Committees thereof; that when Mini≈øters extreamly ≈øcandalous, have been di≈øcovered to the Bi≈øhops and their Officers, and in the High-commi≈ø≈øion Court, they have received no further cen≈øure then admonition, or to be put to purgation, and ≈øo ≈øent home to de≈øtroy more Soules, as if they had not done ≈øufficiently in that way before.

But if any godly, learned, and painfull Preacher hath been di≈øcovered by them, they have ≈øought out all occa≈øions again≈øt ≈øuch, to thru≈øt them out of the Church, and lay their Congregations wa≈øte and de≈øolate, and every trifle, though indifferent in their own account, hath been made u≈øe of, and ≈øufficed them for this, yea, they have made occa≈øions and traps to overthrow ≈øuch worthies without Law and again≈øt Law.
And herein they have inherited the vertues of Diotrephes their fir≈øt Predece≈ø≈øor, who would not receive the brethren, and forbad them that would, and ca≈øt both out of the Church, 3 John 10.

And though ≈øome of the Bi≈øhops have been and are good men, yet look into their Dioce≈ø≈øe, and the Churches in their gift, and judge whether they be good Bi≈øhops or no, you ≈øhall ≈øinde them as faulty concerning this great tru≈øt as any of the re≈øt. And whether it be not from hence evident, or at lea≈øt greatly to be ≈øu≈øpected, that ≈øome cur≈øe cleaves to the very Office of Bi≈øhops, when good men cannot manage it to any better purpo≈øe then the bad, let any man judge.

This Spirituall Monarchy hath two incidents in≈øeparable unto it, fir≈øt that it is alwayes incroaching and u≈øurping upon other powers, and ≈øwallowing them up,
as the ≈øeries of all ages aboundantly manife≈øts. Secondly, that it is ever inclining and returning to Popery, and the Religion of Antichir≈øt, as hath mo≈øt cleerly appeared, even in our daies as well as before ≈øince the re≈øtoring of Religion; I ≈øhall for this time in≈øtance onely in three places of the Rubrick corrupted by Bi≈øhops: In the Rubrick confirmed by act of Parliament, in the beginning of it, It is directed, that prayer ≈øhall be in ≈øuch place of the Church or Chancell, and the Mini≈øter ≈øhall ≈øo turne him, as the people may be≈øt heare.
In the Rubrick as it is now Printed, prayer ≈øhall be u≈øed in the accu≈øtomed place, &c. except it ≈øhall be otherwi≈øe determined by the Ordinary.

Whereby they have introduced the Popi≈øh practice of reading Prayers at the upper end of the Chancell at their Altar, where few in the Church can ≈øee them, and fewer heare them, and turning their faces to the Ea≈øt, and their backs to the people in reading in the Desk, and colour all with the determination of the Ordinary.

Secondly, in the Letany, there are the≈øe words in the book of Common prayer confirmed by the Statutes of 5. and 6. Ed. 6. and of 1 Eliz. From the tyranny of the Bi≈øhop of Rome, and all his dete≈øtable enormities, good Lord deliver us; and that the Bi≈øhops in the latter books have cau≈øed to be left out wholly.

Thirdly, in the Rubrick concerning the admini≈øtration of the Lords Supper, as it ≈øtands now altered, an excellent declaration of the rea≈øon why kneeling at this Sacrament was left in the reformation, and a renunciation of Tran≈øub≈øtantiation, Con≈øub≈øtantiation, adoration of the bread and wine, as abhominable Idolatries, are wholly obliterate and left out, that the u≈øe of that ge≈øture there might be rendred the more ≈øu≈øpicious and ≈øuper≈øtitious, and a more clear way might be made, to induce the Popi≈øh ≈øuper≈øtitious innovations, that have been ≈øince obtruded upon us, concerning the Table,
Altar, ≈øupreminent pre≈øence of God almighty there, cringings, Altar-wor≈øhip and the like. And I conceive alterations were made by the Bi≈øhops, as appeares unto me by the Proclamation they procured to be ≈øet forth 5. Martii, 1. Jac. concerning the booke of Common prayer.

And how can things pro≈øper better in the hands of the Epi≈øcopacy, when Gods ble≈ø≈øing alone giveth out pro≈øperity, and the Lord di≈øpo≈øeth his ble≈ø≈øing in his owne way only, and not in any other?
And this being no plant planted by God in his Church, how can it be expected it ≈øhould yeeld us any better fruits then we have received from it?

Againe, (if I be not much deceived) the Epi≈øcopacy in what≈øoever it exceeds the Presbyters office (in which ≈øen≈øe only I ≈øpeak of it) is abranch of the Hierarchy of Rome, and of the Antichri≈øt: and of that con≈øider what is prophe≈øied Revel. 14.11. They ≈øhall not have any re≈øt day nor night, that receive any print of the name of the Bea≈øt; and examine the former and pre≈øent times, whether the ≈øame hath not been verified among us, and in all ≈øuch places where that Hierarchy hath been entertained, whether the mo≈øt troubles and mi≈øeries of the Churches, and in great part al≈øo of the Common-wealth, have not ≈øprung from the ≈øaid Epi≈øcopacy and the fruites thereof?

Therefore let us proceed to the perfecting of the Reformation of our Church, and to the gathering out of it every ≈øtone that offends, even what≈øoever is not according to God, and the ≈øtandard of his word, and reduce every thing in the government to the rule, and walke in it in Gods way, which is the ≈øure way to have his pre≈øence with us, and ble≈ø≈øing upon us and ours for ever.

It hath ever been a point of higher honour from God, and of greater acceptance and e≈øteem with him to advance
the reformation of his Church and wor≈øhip;2 Cro. 17.6. & 3. iI ‚Ä¢ 1 Kings 15.14. 2 Kings 12.3. 1 Cron. 28.16. Zac. 4.7. and was & ever will be a reproach from him, and blot upon ≈øuch as have left any thing not agreeable to his word unreformed, and not taken away: Up then let us be doing, and the Lord will goe before us, and make plain all mountains that may occurre in our way, and give a ble≈ø≈øed i≈ø≈øue and ≈øucce≈ø≈øe.

div.head: To the honorable Hou≈øes of Parliament now a≈ø≈øembled.
The humble Petition of many of the Inhabitants within his Maje≈øties County of Kent:
div.p: THat by ≈øad experience we doe daily finde the Government of the Church of England, by Arch-Bi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, Deans and Arch-Deacons, with their Courts, Juri≈ødictions, and Admini≈øtrations by them and their inferiour Officers, to be very dangerous both to Church and Commonwealth, to be the occa≈øions of manifold Grievances unto his Maje≈øties Subjects, in their Con≈øciences, Liberties, and E≈øtates, and likely to be fatall unto us in the continuance thereof, the dangerous effects of which Lordly power in them have often appeared in the≈øe particulars following.

list.item: 1 They doe (with a hard hand) over-rule all other Mini≈øters, ≈øubjecting them to their cruell Authority.

2 They doe ≈øu≈øpend and deprive many godly, Religious and painfull Mini≈øters, upon ≈øleight, and upon no grounds, while≈øt in the mean time few of them preach the Word of God them≈øelves, and that but ≈øeldome, but they doe re≈øtrain the painfull preaching of others, both for Lectures, and for afternoon Sermons on the Sabbath day.
3 They doe countenance, and have of late encouraged Papi≈øt Prie≈øts, and Arminian books and per≈øons.
4 They hinder good and godly books, yet they doe licen≈øe to be publi≈øhed many Popi≈øh and Arminian and other dangerous Books and Tenents.
5 They have deformed our Churches with Popi≈øh Pictures, and ≈øeated them with Romi≈øh Altars.
6 They have of late extolled and commended much the Church of Rome, denying the Pope to be Antichri≈øt, affirming the Church of Rome to be a true Church in Fundamentals.

7 They have practi≈øed and enforced antiquated and ob≈øolete Ceremonies, as ≈øtanding at all Hymns, and at Gloria patri, turning to the Ea≈øt at ≈øeverall parts of the Divine Service, Bowing at the Altar, which they term the place of Gods Refidence upon earth, the reading of a ≈øecond Service at the Altar, and denying the holy Sacrament of the Euchari≈øt to ≈øuch as have not come up to the new ≈øet rayl before the Altar.

8 They have made and confirmed new illegall Canons and Con≈øtitutions, and framed a mo≈øt pernitious and de≈øperate Oath, an Oath of covenant and confederacy for their own Hierarchicall greatne≈ø≈øe, be≈øides many other very dangerous and pernitious pa≈ø≈øages in the ≈øaid Canons.

9 They doe di≈øpen≈øe with pluralities of Benefices, they doe both prohibit and grant Marriages, neither of them by the rule of Law or Con≈øcience, but doe prohibit that they may grant, and grant that they may have money.

10 They have procured a licentious liberty for the Lords day, and have pre≈ø≈øed the ≈øtrict ob≈øervation of the Saints Holydayes, and doe puni≈øh, ≈øu≈øpend and deprive godly Mini≈øters, for not publi≈øhing that book for liberty of ≈øports on the Sabbath day.

11 They doe generally abu≈øe the great Ordinance of
Excommunication, making a great gain of it, ≈øometimes, to the great di≈øcomfort of many poore ≈øoules, who for want of money can get no ab≈øolution.
12 They claim their Office and Juri≈ødiction to be jure divino, and doe exerci≈øe the ≈øame contrary to Law in their own names, and under their own Seals.
13 They receive and take upon them temporall Honours, Dignities, Places, and Offices in the Common wealth, as if it were lawfull for them to u≈øe both ≈øwords.
14 They cognizance in their Courts and el≈øwhere of matters determinable at the Common Law.
15 They put Mini≈øters upon Pari≈øhes without the Patrons and without the peoples con≈øent.
16 They doe yearly impo≈øe Oaths upon Churchwardens, to the mo≈øt apparent danger of filling the land with perjuries.
17 They doe exerci≈øe Oaths Ex Officio in the Nature of an inqui≈øition even unto the thoughts of mens.
18 They have apprehended men by Pur≈øevants without ciration or mi≈ø≈øives fir≈øt ≈øent, they break up mens hou≈øes and ≈øtudies, taking away what they plea≈øe.
19 They doe aw the Judges of the Land with their greatne≈ø≈øe to the inhibiting of prohibition, and hindering of Habeas Corpus when it is due.

20 They are ≈øtrongly ≈øu≈øpected to be confederated with the Roman party in this Land, and with them to be Authors, Contrivers, or Con≈øenters to the pre≈øent Commotions in the North, and the rather becau≈øe of a Contribution by the Clergy and by the Papi≈øts in the la≈øt year 1639. and becau≈øe of an ill-named benevolence of ≈øix Subfidies, granted or intended to be granted this yeare 1640. thereby and with the≈øe monies to ingage (as much as in them lay) the two Nations into blood.

div.p:
It is therefore our humble and earne≈øt prayer, that all
this Hierarchicall power may be totally abrogated, if the wi≈ødome of this Honourable Hou≈øe ≈øhall finde that it cannot be maintained by Gods word and to his glory. And your Petitioners ≈øhall ever pray, &c.

div.head: The Petition of the Citizens of London to both hou≈øe of Parliament, wherein is a Demon≈øtration of their grievances, together with their de≈øires for Ju≈øtice to be excuted upon the Earle of Strafford, and other DELINQUENTS. To the mo≈øt Honorable A≈ø≈øembly of the Lords and Commons in this pre≈øent Parliament. The humble Petition of divers Citizens of London
div.p:
SHeweth, that notwith≈øtanding his Maje≈øties gracious An≈øwer to the humble Petition of his Loyall Subjects in ≈øummoning this Parliament, with the great care, and endeavoured pains, taken by both Hou≈øes for the removing the heavy Grievances in Church and Commonwealth, whereof the Petitioners have already received ≈øome fruit; for which they de≈øire to return their mo≈øt humble and utmo≈øt thanks, yet neverthele≈ø≈øe, they are inforced with all Humility to repre≈øent to this mo≈øt Honourable a≈ø≈øemblly, ≈øome of the≈øe Ob≈øtructions which doe ≈øtill hinder that freedome and fulne≈ø≈øe of Trade in this City they have formerly had, & which con≈øidering
the numerous Multitude thereupon depending, they conceive it not able comfortably to ≈øub≈øi≈øt.

As the un≈øetled Condition of the Kingdome, even ≈øince the troubles in Scotland hath cau≈øed both ≈øtrangers, and al≈øo of our own, who did furni≈øh great ≈øumms of money to U≈øe to call it in, and remit much of it by Exchange unto Forraine pars, and ≈øtands now in Expectation of what the i≈ø≈øue of things may be.

The ≈øtopping money in the Mint, which till then was accompted the ≈øafe≈øt place, and ≈øure≈øt ≈øtaple in the≈øe parts in the world, ≈øtill doth hinder the importation of Bullyon, the Scots now di≈øabled to pay ≈øuch debts as they owe to the Petitioners and others in the City, and by rea≈øon of the oppre≈ø≈øions exerci≈øed in Ireland, their debts al≈øo are detained there.
The Engli≈øh Trade by rea≈øon of our generall di≈øtractions and fears is ≈øo much decayed, that Country trade≈ømen can not pay their debts in London as formerly.
The great ≈øumms of money unduly taken by his Maje≈øties Officers and Farmers, for impo≈øitions upon Merchandize exported and imported, and the want of reliefe in Courts of Ju≈øtice again≈øt them.
The drawing out from the City great ≈øumms of money (which is the life and ≈øpirit of Trade) for his Maje≈øties ≈øervice in the North, and being there imployed is not yet returned.

Be≈øides all which from what ≈øtrong and ≈øecret oppo≈øition the Petitioners know not, they have not received what ≈øo much time and pains might give and cau≈øe to hope, but ≈øtill incendiaries of the Kingdoms and other notorious offenders remain unpuni≈øhed, the affaires of the Church notwith≈øtanding many Petitions concerning it and long debate about it remains un≈øettled, the Papi≈øts ≈øtill armed, the Laws again≈øt them not executed, ≈øome of the mo≈øt active of them ≈øtill at Court, Prie≈øts and Je≈ønits not yet bani≈øhed, the Iri≈øh Popi≈øh army not yet
disbanded, Courts of Ju≈øtice not yet reformed, and the Earle of Strafford who as now appears hath coun≈øelled the plundering of this City, and putting it to fine & ran≈øome, and ≈øaid it would never be well till ≈øome of the Aldermen were banged up, becau≈øe they would not yeeld to illegall levies of moneys, hath ≈øo drawn out and ≈øpent his time in his bu≈øine≈ø≈øe to the very great charge of the whol Kingdome, and his endeavour to obtain yet more; all which makes us fear there may be practices now in hand to hinder the birth of your great endeavours, and that we lie under ≈øome more dangerous plot then we can di≈øcover.

All which premi≈ø≈øes with their fears and di≈øtractions growing there-from, and from things of the like nature, the Petitioners humbly offer to the mo≈øt grave con≈øideration of this mo≈øt honorable a≈ø≈øembly, as being the true cau≈øes of decay of Trade, di≈øcouragement of Trade≈ømen, and of the great ≈øcarcity of monies, with the con≈øequences they labour under.

And do humbly pray that their ≈øaid grievances may be redre≈ø≈øed, the cau≈øes of their fears removed, Ju≈øtice executed upon the ≈øaid Earle and other incendiaries and offenders, the rather in regard till then, the Petitioners humbly conceive neither Religion nor their lives, liberties or e≈øtates can be≈øecured.

closer.signed: And as in duty bound they ≈øhall ever pray, &c.

postscript.p: Sub≈øcribed to this Petition 20000. all men of good ranke and quality.

div.head: Sir John Wrayes Speech concerning Bi≈øhops. 1641.
div.p:
THE fir≈øt challenge for Lordly Primacy hath of old been grounded out of the great Charter, by which
they hold an Epi≈øcopall Primacy or Juri≈ødiction to be long to their ≈øtate of Prelacy: this is their temporall ≈øoundation and main object. Here I demand of them, unto what Church this great Charter was granted, and whether it were not granted unto the Church of GOD in England? Let the words of the Magna Charta decide this, which are the≈øe; Conce≈ø≈øimus Deo pro ‚Ä¢ nobis in perpetuum, quod Eccle≈øia Anglicana libera ≈øit, habeat omnia Jura ≈øua iutegra & libertates ≈øuas illae≈øas. Now by this Charter, if it be rightly interpreted, there is fir≈øt provi≈øion made that honour and wor≈øhip be yeelded unto God, as truly and indeed belong unto him.

Secondly, that not only ≈øuch Rights and Liberties as the King and his Progenitors, but al≈øo that ≈øuch as God had endowed the Church of England with, which God him≈øelf hath given by his Law unto the univer≈øall Church, and in that which the Kings of England by their Charter have bequeathed to the particular Church of England; and this we doubt not was the cau≈øe that moved Hen. 8. ≈øo effectually and powerfully to bend him≈øelfe again≈øt the Popes Supremacy, u≈øurped at that time over the Church of England; for, ≈øaith the King, we will with hazard of life and lo≈ø≈øe of our Crown uphold and defend in our Realms what≈øoever we ≈øhall know to be the will of God.
