The Church of God then in England not being free, according to the great Charter, but in bondage and ≈øervitude to the See of Rome, contrary to the Law of God, the King judged it to ≈øtand highly with honour, and his Oath to reform, redre≈ø≈øe, and amend the abu≈øes of the ≈øame See.

If then it might plea≈øe our gracious Soveraign Lord King Charles, that now is, in Imitation of that his noble Progenitor to vouch≈øafe an aboli≈øhment of all Lordly Primacy executed by Archepi≈øcopall and Epi≈øcopall authority over the Mini≈øters of Chri≈øt, his Highne≈ø≈øe
in ≈øo doing could no more rightly be charged with the violation of the great Charter, then might King Henry the eight, with the bani≈øhment of the Popi≈øh Supremacy, or then our late Soveraign Lady Q. Elizabeth could be ju≈øtly burdened with the breach of her Oath by the E≈øtabli≈øhment of the Go≈øpell. Now if the Kings of England by rea≈øon of their Oath were ≈øo ≈øtraitly tied to the words of the great Charter, that they might not in any ≈øort have di≈øanulled any ≈øuppo≈øed Rights or Liberties of the Church u≈øed and confirmed by the ≈øaid Charter unto the Church, that then was ≈øuppo≈øed to be the Church of God in England, then be like King Henry 8. might be attainted to have gone again≈øt the great Charter and again≈øt his Oath, when by the overthrow of Abbeys and Mona≈øteries he took away the Rights and Liberties of the Abbots & Priers, for by expre≈ø≈øe words of the great Charter, Abbots and Priers had as large and ample a Patent for their Rights and Liberties, as our Archbi≈øhops and Bi≈øhops can at this day challenge for their Primacy.

If then the Rights and Liberties of the one, as being again≈øt the Law of God, be duely and lawfully taken away, notwith≈øtanding any matter, clau≈øe or ≈øentence contained in the great Charter, the other having but little rea≈øon by colour of the great Charter to ≈øtand upon their pantofles, and to contend for their painted ≈øheaves, for this is a Rule and Maxime in Gods laws; that In omni Juramento ≈øemper excipitur authoritas majoris.

Unle≈ø≈øe then they be able to ju≈øtifie by the holy ≈øcriptures, that ≈øuch Rights and Liberties, as they pretend for their ≈øpirituall Primacy over the Mini≈øters of Chri≈øt, be in Deed and Truth inferred unto them by the holy law of God, I ≈øuppo≈øe the Kings Highne≈ø≈øe (as ≈øucce≈ø≈øor to Hen. 8. and as mo≈øt ju≈øt inheritour of the Crown of England) by the words of the great Charter, and by his Oath, is bound utterly to aboli≈øh all Lordly Primacy, as hitherto upheld and defended, partly by ignorance and partly by an unrea≈øonable and evill Cu≈øtome.

div.head: My Lord DIGBIES Speech in Parliament, 1640.
div.p:
THis happie meeting, is to bemoane and redre≈ø≈øe the unhappie State of this Common-wealth. Let me have I be≈øeech you your leave, to give you in a word, a ≈øhort view of our griefes, then ≈øee whence they flow. Our Lawes, our liberties, our lives, and which is the life of all, our Religion; all which have been by the endeavours of ≈øo many Ages ≈øecured, and made ≈øo much our owne, can ≈øcarce be called ours. Our Lawes, the only finews and ligeaments of our e≈øtates, which ≈øhould run in an even ≈øtreame, are now made to di≈ødaine their bancks, and to overflow and drown their fields, which they ≈øhould gently redre≈ø≈øe our liberties, the very ≈øpirit and e≈ø≈øence of our weale, which ≈øhould differ us from ≈ølaves, and ≈øpeake us Engli≈øh-men; are held away by them, that even whiles they take them from us, cannot but confe≈ø≈øe they are our proper dues. Are not our lives in danger, when an enemy di≈øgui≈øed like a friend provoked, is as it were ≈øuffered (becau≈øe indirectly, and in vaine re≈øi≈øted) to come almo≈øt into our bo≈øomes, to rifle ≈øome of their goods, others of their loyalty; which perhaps they could not, neither would have touched, might we with united force have re≈øi≈øted. And la≈øtly, which is the ≈øoule of all our grievances; our Religion,
which ≈øhould have beene our Cordiall in all our di≈øtempers; like a forced Virgin laments ever, that her pure innocencie is taken from her; and ≈øure all the≈øe effects mu≈øt have their cau≈øes.

That we have ju≈øt, and wi≈øe Lawes, we may thanke tho≈øe good Kings that made them; the ≈øettled expo≈øition of ju≈øt circum≈øcribed Lawes to binde and defend the Subject. That they are ≈øo well framed and u≈øefud, and to containe enough to make a good King and people, be perfect, be ≈øafe, and happie.

What do we owe to the≈øe grave Councellors‚ñ™ who ≈øate here before us, and that they out-live the malice of ≈øome unbounded ≈øpirits; we are beholding to them that Reprieved them from ruine, with their lives and fortunes; we call them ours, becau≈øe we are freely born to them, as to the Ayre we breath in;we claime them and ≈øhould po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe them under the Protection of our gracious King, who is their great Patron, and di≈øpo≈øes them not incon≈øiderately, but by the advice of tho≈øe learned expo≈øitors of the Lawes (the Judges) and tho≈øe whom he tru≈øts to be his great and faithfull Councellors. If tho≈øe pervert the ground and meaning of the Law, and contract ‚Ä¢ he power of it, or make it ≈øpeake lowder or ≈øofter, as they them≈øelves are tuned for it; the blame ≈øhould de≈øervedly fall on tho≈øe mi≈øtru≈øted mini≈øters, who are the ba≈øe betrayers of his Maje≈øties honor, and his Peoples right; to vindicate which nece≈ø≈øitie, hath here a≈ø≈øembled you.

Mr. Speaker, Is not this offence and m lice, as great, who ≈øhould undermine my Tenour, and ≈øurruptiou≈øly deprive me of my evidence by which I held my Inheritance, as he who by violence ≈øhould wre≈øt it from me. The Scots we have heard branded as Traytors, becau≈øe they have contrary to the law of Nations, and their loyaltie, invaded our Kingdome in Arms; what other title have they merited, who have invaded our Lawes and liberties, the precious evidence by which we ≈øhould freely enjoy our
≈øelves, and our e≈øtates. The fir≈øt, we may re≈øi≈øt and drive forth by united force, and it will be called pietie to the King and Countrie; if force be lay'd again≈øt the other, it will be ≈øtiled Rebellion.

What now remaines, but that we ≈øhould u≈øe the Law; which becau≈øe it hath beene inverted and turned again≈øt us, contrary to its owne naturall and plaine di≈øpo≈øition, ≈øhould now right us and it ≈øelf again≈øt our Adver≈øaries. Surely the Law is not ≈øo weak and improvident, to take care for others, and never provide for its owne defence again≈øt tho≈øe (be they Peeres, or people) that have abu≈øed it. If we examine the Law well, it will tell us what hath beene the reward of ≈øuch ambitious men, as have Monopolized and abu≈øed the Kings Authoritie; what have beene the puni≈øhment of ≈øuch as have betrayed the well meaning Subject to the Kings di≈øplea≈øure, and his Princes Councell to his enemies? what doe they de≈øerve, who have rai≈øed mountaines of Monopolies, heapes of impo≈øitions, oceans of grievances? what have been the puni≈øhment of ≈øuch as have belied Ju≈øtice, and their con≈øcience, and have made truth and hone≈øty our of fa≈øhion.

And la≈øtly, If no penaltie be found for the≈øe, ≈øure there is ≈øome for ≈øuch as have ≈øo di≈øgui≈øed Religion in fanta≈øticke dre≈ø≈øes, that Heaven andearth cannot be but angrie to ≈øee it; and in their politique pride have beene ≈øo long moulding a new State, and a new old Church for their owne advantage, till they have by their too much order put all out of frame, and made us objects of pitie, and them≈øelves of hate. What if for the≈øe innovations, we innovate an examplary puni≈øhment? The≈øe are the ground-works of our mi≈øeries; and ≈øurely, Mr. Speaker, there are too many of all the≈øe ≈øorts, which like envious clouds, hinders us from ‚Ä¢ he gracious ≈øhine our Sun intends us; therefore for his great r lu≈øtre, and our more a≈ø≈øured comfort, let us endeavour to remove the≈øe interpo≈øers,
that he may more freely ≈øee into his peoples bo≈øomes, and reade in their hearts firme characters of loyaltie and glad obedience, which the practices of the≈øe later times have endeavoured to obliterate, but in vaine.

I ≈øhall not dare to borrow one minute of you more; but I ≈øhall alreadie end, though I have ju≈øt now begun. If we con≈øider the ju≈øt extent of our grievances, the deep ≈øearch of which wound I leave to you better abilities; and I be≈øeech you think not that I ≈øigh out the≈øe complaints, undertaking to in≈øtruct the grave Councell of this great A≈ø≈øembly, my infant advice pre≈øumes not to reach ≈øo high: It is but to let you ≈øee how much the ≈ølighte≈øt parts of this abu≈øed Common-wealth, is not only made ≈øen≈øible of our wrongs, but what we feele is farre exceeded by the numberle≈ø≈øe number of our ju≈øt feares, which ≈øhould have before this time utterly di≈øtracted us, had not our great Phi≈øition now at length applied his ≈øoveraigne remedie, to keep up our fainting hopes, by which we mu≈øt either ≈øtand, or fall.

div.head: Ma≈øter Pyms Speech in PARLIAMENT. 1640.
div.p: THe di≈øtempers of this Kingdome are well knowne, they need not repetition. For though we have good Lawes, yet they want their execution; or if they are executed, it is in a wrong ≈øence. I ≈øhall endeavour to apply a remedie to the breaches that are made, and to that end, I ≈øhall di≈øcover fir≈øt the qualitie of the di≈øea≈øe.

Fir≈øt, There is a de≈øigne to alter Law and Religion: the parties that effect this, are Papi≈øts, who are obliged by a maxime in their doctrine, that they are not onely bound to maintaine their Religion, but al≈øo to extirpate all others.

The ≈øecond is their Hierarchie which cannot amount to the height they ayme at, without a breach of our Law. To which their Religion nece≈ø≈øarily ioynes, that if the one ≈øtands, the other mu≈øt fall.

Thirdly, Agents and Pen≈øioners to forraigne States, who ≈øee we cannot comply to them, if we maintaine our Religion e≈øtabli≈øhed, which is contrary to theirs, here they intend chiefly the Spani≈øh white gold works which are of mo≈øt effect.

Fourthly, Favourites, ≈øuch as for promotion prize not con≈øcience, and ≈øuch are our Judges ≈øpirituall, and temporall; ≈øuch are al≈øo ≈øome of our Councellors of State. All the≈øe, though ≈øevered, yet in their contrivements they ayme at one end, and to this they walke on four feet.
Fir≈øt, di≈øcountenancing of Preachers, and vertuous men, they per≈øecute under the law of purity.
Secondly, Countenancing of Preachers of contrary di≈øpo≈øitions.
Thirdly, The negotiating with the faction of Rome by Preaching, and to in≈øtructions to Preach of the ab≈øolute Monarchie of Kings.

p.hi: Here follow ≈øeverall Heads.

div.p: Fir≈øt, The politicall interpretation of the Law to ≈øerve their turnes, and thus to impo≈øe taxes with a colour of Law; a Judge ≈øayd it when a babe is corpus was payd for.

Secondly, By keeping the King in continuall want, that he may ≈øeeke to their coun≈øells for r liefe; to this purpo≈øe, to keepe the Parliaments in di≈øta≈øte, that their coun≈øells may be taken. The King by them is brought to
this, as a woman that u≈øed her ≈øelfe to poy≈øon could not live with good meate. Search the Chronicles, and we ≈øee no King that ever u≈øed Parliaments, was brought to this want.
Thirdly, Arbitrary proceedings in Courts of Ju≈øtice; we have all Law left to the con≈øcience of a ≈øingle man. All Courts are now Courts of con≈øcience, without con≈øcience.
Fourthly, Plotters to inforce a war between Scotland, and us; that when we had well wearied one another, we might be both brought to what ≈øcorn they plea≈øed; The pertition wall is only unity.

Fiftly, The ≈øuddaine di≈ø≈øolving of Parliaments, and puni≈øhing of Parliament men, all to affright us from ≈øpeaking what we thinke. One was committed for not delivering up the Petitions of the Hou≈øe; then a declaration which ≈ølandered our Proceedings, as full of lyes, as leaves, who would have the fir≈øt ground to be our example. And Papi≈øts are under appearance to the King his be≈øt Subjects, for they contibute money to the War, which the Prote≈øtants will not do.

Sixthly, Another is Military, by getting places of importance into the Papi≈øts hands, as who are Commanders in the la≈øt Armie but they? none more ≈øtrong in Armes, then they, to whom their Armour is delivered contrary to the Statute. Their endeavour is to bring in ≈øtrangers to be Billited upon us; we have had no accompt of the Spani≈øh Navie, and now our fear is from Ireland.
La≈øtly, The next is Papi≈øticall that proceeds of Agents here in London, by who≈øe de≈øires many Mona≈øteries and Nunneries here in London were erected.

div.head: Sir Thomas Baringtons Speech in Parliament, 1640.
div.p: WE have of late entred into con≈øideration of the Petition of Right, and the relation of it; and upon good rea≈øon, for it concernes our goods, liberties and lives. But there is a Right of higher nature, that pre≈øerved for us farre greater things, eternall life, our ≈øoules, yea, our God him≈øelfe; a Religion derived to us from the King of Kings, conferred to us by the Kings of this Kingdome, enacted by Lawes in this place, treading downe to us in the bloud of the Martyes, and witne≈ø≈øed from Heaven by miracles, even miraculous deliverances. And this Right in the name of this Nation, I this day require, and claime, that there may be a deepe and ≈øerious con≈øideration of the relations of it.
I de≈øire fir≈øt, that it may be con≈øidered what new paintings are layd on the old face of the Whore of Babylon, to make the more lovely, and to draw ≈øo many Suitors to her.

I de≈øire that it may be con≈øidered, how the Sea of Rome doth eate into our Religion, and fret into he banks and walls of it, the Lawes and Statutes of this Realme, e≈øpecially ≈øince the≈øe Lawes have beene made in a manner by them≈øelves, even by their owne Trea≈øons and bloudy
de≈øignes; and ≈øince that Poperie is a con≈øu≈øed ma≈ø≈øe of errors, ca≈øting downe Kings before Popes, the Precepts of God, before the tradition of men, living, and rea≈øonable men, before dead and ≈øencele≈ø≈øe ≈øtocks and ≈øtones.

I de≈øire that we con≈øider the encrea≈øe of Arminiani≈øme and errors, that makes the grace of God to lackie it after the will of man, that makes the Sheepe keepe the Shepheard, and make an immortall ≈øeed, of a mortall God.

Yea, I de≈øire that we looke into the very belly and bowells of this Trojan hor≈øe, to ≈øee if there be not in it men readie to open the gates of Romi≈øh tyranny, and Spani≈øh Monarchie, for an Arminian is the ≈øpaune of a Papi≈øt; and if their come the warmth of favour upon him, you ≈øhall have him turne into one of tho≈øe frogs that ari≈øe out of the bottomele≈ø≈øe pit; and if you marke it well, you ≈øhall ≈øee an Arminian reach out his hand to a Papi≈øt, to a Je≈øuite, a Je≈øuite gives one hand to the Pope, another to the King of Spaine; and therein having kindled a fire in our neighbors Countrey, now they have brought ≈øome of it hither, to ≈øet on flame this kingdome al≈øo.

Let us further ≈øearch and con≈øider, whether the≈øe be not the men that breake in upon the goods and liberties of this Common-wealth, for by the≈øe meanes they may make way for the taking away of Religion. It was an old tricke of the Devills, when he meant to take away Jobs Religion, he began at his goods; Lay thy hand on all be hath, and be will cur≈øe even to thy face. Rather they thinke hereby to ≈øet a di≈øtance betweene Prince and people, or to finde ≈øome other way of ≈øupply to avoyd or breake Parliaments, that ≈øo they may break in upon our Religion, and bring in their errors: but let us doe as Job did, he held fa≈øt his Religion, and his goods were re≈øtored with advantage; and if we hold fa≈øt God, and our Religion, the≈øe things ≈øhall be unto us.

Let us con≈øider the times pa≈øt, how we flouri≈øhed in honor and abundance, when Religion flouri≈øhed among≈øt us, but when Religion decayed, ≈øo the honour and ≈øtrength of our Nation decayed; when the ≈øoul of this Common-wealth is dead, the bodie cannot long over live it. If a man meete a Dogge alone, the Dog is fearefull, but though never ≈øo fierce by nature; if that Dog have his Ma≈øter by him, he will ≈øet upon that man from whom he fied before. This ≈øhewes, the lower natures being back't with the higher, increa≈øe in courage and ≈øtrength; and certainly, man being back't with omnipotence, is a kinde of omnipotence. Wherefore let it now be the unanimous con≈øent and re≈øolution of us all, to make a vow and Covenant from henceforth, to hold fa≈øt on God, and his Religion; and then may we from henceforth expect pro≈øperitie in the Kingdome and Nation to this Covenant.
div.closer: Let every one of us ≈øay, Amen.

div.head: The Accu≈øation and Impeachment of Sir George Ratcliffe by the Commons in this pre≈øent Parliament A≈ø≈øembled, Charging him with High-Trea≈øon, and other mi≈ødemeanours as en≈øue. 1640.
div.p: IMprimis, That he had con≈øpired with the Earle of Strafford to bring into Ireland an Arbitrary Government, and to ≈øubvert the fundementall Lawes, and did joyn with the Earle to bring in an Armie from Ireland, to ≈øubdue the Subjects of England.
Secondly, That he hath joyned with the Earle to u≈øe Regall power, and to deprive the Subjects of their liberties, and properties.
Thirdly, That he hath joyned with the Earle to take _____ thou≈øand pounds out of the Exchequer in Ireland, and bought Tobacco therewith, and converted the ≈øame profits to their own u≈øes.
Fourthly, That he had Trayterou≈øly confederated with the Earle to countenance Papi≈øts, and build Mona≈øteries, to alienate the affections of the Iri≈øh Subjects from the ≈øubjection of England.
Fiftly, That he had Traiterou≈øly confederated with the Earle, to draw the Subjects of Scotland from the King.
Sixthly, That to pre≈øerve him≈øelfe and the ≈øayd Earle, he had laboured to ≈øubvert the liberties and priviledges of Parliament in Ireland.

div.head: The Charge of the Scotti≈øh Commi≈øsioners again≈øt the Prelate of CANTERBVRY.
div.p: NOvations in Religion, which are univer≈øally acknowledged to be the maine cau≈øe of commotions in Kingdomes and States, and are knowne to be the true cau≈øe of our pre≈øent troubles, were many and great, be≈øide the book of Ordination, and Homilies. 1. Some particular alterations in matters of Religion, pre≈ø≈øed upon us without order, and again≈øt Law, contrary to the forme e≈øtabli≈øhed in our Kirk. 2. A new booke of Canons and Con≈øtitutions Eccle≈øia≈øticall. 3. A Liturgy, or booke of Common-prayer, which did al≈øo carry with them many dangerous errors in matters of Doctrine. Of all which we challenge the Prelate of Canterburie, as the prime cau≈øe on earth.

And fir≈øt, that this Prelate was the Author and urger of ≈øome particular changes, which made great di≈øturbance among≈øt us, we make manife≈øt. 1. By fourteen letters ≈øub≈øcribed, W. Cant. in the ≈øpace of two yeares, to one of our pretended Bi≈øhops, Bannatine, wherein he often enjoyneth him, and other pretended Bi≈øhops, to appeare in the Chappell in their whites, contrary to the cu≈øtome of our Kirk, and to his promi≈øe made to the pretended Bi≈øhop of Edinburgh, at the Coronation, that none of them after that time, ≈øhould be pre≈ø≈øed to weare
the≈øe garments, thereby moving him again≈øt his will to put them on for that time; wherein he directeth him to give order for ≈øaying the Engli≈øh Service in the Chappell twice a day, for his neglect ≈øhewing him, that he was di≈øappointed of the Bi≈øhopricke of Edinburgh, promi≈øing him upon the greater care of the≈øe Novations, advancement to a better Bi≈øhoprick, taxing him for his boldne≈ø≈øe in Preaching the ≈øound Doctrine of the reformed Kirks, again≈øt Ma≈øter Mitchell, who had taught the errors of Arminius in the point of the extent of the merit of Chri≈øt, bidding him ≈øend up a li≈øt of the names of Councellours and Senators of the Colledge of Ju≈øtice, who did not communicate in the Chappell, in a forme which was not received in our Kirk, commending him when he found him ob≈øequious to the≈øe his commands; telling him that he had moved the King the ≈øecond time for the puni≈øhment of ≈øuch as had not received in the Chappell: and wherein he upbraided him bitterly, that in his fir≈øt Synod at Aberdein, he had only di≈øputed again≈øt our cu≈øtome of Scotland, of fa≈øting ≈øometimes on the Lords day, and pre≈øumptuou≈øly cen≈øuring our Kirk, that in this we were oppo≈øite to Chri≈øtianity it ≈øelfe, and that among≈øt us there were no Canons at all: More of this ≈øtuffe may be ≈øeen in the letters them≈øelves.

Secondly, by two papers of memoirs and in≈øtructions from the pretended Bi≈øhop of Saint Androis, to the pretended Bi≈øhop of Ro≈ø≈øe, comming to this Prelate for ordering the affairs of the Kirk, and Kingdome of Scotland; as not only to obtain warrants, to order the Exchequer, the Privy Coun≈øell, the great Commi≈ø≈øion of Surrenders, the matter of Balmerino's proce≈ø≈øe, as might plea≈øe our Prelates; but warrants al≈øo for ≈øitting of the High-Commi≈ø≈øion Court once a weeke in Edinburgh, and to gaine from the Noblemen, for the benefit of Prelates, and their adherents, the Abbacies of Kel≈øo, Arbroith, St. Androis, and Lindors, and in the ≈ømalle≈øt matters to receive
his commands, as for taking downe Galleries and ≈øtonewalls in the Kirk of Edinburgh, and St. Androis, for no other end but to make way for Altars, and adoration towards the Ea≈øt; which be≈øide other evills, made no ≈ømall noi≈øe and di≈øturbance among≈øt the people, deprived hereby of their ordinary accommodation for publique wor≈øhippe.

The ≈øecond Novation which troubled our peace, was a booke of Canons, and Con≈øtitutions Eccle≈øia≈øticall, obtruded upon our Kirk, found by our generall A≈ø≈øembly, to be devi≈øed for e≈øtabli≈øhing a tyrannicall power in the per≈øons of our Prelates, over the wor≈øhip of God, over the con≈øciences, liberties, and goods of the people; and for aboli≈øhing the whole Di≈øcipline and government of our Kirk, by generall and provinciall A≈ø≈øemblies, Presbyteries, and Kirk-Se≈ø≈øions which was ≈øetled by Law, and in continuall practi≈øe ≈øince the time of Reformation; that Canterbury was Ma≈øter of this work is manife≈øt.

By a booke of Canons ≈øent to him, written upon the one ≈øide onely, with the other ≈øide blanke, for corrections, additions, and putting all in better order at his plea≈øure; which accordingly was done, as may appeare by interlinings, marginalls, and filling up of the blanke page, with directions ≈øent to the Prelates; and that it was done by no other then Canterbury, is evident by his Magi≈øteriall way of the pre≈øcribing, and by a new copie of the≈øe Canons, all written with St. Androis owne hand, preci≈øely to a letter, according to the former ca≈øtigations ≈øent back for procuring the Kings warrant unto it, which accordingly was obtained; but with an addition of ≈øome other Canons, and a paper of ≈øome other corrections. According to which, the book of Canons thus compo≈øed, was publi≈øhed in Print, the in≈øpection of the books, in≈øtructions, and his letters of joy for the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of the worke, and of others letters of the Prelate of London, and the Lord Sterling, to the ≈øame purpo≈øe; all which
we are readie to exhibite, will put the matter out of all debate.

Be≈øides this generall, there be ≈øome things more ≈øpeciall worthy to be adverted unto, for di≈øcovering his ≈øpirit. 1. The fourth Canon of Cap. 8. for a≈ømuch as no reformation in Doctrine or Di≈øcipline can be made perfect at once in any Church; therefore it ≈øhall, and may be lawfull fort the Church of Scotland at any time to make remon≈øtrance to his M. or his ≈øucce≈ø≈øors, &c. Becau≈øe this Canon holdeth the doore open to more innovations: He writeth to the Prelate of Ro≈ø≈øe his privie agent in all this worke of his great gladne≈ø≈øe, that this Canon did ≈øtand bebinde the curtaine, and his great de≈øire that this Canon may be printed fully, as one that was to be mo≈øt u≈øefull. Secondly, the title prefixed to the≈øe Canons by our Prelates. Canons agreed upon to be proponed to the ≈øeverall Synods of the Kirk of Scotland; is thus changed by Canterbury; Canons and con≈øtitutions Eccle≈øia≈øticall, &c. Ordained to be ob≈øerved by the Clergy. He will not have Canons to come from the authority of Synods, but from the power of Prelates, or from the Kings Prerogative. Thirdly, the formidable Canon, Cap. 1.3. threatning no le≈ø≈øe then excommunication again≈øt all ≈øuch per≈øons who≈øoever ≈øhall open their mouthes again≈øt any of the≈øe bookes, proceeded not from our Prelates, nor is to be found in the copie ≈øent from them, but is a thunder bolt forged in Canterburies owne fire. 4. Our Prelates in divers places witne≈ø≈øe their di≈ølike of Papi≈øts. A Mini≈øter ≈øhall be depo≈øed if he be found negligent to convert Papi≈øts. Cap. 18.15. The adoration of the bread is a ≈øuper≈øtition to be condemned. Cap. 6.6. They call the ab≈øolute nece≈ø≈øitie of Bapti≈øme, an error of Popery. Cap. 6.2. But in Canterburies Edition, the name of Papi≈øts and Poperie is not ≈øo much as mentioned. 5. Our Prelates have not the boldne≈ø≈øe to trouble us in their Canons, with Altars, Fonts, Chancells, reading of a long Liturgie before
Sermon, &c. But Canterburie is punctuall, and peremptory in all the≈øe. Although the words of the tenth Canon cap. 3. be faire, yet the wicked intentions of Canterburie, and Ro≈ø≈øe, may be ≈øeen in the point of ju≈øtification of a ≈øinner before God, by comparing the Canon as it came from our Prelates, and as it was returned from Canterbury, and printed, our Prelates ≈øay thus: It is manife≈øt that the ≈øuper≈øtition of former Ages, hath turned into a great prophane≈ø≈øe, and that people are growne cold for the mo≈øt part in doing any good, thinking there is no place to good works, becau≈øe they are excluded from ju≈øtification. Therefore ≈øhall all Mini≈øters, as their Text giveth occa≈øion, urge the nece≈ø≈øitie of good works, as they would be ≈øaved, and remember that they are via regni, the way to the Kingdome of Heaven, though not cau≈øa regnandi, howbeit they be not the cau≈øe of ≈øalvation. Here Ro≈ø≈øe giveth his judgement, That he would have this Canon, ≈øimply commanding good workes to be preached, and no mention made what place they have, or have not in ju≈øtification. Upon this motion, ≈øo agreeable to Canterburies minde, the Canon is ≈øet downe as it ≈øtandeth without the di≈øtinction of via regni, or cau≈øa regnandi, or any word ≈øounding that way, urging onely the nece≈ø≈øitie of good works. 7. By comparing Can. 9. cap. 18. as it was ≈øent in writing from our Prelates, and as it is printed at Canterburies command, may be al≈øo manife≈øt, that he went about to e≈øtabli≈øh auricular confe≈ø≈øion, and Popi≈øh ab≈øolution. 8. Our Prelates were not acquainted with Canons, for afflicting of arbitrary penalties: But in Canterburies booke, where≈øoever there is no penalty expre≈ø≈øely ≈øet downe, it is provided that it ≈øhall be arbitrarie, as the Ordinary ≈øhall thinke fitte≈øt. By the≈øe and many other the like, it is apparant, what tyrannicall power he went about to e≈øtabli≈øh in the hands of our Prelates, over the wor≈øhip, and the ≈øouls and goods of men, overturning from the foundation, the whole order of our Kirk, what ≈øeeds of Popery he did ≈øow in our Kirk,
and how large an entry he did make for the gro≈ø≈øe≈øt Novations afterward, which hath been a main cau≈øe of all their combu≈øtion.

The third and great Novation was the booke of Common Prayer, admini≈øtration of the Sacraments, and other parts of divine Service, brought in without warrant from our Kirk to be univer≈øally received, as the only form of divine Service, under al ‚Ä¢ highe≈øt paines both civill and Eccle≈øia≈øticall, which is found by our Nationall A≈ø≈øembly; be≈øides the Popi≈øh frame and formes in divine wor≈øhip, to containe many Popi≈øh errors, and ceremonies, and the ≈øeeds of manifold and gro≈ø≈øe ≈øuper≈øtitions and idolatries, and to be repugnant to the Doctrine, Di≈øcipline, and order of our Reformation, to the confe≈ø≈øion of faith, con≈øtitutions of generall A≈ø≈øemblies, and Acts of Parliament, e≈øtabli≈øhing the true Religion: that this al≈øo was Canterburies worke, we make manife≈øt.

By the memoirs, and in≈øtructions ≈øent unto him from our Prelates, wherein they gave a ≈øpeciall account of the diligence they had u≈øed, to do all which herein they were enjoyned, by the approbation of the Service booke ≈øent to them; and of all the marginall corrections, wherein it varieth from the Engli≈øh book, ≈øhewing their de≈øire to have ≈øome few things changed in it, which notwith≈øtanding was not granted: This we finde written by Saint Androis own hand, and ≈øub≈øcribed by him, and nine other of our Prelates.

By Canterburies owne letters, witne≈ø≈øes of his joy, when the booke was readie for the Pre≈ø≈øe, of his prayers that God would ≈øpeed the worke, of the hope to ≈øee that Service ≈øet up in Scotland, of his diligence to ≈øend for the Printer, and directing him to prepare a black letter, and to ≈øend it to his ≈øervants at Edinburgh, for printing this booke. Of his approbation of his proofes ≈øent from the Pre≈ø≈øe. Of his feare of delay, in bringing the worke ≈øpeedily to an end, for the great good, (not of that
Church, but) of the Church Of his encouraging Ro≈ø≈øe, who was entru≈øted with the Pre≈ø≈øe, to go on in this peece of ≈øervice without feare of enemies. All which may be ≈øeen in the Autographs, and by letters ≈øent from the Prelate of London to Ro≈ø≈øe, wherein as he rejoyceth at the ≈øight of the Scotti≈øh Canons; which although they ≈øhould make ≈øome noi≈øe at the beginning, yet they would be more for the good of the Kirk, than the Canons of Edinburgh, for the good of the Kingdom. So concerning the Leiturgy he ≈øheweth, that Ro≈ø≈øe had ≈øent to him, to have an explanation from Canterbury of ≈øome pa≈ø≈øage of the Service booke, and that the Pre≈ø≈øe behoved to ≈øtand, till the explanation come to Edinburgh, which therefore he had in ha≈øte obtained from his Grace, and ≈øent the di≈øpatch away by Canterburies own conveyance.

But the booke it ≈øelfe as it ≈øtandeth interlined, margined, and patcht up, is much more than all that is expre≈ø≈øed in his letters, and the changes and ≈øupplements them≈øelves taken from the Ma≈ø≈øe-booke, and other Romi≈øh Ritualls, by which he maketh it to vary from the Booke of England, are more pregnant te≈øtimonies of his popi≈øh ≈øpirit, and wicked intentions which he would have put in execution upon us, then can be denied. The large declaration profe≈ø≈øeth, that all the variation of our booke, from the booke of England, that ever the King under≈øtood, was in ≈øuch things as the Scotti≈øh humour would better comply with, than with that which ≈øtood in the Engli≈øh Service. The≈øe popi≈øh innovations therefore have been ≈øurreptitiou≈øly in≈øerted by him, without the Kings knowledge, and again≈øt his purpo≈øe. Our Scotti≈øh Prelates do petition that ≈øomething may be abated of the Engli≈øh ceremonies, as the Cro≈ø≈øe in Bapti≈øme, the Ring in Marriage, and ≈øome other things. But Canterbury will not only have the≈øe kept, but a great many more, and wor≈øe ≈øuperadded, which was nothing el≈øe, but the adding of fewell to the fire. To expre≈ø≈øe and di≈øcover all,
would require a whole booke, we ≈øhall only touch ≈øome few in the matter of the Communion.

This book inverteth the ordor of the Communion in the book of England, as may be ≈øeen by the numbers, ≈øetting down the orders of this new Communion, 1.5.2.6.7.3.4.8.9.10.15. Of the divers ≈øecret rea≈øons of this change, we mention one only; in joyning the ≈øpirituall prai≈øe and thank≈øgiving, which is in the book of England, pertinently after the Communion, with the prayer of Con≈øecration before the Communion, and that under the name of memorable or oblation, for no other end, but that the memoriall and ≈øacrifice of prai≈øe, mentioned in it, may be under≈øtood according to the popi≈øh meaning. Bellar. de Mi≈ø≈øae, lib. 2. cap. 21. Not of the ≈øpirituall ≈øacrifice, but of the oblation of the body of the Lord.

It ≈øeemeth to be no great matter, that without warrant of the book of England, the Presbter going from the North end of the Tabls, ≈øhall ≈øtand during the time of Con≈øecration, at ≈øuch a part of the Table, where he may with the more ea≈øe and decencie u≈øe both hands; yet being tryed; it importeth much, as that he mu≈øt ≈øtand with his hinder parts to the people, repre≈øenting (≈øayth Durand) that which the Lord ≈øayd of Mo≈øes, Thou ≈øhalt ≈øee my hinder parts. He mu≈øt have the u≈øe of both his hands, not for any thing he hath to do about the bread and wine, for that may be done at the North end of the Table, and be better ≈øeen of the people; but (as we are taught by the Rationali≈øts) that he may be ≈øtretching forth his arms, to repre≈øent the exten≈øion of Chri≈øt on the Cro≈ø≈øe, and that he may the more conveniently lift up the bread and wine above his head to be ≈øeen and adored of the people, who in the Rubrick of the generall Confe≈ø≈øion, a little before, are directed to kneel humbly on their knees, that the Prie≈øts elevation ≈øo magnified in the Ma≈ø≈øe, and the peoples adoration may go together; That in this po≈øture, ≈øpeaking with a low voyce, and
muttering (for ≈øometimes he is commanded to ≈øpeak with a lowd voyce, and di≈øtinctly) he be not heard by the people; which is no le≈ø≈øe a mocking of God, and his people, then if the words were ≈øpoken in an unknown language. As there is no word of all this in the Engli≈øh Service, ≈øo doth the booke in King Ed. time, give to every Presbyter his liberty of ge≈øture, which yet gave ≈øuch offence to Bucer, (the cen≈øurer of the book: and even in Ca≈ø≈øanders own judgement, a man of great moderation in matters of this kinde) that he calleth them, Nunquam ≈øatis execrandos Mi≈ø≈øe ge≈øtus, and would have them to be abhorred, becau≈øe they confirm to the ≈øimple and ≈øuper≈øtitious ter impiam & exitialem Mi≈ø≈øe fiduciam.

The corporall pre≈øence of Chri≈øts body in the Sacrament, is al≈øo to be found here: for the words of the Ma≈ø≈ø-book ≈øerving to this purpo≈øe, which are ≈øharply cen≈øured by Bucer in King Ed. Leiturgy, and are not to be found in the book of England, are taken in here. Almighty God is incalled, that of his Almighty goodne≈ø≈øe he may vouch≈øafe ≈øo to ble≈ø≈øe and ≈øanctifie with his Word and Spirit, the≈øe gifts of bread and wine, that they may be unto us the body and bloud of Chri≈øt.

The change here is made the worke of Gods omnipotencie: the words of the Ma≈ø≈øe, ut fiant nobis, are tran≈ølated in King Edwards booke, That they may be unto us, which are againe turned into Latine by Ale≈øius, ut fiant nohis. On the other part, the expre≈ø≈øions of the booke of England at the delivery of the Elements of feeding on Chri≈øt by faith, and of eating and drinking in remembrance that Chri≈øt dyed for thee, are utterly deleated. Many evidences there be in this part of the Communion, of the bodily pre≈øence of Chri≈øt, very agreeable to the doctrines taught by his Secretaries, which this paper cannot containe. They teach us that Chri≈øt is received in the Sacrament, Corporaliter, both objective and ≈øubjective. Corpus Chri≈øti e≈øt objectum quod recipitur, & corpus no≈øtrum ≈øubjectum quo recipitur.

The booke of England aboli≈øheth all that may import the oblation of any unbloudy Sacrifice; but here we have be≈øides the Preparatorie oblation of the Elements, which is neither to be found in the booke of England now, nor in King Edwards booke of old, the oblation of the body and bloud of Chri≈øt, which Bellarmine calleth, Sacrificium Laudis, quia Deus per illud magnopore laudatur. This al≈øo agreeth well with their late Doctrine. We are ready when it ≈øhall be judged convenient, and we ≈øhall be de≈øired, to di≈øcover much more matters of this kinde, as grounds layd for mi≈ø≈øa ≈øicca, or the halfe ma≈ø≈øe, the private ma≈ø≈øe without the people, of communicating in one kinde. Of the con≈øumption by the Prie≈øt, and con≈øummation of the Sacrifice, of receiving the Sacrament in the mouth, and not in the hand, &c.

Our Supplications were many again≈øt the≈øe bookes, but Canterbury procured them to be an≈øwered with terrible Proclamations. We were con≈øtrained to u≈øe the remedie of Prote≈øtation; but for our prote≈øtations, and other lawfull meanes which we u≈øed for our deliverance, Canterbury procured us to be declared Rebels and Traytors in all the Pari≈øh Kirks of England, when we were ≈øeeking to po≈ø≈øe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e our Religion in peace, again≈øt the≈øe devices and Novations, Canterbury kindled warre again≈øt us. In all the≈øe it is knowne that he was, though not the ≈øole, yet the principall Agent and Advi≈øer.

When by the pacification at Barwick, both Kingdoms looked for peace and quietne≈ø≈øe, he ≈øpared not openly in the heating of many, often before the King and privately at the Councell-Table, and the privy Join to to ≈øpeake of us as Rebels and Traytors, and to ≈øpeak again≈øt the pacification as di≈øhonorable, and meet to be broken. Neither did his malignancie and bitterne≈ø≈øe ever ≈øuffer him to re≈øt till a new warre was entred upon, and all things prepared for our de≈øtruction.

By him was it that our Covenant approven by Nationall
A≈ø≈øemblies, ≈øub≈øcribed by his M. Commi≈ø≈øioner, and by the Lords of his M. Coun≈øell, and by them commanded to be ≈øub≈øcribed by all the Subjects of the Kingdome, as a te≈øtimony of our duty to God, and the King, by him was it ≈øtill called ungodly, damnable, Trea≈øonable; by him were oathes invented, and pre≈ø≈øed upon divers of our poore Country-men, upon the pain of impri≈øonment, and many mi≈øeries, which were unwarrantable by Law, and contrary their Nationall oath.

When our Commi≈ø≈øioners did appeare to render the rea≈øons of our demands, he ≈øpared not in the pre≈øence of the King and Committee, to raile again≈øt our Nationall A≈ø≈øembly, as not daring to appeare before the World, and Kirks abroad, where him≈øelfe and his actions were able to endure tryall, and again≈øt our ju≈øt and nece≈ø≈øary defence, as the mo≈øt malicious and Trea≈øonable contempt of Monarchiall Government that any bygone Age hath heard of: His hand al≈øo was at the Warrant for the re≈øtraint and impri≈øonment of our Commi≈ø≈øioners, ≈øent from the Parliament, warranted by the King, and ≈øeeking the peace of the Kingdomes.

When we had by our Declarations, Remon≈øtrances, and Repre≈øentations manife≈øted the truth of our intentions, and lawfulne≈ø≈øe of our actions, to all the good Subjects of the Kingdome of England, when the late Parliament could not be moved to a≈ø≈øi≈øt, or enter in warre again≈øt us, maintaing our Religion, and liberties; Canterbury did not onely advi≈øe the breaking up of that high and honorable Court, to the great griefe and hazzard of the Kingdome; but (which is without example) did ≈øit ≈øtill in the Convocation, and make Canons and Con≈øtitutions again≈øt us, and our ju≈øt and nece≈ø≈øary defence, ordaining under all highe≈øt pains, that hereafter the Clergie ≈øhall preach foure times in he yeare ≈øuch doctrine as is contrary not only to our proceedings, but to the doctrine and proceedings of other reform'd Kirks, to the
judgement of all ≈øound Divines, and politiques, and tending to the utter ≈ølavery and ruining of all E≈øtates and Kingdomes, and to the di≈øhonor of Kings and Monarchs. And as if this had not been ≈øufficient, he procured ≈øix Sub≈øidies to be lifted of the Clergie, under pain of deprivation to all that ≈øhould refu≈øe. And which is yet wor≈øe, and above which malice it ≈øelf cannot a≈øcend, by his means a prayer is framed, printed, and ≈øent through all the Paroches of England, to be ≈øayd in all Churches in time of Divine Service, next after the prayer for the Queene and Royall Progeny, again≈øt our Nation by name of Trayterous Subjects, having ca≈øt of all obedience to our annointed Soveraign, and comming in a rebellious manner to invade England, that ≈øhame may cover our faces, as Enemies to God, and the King.

Who≈øoever ≈øhall impartially examine what hath proceeded from him≈øelfe, in the≈øe two books of Canons and Common-prayer, what Doctrine hath been publi≈øhed and printed the≈øe years by-pa≈øt in England, by his Di≈øciples and Emi≈ø≈øaries, what gro≈ø≈øe Poperie in the mo≈øt materiall points we have found, and are readie to ≈øhew in the po≈øthume writings, of the Prelate of Edinburgh, and Damblane, his own Creatures, his neare≈øt familiars, and mo≈øt willing in≈øtruments to advance his coun≈øells, and projects, ≈øall perceive that his intentions were deep and large again≈øt all the reformed Kirks, and reformation of Religion, which in his Maje≈øties Dominions wes panting, and by this time had rendred up the gho≈øt, if God had not in a wonderfull way of mercy prevented us: and that if the Pope him≈øelfe had been in his place, he could not have been more popi≈øh, nor could he more zealou≈øly have negotiated for Rome, again≈øt the reformed Kirks, to reduce them to the Here≈øies in Doctrine, the Super≈øtitions and Idolatry in wor≈øhip, and the Tyranny in Government which are in that Sea, and for which the reformed Kirks did ≈øeperate from it, and come forth of Babel. From
him certainly hath i≈ø≈øued all this deluge, which almo≈øt hath overturned all. We are therefore confident that your Lord≈øhips will by your meanes deale affectually with the Parliament, that this great firebrand be pre≈øently removed from his Maje≈øties pre≈øence, and that he may be put to triall, and put to his de≈øerved cen≈øure according to the Lawes of the Kingdome, which ≈øall be ≈øervice to God, honor to the King and Parliament; terror to the wicked, and comfort to all good men, and to us in ≈øpeciall; who by his means principally have been put to ≈øo many and grievous afflictions, wherein we had peri≈øhed, if God had not been with us.

We do indeed confe≈ø≈øe that the Prelates of England have been of very different humors, ≈øome of them of a more hot, and others of them, men of a more moderate temper, ≈øome of them more, and ≈øome of them le≈ø≈øe inclinable to Poperie, yet what knowne truth, and con≈øtant experience hath made undeniable, we mu≈øt at this opportunitie profe≈ø≈øe, that from the fir≈øt time of Reformation of the Kirk of Scotland, not only after the comming of King James of happy memory into England, but before the Prelates of England, have been by all means unce≈ø≈øantly working the overthrow of our Di≈øcipline and Government. And it hath come to pa≈ø≈øe of late, that the Prelates of England having prevailed, and brought us to ≈øubjection in the point of government, and finding their long waited for opportunity, and a rare congruity of many ≈øpirits and powers, ready to cooperate for their ends, have made a ≈øtrong a≈ø≈øault upon all the externall wor≈øhip, and Doctrine of our Kirk. By which their doing, they did not ayme to make us conforme to England, but to make Scotland fir≈øt (who≈øe weakne≈ø≈øe in re≈øi≈øting they had before experienced, in the Novations of government, and of ≈øome points of wor≈øhip) and thereafter England conforme to Rome, even in the≈øe matters, wherein England had ≈øeperated from Rome, ever ≈øince the time of Reformation.
An evill therefore which hath i≈ø≈øued, not ≈øo much from the per≈øonall di≈øpo≈øition of the Prelates them≈øelves, as from the innate qualitie and nature of their office and Prelaticall Hierarchy, which did bring forth the Pope in ancient times, and never cea≈øeth till it bringeth forth popi≈øh Doctrine and wor≈øhippe, where it is once rooted, and the principles thereof fomented and con≈øtantly followed. And from that antipathy and incon≈øi≈øtency of the two formes of Eccle≈øia≈øticall Government, which they conceived, and not without cau≈øe, that one I≈øland united al≈øo under one head and Monarch, wes not able to beare; the one being the ≈øame in all the parts and powers, which it wes in the time of Popery, and now is in the Roman Church. The other being the forme of Government, received, maintained, and practi≈øed by all the Reformed Kirks, wherein by their own te≈øtimonies and and confe≈ø≈øions, the Kirk of Scotland had among≈øt them no ≈ømall eminencie. This al≈øo we repre≈øent to your Lord≈øhips mo≈øt ≈øerious con≈øideration, that not only the firebrands may be removed, but that the fire may be provided again≈øt, that there be no more combu≈øtion after this.

div.head: THE CHARGE OF THE SCOTTISH Commi≈øsioners again≈øt the Livetenant of Ireland.
div.p: IN our Declarations we have joyned with Canterbury the Lord Lievetenant of Ireland, who≈øe malice hath ≈øet all his wits and power on work, to devi≈øe and do mi≈øchiefe again≈øt our Kirk and Countrey.

No other cau≈øe of his malice can we conceive, but fir≈øt his pride and ≈øupercilious di≈ødain of the Kirk of Scotland, which in his opinion declared by his ≈øpeeches hath not in it almo≈øt any thing of a Kirk, although the Reformed Kirks, and many worthy Divines of England have given ample te≈øtimony to the Reformation of the Kirk of Scotland.

Secondly, our open oppo≈øition again≈øt the dangerous innovation of Religion intended, and very far promoved in all his Maje≈øties dominions; of which he hath ≈øhewed him≈øelfe in his own way no le≈ø≈øe zealous then Canterbury him≈øelfe, as may appeare by his advancing of his Chaplain, D. Bramble, not only to the Bi≈øhoprick of Derry, but al≈øo to be Vicar-generall of Ireland, a man prompted
for exalting of Canterburian Popery, and Arminiani≈øme, that thus him≈øelf might have the power of both ≈øwords, again≈øt all that ≈øhould maintain the Reformation, by his his bringing of D. Chappel, a man of the ≈øame ≈øpirit, to ∆≤niver≈øity of Dublin, for poy≈øoning the fountains, and corrupting the Seminaries of the Kirk.

And thirdly, when the Primate of Ireland did pre≈ø≈øe a new ratification of the Articles of that Kirk, in Parliament for barring ≈øuch Novations in Religion, he boldly menaced him with the burning by the hand of the Hang-man, of that Confe≈ø≈øion, although confirmed in former Parliaments.

When he found that the Reformation begun in Scotland did ≈øtand in his way, he left no means una≈ø≈øaied to rub di≈øgrace upon us, and our cau≈øe. The peeces printed at Dublin, Examen conjurationis Scoticanae, The ungirding of the Scotti≈øh Armour: the pamphlet bearing the counterfeit name of Li≈øimachus Nicanor; all three ≈øo full of calumnies, ≈ølanders, and ≈øcurrilities again≈øt our Countrey, and Reformation, that the Je≈øuites in their greate≈øt ≈øpite, could not have ≈øayd more, yet not only the Authors were countenanced and rewarded by him, but the books mu≈øt bear his name, as the great Patron both of the work and workman.

When the Nationall Oath and Covenant warranted by our generall A≈ø≈øemblies, was approved by Parliament in the Articles ≈øub≈øcribed in the Kings name, by his Maie≈øties high Commi≈ø≈øioner, and by the Lords of privie Coun≈øell, and Commanded to be ≈øworn by his Maje≈øties Subiects of all ranks; and particular and plenary information was given unto the Lievetenant, by men of ≈øuch quality as he ought to have believed, of the loyalty of our hears to the King, of the lawfulne≈ø≈øe of our proceedings, and innocency of our Covenant, and whole cour≈øe, that he could have no excu≈øe: yet his de≈øperate malice made him to bend his craft and
cruelty, his fraud and forces again≈øt us. For fir≈øt, he did craftily call up to Dublin ≈øome of our Country-men both of the Nobility and Gentry, living in Ireland, ≈øhewing them, that the King would conceive and account them as Con≈øpirers with the Scots, in their rebellious cour≈øes, except ≈øome remedie were provided; and for remedy, ≈øugge≈øting his own wicked invention, to pre≈øent unto him and his own wicked Councell, a petition, which he cau≈øed to be framed by the Bi≈øhop of Raphoe, and was ≈øeen and corrected by him≈øelfe, wherin they petitioned to have an oath given them, containing a formall renunciation of the Scotti≈øh Covenant, and a deep a≈ø≈øurance never ≈øo much as to prote≈øt again≈øt any of his Maje≈øties commandements what≈øoever.

No ≈øooner was this Oath thus craftily contriv'd, but in all ha≈øte it is ≈øent to ≈øuch places of the Kingdome where our Countrey-men had re≈øidence; and men, women, and all other per≈øons above the years of ≈øixteen, con≈øtrained either pre≈øently to take the Oath, and therby renounce their Nationall Covenant as ≈øeditious and trayterous, or with violence and cruelty to be haled to the Jayle, fined above the valew of their e≈øtates, and to be kept clo≈øe pri≈øoners, and ≈øo farre as we know, ≈øome are yet kept in pri≈øon, both men and women of good quality, for not renouncing that Oath which they had taken forty years ≈øince, in obedience to the King who then lived. A cruelty en≈øued, which may paralell the per≈øecutions of the mo≈øt unchri≈øtian times: for weake women dragged to the Bench to take the Oath, dyed in the place, both mother and Child; hundreds driven to hide them≈øelves, till in the darkne≈ø≈øe of the night they might e≈øcape by Sea into Scotland, whither thou≈øands of them did flye, being forced to leave Corn, Cattell, Hou≈øes, and all they po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, to be prey to their per≈øecuting enemies, the Lievetenants Officers. And ≈øome indited and declared guilty of high-trea≈øon, for no
other guiltine≈ø≈øe but for ≈øub≈øcribing our National oath, which was not only impiety and inju≈øtice in it ≈øelf, and an utter undoing of his Maje≈øties Subiects, but was a weakning of the Scots Plantation, to the prejudice of that Kingdome, and his Maje≈øties ≈øervice, and was a high ≈øcandall again≈øt the Kings honour, and intolerable abu≈øe to his Maje≈øties tru≈øt and authority: his Maje≈øties Commi≈ø≈øion, which was procured by the Lievetenant, bearing no other penalty then a certification of noting the names of the refu≈øers of the oath.
But by this his re≈øtle≈ø≈øe rage and in≈øatiable cruelty, again≈øt our Religion and Countrey, cannot be kept within the bounds of Ireland.

By this means a Parliament is called, And although by the ≈øix ≈øub≈øidies granted in Parliament not long before, and by the ba≈øe means which him≈øelf and his Officers did u≈øe, as is contained in a late Remon≈øtrance, that Land was extreamly impoveri≈øhed, yet by his ≈øpeeches full of oathes and a≈ø≈øeverations, That we were Traytors and Rebels, ca≈øting off all Monarchicall Government, &c. he extorted from them foure new Sub≈øidies, and indicta cau≈øa before we were heard, procured that a Warre was udertaken, and forces ≈øhould be levied again≈øt us, as a rebellious Nation, which was al≈øo intended to be an example and pre≈øident to the Parliament of England for granting ≈øub≈øidies, and ≈øending a joynt Armie for our utter ruine.

According to his appointment in Parliament, the Armie was gathered, and brought down to the Coa≈øt, threatning a daily inva≈øion of our Countrey, intending to make us a conquered Province, and to de≈øtroy our Religion, liberties, and Lawes, and thereby laying upon us a nece≈ø≈øity of va≈øt charges, to keep forces on foot on the We≈øt coa≈øt to wait upon his comming.

And as the War was denounced, and forces leavied before we were heard. So before the denouncing of the
War, our Ships, and goods on the Iri≈øh Coa≈øt were taken, and the owners ca≈øt in pri≈øon, and ≈øome of them in Irons. Frigats were ≈øent forth to ≈øcour our Coa≈øts, which did take ≈øome, and burn others of our Barques.
Having thus incited the Kingdome of Ireland, and put his forces in order there again≈øt us, with all ha≈øte he commeth to England.

In his parting, at the giving up of the Sword, he openly avowed our utter ruine and de≈øolation, in the≈øe or the like words, If I returne to that honourable Sword, I ≈øhall leave of the Scots neither root nor branch.

How ≈øoon he commeth to Court, as before he had done very evill offices again≈øt our Commi≈ø≈øioners, cleering our proceedings before the poynt: So now hou≈øeth all means to ≈øtir up the King and Parliament again≈øt us, and to move them to a pre≈øent war, according to the precedent, and example of his own making in the Parliament of Ireland. And finding that his hopes failed him, and his de≈øignes ≈øucceeded not that way, in his nimblene≈ø≈øe he taketh another cour≈øe, that the Parliament of England may be broken up, and de≈øpi≈øing their wi≈øedome and authority, not onely with great gladne≈ø≈øe accepteth, but u≈øeth all means that the conduct of the Army in the expedition again≈øt Scotland, may be put upon him; which accordingly he obtaineth as generall Captain, with power to invade, kill, ≈ølay, and ≈øave at his di≈øcretion, and to make any one, or moe Deputies in his ≈øtead, to do, and execute all the power and authorities committed to him.

According to the largene≈ø≈øe of his Commi≈ø≈øion, and Letters Patents of his devi≈øing, ≈øo were his deportments afterwards; for when the Scots, according to their declarations ≈øent before them, were comming in a peaceable way, far from any intention to invade any of his Maje≈øties Subiects, and ≈øtill to ≈øupplicate his Maje≈øty for a ≈øetled peace, he gave order to his Officers to fight
with them on the way, that the two Nations once entred in bloud, what≈øoever ≈øhould be the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, he might e≈øcape triall and cen≈øure, and his bloudy de≈øigns might be put in execution again≈øt his Maie≈øties Subiects of both Kingdomes.

When the Kings Maie≈øty was again enclined to hearken to our petitions, and to compo≈øe our differences in a peaceable way, and the Peers of England conveened at Yorke, had, as before, in their great wi≈øedome and faithfulne≈ø≈øe given unto his Maie≈øties Coun≈øels of peace, yet this firebrand ≈øtill ≈ømoaketh; and in that honorable A≈ø≈øembly, taketh upon him to breath out threatnings again≈øt us as Traytors, and enemies to Monarchiall government; that we be ≈øent home again in our bloud, and he will whip us out of England.

And as the≈øe were his ≈øpeeches in the time of the Treaty appointed by his Maie≈øty at Rippon, that if it had been po≈ø≈øible, it might have been broken up. So when a Ce≈ø≈øation of Arms was happily agreed upon there, yet he cea≈øeth not, but ≈øtill his practi≈øes were for war; His under officers can tell who it was that gave them Commi≈ø≈øion to draw near in Arms beyond the Tee≈øe, in the time of the Treaty at Rippon.

The Governour of Barwicke, and Carlile can ≈øhew, from whom they had their warrants for their Acts of ho≈øtility after the ce≈ø≈øation was concluded. It may be tryed how it cometh to pa≈ø≈øe, that the Ports of Ireland are yet clo≈øed, our Country-men for the oath ≈øtill kept in pri≈øon, traffique interrupted, and no other face of affairs, then if no ce≈ø≈øation had been agreed upon.

We therefore de≈øire that your Lord≈øhips will repre≈øent to the Parliament, that this great incendiary upon the≈øe and the like offences, not again≈øt particular per≈øons, but again≈øt Kingdomes, and Nations, may be put to a tryall, and from their knowne and renowned ju≈øtice, may have his de≈øerved puni≈øhment.

div.head: THE SCOTTISH Commi≈øsioners Demand concerning the Sixt ARTICLE.
div.p: COncerning our Sixt demand, although it hath often come to pa≈ø≈øe that the≈øe two have been joyned by the bonds of Religion, and nature have ≈øuffered them≈øelves to be divided about the things of this World; and although our Adver≈øaries, who no le≈ø≈øe labour the divi≈øion of the two Kingdomes then we do all ≈øeek peace, and follow after it, as our Common happine≈ø≈øe, do pre≈øume that this will be the partition wall to divide us, and to make us lo≈øe all our labours taken about the former demand, wherein by the help of God, by his Maie≈øties Princely goodne≈ø≈øe end Iu≈øtice, and your Lord≈øhips noble and equall dealing, we have ≈øo fully accorded, and to keep us from providing for a firm and well grounded Peace, by the wi≈øedome and ju≈øtice of the Parliament of England, which is our greate≈øt de≈øire expre≈ø≈øed in our la≈øt Demand. We are ≈øtill confident, that as we ≈øhall concerning this Article repre≈øent nothing but what is true, ju≈øt, and honorable to both Kingdomes; So will your Lord≈øhips hearken to us, and will not ≈øuffer your ≈øelves, by any ≈ølanders or ≈øugge≈øtions to be drawn out of that ≈øtraight and ≈øafe way wherein ye have walked ≈øince the beginning.

It is now, we ≈øuppo≈øe, known to all England, e≈øpecially to both the honorable Hou≈øes of Parliament, and by the occa≈øion of this Treaty, more particularly to your Lord≈øhips, That our di≈øtre≈ø≈øes in our Religion and Liberties, were of late more pre≈ø≈øing than we were able to bear, That our Complaints and Supplications for redre≈ø≈øe, were an≈øwered at la≈øt with the terrors of an Army; That after a pacification greater preparations were made for war, whereby many Acts of Ho≈øtility were done again≈øt us, both by Sea and Land; The Kingdome wanted admini≈øtration of Ju≈øtice, and we con≈øtrained to take Arms for our defence; That we were brought to this extreme and intolerable nece≈ø≈øity, either to maintain divers Armies upon our Borders again≈øt Inva≈øion from England or Ireland, ≈øtill to be deprived of the benefit of all the Courts of Ju≈øtice, and not onely to maintain ≈øo many thou≈øands as were ≈øpoyled of their ≈øhips and goods, but to want all Commerce by Sea, to the undoing of Merchants, of Saylors, and many other who lived by Fi≈øhing, and who≈øe Callings are upholden from hand to mouth by Sea trade: Any one of which evils is able in a ≈øhort time to bring the mo≈øt potent Kingdome to Confu≈øion, Ruine, and De≈øolation, how much more all the three at one time combined to bring the Kingdome of Scotland to be no more a Kingdome: Yet all the≈øe behoved We either to endure and under no other hope, than of the perfect ≈ølavery of our ≈øelves, and our po≈øterity, in our ≈øouls, Lives, and means; Or to re≈øolve to come into England, not to make any Inva≈øion, or with any purpo≈øe to fight, except we were forced, God is our Judge, our actions are our witne≈ø≈øes, and England doth now acknowledge the truth, again≈øt all ≈øu≈øpicions to the contrary, and again≈øt the impudent lies of our enemies, but for our relief, defence, and pre≈øervation which we could finde by no other means, when we had e≈ø≈øayed all means, and had
at large expre≈ø≈øed our pungent, and pre≈ø≈øing nece≈ø≈øities, to the Kingdome and Parliament of England. Since therefore the war on our part (which is no other but our coming into England with a Guard) is defen≈øive, and all men do acknowledge, that in common equity, the defendant ≈øhould not be ≈øuffered to peri≈øh in his ju≈øt and nece≈ø≈øary defence, but that the per≈øuer, whether by way of Legall proce≈ø≈øe in the time of Peace, or by way of violence and unju≈øt inva≈øion in the time of war, ought to bear the charges of the defendant. We tru≈øt that your Lord≈øhips will think that it is not again≈øt rea≈øon for us to demand ≈øome reparation of this kinde, and that the Parliament of England, by who≈øe wi≈øedome and ju≈øtice we have expected the redre≈ø≈øe of our wrongs, will take ≈øuch cour≈øe, as both may in rea≈øon give us ≈øatisfaction, and may in the notable demon≈øtration of their Ju≈øtice, ≈øerve mo≈øt for their own honour.

Our earne≈øtne≈ø≈øe in following this our Demand, doth not ≈øo far wrong our fight, and make us ≈øo undi≈øcerning, as not to make a difference between the Kingdome and Parliament of England, which did neither di≈øcerne nor ≈øet forward a Warre again≈øt us; And that prevalent faction of Prelates and Papi≈øts who have moved every ≈øtone again≈øt us, and u≈øed all ≈øorts of means, not onely their Coun≈øells, Sub≈øidies, and Forces, but their Church Canons and Prayers, for our utter ruine; which maketh them obnoxious to our ju≈øt accu≈øations, and guilty of all the lo≈ø≈øes and wrongs which this time pa≈øt we have ≈øu≈øtained: Yet this we de≈øire your Lord≈øhips to con≈øider, That the States of the Kingdome of Scotland being a≈ø≈øembled, did endeavour by their Declarations, Informations, and Remon≈øtrances, and by the proceedings of their Commi≈ø≈øioners, to make known unto the Councell, Kingdome, and Parliament of England, and to forewarn them of the mi≈øchief intended again≈øt both Kingdomes, in their Religion and Liberties, by the Prelates and papi≈øts, to
the end that our Inva≈øion from England might have been prevented, if by the prevalency of the faction it had been po≈ø≈øible. And therefore we may now with the greater rea≈øon and confidence pre≈ø≈øe our Demand; that your Lord≈øhips, the Parliament, the Kingdome, and the King him≈øelf, may ≈øee us repaired in our lo≈ø≈øes, at the co≈øt of that faction by who≈øe means we have ≈øu≈øtained ≈øo much dammage; And which, except they repent, we finde ≈øorrow recompenced for our grief, torments for our toyl, and an infinite greater lo≈ø≈øe for the Temporall lo≈ø≈øes, they have brought upon a whole Kingdome, which was dwelling by them in peace.

All the devices and doings of our common enemies, were to bear down the truth of Religion, and the ju≈øt liberties of the Subjects in both Kingdomes. They were confident to bring this about one of two wayes: Either by blocking us up by Sea and Land, to con≈øtrain us to admit their will for a law both in Church and Policy, and thus to make us a precedent for the like mi≈øery in England, or by their Inva≈øion of our Kingdome, to compell us furiou≈øly, and without order, to break into England; That the two Nations once entred into a bloody Warre, they might fi≈øh in our troubled waters, and catch their de≈øired prey. But as we declared before our coming: We tru≈øted that God would turn their wi≈øedome into fooli≈øhne≈ø≈øe, and bring their devices upon their own pares, by our Intentions and Re≈øolutions to come into England, as among our Brethren, in the mo≈øt peaceable way that could ≈øtand with our ≈øafety, in re≈øpect of our common enemies, to pre≈øent our petitions for ≈øetling our peace, by a Parliament in England, wherein the intentions and actions, both of our adver≈øaries and ours, might be brought to light; The Kings Maje≈øty and the Kingdome right informed, The Authors and In≈øtruments of our divi≈øions and troubles puni≈øhed, All the mi≈øchiefs of a Nationall and doubtfull warre prevented, and Religion
and Liberty with greater peace and amity than ever before e≈øtabli≈øhed, again≈øt all the craft and violence of our enemies. This was our Declaration before we ≈øet our England, from which our deportments ≈øince have not varied. And it hath been the Lords wonderfull doing, by the wi≈øe coun≈øels, and ju≈øt proceedings of the Parliament, to bring it in a great part to pa≈ø≈øe, and to give us lively hopes of a happy conclu≈øion: And therefore we will never doubt, but that the Parliament in their wi≈øedom and iu≈øtice, will provide that a proportionable part of the co≈øt and charges of a work ≈øo great and ≈øo comfortable to both Nations be born by the Delinquents there, that with the better con≈øcience the good people of England may ≈øit under their own Vines and Fig-trees, refre≈øhing them≈øelves, although upon our great pains and hazard, yet not altogether upon our co≈øt and charges, which we are not able to bear.

The Kingdome of England doth know and confe≈ø≈øe that the innovation of religion and liberties in Scotland, were not the principall de≈øigne of our common enemies, but that both in the intention of the workers, who≈øe zeal was hotte≈øt for ≈øetling their devices at home: and in the condition ≈øo the work, making us whom they conceived to be the weaker for oppo≈øition to be nothing el≈øe but a leading ca≈øe for England. And that although by the power of God, which is made perfect in weakne≈ø≈øe, they have found among≈øt us greater re≈øi≈øtance than they did fear, or either they or our ≈øelves could have apprehended; Yet as it hath been the will of God that we ≈øhould endure the heat of the day, ≈øo in the evening the precious wages of the vindication of religion, liberties, and laws are to be received by both Kingdoms, and will enrich, we hope, to our un≈øpeakable ioy, the pre≈øent age, and the po≈øterity with ble≈ø≈øings that cannot be valued, and with the good people of England, e≈øteem more than trea≈øures of Gold, and willingly would have puacha≈øed with many thou≈øands.
We do not plead that con≈øcience and piety have moved ≈øome men to ≈øerve God upon their own co≈øt, and that ju≈øtice and equity have directed others, where the harve≈øt hath been common to con≈øider the pains of labouring, and the charges of the ≈øowing, yet thus much may we ≈øay, that had a forraigne enemy, intending to reduce the whole I≈øland into Popery, made the fir≈øt a≈ø≈øault upon her weakne≈ø≈øe, we nothing doubt but the Kingdome of England, from their de≈øire to pre≈øerve their Religion and liberties, would have found the way to bear with us the expence of our re≈øi≈øtance and lawfull defence, how much more being invaded, although not by England, yet from England, by common enemies, ≈øeeking the ≈øame ends, we expect to be helped and relieved.

We will never conceive that it is either the will or the weal and honour of England, that we ≈øhould go from ≈øo ble≈ø≈øed a work; after ≈øo many grievous ≈øufferings, bearing on our backs the in≈øupportable burdens of worldly nece≈ø≈øities and di≈øtre≈ø≈øes, return to our Country empty, and exhau≈øted, in which the people of all ranks, ≈øexes, and conditions, have ≈øpent them≈øelves. The po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of every man who devoted him≈øelf heartily to this cau≈øe, are burdened, not onely with his own per≈øonall and particular expence, but with the publike and common charges; of which if there be no relief, neither can our Kingdom have peace at home, nor any more credit for Commerce abroad: Nor will it be po≈ø≈øible for us, either to aid and a≈ø≈øi≈øt our friends, or to re≈øi≈øt and oppo≈øe the re≈øtle≈ø≈øe and working wickedne≈ø≈øe of our enemies: The be≈øt ≈øort will lo≈øe much of the ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe of the enjoying of their religion and liberties, and others will run ≈øuch wayes, and undirect cour≈øes as their de≈øperate nece≈ø≈øity will drive them into. We ≈øhall be but a burthen to our ≈øelves, a vexation unto others, of who≈øe ≈øtrength we de≈øire to be a con≈øiderable part, and a fit ≈øubject for our enemies to work upon for obtaining their now di≈øappointed, but never dying de≈øires.

We will not alledge the example of other Kingdomes, where the lo≈ø≈øes of nece≈ø≈øary and ju≈øt defence had been repaired by the other party, nor will we remember what help we have made, according to our abilities, to other reformed Churches; and what the kingdome of England of old and of late hath done to Germany, France, and Holland; nor do we u≈øe ≈øo many words, that England may be burthened, and we ea≈øed, or that this ≈øhould be a matter of our Covetou≈øne≈ø≈øe, and not of their Ju≈øtice and kindne≈ø≈øe; Ju≈øtice, in re≈øpect of our adver≈øaries, who are the cau≈øes of the great mi≈øery and nece≈ø≈øity to which we have been brought: kindne≈ø≈øe, in the ≈øupply of our wants who have been tender of the welfare of England as of our own, that by this equality and mutuall re≈øpect, both Nations may be ≈øupported in ≈øuch ≈øtrength and ≈øufficiency, that we may be the more ≈øerviceable to his Maje≈øty; and abound in every good work, both towards one another, and for the comfort and reliefe of the reformed Churches beyond the Seas, that we may all ble≈ø≈øe God, and that the ble≈ø≈øing of God may be upon us all.

div.head: The Engli≈øh Peers demand concerning the preceding. Articles.
div.p: WHether this be a po≈øitive demand, or onely an intimation of the charge, thereby to induce the Kingdome of England to take your di≈øtre≈ø≈øed e≈øtate into con≈øideration, and to afford you ≈øome friendly a≈ø≈øi≈øtance.

div.head: The Scotti≈øh Commi≈ø≈øioners an≈øwer to the demand.
div.p:
WE would be no le≈ø≈øe willing to bear our lo≈ø≈øes if we had ability, than we have been ready to undergo the hazard; But becau≈øe the burden of the whole doth far exceed our ≈øtrength. We have (as is more fully conceived in our Papers) repre≈øented to your Lord≈øhips our charges and lo≈ø≈øes, not intending to demand a totall repairation, but of ≈øuch a proportionable part, as that we may in ≈øome mea≈øure bear the remanent, which we conceive your Lord≈øhips (having con≈øidered our rea≈øons) will
judge to be a matter, not of covetou≈øne≈ø≈øe, but of the ≈øaid Ju≈øtice and kindene≈ø≈øe of the Kingdome of England.

div.head: Propo≈øition of the Peers to proceed to the other Demands during the debate of the Scotti≈øh lo≈ø≈øes.
div.p: THat in the Interim, whil≈øt the Hou≈øes of Parliament take into con≈øideration your Demand of lo≈ø≈øes and dammages, you proceed to ≈øettle the other Articles of the peace and intercour≈øe betwixt the two Kingdomes.

div.head: An≈øwer to the Peers Demand.
div.p: WE have repre≈øented our lo≈ø≈øes, and thereby our di≈øtre≈ø≈øed condition ingenuou≈øly, and in the ≈øinglene≈ø≈øe of our hearts, with very great moderation, pa≈ø≈øing over many things which to us are great burthens, that there might be no difficulty or cau≈øe of delay on our part, hoping that the honorable Hou≈øes of Parliament would thereby be moved at their fir≈øt convenience, to take the matter to their con≈øideration.

We do not demand a totall reparation, nor do we ≈øpeak of the payment, till we con≈øult about the ≈øetling of a ≈øolid peace, at which time the wayes of lifting and paying the money, may be con≈øidered; We do onely de≈øire to know what proportion may be expected. That this being once determined, and all impediments ari≈øing from our by-pa≈øt troubles, removed, we may with the greater confidence, and more hearty con≈øent on both ≈øides, proceed to the e≈øtabli≈øhing of a firm and durable peace for time to come.

It is not unknown to your Lord≈øhips, what de≈øperate de≈øires, and mi≈øerable hopes our adver≈øaries have conceived of a breach upon this Article; And we do fore≈øee what ≈ønares to us, and difficulties to your Lord≈øhips may ari≈øe upon the po≈øt poning and laying a≈øide of this Article to the la≈øt place.

And therefore that our adver≈øaries may be out of hope,
and we out of fear, and that the ≈øetling of peace may be the more ea≈øie: We are the more earne≈øt, that as the former articles have been, ≈øo this may be upon greater rea≈øons con≈øidered in its own place and order.

Your Lord≈øhips upon the occa≈øion of ≈øome motions made heretofore of the tran≈øpo≈øing of our Demands, do know, that not onely the ≈øub≈øtance, but the order of the propounding of them, is contained in our in≈øtructions. And as we can alter nothing without warrant, the craving whereof will take more time than the Hou≈øes of Parliament will be≈øtow upon the con≈øideration of this Article. So are we acquainted with the rea≈øons yet ≈øtanding in force, which moved the ordering of this Demand. And therefore let us ≈øtill be earne≈øt with your Lord≈øhips, that there be no halting here, where the adver≈øaries did mo≈øt, and we did lea≈øt of all, by rea≈øon of the ju≈øtice and kindene≈ø≈øe of the Hou≈øes of Parliament expect it.

div.head: Re≈øolved on the Que≈øtion.
div.p: THat this Hou≈øe doth conceive, that the ≈øumme of three hundreth thou≈øand pounds is a fit proportion for that friendly a≈ø≈øi≈øtance and relief, formerly thought fit to be given, towards the ≈øupply of the lo≈ø≈øes and nece≈ø≈øities of our Brethren of Scotland. And that this Hou≈øe will, in due time, take into con≈øideration the manner how, and the time when, the ≈øame ≈øhall be rai≈øed.

div.head: An≈øwer of the Scots Commi≈ø≈øioners.
div.p:
WE intreat your Lord≈øhips, who≈øe endeavours God hath ble≈ø≈øed in this great work, to make known to the Parliament, that we do no le≈ø≈øe de≈øire to ≈øhew our thankfulne≈ø≈øe for their friendly a≈ø≈øi≈øtance and relief, than we have been earne≈øt in demanding the ≈øame. But the thankfulne≈ø≈øe which we conceive to be
due, doth not con≈øi≈øt in our affections or words at this time; but in the mutuall kindene≈ø≈øe, and reall demon≈øtrations to be expected from the whole Kingdome of Scotland in all time coming: and that not onely for the mea≈øure and proportion, which the Parliament hath conceived to be fit; and which (to begin our thankfulne≈ø≈øe now) we do in name of the whole Kingdome cheerfully accept of, but al≈øo for the kinde and Chri≈øtian manner of granting it unto us, as to their Brethren, which addeth a weight above many thou≈øands, and cannot be compen≈øed but by paying their reciprocal love and duty of Brethren. And for the re≈øolution to con≈øider in due time of the rai≈øing of the ≈øame for our relief, which al≈øo maketh the benefit to be double. This maketh us confident that God (who≈øe working at this time hath been wnoderfull) hath decreed the peace and amity of the two Kingdomes, and will remove all rubs out of the way, that our enemies, will at la≈øt de≈øpair to divide us, when they ≈øee that God hath joyned us in ≈øuch a fraternity. And that divine providence will plentifully recompence unto the Kingdome of England, this their ju≈øtice and kindene≈ø≈øe, and unto Scotland all their lo≈ø≈øes, which ≈øhall not by the≈øe and other means among≈øt our ≈øelves be repaired, but by the rich and ≈øweet ble≈ø≈øings of the purity and power of the Go≈øpel, attended with the benefits of an unhappy and durable peace under his Maje≈øties long and pro≈øperous raigne, and of his royall po≈øterity to all generations.
